description: The Certified Information Systems Security Professional (CISSP) certification is the gold standard in the IT Security field. Security professionals that have achieved their CISSP designation are regarded as some of the most talented and knowledgeable people in their field. The certification demonstrates that the holder has been working in IT Security for over five years, has a broad range of knowledge in ten domains related to creating, supporting and maintaining a secure IT infrastructure and can implement things like risk management and risk identification.
name: Certified Information Systems Security Professional (UPDATED 2016)
subtitle: CISSP

episodes.description: *** DOWNLOADS, NOTES AND REFERENCED MATERIAL FOR THIS COURSE ARE AVAILABLE IN THE "EPISODE FILES" ASSOCIATED WITH THIS EPISODE *** In this episode Adam and Mike talk about the three pillars of security, confidentiality, integrity and availability. They explain how to apply security governance principles through alignment of security functions to an organizations strategy, goals, mission and objectives. They discuss applying security governance principles through organizational processes, security roles and responsibilities and control frameworks. They explain and differentiate between due care and due diligence.
episodes.title: Security Governance
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.744 --> 00:00:16.471
Hello and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITPro.tv.

3
00:00:16.471 --> 00:00:21.532
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and
today we're going over Domain 1 and CISSP.

4
00:00:21.532 --> 00:00:24.160
Which is security and risk management, and

5
00:00:24.160 --> 00:00:29.278
specifically we're gonna be looking at
applying the concepts of confidentiality,

6
00:00:29.278 --> 00:00:34.260
availability, and integrity,
as well as security governance compliance.

7
00:00:34.260 --> 00:00:38.280
And with me today to help us out
with all of this is Mr. Adam Gordon.

8
00:00:38.280 --> 00:00:39.050
How you doing Adam?

9
00:00:39.050 --> 00:00:40.490
>> Good, good.
Hey everybody.

10
00:00:40.490 --> 00:00:41.340
Good to be back, welcome.

11
00:00:41.340 --> 00:00:42.580
>> Absolutely.

12
00:00:42.580 --> 00:00:44.830
>> So let's talk a bit about security.

13
00:00:44.830 --> 00:00:47.208
Let's talk about confidentiality,
let's talk about integrity,

14
00:00:47.208 --> 00:00:48.687
let's talk about availability, right?

15
00:00:48.687 --> 00:00:51.500
Cuz these are the three building blocks,
if you will.

16
00:00:51.500 --> 00:00:53.630
The three pillars of information
security management.

17
00:00:53.630 --> 00:00:54.724
When we think about them,

18
00:00:54.724 --> 00:00:58.224
we often talk about them from the respect
of being the information security triad.

19
00:00:58.224 --> 00:01:02.786
Or you often will hear them referred to
as the iron triangle, or the AIC triad.

20
00:01:02.786 --> 00:01:04.230
There's lots of different
way we talk about them.

21
00:01:04.230 --> 00:01:07.620
But at the end of the day what
we're really thinking about is

22
00:01:07.620 --> 00:01:10.650
we're thinking about three things
that form the underlying bedrock,

23
00:01:10.650 --> 00:01:14.100
the baseline of everything we
do within information security.

24
00:01:14.100 --> 00:01:18.190
Confidentiality is all about
the idea that ultimately

25
00:01:18.190 --> 00:01:23.320
we are focusing on ways in which we can
protect information, keep it secure.

26
00:01:23.320 --> 00:01:27.180
If I tell Mike something, and I write
it down and I pass it over to him, so

27
00:01:27.180 --> 00:01:31.150
he doesn't know what it is, but he looks
at it, but nobody's around to see it.

28
00:01:31.150 --> 00:01:34.080
If I say, Mike, keep that secret,
make sure you don't share it with anybody.

29
00:01:34.080 --> 00:01:38.650
Make sure nobody sees it, nobody knows
about it, then that's confidentiality.

30
00:01:38.650 --> 00:01:43.270
If Mike looks at that information, but
maybe George is standing in the corner,

31
00:01:43.270 --> 00:01:46.880
and maybe, inadvertently, George
catches a glimpse of that information.

32
00:01:46.880 --> 00:01:49.360
Then, Mike may have done
what we call exposed or

33
00:01:49.360 --> 00:01:51.490
broken the confidentiality
of the information.

34
00:01:51.490 --> 00:01:53.640
So we wanna make sure we
keep information secure.

35
00:01:53.640 --> 00:01:55.840
We keep it away from,
as we'll talk about later,

36
00:01:55.840 --> 00:01:59.420
people that are unauthorized,
that are not supposed to see it.

37
00:01:59.420 --> 00:02:00.820
When we think about integrity,

38
00:02:00.820 --> 00:02:04.500
we think about the idea of information
that is going to be monitored.

39
00:02:04.500 --> 00:02:07.150
We're gonna figure out what
information looks like, and

40
00:02:07.150 --> 00:02:10.430
ultimately once we know that,
we wanna capture that current state.

41
00:02:10.430 --> 00:02:12.320
We wanna know what that is, and

42
00:02:12.320 --> 00:02:15.480
then once we've done that,
we wanna keep track of it over time.

43
00:02:15.480 --> 00:02:19.020
And if that information changes in any
way, we want to be told about that.

44
00:02:19.020 --> 00:02:23.780
We want to, in other words, be notified
that the information has been modified.

45
00:02:23.780 --> 00:02:25.860
We talked about notification
of modification,

46
00:02:25.860 --> 00:02:27.240
when we talk about integrity.

47
00:02:27.240 --> 00:02:28.530
The idea of integrity,

48
00:02:28.530 --> 00:02:31.480
is all about ensuring not that
information is kept secret.

49
00:02:31.480 --> 00:02:35.570
Not that Mike reads the message, but
doesn't actually show it to anybody but,

50
00:02:35.570 --> 00:02:38.450
rather, that the message
is not going to change.

51
00:02:38.450 --> 00:02:41.550
So if the message to Mike on
the paper that I pass him is,

52
00:02:41.550 --> 00:02:43.700
the dog is blue period.

53
00:02:43.700 --> 00:02:48.030
Then that information should always
stay the same, it should never change.

54
00:02:48.030 --> 00:02:50.080
The dog is blue no period.

55
00:02:50.080 --> 00:02:52.310
The blue is dog, whatever that may be,

56
00:02:52.310 --> 00:02:56.910
however we modify that, is a change in
the integrity status of the information.

57
00:02:56.910 --> 00:03:00.840
Integrity becomes important,
because when information is modified,

58
00:03:00.840 --> 00:03:03.020
the meaning of the information may change.

59
00:03:03.020 --> 00:03:06.742
And if the meaning changes, then as a
result of that, we may not really be able

60
00:03:06.742 --> 00:03:11.220
to communicate effectively what the intent
of that message or that information was.

61
00:03:11.220 --> 00:03:15.410
We'll talk about methods that help us
do both, focus on confidentiality and

62
00:03:15.410 --> 00:03:19.810
integrity in upcoming conversations, but
we'll talk about things such as encryption

63
00:03:19.810 --> 00:03:22.600
and the use of public and
private key encryption, symmetric,

64
00:03:22.600 --> 00:03:25.740
asymmetric solutions to
provide confidentiality.

65
00:03:25.740 --> 00:03:30.480
And we'll talk about integrity mechanisms,
things like hashing and

66
00:03:30.480 --> 00:03:34.030
digital signatures,
in order to be able to provide integrity,

67
00:03:34.030 --> 00:03:37.270
as well as nonrepudiaton and
proof of origin.

68
00:03:37.270 --> 00:03:39.940
And we'll be talking about those
things in relation to integrity in

69
00:03:39.940 --> 00:03:41.310
upcoming conversations as well.

70
00:03:41.310 --> 00:03:45.655
When we think about availability of that,
we think about just what that implies.

71
00:03:45.655 --> 00:03:48.810
Data is there, we could see it,
we use it, we interact with it.

72
00:03:48.810 --> 00:03:52.043
But on demand and most importantly,
when necessary for

73
00:03:52.043 --> 00:03:55.086
those that are authorized
to be able to see the data.

74
00:03:55.086 --> 00:03:58.790
So if Mike is authorized right, and
Mike and I are having a conversation,

75
00:03:58.790 --> 00:04:01.378
then Mike should be able
to interact with the data.

76
00:04:01.378 --> 00:04:06.178
If Mike is only authorized to see the data
between, let's say, normal business hours,

77
00:04:06.178 --> 00:04:08.553
nine to five, let's say hypothetically.

78
00:04:08.553 --> 00:04:13.142
Then, if it's outside that window, Mike
should not have access to the data and

79
00:04:13.142 --> 00:04:18.075
availability controls should ensure, in
this case, something we know as a temporal

80
00:04:18.075 --> 00:04:21.981
control, a time based control,
should ensure or somehow kick in,

81
00:04:21.981 --> 00:04:26.390
and prevent Mike from seeing the data
outside the nine to five window.

82
00:04:26.390 --> 00:04:28.840
This is what we think about when
we think about availability,

83
00:04:28.840 --> 00:04:34.190
but in addition we also focus on things
having to do with business continuity,

84
00:04:34.190 --> 00:04:39.160
disaster recovery, things like being
able to have redundancy in our systems.

85
00:04:39.160 --> 00:04:43.360
So if Mike needs to see the data, but
Mike's using a wireless network connection

86
00:04:43.360 --> 00:04:46.430
to get to the data, what if
the wireless network stops working?

87
00:04:46.430 --> 00:04:50.730
Availability is all about making sure
that, that network has a redundant path,

88
00:04:50.730 --> 00:04:54.720
a secondary solution that would allow
Mike, maybe with a wired connection or

89
00:04:54.720 --> 00:04:58.290
a backup access point that would
kick in if the first one failed or

90
00:04:58.290 --> 00:05:01.680
whatever we talk about to insure
that Mike can still see the data,

91
00:05:01.680 --> 00:05:04.960
if he's authorized to during the period
of time, all those kind of things.

92
00:05:04.960 --> 00:05:08.190
So when we think about confidentiality,
integrity and availability

93
00:05:08.190 --> 00:05:12.710
as we start our conversations off, these
are probably the most critical elements.

94
00:05:12.710 --> 00:05:14.600
The most critical things
we have to focus on.

95
00:05:14.600 --> 00:05:16.270
If we know about those things,

96
00:05:16.270 --> 00:05:19.790
we're gonna be able to then have all
the wide ranging conversations about,

97
00:05:19.790 --> 00:05:24.260
as you heard, risk, compliance,
governance, what we call GRC activities.

98
00:05:24.260 --> 00:05:27.075
But in addition, we're also gonna
be able to make sure that we're

99
00:05:27.075 --> 00:05:29.841
focusing on the mission critical systems,
and how to manage them

100
00:05:29.841 --> 00:05:32.950
as well as the mission critical data,
and how to manage them as well.

101
00:05:32.950 --> 00:05:37.050
And all these things together form the
basis of information security management,

102
00:05:37.050 --> 00:05:38.970
and as CISSP candidates and

103
00:05:38.970 --> 00:05:42.650
ultimately when you are successful
with certifying CISSPs.

104
00:05:42.650 --> 00:05:46.420
This becomes the mantra, this becomes the
thing that we constantly come back to and

105
00:05:46.420 --> 00:05:49.710
refer to,
in regards to security management.

106
00:05:49.710 --> 00:05:52.330
When we build something known as the ISMS,

107
00:05:52.330 --> 00:05:54.850
the information security
management system.

108
00:05:54.850 --> 00:05:57.030
Which there are ISO
standards to talk about.

109
00:05:57.030 --> 00:06:00.840
We'll, at some point later as we
talk about some of these standards,

110
00:06:00.840 --> 00:06:04.590
mention ISO 27001 and
27002 with regards to this.

111
00:06:04.590 --> 00:06:09.810
When you think about building a holistic
system to manage information security,

112
00:06:09.810 --> 00:06:13.060
we think about the ideas of
confidentiality, integrity, and

113
00:06:13.060 --> 00:06:15.720
availability, and how they come
together to be able to do that.

114
00:06:15.720 --> 00:06:18.910
And this is part of that whole
conversation that we're thinking about and

115
00:06:18.910 --> 00:06:21.490
the whole idea behind this is
what we're really getting at.

116
00:06:21.490 --> 00:06:25.910
So as we think about aligning strategy,
think about aligning governance,

117
00:06:25.910 --> 00:06:27.350
think about the goals, missions and

118
00:06:27.350 --> 00:06:32.060
objectives of the organization, we have
to really think about what that means.

119
00:06:32.060 --> 00:06:35.110
Is it enough to say,
we're just gonna focus on confidentiality?

120
00:06:35.110 --> 00:06:37.480
Does the business have integrity and
availability needs?

121
00:06:37.480 --> 00:06:39.640
And more often than not, we find they do.

122
00:06:39.640 --> 00:06:42.780
Does the business have availability
needs that are being met?

123
00:06:42.780 --> 00:06:45.990
Do we have to worry about whether or
not there are new emerging threats and

124
00:06:45.990 --> 00:06:49.950
technologies that may do the job better,
or may put our data at risk?

125
00:06:49.950 --> 00:06:52.580
And these are things that
security professionals today,

126
00:06:52.580 --> 00:06:55.770
that we're constantly thinking about,
that are constantly on our mind.

127
00:06:55.770 --> 00:06:56.835
Is our data secure?

128
00:06:56.835 --> 00:06:59.710
If the answer is yes,
the answer really is yes,

129
00:06:59.710 --> 00:07:02.680
but it's secured today
under these conditions.

130
00:07:02.680 --> 00:07:06.300
Not, it's always secure, and
it's always secure no matter what.

131
00:07:06.300 --> 00:07:10.224
And as a result of that, we come to really
think about and talk about the fact that

132
00:07:10.224 --> 00:07:14.410
security's an ever evolving,
ever emerging thought process.

133
00:07:14.410 --> 00:07:17.970
And if we think of it as a frozen moment
in time, what we often find is that we

134
00:07:17.970 --> 00:07:21.490
miss the general warning signs,
right, the red flags,

135
00:07:21.490 --> 00:07:24.870
the things that we have to look at
as practitioners, as professionals.

136
00:07:24.870 --> 00:07:26.658
And we're not making the policies,

137
00:07:26.658 --> 00:07:29.554
we're not focusing on the areas
that we have to be aware of.

138
00:07:29.554 --> 00:07:32.042
For instance, think about,
as you're listening to us and

139
00:07:32.042 --> 00:07:35.800
going through the conversations with us,
what you're doing with cloud technologies.

140
00:07:35.800 --> 00:07:38.957
What you're doing with the Internet
of things and convergence.

141
00:07:38.957 --> 00:07:41.060
What you're doing with virtualization.

142
00:07:41.060 --> 00:07:44.743
What you're doing with these kinds of
technologies that are probably known to

143
00:07:44.743 --> 00:07:47.864
most of you, but five years ago,
if we'd had this conversation,

144
00:07:47.864 --> 00:07:51.270
would've been theoretical talking
points about technology that may or

145
00:07:51.270 --> 00:07:54.261
may not have made sense and
probably wasn't widely deployed.

146
00:07:54.261 --> 00:07:57.411
At least not the convergence
technologies we talk about today.

147
00:07:57.411 --> 00:08:00.042
Being able to manage
everything with an app and

148
00:08:00.042 --> 00:08:03.146
having an app that does multiple
things Is very easy for

149
00:08:03.146 --> 00:08:06.802
us as security professionals,
it's easy for us as consumers.

150
00:08:06.802 --> 00:08:09.870
But what does it mean for us from
an information security standpoint?

151
00:08:09.870 --> 00:08:11.390
It can mean a lot of things.

152
00:08:11.390 --> 00:08:15.080
It means there's potentially risk,
it means there's potentially governance,

153
00:08:15.080 --> 00:08:17.940
potentially compliance concerns
that we have to focus on.

154
00:08:17.940 --> 00:08:20.930
And integrating all of
these into our business and

155
00:08:20.930 --> 00:08:24.680
our thought processes everyday is part
of what we talk about when we identify,

156
00:08:24.680 --> 00:08:27.160
and ultimately as a result of identifying.

157
00:08:27.160 --> 00:08:30.410
Learn how to better track and
manage confidentiality, integrity,

158
00:08:30.410 --> 00:08:31.540
and availability concerns.

159
00:08:31.540 --> 00:08:35.750
So thinking about how to align
security function of the business

160
00:08:35.750 --> 00:08:38.830
with the overall goals is a very
important thought process.

161
00:08:38.830 --> 00:08:42.320
So do this for just a second, think
through this in your world, if you will,

162
00:08:42.320 --> 00:08:46.140
and Mike's gonna play along with me, and
we're gonna have a little contest here.

163
00:08:46.140 --> 00:08:49.140
So what I want you to think
about is the following, right?

164
00:08:49.140 --> 00:08:52.610
As a security professional or as somebody
who's looking to become one, right?

165
00:08:52.610 --> 00:08:53.910
Either way, doesn't really matter.

166
00:08:53.910 --> 00:08:57.010
But as somebody who is
an IT focused on security,

167
00:08:57.010 --> 00:08:59.270
how good are you at identifying need?

168
00:08:59.270 --> 00:09:02.120
And let's think about need,
let's talk about need for a minute, right?

169
00:09:02.120 --> 00:09:06.500
I have, as Mike knows, a need for
espresso at various points in my day.

170
00:09:06.500 --> 00:09:07.620
It's very important to me, right?

171
00:09:07.620 --> 00:09:10.950
So I have clearly defined needs
when I'm doing this kind of

172
00:09:10.950 --> 00:09:12.210
discussion with you, right?

173
00:09:12.210 --> 00:09:16.830
In order to be chipper up and
focused and hyperfocused on material and

174
00:09:16.830 --> 00:09:19.900
really animated, I have to have at least
one espresso before I talk to you.

175
00:09:19.900 --> 00:09:21.000
So-
>> [LAUGH] Wait, one?

176
00:09:21.000 --> 00:09:24.230
>> Well, only one,
more than one maybe, but at least one.

177
00:09:24.230 --> 00:09:25.120
We take care of that, right.

178
00:09:25.120 --> 00:09:27.710
I have a need, it's been identified,
we service that need.

179
00:09:28.810 --> 00:09:30.840
Do you know what the needs
of your business are?

180
00:09:30.840 --> 00:09:35.350
Do you understand the security needs of
the technology's and the information that

181
00:09:35.350 --> 00:09:38.888
you have been asked for or will be asked,
as a CISSP, to take on the notch.

182
00:09:38.888 --> 00:09:43.270
And if the answer is, I think I do Adam,
but I'm not real sure, well,

183
00:09:43.270 --> 00:09:47.270
that might be a problem because
the business has clearly defined needs.

184
00:09:47.270 --> 00:09:49.630
And whether you realize them,
whether you understand them,

185
00:09:49.630 --> 00:09:52.280
whether you're aware of them or
not, they are there.

186
00:09:52.280 --> 00:09:54.500
And so one of the things,
as a security professional,

187
00:09:54.500 --> 00:09:58.270
we have to get you to start thinking
about is how do you identify need and

188
00:09:58.270 --> 00:09:59.880
you have to do that by asking questions.

189
00:09:59.880 --> 00:10:02.440
I mean,
this is really fairly straight forward.

190
00:10:02.440 --> 00:10:05.590
You've been doing this probably
most of your adult life.

191
00:10:05.590 --> 00:10:07.280
You've been asking these
kind of questions,

192
00:10:07.280 --> 00:10:10.470
you learned about them in school most
likely, they're the five Ws and the H.

193
00:10:10.470 --> 00:10:14.390
The traditional who, what,
when, where, why, and how.

194
00:10:14.390 --> 00:10:16.570
And we often ask those question
intuitively or at least,

195
00:10:16.570 --> 00:10:19.660
we think about them intuitively
as we examine the situation.

196
00:10:19.660 --> 00:10:22.890
What we tend not to do and
what is the really important skill for

197
00:10:22.890 --> 00:10:26.360
an information security professional
to figure out how to master

198
00:10:26.360 --> 00:10:30.150
is to take the information coming
back from those questions.

199
00:10:30.150 --> 00:10:33.340
And put it into some sort
of ongoing dialogue and

200
00:10:33.340 --> 00:10:35.800
have a dialogue and
a dialogue is a conversation, right?

201
00:10:35.800 --> 00:10:40.540
And conversation between Mike and I about
security may go something like this.

202
00:10:40.540 --> 00:10:43.660
So, Mike, let's talk about a security
need for just a second, right?

203
00:10:43.660 --> 00:10:47.350
So when we think about a security need,
what we're thinking about is the ability

204
00:10:47.350 --> 00:10:52.180
to understand how to understand or
identify a problem or a concern.

205
00:10:52.180 --> 00:10:53.340
So if I say to Mike,

206
00:10:53.340 --> 00:10:56.952
Mike, what's the current security problem
that your business is focused on?

207
00:10:56.952 --> 00:10:59.570
Mike's gonna probably have
a laundry list of things.

208
00:10:59.570 --> 00:11:00.692
I'm not sure what they are.

209
00:11:00.692 --> 00:11:02.550
Mike's gonna tell us at
least one of them right now.

210
00:11:02.550 --> 00:11:04.180
So what's one of the primary needs?

211
00:11:04.180 --> 00:11:06.790
>> I've got to make sure that
only authorized people get access

212
00:11:06.790 --> 00:11:07.821
to our course library.

213
00:11:07.821 --> 00:11:10.656
>> Okay, so only authorized people
should get access to the course library,

214
00:11:10.656 --> 00:11:12.370
that's a really important need.

That goes in my box and

Who's gonna be responsible for

Is it gonna be the stakeholder?

00:23:00.320 --> 00:23:01.530
We're gonna partner, but

they're not gonna be hands on every day

00:23:05.890 --> 00:23:08.390
Is it gonna be me as

00:23:08.390 --> 00:23:11.470
I'm gonna play a role, but there's

People that are enforcing and

00:23:44.408 --> 00:23:46.200

00:23:46.200 --> 00:23:48.088

00:23:48.088 --> 00:23:52.159
Senior managers, people that are dealing

00:23:52.159 --> 00:23:55.926
that are implementing are going to be
the people optimally they oversee,

00:23:55.926 --> 00:23:58.980
that are the security managers,
the professionals.

00:23:58.980 --> 00:24:02.893
This is where the CISSP is
going to focus their attention.

486
00:24:02.893 --> 00:24:07.237
And to be clear, CISSPs may roll up their
sleeves and go in and be practitioners.

487
00:24:07.237 --> 00:24:09.028
They may come from that background.

488
00:24:09.028 --> 00:24:12.023
I've been a CISSP for a very long time.

489
00:24:12.023 --> 00:24:15.947
And I started out life many, many years
ago, over 30 years ago in my IT career,

490
00:24:15.947 --> 00:24:17.103
being a practitioner,

491
00:24:17.103 --> 00:24:20.820
because that's how I learned how

492
00:24:20.820 --> 00:24:22.900
I got into the day-to-day activities.

493
00:24:22.900 --> 00:24:26.800
And I rolled up my sleeves and I
implemented firewalls, and I put IDSs and

494
00:24:26.800 --> 00:24:31.630
IPSs in place, intrusion detection,
intrusion prevention systems.

495
00:24:31.630 --> 00:24:34.200
I went ahead and
I learned how to read logs.

496
00:24:34.200 --> 00:24:36.390
And I went ahead and

497
00:24:36.390 --> 00:24:39.200
I learned how to do captures of

498
00:24:39.200 --> 00:24:41.690
All the stuff that security

499
00:24:41.690 --> 00:24:45.280
But when I got good at all that, I then

500
00:24:45.280 --> 00:24:46.210
How do I write policy?

00:24:46.210 --> 00:24:47.190
How do I identify need?

00:24:47.190 --> 00:24:48.690
How do I do those kind of things?

503
00:24:48.690 --> 00:24:51.540
And those are things that I also learned
how to do and get better at, and

00:24:51.540 --> 00:24:53.850

505

We talked about some control frameworks.

506
00:24:56.320 --> 00:25:01.520
You heard me mention ISO 27001 and
27002 briefly with regards to the ISMS,

507
00:25:01.520 --> 00:25:04.530
the Information Security Management System
that we built.

508
00:25:04.530 --> 00:25:07.140
And the idea of identifying
confidentiality, integrity and

509
00:25:07.140 --> 00:25:11.720
availability is really about putting
those things into the proper areas, or

510
00:25:11.720 --> 00:25:14.620
silos inside the ISMS.

511
00:25:14.620 --> 00:25:17.870
And using standards like ISO,
using NIST guidance,

512
00:25:17.870 --> 00:25:20.170
we'll talk about NIST over time as well.

513
00:25:20.170 --> 00:25:24.910
And using other areas, maybe the OECD
eight guiding principles on privacy, for

00:25:24.910 --> 00:25:25.700
instance.

515
00:25:25.700 --> 00:25:27.230
If you're not familiar with them,
stay tuned,

516
00:25:27.230 --> 00:25:29.810
we're going to talk about those in

517
00:25:29.810 --> 00:25:33.400
You may be familiar with things like
the Wassenaar Arrangement, you may not be.

518
00:25:33.400 --> 00:25:35.370
If you're not familiar with Wassenaar,

519
00:25:35.370 --> 00:25:37.920
we'll mention that in one of our
upcoming discussions as well.

520
00:25:37.920 --> 00:25:42.200
These are all areas where IT security
professionals can gain guidance about

521
00:25:42.200 --> 00:25:46.630
whether it's controls for IT systems
in export, Wassenaar deals with that.

522
00:25:46.630 --> 00:25:49.650
Whether it is guardians on
how to implement privacy and

523
00:25:49.650 --> 00:25:53.260
manage privacy which regards to
data security confidentiality.

524
00:25:53.260 --> 00:25:56.000
All things like we always see the guarded
principles to deal with that.

525
00:25:56.000 --> 00:25:59.200
Whether it's building the overall
arching framework in the ecosystem

526
00:25:59.200 --> 00:26:00.580
of information security.

527
00:26:00.580 --> 00:26:03.372
The ISO 27000 one and
two standards deal with that,

528
00:26:03.372 --> 00:26:06.140
as to a lot of NIST
guidance that's available.

529
00:26:06.140 --> 00:26:10.596
NIST 800 and NIST SP 800 160,
I always trip over that.

530
00:26:10.596 --> 00:26:13.670
NIST SP 800 160 for
instance, one document.

531
00:26:13.670 --> 00:26:17.380
You may at some point want to go look up,
is all about supply chain risk and

532
00:26:17.380 --> 00:26:20.540
managing risk up and

533
00:26:20.540 --> 00:26:25.020
NIST SP 800 39, 37 R1, 53R4,
these are all different

00:26:25.020 --> 00:26:30.030
documents that deal with elements

535
00:26:30.030 --> 00:26:33.600
Both from a control perspective as well as
from within the general framework of how

536
00:26:33.600 --> 00:26:36.670
to implement risk management and
risk identification.

537
00:26:36.670 --> 00:26:39.460
These are all things that could be helpful
to the information security management

538
00:26:39.460 --> 00:26:41.900
professional, and
this is what a CISSP does.

539
00:26:41.900 --> 00:26:44.940
This is the bread and butter of the kind
of things that we have to think about.

540
00:26:44.940 --> 00:26:48.960
How we measure and how we ultimately
identify value is all about how we measure

541
00:26:48.960 --> 00:26:53.490
and identify concerns and needs, quantify
them, and then ultimately show whether or

542
00:26:53.490 --> 00:26:56.910
not we are able to be successful at
measuring through that quantification,

543
00:26:56.910 --> 00:26:58.780
through that measurement,
ultimately show success or

544
00:26:58.780 --> 00:27:01.570
failure in terms of our implementation and

545
00:27:01.570 --> 00:27:05.410
ultimately the value that brings in
terms of the protection that we provide.

546
00:27:05.410 --> 00:27:08.310
And to that end,
what we also have to think about, so

547
00:27:08.310 --> 00:27:12.330
we have to make sure we think about
the ideas of due care and due diligence.

548
00:27:12.330 --> 00:27:15.190
And the idea of due care is really
something that's important,

549
00:27:15.190 --> 00:27:16.430
due diligence as well.

550
00:27:16.430 --> 00:27:19.660
But due care and due diligence are often
things that people get confused.

551
00:27:19.660 --> 00:27:22.850
And they're not really sure or
clear how to define them, right.

552
00:27:22.850 --> 00:27:24.100
And I could put Mike on the spot and

553
00:27:24.100 --> 00:27:28.420
ask him to offer us a definition without
giving him the opportunity of studying and

554
00:27:28.420 --> 00:27:30.270
looking up one, but we're not going
to do that because I like Mike.

555
00:27:30.270 --> 00:27:31.963
>> Thank you.
>> So what we're going to do, right,

556
00:27:31.963 --> 00:27:34.460
is instead we're going just
jointly give you the definition,

557
00:27:34.460 --> 00:27:35.830
kind of share it with you here.

558
00:27:35.830 --> 00:27:38.750
Because it is important to really
understand these terms and get them right.

559
00:27:38.750 --> 00:27:42.600
If you can do that up front, all the other
things we talk about become real clear,

560
00:27:42.600 --> 00:27:44.890
because you understand
the focus on the role.

561
00:27:44.890 --> 00:27:46.680
If you're not clear on due care and
due diligence,

562
00:27:46.680 --> 00:27:49.420
it's a little bit harder to
understand certain things right.

563
00:27:49.420 --> 00:27:53.075
If we think about due care, we often
talk about the care that are reason

564
00:27:53.075 --> 00:27:56.255
person would use in order to
approach a problem or a concern.

565
00:27:56.255 --> 00:28:01.405
So you or I or Mike or anybody who is
an IT professional, thinking about looking

566
00:28:01.405 --> 00:28:05.707
at a problem and saying how am I going to
approach this, what would I do, right?

567
00:28:05.707 --> 00:28:07.337
This is the idea of due care.

568
00:28:07.337 --> 00:28:11.157
It's that standard that reasonable
person's standard we talked about, right.

569
00:28:11.157 --> 00:28:14.117
The idea would be that under any
given certain circumstances,

570
00:28:14.117 --> 00:28:15.919
what are the actions I would engage in,

571
00:28:15.919 --> 00:28:19.157
in order to deal with this concern
on this problem, that is due care.

572
00:28:20.167 --> 00:28:23.717
For instance, would I take a pair
of scissors off the shelf and

573
00:28:23.717 --> 00:28:26.410
would I run around with them in my hands,
right?

574
00:28:26.410 --> 00:28:29.400
Mom always said don't run with scissors,
it's a bad thing, don't do that.

575
00:28:29.400 --> 00:28:30.050
Right?

576
00:28:30.050 --> 00:28:31.800
And if you did, you would get hurt.

577
00:28:31.800 --> 00:28:33.630
Right?
Just like don't play with fire, right?

578
00:28:33.630 --> 00:28:37.110
So the idea is that ultimately
due care is all about making sure

579
00:28:37.110 --> 00:28:38.840
that you don't run with scissors.

580
00:28:38.840 --> 00:28:39.850
Right?
As an example.

581
00:28:39.850 --> 00:28:41.780
That would be an exercise in due care.

582
00:28:41.780 --> 00:28:46.700
So in the IT security world, due care
would be make sure we have defense and

583
00:28:46.700 --> 00:28:50.220
depth overlapping control
elements to protect a system.

584
00:28:50.220 --> 00:28:54.570
So we don't rely on simply one
solution that potentially could, or

585
00:28:54.570 --> 00:28:55.955
could not be up to the task.

586
00:28:55.955 --> 00:28:57.900
Because somebody may
breach that control and

587
00:28:57.900 --> 00:29:00.770
if they do, we don't have anything
else standing there behind it.

588
00:29:00.770 --> 00:29:02.130
Then somebody's going to get in.

589
00:29:02.130 --> 00:29:04.080
Back to Mike's need earlier, right?

590
00:29:04.080 --> 00:29:05.150
Keep the bad actors,

591
00:29:05.150 --> 00:29:08.150
the people that don't belong seeking
the content, out of the library.

592
00:29:08.150 --> 00:29:12.280
Well if all we did was use a username and
a password, single factor, a single access

593
00:29:12.280 --> 00:29:17.290
control factor, then due care may not be
exercised properly, because the reality

594
00:29:17.290 --> 00:29:21.320
is we probably needed to exercise
more then one control in that case.

595
00:29:21.320 --> 00:29:26.220
When we think about due diligence, we
think about doing lots of different things

596
00:29:26.220 --> 00:29:30.150
to make sure that we are implementing
policy, we're implementing procedure for

597
00:29:30.150 --> 00:29:32.510
things going, for
being done the way they should be.

598
00:29:32.510 --> 00:29:34.990
So, due diligence is
all about the oversight

599
00:29:34.990 --> 00:29:37.680
making sure that we
are implementing properly.

600
00:29:37.680 --> 00:29:41.310
So, for instance, if Mike is our
stakeholder in our example and

601
00:29:41.310 --> 00:29:44.540
he says to me, Adam here's my need and
we've identified that.

602
00:29:44.540 --> 00:29:46.640
From a due care perspective
you've identified five or

603
00:29:46.640 --> 00:29:49.850
six controls that will be helpful to
make sure we're doing those things.

604
00:29:49.850 --> 00:29:53.140
Due diligence is all about making
sure that we implement those and

605
00:29:53.140 --> 00:29:57.110
we spot check continuously to ensure that
they're actually being applied properly.

606
00:29:57.110 --> 00:30:00.760
Mike has a responsibility under
due diligence as a stake holder to

607
00:30:00.760 --> 00:30:01.920
be involved in that.

608
00:30:01.920 --> 00:30:05.490
But I do also as the professional to
ensure that they're being done correctly.

609
00:30:05.490 --> 00:30:08.630
And I also have a due diligence
responsibility to Mike,

610
00:30:08.630 --> 00:30:11.480
to the business as a stakeholder,
to go back and report to him and

611
00:30:11.480 --> 00:30:14.170
say hey Mike, by the way,
here's what we're doing, right?

612
00:30:14.170 --> 00:30:16.840
And here are the controls
we've put in place.

613
00:30:16.840 --> 00:30:20.890
Due care and due diligence together
are critical for us to understand,

614
00:30:20.890 --> 00:30:25.490
because if we exercise both and we
ascribe the right level of focus to both,

615
00:30:25.490 --> 00:30:28.220
we're going to build a much
more secure solution.

616
00:30:28.220 --> 00:30:30.526
>> Very good Adam,
that's a lot of great information.

617
00:30:30.526 --> 00:30:32.440
I just want to thank you for
not putting me on the spot and

618
00:30:32.440 --> 00:30:36.630
differentiating between due care and due
diligence, but I think we can do that now.

619
00:30:36.630 --> 00:30:39.700
A really good look at some of those
terminology that we're going to have to be

620
00:30:39.700 --> 00:30:41.840
familiar with as a CISSP.

621
00:30:41.840 --> 00:30:44.750
Learning about risk management and

622
00:30:44.750 --> 00:30:49.570
the triad there with confidentiality,
availability, and integrity, and

623
00:30:49.570 --> 00:30:53.260
really showing us that we've got to
be the ones that get in there and

624
00:30:53.260 --> 00:30:56.830
ask those questions and sometimes
that first question isn't enough.

625
00:30:56.830 --> 00:31:01.090
I like the way Adam puts it, we've got to
peel back those layers to really find out

626
00:31:01.090 --> 00:31:06.625
what the needs are in those different
areas as we apply our different controls.

627
00:31:06.625 --> 00:31:09.435
So, fantastic stuff there,
Adam, we appreciate that.

628
00:31:09.435 --> 00:31:11.575
That is going to do it for this episode.

629
00:31:11.575 --> 00:31:16.005
Remember, if you want to attend
one of Adam's live classes,

630
00:31:16.005 --> 00:31:19.493
shoot an email over to SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

631
00:31:19.493 --> 00:31:22.835
That's going to do it for this episode,
signing off, I'm Mike Roderick.

00:31:22.835 --> 00:31:23.850

00:31:23.850 --> 00:31:25.113

1

Hello, and welcome to another

May not be us, right.

But ultimately, somebody somewhere has

00:01:03.808 --> 00:01:09.234
Because what guidance indicates is that

far down the road we can get on that path,

23
00:01:21.582 --> 00:01:22.962

00:01:22.962 --> 00:01:25.913
And when we translate that
into information security,

25
00:01:25.913 --> 00:01:29.126
what we're thinking about is
how we measure, ultimately.

26
00:01:29.126 --> 00:01:31.065
Metrics are very important to do this.

27
00:01:31.065 --> 00:01:36.243
How we measure, ultimately, whether or not
we are successful at pursuing something.

28
00:01:36.243 --> 00:01:41.587
And compliance is specifically about
aligning with whatever the requirements

29
00:01:41.587 --> 00:01:46.702
are to ensure success, typically driven
by legal or regulatory concerns.

30
00:01:46.702 --> 00:01:52.388
So, we may be compliant with the standard
that says that all of our information must

31
00:01:52.388 --> 00:01:57.682
be stored in encrypted fashion when
it's at rest, what we call data at rest.

32
00:01:57.682 --> 00:01:59.903

We're not just thinking

we've got these things called trademarks,

consumption, and trade, and

00:25:44.520 --> 00:25:45.820
We have those as well.

00:25:45.820 --> 00:25:48.840
So those things I just mentioned-
trademarks, patents, and copyrights

00:25:48.840 --> 00:25:53.530
do all those things but we also have
legal agreements that countries sign or

00:25:53.530 --> 00:25:56.110
buy into that also fall
into this category.

497
00:25:56.110 --> 00:25:57.840
We have something known as ITAR.

00:25:57.840 --> 00:26:02.040
ITAR is an acronym that stands for

499
00:26:02.040 --> 00:26:06.900
The ITAR arrangements are a group of
agreements that countries can effectively

500
00:26:06.900 --> 00:26:11.310
sign on for, that govern the use of
what we would call dual use goods.

501
00:26:11.310 --> 00:26:12.640
And you may be thinking,

00:26:12.640 --> 00:26:16.180
why are we talking arms regulation in

503
00:26:16.180 --> 00:26:18.180
We're not selling arms.

504
00:26:18.180 --> 00:26:21.490
No, we're not but
underneath ITAR, underneath

EAR which is the Export Administration

506
00:26:25.230 --> 00:26:28.133
and underneath something known as
the Wassenaar arrangement, and

507
00:26:28.133 --> 00:26:32.720
Wassenaar is also going to be one
of these international agreements.

508
00:26:32.720 --> 00:26:35.820
All three of these classify technology

509
00:26:35.820 --> 00:26:38.660
specifically computer
technology as dual use goods.

510
00:26:38.660 --> 00:26:40.990
And so they are gonna be constrained and

511
00:26:40.990 --> 00:26:44.300
governed underneath these agreements

encryption algorithms items in particular

514
00:26:51.820 --> 00:26:54.640
Right, people get up to no good, and
they can use computers to build weapons

00:26:54.640 --> 00:26:58.320
systems, and they could use computers to

516
00:26:58.320 --> 00:27:01.240
all sorts of stuff that
obviously is regulated by other,

517
00:27:01.240 --> 00:27:04.400
more overarching legal requirements and
legal agreements.

518
00:27:04.400 --> 00:27:08.350
So we have these agreements when we
classify technology form a computer space

00:27:08.350 --> 00:27:11.880
in them, because they are, or
it is considered to be dual use, and

00:27:11.880 --> 00:27:13.890
as a result,
we have to just be aware of that, as well.

521
00:27:13.890 --> 00:27:15.750
Wassenaar is really
probably the biggest one,

522
00:27:15.750 --> 00:27:17.320
one that you would want to be aware of.

523
00:27:17.320 --> 00:27:20.760
Wassenaar.org, if you're
interested is where you can

524
00:27:20.760 --> 00:27:22.952

525
00:27:22.952 --> 00:27:26.050
The Wassenaar arrangement, it's been
around for sometime, and it's fairly

00:27:26.050 --> 00:27:30.250

527
00:27:30.250 --> 00:27:31.530
That's gonna be important.

528
00:27:31.530 --> 00:27:35.070
Generically, when we think about
privacy as we've been talking about

529
00:27:35.070 --> 00:27:37.560
the management of information,
the governance of it.

530
00:27:37.560 --> 00:27:41.170
The association of copyrights,
trademarks, and patents.

531
00:27:41.170 --> 00:27:44.400
We wanna think about privacy from
a slightly different perspective.

532
00:27:44.400 --> 00:27:47.810
the guidelines that help us to
define policy are very important.

533
00:27:47.810 --> 00:27:52.050
The OECD guidelines specifically which
are gonna be the guidelines that

the Organization of Economic or
for Economic Cooperation and

535
00:27:55.190 --> 00:27:56.790
Development's has put out.

00:27:56.790 --> 00:27:59.640
They're called
the OECD Eight Core Principles

537
00:27:59.640 --> 00:28:03.090
are also very important when we think

538
00:28:03.090 --> 00:28:06.300
We think about the idea
of collection limitation.

539
00:28:06.300 --> 00:28:08.170
We think about data quality.

540
00:28:08.170 --> 00:28:10.350
We think about purpose specification.

541
00:28:10.350 --> 00:28:12.410
We think about use limitation.

542
00:28:12.410 --> 00:28:15.060
We think about security
safeguards that's five.

543
00:28:15.060 --> 00:28:20.030
Openness, individual participation,
and data controller accountability.

544
00:28:20.030 --> 00:28:21.560
These are the eight core principals.

545
00:28:21.560 --> 00:28:26.925

546
00:28:26.925 --> 00:28:29.045

548

So for instance when you think about

551
00:28:44.935 --> 00:28:48.660

552
00:28:48.660 --> 00:28:51.900

553

Its one example of how the core guidelines
or the core guiding principles are applied

554

555
00:28:59.970 --> 00:29:02.340
And finally as we wrap up our
conversations in this area,

556
00:29:02.340 --> 00:29:04.270
just some quick definitions, right?

557
00:29:04.270 --> 00:29:06.460
Data breach terminology.

558
00:29:06.460 --> 00:29:08.930
It's always fun to say, terminology,
it's a fun word, right?

559
00:29:08.930 --> 00:29:12.110
What we're thinking about is just
vocabulary, and so we wanna think about

560
00:29:12.110 --> 00:29:15.080
the difference between incident,
the difference between breach.

561
00:29:15.080 --> 00:29:19.160
These two are very similar in definition,
almost identical in fact.

562
00:29:19.160 --> 00:29:21.460
We want to just differentiate
between the focus.

563
00:29:21.460 --> 00:29:23.990
Incident is an event of some kind,
whatever it is.

564
00:29:23.990 --> 00:29:26.280
Obviously security focused in this case,
right?

565
00:29:26.280 --> 00:29:28.520
That has a potential to do harm to one or

566
00:29:28.520 --> 00:29:32.140
more of the elements of confidentiality,
integrity and/or availability.

567
00:29:32.140 --> 00:29:36.470
So then, it's something that's happened
and it has the potential to negatively

568
00:29:36.470 --> 00:29:39.870
impact confidentiality,
integrity and/or availability.

569
00:29:39.870 --> 00:29:43.400
Whereas, a breach is an incident
that has not only happened, but

570
00:29:43.400 --> 00:29:48.030
now we've classified as clearly impacting
one or more of those three elements, and

571
00:29:48.030 --> 00:29:53.750
as a result of that has somehow disclosed
or modified or rendered data unavailable.

572
00:29:53.750 --> 00:29:55.400
And as a result of that, the data,

573
00:29:55.400 --> 00:29:58.508
the target of the breach,
has been compromised as well we would say.

574
00:29:58.508 --> 00:30:01.750
And so and
breach are two very important terms,

575
00:30:01.750 --> 00:30:04.300
as we think about not only
information security but

576

specifically privacy, governance,
risk and compliance based activities.

00:30:08.360 --> 00:30:10.630
>> That's a lot of great
information there, Adam help.

584

585

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike discuss professional ethics. They detail the (ISC)2 Code of Ethics and talk about how it applies as a CISSP, as well as an organizations code of ethics. Then they explain security policies, standards, procedures, and guidelines, and how to develop and implement them.

So we often talk about,

00:17:25.720 --> 00:17:27.860
There's a lot of stuff
documented in there,

343
00:17:27.860 --> 00:17:30.020
it may be hard to understand
what to put in there.

344
00:17:30.020 --> 00:17:32.530
When we think about policy remember
we're thinking about this high level

345
00:17:32.530 --> 00:17:33.750
statement of intent.

346
00:17:33.750 --> 00:17:38.040
We're translating our strategy of
the business, the business requirements,

347
00:17:38.040 --> 00:17:40.940
into an actionable document
that people can go out and

348
00:17:40.940 --> 00:17:45.270
actually create opportunity to be able to
then consume goods and services through.

349
00:17:45.270 --> 00:17:49.490
And so policy may be tough to graph
at the right level, is it too high,

350
00:17:49.490 --> 00:17:53.870
is it too general, is it too low,
too specific, too much detail?

351
00:17:53.870 --> 00:17:58.520
For instance, we wouldn't mention
the name of a specific messaging platform

352
00:17:58.520 --> 00:18:02.850
in an email usage policy, but rather say
generically, we have an email system.

353
00:18:02.850 --> 00:18:06.340
We're gonna give access to that
email system through both the web,

354
00:18:06.340 --> 00:18:08.930
as well as on mobile and
handheld devices and

355
00:18:08.930 --> 00:18:12.180
desktop and desk-bound devices
within the organization.

356
00:18:12.180 --> 00:18:14.220
That's the right level for policy.

357
00:18:14.220 --> 00:18:18.950
Not we're gonna use a Microsoft Exchange
or Google Gmail system, web only,

358
00:18:18.950 --> 00:18:20.400
in order to access mail.

359
00:18:20.400 --> 00:18:22.500
That is not going to be
stipulated in the policy.

360
00:18:22.500 --> 00:18:26.090
Policies should be broad in scope,
and broad in coverage, and

361
00:18:26.090 --> 00:18:29.230
then the detail comes from some of
the supporting documents that we'll

362
00:18:29.230 --> 00:18:31.600
interact with and
we will ultimately slip in below that.

363
00:18:31.600 --> 00:18:34.400
So want to make sure we understand
the right level for policy.

364
00:18:34.400 --> 00:18:39.490
When we think about standards, we think
about the ability to be able to look

365
00:18:39.490 --> 00:18:45.150
to external guidance, perhaps regulatory
or legal guidance, that somebody or

366
00:18:45.150 --> 00:18:48.830
some entity, or some group, a country,
or whoever it may be, is offering us.

367
00:18:48.830 --> 00:18:52.480
And as a result of that,
we need align with and support them.

368
00:18:52.480 --> 00:18:56.875
So for instance, We may have as we said
something like in the United States,

369
00:18:56.875 --> 00:18:57.800
HIPAA.

370
00:18:57.800 --> 00:19:01.680
Or we may have Sarbanes–Oxley,
what's commonly called SARBOX in the US.

371
00:19:01.680 --> 00:19:06.550
Which is a financial services set of
standards that detail for publicly held

372
00:19:06.550 --> 00:19:10.430
companies that are traded on the Stock
Exchange what the financial reporting and

373
00:19:10.430 --> 00:19:12.660
financial regulatory requirements may be.

374
00:19:12.660 --> 00:19:15.400
So that we understand,
have the visibility into their action and

375
00:19:15.400 --> 00:19:17.840
understand that they're
acting honorably and justly.

376
00:19:17.840 --> 00:19:20.300
Reference the code of ethics we
talked about earlier, right?

377
00:19:20.300 --> 00:19:22.940
So that would be a set of
standards that we could reference,

378
00:19:22.940 --> 00:19:26.070
in the healthcare industry, as we said,
in the United States, it would be HIPAA.

379
00:19:26.070 --> 00:19:29.260
And there are others as well, but
HIPAA is the main one we talk about.

380
00:19:29.260 --> 00:19:32.860
Overseas we talked in one of prior
conversations about privacy and

381
00:19:32.860 --> 00:19:35.800
the role of the law with
regards to privacy.

382
00:19:35.800 --> 00:19:40.370
We will look at the EU Privacy Directive
95/46 as an example of a standard

383
00:19:40.370 --> 00:19:43.720
right a law that is in place that we
have to be aligned with and follow.

384
00:19:43.720 --> 00:19:47.820
When we think about procedures we think
about specific tactical guidance.

385
00:19:47.820 --> 00:19:51.320
Step by step how do I break
down what I need to do and

386
00:19:51.320 --> 00:19:55.230
as a result of breaking that down how
do I then have the guidance necessary

387
00:19:55.230 --> 00:19:59.110
to be able to go out and execute
tactically on the strategy divisions.

388
00:19:59.110 --> 00:20:03.700
So, for instance,
if we stick with our email example and

389
00:20:03.700 --> 00:20:07.805
our usage policy is all about email, In
the policy we would stipulate high level,

390
00:20:07.805 --> 00:20:10.435
we want to have a messaging system,
an email system.

391
00:20:10.435 --> 00:20:15.045
We want to give both web access, and
mobile device access remotely for

392
00:20:15.045 --> 00:20:18.655
teleworkers as well as fixed desktop
access within the organization.

393
00:20:18.655 --> 00:20:23.200
Three different ways we will provide
email support and email interaction.

394
00:20:23.200 --> 00:20:27.873
In the procedures we will have detailed
documentary guidance that allows us to

395
00:20:27.873 --> 00:20:31.625
stipulate exactly how somebody
logs on through a web browser,

396
00:20:31.625 --> 00:20:33.678
what web browsers are supported,

397
00:20:33.678 --> 00:20:38.321
what is the URL, what level of access do
they need in order to be able to log in.

398
00:20:38.321 --> 00:20:41.631
Are they an authorized user,
do they need special permission,

399
00:20:41.631 --> 00:20:43.670
is there more than one access control?

400
00:20:43.670 --> 00:20:46.420
If so
how do they gain access to that system?

401
00:20:46.420 --> 00:20:47.560
Do they need both a user name and

402
00:20:47.560 --> 00:20:51.240
a password as well as
a secondary factor of control?

403
00:20:51.240 --> 00:20:55.000
A biometric scan of some sort or
perhaps a pin or

404
00:20:55.000 --> 00:20:58.020
something along with a smart card,
whatever it may be.

405
00:20:58.020 --> 00:21:01.500
Will provide all that guidance and
all of that

406
00:21:01.500 --> 00:21:05.220
is gonna be stipulated step by step in
almost like a cookbook fashion right?

407
00:21:05.220 --> 00:21:08.840
And it's gonna literally be the step
by step process that we go through

408
00:21:08.840 --> 00:21:10.250
to execute that request,

409
00:21:10.250 --> 00:21:14.670
in this case to gain external access
via the web to an email platform.

410
00:21:14.670 --> 00:21:17.150
That will be the procedure in question.

411
00:21:17.150 --> 00:21:18.540
And we think about guidelines,

412
00:21:18.540 --> 00:21:21.370
we're thinking about something
that is optional right.

413
00:21:21.370 --> 00:21:24.554
Guidance, guidelines are optional
things that we can look at.

414
00:21:24.554 --> 00:21:28.633
They may be beneficial, maybe it's
a set of best practices from a vendor,

415
00:21:28.633 --> 00:21:33.038
maybe it is something that people that are
knowledgeable have come up and with and

416
00:21:33.038 --> 00:21:34.944
say this will be good for you to do.

417
00:21:34.944 --> 00:21:37.739
But it's not gonna carry
the force of a regulation,

418
00:21:37.739 --> 00:21:41.470
the force of law that we must
comply with or there are penalties.

419
00:21:41.470 --> 00:21:43.570
It's a hey, if you wanna do this,
this is good, but

420
00:21:43.570 --> 00:21:46.920
if you don't wanna do this,
that's okay as well.

421
00:21:46.920 --> 00:21:47.508
Right?
So

422
00:21:47.508 --> 00:21:49.819
we would say a guideline is optional,
right?

423
00:21:49.819 --> 00:21:52.562
It's gonna be typically best
practice recommendations but

424
00:21:52.562 --> 00:21:55.090
you're not gonna be forced
to follow them or else.

425
00:21:55.090 --> 00:21:57.110
Be very important for us to think about.

426
00:21:57.110 --> 00:21:58.500
>> Very good information there Adam.

427
00:21:58.500 --> 00:22:00.880
That was a lot of information
to try to digest.

428
00:22:00.880 --> 00:22:04.620
We went over ethics and the code of
ethics, we talked about ISC squares

429
00:22:04.620 --> 00:22:09.210
code of ethics very important for us if
we're gonna be taking the CISSP exam or

430
00:22:09.210 --> 00:22:12.800
any of the ISC squared exams that
we understand what that means and

431
00:22:12.800 --> 00:22:15.880
what we have to do to
uphold that code of ethics.

432
00:22:15.880 --> 00:22:20.130
And we also saw to
differentiate between policies,

433
00:22:20.130 --> 00:22:22.820
procedures, standards and guidelines.

434
00:22:22.820 --> 00:22:26.480
Some people try to use those terms
interchangeably, and as Adam has shown us,

435
00:22:26.480 --> 00:22:27.960
they're definitely not the same.

436
00:22:27.960 --> 00:22:31.810
Each one has a specific purpose,
what it should be covering,

437
00:22:31.810 --> 00:22:35.470
and if we're expected to write those,
which we will be as a CISSP,

438
00:22:35.470 --> 00:22:38.690
maybe to lay that framework for
some of those policies and

439
00:22:38.690 --> 00:22:41.710
procedures we need to understand
what should be in there.

440
00:22:41.710 --> 00:22:45.700
And we've got to look at sans.org a great
place to start if you're new to writing

441
00:22:45.700 --> 00:22:48.510
some of those policies and procedures,
you don't even know where to start.

442
00:22:48.510 --> 00:22:51.330
Go there, they've got some
templates they can get you started

443
00:22:51.330 --> 00:22:54.900
down the road to writing really good
policies, procedures and guidelines.

444
00:22:54.900 --> 00:22:58.630
So Adam we thank you for all that
information, remember if you wanna attend

445
00:22:58.630 --> 00:23:04.060
one of Adam's classes live,
drop us an email at SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

446
00:23:04.060 --> 00:23:06.400
Signing off for
this episode I'm Mike Rodrick.

447
00:23:06.400 --> 00:23:07.356
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

448
00:23:07.356 --> 00:23:08.540
>> And we'll see you next time.

449
00:23:08.540 --> 00:23:09.167
>> Take care.

450
00:23:09.167 --> 00:23:15.050
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike look at understanding business continuity requirements. They explain the concept of developing and documenting project scope and plan. They also look at conducting business impact analysis, and define recovery time requirement terms and look at how those elements interact.
episodes.title: Business Continuity
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.249 --> 00:00:10.249
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.236 --> 00:00:15.836
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.836 --> 00:00:20.481
I’m your host Mike Roderick, and
today we're doing our CISSP and specially

4
00:00:20.481 --> 00:00:25.429
we're going to be looking at business
impact analysis and business continuity.

5
00:00:25.429 --> 00:00:29.539
We need to see how we can go about
understanding what kind of requirements we

6
00:00:29.539 --> 00:00:31.378
have with business continuity.

7
00:00:31.378 --> 00:00:33.997
And who better can help us with
that than Mr. Adam Gordon.

8
00:00:33.997 --> 00:00:35.136
How's it going Adam?

9
00:00:35.136 --> 00:00:35.878
>> Awesome.

10
00:00:35.878 --> 00:00:39.525
I'm feeling very continuous, so this
should be a great, great conversation.

11
00:00:39.525 --> 00:00:42.577
All right, so let's think about what
Mike was just talking about, right?

12
00:00:42.577 --> 00:00:46.048
We were talking about, or
Mike was introducing us to the idea,

13
00:00:46.048 --> 00:00:49.399
of thinking about ultimately
what is business continuity?

14
00:00:49.399 --> 00:00:53.613
How do we ensure that operations are gonna
continue in the face of adversity?

15
00:00:53.613 --> 00:00:57.525
But before we get to that, what we have
to think about is what is an operation?

16
00:00:57.525 --> 00:00:58.338
What is important?

17
00:00:58.338 --> 00:01:01.672
In other words, do we have things
that have to happen no matter what?

18
00:01:01.672 --> 00:01:05.664
And do we have things that would be nice
to have happen, but if they don't, may or

19
00:01:05.664 --> 00:01:07.209
may not be all that important.

20
00:01:07.209 --> 00:01:10.517
So for instance,
we may have color printing capabilities.

21
00:01:10.517 --> 00:01:14.878
So I have framed this conversation
with my customers in this way.

22
00:01:14.878 --> 00:01:17.336
You may have color printing
in the organization.

23
00:01:17.336 --> 00:01:18.950
And that's a nice to have, right?

24
00:01:18.950 --> 00:01:21.793
You've heard me talk about nice to haves,
need to haves, and must haves.

25
00:01:21.793 --> 00:01:23.864
I often talk about things in that regard,

26
00:01:23.864 --> 00:01:27.007
cuz I think it helps to simplify
the conversation and focus us.

27
00:01:27.007 --> 00:01:31.642
Color printing may be a nice to have, but
the reality we ask ourselves about in

28
00:01:31.642 --> 00:01:36.348
regards to continuity and recovery, is if
I could focus on all the systems in my

29
00:01:36.348 --> 00:01:40.984
organization, is color printing one of
the ones I have to spend resources and

30
00:01:40.984 --> 00:01:44.156
time recovering right now
in the face of adversity?

31
00:01:44.156 --> 00:01:47.855
Or is that something I can get to later,
when everything else is okay and

32
00:01:47.855 --> 00:01:49.096
we're back to normal.

33
00:01:49.096 --> 00:01:53.853
If we're a marketing organization,
if we are gonna make our living selling

34
00:01:53.853 --> 00:01:58.461
color printed goods and services to
individuals, if we are at Kinko's,

35
00:01:58.461 --> 00:02:00.936
then we probably need color printing.

36
00:02:00.936 --> 00:02:03.958
That's pretty systemic
in part of what we do.

37
00:02:03.958 --> 00:02:07.951
But if we are not in the color printing
business, it's a nice to have,

38
00:02:07.951 --> 00:02:09.789
not a need have or a must to have.

39
00:02:09.789 --> 00:02:13.772
And so what we need to start thinking
about as we begin these conversations,

40
00:02:13.772 --> 00:02:15.467
is what's gonna be important.

41
00:02:15.467 --> 00:02:19.358
And Mike's gonna help us figure out how
we get to what's important as we have our

42
00:02:19.358 --> 00:02:20.182
conversation.

43
00:02:20.182 --> 00:02:23.941
But ultimately as he keeps me honest,
and as he keeps me on target,

44
00:02:23.941 --> 00:02:28.529
what we wanna think about is is this core,
is this central, is this what we want?

45
00:02:28.529 --> 00:02:31.249
If it is,
then let's focus on it a certain way.

46
00:02:31.249 --> 00:02:34.729
If it's not let's put it off to the side,
and we'll talk about that as we go.

47
00:02:34.729 --> 00:02:38.569
So, in order to begin our conversations in
this area, we really have to start with

48
00:02:38.569 --> 00:02:42.022
this thinking about developing, and
documenting a project plan that's

49
00:02:42.022 --> 00:02:44.940
gonna help us understand how
to manage business continuity.

50
00:02:44.940 --> 00:02:50.869
BCP, business continuity planning is all
about what we do to get back to normal.

51
00:02:50.869 --> 00:02:53.527
How do we ensure
continuity of our systems?

52
00:02:53.527 --> 00:02:56.690
How do we ensure that things are running
the way they're supposed to.

53
00:02:56.690 --> 00:02:59.486
Mike, when you showed up to work
this morning, did we have email?

54
00:02:59.486 --> 00:03:00.021
>> We did.

55
00:03:00.021 --> 00:03:01.982
>> We did, right, so email's working.

56
00:03:01.982 --> 00:03:05.054
Now, email working is probably
the normal state of affairs, right,

57
00:03:05.054 --> 00:03:05.999
more often than not.

58
00:03:05.999 --> 00:03:07.707
So, Mike comes into work, email's working.

59
00:03:07.707 --> 00:03:11.157
I said more often than not, it doesn't
always, but more often than not, right?

60
00:03:11.157 --> 00:03:12.831
Email's working, so that's good.

61
00:03:12.831 --> 00:03:14.451
But what if email wasn't working?

62
00:03:14.451 --> 00:03:15.416
What would we do then?

63
00:03:15.416 --> 00:03:17.075
All right, what are we gonna
do if email's not working?

64
00:03:17.075 --> 00:03:19.744
What we'd have to figure
out is number one,

65
00:03:19.744 --> 00:03:22.857
we would have to know what
email not working means.

66
00:03:22.857 --> 00:03:26.961
And then we would have to understand
when email doesn't work is that there

67
00:03:26.961 --> 00:03:31.330
are certain things we probably have to go
through and a prioritized list of some

68
00:03:31.330 --> 00:03:35.962
sort in terms of responses, activities,
understanding the things that are going

69
00:03:35.962 --> 00:03:40.461
on in order to ensure that we work through
the cycle of what not working means to get

70
00:03:40.461 --> 00:03:43.274
to a resolution with
a reasonable amount of time.

71
00:03:43.274 --> 00:03:47.594
But also, a reasonable amount of assurance
that the solution we provide is gonna

72
00:03:47.594 --> 00:03:49.639
restore continuity to that service.

73
00:03:49.639 --> 00:03:51.442
And these are important
things to consider.

74
00:03:51.442 --> 00:03:55.976
So, the way we get there is we first have
to identify that we need a BCP program,

75
00:03:55.976 --> 00:03:57.927
a business continuity program.

76
00:03:57.927 --> 00:04:01.236
And then, we have to plan out or sketch
out the parameters of what that means.

77
00:04:01.236 --> 00:04:06.212
So, when we think about BCP planning, what
we think about is one or more individuals,

78
00:04:06.212 --> 00:04:10.714
typically representatives from different
areas of the organization that get

79
00:04:10.714 --> 00:04:13.670
together and
are gonna jointly come up with a plan.

80
00:04:13.670 --> 00:04:15.108
And a plan can be many things.

81
00:04:15.108 --> 00:04:19.020
A plan can be a set of requirements
written down in a document.

82
00:04:19.020 --> 00:04:22.870
A plan can be a very detailed,
very,very specific

83
00:04:22.870 --> 00:04:27.717
action-oriented capability that
we develop in the business.

84
00:04:27.717 --> 00:04:31.699
A plan could be a story, a narrative about
what we should be thinking about doing if

85
00:04:31.699 --> 00:04:34.949
something isn't working or
something doesn't go the right way.

86
00:04:34.949 --> 00:04:37.701
So Mike, when we came in to a work today.

87
00:04:37.701 --> 00:04:38.258
>> Mm-hm.

88
00:04:38.258 --> 00:04:40.722
>> Did you and I have a plan for
what we're gonna do and

89
00:04:40.722 --> 00:04:43.435
talk about with our lovely
studio audience out there?

90
00:04:43.435 --> 00:04:44.793
>> We did.
>> We had a plan, right?

91
00:04:44.793 --> 00:04:47.668
And in order to have and
put on a show like this, and

92
00:04:47.668 --> 00:04:51.571
put on all the work that we do that
goes to putting in a show like this,

93
00:04:51.571 --> 00:04:53.850
you don't see that behind the scenes.

94
00:04:53.850 --> 00:04:57.159
And it actually would maybe be
interesting at some point of the show,

95
00:04:57.159 --> 00:04:58.826
everybody what we do to get ready.

96
00:04:58.826 --> 00:05:02.357
There's a lot of work that goes
into putting on a small segment for

97
00:05:02.357 --> 00:05:04.613
you let alone an entire course in the end.

98
00:05:04.613 --> 00:05:07.550
And that's part of all the things that
we have to do ahead of time, right?

99
00:05:07.550 --> 00:05:09.677
If we just showed up and
winged it, so to speak,

100
00:05:09.677 --> 00:05:12.938
even though it may look like we're
doing that at certain points in time.

101
00:05:12.938 --> 00:05:14.730
Rest assured, we have a plan.

102
00:05:14.730 --> 00:05:16.017
Things have been worked out.

103
00:05:16.017 --> 00:05:17.746
So, if we make it look effortless,

104
00:05:17.746 --> 00:05:21.668
if we make it look like we're just ad
libbing but it's all coming together well,

105
00:05:21.668 --> 00:05:24.513
then Mike and I have really
done our job exceedingly well.

106
00:05:24.513 --> 00:05:25.662
We have planned so well,

107
00:05:25.662 --> 00:05:28.471
in other words that we know
exactly what's going to happen.

108
00:05:28.471 --> 00:05:31.678
We can anticipate all the things
that potentially will come up, and

109
00:05:31.678 --> 00:05:34.558
we know how to deal with them
in the flow of the conversation.

110
00:05:34.558 --> 00:05:36.090
That's a good plan.

111
00:05:36.090 --> 00:05:40.684
A bad plan would be we're talking to you,
and you start to see things falling behind

112
00:05:40.684 --> 00:05:43.779
me here and
the stage comes apart while we're talking.

113

00:27:05.440 --> 00:27:10.100

recovery time objective.

566
00:27:10.100 --> 00:27:16.110
RTO allows us to be able to focus on
the idea that we have to come up with,

567
00:27:16.110 --> 00:27:21.690
ultimately, a measure of
time that we will recover

568
00:27:21.690 --> 00:27:25.470
before we can say, you know what,
we're back and everything is good.

569
00:27:25.470 --> 00:27:29.985
So RTO, recovery time objective,
is a flag we put in the ground.

570
00:27:29.985 --> 00:27:34.325
That is the point that we strive to
bring the system back online by.

571
00:27:34.325 --> 00:27:35.801
It's a time measure, right?

572
00:27:35.801 --> 00:27:39.645
Our RPO, remember, is a time measure as
well, but RPO says we may lose up to,

573
00:27:39.645 --> 00:27:43.065
let's say 15 minutes, in our example,
of transactional data.

574
00:27:43.065 --> 00:27:46.397
So, that's fine, but
RTO is also a measure of time.

575
00:27:46.397 --> 00:27:52.315
RTO says, we wanna recover that system
within one hour of it being offline.

576
00:27:52.315 --> 00:27:57.390
Now we may not be losing data as a result
of meeting the RTO objective, or we may.

577
00:27:57.390 --> 00:28:02.220
The RPO may say 15 minutes, but if we
have a backup that runs every 15 minutes,

578
00:28:02.220 --> 00:28:05.400
we can recover up to
the last 15 minutes of data.

579
00:28:05.400 --> 00:28:08.080
But it may take us an hour to
bring the system back online,

580
00:28:08.080 --> 00:28:10.770
in order to put that data back in and
have it operational.

581
00:28:10.770 --> 00:28:14.350
RTO is the measure of that time it
takes to bring the system back up and

582
00:28:14.350 --> 00:28:15.460
make it operational.

583
00:28:15.460 --> 00:28:20.168
The earliest, very, very clear, very
important here, earliest time that we can

584
00:28:20.168 --> 00:28:24.219
strive to get that system recovered
is what RTO typically represents.

585
00:28:24.219 --> 00:28:27.975
So, if RTO is our target under everything
working the right way, that set of

586
00:28:27.975 --> 00:28:32.219
circumstances, everything, all the magic
happens, everything comes together.

587
00:28:32.219 --> 00:28:36.925
RTO indicates that earliest time
window where we could successfully

588
00:28:36.925 --> 00:28:40.270
recover the system and
expect to be back online.

589
00:28:40.270 --> 00:28:43.576
That's the measure of time it takes
to recover and put everything back.

590
00:28:43.576 --> 00:28:48.497
Now we also have something that's called
MTD, which is kind of bracket or a brace,

591
00:28:48.497 --> 00:28:52.670
or whatever we would call it at
the top there, A parenthesis perhaps.

592
00:28:52.670 --> 00:28:56.881
And at the top you'll notice that goes
from the left hand side of RTO, all

593
00:28:56.881 --> 00:29:02.220
the way across to the far right hand side,
right, where it says resume production.

594
00:29:02.220 --> 00:29:05.330
Now, MTD incorporates, or
encompasses, that whole window.

595
00:29:05.330 --> 00:29:05.861
And what we say,

596
00:29:05.861 --> 00:29:10.770
and what you need to understand is
that RTO needs to be always set less.

597
00:29:10.770 --> 00:29:16.720
It needs to be shorter, or it needs to be
a time value that is lower than the MTD.

598
00:29:16.720 --> 00:29:20.080
MTD, maximum tolerable downtime,

599
00:29:20.080 --> 00:29:25.080
is gonna be the maximum time amount that
we will spend trying to recover a system.

600
00:29:25.080 --> 00:29:28.220
We say RTO should be less,
because if RTO is less and

601
00:29:28.220 --> 00:29:32.190
we miss the RTO window, we still have
a buffer that we can recover within,

602
00:29:32.190 --> 00:29:34.530
before we have to declare a disaster.

603
00:29:34.530 --> 00:29:39.509
If we hit the MTD barrier, which is
the right-hand side of that diagram,

604
00:29:39.509 --> 00:29:43.706
and we have not recovered by then,
then everything changes.

605
00:29:43.706 --> 00:29:46.826
Because at that point,
we have to declare a disaster and say,

606
00:29:46.826 --> 00:29:49.960
we no longer have any more time,
something's gotta change.

607
00:29:49.960 --> 00:29:51.660
What we're doing isn't working.

608
00:29:51.660 --> 00:29:54.130
And as a result of that,
we now have a disaster.

609
00:29:54.130 --> 00:29:57.270
We have to go into what's known as
disaster recovery planning, DRP,

610
00:29:57.270 --> 00:29:59.810
and execute our disaster recovery plan.

611
00:29:59.810 --> 00:30:02.990
We'll talk more about DRP later in
one of our other conversations.

612
00:30:02.990 --> 00:30:07.948
But MTD, the MTD barrier is the line
in the sand that we must absolutely

613
00:30:07.948 --> 00:30:09.892
recover by no matter what.

614
00:30:09.892 --> 00:30:13.210
And if we can't recover by then,
we have to declare disaster.

615
00:30:13.210 --> 00:30:16.420
Now, before we wrap up, cuz I know Mike
is looking at me expectantly, waiting on

616
00:30:16.420 --> 00:30:20.450
me to finish, and I am going to right now,
but before we do, one quick thing.

617
00:30:20.450 --> 00:30:22.430
If you need, and
you do need rather, I should say,

618
00:30:22.430 --> 00:30:24.430
to understand the following,
as I mentioned.

619
00:30:24.430 --> 00:30:27.930
We do say that RTO should be, and

620
00:30:27.930 --> 00:30:31.220
indeed more often than not is,
set to be less than MTD.

621
00:30:31.220 --> 00:30:33.010
However, that's not a hard fast rule,

622
00:30:33.010 --> 00:30:36.340
in a sense that if you don't do
it that way, things don't work.

623
00:30:36.340 --> 00:30:39.710
The recommendation simply is that
you want to have a buffer, so

624
00:30:39.710 --> 00:30:43.710
if you miss the RTO window for recovery,
you still have time to figure out

625
00:30:43.710 --> 00:30:47.060
how to do something else,
before you have to declare disaster.

626
00:30:47.060 --> 00:30:50.944
This is why we say RTO should
typically be less than MTD.

627
00:30:50.944 --> 00:30:52.830
But I wanna be clear that this is not,

628
00:30:52.830 --> 00:30:55.530
if you don't do it this way,
everything breaks.

629
00:30:55.530 --> 00:30:57.410
This is simply a recommendation.

630
00:30:57.410 --> 00:31:00.560
And this is the best practice
recommendation we often follow.

631
00:31:00.560 --> 00:31:02.340
>> All right, Adam,
lot of great information there.

632
00:31:02.340 --> 00:31:06.050
Looking at that business continuity and
business impact analysis.

633
00:31:06.050 --> 00:31:07.740
A lot of important terms in there,
as well.

634
00:31:07.740 --> 00:31:11.870
We've got our recovery point objective,
our recovery time objective, and

635
00:31:11.870 --> 00:31:14.060
that maximum tolerable downtime.

636
00:31:14.060 --> 00:31:18.100
And seeing how they all fit together in
building that timeline, so we can make

637
00:31:18.100 --> 00:31:23.920
the appropriate plans and get our systems
back online, and keep our business going.

638
00:31:23.920 --> 00:31:26.310
All right, well, Adam,
we appreciate that, great stuff.

639
00:31:26.310 --> 00:31:30.080
Remember, if you wanna see Adam and
wanna attend one of his live classes,

640
00:31:30.080 --> 00:31:33.610
shoot an email over there
to SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

641
00:31:33.610 --> 00:31:36.357
But for this episode,
signing out, I'm Mike Rodrick.

642
00:31:36.357 --> 00:31:38.960
>> I'm Adam, and remember,
recover early and recover often.

643
00:31:38.960 --> 00:31:40.066
We'll see you soon.

644
00:31:40.066 --> 00:31:45.920
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike discuss several types of personnel security policies. They start with employment candidate screening, like reference checks and education verification. They talk about employment agreements and policies and the termination process. Then they cover vendor, consultant, and contractor controls, and also look at compliance and privacy.
episodes.title: Personnel Security

WEBVTT

[MUSIC]

Right?
We've gotta deal with people that work for

How's it going, Adam?

>> I'm good.
I'm feeling very secure, Mike.

00:00:39.235 --> 00:00:40.395
So, you're making me feel comfortable,

00:00:40.395 --> 00:00:43.375
which is important when we talk

So, when we think about
personnel security, and

00:00:45.535 --> 00:00:48.035
we think about what's involved
in personnel security, well,

we have to think about is,what

Right up until now we've really been
talking about how do we focus on

00:01:04.490 --> 00:01:06.050

26

What is confidentiality?

Why do we need integrity?

29
00:01:09.960 --> 00:01:11.660
Why is availability important?

30
00:01:11.660 --> 00:01:15.120
All that stuff is good, but
it all pertains to data.

31
00:01:15.120 --> 00:01:16.260
Now, data's important.

32

Information's important.

33

But information's not the whole story

34
00:01:21.370 --> 00:01:23.510
And we probably should think

35
00:01:23.510 --> 00:01:25.300
We are focusing on information.

36
00:01:25.300 --> 00:01:29.340
But more broadly, when we think about
security, infrastructure security,

37
00:01:29.340 --> 00:01:33.370
personnel security as Mike was alluding
to in his introductory comments,

38
00:01:33.370 --> 00:01:36.890
we're thinking about the security of
things that support the use of, and

39
00:01:36.890 --> 00:01:41.500
indeed, consume data but are lateral and
in some cases ancillary to it.

40
00:01:41.500 --> 00:01:43.390
And so,
when we think about personnel security,

41
00:01:43.390 --> 00:01:46.110
what we're thinking about
is how do we hire people?

42

And what do we do to make sure we

44
00:01:51.710 --> 00:01:53.210
How do we know the people
that come to work for

45

us are indeed gonna act honorably,
gonna have integrity,

46
00:01:56.520 --> 00:02:00.410
are gonna do the things that the business
says are important to be able to focus on?

47
00:02:00.410 --> 00:02:01.460
We have to screen them, right?

48
00:02:01.460 --> 00:02:03.380
In some way,
we have to know who we're dealing with.

49
00:02:03.380 --> 00:02:05.110
So, we may look at hiring practices.

50
00:02:05.110 --> 00:02:08.120
We may be thinking about doing
background checks, for instance.

51
00:02:08.120 --> 00:02:09.074
Right?
And most of us,

52
00:02:09.074 --> 00:02:11.762
I know in my professional life,
even though you look at me and

53
00:02:11.762 --> 00:02:14.770
say, who the hell would hire
somebody looking him, right?

54
00:02:14.770 --> 00:02:18.230
But the reality is, look at me and
you say, okay, well,

55
00:02:18.230 --> 00:02:20.840
maybe a bit of a scary individual, right?

56
00:02:20.840 --> 00:02:23.900
Looks a little crazy,
got the long hair and got all the jewelry.

57
00:02:23.900 --> 00:02:26.222
I was in the music business
at one point early on.

58
00:02:26.222 --> 00:02:28.730
You would never know that by
looking at me, but I was.

59
00:02:28.730 --> 00:02:29.494
>> [LAUGH] Never.

60
00:02:29.494 --> 00:02:32.267
>> Well, when you think about that,
you think about, okay, well,

61
00:02:32.267 --> 00:02:33.963
I wanna know who this person is, right?

62
00:02:33.963 --> 00:02:35.381
So, you wanna background screen.

63
00:02:35.381 --> 00:02:39.007
You wanna be able to ask questions during
an interview that indicate where somebody

64
00:02:39.007 --> 00:02:41.230
has been, what have they done,
what do they know,

65
00:02:41.230 --> 00:02:43.180
what kind of skills do
they bring to a table?

66
