So, we ask for a resume typically, right?

67
00:02:45.565 --> 00:02:47.060
And we want to see information.

68
00:02:47.060 --> 00:02:48.170
We want to see references.

69
00:02:48.170 --> 00:02:51.605
The standard stuff we think about are the
things that we focus on in this area.

70
00:02:51.605 --> 00:02:52.880
Right?
A lot of it, and

71
00:02:52.880 --> 00:02:55.580
I often talk to my customers and
my students about this in classes and

72
00:02:55.580 --> 00:02:59.030
when I have meetings, a lot of what
we do in information security,

73
00:02:59.030 --> 00:03:01.930
generically, is really not surprising.

74
00:03:01.930 --> 00:03:03.425
I mean,
you break it down it's common sense.

75
00:03:03.425 --> 00:03:04.300
Right?
Don't hire

76
00:03:04.300 --> 00:03:07.110
people that are strangers unless we
know where they're coming from and

77
00:03:07.110 --> 00:03:10.586
what they're about to do because mommy
always said don't talk to strangers.

78
00:03:10.586 --> 00:03:13.025
Right?
You talk to strangers, bad things happen.

79
00:03:13.025 --> 00:03:15.030
Right?
Stranger danger, you've heard about that?

80
00:03:15.030 --> 00:03:16.680
Don't take candy from strange people?

81
00:03:16.680 --> 00:03:17.557
That kind of stuff.

82
00:03:17.557 --> 00:03:18.740
It's very important.

83
00:03:18.740 --> 00:03:21.820
So, if a stranger is gonna present
themselves and wanna come to work for

84
00:03:21.820 --> 00:03:23.240
me, I wanna interview them.

85
00:03:23.240 --> 00:03:24.070
I wanna know more about them.

86
00:03:24.070 --> 00:03:25.500
I wanna know where they're coming from.

87
00:03:25.500 --> 00:03:26.350
I wanna know who they know.

88
00:03:26.350 --> 00:03:29.310
I wanna know what they've done
professionally cuz I wanna make sure

89
00:03:29.310 --> 00:03:31.510
they're gonna be a good fit for
our organization.

90
00:03:31.510 --> 00:03:37.260
Now, this brings up an interesting issue
which is, as an organization, do we

91
00:03:37.260 --> 00:03:42.020
actually have a way of measuring whether
or not that person's gonna be a good fit?

92
00:03:42.020 --> 00:03:46.490
So, for instance,
do we have a culture of security?

93
00:03:46.490 --> 00:03:50.770
Do we have awareness of security in the
organization that we can look to and say,

94
00:03:50.770 --> 00:03:56.410
well, based on our culture of security, we
have things that we measure everybody by.

95
00:03:56.410 --> 00:04:00.670
And we say our values, our missions,
mission statements, our objectives,

96
00:04:00.670 --> 00:04:03.374
our purposes, these are the things that
are important to the organization.

97
00:04:03.374 --> 00:04:04.150
They're common.

98
00:04:04.150 --> 00:04:05.670
They're shared by everybody.

99
00:04:05.670 --> 00:04:08.750
And Mr or Mrs candidate,
we want you to be aware of them.

100
00:04:08.750 --> 00:04:10.980
And if you're gonna come work for
us, you have to share them and

101
00:04:10.980 --> 00:04:12.140
you have to be a part of that.

102
00:04:12.140 --> 00:04:14.530
And if you're willing to, we can talk
about whether or not it's a good fit.

103
00:04:14.530 --> 00:04:17.620
If you're not,
probably not gonna be a good fit for us.

104
00:04:17.620 --> 00:04:20.520
Maybe we should talk about what you
could do outside the organization or

105
00:04:20.520 --> 00:04:23.760
in a different area, because you're
not gonna be a good fit for us here.

106
00:04:23.760 --> 00:04:26.940
So, it's really incumbent on
us as security professionals

107
00:04:26.940 --> 00:04:30.370
to be able to think about,
not just what security equals, but

108
00:04:30.370 --> 00:04:33.980
how do we communicate that broadly and
widely in the organization and

109
00:04:33.980 --> 00:04:38.230
create a security awareness solution,
but also a culture of security.

110
00:04:38.230 --> 00:04:43.480
As I look around the ITProTV landscape,
right?

111
00:04:43.480 --> 00:04:47.170
And I think about the students that
are gonna be obviously listening to us.

112
00:04:47.170 --> 00:04:50.530
But more broadly are just members, and
obviously are communicating with us about

113
00:04:50.530 --> 00:04:54.330
the things they wanna see, content they're
interested in, things of that nature.

114
00:04:54.330 --> 00:04:57.650
I think about the care we take in order
to reach out to our customers and

115
00:04:57.650 --> 00:04:59.310
make sure we understand
what their needs are.

116
00:04:59.310 --> 00:05:02.450
But I also think about the mission policy,
the purpose, the values,

117
00:05:02.450 --> 00:05:06.660
the objectives of the organization that
we've put forward to service all of you

118
00:05:06.660 --> 00:05:09.880
that are listening to the content and
taking part in our conversations.

119
00:05:09.880 --> 00:05:11.980
And the care and the purpose and
the mission that Mike and

120
00:05:11.980 --> 00:05:13.450
I have as we present this content.

121
00:05:13.450 --> 00:05:16.920
And more broadly, as any of our
presenters, present content for

122
00:05:16.920 --> 00:05:19.000
you and
any of the classes you may be engaged in.

123
00:05:19.000 --> 00:05:19.790
We have a purpose.

124
00:05:19.790 --> 00:05:20.870
We have a shared purpose.

125
00:05:20.870 --> 00:05:21.760
You wanna learn.

126
00:05:21.760 --> 00:05:24.250
We wanna, obviously,
help you to do that and educate you.

127
00:05:24.250 --> 00:05:28.310
We have really important and
invaluable stuff we wanna communicate.

128
00:05:28.310 --> 00:05:31.100
A lot of it is very relevant
to the obvious topics and

129
00:05:31.100 --> 00:05:32.300
things you wanna be involved with.

130
00:05:32.300 --> 00:05:36.260
And you, as students, wanna come in and
gain the experience and the value of that.

131
00:05:36.260 --> 00:05:37.460
So, we have a shared purposed.

132
00:05:37.460 --> 00:05:38.470
We have context.

133
00:05:38.470 --> 00:05:41.070
And we have the ability to be
able to communicate broadly, but

134
00:05:41.070 --> 00:05:43.770
also with specificity about
the things that are important to us.

135
00:05:43.770 --> 00:05:45.950
You gives us feedback, and
we obviously adjust and

136
00:05:45.950 --> 00:05:48.060
present things in a matter
that makes sense to you.

137
00:05:48.060 --> 00:05:50.773
This is all about the way in
which we create common ground.

138
00:05:50.773 --> 00:05:53.150
And common ground's very important
when we talk about about,

139
00:05:53.150 --> 00:05:55.890
not just information security,
but more broadly,

140
00:05:55.890 --> 00:05:59.170
this idea of how do we communicate
information securely, effectively

141
00:05:59.170 --> 00:06:03.310
to those people that we are charged with
and responsible with for taking care of.

142
00:06:03.310 --> 00:06:05.910
In an organization as the CISSP,

143
00:06:05.910 --> 00:06:08.580
you're going to be a mid level
to senior level manager.

144
00:06:08.580 --> 00:06:13.560
You are gonna have purview, perspective
and, obviously, responsibility ultimately

145
00:06:13.560 --> 00:06:17.220
for the security policy of one or

00:26:26.380 --> 00:26:27.650
What about consultants?

603
00:26:27.650 --> 00:26:31.460
What about people that don't work for
the organization formally and fully but

604
00:26:31.460 --> 00:26:35.580
rather are, as Mike indicated early on
when he talked about maybe outsourcing or

605
00:26:35.580 --> 00:26:37.380
bringing in special expertise.

606
00:26:37.380 --> 00:26:38.170
How do we do that?

607
00:26:38.170 --> 00:26:40.340
Well we have to have contracts and
agreements in place.

608
00:26:40.340 --> 00:26:43.100
We have to think about those people,
think about their skills,

609
00:26:43.100 --> 00:26:47.130

610
00:26:47.130 --> 00:26:48.550
Do we have a relationship with them?

611
00:26:48.550 --> 00:26:50.300
Do we know anything about them?

612
00:26:50.300 --> 00:26:53.230
All the things we've talked about are
gonna be important, reference checks and

613
00:26:53.230 --> 00:26:54.350
things of that nature.

614
00:26:54.350 --> 00:26:59.260
But even then, right we really at the end
of the day don't know who they are.

615
00:26:59.260 --> 00:27:02.520
I mean if you think about we do
a background check on anybody, but

616
00:27:02.520 --> 00:27:05.800
that doesn't mean you really know who
that person is and what they're up to.

617
00:27:05.800 --> 00:27:07.718
You just simply know what you
see in the background check.

618
00:27:07.718 --> 00:27:11.698
If that person's very successful at hiding
the bad activities they've been up to up

619
00:27:11.698 --> 00:27:13.994
until now,
you many not find out about them, and

620
00:27:13.994 --> 00:27:16.025
you may not really know
who that person is.

621
00:27:16.025 --> 00:27:20.309
And so you have to do multiple things, not
just one thing to really understand it,

622
00:27:20.309 --> 00:27:24.570
ultimately see who's coming to work for
you and what they're capable of.

623
00:27:24.570 --> 00:27:26.790
It's not just about hey,
let's do a background check.

624
00:27:26.790 --> 00:27:29.310
Let's sign a contract,
let's do all that stuff.

625
00:27:29.310 --> 00:27:32.680
You have to have active monitoring
in place inside the organization.

626
00:27:32.680 --> 00:27:35.470
You know, the though process we
often use when we think about

627
00:27:35.470 --> 00:27:38.270

which is trust but verify.

628
00:27:38.270 --> 00:27:41.450
So the idea is you know, I trust you but

629
00:27:41.450 --> 00:27:43.890
I want to make sure that
my trust is well placed.

630
00:27:43.890 --> 00:27:45.510
Right?
So I'm not just going to take

631
00:27:45.510 --> 00:27:48.970
you at face value and I don't want you
to take for granted that I trust you.

632
00:27:48.970 --> 00:27:52.510
I you to feel that I trust you but
I also want to prove that I can.

633
00:27:52.510 --> 00:27:54.970
And so
as a result I'm gonna look at what you do.

634
00:27:54.970 --> 00:27:57.220
We're gonna monitor systems
you have access to.

635
00:27:57.220 --> 00:27:59.120
Gonna look at information
you're accessing.

636
00:27:59.120 --> 00:28:02.920
And if you're not supposed to see
the spreadsheet in the file that says

637
00:28:02.920 --> 00:28:05.820
don't open up under any circumstances and
you go look at it.

638
00:28:05.820 --> 00:28:07.020
I'm gonna wanna know why.

639
00:28:07.020 --> 00:28:08.860
Because clearly you weren't
supposed to be there.

640
00:28:08.860 --> 00:28:12.100
Now you may have a perfectly
plausible explanation for that, but

641
00:28:12.100 --> 00:28:14.678
we're gonna talk about what that is and
why that happened.

642
00:28:14.678 --> 00:28:18.140
And depending on what you tell me,
I may or may not trust you anymore, right.

643
00:28:18.140 --> 00:28:21.590
So trust but verify becomes a really
important operational criteria

644
00:28:21.590 --> 00:28:24.270
of how we frame this conversation,
what we think about as well.

645
00:28:24.270 --> 00:28:28.265
And we've talked a lot about
privacy in prior conversations,

646
00:28:28.265 --> 00:28:31.280
it's a theme we carry forward
many of the things we do.

647
00:28:31.280 --> 00:28:33.770
Privacy is really at the heart of
what we're talking about here.

648
00:28:33.770 --> 00:28:37.010
It's the idea of safeguarding
confidentiality as well as integrity

649
00:28:37.010 --> 00:28:41.100
of information, that we focus on when we
think about anything having to do with not

650
00:28:41.100 --> 00:28:45.140
just personnel security, but information
security more broadly as I said,

651
00:28:45.140 --> 00:28:47.280
that we can classify
security in many ways.

652
00:28:47.280 --> 00:28:49.480
And any of those things we
put in front of security.

653
00:28:49.480 --> 00:28:53.970
Hardware, software, identity and
access, management and

654
00:28:53.970 --> 00:28:57.390
security as a result of that
personnel security, all those things,

655
00:28:57.390 --> 00:29:00.890
all are focused on the ability
to understand how to safeguard

656
00:29:00.890 --> 00:29:04.920

ensure only qualified and

657
00:29:04.920 --> 00:29:08.580

658

These are all very important things for
us to think about.

659

And to be aware of, right?

660

So just make sure that we're
thinking about those things and

665

We see data.

We wanna protect data, personnel,
big part of it as well.

667

It's going to be a big

668
00:29:30.760 --> 00:29:33.140
All right,well thanks Adam for
all that information.

669

And so we have to think about that and

34

To that end, let's go ahead and

So, you'll hear me talking but

not see my smiling face-

62

63

64
00:02:56.796 --> 00:03:00.935
These are the bad people and
the bad software, the malware, for

65

instance things like that.

66
00:03:03.320 --> 00:03:06.240
And the bad websites,
where we get that stuff from.

67
00:03:06.240 --> 00:03:10.550

lead us down the road of having a concern

68
00:03:10.550 --> 00:03:11.680
or problem.

69
00:03:11.680 --> 00:03:14.750
And threat sources are where
things that can potentially

70
00:03:14.750 --> 00:03:19.130
would underscore the work potentially
do us harm, may come from.

71
00:03:19.130 --> 00:03:21.370

76

77

So these are things we wanna think about.

81

83

Where's it coming from?

84

And that's what the threat source is.

85
00:03:59.400 --> 00:04:04.565
Threat sources initiate threat events,

86
00:04:04.565 --> 00:04:09.310
Threat events are going to be things that
when carried out in a certain sequence,

87
00:04:09.310 --> 00:04:13.130
as we say there with sequence of actions,
activities, or scenarios.

88
00:04:13.130 --> 00:04:17.110
When certain things are done
a certain way, as a result of that,

89
00:04:17.110 --> 00:04:19.120
it is more likely, as we say,

90
00:04:19.120 --> 00:04:23.920
exploiting with likelihood of success,
that something is going to occur.

91
00:04:23.920 --> 00:04:27.584
That something, as we said,
is traditionally seen as being negative,

92
00:04:27.584 --> 00:04:28.853
but not always, right?

93
00:04:28.853 --> 00:04:32.439
Threat events talk about things that
potentially are gonna be bad outcomes.

94
00:04:32.439 --> 00:04:36.405
But we can talk about the fact that if we
interdict and we stop the threat source

95
00:04:36.405 --> 00:04:40.280

then we have been successful.

96
00:04:40.280 --> 00:04:45.400
And so not all risks, not all threats

97
00:04:45.400 --> 00:04:47.690
We just wanna keep that in mind and
consider that.

98
00:04:47.690 --> 00:04:51.572
So threat events are the sequence
of actions, activities,

99
00:04:51.572 --> 00:04:56.365
whatever those things may be, that when
done or executed in a certain way,

100
00:04:56.365 --> 00:05:00.041
lead us to be able to exploit,
exploit is an action word.

101
00:05:00.041 --> 00:05:02.980
I'm gonna take action of some
sort to exploit something.

102
00:05:02.980 --> 00:05:05.150
That something is called
the vulnerability.

103
00:05:05.150 --> 00:05:07.640
A vulnerability is
a going to be a weakness,

104
00:05:07.640 --> 00:05:10.860
typically that's how vulnerabilities
are described their weaknesses.

105
00:05:10.860 --> 00:05:12.350
A weakness in the system.

106
00:05:12.350 --> 00:05:15.510
It could be because of
a misconfiguration as we said.

107
00:05:15.510 --> 00:05:18.730
It could be because of some
sort of unknown bug or

108
00:05:18.730 --> 00:05:23.780
some sort of unknown concern in
the software, in the code of the system.

109
00:05:23.780 --> 00:05:28.210
And we find that by probing and
people doing things to the system.

110
00:05:28.210 --> 00:05:30.959
We suddenly discover that
there's this hole over here.

111
00:05:30.959 --> 00:05:33.279
And if we execute this
sequence of keystrokes,

112
00:05:33.279 --> 00:05:35.723
then all of a sudden we can
take advantage of that.

113
00:05:35.723 --> 00:05:38.480
And so that vulnerability,
that weakness is discovered, and

114
00:05:38.480 --> 00:05:41.640
somebody or something is gonna
look to take advantage of it.

115
00:05:41.640 --> 00:05:42.930
Whatever that is right?

116
00:05:42.930 --> 00:05:44.460
So that's a vulnerability.

117
00:05:44.460 --> 00:05:48.640
A vulnerability is gonna be
measured in terms of severity.

118
00:05:48.640 --> 00:05:51.080
Is it a vulnerability
that is catastrophic,

119
00:05:51.080 --> 00:05:54.020
something that if it's executed on and
somebody takes advantage of,

120
00:05:54.020 --> 00:05:56.340
will just immediately
take down our system?

121
00:05:56.340 --> 00:05:57.688
Is it something that's minor?

122
00:05:57.688 --> 00:06:00.014
It's gonna be nuisance,
we don't want it to happen, but

123
00:06:00.014 --> 00:06:01.420
if it does we can live with it.

124
00:06:01.420 --> 00:06:03.206
We can deal with it relatively easily.

125
00:06:03.206 --> 00:06:07.228
Vulnerabilities have effectively
a scale associated with them for

126
00:06:07.228 --> 00:06:10.520
us to measure how impactful
they're going to be.

127
00:06:10.520 --> 00:06:13.780
This is going to be vulnerability causing,
as we look to the right and

128
00:06:13.780 --> 00:06:17.460
the arrow moves over, with some
sort of degree of adverse impact.

129
00:06:17.460 --> 00:06:19.570
How impactful is the vulnerability?

130
00:06:19.570 --> 00:06:21.510
Again, is it a high level vulnerability,

131
00:06:21.510 --> 00:06:23.702
what we would call
a critical vulnerability?

132
00:06:23.702 --> 00:06:24.970
Is it Is it a medium level?

133
00:06:24.970 --> 00:06:28.350
It is gonna be important but not severe.

134
00:06:28.350 --> 00:06:29.920
Is it a low level vulnerability?

135
00:06:29.920 --> 00:06:32.120
One that we can live with,
and if there is an exploit,

136
00:06:32.120 --> 00:06:34.130
we're not gonna necessarily have an issue,
right?

137
00:06:34.130 --> 00:06:36.240
Or at least not one that
we can't recover easily.

138
00:06:36.240 --> 00:06:37.656
So we wanna make sure we're aware of that.

139
00:06:37.656 --> 00:06:39.687
Adverse impact, in other words,

140
00:06:39.687 --> 00:06:43.900
is gonna measure what that vulnerability
means to us if it is realized.

141
00:06:43.900 --> 00:06:47.050
Somebody's able to execute some
kind of attack against that

142
00:06:47.050 --> 00:06:49.010
weakness that we have uncovered.

143
00:06:49.010 --> 00:06:53.640
And then based on that, adverse impact
produces, arrow going down on the right

144
00:06:53.640 --> 00:06:58.090
hand side, towards the lower right-hand
of the diagram, organizational risk.

145
00:06:58.090 --> 00:07:03.079
Organizational risk, or generically
just risk, is going to be the idea, or

146
00:07:03.079 --> 00:07:07.839
from our perspective, is going to be
the probability or the likelihood,

147
00:07:07.839 --> 00:07:08.946
as we often say.

148
00:07:08.946 --> 00:07:11.496
That a given threat source,
a given threat actor,

149
00:07:11.496 --> 00:07:13.950
will exercise a particular vulnerability.

150
00:07:13.950 --> 00:07:19.020
Will be able to through threat events,
exploit some sort of weakness, and

151
00:07:19.020 --> 00:07:20.890
the resulting impact that will occur.

152
00:07:20.890 --> 00:07:22.450
That is what risk is.

153
00:07:22.450 --> 00:07:26.323
So it's the distillation down of
a threat source taking on actions or

154
00:07:26.323 --> 00:07:30.131
activities, or engaging in actions and

You've got seven different
control types listed on the list.

28
00:01:23.397 --> 00:01:29.022
We've got different control elements or if
you wanna think of them as not categories,

29
00:01:29.022 --> 00:01:32.258
but different ways in which
controls can be used or

30
00:01:32.258 --> 00:01:36.898
different types of controls that we
can see inside of an organization.

31
00:01:36.898 --> 00:01:39.689
So when we think about them,
we have in no particular order.

32
00:01:39.689 --> 00:01:43.102
Again, these are not a numbered list,
just a list that we put together.

33
00:01:43.102 --> 00:01:46.500
Directive, deterrent,
preventive, compensating,

34
00:01:46.500 --> 00:01:50.404
detective as opposed to directive,
corrective and a recovery.

35
00:01:50.404 --> 00:01:52.849
So let's start with
a compensating control,

36
00:01:52.849 --> 00:01:55.430
just randomly jumping in
the middle of the list.

37
00:01:55.430 --> 00:01:58.480
Let's just talk about an example
of the compensating control.

38
00:01:58.480 --> 00:02:03.173
A compensating control is a control
that is designed to be in place, so

39
00:02:03.173 --> 00:02:05.321
that if another control fails,

40
00:02:05.321 --> 00:02:10.026
that control picks up the slack in
effect and will offset the failure.

41
00:02:10.026 --> 00:02:15.923
So for instance, we have anti-lock
braking technology on cars today.

42
00:02:15.923 --> 00:02:18.294
Most cars, almost without exception today,

43
00:02:18.294 --> 00:02:22.320
come with anti-lock brakes standard as
part of just a normal way you buy a car.

44
00:02:22.320 --> 00:02:27.150
But in addition to anti-locking brakes,
which are power assisted.

45
00:02:27.150 --> 00:02:28.131
If the brakes for

46
00:02:28.131 --> 00:02:31.921
some reason are augmented with
an additional security system,

47
00:02:31.921 --> 00:02:36.976
some of the newer cars have anti-collision
technology that will sense that there's

48
00:02:36.976 --> 00:02:41.396
somebody in front of you or somebody
that's stopping and comes to a stop and

49
00:02:41.396 --> 00:02:46.189
will brake the car for you even though you
may not be able to brake quickly enough.

50
00:02:46.189 --> 00:02:49.413
And it will use the anti-lock
braking technology to be able to

51
00:02:49.413 --> 00:02:51.961
avoid the car skidding out or
sliding sideways.

52
00:02:51.961 --> 00:02:54.283
It's really what anti-lock
braking technology does.

53
00:02:54.283 --> 00:02:56.837
It applies brake pressure
in kind of an up and

54
00:02:56.837 --> 00:03:00.426
down motion to pump the brakes
to prevent you from basically,

55
00:03:00.426 --> 00:03:05.068
hard mashing the brakes or coming down on
them hard, so that the cars skids out.

56
00:03:05.068 --> 00:03:06.774
Or effect, moves sideways.

57
00:03:06.774 --> 00:03:10.633
As a result of that, if the anti-lock
braking system were to fail,

58
00:03:10.633 --> 00:03:13.286
the anti-collision technology takes over.

59
00:03:13.286 --> 00:03:15.212
And actually, it's a compensating control.

60
00:03:15.212 --> 00:03:17.369
So it brings the car to a stop,
but does so

61
00:03:17.369 --> 00:03:22.060
perhaps not in as graceful a way as
the anti-locking braking technology would.

62
00:03:22.060 --> 00:03:26.219
We can see the idea of a compensated
control working in IT the same way.

63
00:03:26.219 --> 00:03:30.119
Did we just deploy a firewall, for
instance, when we think about controls?

64
00:03:30.119 --> 00:03:34.230
We tend to deploy a firewall as
a mechanism of control that will prevent

65
00:03:34.230 --> 00:03:39.039
inbound attacks from occurring, but we
also tend to then prevent attacks by using

66
00:03:39.039 --> 00:03:43.796
another system, either intrusion
detection or intrusion prevention system.

67
00:03:43.796 --> 00:03:48.291
Or today, one is that a combination
an IDPS system kind of a next generation,

68
00:03:48.291 --> 00:03:50.446
which involves both technologies.

69
00:03:50.446 --> 00:03:54.329
Intrusion detection is gonna be
passive technology, it monitors and

70
00:03:54.329 --> 00:03:57.366
alerts us, but
doesn't take an retaliatory action.

71
00:03:57.366 --> 00:04:00.896
Intrusion prevention systems are active,
they monitor the alert.

72
00:04:00.896 --> 00:04:05.922
But they also can go out and reconfigure
a pathway, they can shut down a port.

73
00:04:05.922 --> 00:04:08.847
They can change an IP address,
they can do all sorts of other things.

74
00:04:08.847 --> 00:04:13.902
So as compensating controls by
lining up both firewalls and

75
00:04:13.902 --> 00:04:16.637
IDS or IPS systems side by side.

76
00:04:16.637 --> 00:04:19.818
If one were to fail, the other in
theory could take up the slack.

77
00:04:19.818 --> 00:04:22.650
And therefore, hopefully,
still prevent the attack from occurring.

78
00:04:22.650 --> 00:04:24.787
So this is one example of a control type.

79
00:04:24.787 --> 00:04:27.689
A directive control is a policy control.

80
00:04:27.689 --> 00:04:31.208
Some sort of a control that says, hey,
go do this and do it this way for

81
00:04:31.208 --> 00:04:32.077
these reasons.

82
00:04:32.077 --> 00:04:33.889
That's what a directive control would be.

83
00:04:33.889 --> 00:04:35.036
So if a policy says,

84
00:04:35.036 --> 00:04:39.764
we only allow external access remotely
inbound from outside through a VPN tunnel,

85
00:04:39.764 --> 00:04:44.492
then a directive control would implement
or would indicate that you must implement

86
00:04:44.492 --> 00:04:48.028
a VPN tunnel in order to be able
to access the system securely.

87
00:04:48.028 --> 00:04:50.247
It's an example of a directive control.

88
00:04:50.247 --> 00:04:53.707
A deterrent control,
something that is supposed to not prevent,

89
00:04:53.707 --> 00:04:56.260
because we do talk about
preventative control.

90
00:04:56.260 --> 00:05:00.520
These are small differences between
the two, but very important and subtle.

91
00:05:00.520 --> 00:05:03.373
A deterrence control is
something that should deter.

92
00:05:03.373 --> 00:05:06.019
You could say that well,
is it deterrence like prevention?

93
00:05:06.019 --> 00:05:08.574
And yes, we're splitting
hairs cuz it is very similar.

94
00:05:08.574 --> 00:05:09.888
But if wanna deter you,

95
00:05:09.888 --> 00:05:13.119
I'm going to encourage you
strongly not to do something.

96
00:05:13.119 --> 00:05:14.743
And hopefully, you will get the message.

97
00:05:14.743 --> 00:05:19.030
If you don't get the message, I'm gonna
pull out the big guns and prevent you.

98
00:05:19.030 --> 00:05:22.433
So deterrence may be putting up
a sign that says, hey, smile,

99
00:05:22.433 --> 00:05:25.336
you're on camera,
because we're monitoring you.

100
00:05:25.336 --> 00:05:29.435
That would be a deterrence or
some sort of a deterrent control.

101
00:05:29.435 --> 00:05:32.648
A preventative control
would actually be having

102
00:05:32.648 --> 00:05:37.503
the camera in plain view using with or
along with the sign in combination,

103
00:05:37.503 --> 00:05:42.778
because the preventative control may act
to prevent you from doing something.

104
00:05:42.778 --> 00:05:47.121
If you know there's a camera there staring
you in the face, you're a lot less likely,

105
00:05:47.121 --> 00:05:50.572
potentially anyway, a lot less likely
to engage in some sort of bad or

106
00:05:50.572 --> 00:05:51.787
suspicious behavior.

107
00:05:51.787 --> 00:05:54.473
It could also be that maybe
we put a lock on something,

108
00:05:54.473 --> 00:05:57.519
physically locking it down so
you can't walk away with it and

109
00:05:57.519 --> 00:06:00.285
the preventative control
would be the use of the lock.

110
00:06:00.285 --> 00:06:03.903
Whereas a deterrent control may be,
you could actually think of the camera

111
00:06:03.903 --> 00:06:06.265
potentially being
a deterrent control as well.

112
00:06:06.265 --> 00:06:10.107
Some people think well, isn't the camera
a deterrent preventative measure?

113
00:06:10.107 --> 00:06:12.405
Absolutely, you could
categorize it either way.

114
00:06:12.405 --> 00:06:16.044
But the point is you wanna make the
difference clear, make it apparent that

115
00:06:16.044 --> 00:06:19.882
deterrent controls and preventative
controls have different focal points.

116
00:06:19.882 --> 00:06:21.682
We've talked about

117
00:06:21.682 --> 00:06:23.202

119
00:06:27.462 --> 00:06:31.515
An IDS is a detective control,
it finds suspicious behavior and

120
00:06:31.515 --> 00:06:32.872
will then alert you.

121
00:06:32.872 --> 00:06:36.806
A corrective control could be something
that is done when we find suspicious

122
00:06:36.806 --> 00:06:37.424
behavior.

123
00:06:37.424 --> 00:06:40.279
So, an IPS may be an example
of a corrective control,

124
00:06:40.279 --> 00:06:44.088
one that will effectively take action
to correct some sort of attack and

125
00:06:44.088 --> 00:06:46.512
prevent it, ultimately, from occurring.

126
00:06:46.512 --> 00:06:49.567
Could be classified in different
ways in different areas.

127
00:06:49.567 --> 00:06:53.328
A recovery control is something
that we implement to fix a problem.

128
00:06:53.328 --> 00:06:56.163
If we can run a script that
will restore function,

129
00:06:56.163 --> 00:07:00.363
that can be seen as a recovery control or
at least one element of it anyway.

130
00:07:00.363 --> 00:07:04.670

specify what the control types are.

00:32:16.850 --> 00:32:21.350
I'm probably given access to certain
information about the structure

718
00:32:21.350 --> 00:32:22.360
of the network.

719
00:32:22.360 --> 00:32:23.640
I may be told there's a DMZ.

720
00:32:23.640 --> 00:32:27.780
I may be told there's certain systems
running in certain places, but

721
00:32:27.780 --> 00:32:29.300
I'm not gonna be given full access.

722
00:32:29.300 --> 00:32:32.190
I'm not gonna be given passwords and
user names to everything.

723
00:32:32.190 --> 00:32:33.590
Maybe only certain systems, but

724
00:32:33.590 --> 00:32:37.470
I'm not gonna be given a total,
basically all-access pass.

725
00:32:37.470 --> 00:32:39.410
Whereas in full knowledge,
I'm given everything.

726
00:32:39.410 --> 00:32:40.980
I'm on the inside.

727
00:32:40.980 --> 00:32:42.660
I'm running from inside the network, so

728
00:32:42.660 --> 00:32:47.520
I'm probably sitting in the on the lan
in the network operation center.

729
00:32:47.520 --> 00:32:50.980
I'm fully connected internally
behind all the security perimeters,

730
00:32:50.980 --> 00:32:53.910
I have all the user names and
passwords with full admin access, and

731
00:32:53.910 --> 00:32:58.120
I'm in there hacking away, probing to see
what I can find, and specifically what I'm

732
00:32:58.120 --> 00:33:01.380
looking for are what are the unknown
weaknesses or vulnerabilities

733
00:33:01.380 --> 00:33:05.130
that an attacker if they gain access
may compromise and take advantage of.

734
00:33:05.130 --> 00:33:07.580
That's really what we're gonna look for
with full knowledge.

735
00:33:07.580 --> 00:33:09.640
Zero and partial knowledge looks for
that, but

736
00:33:09.640 --> 00:33:12.540
it's not as thorough because I'm
not gonna be on the inside and

737
00:33:12.540 --> 00:33:15.480
I'm not gonna have as much access so
i may not find as many things.

738
00:33:15.480 --> 00:33:16.460
>> Very good.

739
00:33:16.460 --> 00:33:20.620
All right, well Adam a lot of great
information there on doing our penetration

740
00:33:20.620 --> 00:33:22.810
test and methodologies, if I can say that.

741
00:33:22.810 --> 00:33:23.410
>> It's a hard word.

742
00:33:23.410 --> 00:33:24.660
>> It is.
It's tricky.

743
00:33:24.660 --> 00:33:26.130
And those control types right.

744
00:33:26.130 --> 00:33:30.162
Learning the different types of control
and the general categories that we can put

745
00:33:30.162 --> 00:33:32.910
them in so we know what to
expect out of those controls and

746
00:33:32.910 --> 00:33:36.359
we talked a little bit again more
about layering those controls to make

747
00:33:36.359 --> 00:33:38.650
sure we're relying on
one individual thing.

748
00:33:38.650 --> 00:33:41.290
So, fantastic information
we appreciate that Adam.

749
00:33:41.290 --> 00:33:43.510
We are out of time for
this particular episode, so

750
00:33:43.510 --> 00:33:44.890
we're gonna go ahead and sign off.

751
00:33:44.890 --> 00:33:49.100
But before I do, let me remind you, if you
want to attend one of Adam's classes live,

752
00:33:49.100 --> 00:33:53.450
make sure you drop us
a line at SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

753
00:33:53.450 --> 00:33:55.610
For now, signing off, I'm Mike Rodrick.

754
00:33:55.610 --> 00:33:56.587
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

755
00:33:56.587 --> 00:33:57.841
>> And we'll see you next time.

756
00:33:57.841 --> 00:33:59.886
>> Take care everybody.

757
00:33:59.886 --> 00:34:05.650
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike discuss understanding and applying threat modeling. They break down the penetration testing methodology. They also look at some online resources that can be helpful when it comes to threat modeling.
episodes.title: Threat Modeling
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.080 --> 00:00:15.361
Hello and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITproTV.

3
00:00:15.361 --> 00:00:20.275
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick, and
today we're gonna be doing our CISSP,

4
00:00:20.275 --> 00:00:25.267
specifically we're looking at threat
modeling as well as doing a little bit

5
00:00:25.267 --> 00:00:30.353
of review on our penetration testing
methodology, and who do I have with me?

6
00:00:30.353 --> 00:00:31.188
Mister Adam Gordon.

7
00:00:31.188 --> 00:00:32.746
How's it going Adam?

8
00:00:32.746 --> 00:00:34.541
>> It's going well,
how's everybody doing today?

9
00:00:34.541 --> 00:00:35.561
Hopefully you guys are doing well.

10
00:00:35.561 --> 00:00:38.530
Sorry Mike and I were just sharing
a joke before we got on there.

11
00:00:38.530 --> 00:00:39.317
All right, anyway.

12
00:00:39.317 --> 00:00:42.334
So we're here to talk
a little bit more about risk.

13
00:00:42.334 --> 00:00:44.637
And when we talk about risk,
we talk about pen testing,

14
00:00:44.637 --> 00:00:46.410
talking about how all that stuff works.

15
00:00:46.410 --> 00:00:48.250
We've had some really good
conversations about that,

16
00:00:48.250 --> 00:00:51.770
gonna continue that obviously, but wanted
to remind you, take you back for a minute,

17
00:00:51.770 --> 00:00:53.950
it's always good to look
back before we look ahead.

18
00:00:53.950 --> 00:00:56.900
And we wanna make sure we think about some
of the stuff we've been discussing in that

19
00:00:56.900 --> 00:01:01.690
area, so wanted to quickly remind you of
what vulnerability assessment as well as

20
00:01:01.690 --> 00:01:04.450
penetration testing is, and
make sure we have that in mind.

21
00:01:04.450 --> 00:01:07.350
We're gonna throw a little list up for
you by way of doing that review and

22
00:01:07.350 --> 00:01:10.230
help you to think through
the penetration testing methodology,

23
00:01:10.230 --> 00:01:13.090
and then we'll continue talking
about threats, threat modeling, and

24
00:01:13.090 --> 00:01:15.400
some of the other stuff we're
here to discuss as well.

25
00:01:15.400 --> 00:01:17.770
So when we spoke about
vulnerability assessments and

26
00:01:17.770 --> 00:01:21.640
we spoke about pen testing, if you
remember from our prior episode, and

27
00:01:21.640 --> 00:01:24.750
if you haven't seen it by the way,
it's a killer, right?

28
00:01:24.750 --> 00:01:25.520
It's a cliffhanger.

29
00:01:25.520 --> 00:01:27.850
It's the season end and
it is like awesome.

30
00:01:27.850 --> 00:01:30.010
We don't know if Mike's gonna survive or
not.

31
00:01:30.010 --> 00:01:31.676
Well I gave it away cuz he's here,
so he does survive.

32
00:01:31.676 --> 00:01:34.152
>> [CROSSTALK]
>> But the point is but it was unclear,

33
00:01:34.152 --> 00:01:35.343
we weren't sure.

34
00:01:35.343 --> 00:01:38.140
But what we were talking about there,
all kidding aside, was the following.

35
00:01:38.140 --> 00:01:42.476
We were talking about how you would create
or go through the activities around

36
00:01:42.476 --> 00:01:45.877
a vulnerability assessment as
a prelude to pen testing, and

37
00:01:45.877 --> 00:01:50.080
what kind of pen testing could take place,
external, internal, blind,

38
00:01:50.080 --> 00:01:54.616
double-blind, as well as the types of
knowledge you may have around pen tests,

39
00:01:54.616 --> 00:01:58.528
say zero knowledge, partial knowledge or
full knowledge pen test.

40
00:01:58.528 --> 00:02:01.975
We put all that together, we come up
with a pen testing methodology, and

41
00:02:01.975 --> 00:02:04.445
the methodology's on
the screen in front of you.

42
00:02:04.445 --> 00:02:08.975
This is one of those times when a numbered
sequence list of activities is a trigger

43
00:02:08.975 --> 00:02:12.205
for you to makes some notes, to make
sure you understand things in order.

44
00:02:12.205 --> 00:02:14.885
We have talked a couple of
times in some of our prior

45
00:02:14.885 --> 00:02:18.045
episodes about the fact that when
we do put up a numbered list and

46
00:02:18.045 --> 00:02:20.975
we specify that it is important
to know something in order,

47
00:02:20.975 --> 00:02:24.160
that you should take notice of that and
obviously act accordingly.

48
00:02:24.160 --> 00:02:25.750
So you'll see pen test methodology.

49
00:02:25.750 --> 00:02:27.210
Step one, reconnaissance.

50
00:02:27.210 --> 00:02:29.900
We have to go out and
examine what's going on around us.

51
00:02:29.900 --> 00:02:31.330
We have to probe a little bit.

52
00:02:31.330 --> 00:02:35.950
This is where the ability to be able
to do some requirements gathering,

53
00:02:35.950 --> 00:02:39.850
looking at operating system
fingerprinting, looking at open ports.

54
00:02:39.850 --> 00:02:43.670
Things of that nature may help us
to better understand the nature of

55
00:02:43.670 --> 00:02:44.480
what's there.

56
00:02:44.480 --> 00:02:47.537
Enumeration helps us to do some
of that in step two as well.

57
00:02:47.537 --> 00:02:51.553
But reconnaissance may involve
passively looking at the company.

58
00:02:51.553 --> 00:02:53.812
Can we go out online and
see, for instance,

59
00:02:53.812 --> 00:02:57.630
what is out there on LinkedIn about
people may work for the company?

60
00:02:57.630 --> 00:03:00.640
What's on Facebook,
what kind of activity are they sharing?

61
00:03:00.640 --> 00:03:05.830
Are they tagging themselves in pictures
in locations that may expose information

62
00:03:05.830 --> 00:03:09.390
about the internal workings of the
company, maybe network engineers taking

63
00:03:09.390 --> 00:03:13.360
pictures of themselves in the operating
environment of the data center, and

64
00:03:13.360 --> 00:03:15.840
maybe we could see the racks and
see what kind of equipment they run.

65
00:03:15.840 --> 00:03:18.200
And that could be valuable,
even though you don't think about that,

66
00:03:18.200 --> 00:03:19.330
that could be valuable.

67
00:03:19.330 --> 00:03:20.920
So reconnaissance is about looking for

68
00:03:20.920 --> 00:03:24.612
what's available outside of
the organization, effectively on the web.

69
00:03:24.612 --> 00:03:27.987
We search LinkedIn,
we look at Facebook, we Google.

70
00:03:27.987 --> 00:03:32.380
We try to get, if it's a public trading
company, we try to get a prospectus or

71
00:03:32.380 --> 00:03:36.706
a share listing so we'll get the the
reported information from the last year

72
00:03:36.706 --> 00:03:39.769
financial reporting that
the company went through.

73
00:03:39.769 --> 00:03:41.753
We'll see who the board of directors are,

74
00:03:41.753 --> 00:03:45.615
we'll take a look at the officers of the
company, we'll then go profile them, and

75
00:03:45.615 --> 00:03:47.900
try and find out information about them.

76
00:03:47.900 --> 00:03:48.770
You know what do they do?

77
00:03:48.770 --> 00:03:50.240
What are they responsible for?

78
00:03:50.240 --> 00:03:51.930
What kind of stuff are they involved with?

79
00:03:51.930 --> 00:03:53.470
Can we find out more about them?

80
00:03:53.470 --> 00:03:56.830
It's the kind of thing that can lead
to a lot of interesting information.

81
00:03:56.830 --> 00:04:00.200
If you remember,
sometime in the last year or

82
00:04:00.200 --> 00:04:03.560
so, we've had several spectacular examples

83
00:04:03.560 --> 00:04:07.600
of social engineering that have turned
up some very interesting information.

84
00:04:07.600 --> 00:04:11.380
The directors of some of the intelligence
organizations of the United States

85
00:04:11.380 --> 00:04:15.160
were recently the subject of some of this
activity, and without going into the gory

86
00:04:15.160 --> 00:04:19.490
details, effectively have their email,
their personal email accounts hacked, and

87
00:04:19.490 --> 00:04:23.330
information about them that should not
have been exposed was exposed along with

88
00:04:23.330 --> 00:04:26.170
probably other stuff that we
should not know about, right?

89
00:04:26.170 --> 00:04:29.690
You can think about some of the
information that ever so often leaks out.

90
00:04:29.690 --> 00:04:35.340
Earlier this past year, we had the iCloud,
iPhoto thing that went on,

91
00:04:35.340 --> 00:04:38.960
where a lot of celebrities and
just average, innocent everyday people

92
00:04:38.960 --> 00:04:42.630
that were not as famous had their
photos hacked, and therefore exposed,

93
00:04:42.630 --> 00:04:47.410
online, because iCloud was found not to be
quite as secure as it should have been.

94
00:04:47.410 --> 00:04:49.504
And this was all done through pen testing,
but

95
00:04:49.504 --> 00:04:53.200
obviously bad hackers were looking
into hacking the system actually for

96
00:04:53.200 --> 00:04:55.670
taking on these activities and
carrying them out.

97
00:04:55.670 --> 00:04:56.930
And you know these things happen.

98
00:04:56.930 --> 00:05:00.500
Chase Manhattan or Chase Bank had
a big problem earlier this year,

99
00:05:00.500 --> 00:05:03.370
JP Chase Morgan, or
JP Morgan Chase rather.

100
00:05:03.370 --> 00:05:06.910
JP Morgan Chase had a problem earlier this
year as well where they were the subject

101
00:05:06.910 --> 00:05:08.780
of some pen testing gone awry,

102
00:05:08.780 --> 00:05:13.450
meaning hackers trying to get into
their systems, and as a result had some

103
00:05:13.450 --> 00:05:16.140
information disclosures that
they were not too pleased about.

104
00:05:16.140 --> 00:05:18.450
Lots and lots of companies
are dealing with these issues today.

105
00:05:18.450 --> 00:05:21.550
It is up to us as CISSPs,
the security professionals,

106
00:05:21.550 --> 00:05:26.510
to stand on the border, that form the
first line of defense to be ever vigilant.

107
00:05:26.510 --> 00:05:29.420
We talked often in some of
our prior discussions about

108
00:05:29.420 --> 00:05:32.220
the fact that you have to be better
than those that coming to attack you.

109
00:05:32.220 --> 00:05:36.060
And I made the point that luck is
not the operational methodology

110
00:05:36.060 --> 00:05:37.740
that we want to use to manage risk.

111
00:05:37.740 --> 00:05:40.650
You may be better on any given day,
but the reality is you have to be

112
00:05:40.650 --> 00:05:44.460
better all the time, and that's what
separates us, as security professionals

113
00:05:44.460 --> 00:05:47.250
from amateurs who do this but don't
really understand what they're doing.

114
00:05:47.250 --> 00:05:50.880
You don't get to be this grey without
this much hair on your head, right?

115
00:05:50.880 --> 00:05:53.120
If you're not this good all the time and
know what you're doing and

116
00:05:53.120 --> 00:05:54.680
stress as a result of it, right?

117
00:05:54.680 --> 00:05:55.495
I'm kidding, of course.

118
00:05:55.495 --> 00:05:58.485
You could do this and
obviously be very successful at it

119
00:05:58.485 --> 00:06:00.005
regardless of whether you have
hair on your head or not.

120
00:06:00.005 --> 00:06:01.705
I don't wanna exclude anybody
who doesn't have hair.

121
00:06:01.705 --> 00:06:06.245
But I do wanna make it clear that it is
important for you to practice your skills,

122
00:06:06.245 --> 00:06:09.495
and for you to become good at
something implies hours and

123
00:06:09.495 --> 00:06:13.055
hours of the pursuit of that skill.

124
00:06:13.055 --> 00:06:15.945
Often we would talk about in earlier
times, when I say earlier I mean hundreds

125
00:06:15.945 --> 00:06:19.620
of year ago, we would talk about
the concept of the Renaissance person.

126
00:06:19.620 --> 00:06:23.128
Renaissance man, Renaissance women,
Leonardo Da Vinci for instance,

127
00:06:23.128 --> 00:06:26.170
Michelangelo, were examples for
Renaissance people.

128
00:06:26.170 --> 00:06:29.010
People that were not just good at one
thing, these people are the most famous

129
00:06:29.010 --> 00:06:31.240
artists in the world that
we're talking about, right?

130
00:06:31.240 --> 00:06:35.500
Sir Issac Newton, another great example
of a Reconnaissance individual.

131
00:06:35.500 --> 00:06:39.190
You can think of Albert Einstein as being
somebody in the modern day that fits into

132
00:06:39.190 --> 00:06:40.830
this particular category.

133
00:06:40.830 --> 00:06:44.230
These are people that were good at a lot
of things, not just mastering one thing.

134
00:06:44.230 --> 00:06:47.250
But masters of all they surveyed,
and they ultimately touched and

135
00:06:47.250 --> 00:06:48.640
wanted to learn how to do.

136
00:06:48.640 --> 00:06:51.840
And so the reality is, to get good
at security today, you have to have

137
00:06:51.840 --> 00:06:55.360
that Renaissance mindset, that philosophy
that I have to be good at a lot fo things.

138
00:06:55.360 --> 00:06:57.560
Because if all I'm good
at is just pen testing,

139
00:06:57.560 --> 00:07:00.680
you're gonna be very good at this,
but this is not the only thing we do.

140
00:07:00.680 --> 00:07:02.370
You have to be good at crafting policy.

141
00:07:02.370 --> 00:07:04.310
You have to be good at
vulnerability assessments.

142
00:07:04.310 --> 00:07:07.960
You have to be good at understanding
how to manage a team of individuals.

143
00:07:07.960 --> 00:07:11.480
You have to be good at understanding how
to have a conversation with people in

144
00:07:11.480 --> 00:07:12.800
the C Suite about security and

145
00:07:12.800 --> 00:07:17.010
those needs, and create a budget request
that reflects those and manage change.

146
00:07:17.010 --> 00:07:20.500
And these are all skills that are related
to penetration testing in one form or

147
00:07:20.500 --> 00:07:24.690
another, but are not directly related to
in sense that they flow directly from it.

148
00:07:24.690 --> 00:07:26.680
And if all you're good at is pen testing,

149
00:07:26.680 --> 00:07:29.120
you're going to be what we
call a one trick pony, right?

150
00:07:29.120 --> 00:07:29.940
>> Mm-hm.
>> Which means you're very good

151
00:07:29.940 --> 00:07:30.730
at only one thing.

152
00:07:30.730 --> 00:07:33.810
But unfortunately you're not going to be
very valuable to the organization if we

153
00:07:33.810 --> 00:07:35.610
don't need that particular thing.

154
00:07:35.610 --> 00:07:38.170
And so as much from
the perspective of being able to

155
00:07:38.170 --> 00:07:41.170
really get better at your craft and
ultimately spread the knowledge, but

156
00:07:41.170 --> 00:07:43.900
also become more valuable
to the organization, right?

157
00:07:43.900 --> 00:07:47.600
Self preservation if nothing else,
you want to get good at a lot of things.

158
00:07:47.600 --> 00:07:50.070
But you know, it's hard, I have this
conversation all the time with students.

159
00:07:50.070 --> 00:07:53.193
How do I get better at stuff if nobody
let's me do anything because nobody thinks

160
00:07:53.193 --> 00:07:56.310
I know how to do it, and when I go to do
it they tell no, no, no you can't do that,

161
00:07:56.310 --> 00:07:57.730
you're gonna mess everything up.

162
00:07:57.730 --> 00:08:00.238
It's very hard to learn how
to do these things today.

163
00:08:00.238 --> 00:08:03.463
You don't often get a chance to
go pen test on a live network,

164
00:08:03.463 --> 00:08:04.928
that's just the reality.

165
00:08:04.928 --> 00:08:09.895
If you do, then that is fairly unusual,
let's put it that way.

166
00:08:09.895 --> 00:08:11.560
>> [LAUGH]
>> So you certainly could go and

167
00:08:11.560 --> 00:08:13.460
take classes, and
I'm not trying to dissuade you and

168
00:08:13.460 --> 00:08:15.140
say training is or is not appropriate.

169
00:08:15.140 --> 00:08:17.690
It's a very good way to learn,
or Mike and I wouldn't be

170
00:08:17.690 --> 00:08:20.120
spending all this time trying to
help you figure all this stuff out.

171
00:08:20.120 --> 00:08:22.010
But it's not the only thing,
you've got to go out and

172
00:08:22.010 --> 00:08:24.170
practice those skills by
putting them in to play.

173
00:08:24.170 --> 00:08:27.690
So, in addition to all the stuff we talk
about here, what I would suggest to you,

174
00:08:27.690 --> 00:08:30.740
especially in an area like this
where we talk about some technology,

175
00:08:30.740 --> 00:08:34.990
we talked in one of our prior episodes
about tools like N-Map or ZenMap or

176
00:08:34.990 --> 00:08:39.140
the Metasploit framework and things of
that nature, think of virtualization.

177
00:08:39.140 --> 00:08:41.810
Think of the virtualization
platforms we have today,

178
00:08:41.810 --> 00:08:44.750
think of virtual desktop infrastructure,
virtual machines,

179
00:08:44.750 --> 00:08:48.130
think about the things you can do by
building a small virtual network, and

180
00:08:48.130 --> 00:08:51.900
the kind of skills you can practice and
ultimately hone in those networks until

181
00:08:51.900 --> 00:08:54.760
you get good at them enough that you can
go out and use them in the real world.

182
00:08:54.760 --> 00:08:57.800

So that's also OWASP.

404
00:19:53.430 --> 00:19:57.130
You see OWASP was there, but then there's
also other ones from different vendors.

405
00:19:57.130 --> 00:20:01.010
Things like, Top 10 External and
Internal Vulnerabilities from a company.

406
00:20:01.010 --> 00:20:02.800
From this company,
that company or whatever.

407
00:20:02.800 --> 00:20:04.500
So you can see there's a lot there, but

408
00:20:04.500 --> 00:20:06.936
there's also a lot of other
things we can link to.

409
00:20:06.936 --> 00:20:09.430
So we want to think about the fact
when we think about threats and

410
00:20:09.430 --> 00:20:12.920
vulnerabilities, we
are thinking about a very broad

411
00:20:12.920 --> 00:20:15.910
set of concerns that we may have
as a security professional.

412
00:20:15.910 --> 00:20:17.050
If you don't do anything with the web,

413
00:20:17.050 --> 00:20:19.960
are you really worried about
what OWASP has to say?

414
00:20:19.960 --> 00:20:22.250
It's probably not all
that relevant to you.

415
00:20:22.250 --> 00:20:24.230
But if your company starts
doing web services,

416
00:20:24.230 --> 00:20:26.360
it's going to become really
relevant very quickly.

417
00:20:26.360 --> 00:20:29.950
I had a customer couple years
ago come through one of

418
00:20:29.950 --> 00:20:34.750
my seminars when I was speaking and
I had been talking about the cloud and

419
00:20:34.750 --> 00:20:36.540
security based
vulnerabilities in the cloud.

420
00:20:36.540 --> 00:20:38.000
And after we got done,
she was very polite,

421
00:20:38.000 --> 00:20:39.020
she sat through the whole presentation.

422
00:20:39.020 --> 00:20:40.660
She came up to me afterwards and
talked to me for a little bit.

423
00:20:40.660 --> 00:20:43.410
She said you know this is really
interesting stuff, I'm glad I came,

424
00:20:43.410 --> 00:20:45.130
I learned a lot, it's very valuable.

425
00:20:45.130 --> 00:20:48.950
But my company has no need for
this we're not doing cloud services.

426
00:20:48.950 --> 00:20:50.580
And so
we had a very interesting conversation.

427
00:20:50.580 --> 00:20:53.690
I said that it's interesting that
you're not doing cloud services today.

428
00:20:53.690 --> 00:20:56.320
Not a big deal one way or the other,
but you say you have no need for

429
00:20:56.320 --> 00:20:57.100
what we talked about.

430
00:20:57.100 --> 00:20:58.520
You're not doing cloud.

431
00:20:58.520 --> 00:21:01.470
So we talked a little bit about
the fact that cloud may not

432
00:21:01.470 --> 00:21:03.280
be as obvious as some people think it is.

433
00:21:03.280 --> 00:21:06.320
So I said hey do you
access email by the web?

434
00:21:06.320 --> 00:21:08.320
She said, yeah,
we use a web-based interface,

435
00:21:08.320 --> 00:21:11.470
something like Outlook Web Access or
whatever it is, to access email.

436
00:21:11.470 --> 00:21:13.430
I said great,
do you have any people that access this,

437
00:21:13.430 --> 00:21:17.610
or are accessing information remotely,
from outside the organization?

438
00:21:17.610 --> 00:21:19.720
Remote teleworkers, right, telecommuters.

439
00:21:19.720 --> 00:21:20.860
Yeah, we have some of those.

440
00:21:20.860 --> 00:21:23.540
So I walked her through, so you can
probably see where this is going, right?

441
00:21:23.540 --> 00:21:26.410
She's using the cloud all the time,
she just doesn't realize and

442
00:21:26.410 --> 00:21:30.975
as a result of that, what I showed her,
was that this conversation's incredibly

443
00:21:30.975 --> 00:21:33.370
relevant to her,
even though she doesn't realize it is,

444
00:21:33.370 --> 00:21:37.470
because the definition of cloud is
really what she was struggling with.

445
00:21:37.470 --> 00:21:39.390
Not the fact that she needed to secure it.

446
00:21:39.390 --> 00:21:40.820
She just bypassed the thought process,

447
00:21:40.820 --> 00:21:42.630
because she didn't think she needed to,
but

448
00:21:42.630 --> 00:21:46.950
we pointed out to her that she actually is
using the same technology that she thought

449
00:21:46.950 --> 00:21:49.750
really didn't make sense and as a result
didn't have to pay attention to.

450
00:21:49.750 --> 00:21:53.080
Now I'm not saying she didn't have
security regimes in place to protect email

451
00:21:53.080 --> 00:21:54.580
and things like that, she did.

452
00:21:54.580 --> 00:21:57.320
The leap of faith she had to make
was that thinking about those

453
00:21:57.320 --> 00:22:00.500
technologies in relation to
the threats associated with cloud,

454
00:22:00.500 --> 00:22:03.970
opened her mind up to different ways
of approaching and managing that.

455
00:22:03.970 --> 00:22:06.320
That she wasn't seeing,
wasn't making the connection with,

456
00:22:06.320 --> 00:22:08.580
because she didn't think they
were related to the cloud.

457
00:22:08.580 --> 00:22:11.430
This is one of the things CISSPs do and
do every day.

458
00:22:11.430 --> 00:22:15.880
We make the simple very,
very easily approachable for people.

459
00:22:15.880 --> 00:22:19.020
We make the complex something that
people can have a dialogue about.

460
00:22:19.020 --> 00:22:22.440
It's our job to translate the complex
into something that the company and

461
00:22:22.440 --> 00:22:25.980
the organization can have a dialogue
about, whether it's through identification

462
00:22:25.980 --> 00:22:29.110
threat, whether it's through management
of risk, whether it's through

463
00:22:29.110 --> 00:22:33.400
tangible explanation, quantifiable
in qualitative assessment of risk.

464
00:22:33.400 --> 00:22:36.420
Whether it's through penetration
testing and vulnerability assessment.

465
00:22:36.420 --> 00:22:38.300
And then the reporting
of that information.

466
00:22:38.300 --> 00:22:42.760
If you're not able to do those things
as a security professional today,

467
00:22:42.760 --> 00:22:45.850
it is very unlikely that you are going
to be successful ultimately.

468
00:22:45.850 --> 00:22:49.550
You will become the CISSP, I'm not
suggesting you won't be able to do that.

469
00:22:49.550 --> 00:22:52.390
You'll study hard, and you will most
likely pass and take and therefore,

470
00:22:52.390 --> 00:22:54.460
ultimately, certify out through the exam.

471
00:22:54.460 --> 00:22:57.660
But the really challenge to that is
that how do you then take that and

472
00:22:57.660 --> 00:23:00.320
actually use that everyday,
become better at what you do?

473
00:23:00.320 --> 00:23:03.770
It's hard, don't get me wrong,
it's very hard to pass this exam.

474
00:23:03.770 --> 00:23:05.480
It's 250 questions, right.

475
00:23:05.480 --> 00:23:08.780
It's six hours of sitting in one place,
answering questions.

476
00:23:08.780 --> 00:23:10.250
I don't like to do much of anything for

477
00:23:10.250 --> 00:23:11.400
six hours-
>> [LAUGH]

478
00:23:11.400 --> 00:23:13.150
>> in a row, right, let alone sit and

479
00:23:13.150 --> 00:23:14.150
answer questions.

480
00:23:14.150 --> 00:23:15.500
Now I took the test years ago.

481
00:23:15.500 --> 00:23:18.662
I took it the old school way where it was
a Scantron sheet with the bubble answer

482
00:23:18.662 --> 00:23:21.045
grid, [CROSSTALK] and
you had a number two pencil, right,

483
00:23:21.045 --> 00:23:22.813
just like back in the old
days with school.

484
00:23:22.813 --> 00:23:27.280
And most of you that are listening to
this now are probably not already CISPs.

485
00:23:27.280 --> 00:23:29.306
A piece of the reality is you're going
to go out and try to become one.

486
00:23:29.306 --> 00:23:32.460
So you're going to take the test
now using computer testing,

487
00:23:32.460 --> 00:23:34.700
which is how we've been doing
the exams for several years.

488
00:23:34.700 --> 00:23:36.906
You're still going to answer questions,
but you're going to do it in a point and

489
00:23:36.906 --> 00:23:37.760
click environment.

490
00:23:37.760 --> 00:23:40.580
It's no less fun,
it's very exciting to sit and

491
00:23:40.580 --> 00:23:42.470
answer questions six hours either way.

492
00:23:42.470 --> 00:23:46.960
But my point is listen,while it's very
hard to do this and to become successful

493
00:23:46.960 --> 00:23:51.260
at passing the exam, it is the easiest
of all the challenges in front of you.

494
00:23:51.260 --> 00:23:55.670
Because once you pass that exam, put those
letter after your name, if you apply and

495
00:23:55.670 --> 00:23:59.774
you are given the status of a CISSP,
hopefully one in good standing, right?

496
00:23:59.774 --> 00:24:01.262
Cuz you're gonna subscribe
to the code of ethics.

497
00:24:01.262 --> 00:24:02.580
We know how important that is.

498
00:24:02.580 --> 00:24:04.889
Once you've done that,
the challenge really begins.

499
00:24:04.889 --> 00:24:08.594
Because the hard part is now how do I put
my skills to work for the organization or

500
00:24:08.594 --> 00:24:10.800
whatever you're gonna
do with those skills.

501
00:24:10.800 --> 00:24:13.690
How do I put them to work in
the business or as a consultant for

502
00:24:13.690 --> 00:24:17.620
many businesses to actually make the world
a safer place, to make it more secure?

503
00:24:17.620 --> 00:24:20.760
I don't make light of it, I also
don't spend a lot of time on it, but

504
00:24:20.760 --> 00:24:22.680
this is what CISSPs do.

505
00:24:22.680 --> 00:24:25.580
We are the superheros of
the information security world, right?

506
00:24:25.580 --> 00:24:27.780
Because we make the world
a safer place for

507
00:24:27.780 --> 00:24:30.460
those that we are ultimately
sworn to protect.

508
00:24:30.460 --> 00:24:32.200
It's our job to implement policies.

509
00:24:32.200 --> 00:24:35.000
It's our job to make the systems
that we are accountable for

510
00:24:35.000 --> 00:24:37.140
and ultimately responsible for
more secure.

511
00:24:37.140 --> 00:24:38.550
That's what superheroes do every day.

512
00:24:38.550 --> 00:24:40.520
You don't see me with
my cape on right now.

513
00:24:40.520 --> 00:24:42.370
I took my mask off so you could see me.

514
00:24:42.370 --> 00:24:43.345
But I have it in the back.

515
00:24:43.345 --> 00:24:47.355
Mike was trying it on early before we got
on and he was running around the studio.

516
00:24:47.355 --> 00:24:49.765
We got a blooper reel we may
show you at one point later.

517
00:24:49.765 --> 00:24:52.525
He was trying to fly it
didn't end very well but.

518
00:24:52.525 --> 00:24:56.057
So you know the reality is becoming
a CISSP is the easy part the journey

519
00:24:56.057 --> 00:24:59.827
that you take is not hard by comparison
to the work you do afterwards,

520
00:24:59.827 --> 00:25:01.077
when you become certified.

521
00:25:01.077 --> 00:25:03.947
So think about that as we wrap up
our conversations around threat and

522
00:25:03.947 --> 00:25:05.857
threat management, and
identification of threat.

523
00:25:05.857 --> 00:25:10.297
Because this is really ultimately what
you're signing on to do, manage risk,

524
00:25:10.297 --> 00:25:11.680
identify threats.

525
00:25:11.680 --> 00:25:14.800
Engage in that dialogue at the corporate
level inside the organization

526
00:25:14.800 --> 00:25:15.790
day in and day out.

527
00:25:15.790 --> 00:25:17.030
Relentlessly.

528
00:25:17.030 --> 00:25:18.070
Relentlessly.

529
00:25:18.070 --> 00:25:18.620
Right?

530
00:25:18.620 --> 00:25:21.540
Go through those activities and
figure out how to make everything better.

531
00:25:21.540 --> 00:25:24.230
And there are gonna be days when
you wake up, go to work, and

532
00:25:24.230 --> 00:25:25.500
nothing works the right way.

533
00:25:25.500 --> 00:25:26.460
Right?
It's a bad day.

534
00:25:26.460 --> 00:25:27.690
Those are usually Mondays, by the way.

535
00:25:27.690 --> 00:25:30.170
So if you skip Mondays,
Tuesdays are typically better.

536
00:25:30.170 --> 00:25:31.550
Right?
So if you go in and

537
00:25:31.550 --> 00:25:33.660
nothing is working the right way,
you've had a problem and

538
00:25:33.660 --> 00:25:35.410
it's just getting worse by the day?

539
00:25:35.410 --> 00:25:38.180
Those are days you dread, but listen,
every organization in the world,

540
00:25:38.180 --> 00:25:40.490
every business, every job has those days.

541
00:25:40.490 --> 00:25:43.295
They're not unique to us, it's just
that we get to play with really cool,

542
00:25:43.295 --> 00:25:46.265
high-priced technology, which makes
them more exciting ultimately, right?

543
00:25:46.265 --> 00:25:47.060
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, so

544
00:25:47.060 --> 00:25:49.540
we're going to wrap up
this particular episode.

545
00:25:49.540 --> 00:25:52.290
And we're gonna come back and
talk about some cool and exciting things.

546
00:25:52.290 --> 00:25:55.140
Please remember the five step
methodology for pen testing.

547
00:25:55.140 --> 00:25:58.790
Please remember the definitions of all
the terminology we share with you,

548
00:25:58.790 --> 00:26:00.870
whether it's threat event, threat source.

549
00:26:00.870 --> 00:26:02.190
Whether it is vulnerability,

550
00:26:02.190 --> 00:26:06.700
whether it is the types of knowledge
we need to engage in a pen test, right?

551
00:26:06.700 --> 00:26:08.460
There are three,
you should know what they are.

552
00:26:08.460 --> 00:26:12.400
Whether it is the different kinds of
penetration testing, there are four types.

553
00:26:12.400 --> 00:26:13.500
Know what they are.

554
00:26:13.500 --> 00:26:14.920
Right?
Make sure you know all that stuff.

555
00:26:14.920 --> 00:26:17.770
Remember, we talked about mile wide,
inch deep.

556
00:26:17.770 --> 00:26:21.180
Mile wide and inch deep is
the mantra of the CISSP candidate.

557
00:26:21.180 --> 00:26:24.870
It's something if you can say over and
over again, ultimately get it into your

558
00:26:24.870 --> 00:26:28.209
head as you're studying, you'll be
success at taking and passing this exam.

559
00:26:29.290 --> 00:26:32.995
>> Very good Adam we appreciate it a lot
of great information there learning that

560
00:26:32.995 --> 00:26:35.845
threat modeling and
that penetration test methodology and

561
00:26:35.845 --> 00:26:38.470
a couple great resources
that he pointed out, right?

562
00:26:38.470 --> 00:26:42.840
Using those niche special publications and
OSP's top ten list.

563
00:26:42.840 --> 00:26:47.400
Stuff that we can use as we're
preparing to get certified as CISSP.

564
00:26:47.400 --> 00:26:50.526
We thank you for that Adam and we
appreciate everybody out there watching.

565
00:26:50.526 --> 00:26:54.555
Remember if you want to attend
one of Adam's classes live,

566
00:26:54.555 --> 00:26:57.408
drop us an email at SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

567
00:26:57.408 --> 00:27:01.360
That's gonna do it for now,
signing off, I'm Mike Roderick.

568
00:27:01.360 --> 00:27:02.510
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

569
00:27:02.510 --> 00:27:03.820
>> And we'll see you next time.

570
00:27:03.820 --> 00:27:04.522
>> Take care everybody.

571
00:27:04.522 --> 00:27:09.802
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike talk about integrating risk assessment into acquisition strategies, like hardware purchases as well as outsourcing. They talk about the importance of auditing vendors and having service level agreements. They also talk about best practices for information security education, training and awareness.
episodes.title: Acquisition Risk Strategy
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.465 --> 00:00:15.341
Hello and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.341 --> 00:00:20.270
I'm your host Mike Rodrick,
today we're doing our CISSP and

4
00:00:20.270 --> 00:00:24.530
specifically we're gonna be going
into risk acquisition strategy.

5
00:00:24.530 --> 00:00:27.590
All right, we've gotta think about
what happens when our network,

6
00:00:27.590 --> 00:00:29.380
our organization, starts to grow.

7
00:00:29.380 --> 00:00:31.440
We start bringing in new hardware.

8
00:00:31.440 --> 00:00:35.580
Where do we get that from, what are the
security risks associated with that?

9
00:00:35.580 --> 00:00:40.400
We start outsourcing to third party
providers, what do we have to think about?

10
00:00:40.400 --> 00:00:43.070
And here to help with all of that is Mr.
Adam Gordon.

11
00:00:43.070 --> 00:00:43.920
How's it going, Adam?

12
00:00:43.920 --> 00:00:46.360
>> Good, how is everybody doing today?

13
00:00:46.360 --> 00:00:48.980
Hopefully it's a good
weather day where you are.

14
00:00:48.980 --> 00:00:52.770
>> Yeah, not so much-
>> Not so much for us, but that's okay.

15
00:00:52.770 --> 00:00:56.630
All right, so it's good to talk about risk
and we've talked a lot about risk and

16
00:00:56.630 --> 00:00:57.340
it's good, obviously,

17
00:00:57.340 --> 00:01:00.560
to be aware of risk in many different
areas for many different reasons, right?

18
00:01:00.560 --> 00:01:04.250
So when we think about risk and
we think about acquisition and

19
00:01:04.250 --> 00:01:07.000
acquisition strategy and
how we manage risk in the supply chain,

20
00:01:07.000 --> 00:01:08.900
what we wanna do is actually step back for
a minute.

21
00:01:08.900 --> 00:01:13.220
And what we wanna really think about
first is what are the potential vectors,

22
00:01:13.220 --> 00:01:15.870
the potential places where risk
may come into the organization?

23
00:01:15.870 --> 00:01:20.180
We talked a lot about threat sources,
threat actors, bad actors.

24
00:01:20.180 --> 00:01:24.130
People, services, malware,
things that are looking to do us harm.

25
00:01:24.130 --> 00:01:28.670
We know from our prior episode
conversations about risk that this is one

26
00:01:28.670 --> 00:01:32.950
of the places, probably the primary place,
where we focus on the impact of risk

27
00:01:32.950 --> 00:01:36.830
because we think about threat sources,
leading to threat events, threat events

28
00:01:36.830 --> 00:01:40.900
ultimately lead to the likelihood that a
vulnerability will become exploited, which

29
00:01:40.900 --> 00:01:45.170
eventually, depending on what happens and
how we deal with that through mitigation,

30
00:01:45.170 --> 00:01:49.550
acceptance, transference, and/or avoidance
of risk, may lead to organizational risk,

31
00:01:49.550 --> 00:01:53.130
and we have to then measure, quantify,
what that risk may look like from

32
00:01:53.130 --> 00:01:55.960
an impact perspective, and
we have to think about qualitatively

33
00:01:55.960 --> 00:01:59.850
measuring what the impact of that risk
is in a soft, as opposed to a hard, way.

34
00:01:59.850 --> 00:02:01.240
So we've talked about all this already.

35
00:02:01.240 --> 00:02:04.880
Well, we haven't really linked to this
conversation is what some of the potential

36
00:02:04.880 --> 00:02:08.590
attacks, the places where we actually
see this happening can occur from.

37
00:02:08.590 --> 00:02:12.630
And I think a great way to start talking
about acquisition strategies is by looking

38
00:02:12.630 --> 00:02:17.220
at places where we may fall prey to or
be subject to attack and be aware of those

39
00:02:17.220 --> 00:02:20.520
helps us to frame the conversation about
what we look to do when we protect not

40
00:02:20.520 --> 00:02:25.440
only the supply chain but protect the
information of the systems that come to us

41
00:02:25.440 --> 00:02:29.160
through that outsourcing or
reciprocal arrangement when we contract.

42
00:02:29.160 --> 00:02:31.980
So if we step back and
think about things like social engineering

43
00:02:31.980 --> 00:02:34.580
as an attack vector,
what does that mean to us?

44
00:02:34.580 --> 00:02:38.040
It means typically that people that
are gonna have information in our

45
00:02:38.040 --> 00:02:39.780
organizations may be targeted, all right.

46
00:02:39.780 --> 00:02:44.140
Somebody may walk up to them and try to
ask them questions, seemingly innocently.

47
00:02:44.140 --> 00:02:46.280
Hey, I see you've got an ITProTV shirt on.

48
00:02:46.280 --> 00:02:48.810
I'd point to mine but
I don't have one on today, right.

49
00:02:48.810 --> 00:02:51.730
But an ITProTV shirt and
that must mean you work for them,

50
00:02:51.730 --> 00:02:52.690
that's a really cool company.

51
00:02:52.690 --> 00:02:55.060
I've heard a little about them, but
I'm not really sure what you do.

52
00:02:55.060 --> 00:02:57.930
Can you tell me a little
about what ITProTV does?

53
00:02:57.930 --> 00:03:00.450
That's a pretty seemingly
innocent conversation.

54
00:03:00.450 --> 00:03:03.979
The reality is if I'm trying to get
information out of you about not just what

55
00:03:03.979 --> 00:03:07.510
it is but more importantly I work into
