They're just internal-facing SLAs,
they effectively are the same thing for

508
00:24:52.280 --> 00:24:53.820
the purposes of our discussion.

509
00:24:53.820 --> 00:24:54.560
Just be aware of them.

510
00:24:54.560 --> 00:24:55.820
Understand what they are.

511
00:24:55.820 --> 00:24:59.220
They help us to typically stipulate what
minimum acceptable requirements are.

512
00:24:59.220 --> 00:25:02.860
Both from a performance and
in some cases from a security perspective,

513
00:25:02.860 --> 00:25:05.810
and identifying minimum
requirements is very important.

514
00:25:05.810 --> 00:25:09.920
We've talked about requirements gathering,
and how this works as well.

515
00:25:09.920 --> 00:25:12.030
We spent several minutes
in at least one or

516
00:25:12.030 --> 00:25:15.820
two of our prior discussions in other
episodes, detailing through and

517
00:25:15.820 --> 00:25:18.950
walking through the process of how
you would do requirements gathering.

518
00:25:18.950 --> 00:25:21.970
So making sure we understand how
to do requirements gathering,

519
00:25:21.970 --> 00:25:25.470
reminding you of that here in this area,
is also a good thought process for

520
00:25:25.470 --> 00:25:27.130
us to be thinking through.

521
00:25:27.130 --> 00:25:30.810
We want to also make sure that we're
thinking about how we're gonna report out

522
00:25:30.810 --> 00:25:32.060
on the levels of service, and

523
00:25:32.060 --> 00:25:34.130
the management of service
that we're providing.

524
00:25:34.130 --> 00:25:37.420
We've talked a lot about the value of
reporting and communicating findings.

525
00:25:37.420 --> 00:25:40.660
Service level reporting around
the implementation of the SLA.

526
00:25:40.660 --> 00:25:44.420
The management of risk, the current
state of risk becomes important

527
00:25:44.420 --> 00:25:47.520
as part of the overall function
that we're thinking about as well.

528
00:25:47.520 --> 00:25:49.660
And we wanna wrap this
all up in a pretty bow.

529
00:25:49.660 --> 00:25:51.892
Right?
And really put it together in a way that's

530
00:25:51.892 --> 00:25:54.397
gonna present it,
not just to the organization, but

531
00:25:54.397 --> 00:25:57.682
present it to each individual in
the organization or in the business,

532
00:25:57.682 --> 00:25:59.310
in a meaningful and personal way.

533
00:25:59.310 --> 00:26:02.740
And this is where security awareness
training comes back into the conversation.

534
00:26:02.740 --> 00:26:05.210
When we've been thinking about
security awareness training,

535
00:26:05.210 --> 00:26:08.440
we've really couched that conversation
when we've had it with you in terms of,

536
00:26:08.440 --> 00:26:10.780
hey, these are good things
to tell people about.

537
00:26:10.780 --> 00:26:12.440
Make sure they're relevant to their job.

538
00:26:12.440 --> 00:26:15.640
Make sure they understand how
to engage in that activity.

539
00:26:15.640 --> 00:26:16.890
All that's important.

540
00:26:16.890 --> 00:26:19.380
But the most important
thing we need to do,

541
00:26:19.380 --> 00:26:21.900
is to figure out what are the messages,

542
00:26:21.900 --> 00:26:25.610
the things we have to tell the individual
users in the business by job role,

543
00:26:25.610 --> 00:26:29.990
by area, by function, and then train
down on them to make them aware of them.

544
00:26:29.990 --> 00:26:31.760
But this is one thing we
have to kinda agree on.

545
00:26:31.760 --> 00:26:34.110
You're just gonna have
to trust me on this.

546
00:26:34.110 --> 00:26:37.700
Because I've done this with so
many cycles, with so many businesses over

547
00:26:37.700 --> 00:26:41.160
the years, I could tell you from first
hand experience, this is how it works.

548
00:26:41.160 --> 00:26:43.840
If you don't do this on a rolling basis,

549
00:26:43.840 --> 00:26:47.120
in other words if all you do is security
awareness training once a year.

550
00:26:47.120 --> 00:26:51.390
And it becomes an afterthought for most
people that they have to check off the box

551
00:26:51.390 --> 00:26:55.550
proverbially or literally, by reading
through some material, looking at a video,

552
00:26:55.550 --> 00:26:58.760
answering some questions,
it's like an HR function in effect.

553
00:26:58.760 --> 00:27:02.650
If that's how you couch it for
individuals, it's not very meaningful.

554
00:27:02.650 --> 00:27:05.950
Oh, that's that whole thing I gotta
do before the end of the year,

555
00:27:05.950 --> 00:27:06.890
I gotta get that done.

556
00:27:06.890 --> 00:27:09.130
And then everybody celebrates, says yay,

557
00:27:09.130 --> 00:27:12.680
we got 95 or 98%, almost everybody
in the company went through it.

558
00:27:12.680 --> 00:27:15.230
Awesome, we're good for another year.

559
00:27:15.230 --> 00:27:16.330
No, you're really not.

560
00:27:16.330 --> 00:27:19.500
All you've done is effectively wasted
a half hour of everybody's time in

561
00:27:19.500 --> 00:27:22.260
the organization, because you haven't
really made an impact on them.

562
00:27:22.260 --> 00:27:23.480
It's not meaningful,

563
00:27:23.480 --> 00:27:27.630
it's not relevant, it's not timely and
it's not helping them do their job better.

564
00:27:27.630 --> 00:27:28.880
It's something they don't look forward to.

565
00:27:28.880 --> 00:27:30.640
It's something they don't take seriously.

566
00:27:30.640 --> 00:27:34.990
And the context in the meaning in
the organization is just very irrelevant.

567
00:27:34.990 --> 00:27:36.820
It just doesn't really
register with people.

568
00:27:36.820 --> 00:27:40.650
If you make security awareness training
something that happens on a regular basis,

569
00:27:40.650 --> 00:27:42.950
continuously in the organization.

570
00:27:42.950 --> 00:27:46.900
Repurposing and refocusing people's
thought process around security,

571
00:27:46.900 --> 00:27:51.150
around risk management, around engagement
throughout the course of the year.

572
00:27:51.150 --> 00:27:54.520
Engagement around themed activities or
themed messages.

573
00:27:54.520 --> 00:27:57.720
There's a million ways to do this,
I'm not suggesting become a party planner.

574
00:27:57.720 --> 00:27:59.900
I'm just pointing out that ultimately,

575
00:27:59.900 --> 00:28:03.370
security awareness training is more than
a simple half hour video once a year.

576
00:28:03.370 --> 00:28:05.560
If you want it to be meaningful
to your constituents,

577
00:28:05.560 --> 00:28:10.650
people you are charged with managing
security on behalf of, and as a CISSP.

578
00:28:10.650 --> 00:28:13.860
We have to create policies to
manage security awareness training,

579
00:28:13.860 --> 00:28:16.010
we have to create procedures
to implement it, and

580
00:28:16.010 --> 00:28:20.340
then we have to manage it throughout the
course of the year in the organization.

581
00:28:20.340 --> 00:28:23.670
Do more in other words than just make
it a simple half hour moment in time.

582
00:28:23.670 --> 00:28:26.160
That's a check box and
it becomes very relevant

583
00:28:26.160 --> 00:28:28.520
to those people that your trying
to reach out and engage with.

584
00:28:28.520 --> 00:28:32.615
And as a result, they become much more
effective at helping you to manage risk.

585
00:28:32.615 --> 00:28:34.495
And that's what really what
ultimately we wanna have happen.

586
00:28:35.795 --> 00:28:36.445
>> Very good, Adam.

587
00:28:36.445 --> 00:28:37.315
We appreciate that.

588
00:28:37.315 --> 00:28:39.365
A lot of great information
on risk management.

589
00:28:39.365 --> 00:28:43.485
And as we start to extend that
out beyond our organization,

590
00:28:43.485 --> 00:28:46.212
which are bringing in third parties or,
acquisitions.

591
00:28:46.212 --> 00:28:49.992
We've gotta see how that changes our risk
management, and what we need to look for,

592
00:28:49.992 --> 00:28:52.572
and we're all looking forward
to our next security party.

593
00:28:52.572 --> 00:28:55.012
I think it's going to be a blast,
I can't wait to see that.

594
00:28:55.012 --> 00:28:58.352
You've got to make that relevant, as you
said, once a year isn't gonna cut it.

595
00:28:58.352 --> 00:29:01.551
It's gotta be be something that
really does stick with them, and

596
00:29:01.551 --> 00:29:04.981
it's gotta be a continual thing,
otherwise it's really not worth doing.

597
00:29:04.981 --> 00:29:06.511
All right, Adam, we appreciate that.

598
00:29:06.511 --> 00:29:07.291
Remember, ladies and

599
00:29:07.291 --> 00:29:10.441
gentlemen, if you want to check
out one of Adam's live classes,

600
00:29:10.441 --> 00:29:15.821
if you want to attend his live classes,
shoot us an email at SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

601
00:29:15.821 --> 00:29:18.260
For now, signing off, I'm Mike Roderick.

602
00:29:18.260 --> 00:29:21.330
I'm Adam Gordon and
we'll see you next time.

603
00:29:21.330 --> 00:29:22.466
Take care everybody.

604
00:29:22.466 --> 00:29:28.390
>> [MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike cover asset security, starting with defining what assets are. They discuss the need for classification and describe different classification systems. They talk about data ownership, who is responsible for data classification, and the fact that classification is not static and must be reviewed periodically.
episodes.title: Asset Classification
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.053 --> 00:00:15.101
Hello and welcome to another
exciting here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.101 --> 00:00:19.060
I'm your host Mike Roderick and
today we're doing our CISSP,

4
00:00:19.060 --> 00:00:23.150
and specifically we're gonna be
looking at asset classification.

5
00:00:23.150 --> 00:00:26.190
How we go about classifying
these apps assets and

6
00:00:26.190 --> 00:00:29.300
how that affects the way
we protect those assets.

7
00:00:29.300 --> 00:00:31.470
And here to help us with
that is Mister Adam Gordon.

8
00:00:31.470 --> 00:00:32.430
How's it going Adam?

9
00:00:32.430 --> 00:00:33.060
>> Good.
Good.

10
00:00:33.060 --> 00:00:34.340
How's everybody doing out there?

11
00:00:34.340 --> 00:00:36.980
By the way, today is cool argyle sock day.

12
00:00:36.980 --> 00:00:38.860
>> Ha ha.
>> In case you didn't know that.

13
00:00:38.860 --> 00:00:41.475
All right, so let's talk about
asset classification, all right?

14
00:00:41.475 --> 00:00:45.050
As Mike was saying, the real important
thing we gotta think about first

15
00:00:45.050 --> 00:00:47.920
when we start talking about
assets in this domain and

16
00:00:47.920 --> 00:00:51.000
in this general area of knowledge is,
what is an asset, right?

17
00:00:51.000 --> 00:00:54.110
I mean, it's an obvious question, but it's
one that we really have to start out with.

18
00:00:54.110 --> 00:00:58.490
And from there, if we can come up with
a clear definition of an asset equals

19
00:00:58.490 --> 00:01:01.640
a computer,
an asset equals a piece of information,

20
00:01:01.640 --> 00:01:05.200
an asset equals a person,
a resource within the organization.

21
00:01:05.200 --> 00:01:07.520
Any and or all these things,
by the way, can be assets.

22
00:01:07.520 --> 00:01:10.970
Assets can be a chair, they can be
a mouse pad, they can be a mouse.

23
00:01:10.970 --> 00:01:13.220
So lot's of things that can be assets.

24
00:01:13.220 --> 00:01:14.330
We want to protect them, but

25
00:01:14.330 --> 00:01:17.120
we don't necessarily want to
protect all of them they same way.

26
00:01:17.120 --> 00:01:20.650
A mouse pad doesn't need
the same kind of protection that

27
00:01:20.650 --> 00:01:25.350
confidential proprietary financial
data within the organization does.

28
00:01:25.350 --> 00:01:26.400
They both are important.

29
00:01:26.400 --> 00:01:29.070
But one is a little bit more
important than the other,

30
00:01:29.070 --> 00:01:31.670
although mousepads
are definitely very important.

31
00:01:31.670 --> 00:01:34.450
Want to make sure we guard those,
very, very important.

32
00:01:34.450 --> 00:01:35.130
So it is funny.

33
00:01:35.130 --> 00:01:37.330
And I'll tell you a quick story
about asset classification

34
00:01:37.330 --> 00:01:38.180
by way of getting it started.

35
00:01:38.180 --> 00:01:40.560
So talking about mousepads, right?

36
00:01:40.560 --> 00:01:43.830
Do a lot of work with the government,
with the military in particular within

37
00:01:43.830 --> 00:01:46.260
the United States and
in other countries as well.

38
00:01:46.260 --> 00:01:50.220
And so I'm on a base, several bases
over the last year, doing work, but

39
00:01:50.220 --> 00:01:51.600
one base in particular.

40
00:01:51.600 --> 00:01:54.410
And I do a lot of work at
this particular location.

41
00:01:54.410 --> 00:01:56.990
And so I'm there and
I'm walking through the halls.

42
00:01:56.990 --> 00:01:59.260
And if you've ever been in the military,
or work in the government and

43
00:01:59.260 --> 00:02:02.350
work in secure areas,
you have a sense of this, right?

44
00:02:02.350 --> 00:02:05.580
Although I have a clearance,
I'm given a special visitor badge,

45
00:02:05.580 --> 00:02:07.450
whatever based the level
of clearance I have.

46
00:02:07.450 --> 00:02:11.280
I'm not classified at a security level
that allows me to walk freely throughout

47
00:02:11.280 --> 00:02:14.260
the building, typically,
because I'm not active duty.

48
00:02:14.260 --> 00:02:16.400
And I'm not gonna have that
kind of security clearance.

49
00:02:16.400 --> 00:02:18.490
So I have to have
an escort everywhere I go.

50
00:02:18.490 --> 00:02:21.680
So I've got an escort with me, and
when I say everywhere, I mean literally.

51
00:02:21.680 --> 00:02:25.360
If I go to the bathroom, this nice person
stands right outside the door waiting for

52
00:02:25.360 --> 00:02:28.360
me to take care of what I have to
take care of, come back out, and

53
00:02:28.360 --> 00:02:30.500
then they walk with me
wherever I'm gonna go.

54
00:02:30.500 --> 00:02:32.160
So that part's okay, no big deal.

55
00:02:32.160 --> 00:02:33.990
I never get lost so that works out well.

56
00:02:33.990 --> 00:02:36.450
But you're walking through these areas,
and

57
00:02:36.450 --> 00:02:40.170
a lot of times there's very sensitive
classified information being dealt with

58
00:02:40.170 --> 00:02:44.000
in a lot of the bases that I work with and
a lot of the places I do work in.

59
00:02:44.000 --> 00:02:48.300
And so you'll here as I'm walking down
the hall, right, you'll hear somebody will

60
00:02:48.300 --> 00:02:54.440
scream typically classified information or
unclass on deck, depending on where I am.

61
00:02:54.440 --> 00:02:58.090
And everybody shuts their door or
everybody turns and does whatever they

62
00:02:58.090 --> 00:03:02.350
have to do so he can see anything, which
is all fine, but in most of these areas

63
00:03:02.350 --> 00:03:06.710
where you have classified assets being
used, all the systems are tagged.

64
00:03:06.710 --> 00:03:11.230
So you have a red tag, which at least
in the US government in the military,

65
00:03:11.230 --> 00:03:15.250
red tag white writing,
classified red effectively means secure.

66
00:03:15.250 --> 00:03:19.340
Green unclassified, green sticker,
white writing unclassified means

67
00:03:19.340 --> 00:03:22.290
effectively that it's for
use in an unclassified environment.

68
00:03:22.290 --> 00:03:25.980
So entire systems are classified, so
literally everything has a sticker so

69
00:03:25.980 --> 00:03:30.650
you walk by the monitor has a red class
sticker on it, the system itself and

70
00:03:30.650 --> 00:03:34.260
even the mouse pad, you turn the mouse pad
over and it has a sticker on the bottom

71
00:03:34.260 --> 00:03:35.630
that says classified, so-
>> [LAUGH]

72
00:03:35.630 --> 00:03:37.590
>> Classified mouse pads,

73
00:03:37.590 --> 00:03:38.732
coming to a system near you soon.

74
00:03:38.732 --> 00:03:39.780
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, so

75
00:03:39.780 --> 00:03:42.720
when we talk about asset management and
classified of assets,

76
00:03:42.720 --> 00:03:45.010
what we really need to start
thinking about is what is an asset,

77
00:03:45.010 --> 00:03:47.380
and what does it mean to
us in the organization?

78
00:03:47.380 --> 00:03:50.280
Based on that,
we literally then can decide

79
00:03:50.280 --> 00:03:53.610
how to mark information when we
talk about data specifically.

80
00:03:53.610 --> 00:03:56.450
How to mark information,
how to mark those assets so

81
00:03:56.450 --> 00:03:58.800
that we know they are classified,
or they're unclassified.

82
00:03:58.800 --> 00:04:02.550
Or they should be used by this group of
people, maybe not that group of people.

83
00:04:02.550 --> 00:04:06.370
So while it is a little bit crazy to say,
let's put the classified sticker on

84
00:04:06.370 --> 00:04:11.130
the mouse pad, the logic of it is, it's
part of a system that is classified and

85
00:04:11.130 --> 00:04:14.340
everything associated with the system
has to be classified the same way.

86
00:04:14.340 --> 00:04:16.870
The logic is actually very specific and

87
00:04:16.870 --> 00:04:20.690
very sound, even though in the real world
it translates into a funny anecdote,

88
00:04:20.690 --> 00:04:23.600
because you classify a mouse
pad as being secure.

89
00:04:23.600 --> 00:04:26.900
But the point is not that the mouse
pad itself is secure, but rather that

90
00:04:26.900 --> 00:04:30.930
the entire system the mouse pad is
a part of is classified as being secure.

91
00:04:30.930 --> 00:04:34.020
And every element, according to
the data classification policy,

92
00:04:34.020 --> 00:04:36.520
has to be labeled and
classified accordingly.

93
00:04:36.520 --> 00:04:39.400
That's why we label mouse pads
as being classified, right?

94
00:04:39.400 --> 00:04:42.420
So just think about the logic of that and
what classification means.

95
00:04:42.420 --> 00:04:45.630
When we think about
categorization of information,

96
00:04:45.630 --> 00:04:49.740
we're thinking about determining not
what the classification should be, but

97
00:04:49.740 --> 00:04:54.120
rather what the impact is if that
organizational asset, the data, or

98
00:04:54.120 --> 00:04:56.830
whatever it may be that were
classified is exposed, and

99
00:04:56.830 --> 00:05:00.070
therefore potentially breached or
lost to us in some way.

100
00:05:00.070 --> 00:05:04.490
So, attacks against confidentiality,
integrity, and durability in terms of

101
00:05:04.490 --> 00:05:08.430
categorization, we have to understand
what the impact of that attack could be.

102
00:05:08.430 --> 00:05:13.450
And categorizing information helps us,
again, to understand impact specifically.

103
00:05:13.450 --> 00:05:15.728
Wanna make sure we make that connection,
we're aware of that.

104
00:05:15.728 --> 00:05:18.480
So classification and/or
categorization systems,

105
00:05:18.480 --> 00:05:21.270
there are many,
many that we can point to, again.

106
00:05:21.270 --> 00:05:24.250
Number one, not an exhaustive list
that I'm about to share with you.

107
00:05:24.250 --> 00:05:25.170
Number two,

108
00:05:25.170 --> 00:05:30.540
merely examples of systems worldwide that
give you a sense of what may be done.

109
00:05:30.540 --> 00:05:33.040
Are we suggesting you go out and
study these?

110
00:05:33.040 --> 00:05:34.710
No.
Are we suggesting that you have some

111
00:05:34.710 --> 00:05:39.040
passing knowledge familiarity with them,
as a security professional today?

112
00:05:39.040 --> 00:05:41.920
If you work in these areas, absolutely.

113
00:05:41.920 --> 00:05:44.940
But to prepare for the exam,
I don't expect you to go out and

114
00:05:44.940 --> 00:05:47.700
read up on Canada's Security
of Information Act,

115
00:05:47.700 --> 00:05:49.440
that's one of the acts
that you can look at.

116
00:05:49.440 --> 00:05:52.630
It's a good thing to know about
if you do work in Canada, and

117
00:05:52.630 --> 00:05:57.400
are subject to data classification, the
categorization requirements within Canada.

118
00:05:57.400 --> 00:06:01.530
But if you're not, there's probably not a
lot of reason for you to read up on that.

119
00:06:01.530 --> 00:06:04.790
China has a law called Guarding State
Secrets that deals with this, right?

120
00:06:04.790 --> 00:06:06.120
Again, is it important to know?

121
00:06:06.120 --> 00:06:08.480
Yeah, if you're gonna be traveling
in China, doing business there,

122
00:06:08.480 --> 00:06:09.810
it's probably important to know.

123
00:06:09.810 --> 00:06:10.450
If you're not,

124
00:06:10.450 --> 00:06:13.320
it may not be something that you
really have to spend a lot of time on.

125
00:06:13.320 --> 00:06:16.250
The UK has the Official Secrets Act
that's been in the news over the last

126
00:06:16.250 --> 00:06:19.060
couple of years given what

00:28:41.067 --> 00:28:45.768
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike talk about protecting the privacy of information. They discuss the importance of privacy policies as well as defining boundaries for data usage. They differentiate between data owners and data custodians, and what their responsibilities are. They talk about the importance of documenting policies in regards to auditing.
episodes.title: Protect Privacy
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.922 --> 00:00:15.127
>> Hello and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.127 --> 00:00:16.845
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:16.845 --> 00:00:19.493
Today, we're doing our CISSP.

5
00:00:19.493 --> 00:00:23.377
And specifically, we're gonna be
looking into protecting privacy and

6
00:00:23.377 --> 00:00:27.210
this is a pretty large topic and
it deals with a lot of different things.

7
00:00:27.210 --> 00:00:30.120
Some of them might be more
obvious to you like you may

8
00:00:30.120 --> 00:00:34.588
be thinking about end user privacy, but
we've also got to consider data in for

9
00:00:34.588 --> 00:00:37.111
our corporation and keeping that private.

10
00:00:37.111 --> 00:00:39.897
And here to help us with that is Mr.
Adam Gordon.

11
00:00:39.897 --> 00:00:40.874
How are you doing today, Adam?

12
00:00:40.874 --> 00:00:42.731
>> I'm doing well, I'm doing well.

13
00:00:42.731 --> 00:00:44.544
So let's talk about privacy a little bit.

14
00:00:44.544 --> 00:00:47.377
Let's think about privacy and
we've spoken about privacy already.

15
00:00:47.377 --> 00:00:51.556
We've spoken a lot about what privacy
means from the individual's perspective.

16
00:00:51.556 --> 00:00:55.200
Think about what we talk about as PII,
P-I-I.

17
00:00:55.200 --> 00:00:58.697
Personally identifiable information
is what PII represents or

18
00:00:58.697 --> 00:00:59.867
what is meant by PII.

19
00:00:59.867 --> 00:01:02.381
And when we think about personally
identifiable information,

20
00:01:02.381 --> 00:01:04.760
we're thinking about data that
is unique to an individual.

21
00:01:04.760 --> 00:01:08.139
So, a driver's license number,
uniquely identifies me.

22
00:01:08.139 --> 00:01:11.960
The United States, a social
security number, a passport number.

23
00:01:11.960 --> 00:01:15.003
There may be many different things
that identify an individual.

24
00:01:15.003 --> 00:01:19.851
Maybe they're medical records, perhaps
an employee ID within a either a ERP

25
00:01:19.851 --> 00:01:24.701
system or a customer ID in a CRM system,
customer relationship management,

26
00:01:24.701 --> 00:01:28.830
enterprise resource provisioning
is what ERP stands for.

27
00:01:28.830 --> 00:01:32.141
So the idea generically is how do
we take all that unique data and

28
00:01:32.141 --> 00:01:35.589
not just mange it, not just use it,
but how do we safe guard it??

29
00:01:35.589 --> 00:01:39.070
How do we apply confidentiality,
integrity at minimum?

30
00:01:39.070 --> 00:01:42.700
And certainly, availability standards to
it to safeguard that data and this is

31
00:01:42.700 --> 00:01:46.614
really what protecting privacy and privacy
though processes have to be about today.

32
00:01:46.614 --> 00:01:50.091
It's about all the things that can
go wrong with data, exposing it

33
00:01:50.091 --> 00:01:54.380
unnecessarily that we really are
attempting to discuss and think through.

34
00:01:54.380 --> 00:01:59.154
So individuals, starting from this
thought process or this particular point.

35
00:01:59.154 --> 00:02:02.110
Individuals should be given
the right to control their own data.

36
00:02:02.110 --> 00:02:06.992
We can probably all agree that whether or
not in law, that is stipulated,

37
00:02:06.992 --> 00:02:08.266
it's a good idea.

38
00:02:08.266 --> 00:02:12.162
And so although we struggle with it, for
instance, here in the United States,

39
00:02:12.162 --> 00:02:14.650
it is not something that
is enshrined in law.

40
00:02:14.650 --> 00:02:18.098
The way it is in the European Union, but
we still have a thought process that

41
00:02:18.098 --> 00:02:22.042
individuals should have control over their
own data, but promise we don't back it up

42
00:02:22.042 --> 00:02:25.153
with this many loss and
protections as they do in other countries.

43
00:02:25.153 --> 00:02:27.443
So we still think that that's importing,
but

44
00:02:27.443 --> 00:02:30.760
we have an acted necessarily
in the same forth right now.

45
00:02:30.760 --> 00:02:32.322
Having said that though,

46
00:02:32.322 --> 00:02:35.588
as a CISSP working inside of
a company being in charge or

47
00:02:35.588 --> 00:02:40.632
ultimately being focused on data privacy,
you still have to come up with policies.

48
00:02:40.632 --> 00:02:43.451
You still have to implement
procedures ultimately and

49
00:02:43.451 --> 00:02:46.610
you still have to manage data access and
data security.

50
00:02:46.610 --> 00:02:48.664
Whether or not it's the law of the land,

51
00:02:48.664 --> 00:02:51.816
that individual should have
ultimate control of their data.

52
00:02:51.816 --> 00:02:55.768
You have to decide what data control means
within the boundary of the organization

53
00:02:55.768 --> 00:02:59.500
and what we have to really then struggle
with is what does that boundary mean?

54
00:02:59.500 --> 00:03:04.224
We've talked about data classification and
data not only classification, but

55
00:03:04.224 --> 00:03:06.725
categorization in terms
of what data is and

56
00:03:06.725 --> 00:03:09.796
what it means to the organization
to have that data.

57
00:03:09.796 --> 00:03:12.550
We've spoken about this and
talked about this in a prior episode.

58
00:03:12.550 --> 00:03:14.706
What we have to do is take
that thought process.

59
00:03:14.706 --> 00:03:18.429
Link that to the geographical
conversation about what the boundary or

60
00:03:18.429 --> 00:03:20.910
border of the information is going to be.

61
00:03:20.910 --> 00:03:23.253
Is it just literally
within our organization?

62
00:03:23.253 --> 00:03:27.593
Is it being shared with other partners,
other vendors inside of our supply chain,

63
00:03:27.593 --> 00:03:29.640
up and down and throughout that chain?

64
00:03:29.640 --> 00:03:32.870
And if it is,
does the border now really extend to them?

65
00:03:32.870 --> 00:03:34.378
And then what if they turn around and

66
00:03:34.378 --> 00:03:36.950
share that with one of their
subcontracted relationships?

67
00:03:36.950 --> 00:03:40.696
How far down the level or how far down,
rather that level do we go or

68
00:03:40.696 --> 00:03:44.602
that particular rat hole or black hole or
not rat hole or black hole?

69
00:03:44.602 --> 00:03:45.982
>> [LAUGH]
>> Rabbit hole,

70
00:03:45.982 --> 00:03:47.318
that's the one I'm trying to come up with.

71
00:03:47.318 --> 00:03:51.400
How far down that hole do we actually
go in order to track our data?

72
00:03:51.400 --> 00:03:55.885
This is a very complicated decision
point for us as security professionals,

73
00:03:55.885 --> 00:03:58.856
because if we want to extend
the border of the data.

74
00:03:58.856 --> 00:04:02.329
And therefore, the protection of the data
to individuals outside the immediate

75
00:04:02.329 --> 00:04:05.751
organization, we have to come up with
ways to ensure that they're gonna manage

76
00:04:05.751 --> 00:04:08.170
the data the same way that we
want the data to be secured.

77
00:04:08.170 --> 00:04:11.165
If they're not gonna do that, we probably
shouldn't share the data with them.

78
00:04:11.165 --> 00:04:12.030
That's just the reality.

79
00:04:12.030 --> 00:04:13.870
So how secure is the data?

80
00:04:13.870 --> 00:04:15.720
How accessible is the data?

81
00:04:15.720 --> 00:04:17.823
Under what format will the data be used?

82
00:04:17.823 --> 00:04:22.440
And what shape and form will the data be
used will it stored, will it be transfer?

83
00:04:22.440 --> 00:04:25.511
These are questions that really can
complicate our lives dramatically when we

84
00:04:25.511 --> 00:04:26.731
think about data protection.

85
00:04:26.731 --> 00:04:30.725
The EU, the European Union as I've talked
about in some of our prior discussions has

86
00:04:30.725 --> 00:04:32.470
really taken the lead on this.

87
00:04:32.470 --> 00:04:35.808
They have through their data
protection Directive 95/46,

88
00:04:35.808 --> 00:04:38.537
really stood out in front
of everybody else and said,

89
00:04:38.537 --> 00:04:41.935
this is how we view the data
protection rights of the individual and

90
00:04:41.935 --> 00:04:46.142
the rights of the individual to manage
their data throughout the data lifecycle.

91
00:04:46.142 --> 00:04:50.113
So strengthening individual's rights is
really what the focus of that directive

92
00:04:50.113 --> 00:04:53.852
has been and being able to give users,
individual users the rights to control

93
00:04:53.852 --> 00:04:57.960
the disposition of their data is what the
ultimate goal of that directive has been.

94
00:04:57.960 --> 00:05:00.298
So we wanna be thinking about that,
understanding that,

95
00:05:00.298 --> 00:05:01.834
insuring that we have a sense of that.

96
00:05:01.834 --> 00:05:05.555
Obviously, along with that, we then have
to think about, as I was just saying,

97
00:05:05.555 --> 00:05:08.910
how we extend the border of that
protection out beyond the EU.

98
00:05:08.910 --> 00:05:11.468
So we talked about a concept
known as safe harbor provisions.

99
00:05:11.468 --> 00:05:15.622
Whether we get into the conversation
specifically about what safe harbor

100
00:05:15.622 --> 00:05:19.709
permissions or protections exist
currently today and they are in flux,

101
00:05:19.709 --> 00:05:23.030
as I've mentioned in one
of our prior conversations.

102
00:05:23.030 --> 00:05:26.957
The idea of safe harbor right now is being
reevaluated, which means that although we

103
00:05:26.957 --> 00:05:30.773
have the generic concept of safe harbor
and we should understand generically what

104
00:05:30.773 --> 00:05:34.554
that means the specificity of how it's
being implemented may change over time.

105
00:05:34.554 --> 00:05:36.309
And so let's focus more broadly,

106
00:05:36.309 --> 00:05:39.758
just generally the idea of what
a safe harbor provision looks like,

107
00:05:39.758 --> 00:05:43.283
not the specificity of what one may or
may not be at any moment in time.

108
00:05:43.283 --> 00:05:46.954
And the idea of a safe harbor
provision effectively helps us,

109
00:05:46.954 --> 00:05:50.835
as a company that is looking to
do business with, individuals and

110
00:05:50.835 --> 00:05:55.355
secure and safeguard their data to
understand what the requirements are for

111
00:05:55.355 --> 00:05:58.760
us to align with in order to secure and
to do exactly that.

112
00:05:58.760 --> 00:05:59.898
Safeguard their data and

113
00:05:59.898 --> 00:06:03.266
align them with whatever the national
legislative requirements may be.

114
00:06:03.266 --> 00:06:04.590
So in just plain English,

115
00:06:04.590 --> 00:06:08.386
we have to effectively use safe harbor
provisions to give us the rule book,

116
00:06:08.386 --> 00:06:12.302
the play book that we should manage the
data through in order to be aligned with

117
00:06:12.302 --> 00:06:16.067
the requirements of the country that
has said, this is what our laws are.

118
00:06:16.067 --> 00:06:21.260
So in the example of the EU Data
Protection Directive, the 9546 directive.

119
00:06:21.260 --> 00:06:25.140
The United States and
other entities that want to do business

120
00:06:25.140 --> 00:06:30.140
with European Union and subjects that live
in the EU, individuals that are there that

121
00:06:30.140 --> 00:06:35.130
want to provide their data to some sort of
business, so that they can buy something.

122
00:06:35.130 --> 00:06:37.146
Or maybe a doctor or a hospital concern or

123
00:06:37.146 --> 00:06:41.061
healthcare concern that may expose their
data outside of the border of the EU in

124
00:06:41.061 --> 00:06:43.694
order to work with a partner,
something like that.

125
00:06:43.694 --> 00:06:45.556
If they're doing that,

126
00:06:45.556 --> 00:06:50.740
that data is not subject necessarily
to EU data protection laws.

127
00:06:50.740 --> 00:06:52.559
Some countries may not
recognize those laws.

128
00:06:52.559 --> 00:06:55.453
And as a result, may say, well,
that's nice, but we have our own laws or

129
00:06:55.453 --> 00:06:57.590
in protect the data based on what we say.

130
00:06:57.590 --> 00:07:01.528
What safe harbor effectively says to
those countries is if you want access

131
00:07:01.528 --> 00:07:05.529
to the data, you're gonna have to abide
by the boiled down version of the EU

132
00:07:05.529 --> 00:07:07.899
data protection laws that are stipulated.

133
00:07:07.899 --> 00:07:12.128
In the safe harbor agreement that we
negotiate between the country that wants

134
00:07:12.128 --> 00:07:15.560
the data and wants the business and
in this case the EU.

135
00:07:15.560 --> 00:07:18.614
And having done that, it gives us
a playbook, a rule book that says,

136
00:07:18.614 --> 00:07:20.681
these are the basic tenets
you have to follow.

137
00:07:20.681 --> 00:07:22.590
You have to implement
these basic protections.

138
00:07:22.590 --> 00:07:24.616
You have to help us to
manage your data this way.

139
00:07:24.616 --> 00:07:28.923
Although you may not follow the exact
letter of the law using safe harbor,

140
00:07:28.923 --> 00:07:31.470
you will follow the spirit of the law.

141
00:07:31.470 --> 00:07:34.716
And by following the spirit of the law,
you are aligned enough.

142
00:07:34.716 --> 00:07:38.146
You are providing enough protection
that we will say that it's okay for

143
00:07:38.146 --> 00:07:40.320
you to manage the data on our behalf.

144
00:07:40.320 --> 00:07:42.272
This is effectively what
safe harbor provides.

145
00:07:42.272 --> 00:07:45.661
So whether it is a safe harbor
agreement between the United States,

146
00:07:45.661 --> 00:07:49.882
hypothetically and the EU, whether it is a
safe harbor between the United States and

147
00:07:49.882 --> 00:07:53.284
another country, whatever it may be,
it doesn't really matter.

148
00:07:53.284 --> 00:07:57.034
Two countries that are just simply looking
to exchange information where both

149
00:07:57.034 --> 00:08:00.615
countries have very clear legislative
requirements that are different,

150
00:08:00.615 --> 00:08:02.772
a safe harbor agreement
can bridge the gap and

151
00:08:02.772 --> 00:08:05.986
allow the two countries to
effectively manage data effectively.

152
00:08:05.986 --> 00:08:07.925
That's what a Safe Harbor
requirement will do.

153
00:08:07.925 --> 00:08:11.340
So sort of be thinking about that, be
aware of that as part of our conversation.

154
00:08:12.460 --> 00:08:15.140
When we think about it, we've already
talked about data information

155
00:08:15.140 --> 00:08:16.870
from the respective of ownership.

156
00:08:16.870 --> 00:08:19.750
We know that the data owner should
help us to classify data and

157
00:08:19.750 --> 00:08:22.390
should stipulate how
data will be classified.

158
00:08:22.390 --> 00:08:25.630
Remember that data ownership
is really about understanding

159
00:08:25.630 --> 00:08:28.280
who is ultimately responsible for data.

160
00:08:28.280 --> 00:08:29.960
When I own data, it's mine.

161
00:08:29.960 --> 00:08:33.210
In effect, if I own it,
I can decide what will be done with.

162
00:08:33.210 --> 00:08:35.190
I can decide how long
it will stick around.

163
00:08:35.190 --> 00:08:37.260
I could decide who should
have access to it.

164
00:08:37.260 --> 00:08:39.650
I could decide if it should
be destroyed and when.

165
00:08:39.650 --> 00:08:43.560
So I wanna be thinking about the fact
that ownership implies control, right?

166
00:08:43.560 --> 00:08:47.690
This is a very important thought process
for me, important thought process for you.

167
00:08:47.690 --> 00:08:53.550
When you think about becoming a CISSP,
we focus a lot on data management.

168
00:08:53.550 --> 00:08:57.000
We focus a lot on data ownership,
data accountability,

169
00:08:57.000 --> 00:08:59.710
in terms of who's gonna be accountable and
responsible for data.

170
00:08:59.710 --> 00:09:02.840
And we talk about access control
systems that help us to do this.

171
00:09:02.840 --> 00:09:07.118
Things like discretionary access control,
mandatory access control,

172
00:09:07.118 --> 00:09:11.327
attribute-based access control,
temporal-based access control,

173
00:09:11.327 --> 00:09:14.925
rule-based access control,
role-based access control.

174
00:09:14.925 --> 00:09:16.975
Stop me when you here one
that you may like, right?

175
00:09:16.975 --> 00:09:18.885
Any or all these, and
there are more, by the way, and

176
00:09:18.885 --> 00:09:22.265
we'll talk about all those at some
point in one of our episodes together.

177
00:09:22.265 --> 00:09:24.715
And you'll hear us go through and
explain what they are.

178
00:09:24.715 --> 00:09:27.240
But the idea is that there
are many access control models.

179
00:09:27.240 --> 00:09:30.050
They are used, regardless of
how they're set up to operate,

180
00:09:30.050 --> 00:09:35.580
to implement control of data, and control
of the users that are accessing data.

181
00:09:35.580 --> 00:09:38.360
We talked about subjects and
objects in those models.

182
00:09:38.360 --> 00:09:41.380
Subjects are going to be the users, and

183
00:09:41.380 --> 00:09:43.630
then objects are going
to represent the data.

184
00:09:43.630 --> 00:09:47.910
And so, subjects want access to objects,
and objects have to effectively

185
00:09:47.910 --> 00:09:52.340
allow themselves to be accessed by
authenticating users into the system.

186
00:09:52.340 --> 00:09:55.720
And so we talked more about how all that
works, but information ownership and

187
00:09:55.720 --> 00:09:57.380
data ownership is a very big part of that.

188
00:09:57.380 --> 00:09:59.750
We have to understand
who owns the data and

189
00:09:59.750 --> 00:10:02.720
effectively based on that,
what they decide the data will or

190
00:10:02.720 --> 00:10:07.080
will not be allowed to be able to be
used as, or used for, or seen by.

191
00:10:07.080 --> 00:10:09.680
And those kind of questions come
up with regards to ownership.

192
00:10:09.680 --> 00:10:12.850
Determining the impact the information
has on the organization,

193
00:10:12.850 --> 00:10:14.815
in other words it's
a function of ownership.

194
00:10:14.815 --> 00:10:18.750
Understanding the replacement cost of the
information, is a a function of ownership.

195
00:10:18.750 --> 00:10:22.300
Determining who has a need to see
the data and under what circumstances,

196
00:10:22.300 --> 00:10:23.780
these are all functions of ownership.

197
00:10:23.780 --> 00:10:26.810
These are things that data ownership
implies that we would be doing.

198
00:10:26.810 --> 00:10:28.540
So, want to just make sure
we're aware of that and

199
00:10:28.540 --> 00:10:31.530
we understand that as
part of the discussion.

200
00:10:31.530 --> 00:10:35.000
We've talked a lot about documentation and
why documentation is so important.

201
00:10:35.000 --> 00:10:38.030
Every time we do something, we should
have a written record of what it is.

202
00:10:38.030 --> 00:10:41.830
We talk a lot in the discussions
about intrusion detection and

203
00:10:41.830 --> 00:10:45.880
intrusion prevention systems and
firewalls, about the value of logging and

204
00:10:45.880 --> 00:10:48.810
writing everything down in a log so
we know it's been happening.

205
00:10:48.810 --> 00:10:52.980
We talk a lot in our discussions with
databases about transactional logging.

206
00:10:52.980 --> 00:10:55.970
So we understand what's happening in
writing down all the transactions.

207
00:10:55.970 --> 00:10:58.360
So we see them and
can reproduce them if we need to.

208
00:10:58.360 --> 00:11:01.870
Everywhere we go, everywhere we look,
everywhere we turn, we see a discussion

209
00:11:01.870 --> 00:11:04.900
about documentation cropping up
with regards to system management.

210
00:11:04.900 --> 00:11:06.270
It's very, very important.

211
00:11:06.270 --> 00:11:09.890
So, generically, the idea for
CISSP, and for that matter for

212
00:11:09.890 --> 00:11:14.670
any IT professional not just a security
focused one, but any IT professional,

213
00:11:14.670 --> 00:11:17.940
is the more documentation we have,
the better we are right?

214
00:11:17.940 --> 00:11:21.870
And we can never have too much as we know,
because when we ask people on average,

215
00:11:21.870 --> 00:11:24.705
hey do you think your
documentation is really good?

216
00:11:24.705 --> 00:11:28.080
What we often hear from them is, you know
it's okay but it could be better, right?

217
00:11:28.080 --> 00:11:31.120
Could always do a better job
if I had more time, right?

218
00:11:31.120 --> 00:11:32.580
Everybody's always whining about time.

219
00:11:32.580 --> 00:11:33.968
If I just had more time.

220
00:11:33.968 --> 00:11:37.045
If you stopped complaining so
much and you started doing your job,

221
00:11:37.045 --> 00:11:38.730
you'd have a lot more time, right?

222
00:11:38.730 --> 00:11:41.740
So, the idea is that when we do,

we clearly could do a better job if

00:11:44.920 --> 00:11:46.170
There's no doubt about that.

225
00:11:46.170 --> 00:11:50.540
But the balance and the problem is we only

226
00:11:50.540 --> 00:11:53.060
And we only have so
many things that we can get done.

227
00:11:53.060 --> 00:11:55.908
And usually documentation,
although it's very important,

00:11:55.908 --> 00:11:58.605
it's further down the list of

229
00:11:58.605 --> 00:12:01.036
But sometimes, and
more often than not let's be honest,

00:12:01.036 --> 00:12:02.720

00:12:02.720 --> 00:12:04.420
Right, that's usually the rub and

232
00:12:04.420 --> 00:12:09.420
So while documentation is very important,
data ownership implies the documentation

00:12:09.420 --> 00:12:12.320
about the data should be
kept up to date as well.

234
00:12:12.320 --> 00:12:16.280
Data owners have the responsibility to

235
00:12:16.280 --> 00:12:17.090

00:12:17.090 --> 00:12:20.630
That's one of the few things that data

237
00:12:20.630 --> 00:12:23.150
is that documentation about

238
00:12:23.150 --> 00:12:27.108
So, ownership of the data,

00:12:27.108 --> 00:12:30.860
getting a patent, perhaps a trademark,

00:12:30.860 --> 00:12:33.940
Those are things the data owner would

00:12:33.940 --> 00:12:36.500

00:12:36.500 --> 00:12:42.710
Making sure, not that we actually pull

00:12:42.710 --> 00:12:46.300

00:12:46.300 --> 00:12:49.720

00:12:49.720 --> 00:12:52.240
And we'll have copies of it in

00:12:52.240 --> 00:12:53.420

00:12:53.420 --> 00:12:56.310
That's part of data ownership,

248
00:12:56.310 --> 00:12:58.820
So, these are all things we

249
00:12:58.820 --> 00:12:59.900
We want to juxtapose,

00:12:59.900 --> 00:13:03.810
we want to compare data ownership with

00:13:03.810 --> 00:13:06.320
Little bit of a different thought process,

252
00:13:06.320 --> 00:13:10.380
What custodianship really means,
is that we are going to be the caretakers

253
00:13:10.380 --> 00:13:13.510

day operational basis.

254
00:13:13.510 --> 00:13:17.510
Ownership implies overarching
accountability and responsibility for

255
00:13:17.510 --> 00:13:22.070
the systems around the management of
that data, and the classification of it,

256
00:13:22.070 --> 00:13:25.810
to ensure that the data is going to
be used in the appropriate ways.

257
00:13:25.810 --> 00:13:30.030
Custodianship is the implementation of
those controls and the management of data

258
00:13:30.030 --> 00:13:34.880
within those systems, moment to moment,
day to day, day in, day out kind of thing.

259
00:13:34.880 --> 00:13:38.360
So custodianship is about the actual
tactical management of data,

260
00:13:38.360 --> 00:13:42.320
whereas ownership is about
the strategic operationalizing or

261
00:13:42.320 --> 00:13:45.800
setting up, and therefore

262
00:13:45.800 --> 00:13:48.370
We want to make a clear distinction

00:13:48.370 --> 00:13:52.200
They both are very important, and

00:13:52.200 --> 00:13:53.570

00:13:53.570 --> 00:13:56.740

00:13:56.740 --> 00:13:58.310

00:13:58.310 --> 00:13:59.610

00:13:59.610 --> 00:14:03.140

00:14:03.140 --> 00:14:05.240
Adam's gonna see it and

00:14:05.240 --> 00:14:06.730
Anybody else Mike, no, nobody else.

00:14:06.730 --> 00:14:08.240
Great, Mike, thank you.

00:14:08.240 --> 00:14:10.290
And then that's all we do and

00:14:10.290 --> 00:14:13.140

00:14:13.140 --> 00:14:15.840

00:14:15.840 --> 00:14:18.310

00:14:18.310 --> 00:14:21.150

00:14:24.740 --> 00:14:25.660

00:14:29.630 --> 00:14:32.120

00:14:32.120 --> 00:14:36.360

00:14:36.360 --> 00:14:38.742
So, this is very a big important
distinction for us, so

00:14:38.742 --> 00:14:40.390
we wanna make sure we draw.

00:14:40.390 --> 00:14:43.559
So, when we assign the role of data

00:14:43.559 --> 00:14:46.655
we have to be unequivocal about

00:14:46.655 --> 00:14:51.450
In most organizations IT administrators

00:14:51.450 --> 00:14:55.460
But we want to keep in mind that

00:14:55.460 --> 00:14:56.550
control model.

00:14:56.550 --> 00:15:00.830

00:15:04.710 --> 00:15:07.890

00:15:07.890 --> 00:15:12.700
Because the mandatory access control

00:15:16.030 --> 00:15:19.720
And they have to be at the same level

00:15:19.720 --> 00:15:20.490
each other.

00:15:20.490 --> 00:15:24.290
Or the user has to be at a minimum,

297
00:15:24.290 --> 00:15:27.740
They may be above the data, but

298
00:15:27.740 --> 00:15:30.740

00:15:30.740 --> 00:15:33.960
So if we have a three tiered system,

00:15:33.960 --> 00:15:36.968

00:15:36.968 --> 00:15:41.150
If a user's labeled at level one,
or given level one access, and

302
00:15:41.150 --> 00:15:42.740
data exists at level one.

303
00:15:42.740 --> 00:15:45.740
They're both at the same level, and in

304
00:15:45.740 --> 00:15:47.800
And, as a result, user and

305
00:15:47.800 --> 00:15:50.985
The mandatory access control

306
00:15:50.985 --> 00:15:54.217
It's acting as the custodian of the data,

00:15:54.217 --> 00:15:56.072

00:15:56.072 --> 00:16:00.052

00:16:04.052 --> 00:16:05.760
If I was a level two user and

00:16:05.760 --> 00:16:09.910

00:16:09.910 --> 00:16:15.190
But if we invert that, if data's at

00:16:15.190 --> 00:16:17.660
user doesn't see the data

00:16:17.660 --> 00:16:20.390
So we want to to make sure we
understand the data custodianship

00:16:20.390 --> 00:16:24.850
has to be assigned as a role, but
that rule may then actually be implemented

00:16:24.850 --> 00:16:26.880
through an axis control
mechanism of some kind.

00:16:26.880 --> 00:16:28.220
We wanna just be aware of that and

kinda keep that in the back

When we think about data and

we think about how data

Quality control is really

00:17:41.060 --> 00:17:43.660
the system but

QA is typically thought of as an external

00:18:00.810 --> 00:18:01.930

00:18:01.930 --> 00:18:03.390
Just want to differentiate

00:18:03.390 --> 00:18:07.250

00:18:08.340 --> 00:18:11.520
When we assess data quality we

00:18:11.520 --> 00:18:13.440

00:18:13.440 --> 00:18:14.760
I just want to remind you of that.

00:18:14.760 --> 00:18:17.980
It's not just about hey from a QA

We have to verify the data still has

00:18:21.710 --> 00:18:25.760
And this is also a very important thought

00:18:25.760 --> 00:18:27.320

If you have never been involved

of sales figures in it and we wanna be

00:22:40.490 --> 00:22:43.980
able to see what the cumulative sales
where for that particular time period.

449
00:22:43.980 --> 00:22:44.890
That's pretty straightforward.

450
00:22:44.890 --> 00:22:46.500
That's just a quick calculation.

451
00:22:46.500 --> 00:22:48.385
But what about trending in that data?

452
00:22:48.385 --> 00:22:51.890
Did the sales go up or down,
day by day, week by week,

453
00:22:51.890 --> 00:22:53.610
month by month over the term?

454
00:22:53.610 --> 00:22:56.470
That's apparent when we start to
step back and look at the data

455
00:22:56.470 --> 00:23:00.130
at a broader scope by looking at each
individual transaction it's very hard for

456
00:23:00.130 --> 00:23:02.455
us to get a sense of whether
we're trending up or down.

457
00:23:02.455 --> 00:23:04.795
So there may be a reason to
be able to do data modeling,

458
00:23:04.795 --> 00:23:08.135
to answer questions about what
the hidden value of the data is.

459
00:23:08.135 --> 00:23:10.905
And this is what really data
modeling helps us to understand and

460
00:23:10.905 --> 00:23:11.905
helps us to think through.

461
00:23:11.905 --> 00:23:14.815
So, wanna make sure we're aware of that,
really understand that.

462
00:23:14.815 --> 00:23:19.440
We obviously have to think about
the design of these systems conceptually,

463
00:23:19.440 --> 00:23:21.510
what is a database gonna be designed like?

464
00:23:21.510 --> 00:23:23.160
What kind of access do we have?

465
00:23:23.160 --> 00:23:24.630
Is it a relational model?

466
00:23:24.630 --> 00:23:26.700
Is it gonna be a different
kind of database?

467
00:23:26.700 --> 00:23:30.730
Are we gonna store data outside of
databases just in file share somewhere?

468
00:23:30.730 --> 00:23:34.400
Use what's called an enterprise content
management system, and ECM system,

469
00:23:34.400 --> 00:23:35.530
to get access to it.

470
00:23:35.530 --> 00:23:38.910
Think about Websphere,
think about SharePoint.

471
00:23:38.910 --> 00:23:41.520
Think about these kinds of systems
that allow us to effectively

472
00:23:41.520 --> 00:23:43.580
create large electronic filing cabinets,
right?

473
00:23:43.580 --> 00:23:48.425
And then with a web front end access
the data pretty much on demand.

474
00:23:48.425 --> 00:23:51.375
Whenever we want to see it provided
we authenticate into the system and

475
00:23:51.375 --> 00:23:53.245
follow the appropriate usage rules.

476
00:23:53.245 --> 00:23:54.774
Write a program up front.

477
00:23:54.774 --> 00:23:57.532
Write web based API to be
able to access the data.

478
00:23:57.532 --> 00:24:00.960
Write level of access, or
write level of access control.

479
00:24:00.960 --> 00:24:02.085
And they were able to get to the data.

480
00:24:02.085 --> 00:24:03.583
So what's the design look like?

481
00:24:03.583 --> 00:24:07.890
These are also important for us as
security professionals to think about.

482
00:24:07.890 --> 00:24:10.390
We may not work with data
bases on a regular basis.

483
00:24:10.390 --> 00:24:12.890
We may not be the data base manager or
in other words,

484
00:24:12.890 --> 00:24:15.670
the DBA administrator or analyst.

485
00:24:15.670 --> 00:24:18.200
That doesn't mean we don't
have the responsibility

486
00:24:18.200 --> 00:24:21.500
to understand the data is stored
in places that needs security.

487
00:24:21.500 --> 00:24:23.680
And we have to provide confidentiality,
integrity, and

488
00:24:23.680 --> 00:24:25.870
availability to controls to that data.

489
00:24:25.870 --> 00:24:27.890
We may have to partner
in other words right and

490
00:24:27.890 --> 00:24:30.590
work with a team of individuals
that help us to understand

491
00:24:30.590 --> 00:24:34.220
the specifics of the technology so
that we can better do our job.

492
00:24:34.220 --> 00:24:38.810
And database management is a subset of
a very important larger conversation

493
00:24:38.810 --> 00:24:40.640
around asset management and privacy.

494
00:24:40.640 --> 00:24:44.510
But if you don't specialize in database
management then you'd better specialize in

495
00:24:44.510 --> 00:24:48.710
partnering with people that do is what I
often tell my customers and my students.

496
00:24:48.710 --> 00:24:51.110
Because you're not gonna
be good at everything.

497
00:24:51.110 --> 00:24:54.438
And it's foolish, it's a fallacy,
to try to get good at everything.

498
00:24:54.438 --> 00:24:57.360
Because you're just not gonna
be able to get good enough

499
00:24:57.360 --> 00:25:00.380
that you're really going to make
a difference at doing it the right way.

500
00:25:00.380 --> 00:25:01.280
You're gonna do it, but

501
00:25:01.280 --> 00:25:04.060
you're probably not gonna get it as right
as you could is what I'm suggesting.

502
00:25:04.060 --> 00:25:07.060
Specialize in things that you
really know how to do well,

503
00:25:07.060 --> 00:25:10.040
that you have a passion for and find
the people that specialize in the other

504
00:25:10.040 --> 00:25:13.380
things you need that they do well and
they have a passion for.

505
00:25:13.380 --> 00:25:16.590
Get really good at partnering, and you
will get really good at security in other

506
00:25:16.590 --> 00:25:18.900
words, is what I would suggest to you and
I want you to think about.

507
00:25:18.900 --> 00:25:20.250
So just think about that.

508
00:25:20.250 --> 00:25:22.200
How do we look at auditing?

509
00:25:22.200 --> 00:25:24.070
We've got data stored,
got it in the database,

510
00:25:24.070 --> 00:25:27.360
we've classified it, we've categorized it,
we've assigned ownership of it.

511
00:25:27.360 --> 00:25:30.100
We're using it, but
how do we verify what's going on?

512
00:25:30.100 --> 00:25:32.890
How do we audit data to ensure
that ultimately the use of

513
00:25:32.890 --> 00:25:36.380
data is happening along the guidelines
that we've set out and stipulate it?

514
00:25:36.380 --> 00:25:38.550
This is an issue,
this is a really concern.

515
00:25:38.550 --> 00:25:41.380
If we can't verify what's happening,
we can't know for

516
00:25:41.380 --> 00:25:43.450
sure it's happening the right way.

517
00:25:43.450 --> 00:25:48.150
And audits are incredibly important
events in the lifecycle of data,

518
00:25:48.150 --> 00:25:53.140
because audits stipulate and therefore
specify what is actually happening,

519
00:25:53.140 --> 00:25:54.720
as opposed to what we think is happening.

520
00:25:54.720 --> 00:25:58.960
So we have the effectively
the to be situation, right?

521
00:25:58.960 --> 00:26:00.860
I'd like to be like that.

522
00:26:00.860 --> 00:26:05.040
But audits really help us to understand
what we currently are doing, the as is,

523
00:26:05.040 --> 00:26:06.100
as opposed to the to be.

524
00:26:06.100 --> 00:26:08.390
And they verify that the as is,

525
00:26:08.390 --> 00:26:11.210
the current state,
is exactly what we hope it would be.

526
00:26:11.210 --> 00:26:13.870
And if it's not,
it shows us the delta's the gaps, and

527
00:26:13.870 --> 00:26:17.710
points to places where we may need
to make some additional fixes or

528
00:26:17.710 --> 00:26:20.330
determinations about doing
something differently, ultimately.

529
00:26:20.330 --> 00:26:22.700
Audits often are scary words for
people, right?

530
00:26:22.700 --> 00:26:25.440
We hear auditing and we think oh my god,
someone's gonna come in and

531
00:26:25.440 --> 00:26:28.620
tell me I'm doing everything wrong, and
I'm gonna have to start over again.

532
00:26:28.620 --> 00:26:30.020
Audits don't actually have to be that.

533
00:26:30.020 --> 00:26:32.900
They're not adversarial unless
you make them that way.

534
00:26:32.900 --> 00:26:35.350
What you need to understand is
that the auditor has a job to do.

535
00:26:35.350 --> 00:26:39.760
And that auditor is there to figure out
what you're supposed to be doing and

536
00:26:39.760 --> 00:26:41.330
whether you're doing it the right way.

537
00:26:41.330 --> 00:26:43.220
If you already know what
you're supposed to do and

538
00:26:43.220 --> 00:26:47.090
you're doing it the right way, the auditor
is not gonna have a lot to do, right?

539
00:26:47.090 --> 00:26:48.790
You're gonna buy them a cup of coffee,

540
00:26:48.790 --> 00:26:51.830
you're gonna hang out with them a little
bit, cuz their usually fun people.

541
00:26:51.830 --> 00:26:53.390
I know that cuz I'm an auditor and

542
00:26:53.390 --> 00:26:55.510
look at the cool socks I was
wearing when we started.

543
00:26:55.510 --> 00:26:58.190
Auditors that wear cool socks
like that have to be cool.

544
00:26:58.190 --> 00:27:00.200
How else could you possibly
interpret that, right?

545
00:27:00.200 --> 00:27:02.140
So you're gonna buy them a cup of coffee.

546
00:27:02.140 --> 00:27:03.200
You're gonna talk to them.

547
00:27:03.200 --> 00:27:04.420
You're gonna let them do their job,

548
00:27:04.420 --> 00:27:06.950
get out of their way when they say I
need some time to look at this stuff.

549
00:27:06.950 --> 00:27:09.700
But hopefully they're gonna come back and
tell you, hey everything is good.

550
00:27:09.700 --> 00:27:12.130
Because you're exactly in
the place you need to be.

551
00:27:12.130 --> 00:27:13.470
You're doing the right things.

552
00:27:13.470 --> 00:27:15.210
If you're not following procedure.

553
00:27:15.210 --> 00:27:16.840
If you're not following policy.

554
00:27:16.840 --> 00:27:18.650
If you don't have good documentation.

555
00:27:18.650 --> 00:27:22.410
If we ask you where is the policy
that stipulates how to do this, and

556
00:27:22.410 --> 00:27:24.105
your answer is, what's a policy?

557
00:27:24.105 --> 00:27:26.620
>> [LAUGH]
>> You're not gonna have a good day.

558
00:27:26.620 --> 00:27:27.640
Right?

559
00:27:27.640 --> 00:27:31.570
No matter how much coffee you buy me,
you're gonna see me look like this.

560
00:27:31.570 --> 00:27:32.300
I'm gonna be very stern.

561
00:27:32.300 --> 00:27:34.450
I'm not gonna look like this,
very happy, right?

562
00:27:34.450 --> 00:27:37.920
So when we audit we wanna give
you a clean bill of health.

563
00:27:37.920 --> 00:27:41.480
We can only do that legitimately if you're
actually doing the job the right way.

564
00:27:41.480 --> 00:27:42.630
That's just the reality of audits.

565
00:27:42.630 --> 00:27:43.190
That's what they are.

566
00:27:43.190 --> 00:27:44.420
So just make sure you understand that.

567
00:27:44.420 --> 00:27:45.380
Make sure you understand that.

568
00:27:45.380 --> 00:27:47.720
Obviously very important
to think about that.

569
00:27:47.720 --> 00:27:51.060
You'll finally as we're wrapping up our
conversations in this area thinking about

570
00:27:51.060 --> 00:27:54.970
data access, data sharing, decimation,
are also important points when we come to

571
00:27:54.970 --> 00:27:59.340
privacy in the conversation about asset
management and data privacy overall.

572
00:27:59.340 --> 00:28:01.220
When we think about how How
we're gonna access data.

573
00:28:01.220 --> 00:28:02.590
Are we doing that securely?

574
00:28:02.590 --> 00:28:05.920
Are we using secure encrypted
communication mechanisms?

575
00:28:05.920 --> 00:28:06.980
When we're storing data,

576
00:28:06.980 --> 00:28:10.720
are we storing data in encrypted form
to prevent it from being compromised?

577
00:28:10.720 --> 00:28:13.560
When we are decimating we're
sharing broadly and sending it out.

578
00:28:13.560 --> 00:28:18.770
Are we doing that via email without any
sort of digital signatures, without any

579
00:28:18.770 --> 00:28:21.690
sort of encryption so people don't know
whether the data is legitimate and

580
00:28:21.690 --> 00:28:23.290
know whether it's been secured?

581
00:28:23.290 --> 00:28:25.190
When we have our
cryptography conversation,

582
00:28:25.190 --> 00:28:28.510
one of our upcoming episodes,
we'll talk about both symmetric and

583
00:28:28.510 --> 00:28:33.030
asymmetric cryptography, and the value
of using cryptography to secure data.

584
00:28:33.030 --> 00:28:37.110
But also to create integrity,
non-repudiation or proof or origin for

585
00:28:37.110 --> 00:28:41.120
data, when we think about being able
to use integrity controls like hashing

586
00:28:41.120 --> 00:28:42.280
to do these kind of things.

587
00:28:42.280 --> 00:28:45.250
These are important conversations, and
this is the kind of thing we have to think

588
00:28:45.250 --> 00:28:48.720
about in this area as well, because
if we're not focused on those things.

589
00:28:48.720 --> 00:28:52.530
If we're not focusing on or thinking about
how we access data, how we share it,

590
00:28:52.530 --> 00:28:55.940
how we disseminate it, then what's gonna
happen is, somebody's gonna come and

591
00:28:55.940 --> 00:28:57.910
access it in a way
they're not supposed to.

592
00:28:57.910 --> 00:29:02.500
Or they're gonna take it away from us,
and or when we have data that's in

593
00:29:02.500 --> 00:29:06.440
the system and we think we're securing it,
what about the data that's left behind

594
00:29:06.440 --> 00:29:10.030
when we destroy the data when we get rid
of it at the end of the data life cycle?

595
00:29:10.030 --> 00:29:11.520
What about data remnants?

596
00:29:11.520 --> 00:29:14.460
We've talked about residual risk before,
risk that's left over.

597
00:29:14.460 --> 00:29:15.790
Data get's left over as well.

598
00:29:15.790 --> 00:29:18.600
This is another important element
of the conversation here.

599
00:29:18.600 --> 00:29:23.160
Data remanence is data that's left over
when we destroy the data in the system

600
00:29:23.160 --> 00:29:24.440
through accepted methods.

601
00:29:24.440 --> 00:29:28.080
We overwrite the data,
we degauss the drive, whatever we may do.

602
00:29:28.080 --> 00:29:30.090
There's always something left behind.

603
00:29:30.090 --> 00:29:32.660
The question is whether we can
actually get to the data and

604
00:29:32.660 --> 00:29:33.700
reconstitute it or not.

605
00:29:33.700 --> 00:29:38.040
And this is also a part of the data
privacy and data auditing conversation.

606
00:29:38.040 --> 00:29:42.480
Destroying media and getting rid of
the data that is there in a standard or

607
00:29:42.480 --> 00:29:45.650
certified way to ensure
the data is not exposed.

608
00:29:45.650 --> 00:29:49.960
We don't breach confidentiality, we don't
breach integrity, but we do safeguard

609
00:29:49.960 --> 00:29:54.530
the data destruction process is incredibly
important for the security professional.

610
00:29:54.530 --> 00:29:56.280
We talked about what gets left behind.

611
00:29:56.280 --> 00:29:58.130
We talked about some of
the ways you can do that.

612
00:29:58.130 --> 00:30:00.740
Make sure you're aware of all these
things, all these encompassing points of

613
00:30:00.740 --> 00:30:03.756
the conversation we've had
with regards to privacy.

614
00:30:03.756 --> 00:30:06.410
>> Very good Adam,
it's a great look at privacy and

615
00:30:06.410 --> 00:30:10.790
how to protect that data that information
make sure it's kept secure again.

616
00:30:10.790 --> 00:30:13.280
Another one of those throughout
it's life cycle right,

617
00:30:13.280 --> 00:30:17.360
from when that data was created,
to when it's stores, maintained, accessed

618
00:30:17.360 --> 00:30:20.750
as well as in the end of its lifetime
when we have to get rid of that data.

619
00:30:20.750 --> 00:30:23.400
Also a little insightful look
into the world of auditors and

620
00:30:23.400 --> 00:30:26.700
how to keep them happy and
make sure your auditors know.

621
00:30:26.700 --> 00:30:29.230
Make sure you're doing it right and
get them coffee and you should

622
00:30:29.230 --> 00:30:30.650
>> And compliment them on their socks.

623
00:30:30.650 --> 00:30:31.970
That's also very important.

624
00:30:31.970 --> 00:30:33.940
>> Absolutely,
make sure you look at their socks.

625
00:30:33.940 --> 00:30:37.070
All right, Adam, we appreciate all that,
we hope everybody enjoyed watching.

626
00:30:37.070 --> 00:30:40.503
Remember, if you wanna attend
one of Adam's classes live,

627
00:30:40.503 --> 00:30:43.887
all you gotta do is drop us
an email at SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

628
00:30:43.887 --> 00:30:46.910
That's gonna do it for this episode,
signing out, I'm Mike Roderick.

629
00:30:46.910 --> 00:30:47.770
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

630
00:30:47.770 --> 00:30:48.900
>> And we'll see you next time.

631
00:30:48.900 --> 00:30:50.202
>> Take care.

632
00:30:50.202 --> 00:30:55.594

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike discuss retention policies for data, hardware and even personnel, and the importance of aligning these policies with business requirements. They talk about using baselines to ensure consistency, scoping and tailoring our choice of controls to the organizational needs.
episodes.title: Retention and Data Security

So generically the idea is the same

Do we keep things forever?

You may be one of those people that

file from 1925 just in case somebody may

I have every email that goes back 20 years

in our organization on

But the reality is it's important to

you will create and simply use, but
