00:24:30.007 --> 00:24:32.920
those images are indeed
considered to be baselines.

492
00:24:32.920 --> 00:24:35.060
So you may use
Windows Deployment Services,

493
00:24:35.060 --> 00:24:38.670
what we call WDS,
old school, OG form of that.

494
00:24:38.670 --> 00:24:41.980
Remember RIS,
Remote Install Services, right?

495
00:24:41.980 --> 00:24:42.740
So you may use RIS.

496
00:24:42.740 --> 00:24:44.070
That's an oldie but a goodie.

497
00:24:44.070 --> 00:24:47.570
Not around much anymore unless you happen
to play with NT4 in Windows 2000 on

498
00:24:47.570 --> 00:24:48.650
some occasion.

499
00:24:48.650 --> 00:24:50.970
But RIS and/or WDS back in the day.

500
00:24:50.970 --> 00:24:52.200
You may be ghosting.

501
00:24:52.200 --> 00:24:53.960
You may be using Altiris, right?

502
00:24:53.960 --> 00:24:55.950
There's different software
platforms out there.

503
00:24:55.950 --> 00:24:57.850
System Center Config Manager.

504
00:24:57.850 --> 00:25:00.550
Mike and I were having that conversation
just before we got started.

505
00:25:00.550 --> 00:25:03.370
So whatever your configuration
management solution is,

506
00:25:03.370 --> 00:25:05.390
that's where your
baselines are going to be.

507
00:25:05.390 --> 00:25:06.490
That's where you're going to store them.

508
00:25:06.490 --> 00:25:07.580
Because that's where your images are.

509
00:25:07.580 --> 00:25:10.205
So you're going to be looking at
that kind of software platform and

510
00:25:10.205 --> 00:25:11.940
tying those skills in to manage it.

511
00:25:11.940 --> 00:25:14.020
Remember my admonition to you earlier.

512
00:25:14.020 --> 00:25:15.690
That's a key vocabulary word by the way.

513
00:25:15.690 --> 00:25:17.810
Remember my admonition to you earlier.

514
00:25:17.810 --> 00:25:18.610
Right.

515
00:25:18.610 --> 00:25:21.590
Where I said to you in one
of our earlier discussions

516
00:25:21.590 --> 00:25:25.680
that you need to partner with the people
that have the skills that you need if

517
00:25:25.680 --> 00:25:27.510
you're not an expert in this technology.

518
00:25:27.510 --> 00:25:31.540
If configuration management and baselines
are just not your thing, and that's okay,

519
00:25:31.540 --> 00:25:35.150
there's nothing wrong with that, if that's
not you, you better just find the people

520
00:25:35.150 --> 00:25:37.530
in the organization that know
how to manage those systems.

521
00:25:37.530 --> 00:25:42.230
And work with them to integrate security
into those baselines, make sure

522
00:25:42.230 --> 00:25:46.280
patch management is happening, make sure
you're stripping out the hardware and

523
00:25:46.280 --> 00:25:50.100
the software that you no longer need on
those systems and by doing that you're

524
00:25:50.100 --> 00:25:54.610
gonna create a more secure and more robust
way of managing your infrastructure.

525
00:25:54.610 --> 00:25:57.480
To that end we want to talk quickly
about two terms that are important.

526
00:25:57.480 --> 00:25:58.890
Scoping and tailoring.

527
00:25:58.890 --> 00:25:59.520
Right?

528
00:25:59.520 --> 00:26:01.630
Not the tailoring that you think
of when you go to the tailor and

529
00:26:01.630 --> 00:26:04.020
they adjust your clothes for
you but it's close.

530
00:26:04.020 --> 00:26:06.070
But let's talk about scoping and
tailoring.

531
00:26:06.070 --> 00:26:08.990
So scoping is the idea of
providing through the thought

532
00:26:08.990 --> 00:26:10.640
process that we use to manage.

533
00:26:10.640 --> 00:26:14.230
Providing an enterprise with specific or
a business with specific terms and

534
00:26:14.230 --> 00:26:16.700
conditions on
the applicability of controls.

535
00:26:16.700 --> 00:26:22.010
In other words we have to make sure
that we are able to give context,

536
00:26:22.010 --> 00:26:24.260
which is really what scoping is all about.

537
00:26:24.260 --> 00:26:27.480
Give context to the organizational
thought process

538
00:26:27.480 --> 00:26:29.870
around what controls we're using and why.

539
00:26:29.870 --> 00:26:32.940
So scoping is really about creating
that context and understanding how to

540
00:26:32.940 --> 00:26:36.700
answer the question why if you wanna
think about what scoping does, right.

541
00:26:36.700 --> 00:26:41.090
When we think about tailoring, tailoring
involves an element of scoping, we're kind

542
00:26:41.090 --> 00:26:45.880
of taking the scope, the context, but
we're now narrowly focusing, tactfully,

543
00:26:45.880 --> 00:26:49.510
so that we can actually apply the controls
that are specific to the need.

544
00:26:49.510 --> 00:26:54.210
And we can then communicate effectively
as to the who, what, where, when, and

545
00:26:54.210 --> 00:26:56.260
how, notice I left out the why.

546
00:26:56.260 --> 00:27:00.880
Who, what, when, where and how about those
controls and the importance of them.

547
00:27:00.880 --> 00:27:03.000
So tailoring is really about narrowing and

548
00:27:03.000 --> 00:27:07.610
focusing on the tactical elements of
what we're going to do to implement.

549
00:27:07.610 --> 00:27:11.450
Whereas scoping is really more about
the strategic thought process and

550
00:27:11.450 --> 00:27:12.890
answering the question of why.

551
00:27:12.890 --> 00:27:13.820
Creating the context.

552
00:27:13.820 --> 00:27:16.930
And if you could marry those
two thought processes together,

553
00:27:16.930 --> 00:27:18.900
we really hit all the highlights, right?

554
00:27:18.900 --> 00:27:22.670
We hit the who, what, when, where,
why, and how, the five Ws and the H.

555
00:27:22.670 --> 00:27:26.680
But we get the thought process that is
more high level in the organization,

556
00:27:26.680 --> 00:27:31.000
more strategic about context and need, and
then we get the tactical conversation with

557
00:27:31.000 --> 00:27:34.890
the tailoring and the focus to make sure
that those controls are implemented in

558
00:27:34.890 --> 00:27:38.930
a way, that they not only are business
aligned, but they add relevancy and

559
00:27:38.930 --> 00:27:41.900
they ensure that we then are able
to understand what we need to do.

560
00:27:41.900 --> 00:27:43.280
That's right.

561
00:27:43.280 --> 00:27:45.440
So when we think about scoping and

562
00:27:45.440 --> 00:27:49.160
tailoring, we wanna look at two specific
areas that may be helpful to you.

563
00:27:49.160 --> 00:27:51.770
Some practical real world examples
I wanna share with you quickly.

564
00:27:51.770 --> 00:27:54.030
We're gonna throw up a quick web page for
you.

565
00:27:54.030 --> 00:27:56.240
Actually, two, but
we're gonna start with the first one here.

566
00:27:56.240 --> 00:27:59.770
Which is again something from NIST,
and we'll just zoom in a little bit so

567
00:27:59.770 --> 00:28:00.850
you can see that.

568
00:28:00.850 --> 00:28:04.580
And on the NIST website,
we are talking specifically about

569
00:28:04.580 --> 00:28:08.540
the Security Content Automation Protocol,
commonly called SCAP as you can see.

570
00:28:08.540 --> 00:28:12.830
And what SCAP allows us to
do is to really focus in on

571
00:28:12.830 --> 00:28:17.020
automation of scoping and tailoring
needs and concerns in the business

572
00:28:17.020 --> 00:28:20.480
to try to figure out how to create
these base lines and work with them

573
00:28:20.480 --> 00:28:24.040
in order to be able apply them inside
the organization or in the business.

574
00:28:24.040 --> 00:28:27.270
So this is one practical real
world example of scoping and

575
00:28:27.270 --> 00:28:29.750
tailoring that NIST has provided and
put out there.

576
00:28:29.750 --> 00:28:30.980
Now SCAP is not new.

577
00:28:30.980 --> 00:28:32.458
SCAP's been around.

578
00:28:32.458 --> 00:28:34.432
Well this is probably 2009 or so.

579
00:28:34.432 --> 00:28:36.930
So it's been around for
several years at this point.

580
00:28:36.930 --> 00:28:41.000
Goes through iterations every so often,
but the website as you can see talks about

581
00:28:41.000 --> 00:28:45.240
validation, content, specification,
and all the things associated with it.

582
00:28:45.240 --> 00:28:46.877
Another area that we
should look at quickly,

583
00:28:46.877 --> 00:28:49.516
just another website Mike's gonna help
me with and throw up here for us.

584
00:28:49.516 --> 00:28:53.500
Is coming to us not from this, but
rather from SANS, and you can see the CIS,

585
00:28:53.500 --> 00:28:58.385
the Critical Information Security Critical
Security Controls, currently in Version 6.

586
00:28:58.385 --> 00:29:00.090
They go through revisions every so often.

587
00:29:00.090 --> 00:29:01.840
Thank you for
zooming in there a little bit.

588
00:29:01.840 --> 00:29:02.840
They go through revisions.

589
00:29:02.840 --> 00:29:04.320
We're currently at Version 6.

590
00:29:04.320 --> 00:29:08.860
And the idea is this is a list of
the top 20 critical security controls

591
00:29:08.860 --> 00:29:14.000
that are broken up into typically five
categories or critical tenant areas,

592
00:29:14.000 --> 00:29:17.470
offense informs defense, so
the idea of being able to think about

593
00:29:17.470 --> 00:29:21.320
having a good offense and having that
defense kind of be linked to that,

594
00:29:21.320 --> 00:29:25.140
prioritizing the need in the business, and
figuring out what controls are important.

595
00:29:25.140 --> 00:29:28.390
Having metrics to measure against,
using continuous monitoring and

596
00:29:28.390 --> 00:29:32.510
automation to be able to scale, and
to scope, and tailor controls as needed,

597
00:29:32.510 --> 00:29:34.945
and you'll see there are 20
controls on the list.

598
00:29:34.945 --> 00:29:39.350
Mike kind of scrolled up and down real
quickly, so he was showing them to you.

599
00:29:39.350 --> 00:29:42.530
But the idea with these controls are that
if you go and take a look at them,

600
00:29:42.530 --> 00:29:46.360
and randomly if you'd just look at
a couple, things boundary defense there,

601
00:29:46.360 --> 00:29:50.110
CSC 12, data protection, number 13.

602
00:29:50.110 --> 00:29:52.790
Wireless access control, number 15.

603
00:29:52.790 --> 00:29:54.640
Application software security, number 18.

604
00:29:54.640 --> 00:29:55.960
You get the idea.

605
00:29:55.960 --> 00:30:00.270
These are all very important elements and
we probably have a need for all 20 but

606
00:30:00.270 --> 00:30:04.680
the reality is if we're not doing things
with web related services, we may be able

607
00:30:04.680 --> 00:30:07.800
to bypass that control, because
maybe it's just not important to us.

608
00:30:07.800 --> 00:30:11.470
So this is another example of the concept
that we can apply by looking for

609
00:30:11.470 --> 00:30:14.020
external guidance to figure how scope and
tailor.

610
00:30:14.020 --> 00:30:15.170
>> Another great episode there Adam.

611
00:30:15.170 --> 00:30:19.580
You know we looked at base lines and
really kind of took it to that next level

612
00:30:19.580 --> 00:30:23.420
by looking at baselines and
scoping those, and tailoring those down.

613
00:30:23.420 --> 00:30:26.090
Couple of great resources
we can use if we want to

614
00:30:26.090 --> 00:30:27.330
dive into that a little bit further.

615
00:30:27.330 --> 00:30:30.270
And then, back to the beginning of
the episode when we were talking

616
00:30:30.270 --> 00:30:34.500
about retention policies and some of
the things that I hadn't thought about.

617
00:30:34.500 --> 00:30:37.920
We were used to putting stuff away
in a box and putting it on a shelf.

618
00:30:37.920 --> 00:30:39.890
And now everything is
going out to the cloud and

619
00:30:39.890 --> 00:30:43.870
different ways of storing information,
electronically in the cloud or locally,

620
00:30:43.870 --> 00:30:47.980
but how about the software I use to
create or access that data ten years ago?

621
00:30:47.980 --> 00:30:49.510
Can I still access it?

622
00:30:49.510 --> 00:30:52.010
So, great information there,
we appreciate that Adam.

623
00:30:52.010 --> 00:30:55.380
Remember, if you guys ever want to
attend one of Adam's classes live

624
00:30:55.380 --> 00:30:56.200
shoot us an email.

625
00:30:56.200 --> 00:31:00.630
We can get you in touch, SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

626
00:31:00.630 --> 00:31:03.710
That's gonna do it for this episode so
signing off I'm Mike Roderick.

627
00:31:03.710 --> 00:31:06.675
>> And I'm gonna be here next time
because we have a retention policy that

628
00:31:06.675 --> 00:31:07.486
stipulates that.

629
00:31:07.486 --> 00:31:08.600
I'll see you soon.
>> He's gonna be here for seven years.

630
00:31:08.600 --> 00:31:09.726
>> I will be.

631
00:31:09.726 --> 00:31:10.643
>> We'll see you soon.

632
00:31:10.643 --> 00:31:16.220
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike discuss data handling requirements and aligning those with retention policies. They differentiate between data at rest and data in transit, and the different ways we protect each. They look at encryption as a method to protect data, both at rest and in transit.
episodes.title: Data Handling Requirements
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.088 --> 00:00:10.088
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.162 --> 00:00:15.809
Hello and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.809 --> 00:00:17.370
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:17.370 --> 00:00:19.740
Today we are doing our CISSP and

5
00:00:19.740 --> 00:00:23.760
specifically we're going to be going
into our data handling requirements.

6
00:00:23.760 --> 00:00:27.530
We've talked a little bit about data
retention in previous conversations.

7
00:00:27.530 --> 00:00:29.990
Now we're gonna look at what
those handling requirements are.

8
00:00:29.990 --> 00:00:33.070
If we're gonna keep that data around,
how do we keep it around?

9
00:00:33.070 --> 00:00:34.920
How do we protect it, keep it safe?

10
00:00:34.920 --> 00:00:37.160
And here to help us with that is Mr.
Adam Gordon.

11
00:00:37.160 --> 00:00:38.620
How you doing Adam?

12
00:00:38.620 --> 00:00:40.820
>> I'm good, I'm good, I'm excited and

13
00:00:40.820 --> 00:00:44.940
all aflutter with anticipation around
data handling requirements myself.

14
00:00:44.940 --> 00:00:47.460
So let's talk about those for
just a little bit, shall we?

15
00:00:47.460 --> 00:00:50.680
So when we think about data, and
we've had a lot to say about data,

16
00:00:50.680 --> 00:00:52.840
we've had a lot to say about retention so
far.

17
00:00:52.840 --> 00:00:54.680
Had a lot to say about
the need to protect data.

18
00:00:54.680 --> 00:00:56.800
So I think we're pretty good about that.

19
00:00:56.800 --> 00:00:59.380
But, generically, let's just remind
ourselves about the reason we're here,

20
00:00:59.380 --> 00:01:03.360
which is focusing on confidentiality,
focusing on integrity.

21
00:01:03.360 --> 00:01:05.500
Obviously availability
is part of that as well.

22
00:01:05.500 --> 00:01:09.380
But primarily when we think about data
handling and data handling requirements,

23
00:01:09.380 --> 00:01:12.630
we need to think about how we're gonna
safeguard our data when it's in motion,

24
00:01:12.630 --> 00:01:13.905
when it's at rest.

25
00:01:13.905 --> 00:01:17.070
And what are we gonna do to ensure
confidentiality first and foremost, and

26
00:01:17.070 --> 00:01:19.660
of course integrity,
and then availability?

27
00:01:19.660 --> 00:01:20.430
Don't wanna leave that out.

28
00:01:20.430 --> 00:01:22.300
That's always gonna be
an important consideration.

29
00:01:22.300 --> 00:01:26.060
So cryptography is gonna be one of those
very important tools that we can bring to

30
00:01:26.060 --> 00:01:30.540
bear in order to ensure that data is
going to be handled and secured using

31
00:01:30.540 --> 00:01:33.850
the proper thought process along with
business requirements and things of that.

32
00:01:33.850 --> 00:01:35.890
So, protection of data becomes key.

33
00:01:35.890 --> 00:01:37.510
And this is really what we're focused on.

34
00:01:37.510 --> 00:01:41.190
Data protection involves data at
rest as well as data in transit.

35
00:01:41.190 --> 00:01:43.980
Want to make sure we focus on both and
we're gonna break our conversation

36
00:01:43.980 --> 00:01:47.028
down along those lines
starting with data at rest.

37
00:01:47.028 --> 00:01:50.350
Data at rest can be defined as
data that is either in storage so

38
00:01:50.350 --> 00:01:54.420
data that is put somewhere whether
it is on a removable thumbdrive,

39
00:01:54.420 --> 00:01:58.190
so USB drive, whether it's in
a fixed drive in your machine

40
00:01:58.190 --> 00:02:01.000
out in the cloud somewhere that
we can then go access remotely.

41
00:02:01.000 --> 00:02:04.580
We're talking about data that's being
stored somewhere that we then we have to

42
00:02:04.580 --> 00:02:09.230
pull out and make available to us during
the process of actually engaging its user.

43
00:02:09.230 --> 00:02:12.100
We'll talk about data in transit
as the next stop on that road.

44
00:02:12.100 --> 00:02:14.510
Because, obviously,
once we start to consume the data and

45
00:02:14.510 --> 00:02:17.270
pull it off the device or
remove it from where it is and

46
00:02:17.270 --> 00:02:20.420
bring it back to us remotely,
we're now talking about moving data.

47
00:02:20.420 --> 00:02:21.800
Let's start with data at rest.

48
00:02:21.800 --> 00:02:26.560
Data at rest is really the idea of
focusing on data that is in some way

49
00:02:26.560 --> 00:02:30.710
being stored for later use or
continuous use but on demand.

50
00:02:30.710 --> 00:02:31.890
And so how do we deal with that?

51
00:02:31.890 --> 00:02:34.230
Well, we have physical things
we have to think about.

52
00:02:34.230 --> 00:02:38.260
Is the place where the data is secured or
rather where the data is stored secure?

53
00:02:38.260 --> 00:02:41.170
So, do we have closed
circuit TV monitoring?

54
00:02:41.170 --> 00:02:44.620
If it's in a data center with
other data that somebody may want

55
00:02:44.620 --> 00:02:46.340
do we have locks on the doors?

56
00:02:46.340 --> 00:02:47.670
Do we have guards?

57
00:02:47.670 --> 00:02:51.420
What if that data's being stored in
a cloud vendor based environment,

58
00:02:51.420 --> 00:02:53.525
in a multi-tenant scenario?

59
00:02:53.525 --> 00:02:56.320
Multi-tenant scenarios in
the cloud imply you have one or

60
00:02:56.320 --> 00:03:00.130
more customers being, using or
storing data in this case,

61
00:03:00.130 --> 00:03:04.720
and using systems, commingling in effect,
causing pools of resources.

62
00:03:04.720 --> 00:03:08.240
We want to segment that data so
that it's only available to the customer

63
00:03:08.240 --> 00:03:10.920
that owns it, so
we have to think about zoning and masking.

64
00:03:10.920 --> 00:03:13.790
These are things that we do in
the storage network to be able to

65
00:03:13.790 --> 00:03:17.470
present the data in a way that is only
available to the individual customer.

66
00:03:17.470 --> 00:03:20.600
Protecting the data from being
exposed to everybody else.

67
00:03:20.600 --> 00:03:22.840
That's a logical set of controls but

68
00:03:22.840 --> 00:03:25.600
it's also a physical
solution that we can apply.

69
00:03:25.600 --> 00:03:26.890
But then we have to do other things,

70
00:03:26.890 --> 00:03:30.380
we have to make sure that people who come
into the data center are signing in and

71
00:03:30.380 --> 00:03:33.300
are gonna be checks that they
are not bringing in information

72
00:03:33.300 --> 00:03:35.130
that may be used to
compromise our systems.

73
00:03:35.130 --> 00:03:37.430
So data at rest protection
can be complicated,

74
00:03:37.430 --> 00:03:42.830
it could be something where we potentially
are going to use offsite storage and

75
00:03:42.830 --> 00:03:47.170
have a copy, a backup of the data, that's
actively being used in our system, so

76
00:03:47.170 --> 00:03:51.550
data being used, data being consumed
is different than data at rest.

77
00:03:51.550 --> 00:03:54.760
Data that's at rest could be a backup
copy for disaster recovery and

78
00:03:54.760 --> 00:03:56.280
business continuity purposes.

79
00:03:56.280 --> 00:03:58.330
That's another form of data at rest.

80
00:03:58.330 --> 00:04:01.500
But what about when it's being
transitted between our facility and

81
00:04:01.500 --> 00:04:03.110
the location where it's gonna wind up?

82
00:04:03.110 --> 00:04:04.530
How are we protecting it then?

83
00:04:04.530 --> 00:04:07.490
Those are data in transit questions,
and we'll talk about those.

84
00:04:07.490 --> 00:04:11.440
But traditionally, we would apply
cryptography and cryptographic solutions

85
00:04:11.440 --> 00:04:15.430
to data at rest, in order to provide

some kind that's not rewritable.

539
00:25:45.780 --> 00:25:48.770
It is removable, but it's fixed,
it's gonna be in that form and not change.

540
00:25:48.770 --> 00:25:51.360
Is it going to be stored
electronically somewhere?

541
00:25:51.360 --> 00:25:54.420
Is there a physical copy of
it in a vault somewhere else?

542
00:25:54.420 --> 00:25:57.365
I use a lot of movie references when I
teach so I'm going to use another one now.

543
00:25:57.365 --> 00:25:59.190
So you ever see Reds?

544
00:25:59.190 --> 00:26:02.680
The movie with Bruce Willis and
Morgan Freeman and all of those.

545
00:26:02.680 --> 00:26:03.660
Right, the spy movie.

546
00:26:03.660 --> 00:26:04.630
So it's a great movie.

547
00:26:04.630 --> 00:26:07.750
At a certain point in the movie,
spoiler alert,

548
00:26:07.750 --> 00:26:09.670
if you havent seen the movie
stop watching right now.

549
00:26:10.800 --> 00:26:14.190
So at a certain point in the movie,
Bruce Willis who is kind of, you know,

550
00:26:14.190 --> 00:26:15.930
the focus of the first,
cuz there were two movies.

551
00:26:15.930 --> 00:26:17.068
He's the focus of the first one.

552
00:26:17.068 --> 00:26:19.645
He's a retired CIA super spy, right?

553
00:26:19.645 --> 00:26:24.500
So he's kind of the guy who could do
anything, go anywhere kind of thing.

554
00:26:24.500 --> 00:26:25.450
He's retired.

555
00:26:25.450 --> 00:26:29.560
And then he gets dragged back in to this
whole life, because of some circumstances.

556
00:26:29.560 --> 00:26:32.310
So, at a certain point,
they have to break in.

557
00:26:32.310 --> 00:26:35.880
He and the love interest that he develops,
this girl who's helping him, have to break

558
00:26:35.880 --> 00:26:42.800
into the CIA to effectively access
his personnel file to be able to find

559
00:26:42.800 --> 00:26:45.830
some information buried in his past that
leads them to understand what's happening.

560
00:26:45.830 --> 00:26:50.650
So, they go down to the vault because
the records are, you know, not electronic.

561
00:26:50.650 --> 00:26:54.100
He doesn't have a real electronic
file because he retired.

562
00:26:54.100 --> 00:26:56.280
He's effectively now like a paper file.

563
00:26:56.280 --> 00:26:59.220
So they have to go into the vault,
and in order to get into the vault,

564
00:26:59.220 --> 00:27:04.180
cuz the vault door is not working, the
access is not working, he punches a hole

565
00:27:04.180 --> 00:27:09.180
in the drywall, rips the controller out
of the wall, and opens the vault door.

566
00:27:09.180 --> 00:27:12.490
And then Ernest Borgnine, if you know who
that is, a very famous older character

567
00:27:12.490 --> 00:27:15.310
actor, is sitting there as like the keeper
of the vault, he's got all the files.

568
00:27:15.310 --> 00:27:17.370
He says oh, wow, it's so great to see you.

569
00:27:17.370 --> 00:27:19.300
And he pulls a file out of
this big filing cabinet.

570
00:27:19.300 --> 00:27:22.970
The file's like, this big, and
this high, but it's all paper.

571
00:27:22.970 --> 00:27:25.670
And he throws it on the desk,
and they open it up, and

572
00:27:25.670 --> 00:27:27.400
almost everything in there is redacted.

573
00:27:27.400 --> 00:27:30.300
All you see is this stack of
paper with black lines on it,

574
00:27:30.300 --> 00:27:31.830
there's nothing that you can see.

575
00:27:31.830 --> 00:27:34.530
But it's just really funny
because he has to go get the file

576
00:27:34.530 --> 00:27:37.870
because the only file that exists is
this old paper file, stored in a vault,

577
00:27:37.870 --> 00:27:39.950
locked up in the bottom of this building.

578
00:27:39.950 --> 00:27:41.270
So sometimes it's that.

579
00:27:41.270 --> 00:27:42.430
It's really just paper.

580
00:27:42.430 --> 00:27:44.650
But more and
more today it's going to be media.

581
00:27:44.650 --> 00:27:47.570
It's going to be electronic bits and
bytes that we have to account for.

582
00:27:47.570 --> 00:27:53.970
When you store data in multiple places and
you then are managing that data centrally,

583
00:27:53.970 --> 00:27:56.510
is the management going to apply
equally to all the copies of the data?

584
00:27:56.510 --> 00:27:58.090
This is something else
we have to think about.

585
00:27:58.090 --> 00:28:01.372
So, when we think about mobile devices and
mobile device management,

586
00:28:01.372 --> 00:28:04.928
is our data policy gonna extend to mobile
devices and safeguard the data there

587
00:28:04.928 --> 00:28:07.849
as well as safeguarding the data
that's in the system itself?

588
00:28:07.849 --> 00:28:11.641
And if we don't reach out and touch the
data there, are we really doing a good job

589
00:28:11.641 --> 00:28:14.652
of management, with handling and
requirements around that?

590
00:28:14.652 --> 00:28:15.420
We may or may not be.

591
00:28:15.420 --> 00:28:16.590
That's gonna be important.

592
00:28:16.590 --> 00:28:18.530
Are we marking the data and
classifying it?

593
00:28:18.530 --> 00:28:20.660
We talked about this as well and
why marking and

594
00:28:20.660 --> 00:28:22.640
classification is so important.

595
00:28:22.640 --> 00:28:24.440
The data has to be marked
at a certain level.

596
00:28:24.440 --> 00:28:27.230
So, we understand it's to be
treated in a certain way.

597
00:28:27.230 --> 00:28:29.680
Do we have special handling
requirements for the data?

598
00:28:29.680 --> 00:28:32.385
Yeah, you can only go into the secure
vault and see the data in there.

599
00:28:32.385 --> 00:28:33.917
You can't remove the data from the system.

600
00:28:33.917 --> 00:28:34.661
Those kind of things.

601
00:28:34.661 --> 00:28:36.018
Those will be handling requirements.

602
00:28:36.018 --> 00:28:37.740
Very important thing about it as well.

603
00:28:37.740 --> 00:28:39.610
We already talked extensively
about storing, and

604
00:28:39.610 --> 00:28:41.380
where we store data and
how to manage that.

605
00:28:41.380 --> 00:28:47.820
One of the things that often happens,
especially if we have NAS devices,

606
00:28:47.820 --> 00:28:52.770
or storage area network devices, where we
store large volumes of data, is that we

607
00:28:52.770 --> 00:28:56.140
have web interfaces today that allow us to
configure and program these systems and

608
00:28:56.140 --> 00:28:59.920
set them up for management as well
as configuration and security.

609
00:28:59.920 --> 00:29:03.010
That's all good, but the problem is that
we're not securing the web interface,

610
00:29:03.010 --> 00:29:06.470
and all we do is focus on the physical
security of the device itself.

611
00:29:06.470 --> 00:29:09.040
You know, the network connection, and
the device is sitting on a shelf,

612
00:29:09.040 --> 00:29:11.220
let's make sure we safeguard that,
let's lock up the room,

613
00:29:11.220 --> 00:29:12.940
let's not let people in there physically.

614
00:29:12.940 --> 00:29:16.380
But if we let people in there logically
through the web to connect without proper

615
00:29:16.380 --> 00:29:19.430
security protocols we've effectively
done the same thing as putting it out

616
00:29:19.430 --> 00:29:22.755
in the middle room with a big sign on it
that says free data please come and take.

617
00:29:22.755 --> 00:29:24.200
>> [LAUGH]
>> Right, because effectively if

618
00:29:24.200 --> 00:29:28.470
a user can get into the web interface and
reconstruct or control and change

619
00:29:28.470 --> 00:29:32.230
the security settings on the system, they
effectively own the data and they can copy

620
00:29:32.230 --> 00:29:34.560
it and move it and do whatever they
want with it and we would never know.

621
00:29:34.560 --> 00:29:37.210
So these are all things we have to
think about and really be aware of.

622
00:29:37.210 --> 00:29:38.340
We finally have to think about and

623
00:29:38.340 --> 00:29:41.980
ultimately wrap up our conversation
in this area with destruction.

624
00:29:41.980 --> 00:29:43.100
How do we safeguard data?

625
00:29:43.100 --> 00:29:44.030
That's all important.

626
00:29:44.030 --> 00:29:46.130
How do we get rid of data,
how do we destroy it?

627
00:29:46.130 --> 00:29:50.530
Whether we're gonna by, in fact we're
using a magnetic field to clear the data,

628
00:29:50.530 --> 00:29:53.470
whether we're gonna override it
several times by scrambling the bits

629
00:29:53.470 --> 00:29:57.460
effectively and moving them around in such
a way that they no longer are associated.

630
00:29:57.460 --> 00:30:01.560
Whether we're gonna physically destroy the
data by putting the drive into a shredder,

631
00:30:01.560 --> 00:30:05.080
a hammer mill or liquefying it in
a furnace or something like that.

632
00:30:05.080 --> 00:30:07.150
Using thermite to actually melt the drive.

633
00:30:07.150 --> 00:30:08.325
There's a cool demo for you.

634
00:30:08.325 --> 00:30:09.500
>> [LAUGH]
>> You'll have to YouTube and

635
00:30:09.500 --> 00:30:10.140
look that one up.

636
00:30:10.140 --> 00:30:11.420
That's really neat, right?

637
00:30:11.420 --> 00:30:13.128
So, you know?
The idea is, ultimately,

638
00:30:13.128 --> 00:30:16.549
that we have to figure out how to destroy
data commensurate with the level of

639
00:30:16.549 --> 00:30:18.034
protection the data requires.

640
00:30:18.034 --> 00:30:21.281
If the data is not sensitive, we don't
have to go to the trouble of liquefying it

641
00:30:21.281 --> 00:30:24.199
with a thermite grenade strapped to
the side of the hard drive, right?

642
00:30:24.199 --> 00:30:25.328
>> [LAUGH]
>> All we have to do

643
00:30:25.328 --> 00:30:28.810
is just hit the Delete button and
ensure that the data is gone.

644
00:30:28.810 --> 00:30:30.130
Now we know data is still there.

645
00:30:30.130 --> 00:30:33.350
There's remnant data, people can get it,
but if we're not really worried about that

646
00:30:33.350 --> 00:30:35.920
and all we want to do is make it
disappear from the file system so

647
00:30:35.920 --> 00:30:36.840
nobody can easily find it.

648
00:30:36.840 --> 00:30:39.380
Then that's probably
okay that's good enough.

649
00:30:39.380 --> 00:30:42.370
But if we know we need stronger
protection, we have to do other things.

650
00:30:42.370 --> 00:30:45.086
The point is,
make sure that the end of the lifecycle,

651
00:30:45.086 --> 00:30:47.805
the destruction and
the decommissioning of the data,

652
00:30:47.805 --> 00:30:51.469
is gonna be governed by the same policy
and the same level of protection for

653
00:30:51.469 --> 00:30:55.161
that data, as it was during its
lifecycle when we're actually using it.

654
00:30:55.161 --> 00:30:57.888
So we wanna make sure we apply that
thought process all the way through.

655
00:30:57.888 --> 00:30:58.562
>> Very good.

656
00:30:58.562 --> 00:31:02.817
Another great episode there, a look at
data handling requirements throughout its

657
00:31:02.817 --> 00:31:06.888
lifetime, through creation, storage and
then at the end, the destruction or

658
00:31:06.888 --> 00:31:10.740
removal of that data and also a look
at data in its different forms, right.

659
00:31:10.740 --> 00:31:13.830
Data at rest versus data in motion.

660
00:31:13.830 --> 00:31:15.690
And it's gonna be different
the way we handle it.

661
00:31:15.690 --> 00:31:18.730
We might find one solution to those both,
or we might need to handle it a little

662
00:31:18.730 --> 00:31:21.750
differently if it's at rest
versus when it's in motion.

663
00:31:21.750 --> 00:31:25.150
And of course pop culture references,
we always love those, Adam.

664
00:31:25.150 --> 00:31:26.550
So thank you for those.

665
00:31:26.550 --> 00:31:27.430
>> I try, I try.

666
00:31:27.430 --> 00:31:28.510
It's the socks.

667
00:31:28.510 --> 00:31:29.952
It's just all about the socks.

668
00:31:29.952 --> 00:31:33.340
>> [LAUGH] I hope everybody enjoyed
watching, that's gonna do it for this one.

669
00:31:33.340 --> 00:31:35.740
Signing out, oh let me tell them too,
I forgot to let them know,

670
00:31:35.740 --> 00:31:40.250
if you guys want to see Adam in one of
his classes, you want to attend one live,

671
00:31:40.250 --> 00:31:44.165
make sure you send us an e-mail
at seeAdam at it.pro.tv.

672
00:31:44.165 --> 00:31:46.300
That being said we're gonna sign off.

673
00:31:46.300 --> 00:31:47.640
I'm Mike Roderick.

674
00:31:47.640 --> 00:31:48.992
>> I'm not.

675
00:31:48.992 --> 00:31:49.991
>> We'll see you next time.

676
00:31:49.991 --> 00:31:51.349
>> Take care.

677
00:31:51.349 --> 00:31:58.080
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike talk about implementing and managing the engineering processes using secure design principles. They discuss the role of a CISSP in the system engineering process, and look at some system engineering models. They also discuss standards from NIST and ISO, and how they apply secure design principles.
episodes.title: Secure Design Principles
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.679 --> 00:00:15.140
Hello and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.140 --> 00:00:19.820
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and
today we're doing our CISSP.

4
00:00:19.820 --> 00:00:23.100
Specifically, we're gonna be looking
at secure design principles.

5
00:00:23.100 --> 00:00:28.090
We're gonna talk about implementing it and
managing an engineering process

6
00:00:28.090 --> 00:00:32.450
using secure design principles, and here
to help us with that is Mr. Adam Gordon.

7
00:00:32.450 --> 00:00:33.410
How's it going, Adam?

8
00:00:33.410 --> 00:00:33.920
>> Good, good.

9
00:00:33.920 --> 00:00:35.405
I'm feeling very secure today.

10
00:00:35.405 --> 00:00:36.350
>> [LAUGH]
>> Sorry.

11
00:00:36.350 --> 00:00:38.946
>> Hopefully engineered to be that way,
we'll see how that goes.

12
00:00:38.946 --> 00:00:40.840
So, let's talk a little
bit about implementing and

13
00:00:40.840 --> 00:00:44.670
managing an engineering life cycle using
security design principles, which if you

14
00:00:44.670 --> 00:00:48.700
could say three times quickly without
screwing up you get a gold star for it.

15
00:00:48.700 --> 00:00:50.470
So systems engineering models and

16
00:00:50.470 --> 00:00:51.840
processes is really what
we're talking about.

17
00:00:51.840 --> 00:00:55.600
When we think about systems engineering,
we're thinking about stepping back and

18
00:00:55.600 --> 00:00:59.160
looking at a slightly different
perspective than the CISSP,

19
00:00:59.160 --> 00:01:02.880
it's really taken and
thought about up until now.

20
00:01:02.880 --> 00:01:05.250
When I say up until now, what I mean
is not just in our episodes and

21
00:01:05.250 --> 00:01:08.720
our conversations until now, but
actually as a refocusing and

22
00:01:08.720 --> 00:01:13.470
a repurposing of the thought
process of the CISSP holistically.

23
00:01:13.470 --> 00:01:17.960
The rebranding of the CISSP in terms of
the changing of the number of domains, and

24
00:01:17.960 --> 00:01:21.610
the information in those domains
that occurred in early 2015,

25
00:01:21.610 --> 00:01:26.050
in April of 2015,
really changed several things.

26
00:01:26.050 --> 00:01:28.470
A lot of things stayed the same.

27
00:01:28.470 --> 00:01:30.130
We went from ten domains down to eight.

28
00:01:30.130 --> 00:01:33.420
What we called the bodies of knowledge or
the common bodies of knowledge.

29
00:01:33.420 --> 00:01:35.540
Domains are what we
generically refer to them as.

30
00:01:35.540 --> 00:01:37.170
We went from ten to eight.

31
00:01:37.170 --> 00:01:41.600
All the information that was originally
in the ten domains is still in the eight

32
00:01:41.600 --> 00:01:45.226
domains in one form or another,
re-purposed, moved around,

33
00:01:45.226 --> 00:01:46.850
shuffled if you will.

34
00:01:46.850 --> 00:01:51.320
But we've also added an entire
discussion area on systems engineering.

35
00:01:51.320 --> 00:01:54.360
We've incorporated some of the things,
such as cryptography,

36
00:01:54.360 --> 00:01:57.540
that were stand-alone domains before,
into this domain.

37
00:01:57.540 --> 00:02:00.200
So we've now just simply
taken cryptography,

38
00:02:00.200 --> 00:02:04.130
instead of having it stand on its own,
we've incorporated it up into this domain.

39
00:02:04.130 --> 00:02:07.700
Well, we've added new material with
regards to systems engineering,

40
00:02:07.700 --> 00:02:11.570
an area that the CISSP should be familiar
with, should have knowledge of and

41
00:02:11.570 --> 00:02:17.350
should be, at least at some level, able
to apply in terms of the principles and

42
00:02:17.350 --> 00:02:21.060
the design guidelines that systems
engineering will bring to the table for

43
00:02:21.060 --> 00:02:25.450
us to think about when we add security
to the systems engineering piece.

44
00:02:25.450 --> 00:02:29.375
And there is some interesting work being
done in the space both in the ISO area and

45
00:02:29.375 --> 00:02:33.495
in the NIST area in terms of developing
standards, we'll talk about some of them.

46
00:02:33.495 --> 00:02:35.486
The ISO 15288 standard, and

47
00:02:35.486 --> 00:02:40.230
the NIST standard that is also supporting
security-based system engineering.

48
00:02:40.230 --> 00:02:42.870
So we'll mention some of those and
some of the others that exist out there.

49
00:02:42.870 --> 00:02:45.279
But the beginning of our
discussion in this domain

50
00:02:46.470 --> 00:02:50.510
is really gonna take the approach of what
does it mean to be a systems engineer?

51
00:02:50.510 --> 00:02:51.900
What is that thought process?

52
00:02:51.900 --> 00:02:53.470
What are the design elements?

53
00:02:53.470 --> 00:02:54.620
What are we doing?

54
00:02:54.620 --> 00:02:56.710
Are we really becoming an architect?

55
00:02:56.710 --> 00:02:59.510
Are we really becoming somebody
who's building things?

56
00:02:59.510 --> 00:03:00.780
Are we an electrical engineer?

57
00:03:00.780 --> 00:03:02.280
I get that question sometimes.

58
00:03:02.280 --> 00:03:04.970
I have to be an electrical
engineer now to be a CISSP,

59
00:03:04.970 --> 00:03:07.190
absolutely not unless you want to be.

60
00:03:07.190 --> 00:03:09.830
But what you need to understand
is that there's a bigger,

61
00:03:09.830 --> 00:03:15.510
broader world out there than simply just
the nuts and bolts of access control and

62
00:03:15.510 --> 00:03:19.250
the nuts and bolts of making
sure that data is classified and

63
00:03:19.250 --> 00:03:22.860
that we manage assets and
have documentation for everything.

64
00:03:22.860 --> 00:03:26.990
We need to have a lot more in terms of the
depth of the conversations around how we

65
00:03:26.990 --> 00:03:31.150
build secure systems to make sure that
as we architect, as we design and

66
00:03:31.150 --> 00:03:31.765
we think through and

67
00:03:31.765 --> 00:03:36.395
ultimately implement the designs that
are what we call enterprise architecture.

68
00:03:36.395 --> 00:03:39.640
The designs that build out entire
systems for us to work with

69
00:03:39.640 --> 00:03:42.870
that we're always thinking about
security and we're bolting security on.

70
00:03:42.870 --> 00:03:46.590
And we're adding security into the mix and
all those conversations.

71
00:03:46.590 --> 00:03:50.430
That's truly what the security systems
engineering perspective is all about and

72
00:03:50.430 --> 00:03:52.900
that's the thought process
we're gonna examine here for

73
00:03:52.900 --> 00:03:54.890
a few minutes as we
begin our conversation.

74
00:03:54.890 --> 00:03:58.465
So when you think about systems
engineering models and processes,

75
00:03:58.465 --> 00:04:01.861
we think about the ISO standard,
the ISO 15288 standard.

76
00:04:01.861 --> 00:04:04.160
We're gonna take a look at
that quickly on the web.

77
00:04:04.160 --> 00:04:07.310
So we're gonna put that up for you, in
just a minute we'll be able to see that.

78
00:04:07.310 --> 00:04:10.440
What you'll see there, and
Mike will be able to zoom in I'm sure for

79
00:04:10.440 --> 00:04:11.820
us there in just a moment.

80
00:04:11.820 --> 00:04:14.108
What we're looking at, not quite
that much, but there we go, good.

81
00:04:14.108 --> 00:04:16.280
>> [LAUGH].
>> This is live, after all, remember.

82
00:04:16.280 --> 00:04:18.530
Right up to the top of the screen.

83
00:04:18.530 --> 00:04:21.264
So what you'll see there, it's actually
go right to the top, actually.

84
00:04:21.264 --> 00:04:24.500

but the idea is that each of those

244
00:12:20.777 --> 00:12:24.014
has an associated numerical
value called a protection key.

245
00:12:24.014 --> 00:12:27.479
And the idea then is that each
process is then gonna be given access

246
00:12:27.479 --> 00:12:30.881
to a certain amount of memory based
on the use of that shared key,

247
00:12:30.881 --> 00:12:34.482
that key that effectively gives
you access to those memory blocks.

248
00:12:34.482 --> 00:12:38.150
And by using protection key, it's very
similar to the idea of using a private

249
00:12:38.150 --> 00:12:42.102
key, what we would think of asymmetric key
and we'll talk more about that in some of

250
00:12:42.102 --> 00:12:45.508
our coming episodes when we get to
cryptography as a discussion topic.

251
00:12:45.508 --> 00:12:50.265
We're going to use effectively a private
key to access secure memory spaces and

252
00:12:50.265 --> 00:12:54.809
only allow the process, the running
application or running process that is

253
00:12:54.809 --> 00:12:58.937
accessing the memory to have access
to that data if they have the key.

254
00:12:58.937 --> 00:13:00.934
They don't have the key,
they can't access the data.

255
00:13:00.934 --> 00:13:05.395
As a result again, we keep bad processes,
malware, things like that that may get

256
00:13:05.395 --> 00:13:09.082
into the system from accessing
sensitive data stored in real time,

257
00:13:09.082 --> 00:13:10.519
dynamically available.

258
00:13:10.519 --> 00:13:14.656
Cuz in theory, the logic is the malware
process won't have the key at least it

259
00:13:14.656 --> 00:13:16.640
shouldn't, anyway, hopefully.

260
00:13:16.640 --> 00:13:18.233
So this is called protection keying,

261
00:13:18.233 --> 00:13:20.483
these are different memory
protection techniques.

00:13:20.483 --> 00:13:23.833
We wanna make sure we're aware of them and

00:13:23.833 --> 00:13:26.834
because it is important as we said,
as we begin to talk about,

00:13:26.834 --> 00:13:29.635

00:13:29.635 --> 00:13:32.730
We have to understand all the moving
parts and the processes to go and

00:13:32.730 --> 00:13:36.532
making them to work together and how they

00:13:36.532 --> 00:13:38.451
what we are talking about on this regard.

268
00:13:38.451 --> 00:13:41.726
Address space layout
randomization as I said, ASLR.

269
00:13:41.726 --> 00:13:46.031
So I mentioned a moment ago, the idea of
randomly scattering data within the memory

270
00:13:46.031 --> 00:13:50.152
map and then keeping track of where we put
it, so we can pull it back together when

271
00:13:50.152 --> 00:13:52.943
we need it, but
not giving anybody else access to it.

272
00:13:52.943 --> 00:13:53.707
In other words,

00:13:53.707 --> 00:13:56.878
the process that owns the data will

00:13:56.878 --> 00:14:01.018
Marking where it puts it, but not giving
access to any other processes for that

275
00:14:01.018 --> 00:14:04.986
data unless they go through and request

00:14:04.986 --> 00:14:08.202
Address space layout randomization,
called ASLR.

00:14:08.202 --> 00:14:10.900
It's used in more modern versions

00:14:10.900 --> 00:14:14.155
So for instance, in Windows 2008, in 2012,

00:14:14.155 --> 00:14:19.060
in 2016, server 2016, we use ASLR

00:14:19.060 --> 00:14:22.266
We also wanna think about storage,

00:14:22.266 --> 00:14:24.413
storage, but

00:14:24.413 --> 00:14:28.290
I mentioned cache or

cache as some people often refer to it,
but the cache or

00:14:31.856 --> 00:14:37.190
memory cache is gonna be an onboard,

00:14:37.190 --> 00:14:40.771
Small area of memory that is used to

00:14:40.771 --> 00:14:44.408

00:14:44.408 --> 00:14:45.057

00:14:45.057 --> 00:14:47.658
We store information we need

00:14:49.295 --> 00:14:50.462
Fetching from the cache,

00:14:57.367 --> 00:15:00.811

00:15:00.811 --> 00:15:04.872

00:15:04.872 --> 00:15:09.083

00:15:09.083 --> 00:15:12.577
There may be a level one or a level one

00:15:12.577 --> 00:15:14.553
level three cache built into your system.

00:15:14.553 --> 00:15:16.399
So, it really just depends

00:15:16.399 --> 00:15:19.498
So you could think about those things and

00:15:19.498 --> 00:15:21.646
We may also have what's

00:15:21.646 --> 00:15:25.837
Virtually memory is often referred

00:15:25.837 --> 00:15:27.846

00:15:27.846 --> 00:15:31.796

00:15:39.594 --> 00:15:42.032

00:15:42.032 --> 00:15:44.981
This is done by using secondary storage.

00:15:44.981 --> 00:15:48.395
In effect, we're writing data

00:15:48.395 --> 00:15:51.463
Typically, a local hard drive, that's
more often than not where we put that.

00:15:51.463 --> 00:15:54.946
So when you hear virtual memory, we're

00:15:54.946 --> 00:15:56.711
That's what it's often referred to as.

00:15:56.711 --> 00:15:58.290

Which are the instructions of

00:16:34.280 --> 00:16:36.660
This would be a bit of

00:16:36.660 --> 00:16:39.250
Not to physically apply power

00:16:39.250 --> 00:16:43.030

00:16:43.030 --> 00:16:43.660
talking about.

00:16:43.660 --> 00:16:46.840
And the instructions to do that

00:16:46.840 --> 00:16:50.180
So, it has to be stored in read-only

00:16:50.180 --> 00:16:53.220

00:16:53.220 --> 00:16:56.800
And as power comes on, we're able to then

00:16:56.800 --> 00:16:58.830

00:16:58.830 --> 00:17:02.750
And then start operating against it in

00:17:02.750 --> 00:17:04.390
whatever needs to happen

00:17:04.390 --> 00:17:05.790
So, that is called firmware.

00:17:06.910 --> 00:17:10.820
Generically, you often think of

00:17:10.820 --> 00:17:11.760
It's more than that,

00:17:11.760 --> 00:17:16.350

00:17:22.510 --> 00:17:25.460

00:17:25.460 --> 00:17:27.560

15 seconds in says sorry,

00:17:42.730 --> 00:17:46.811

Schedules task swapping,

00:18:59.840 --> 00:19:03.590
These are the four things that the system

00:19:03.590 --> 00:19:05.420
One more time, just so

00:19:05.420 --> 00:19:08.865
Loads and runs binary programs,
schedules task swapping,

00:19:08.865 --> 00:19:13.255

location of files on the hard drive so

00:19:13.255 --> 00:19:17.779

00:19:17.779 --> 00:19:19.965

00:19:24.285 --> 00:19:26.290
This is what the system kernel does.

How all this comes together

00:19:56.210 --> 00:20:00.430

00:20:00.430 --> 00:20:03.570

then a security architecture for

A security architecture for

VoIP would be another big area,

We will have detailed specifications

467
00:23:45.630 --> 00:23:48.209
It means that they actually
may be involved in managing

468
00:23:48.209 --> 00:23:51.079
the teams that implement those systems,
probably do that.

469
00:23:51.079 --> 00:23:55.399
They maybe involved in drafting not just
the policy but maybe the procedures as

470
00:23:55.399 --> 00:23:58.344
well as the controls that
are gonna be used to audit and

471
00:23:58.344 --> 00:24:01.571
make sure those procedures
are being followed properly.

472
00:24:01.571 --> 00:24:03.313
Probably do elements of that.

473
00:24:03.313 --> 00:24:06.099
But again you may not actually
build the system start to finish.

474
00:24:06.099 --> 00:24:08.260
It's a highly specialized set of skills.

475
00:24:08.260 --> 00:24:09.470
So we want to just be aware of that and

476
00:24:09.470 --> 00:24:12.120
be thinking about that as
part of the overarching

477
00:24:12.120 --> 00:24:14.890
thought process that we talked about
with architecture integration.

478
00:24:14.890 --> 00:24:17.790
We also want to be thinking about
common security services that are gonna

479
00:24:17.790 --> 00:24:20.800
be provided, when we think about security,
we think about things.

480
00:24:20.800 --> 00:24:22.020
Some of them I already mentioned.

481
00:24:22.020 --> 00:24:24.660
But we think about things
like access control.

482
00:24:24.660 --> 00:24:26.380
We think about integrity services.

483
00:24:26.380 --> 00:24:28.620
We think about cryptographic services.

484
00:24:28.620 --> 00:24:30.270
We think about boundary control.

485
00:24:30.270 --> 00:24:31.600
What is the external boundary?

486
00:24:31.600 --> 00:24:33.040
What's the internal boundary?

487
00:24:33.040 --> 00:24:36.290
Maybe creating a DMZ would be one way
to think about boundary control and

488
00:24:36.290 --> 00:24:37.960
differentiating between them.

489
00:24:37.960 --> 00:24:40.680
A DMZ stands for
demilitarized zone, by the way.

490
00:24:40.680 --> 00:24:43.970
This is the area we create
where we exclude the external

491
00:24:43.970 --> 00:24:47.120
part of the network from seeing
the internal part of the network directly.

492
00:24:47.120 --> 00:24:50.878
But rather build a common area that's
not quite private, not quite public.

493
00:24:50.878 --> 00:24:54.346
And then we allow information to be
exchanged inside that area securely and

494
00:24:54.346 --> 00:24:55.960
confidentially typically.

495
00:24:55.960 --> 00:24:59.610
But we have firewalls typically on either
side of that boundary so that way we can

496
00:24:59.610 --> 00:25:02.580
differentiate and demarcate what
is internal, what is external.

497
00:25:02.580 --> 00:25:06.730
This is what the DMZ represents, and
boundary control is one security service

498
00:25:06.730 --> 00:25:10.050
that we may be providing as part
of an integrated architecture.

499
00:25:10.050 --> 00:25:12.320
We also wanna think about security zones,
and

500
00:25:12.320 --> 00:25:15.195
I mentioned the DMZ as one
example of a security zone.

501
00:25:15.195 --> 00:25:19.375
Security zones allow us to specify
what takes place in that area.

502
00:25:19.375 --> 00:25:22.865
Is it highly confidential information,
do we have to process it securely?

503
00:25:22.865 --> 00:25:25.935
Or can we let people walk around and
see whatever's there because it's just

504
00:25:25.935 --> 00:25:28.615
publicly available,
we don't worry about it.

505
00:25:28.615 --> 00:25:32.625
A security zone is really just that area
that we specify certain activity and

506
00:25:32.625 --> 00:25:34.425
certain behaviors will or
will not be allowed within.

507
00:25:34.425 --> 00:25:37.630
This is something else you want to
think about and be aware of as well.

508
00:25:37.630 --> 00:25:40.790
And we also have certain kinds of
frameworks that help us to guide through

509
00:25:40.790 --> 00:25:42.490
these architecture discussions.

510
00:25:42.490 --> 00:25:46.120
We have guidance, in other words, we can
add to the mix and give to the security

511
00:25:46.120 --> 00:25:49.478
practitioner, the security professional,
the security architect.

512
00:25:49.478 --> 00:25:51.929
So that they can figure out
how to do these things and

513
00:25:51.929 --> 00:25:55.160
learn from the examples that
have already gone before them.

514
00:25:55.160 --> 00:25:56.960
Things like the Zachman Framework,

515
00:25:56.960 --> 00:25:59.920
the Zachman Framework is one kind
of framework that exists out there.

516
00:25:59.920 --> 00:26:03.520
It is a framework that allows us to
understand how to do security architecture

517
00:26:03.520 --> 00:26:04.650
and security design.

518
00:26:04.650 --> 00:26:06.861
There's also SABSA, SABSA, stands for

519
00:26:06.861 --> 00:26:10.284
Sherwood Applied Business
Security Architecture framework.

520
00:26:10.284 --> 00:26:12.542
SABSA is just another framework
that exists out there.

521
00:26:12.542 --> 00:26:16.951
It's a holistic lifecycle framework for
developing security architecture and

522
00:26:16.951 --> 00:26:20.721
looking at different levels of
integration that we have to achieve.

523
00:26:20.721 --> 00:26:24.379
There are going to be a total of six
architectural views in the SABSA

524
00:26:24.379 --> 00:26:29.080
model that are used to represent different
elements of architectural design.

525
00:26:29.080 --> 00:26:31.880
And so we can apply that level
of detail if we choose to.

526
00:26:31.880 --> 00:26:36.000
There's also something known as TOGAF,
the open group architecture framework.

527
00:26:36.000 --> 00:26:39.520
TOGAF is a very popular framework as well,
again, for security architecture.

528
00:26:39.520 --> 00:26:42.910
You can look up any or all of these
frameworks simply by going out on the Web

529
00:26:42.910 --> 00:26:45.220
and reading up about them
if you're interested.

530
00:26:45.220 --> 00:26:47.710
You would have to have just a general
sense of the fact that there

531
00:26:47.710 --> 00:26:49.910
are frameworks that exist and
can be applied.

532
00:26:49.910 --> 00:26:53.510
But I wouldn't spend a huge amount of time
trying to spend the intricate details

533
00:26:53.510 --> 00:26:55.370
of any of these frameworks if I was you.

534
00:26:55.370 --> 00:26:59.080
In this particular area,
this particular discussion element,

535
00:26:59.080 --> 00:27:01.740
we really just want to raise awareness
overall of the fact that security

536
00:27:01.740 --> 00:27:04.850
architecture is made up of
various components and parts.

537
00:27:04.850 --> 00:27:06.960
And there are handbooks or
guidebooks, if you will,

538
00:27:06.960 --> 00:27:11.070
frameworks can fill in this category of
knowledge for us to give guidance to us,

539
00:27:11.070 --> 00:27:13.510
but they may not be necessarily
something you specialize in.

540
00:27:13.510 --> 00:27:17.340
And you would not wanna spend a huge
amount of time getting familiar with them,

541
00:27:17.340 --> 00:27:20.300
with regards to trying to prepare for
the CISSP exam.

542
00:27:20.300 --> 00:27:22.780
But knowledge of them would be
very helpful and very beneficial.

543
00:27:22.780 --> 00:27:24.240
So just be aware of that.

544
00:27:24.240 --> 00:27:25.690
There may be something like ITIL.

545
00:27:25.690 --> 00:27:30.040
We've talked about ITIL in some of our
prior episodes, IT infrastructure library.

546
00:27:30.040 --> 00:27:33.370
ITIL itself is a customer service,
customer-centered framework

547
00:27:33.370 --> 00:27:36.680
with regards to how to manage
the provisioning of IT services.

548
00:27:36.680 --> 00:27:40.200
But it also deals with security
aspects of the architecture, and

549
00:27:40.200 --> 00:27:43.630
creating a service-oriented
architecture is part of

550
00:27:43.630 --> 00:27:45.660
how we would create an enterprise
security architecture.

551
00:27:45.660 --> 00:27:48.390
So ITIL can offer some
guidance to us as well.

552
00:27:48.390 --> 00:27:51.330
And the five stages of ITIL,
we've talked about them before,

553
00:27:51.330 --> 00:27:53.720
are probably worth mentioning
again here quickly.

554
00:27:53.720 --> 00:27:59.670
The idea of being able to go in and think
about service strategy, service design,

555
00:27:59.670 --> 00:28:04.640
service transition, service operation,
as well as continual service improvement,

556
00:28:04.640 --> 00:28:07.450
these are the five areas
of the ITIL framework.

557
00:28:07.450 --> 00:28:11.985
And as we think about ITIL, we think about
the way we go from strategy all the way

558
00:28:11.985 --> 00:28:16.066
through to inventing and
designing that model, that's the design.

559
00:28:16.066 --> 00:28:19.343
We think about transitioning building,
we think about operation, so

560
00:28:19.343 --> 00:28:20.607
we think about going live.

561
00:28:20.607 --> 00:28:24.039
And then we think about constantly
re-envisioning that and revisiting that,

562
00:28:24.039 --> 00:28:27.220
so we do continual service
improvements to make it better.

563
00:28:27.220 --> 00:28:30.700
And so as a result of that,
that's what we're ultimately gonna do when

564
00:28:30.700 --> 00:28:33.690
we think about ITIL,
that whole holistic vision.

565
00:28:33.690 --> 00:28:36.800
The whole holistic solution
is what comes to bear there.

566
00:28:36.800 --> 00:28:40.440
>> Very good, Adam, that's a great
look at security model concepts.

567
00:28:40.440 --> 00:28:42.840
I know we got more to go,
we haven't finished,

568
00:28:42.840 --> 00:28:45.260
we haven't even come close,
maybe to getting through all of that.

569
00:28:45.260 --> 00:28:49.104
But a great start, we got to look at some
of those core components in a system.

570
00:28:49.104 --> 00:28:52.439
We talked about system security
architecture as well as enterprise

571
00:28:52.439 --> 00:28:54.779
security architecture and
then we broke down or

572
00:28:54.779 --> 00:28:58.814
we mentioned some of those frameworks that
you might be interested in that can help

573
00:28:58.814 --> 00:29:01.467
you if you have to get involved
in the design process.

574
00:29:01.467 --> 00:29:05.460
Great information, looking forward to
the next episode but for this one.

575
00:29:05.460 --> 00:29:07.750
And that's gonna have to do it,
we are out of time.

576
00:29:07.750 --> 00:29:10.940
Remember, if you guys want to
attend one of Adam's classes live,

00:29:10.940 --> 00:29:14.830
make sure you shoot us

578
00:29:14.830 --> 00:29:16.730
Signing off for now, I'm Mike Roderick.

579
00:29:16.730 --> 00:29:17.640
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike define five security model categories that CISSPs should be familiar with. They then look at specific models including Bell–LaPadula, Biba, and Clark-Wilson. They also talk about requirements, both functional and non-functional, and how to gather this information. They finish up by discussing certification and accreditation, and looking at evaluation systems used to rank the security and confidence we have in a system.

1

2

Hello and welcome to another

I'm your host Mike Rodrick and

00:00:19.300 --> 00:00:20.590
And specifically,

we're gonna be continuing on our

13
00:00:34.280 --> 00:00:35.470
Let's jump in as Mike was saying.

14
00:00:35.470 --> 00:00:38.460
So we wanna talk about types
of security models and

15

really define that a little bit more, give
us a sense of what those models look like.

16
00:00:43.530 --> 00:00:46.550
And speaking of models, what we're gonna
do is actually take a look right now

17
00:00:46.550 --> 00:00:48.890
While we're talking about them,
put a bullet list up so

18
00:00:48.890 --> 00:00:50.230
we can talk through them with you.

19
00:00:50.230 --> 00:00:51.240
It's always good to see them.

20
00:00:51.240 --> 00:00:53.900
It's always good to understand them, but
it's better to have a list and then be

21
00:00:53.900 --> 00:00:57.800
able to hear the definition, and associate
the definition with the model type.

22
00:00:57.800 --> 00:00:59.570
So we've got five we're gonna go through.

23
00:00:59.570 --> 00:01:02.180
You'll see them in the screen,
on the screen in front of you.

24
00:01:02.180 --> 00:01:03.790
Let's start with state machine model.

25
00:01:03.790 --> 00:01:08.640
The state machine model is effectively
gonna describe The behavior of a system

26
00:01:08.640 --> 00:01:10.970
as it moves between one state at another.

27
00:01:10.970 --> 00:01:14.790
In effect as the machine is
gonna be doing various things

28
00:01:14.790 --> 00:01:18.810
we're gonna be using the state machine
model to describe what they are going from

29
00:01:18.810 --> 00:01:20.860
one known state to another known state.

30
00:01:20.860 --> 00:01:24.470
The purpose essentially is to define
the actions that should be permitted

31
00:01:24.470 --> 00:01:28.070
to allow the system to carry out certain
activities and do certain things.

32
00:01:28.070 --> 00:01:30.520
But keeping in mind we
are always focused on security.

33
00:01:30.520 --> 00:01:34.770
So we wanted to find those actions in
those states from a security stand point.

34
00:01:34.770 --> 00:01:37.460
So that we never leave the system or
operate the system or

35
00:01:37.460 --> 00:01:42.090
in any way interact with it in a way that
is unsecure or nonsecure, or insecure,

36
00:01:42.090 --> 00:01:44.420
whatever term would make sense there.

37
00:01:44.420 --> 00:01:48.510
The goal is to preserver the security of
the system at all times in other words.

38
00:01:48.510 --> 00:01:51.670
That's what the state machine
model helps us to understand.

39
00:01:51.670 --> 00:01:55.900
A multi level lattice model,
item number two on our list.

40
00:01:55.900 --> 00:01:59.730
Describe strict layers of subjects and
objects, remember that subjects and

41
00:01:59.730 --> 00:02:03.640
objects are what we often use,
the terms we use, to interact between or

42
00:02:03.640 --> 00:02:05.320
to talk about the difference between.

43
00:02:05.320 --> 00:02:09.970
Users and data, subjects are users
traditionally in our discussion,

44
00:02:09.970 --> 00:02:12.980
objects typically is going
to be used to refer to data,

45
00:02:12.980 --> 00:02:17.600
keeping in mind that a service, an
application may proxy, may make a request,

46
00:02:17.600 --> 00:02:21.950
on behalf of a user, so a service or
an application may also be a subject.

47
00:02:21.950 --> 00:02:23.350
At certain points in time.

48
00:02:23.350 --> 00:02:28.100
But, generically, subjects are seen as
users, objects are gonna be seen as data.

49
00:02:28.100 --> 00:02:31.990
So multi-level lattice models
describe strict layers of object and

50
00:02:31.990 --> 00:02:36.750
subject interaction, and defines, clearly,
the rules allowed or not allowed.

51
00:02:36.750 --> 00:02:38.820
The rules, in other words,
of operation, and

52
00:02:38.820 --> 00:02:42.505
how we interact between subjects and
objects.

53
00:02:42.505 --> 00:02:46.600
Multi-level Lattice models are really
gonna define for us unequivocally

54
00:02:46.600 --> 00:02:50.730
What subjects and objects, users and data,
can do when they interact with each other.

55
00:02:50.730 --> 00:02:54.060
And we do so based on what we know as
rules, and we'll talk more about that and

56
00:02:54.060 --> 00:02:54.945
how that works in a bit.

57
00:02:54.945 --> 00:02:57.860
Non-interference models.

58
00:02:57.860 --> 00:03:01.900
The goal here is to be able to
effectively ensure that inputs,

59
00:03:01.900 --> 00:03:04.340
what we call high level actions.

60
00:03:04.340 --> 00:03:06.660
High level actions are inputs.

61
00:03:06.660 --> 00:03:11.710
So high level actions do not determine
what low level users can see,

62
00:03:11.710 --> 00:03:13.200
in other words, output.

63
00:03:13.200 --> 00:03:17.370
So what we're dealing with here with
non interference models is making sure

64
00:03:17.370 --> 00:03:20.990
that high level actions or
inputs that are coming into the system

65
00:03:20.990 --> 00:03:24.980
are not going to exclusively
determine what users get to see.

66
00:03:24.980 --> 00:03:28.220
In other words we have to make sure
that a non interference model's,

67
00:03:28.220 --> 00:03:33.400
That we are not allowing input to
effectively block or modify or

68
00:03:33.400 --> 00:03:38.160
allow or disallow output to
users exclusively by itself.

69
00:03:38.160 --> 00:03:40.300
We have to mix in other things,
in other words, right?

70
00:03:40.300 --> 00:03:46.840
So, a non-interference model would
say that, if I hit the Delete key

71
00:03:46.840 --> 00:03:51.650
that I should not delete a system file
without first prompting in effect, right?

72
00:03:51.650 --> 00:03:56.200
To give the user some input and as a
result rather take input from the system,

73
00:03:56.200 --> 00:04:00.540
give output to the user in a way that does
not automatically execute that activity,

74
00:04:00.540 --> 00:04:03.160
but rather Gives them
the ability to interact, and

75
00:04:03.160 --> 00:04:06.050
gives them information that they
can then use to make a decision.

76
00:04:06.050 --> 00:04:08.890
This is the non-interference model.

77
00:04:08.890 --> 00:04:11.600
We also have the matrix-based models,
going down the list.

78
00:04:11.600 --> 00:04:12.740
So a matrix-based model.

79
00:04:13.890 --> 00:04:15.960
We think here about
an access control matrix,

80
00:04:15.960 --> 00:04:19.560
this really what a matrix-based
model was going to be talking about.

81
00:04:19.560 --> 00:04:24.790
An access control matrix, excuse me,
is a two-dimensional table.

82
00:04:24.790 --> 00:04:29.110
Effectively a table that allows subjects
and objects to be related to each other.

83
00:04:29.110 --> 00:04:30.950
So the idea is that we
would have subjects.

84
00:04:30.950 --> 00:04:33.180
We would have users, or groups of users.

85
00:04:33.180 --> 00:04:34.510
And we would have data.

86
00:04:34.510 --> 00:04:38.100
Think of it as maybe as a list
of users on one side, and

87
00:04:38.100 --> 00:04:40.240
a list of files on the other.

88
00:04:40.240 --> 00:04:40.800
Right.
>> Mm-hm.

89
00:04:40.800 --> 00:04:42.800
>> And effectively how the two interact.

90
00:04:42.800 --> 00:04:45.790
Does Billy have read
only access to file one?

91
00:04:45.790 --> 00:04:47.790
Or does Billy have full control?

92
00:04:47.790 --> 00:04:51.110
That would be the idea behind
a matrix-based model or

93
00:04:51.110 --> 00:04:55.800
an access control matrix that allows us
to relate subjects and objects together

94
00:04:55.800 --> 00:05:00.120
to allow us to understand how ultimately
the two interact, or in some cases how

95
00:05:00.120 --> 00:05:03.870
they don't interact cuz want to make
sure we're aware of that as well.

96
00:05:03.870 --> 00:05:07.520
Information flow models,
the last model down on the list.

97
00:05:07.520 --> 00:05:10.000
This focuses on how
information is allowed or

98
00:05:10.000 --> 00:05:12.750
not allowed to move between
individual objects.

99
00:05:12.750 --> 00:05:17.820
In other words, excuse me, between
individual subjects, rather, excuse me.

100
00:05:17.820 --> 00:05:21.980
Information flow models are really how
information is allowed to be processed and

101
00:05:21.980 --> 00:05:24.960
moved and
shared among users within the system.

102
00:05:24.960 --> 00:05:25.680
What is the flow?

103
00:05:25.680 --> 00:05:29.460
What is the process of that information
moving from place to place?

104
00:05:29.460 --> 00:05:32.580
So we're looking at information and
management of information.

105
00:05:32.580 --> 00:05:36.100
And how that information is then
controlled is what information flow models

106
00:05:36.100 --> 00:05:36.980
are all about.

107
00:05:36.980 --> 00:05:40.820
So we wanna be thinking about all
of these five kinds of models,

108
00:05:40.820 --> 00:05:42.960
making sure we understand what they are.

109
00:05:42.960 --> 00:05:46.960
Making sure we have a good understanding
of them, because the types of security

110
00:05:46.960 --> 00:05:51.020
models that we use, the five models that

does when it is being delivered.

571
00:27:16.950 --> 00:27:19.310
And we have to give that
functional statement,

572
00:27:19.310 --> 00:27:21.090
what the system is capable of doing.

573
00:27:21.090 --> 00:27:24.870
We have to give that to the stakeholder,
and they have to sign off on that,

574
00:27:24.870 --> 00:27:27.930
they have to accept
the system certification.

575
00:27:27.930 --> 00:27:30.270
Because if they accept
the system certification,

576
00:27:30.270 --> 00:27:32.060
they accept the system as delivered.

577
00:27:32.060 --> 00:27:35.540
They then can go ahead and decide to
turn the system on and operate it.

578
00:27:35.540 --> 00:27:38.310
When they do that they
are accrediting the system.

579
00:27:38.310 --> 00:27:42.500
Accreditation is the act of acceptance
of the system as delivered.

580
00:27:42.500 --> 00:27:46.670
As certified in order to then operate
the system with all the bells, whistles,

581
00:27:46.670 --> 00:27:48.290
bumps, and the works that go with it.

582
00:27:48.290 --> 00:27:53.180
It's the act of the stakeholder
accepting the system as certified for

583
00:27:53.180 --> 00:27:55.770
actual operation,
that's what accreditation is.

584
00:27:55.770 --> 00:28:00.480
So systems must be certified
in order to be accredited, but

585
00:28:00.480 --> 00:28:04.520
not all systems are accredited
once they are certified.

586
00:28:04.520 --> 00:28:05.970
So think about the logic of that.

587
00:28:05.970 --> 00:28:09.000
In order to operate a system,
it must be first certified.

588
00:28:09.000 --> 00:28:09.920
Okay, we get that.

589
00:28:09.920 --> 00:28:12.870
You gotta tell me what the system's
capable of doing before I decide whether

590
00:28:12.870 --> 00:28:14.270
I wanna turn it on and do that.

591
00:28:14.270 --> 00:28:15.130
That's certification.

592
00:28:16.150 --> 00:28:17.520
When we certify a system,

593
00:28:17.520 --> 00:28:19.850
that's not a guarantee that
a system will be accredited.

594
00:28:19.850 --> 00:28:22.710
That's not a guarantee that
the stakeholder will accept the system as

595
00:28:22.710 --> 00:28:24.980
delivered and
choose to operate the system.

596
00:28:24.980 --> 00:28:27.960
Because now what we're really
talking about is acceptance of risk.

597
00:28:27.960 --> 00:28:30.510
And we have to link the idea
of risk to certification and

598
00:28:30.510 --> 00:28:33.920
accreditation, because just
because the system is certified

599
00:28:33.920 --> 00:28:36.590
doesn't mean that we want to
operate that system that way.

600
00:28:36.590 --> 00:28:39.940
We may not be willing to accredit
the system, to turn it on,

601
00:28:39.940 --> 00:28:41.250
given the certification.

602
00:28:41.250 --> 00:28:46.000
We may feel that's not acceptable, or the
system may have taken so long to become

603
00:28:46.000 --> 00:28:50.380
a viable system to be certified that it no
longer meets the operational criteria and

604
00:28:50.380 --> 00:28:53.310
so we're not going to accredit it,
give it the right to operate,

605
00:28:53.310 --> 00:28:54.540
in order to turn it on.

606
00:28:54.540 --> 00:28:57.410
Because if we did it wouldn't meet
the mission objectives we have.

607
00:28:57.410 --> 00:29:00.390
So this is a potential conundrum,
a potential problem for us.

608
00:29:00.390 --> 00:29:02.190
Systems can be certified, but

609
00:29:02.190 --> 00:29:05.780
certification does not necessarily
equate to accreditation.

610
00:29:05.780 --> 00:29:07.270
So I want to think about that and
be aware of that.

611
00:29:07.270 --> 00:29:10.210
It's very, very important as we
continue this thought process of

612
00:29:10.210 --> 00:29:14.130
"Hey how do I effectively know whether a
system does what I want it to do, right"?

613
00:29:14.130 --> 00:29:16.160
The evaluation criteria tell us that, but

614
00:29:16.160 --> 00:29:19.590
we also have to map to the requirements
associated with that to understand that.

615
00:29:19.590 --> 00:29:23.490
And we go through different certification
phases in order to be able to figure out

616
00:29:23.490 --> 00:29:26.740
what that ultimately looks like, and
we walk through that process certifying

617
00:29:26.740 --> 00:29:30.140
systems, and then maybe ultimately
crediting them as we go.

618
00:29:30.140 --> 00:29:33.030
If management decides to accept
the system as delivered.

619
00:29:33.030 --> 00:29:33.740
As certified and

620
00:29:33.740 --> 00:29:36.910
accept the risk of running it,
we say the system has been accredited.

621
00:29:36.910 --> 00:29:38.410
Very important for us to think about.

we have three more things

638
00:30:02.880 --> 00:30:06.340
So when we think about certification
accreditation, we also want to think about

639
00:30:06.340 --> 00:30:09.960
is, we go back to that idea, circle

640
00:30:09.960 --> 00:30:12.600
And we're gonna bring that forward, we're

00:30:12.600 --> 00:30:15.250
which we effectively develop

642
00:30:15.250 --> 00:30:18.060
There have been three systems

00:30:18.060 --> 00:30:20.480
information security evaluation criteria.

644
00:30:20.480 --> 00:30:23.530
The original one is something I

00:30:23.530 --> 00:30:25.860

00:30:25.860 --> 00:30:28.785

00:30:28.785 --> 00:30:32.135

00:30:32.135 --> 00:30:34.845
We actually showed you

649
00:30:34.845 --> 00:30:37.635
So I wanna go back through those
