650
00:30:37.635 --> 00:30:41.625
The TCSEC stands for Trusted
Computer System Evaluation Criteria.

651
00:30:41.625 --> 00:30:45.175
It's commonly called the Orange Book
because there was a series of books

652
00:30:45.175 --> 00:30:49.235
out by IBM back in the 1970s that
helped us to understand system and

653
00:30:49.235 --> 00:30:50.610
security architecture.

654
00:30:50.610 --> 00:30:52.950
Everyone of them had
a color coded cover and

655
00:30:52.950 --> 00:30:56.360
the bulk of them had been lost to the
the mist of time but the Orange Book and

656
00:30:56.360 --> 00:30:58.190
the red book were the two
that really stood out.

657
00:30:58.190 --> 00:30:59.950
The Orange Book became the basis for

658
00:30:59.950 --> 00:31:04.480
the TCSEC the red book was called the TNI
the Trusted Network Interpretation

659
00:31:04.480 --> 00:31:06.920
they talked about how to set up trusted or
secure networks.

660
00:31:06.920 --> 00:31:10.320
If you're interested in finding out
more about them Actually go out and

661
00:31:10.320 --> 00:31:11.950
Google the Orange Book,
or rather, excuse me,

662
00:31:11.950 --> 00:31:15.550
Google the Rainbow series, which is
the name for the entire series of books.

663
00:31:15.550 --> 00:31:18.200
But Google the Rainbow series, you'll
actually find a copy of them online.

664
00:31:18.200 --> 00:31:20.610
They are digitized,
you can actually download them today and

665
00:31:20.610 --> 00:31:23.540
you could take a look at them, but there's
really no reason to look at them any more,

666
00:31:23.540 --> 00:31:26.660
we really don't use them for anything,
they're just a historical footnote.

667
00:31:26.660 --> 00:31:28.710
But the Orange Book was
the book that came up with or

668
00:31:28.710 --> 00:31:32.700
allowed us to come up with what's known as
the TCSEC, the Trusted Computing System,

669
00:31:32.700 --> 00:31:35.050
or Computer System, Evaluations Criteria.

670
00:31:35.050 --> 00:31:37.820
This was the United States DOD,
Department of Defense,

671
00:31:37.820 --> 00:31:40.880
take on how to build
secure computing systems.

672
00:31:40.880 --> 00:31:44.854
Unique to their environmental operational
in our operational variables and

673
00:31:44.854 --> 00:31:47.000
all things they do inside their systems.

674
00:31:47.000 --> 00:31:50.761
Really not widely used outside of
the US government and the military but

675
00:31:50.761 --> 00:31:55.160
it was the first general thought process
we had about evaluation system criteria.

676
00:31:55.160 --> 00:31:58.854
The summer of the Orange Book evaluation
criteria we have a chart for, we're gonna

677
00:31:58.854 --> 00:32:02.100
quickly just show you what they are,
just so you could see what they are.

678
00:32:02.100 --> 00:32:05.274
You'll see them there,
we have Evaluation Division on the left,

679
00:32:05.274 --> 00:32:08.970
we have Evaluation Class in the middle,
we have Degree of Trust on the right.

680
00:32:08.970 --> 00:32:12.800
We're gonna scroll down a little in a
moment cuz there is some stuff down below.

681
00:32:12.800 --> 00:32:14.780
And actually,
let's scroll down to the bottom and

682
00:32:14.780 --> 00:32:16.240
come back up cuz we start at the bottom.

683
00:32:17.430 --> 00:32:21.840
So evaluation division on the left,
which is D for very, very lowest class,

684
00:32:21.840 --> 00:32:25.400
minimal protection, is gonna be
classified as evaluation criteria,

685
00:32:25.400 --> 00:32:27.310
evaluation class level D1.

686
00:32:27.310 --> 00:32:30.700
Minimal protection provides
the lowest degree of trust,

687
00:32:30.700 --> 00:32:32.980
lowest degree of security in other words.

688
00:32:32.980 --> 00:32:37.480
We work our way up from class D1
all the way up through C and B and

689
00:32:37.480 --> 00:32:39.020
up ultimately to A.

690
00:32:39.020 --> 00:32:41.580
To A1 at the top of the list,
we can scroll back up.

691
00:32:41.580 --> 00:32:45.750
A1 at the top of the list, which is
verified protection, verified design, and

692
00:32:45.750 --> 00:32:47.560
the highest degree of trust.

693
00:32:47.560 --> 00:32:51.150
A1 systems are considered to be
artificially intelligent systems by

694
00:32:51.150 --> 00:32:55.200
today's standards, meaning systems that
are capable of learning on their own and

695
00:32:55.200 --> 00:32:57.240
developing awareness on their own.

696
00:32:57.240 --> 00:33:00.290
That would be considered to be
an A1 Verified Design system.

697
00:33:00.290 --> 00:33:05.260
So we have this ranking model in the TCSEC
that's based on an alphabetical ranking,

698
00:33:05.260 --> 00:33:06.000
A, B, C, D.

699
00:33:06.000 --> 00:33:08.200
D being the lowest, A being the highest.

700
00:33:08.200 --> 00:33:09.670
And sub-levels within there.

701
00:33:09.670 --> 00:33:13.400
So if you look at B, Mandatory Protection,
for instance, you'll see B1, B2,

702
00:33:13.400 --> 00:33:16.220
and B3 as we go up.

703
00:33:16.220 --> 00:33:22.754
And B1 is going to be less secure than B2,
and B3 is more secure than B2 etc.

704
00:33:22.754 --> 00:33:24.430
So you get the idea as we move up.

705
00:33:24.430 --> 00:33:28.990
So the idea ultimately is that we go from
D all the way through A with the TCSEC.

706
00:33:28.990 --> 00:33:32.270
This is one set of evaluation criteria.

707
00:33:32.270 --> 00:33:34.590
We also have what's known as the ITSEC.

708
00:33:34.590 --> 00:33:37.000
We don't have a chart for ITSEC,
but we're going to stay here for

709
00:33:37.000 --> 00:33:40.650
just a second, because we're going to show
you another chart in just a minute for

710
00:33:40.650 --> 00:33:41.770
the common criteria.

711
00:33:41.770 --> 00:33:44.340
So that way we get to stay here
instead of flipping back and forth.

712
00:33:44.340 --> 00:33:46.808
And having you see me for
a second, then not seeing me again.

713
00:33:46.808 --> 00:33:51.420
So the ITSEC is what happens when
the other areas of the world,

714
00:33:51.420 --> 00:33:54.620
some of the other countries get together
and say we want our own standard too.

715
00:33:54.620 --> 00:33:57.170
We want to evaluation criteria standard.

716
00:33:57.170 --> 00:34:00.725
And so they create something that's based,
initially, on the TC SEC but

717
00:34:00.725 --> 00:34:03.930
has a little bit of a slightly different
take, they call that the ITSEC,

718
00:34:03.930 --> 00:34:07.850
Information Technology
Security Evaluation Criteria.

719
00:34:07.850 --> 00:34:12.068
The ITSEC was used by a group of countries
but not internationally agreed upon and

720
00:34:12.068 --> 00:34:13.070
recognized.

721
00:34:13.070 --> 00:34:15.952
Not everybody thought
the ITSEC was a good idea.

722
00:34:15.952 --> 00:34:20.970
The ITSEC had requirement
levels from E1 through E6, so

723
00:34:20.970 --> 00:34:26.910
you saw E1, E2, E3 instead of D1 or
A1 or B2 or D3 or whatever.

724
00:34:26.910 --> 00:34:28.810
So we have that with the ITSEC.

725
00:34:28.810 --> 00:34:31.800
That didn't stick around very long,
it was there for a few years.

726
00:34:31.800 --> 00:34:33.370
Not everybody got together and
agreed on it.

727
00:34:33.370 --> 00:34:36.590
So instead, we moved to what's
known as the common criteria.

728
00:34:36.590 --> 00:34:42.040
Common criteria, remember, is ISO
standard 15408, so what we're going to do

729
00:34:42.040 --> 00:34:47.420
is show you what the evaluation
criteria for, the common criteria are.

730
00:34:47.420 --> 00:34:51.710
The common criteria uses the concept of
what are known as protection profiles.

731
00:34:51.710 --> 00:34:55.910
A protection profile is effectively
a set of common functional and

732
00:34:55.910 --> 00:34:58.370
assurance requirements that are evaluated.

733
00:34:58.370 --> 00:35:03.310
And then as a result of that we ascribe
an EAL, a Evaluation Assurance Level,

734
00:35:03.310 --> 00:35:06.190
that's what EAL stands for,
an EAL ranking or

735
00:35:06.190 --> 00:35:11.195
level, to that particular product
from EAL 1 all the way through EAL

736
00:35:11.195 --> 00:35:14.640
7as you can see as we scroll down
towards the bottom of the list.

737
00:35:14.640 --> 00:35:18.210
Going from lowest to ultimately
highest level of confidence.

738
00:35:18.210 --> 00:35:21.740
And so we are gaining confidence
as we go higher in the model, and

739
00:35:21.740 --> 00:35:25.630
you can see that each in the middle,
in the long-name column in the middle,

740
00:35:25.630 --> 00:35:31.320
each EAL level has a kind
of formality to it.

741
00:35:31.320 --> 00:35:34.790
It's either functionally tested or
structurally tested or

742
00:35:34.790 --> 00:35:36.870
methodically tested and checked.

743
00:35:36.870 --> 00:35:40.080
Or semi-formally verified,
you get the sense of that.

744
00:35:40.080 --> 00:35:43.780
So as we scroll down and as we move
through all the different levels,

745
00:35:43.780 --> 00:35:47.570
right, the idea is that we're
getting more protection, and

746
00:35:47.570 --> 00:35:51.890
as a result of that more confidence in
the system that we are ultimately gonna

747
00:35:51.890 --> 00:35:56.720
certify and use because it meets
higher criteria for being accepted.

748
00:35:56.720 --> 00:36:02.150
So formally verified and designed and
tested systems which is EAL, level number

749
00:36:02.150 --> 00:36:07.500
7 is going to be a system that is
rigorously tested, formally verified,

750
00:36:07.500 --> 00:36:14.040
and ultimately is going to be an
incredibly secure system, one that is most

751
00:36:14.040 --> 00:36:18.660
likely gonna operate the highest levels
of security in most modern systems today.

752
00:36:18.660 --> 00:36:21.410
Whereas as an EAL certified
system at level 1 or

753
00:36:21.410 --> 00:36:23.600
2 is a relatively low level system.

754
00:36:23.600 --> 00:36:26.030
One that has a very low
level of confidence in it.

755
00:36:26.030 --> 00:36:29.270
If you want more information on the common
criteria, we'd invite you and encourage

The ISO standard for
the common criteria, 15408.

00:36:53.830 --> 00:36:56.990

The most modern format that we use

And that's the one you want

In addition to talking about the control

This is also gonna be some
important information, so

00:14:00.150 --> 00:14:02.920

00:14:02.920 --> 00:14:05.870
I've mentioned several of the access

00:14:05.870 --> 00:14:10.830

These are all models,

00:14:19.230 --> 00:14:24.190

00:14:24.190 --> 00:14:28.110
We've talked about access control

Something you have,

00:15:18.010 --> 00:15:21.190

00:15:21.190 --> 00:15:24.840
The point is that we have a variety of

00:15:24.840 --> 00:15:29.170

00:15:33.890 --> 00:15:36.370
If we left everything wide open and

00:15:54.634 --> 00:15:59.032

00:16:23.560 --> 00:16:25.760
Clearly wouldn't be worried

00:16:25.760 --> 00:16:28.411
availability is pretty much

00:16:28.411 --> 00:16:30.370
We're just not getting in the way of it.

00:16:30.370 --> 00:16:34.280
So it would really be a different world is

00:16:34.280 --> 00:16:38.490
in that world, at least I don't

00:16:38.490 --> 00:16:41.710
And I like being able to help people

00:16:41.710 --> 00:16:45.770
is secure, and I'm sure you do as well,

308
00:16:45.770 --> 00:16:49.320
So as a result of that, we all agree

309
00:16:49.320 --> 00:16:52.130
Because of that,
all systems should be able to do

00:16:52.130 --> 00:16:54.620

311
00:16:54.620 --> 00:16:58.070
And specifically things like being able

312
00:16:58.070 --> 00:17:00.000
objects as an example.

313
00:17:00.000 --> 00:17:02.280
We've talked about subjects being users,

314
00:17:02.280 --> 00:17:06.580
objects traditionally being referred

315
00:17:06.580 --> 00:17:08.750
The focus of the subject action,
in other words,

316
00:17:08.750 --> 00:17:12.590
is the object, objects are gonna
be interactive with bi-subjects.

00:17:12.590 --> 00:17:17.043
Remember, subjects are typically users,
but I made the point several times

318
00:17:17.043 --> 00:17:20.879
that subjects may also be classified
as services that are acting or

00:17:20.879 --> 00:17:22.608
proxying on behalf of a user.

320
00:17:22.608 --> 00:17:29.606
When you go out to a web browser, you
type an HTTP www.itpro.tv and hit Enter.

00:17:29.606 --> 00:17:35.095
Well, you're going to effectively ask

322
00:17:35.095 --> 00:17:40.332

00:17:40.332 --> 00:17:45.680
behalf to go out and get whatever is

00:17:45.680 --> 00:17:50.740
The itpro.tv website or whatever the

00:17:50.740 --> 00:17:54.570
As a result of that,
if there was a purple squirrel or

326
00:17:54.570 --> 00:17:57.880
a purple unicorn on that webpage,

00:17:57.880 --> 00:18:01.720
But the reality is, we don't know what's

00:18:01.720 --> 00:18:02.400

00:18:02.400 --> 00:18:03.499
I told you I would work that in somehow.

>> [LAUGH]
>> So we would see that there.

00:18:05.685 --> 00:18:07.709
That's a little thing between Mike and I.

00:18:07.709 --> 00:18:10.060
So we will see whatever's at

00:18:10.060 --> 00:18:12.300
is it really me the user

00:18:12.300 --> 00:18:14.570
Or is the service on behalf of me?

00:18:14.570 --> 00:18:18.180
Well, the reality is there's two

00:18:18.180 --> 00:18:22.130
There's the user subject, but then there's

00:18:22.130 --> 00:18:24.870

00:18:32.870 --> 00:18:36.260
Generically, accessed control mechanisms

00:18:36.260 --> 00:18:37.530
subject and object.

00:18:37.530 --> 00:18:40.240
If we don't understand what

there's no way to apply

00:18:42.630 --> 00:18:43.946
So we wanna make sure we understand that.

00:18:43.946 --> 00:18:47.732
We have to make appropriate decisions as

346
00:18:47.732 --> 00:18:51.090
and therefore, should be able to see

00:18:51.090 --> 00:18:52.290

00:18:52.290 --> 00:18:54.110
This is also very important.

349
00:18:54.110 --> 00:18:57.585
Wanna assign unique identifiers

350
00:18:57.585 --> 00:19:01.203
making sure we can uniquely identify

351
00:19:01.203 --> 00:19:05.103
If there are two Adams in the user
database, two subjects called Adam,

352
00:19:05.103 --> 00:19:09.394
I have to differentiate because the Adam

00:19:09.394 --> 00:19:13.680
gonna be different than the Adam that

00:19:13.680 --> 00:19:15.420
Or if both Adams have a green Polo,

00:19:15.420 --> 00:19:18.370
then we have to figure out

00:19:18.370 --> 00:19:23.030
So we usually we use first name,
last name, first name, last, initial.

357
00:19:23.030 --> 00:19:26.110
That stuff works, but even that I

358
00:19:26.110 --> 00:19:26.716
two Adam Gs.

00:19:26.716 --> 00:19:30.182
So what we really rely on in most

00:19:30.182 --> 00:19:34.730

00:19:34.730 --> 00:19:39.260
It's made up of a SID,

362
00:19:39.260 --> 00:19:41.790
Relative ID gives you
the naming convention,

363
00:19:41.790 --> 00:19:44.600
your place in the world

00:19:44.600 --> 00:19:47.810
So that references part of your
unique identity, and then the SID,

365
00:19:47.810 --> 00:19:51.395
the security identifier,
is a unique multi-digit string,

366
00:19:51.395 --> 00:19:55.260
an alpha-numeric string that
effectively identifies you

367
00:19:55.260 --> 00:19:59.000
as unique instance within that relative
ID space within the namespace.

368
00:19:59.000 --> 00:20:00.150
This is how it's done in Windows.

369
00:20:00.150 --> 00:20:03.330
And we have a similar thought process
in Linux and Unix-based systems.

370
00:20:03.330 --> 00:20:07.110
We have a relative ID that allows
us to identify who you are.

371
00:20:07.110 --> 00:20:09.000
That GUID is going to be unique, and

372
00:20:09.000 --> 00:20:13.221
ultimately no matter how many Adam Gordons
or how many Adam Gs or how many Adams in

373
00:20:13.221 --> 00:20:16.881
green shirts we have, every one of
them will be seen as being unique.

374
00:20:16.881 --> 00:20:20.255
Access control mechanisms have to
ensure that this behavior occurs,

375
00:20:20.255 --> 00:20:24.142
because otherwise, we'd have no way of
differentiating between the different

376
00:20:24.142 --> 00:20:26.900
Adams that are wearing shirts
within the organization.

377
00:20:26.900 --> 00:20:28.970
So that's gonna obviously

378
00:20:28.970 --> 00:20:33.120
And we also have to authenticate all
subjects before we allow them to access

379
00:20:33.120 --> 00:20:35.120
data or to access objects.

380
00:20:35.120 --> 00:20:39.390
These are all things that access control

381
00:20:39.390 --> 00:20:44.600

Enterprise Security Architecture.

382
00:20:44.600 --> 00:20:47.390
We also have to have what is
known as complete mediation.

383
00:20:47.390 --> 00:20:51.900
Complete mediation implies that no subject
should ever be able to gain access to

384
00:20:51.900 --> 00:20:53.936
an object without authorization.

385
00:20:53.936 --> 00:20:58.639
We often talk when we're thinking about
access control about the concept of

386
00:20:58.639 --> 00:21:03.345
identification, authorization as
happening as part of that process, but

387
00:21:03.345 --> 00:21:05.270
it happens a little bit later.

388
00:21:05.270 --> 00:21:09.390
What we actually need to do
is first identify, then we,

389
00:21:09.390 --> 00:21:11.750
I was making up a new word,
identicate, that's so cool!

390
00:21:11.750 --> 00:21:12.750
>> I like it.
>> We're gonna put that on

391
00:21:12.750 --> 00:21:14.360
vocabulary words for you.

392
00:21:14.360 --> 00:21:18.340
So we have to identify,
then we have to authenticate,

393
00:21:18.340 --> 00:21:22.540
then we have to authorize, that is the
step-by-step process that we go through

394
00:21:22.540 --> 00:21:26.840
with regards to identity access management
and with regards to access control.

395
00:21:26.840 --> 00:21:31.350
So when we identify, we're asking you to
provide some sort of information that will

396
00:21:31.350 --> 00:21:32.670
stipulate who you are.

397
00:21:32.670 --> 00:21:35.900
It's usually a username and a password,
but it could be other things as well.

398
00:21:35.900 --> 00:21:38.980
You may insert your smart card
into a smart card reader.

399
00:21:38.980 --> 00:21:40.490
You may provide a pin.

400
00:21:40.490 --> 00:21:42.530
You provide a biometrics scan.

401
00:21:42.530 --> 00:21:45.610
You may provide a challenge from
a challenge-response token, or

402
00:21:45.610 --> 00:21:47.484
a response to that, whatever it may be.

403
00:21:47.484 --> 00:21:50.631
Whatever that is,
you're gonna identify yourself up front.

404
00:21:50.631 --> 00:21:54.020
We're then gonna authenticate
that identification request.

405
00:21:54.020 --> 00:21:56.980
We're gonna take that, we're gonna match
it against what the known quantities

406
00:21:56.980 --> 00:22:01.240
are that are stored in the LDAP directory
somewhere, using some sort of mechanism.

407
00:22:01.240 --> 00:22:05.140
Whether it's a hash of the username and
password, whether it's comparison

408
00:22:05.140 --> 00:22:10.040
of the token response and challenge
information to make sure the token is

409
00:22:10.040 --> 00:22:13.850
indeed providing the right response to
the right challenge at the right time,

410
00:22:13.850 --> 00:22:16.570
if it's a synchronized token,
things of that nature.

411
00:22:16.570 --> 00:22:20.280
If it's a biometric scan, we're going
to measure the information you provided

412
00:22:20.280 --> 00:22:25.160
against the stored record in the database
and make sure the two match.

413
00:22:25.160 --> 00:22:27.350
Whatever that is we authenticate.

414
00:22:27.350 --> 00:22:30.150
Once we authenticate,
we then have to authorize.

415
00:22:30.150 --> 00:22:33.800
Authorization is the idea of
granting the user or the requestor,

416
00:22:33.800 --> 00:22:37.060
whoever the subject or whatever
the subject is, the right to engage in

417
00:22:37.060 --> 00:22:41.180
certain activity based on the fact that
they have authenticated successfully.

418
00:22:41.180 --> 00:22:44.271
And then, that,
whatever that level of access is,

419
00:22:44.271 --> 00:22:47.575
is granted to you when you
engage in those activities for

420
00:22:47.575 --> 00:22:52.023
what we call the time of the logon, or
commonly referred to as the session.

421
00:22:52.023 --> 00:22:53.416
You engage in a session.

422
00:22:53.416 --> 00:22:55.760
Activities are gonna be based on session.

423
00:22:55.760 --> 00:22:57.950
And as a result of that,
you're authenticated and

424
00:22:57.950 --> 00:23:00.980
authorized to engage in those
activities during that session.

425
00:23:00.980 --> 00:23:04.140
You log off, session disappears,
you log back in again,

426
00:23:04.140 --> 00:23:07.940
you reidentify, reauthenticate,
reauthorize, you have a new session.

427
00:23:07.940 --> 00:23:11.700
And we assign a unique session ID to
that session to track not just you,

428
00:23:11.700 --> 00:23:14.330
but everything that takes
place with regards to you and

429
00:23:14.330 --> 00:23:16.200
your interaction within the system.

430
00:23:16.200 --> 00:23:18.970
So everything is gonna be auditable,
everything is traceable,

431
00:23:18.970 --> 00:23:20.560
we have visibility in
everything in other words.

432
00:23:20.560 --> 00:23:21.690
We're always watching.

433
00:23:21.690 --> 00:23:25.030
And complete mediation is
the idea that no subject

434
00:23:25.030 --> 00:23:29.020
should ever be able to gain access to an
object without authorization taking place.

435
00:23:29.020 --> 00:23:32.950
If you can, you've effectively
broken the authentication mechanism

436
00:23:32.950 --> 00:23:34.280
because you're bypassing it.

437
00:23:34.280 --> 00:23:37.810
And so we talk about the idea of
complete mediation being very important.

438
00:23:37.810 --> 00:23:39.591
So we wanna think about that,
keep that in mind.

439
00:23:39.591 --> 00:23:44.152
Complete mediation is normally seen as
being the responsibility of the security

440
00:23:44.152 --> 00:23:48.375
kernel, which implements a reference
monitor in order to be able to keep of

441
00:23:48.375 --> 00:23:49.460
track of all this.

442
00:23:49.460 --> 00:23:53.213
And these are terms, That we have
not really talked about before.

443
00:23:53.213 --> 00:23:57.152
The security kernel, we've talked about
the kernel in the operating system,

444
00:23:57.152 --> 00:24:00.975
kind of the functional element that
implements some of the core capabilities

445
00:24:00.975 --> 00:24:02.294
of the operating system.

446
00:24:02.294 --> 00:24:04.782
The security kernel can be
thought of as that, but for

447
00:24:04.782 --> 00:24:07.287
the security functions
within the OS specifically.

448
00:24:07.287 --> 00:24:11.172
It's the core functionality that we used
to implement security functioning and

449
00:24:11.172 --> 00:24:14.658
security monitoring within the operating
system or within the system,

450
00:24:14.658 --> 00:24:16.446
whatever it is we are talking about.

451
00:24:16.446 --> 00:24:20.811
A reference monitor is effectively
implemented through the security kernel,

452
00:24:20.811 --> 00:24:25.108
and it's a process that examines all
attempts by subjects to access objects,

453
00:24:25.108 --> 00:24:26.230
and mediates them.

454
00:24:26.230 --> 00:24:28.345
It implements mediation.

455
00:24:28.345 --> 00:24:31.270
So complete mediation is implemented
through the reference monitor.

456
00:24:31.270 --> 00:24:35.253
And it's a function of the security
kernel if you understand and

457
00:24:35.253 --> 00:24:37.181
contract through that logic.

458
00:24:37.181 --> 00:24:40.119
When we think about access management,
we're also thinking about,

459
00:24:40.119 --> 00:24:41.327
not just letting people in.

460
00:24:41.327 --> 00:24:44.056
Not just identifying then,
not just authenticating them,

461
00:24:44.056 --> 00:24:45.349
not just authorizing them.

462
00:24:45.349 --> 00:24:47.713
But we also have to think about
what it is they're going to do,

463
00:24:47.713 --> 00:24:48.948
once they come into the system.

464
00:24:48.948 --> 00:24:52.080
They're going to interact with objects,
with data, and they're going to do so

465
00:24:52.080 --> 00:24:52.920
in a variety of ways.

466
00:24:52.920 --> 00:24:57.298
In one of our prior episodes,
we've talked about processors, CPU's,

467
00:24:57.298 --> 00:25:00.201
breaking them down,
what their functions are.

468
00:25:00.201 --> 00:25:05.042
They fetch, they decode, they store, those
are the things we talked about them doing.

469
00:25:05.042 --> 00:25:08.329
We also talked about memory and memory
management and the fact that we have

470
00:25:08.329 --> 00:25:11.722
dynamic and static memory and how we
will use memory to store information and

471
00:25:11.722 --> 00:25:14.460
then retrieve it and
use it when we have a need for it.

472
00:25:14.460 --> 00:25:18.714
So we talked about the fact that memory
is important as a security mechanism.

473
00:25:18.714 --> 00:25:22.378
We wanna make sure that when we're
thinking about memory we're thinking about

474
00:25:22.378 --> 00:25:23.368
memory management.

475
00:25:23.368 --> 00:25:25.275
The management of data within memory,

476
00:25:25.275 --> 00:25:28.396
the management of information
in other words stored in memory,

477
00:25:28.396 --> 00:25:32.177
has to be done securely because if we
put stuff there and we don't protect it.

478
00:25:32.177 --> 00:25:36.543
And we talked about things like address
based layout randomization, ASLR,

479
00:25:36.543 --> 00:25:38.029
as a mechanism to do that.

480
00:25:38.029 --> 00:25:40.189
We talked about page keying.

481
00:25:40.189 --> 00:25:42.748
Dividing memory up into memory blocks or
pages, and

482
00:25:42.748 --> 00:25:46.648
then keying that access to that with a
private key that effectively prevents you

483
00:25:46.648 --> 00:25:50.255
from getting into that memory space
unless you have a reason to be there and

484
00:25:50.255 --> 00:25:52.740
can provide the key to
validate your access.

485
00:25:52.740 --> 00:25:55.128
So we've talked about different ways
we secure memory, and manage it.

486
00:25:55.128 --> 00:25:59.017
We just wanna remind you of the fact that
these are all gonna be part of access

487
00:25:59.017 --> 00:26:00.570
control mechanisms as well.

488
00:26:00.570 --> 00:26:03.859
And these are things we have to
think about, and also, in our mind,

489
00:26:03.859 --> 00:26:04.975
have an awareness of.

490
00:26:04.975 --> 00:26:07.646
Also the ability for processors, for CPUs,

491
00:26:07.646 --> 00:26:11.040
to operate security is also
a part of access control.

492
00:26:11.040 --> 00:26:13.266
Again, accessing information.

493
00:26:13.266 --> 00:26:17.686
Processing it through the system,
using access to gain information and

494
00:26:17.686 --> 00:26:19.720
use it is part of access control.

495
00:26:19.720 --> 00:26:24.096
We don't often think of the function of
a CPU being couched in the terms of access

496
00:26:24.096 --> 00:26:25.349
control management.

497
00:26:25.349 --> 00:26:28.770
But there are multiple layers of access
control taking place within the system.

498
00:26:28.770 --> 00:26:32.214
Within the processor,
we think about two distinct states,

499
00:26:32.214 --> 00:26:34.586
or ways in which the processor can exist.

500
00:26:34.586 --> 00:26:38.865
We think about what's known as supervisory
state, often referred to as kernel mode,

501
00:26:38.865 --> 00:26:42.457
and we think about problem state which
is often referred to as user mode.

502
00:26:42.457 --> 00:26:46.430
Supervisory mode or kernel mode is the
lowest level functioning of the kernel.

503
00:26:46.430 --> 00:26:50.526
The idea behind it is that
the operating system kernel is gonna

504
00:26:50.526 --> 00:26:54.858
exist at that level,
execute within the CPU when necessary, and

505
00:26:54.858 --> 00:27:00.015
is gonna have complete and unfettered
access to the resources of the system.

506
00:27:00.015 --> 00:27:01.608
It can do everything.
It can access everything and

507
00:27:01.608 --> 00:27:02.546
it can see everything.

508
00:27:02.546 --> 00:27:06.910
It has effectively what we would refer to
in Linux and Unix as root level access.

509
00:27:06.910 --> 00:27:11.086
In a Windows system, we just call it
administrative access for full control.

510
00:27:11.086 --> 00:27:13.220
But the reality is,
it's effectively the same thing.

511
00:27:13.220 --> 00:27:15.809
It has unrestricted access
to everything in the system.

512
00:27:15.809 --> 00:27:18.438
The problem state, which if you
think about it is aptly named,

513
00:27:18.438 --> 00:27:20.770
when we think about referring
to it as user mode.

514
00:27:20.770 --> 00:27:24.383
So the problem state of
a processor [COUGH] excuse me,

515
00:27:24.383 --> 00:27:28.979
or the user mode, is going to be
effectively the idea behind the way

516
00:27:28.979 --> 00:27:32.938
the processor works with
regards to user access to data.

517
00:27:32.938 --> 00:27:36.881
In other words, we effectively don't
give users compete, unfettered,

518
00:27:36.881 --> 00:27:40.826
access to hardware, and to the
infrastructure of the system, the same way

519
00:27:40.826 --> 00:27:44.643
we do when we have a supervisor, or
kernel-mode access request because

520
00:27:44.643 --> 00:27:49.210
the kernel needs to operate without any
restrictions in order to do its job.

521
00:27:49.210 --> 00:27:52.659
User access, meaning things that
are proxied on behalf of a user from

522
00:27:52.659 --> 00:27:56.586
an application, hypothetically don't
need complete unfettered access but

523
00:27:56.586 --> 00:27:57.788
have to be controlled.

524
00:27:57.788 --> 00:28:01.280
Otherwise they may lock open resources and
cause the system to crash.

525
00:28:01.280 --> 00:28:04.815
So we have to think about a distinction
in the processor state as well when we

526
00:28:04.815 --> 00:28:08.086
think about access control between
supervisory and problem state.

527
00:28:08.086 --> 00:28:10.420
This is also very important.

528
00:28:10.420 --> 00:28:13.010
When we also want to think about
access control mechanisms,

529
00:28:13.010 --> 00:28:14.855
we want to think about process isolation.

530
00:28:14.855 --> 00:28:18.099
We've kind of walked up the chain and
the memory and

531
00:28:18.099 --> 00:28:20.901
the processor in terms
of the CPU function.

532
00:28:20.901 --> 00:28:23.320
We think about process isolation.

533
00:28:23.320 --> 00:28:27.794
We think about applying a unique process
ID to every execution request and

534
00:28:27.794 --> 00:28:32.053
then being able to track that, but
also identifying each uniquely and

535
00:28:32.053 --> 00:28:33.944
isolating it from the others.

536
00:28:33.944 --> 00:28:36.948
So, if you were to bring up task
manager in Windows, hypothetically,

537
00:28:36.948 --> 00:28:39.140
right Ctrl+Alt+Delete, see task manager.

538
00:28:39.140 --> 00:28:43.704
You go look at the process tab, you will
see not every process in the system.

539
00:28:43.704 --> 00:28:45.620
People often misunderstand
what's in Task Manager.

540
00:28:45.620 --> 00:28:48.190
You're seeing all the processes
that are exposed to the GUI,

541
00:28:48.190 --> 00:28:50.126
to the Windows-based environment, right?

542
00:28:50.126 --> 00:28:52.007
GUI stands for graphical user interface.

543
00:28:52.007 --> 00:28:53.841
It's fun to say, by the way, GUI.

544
00:28:53.841 --> 00:28:54.561
Say it with me, GUI.

545
00:28:54.561 --> 00:28:56.116
>> GUI.

546
00:28:56.116 --> 00:28:57.486
>> See there you go,
Mike enjoyed saying it.

547
00:28:57.486 --> 00:29:01.185
So the GUI only is going to represent
the processes that are exposed through

548
00:29:01.185 --> 00:29:01.940
Windows.

549
00:29:01.940 --> 00:29:05.682
There are other processes that are running
that we commonly refer to as being hidden

550
00:29:05.682 --> 00:29:07.242
within the Windows environment.

551
00:29:07.242 --> 00:29:08.900
You don't see them in Task Manager.

552
00:29:08.900 --> 00:29:11.828
They run, but you have to use
a command line interface to see them.

553
00:29:11.828 --> 00:29:16.958
Something like, pslist in Windows which is
process list tool from the Winternals or

554
00:29:16.958 --> 00:29:20.365
Sysinternals tool set depending
on how far back you go.

555
00:29:20.365 --> 00:29:22.511
You may in Linux and Linux environments,

556
00:29:22.511 --> 00:29:25.698
use top or proc which are command
line tools that can be used for

557
00:29:25.698 --> 00:29:29.990
commands out of command line, that can
be used to list all running processes.

558
00:29:29.990 --> 00:29:33.531
You will see that every process has
a unique ID, and you will see that we

559
00:29:33.531 --> 00:29:37.255
isolate processes from each other in
order to safeguard the integrity and

560
00:29:37.255 --> 00:29:40.918
the processing information that is
contained in those memory spaces for

561
00:29:40.918 --> 00:29:41.900
those processes.

562
00:29:41.900 --> 00:29:44.770
So we want to make sure that
we're aware of that concept.

563
00:29:44.770 --> 00:29:49.147
Also wanna make sure that we're thinking
about being able to effectively hide data,

564
00:29:49.147 --> 00:29:50.070
and abstract it.

565
00:29:50.070 --> 00:29:53.582
I wanna make sure we understand
that data is being hidden and

566
00:29:53.582 --> 00:29:57.300
is also not going to be seen by
anybody unless we allow them to.

567
00:29:57.300 --> 00:30:01.754
So this idea of kernel state and user
state are supervisor mode and user mode.

568
00:30:01.754 --> 00:30:05.461
Kernel state problem state those kind of
things, these are gonna be important for

569
00:30:05.461 --> 00:30:08.130
us to consider and to think about as well.

570
00:30:08.130 --> 00:30:09.256
>> Very good, Adam.

571
00:30:09.256 --> 00:30:11.340
A lot of great information
there we got to see, and

572
00:30:11.340 --> 00:30:14.815
some information about the controls that
are provided by the different frameworks

573
00:30:14.815 --> 00:30:16.310
that we've talked about.

574
00:30:16.310 --> 00:30:20.344
We also took a really in-depth
look at access control, and

575
00:30:20.344 --> 00:30:24.470
how we can differentiate between
the objects and subjects.

576
00:30:24.470 --> 00:30:25.870
>> Subjects and objects.

577
00:30:25.870 --> 00:30:30.727
>> The importance of being able to
uniquely identify the different subjects

578
00:30:30.727 --> 00:30:35.907
and objects, and how that process works,
and that authentication process.

579
00:30:35.907 --> 00:30:38.820
Very good stuff, Adam, appreciate that.

580
00:30:38.820 --> 00:30:42.495
Remember, if you guys want to
attend one of Adam's classes,

581
00:30:42.495 --> 00:30:46.114
all you gotta do is shoot us an email,
seeadam@itpro.tv.

582
00:30:46.114 --> 00:30:47.716
That's gonna do it for this episode.

583
00:30:47.716 --> 00:30:49.040
Signing off, I'm Mike Roderick.

584
00:30:49.040 --> 00:30:50.479
>> I'm Adam Borden.

585
00:30:50.479 --> 00:30:51.965
>> And we'll see you next time.

586
00:30:51.965 --> 00:30:52.847
>> Take care.

587

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike discuss assessing and mitigating vulnerabilities related to security architecture. They talk about hardware failure, privilege misuse and emanation threats. They also talk about race conditions, covert channels, and centralized and decentralized architecture.

00:01:05.340 --> 00:01:06.780

How we build a secure infrastructure.

28

How do we set up controls to do that?

29
00:01:13.240 --> 00:01:14.910
How do we identify risk?

30
00:01:14.910 --> 00:01:18.300
How do we shape and
control behavior with policy?

31
00:01:18.300 --> 00:01:20.060
These are things we've
been talking a lot about.

32
00:01:20.060 --> 00:01:23.050
We have to identify common threats
throughout the organization,

33
00:01:23.050 --> 00:01:24.380

34
00:01:24.380 --> 00:01:26.250
In order to be able to assess and

35

The stuff's gonna be a very

39

So things such as hardware failure right?

46

What if somebody's able to

All of the sudden they have full access

50
00:02:05.810 --> 00:02:07.830
That can obviously lead to complications.

51
00:02:07.830 --> 00:02:09.820
What about things like denial of service?

52

Somebody's able to launch an attack

55
00:02:20.320 --> 00:02:22.920
This would obviously lead to an issue and
a concern.

56
00:02:22.920 --> 00:02:24.760
Hacking, in general,
is obviously always a concern.

57
00:02:24.760 --> 00:02:26.540
You know,
these are areas of common threats.

58
00:02:26.540 --> 00:02:30.510
And we have to be identifying
key areas to focus on

59
00:02:30.510 --> 00:02:32.340
as a result of focusing in on them.

60

We can begin to craft not only the
assessment regimes but also the mitigation

61
00:02:36.620 --> 00:02:40.150
strategies that help us to prevent
these things from becoming a reality.

62
00:02:40.150 --> 00:02:41.910
So when we think about
system architecture,

63
00:02:41.910 --> 00:02:45.580
we have to think about emanation, this
is one of the first areas we talk about.

64
00:02:45.580 --> 00:02:49.030
When we thing about a computer system,
much like the laptop I'm using for

65
00:02:49.030 --> 00:02:51.409
instance where I have my notes and
I'm talking to you.

66
00:02:52.420 --> 00:02:56.490
This laptop or any computer for
that matter, any computing device

67
00:02:56.490 --> 00:03:00.720
is going to radiate out beyond
the boundary of the shell of the system.

68
00:03:00.720 --> 00:03:03.440
Electronic eminance, in other words.

69
00:03:03.440 --> 00:03:07.780
Information is coming off of this
system through electronic radiation,

70
00:03:07.780 --> 00:03:12.720
specifically what we call electronic
signals that you can pick up in effect.

71
00:03:12.720 --> 00:03:16.230
And you can reproduce within a couple
of feet of the machine, depending on

72
00:03:16.230 --> 00:03:19.670
the strength of the machine and certain
parameters associated with how it's built.

73
00:03:19.670 --> 00:03:22.570
System emanations,
in other words, can be a problem

74
00:03:22.570 --> 00:03:26.130
because if somebody's able to pick them up
and reproduce them, they affectively can

75
00:03:26.130 --> 00:03:29.420
see the information on my screen,
even though they're not looking at it.

76
00:03:29.420 --> 00:03:32.020
Now, this is not something
that's normally done every day.

77
00:03:32.020 --> 00:03:34.850
This is not something that you
could just walk up to a computer.

78
00:03:34.850 --> 00:03:38.657
Sit down five feet away,
point your computer at the screen and do.

79
00:03:38.657 --> 00:03:42.891
You need special equipment to pick up
this electromagnetic radiation and

80
00:03:42.891 --> 00:03:44.340
then reproduce it.

81
00:03:44.340 --> 00:03:45.810
But the point is, it can be done.

82
00:03:45.810 --> 00:03:49.330
It bleeds everywhere, much like
a wireless signal, it's there for

83
00:03:49.330 --> 00:03:51.310
the taking if you know how to find it.

84
00:03:51.310 --> 00:03:54.250
So in order to protect
against emanation threats,

85
00:03:54.250 --> 00:03:56.530
we use something known
as tempest shielding.

86
00:03:56.530 --> 00:04:00.720
And tempest shielding is effectively
going to allow us to be able to

87
00:04:00.720 --> 00:04:04.580
use technology that will absorb
the electromagnetic radiation,

88
00:04:04.580 --> 00:04:08.710
the emanations that come from
the hard drive, the CPU, the memory.

89
00:04:08.710 --> 00:04:12.380
All electronic devices create
this electromagnetic radiation.

90
00:04:12.380 --> 00:04:15.350
And as a result of that tempest
shielding absorbs it and

91
00:04:15.350 --> 00:04:17.250
effectively stealths the machine.

92
00:04:17.250 --> 00:04:20.120
Prevents the radiation from
seeping out and being read or

93
00:04:20.120 --> 00:04:24.010
being seen out beyond the boundary
of the border of the device.

94
00:04:24.010 --> 00:04:27.390
We talk about a Faraday cage with

But it could also lead to infection of
multiple systems which could easily

546
00:26:06.890 --> 00:26:08.250
also be a problem.

547
00:26:08.250 --> 00:26:11.810
Do we have intrusion detection and
intrusion prevention systems running?

548
00:26:11.810 --> 00:26:13.140
Are we using firewalls?

549
00:26:13.140 --> 00:26:14.510
Are we doing patch management?

550
00:26:14.510 --> 00:26:17.660
These are all things we think about in
this area with regards to desktops,

551
00:26:17.660 --> 00:26:20.140
laptops, servers, clients,
things of that nature.

552
00:26:20.140 --> 00:26:23.050
We've talked about mobile devices
extensively already as well, we

553
00:26:23.050 --> 00:26:26.640
talked about server based solutions, all
these areas have to be brought to bear or

554
00:26:26.640 --> 00:26:28.650
will it be part of
the conversation we're having.

555
00:26:29.780 --> 00:26:31.710
We should also think about data flow and

556
00:26:31.710 --> 00:26:35.750
how data moves through a system with
regards to assessing vulnerabilities and

557
00:26:35.750 --> 00:26:38.030
assessing and
then ultimately mitigating them.

558
00:26:38.030 --> 00:26:39.940
Do we understand the data flow pathways?

559
00:26:39.940 --> 00:26:43.640
In other words, have we mapped
out the data flow in our systems?

560
00:26:43.640 --> 00:26:45.720
Do we have what's called
a data flow diagram?

561
00:26:45.720 --> 00:26:48.835
If we do, we should be able to, and
I often see this when I go into customer's

562
00:26:48.835 --> 00:26:52.110
emergency operation centers, or
KNOX, or I walk in their offices.

563
00:26:52.110 --> 00:26:55.380
You know, they have the huge plotter
printout on the wall, right?

564
00:26:55.380 --> 00:26:57.580
You know, they've go the 20 by 20,
or whatever it is, and

565
00:26:57.580 --> 00:27:00.810
they've got the network map with all
the servers and everything laid out.

566
00:27:00.810 --> 00:27:03.350
The routing guys, or routing girls,
typically have that as well,

567
00:27:03.350 --> 00:27:05.960
they'll have the routing topology
printed out and laid out.

568
00:27:05.960 --> 00:27:10.110
The web hosting and database hosting
areas have their own, that kind of thing.

569
00:27:10.110 --> 00:27:13.900
These are schematics, they're diagrams
about how systems are wired together.

570
00:27:13.900 --> 00:27:16.930
What I don't often see though,
is the data flow diagram,

571
00:27:16.930 --> 00:27:19.420
how does that actually move
through those systems?

572
00:27:19.420 --> 00:27:23.210
If we don't understand that, we also could
have a vulnerability in the problem for

573
00:27:23.210 --> 00:27:25.250
not creating multi-path redundancies so

574
00:27:25.250 --> 00:27:28.770
data can flow through more than one,
pathway to get from point A to point C.

575
00:27:28.770 --> 00:27:32.370
That could be an issue,
if we are using multi-path redundancy but

576
00:27:32.370 --> 00:27:36.050
we are not implementing and testing and
validating multi-pathing but

577
00:27:36.050 --> 00:27:39.050
just assuming it's working the right way,
we could have a problem.

578
00:27:39.050 --> 00:27:43.530
Had a customer that had a yearly annual
failover event that they would use for

579
00:27:43.530 --> 00:27:44.650
testing purposes.

580
00:27:44.650 --> 00:27:48.320
Under regulatory law, they had to test
fail over at least once a year here in

581
00:27:48.320 --> 00:27:51.350
the United States, during the financial
and banking services industry.

582
00:27:51.350 --> 00:27:55.030
And so they were required to do a full on
interruption test at least once a year, so

583
00:27:55.030 --> 00:27:56.139
they went and did the test.

584
00:27:57.230 --> 00:28:00.190
This is the interesting part, not that
they did the test, it's what happened, so

585
00:28:00.190 --> 00:28:01.350
they did the test.

586
00:28:01.350 --> 00:28:05.050
They were able to fail the systems over
to wha they thought was their emergency

587
00:28:05.050 --> 00:28:05.950
operation center.

588
00:28:05.950 --> 00:28:08.940
The problem is, when they failed over, A)

589
00:28:08.940 --> 00:28:13.080
the traffic wasn't going to where it was
supposed to, B) they couldn't fail back.

590
00:28:13.080 --> 00:28:16.040
And so what had happened, and it took them
three days to figure this out, so you

591
00:28:16.040 --> 00:28:20.650
could imagine the impact to their systems
to finally figure out what the answer was.

592
00:28:20.650 --> 00:28:22.390
And the answer is often very simple.

593
00:28:22.390 --> 00:28:24.420
The problem is incredibly complex, but

594
00:28:24.420 --> 00:28:27.300
when we finally get down to it,
it was actually a very simple answer,

595
00:28:27.300 --> 00:28:31.040
although the problem hid the simplicity
of the answer for three days.

596
00:28:31.040 --> 00:28:34.120
What ultimately had happened was right
before the failure, or, excuse me, right

597
00:28:34.120 --> 00:28:37.340
before the failover and then the failure,
they had gone through a patch cycle and

598
00:28:37.340 --> 00:28:41.160
had updated patches and firmware
across their routing infrastructure.

599
00:28:41.160 --> 00:28:44.010
Cisco had put out a series of updates and
they had done that.

600
00:28:44.010 --> 00:28:46.630
Because of the nature of
their failover topology,

601
00:28:46.630 --> 00:28:49.740
everything had to be patched to the exact
same level or things wouldn't work.

602
00:28:49.740 --> 00:28:51.900
You can see where I'm going with this,
right?

603
00:28:51.900 --> 00:28:55.780
So, they had patched but they didn't patch
to the same level across all the systems.

604
00:28:55.780 --> 00:28:58.270
And one of the systems that was
critical in the middle of the path

605
00:28:58.270 --> 00:29:00.630
effectively was different
than all the others and

606
00:29:00.630 --> 00:29:03.740
went off effectively into space and
never came back.

607
00:29:03.740 --> 00:29:06.990
And it took three days of debunking and
working with Cisco engineers

608
00:29:06.990 --> 00:29:09.120
to troubleshoot and
figure out what had gone wrong.

609
00:29:09.120 --> 00:29:11.460
Because all the obvious
things are the paths there,

610
00:29:11.460 --> 00:29:14.250
we're using deterministic routing,
are all the static paths there?

611
00:29:14.250 --> 00:29:16.730
Is everything up we can ping all
the interfaces everything's working

612
00:29:16.730 --> 00:29:18.250
all that was fine.

613
00:29:18.250 --> 00:29:21.460
They could move traffic back and
forth in controlled conditions, but

614
00:29:21.460 --> 00:29:24.590
they couldn't fail it over and
then bring it back, that was the problem.

615
00:29:24.590 --> 00:29:27.220
And they couldn't do that because one
of the patches that had been applied,

616
00:29:27.220 --> 00:29:30.310
that was applied at a different
level had changed the nature of one

617
00:29:30.310 --> 00:29:33.240
of the ways in which this particular
technology was supposed to work.

618
00:29:33.240 --> 00:29:35.480
And it was a minute change,
but it was an important one.

619
00:29:35.480 --> 00:29:39.060
The failure there was not just doing
that before a major failover event, but

620
00:29:39.060 --> 00:29:42.400
the failure was that they had not
documented properly what patch levels were

621
00:29:42.400 --> 00:29:43.580
applied to every system.

622
00:29:43.580 --> 00:29:47.430
We've talked significantly in many
respects about the value of documentation,

623
00:29:47.430 --> 00:29:49.540
how important it is and
why we have to keep up with it so.

624
00:29:50.620 --> 00:29:53.145
Just wanna think about that and
be aware of that as well, right?

625
00:29:53.145 --> 00:29:57.485
So just keeping that in mind as we begin
an obviously in this particular case

626
00:29:57.485 --> 00:30:00.085
start to wrap up our conversations
in this particular episode.

627
00:30:00.085 --> 00:30:02.815
But we're going to have a lot
more to say about assessing and

628
00:30:02.815 --> 00:30:04.115
mitigating vulnerabilities.

629
00:30:04.115 --> 00:30:07.095
So hopefully you're going to be sticking
around for those conversations.

630
00:30:07.095 --> 00:30:08.966
We'll have a lot of interesting
things to continue to talk about.

631
00:30:08.966 --> 00:30:12.465
>> Absolutely, I hope you boys and
girls, ladies and gentlemen out there,

632
00:30:12.465 --> 00:30:15.520
if your head is swimming like mine,
it;s a ton of information.

633
00:30:15.520 --> 00:30:19.870
A lot of vulnerabilities kinda, I'm trying
to think of a good way to say this,

634
00:30:19.870 --> 00:30:21.540
it's almost mind boggling.

635
00:30:21.540 --> 00:30:23.710
And we're not done,
we've got more to go over.

636
00:30:23.710 --> 00:30:27.920
So we're gonna have to come back for
part two to finish up our assessing and

637
00:30:27.920 --> 00:30:31.250
mitigating vulnerabilities in
our security architecture.

638
00:30:31.250 --> 00:30:32.780
Remember, if you guys want to see or

639
00:30:32.780 --> 00:30:37.240
attend one of Adam's classes shoot
us an email, see Adam at itpro.tv.

640
00:30:37.240 --> 00:30:40.040
Signing off for now, I'm Mike Rodrick.

641
00:30:40.040 --> 00:30:44.710
>> I'm vulnerable, but I'm also sensitive,
my name is Adam, come back and join us for

642
00:30:44.710 --> 00:30:45.570
another conversation.

643
00:30:45.570 --> 00:30:51.234
>> We'll see you soon.
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike continue to discuss assessing and mitigating vulnerabilities, focusing on what is running on our systems. They look at risks associated with data, big data, and data warehousing. They also talk about data aggregation, data inference, and data mining.
episodes.title: Assess Vulnerabilities Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.268 --> 00:00:15.091
Hello and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.091 --> 00:00:20.870
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and
we are continuing on with our CISSP.

4
00:00:20.870 --> 00:00:24.840
And specifically in this episode, we're
continuing our conversation on assessing

5
00:00:24.840 --> 00:00:28.090
and mitigating vulnerabilities
in our system architecture.

6
00:00:28.090 --> 00:00:29.480
So we're just going to
get right back into it,

7
00:00:29.480 --> 00:00:33.960
there's a lot of stuff we got to talk
about and here is Miser Adam Gordon.

8
00:00:33.960 --> 00:00:34.560
Hello everybody.

9
00:00:34.560 --> 00:00:37.972
I gave you the official Bullwinkle
greeting before but nobody responded.

10
00:00:37.972 --> 00:00:41.000
>> [LAUGH] They're all doing it at home,
I'm sure.

11
00:00:41.000 --> 00:00:42.940
>> Happy Vulnerability Mitigation Day.

12
00:00:42.940 --> 00:00:45.990
All right, so let's jump back in to
talk about what we're here to discuss.

13
00:00:45.990 --> 00:00:48.720
So we're gonna continue on with the theme
we've been going through in our prior

14
00:00:48.720 --> 00:00:51.630
episode, which is assessment of
vulnerabilities, mitigation of them

15
00:00:51.630 --> 00:00:55.230
in systems architecture, and
security related concerns.

16
00:00:55.230 --> 00:00:58.390
We've talked a lot about all the building
blocks of systems in the prior episode.

17
00:00:58.390 --> 00:00:59.170
We're gonna jump in and

18
00:00:59.170 --> 00:01:02.550
talk about some of the things that
now run on top of those systems.

19
00:01:02.550 --> 00:01:07.400
Things like data, big data, how we
manage data, cloud based systems and

20
00:01:07.400 --> 00:01:08.024
cloud computing,

21
00:01:08.024 --> 00:01:11.320
and things of that nature will be
the focus of our general discussions here.

22
00:01:11.320 --> 00:01:13.800
So when we think about data,
what we first have to do and

23
00:01:13.800 --> 00:01:16.940
we've already talked about subject object,
and the distinction between them.

24
00:01:16.940 --> 00:01:19.800
We talk about object related stuff,
we talk about data.

25
00:01:19.800 --> 00:01:21.790
We have to think about what kind
of data we're talking about.

26
00:01:21.790 --> 00:01:23.020
We know it's bits and bytes.

27
00:01:23.020 --> 00:01:27.020
We know data, generically, is that,
at least in a computer, anyway, but it can

28
00:01:27.020 --> 00:01:32.750
take lots of different capabilities,
lots of different data classifications,

29
00:01:32.750 --> 00:01:36.900
lots of different concerns to help
understand and articulate what data is.

30
00:01:36.900 --> 00:01:40.120
And as a result of that,
figure out how to manage it effectively.

31
00:01:40.120 --> 00:01:43.220
We talked a lot about the importance
of classification of data.

32
00:01:43.220 --> 00:01:46.690
Is data going to have a certain level
of protection associated with it?

33
00:01:46.690 --> 00:01:47.830
The answer is yes.

34
00:01:47.830 --> 00:01:49.630
We need to understand
the meaning of the data and

35
00:01:49.630 --> 00:01:51.760
the impact of the data
to the organization.

36
00:01:51.760 --> 00:01:53.180
So where do we store data?

37
00:01:53.180 --> 00:01:53.850
Let's start with that.

38
00:01:53.850 --> 00:01:54.860
We typically put it, obviously,

39
00:01:54.860 --> 00:01:58.622
clearly, in storage devices,
whether it is short-term in memory,

40
00:01:58.622 --> 00:02:02.220
long-term on a hard drive,
out on a storage array, wherever it is.

41
00:02:02.220 --> 00:02:04.160
If we have a large volume of data,

42
00:02:04.160 --> 00:02:06.410
we often talk about putting
that into a data warehouse.

43
00:02:06.410 --> 00:02:10.390
A data warehouse is simply just a very
large database that is constructed in such

44
00:02:10.390 --> 00:02:15.660
a way that we can use special tools to
able to interact with and manage the data.

45
00:02:15.660 --> 00:02:17.150
When we're talking about petabytes or

46
00:02:17.150 --> 00:02:20.970
terabytes of data, we're talking about
probably putting it into a data warehouse.

47
00:02:20.970 --> 00:02:23.193
When we're talking about megabytes or
gigabytes of data,

48
00:02:23.193 --> 00:02:26.125
we're most likely talking
about storing it locally.

49
00:02:26.125 --> 00:02:29.025
And so the idea of using a data warehouse

50
00:02:29.025 --> 00:02:31.325
is one way that we can
assess vulnerabilities, and

51
00:02:31.325 --> 00:02:35.045
then come up with a mitigation strategy
to manage data more effectively.

52
00:02:35.045 --> 00:02:39.250
Because by warehousing, putting large
volumes of data into a central system

53
00:02:39.250 --> 00:02:43.260
that can be access controlled,
can be continuously monitored, can be risk

54
00:02:43.260 --> 00:02:48.110
assessed, can be audited, can be managed
so that people can interact with it, but

55
00:02:48.110 --> 00:02:51.840
we can understand and log and create
traceability and create visibilit,y and

56
00:02:51.840 --> 00:02:55.102
therefore accountability around
those interactions is a good thing.

57
00:02:55.102 --> 00:02:58.740
And so using data warehousing is going
to be a mechanism that we should be

58
00:02:58.740 --> 00:03:01.440
thinking about because it let's
us combine data that may be

59
00:03:01.440 --> 00:03:04.920
stored locally in different areas in
the system, that is harder to manage,

60
00:03:04.920 --> 00:03:09.930
harder to keep track of in one location,
centralizing data storage and data usage,

61
00:03:09.930 --> 00:03:13.800
also centralizes data security, and it
makes it easier to keep track of things.

62
00:03:13.800 --> 00:03:17.220
So data warehousing may be a good
thing for us to think about.

63
00:03:17.220 --> 00:03:20.960
The idea behind managing data is
fairly straightforward, right?

64
00:03:20.960 --> 00:03:22.100
Put the data in one place,

65
00:03:22.100 --> 00:03:25.030
apply access controls to it,
figure out who's coming and going,

66
00:03:25.030 --> 00:03:28.950
what they're doing, and only show them
the data that they're supposed to see.

67
00:03:28.950 --> 00:03:30.600
That part's pretty straight forward.

68
00:03:30.600 --> 00:03:34.350
But what if we show you the data you're
supposed to see, but as a result of doing

69
00:03:34.350 --> 00:03:38.040
that, you may actually be able to figure
out there's other data in the system.

70
00:03:38.040 --> 00:03:39.970
But, we're not showing it to you.

71
00:03:39.970 --> 00:03:42.290
You'd be a pretty smart
person if you could do that.

72
00:03:42.290 --> 00:03:45.410
Mike was actually practicing this
technique while we were off camera, and

73
00:03:45.410 --> 00:03:47.370
he was doing something known as inference.

74
00:03:47.370 --> 00:03:52.500
Now, what inference is, is the ability to
be able to deduce, to affectively infer

75
00:03:52.500 --> 00:03:55.870
that there is information available
in the system that may be hidden,

76
00:03:55.870 --> 00:03:59.000
that we're not seeing,
from other information that we are seeing.

77
00:03:59.000 --> 00:04:02.980
So for instance, if I was to give
you three pieces of information, and

78
00:04:02.980 --> 00:04:07.730
I was to say to you my first name is Adam,
I like colorful

79
00:04:07.730 --> 00:04:12.710
socks as you all well know, and
as a result of being named Adam and

80
00:04:12.710 --> 00:04:16.650
liking colorful socks, I'm going
to be presenting to you today and

81
00:04:16.650 --> 00:04:20.100
talking to you about CISSP
related information.

82
00:04:20.100 --> 00:04:21.890
You could probably deduce or

83
00:04:21.890 --> 00:04:25.180
infer several things from those
three pieces of information.

84
00:04:25.180 --> 00:04:27.160
You could deduce that I'm a very sharp and

85
00:04:27.160 --> 00:04:31.170
snazzy dresser who has a sense of fashion,
because I wear colorful socks.

86
00:04:31.170 --> 00:04:36.150
You could deduce that I probably know
something about CISSP and CISSP related

87
00:04:36.150 --> 00:04:39.740
information, because I've been asked
to present that to you here today.

88
00:04:39.740 --> 00:04:43.670
You may also deduce the fact that
Mike may have developed laryngitis,

89
00:04:43.670 --> 00:04:46.520
because he's not able to speak, and
so I have to speak on his behalf.

90
00:04:46.520 --> 00:04:50.630
Any or all of those things may be
possible for you to infer, or deduce,

91
00:04:50.630 --> 00:04:54.630
from at least two of the three pieces of
information that I've shared with you.

92
00:04:54.630 --> 00:04:57.360
I never came right out and
told you any of those things.

93
00:04:57.360 --> 00:04:59.480
I simply gave you basic information.

94
00:04:59.480 --> 00:05:02.250
But you are able to potentially infer or

95
00:05:02.250 --> 00:05:05.970
understand that there may have been other
things that were there but just not said.

96
00:05:05.970 --> 00:05:07.740
And this is the idea behind inference.

97
00:05:07.740 --> 00:05:11.070
The idea is that if we show you
information during the normal course of

98
00:05:11.070 --> 00:05:16.300
data management, we show you a spreadsheet
with sales figures in it, but

99
00:05:16.300 --> 00:05:18.990
there are other columns in
the spreadsheet that are hidden.

100
00:05:18.990 --> 00:05:22.090
You may be able to deduce
information about the value

101
00:05:22.090 --> 00:05:26.310
of information in those columns if we're
not very careful about how we present

102
00:05:26.310 --> 00:05:29.780
the available information to you
that you're supposed to see, and

103
00:05:29.780 --> 00:05:33.450
the ways in which we do that have to
really be understood, have to monitored,

104
00:05:33.450 --> 00:05:37.310
have to be managed, have to be vetted,
or we may inadvertently, by accident,

105
00:05:37.310 --> 00:05:41.070
expose information through inference that
actually is suppose to be kept secret.

106
00:05:41.070 --> 00:05:44.250
So this is something we have to really
think about and be aware of cuz this poses

107
00:05:44.250 --> 00:05:48.730
a potential vulnerability, and a threat,
potentially, to information security,

108
00:05:48.730 --> 00:05:50.760
to confidentially, and
of course, to integrity.

109
00:05:50.760 --> 00:05:54.080
And this is something we have to
think about and obviously understand.

110
00:05:54.080 --> 00:05:56.030
So something to be concerned about.

111
00:05:56.030 --> 00:05:59.660
Aggregation is also something we have
to think with regards to data and

112
00:05:59.660 --> 00:06:00.872
the management of data.

113
00:06:00.872 --> 00:06:05.900
Combining non-sensitive data from separate
sources together to create sensitive data

114
00:06:05.900 --> 00:06:07.270
is what aggregation's all about.

115
00:06:07.270 --> 00:06:09.350
We can take out sensitive,
non-sensitive and

116
00:06:09.350 --> 00:06:12.870
simply say combining data from
different sources together

117
00:06:12.870 --> 00:06:17.072
to understand additional data,
create additional data, is aggregation.

118
00:06:17.072 --> 00:06:22.020
We're building a whole
from different parts and

119
00:06:22.020 --> 00:06:25.450
effectively by doing that, we are
stitching together and creating a picture

120
00:06:25.450 --> 00:06:29.580
of something, that under normal
circumstances, we may not be able to see.

121
00:06:29.580 --> 00:06:33.575
So I may be able to take data from several

We logon.

352
00:17:59.960 --> 00:18:01.660
The OS is already there.

353
00:18:01.660 --> 00:18:05.750
Now, what we do, the customer,
we load our applications and our data, and

354
00:18:05.750 --> 00:18:09.850
our development environments, and then
we manage them on top of the platform.

355
00:18:09.850 --> 00:18:12.050
So, the provider is giving
us the full platform,

356
00:18:12.050 --> 00:18:15.520
infrastructure and
operational system or OS.

357
00:18:15.520 --> 00:18:18.040
We are then loading everything else up and
managing that.

358
00:18:18.040 --> 00:18:20.690
So, that's the break
point there with PaaS.

359
00:18:20.690 --> 00:18:23.280
PaaS is traditionally seen
as a dev environment, or

360
00:18:23.280 --> 00:18:25.760
an application hosting
environment on demand.

361
00:18:25.760 --> 00:18:27.450
That's usually what it's used for.

362
00:18:27.450 --> 00:18:30.350
Companies that want to do application
development, that want to host their own

363
00:18:30.350 --> 00:18:34.250
databases, run their own application
services, will use a PaaS model.

364
00:18:34.250 --> 00:18:36.010
That's traditionally what they use.

365
00:18:36.010 --> 00:18:40.550
SaaS, Software as a Service, incorporates
infrastructure as well as platform.

366
00:18:40.550 --> 00:18:44.920
And what you get there is the ability
to basically rent all of that including

367
00:18:44.920 --> 00:18:49.360
vendor based software,
whatever that may be, for a fee monthly.

368
00:18:49.360 --> 00:18:51.140
So, think about Office 365.

369
00:18:51.140 --> 00:18:53.329
Think about Salesforce.com.

370
00:18:53.329 --> 00:18:56.710
These are Software as a Service models.

371
00:18:56.710 --> 00:19:00.350
Specifically, within Software as a Service
we have two distinct software models.

372
00:19:00.350 --> 00:19:02.440
We have hosted application management.

373
00:19:02.440 --> 00:19:07.225
So, we have an Office 365 model,
where you can pay the provider to host or

374
00:19:07.225 --> 00:19:10.680
Salesforce.com, where you could pay
the provider to host your data.

375
00:19:10.680 --> 00:19:13.530
And they give you access
to an application.

376
00:19:13.530 --> 00:19:15.140
Microsoft Exchange for email.

377
00:19:15.140 --> 00:19:18.195
Microsoft SharePoint for
enterprise content management.

378
00:19:18.195 --> 00:19:20.720
Salesforce.com for CRM.

379
00:19:20.720 --> 00:19:24.210
That's a hosted application model,
where they host the entire application.

380
00:19:24.210 --> 00:19:26.975
And all the infrastructure and
platforms support that goes with it.

381
00:19:26.975 --> 00:19:28.805
They do all the updates
to the application.

382
00:19:28.805 --> 00:19:30.135
They do the patch management.

383
00:19:30.135 --> 00:19:31.825
They do the database management.

384
00:19:31.825 --> 00:19:33.285
They do the access control.

385
00:19:33.285 --> 00:19:34.985
They'll provide the back end for that.

386
00:19:34.985 --> 00:19:36.225
You will provision users, but

387
00:19:36.225 --> 00:19:39.355
they provide the actual enforcement
mechanisms on the back end.

388
00:19:39.355 --> 00:19:40.735
They do all the logging.

389
00:19:40.735 --> 00:19:43.135
They do all the transactional monitoring.

390
00:19:43.135 --> 00:19:45.265
They do all the configuration management.

391
00:19:45.265 --> 00:19:46.235
They build the whole thing.

392
00:19:46.235 --> 00:19:48.800
All you do is put your data there and
consume.

393
00:19:48.800 --> 00:19:50.400
And the other kind of SaaS model,

394
00:19:50.400 --> 00:19:52.970
you're renting just individual
application software.

395
00:19:52.970 --> 00:19:57.090
This is the Office 365 model, but
specifically, the Office portion of it,

396
00:19:57.090 --> 00:20:00.510
where you download Microsoft Office and
install it on demand.

397
00:20:00.510 --> 00:20:02.200
We call it on demand software.

398
00:20:02.200 --> 00:20:06.190
And you install Microsoft Office,
from the cloud, and

399
00:20:06.190 --> 00:20:09.350
you then run Office on your
local machine for a monthly fee.

400
00:20:09.350 --> 00:20:11.640
That's the other kind of
SaaS model that we have.

401
00:20:11.640 --> 00:20:15.140
So, Software as a Service effectively
means you're renting the software.

402
00:20:15.140 --> 00:20:18.485
And you're providing access to
to the software in that model.

403
00:20:18.485 --> 00:20:21.975
As a result of having those
three software models,

404
00:20:21.975 --> 00:20:24.315
we still now have to talk about
the three cloud service models.

405
00:20:24.315 --> 00:20:25.915
We have one more list we have to go to.

406
00:20:25.915 --> 00:20:28.055
We have to talk about the cloud
deployment models, so

407
00:20:28.055 --> 00:20:29.985
we're gonna put those up on the screen.

408
00:20:29.985 --> 00:20:32.985
And the cloud deployment models,
allow us to shape and

409
00:20:32.985 --> 00:20:36.165
discuss what type of
cloud we're gonna use.

410
00:20:36.165 --> 00:20:36.985
We have four models.

411
00:20:36.985 --> 00:20:40.360
Now, you may be familiar with the first
three, you may have heard of them.

412
00:20:40.360 --> 00:20:42.130
Probably, haven't heard of
the fourth one as much.

413
00:20:42.130 --> 00:20:45.285
Community cloud is not one that a lot
of people know about or talk about.

414
00:20:45.285 --> 00:20:46.790
So,let's talk about all of them.

415
00:20:46.790 --> 00:20:49.750
The private cloud is going to
be the ability to run a cloud

416
00:20:49.750 --> 00:20:53.490
internal to your network, really just for
your team members, your employees,

417
00:20:53.490 --> 00:20:55.570
nobody else from the outside
can get into it.

418
00:20:55.570 --> 00:20:59.640
You typically will either host
it on-prem inside your company.

419
00:20:59.640 --> 00:21:01.740
You may pay somebody to host it for you.

420
00:21:01.740 --> 00:21:05.550
Microsoft, Google, Amazon,
can host private clouds for you as well.

421
00:21:05.550 --> 00:21:07.390
You will provision and manage that.

422
00:21:07.390 --> 00:21:10.900
That is what we would have thought of
years ago as an intranet, an internal

423
00:21:10.900 --> 00:21:14.972
private network, is effectively
now re-branded as a private cloud.

424
00:21:14.972 --> 00:21:17.110
I wanna get the gig where I sit in a room,

425
00:21:17.110 --> 00:21:19.475
I come up with new innovative
marketing slogans.

426
00:21:19.475 --> 00:21:21.600
>> Right?
>> And I remake everybody's world.

427
00:21:21.600 --> 00:21:24.050
It's something new, but
it's still the same thing.

428
00:21:24.050 --> 00:21:24.590
>> The same thing.

429
00:21:24.590 --> 00:21:25.115
>> Right.
>> Yeah.

430
00:21:25.115 --> 00:21:26.130
[LAUGH]

431
00:21:26.130 --> 00:21:27.160
>> That's what I wanna do when I

432
00:21:27.160 --> 00:21:27.880
grow up, right?

433
00:21:27.880 --> 00:21:30.340
So, if anybody has that job out there.

434
00:21:30.340 --> 00:21:31.910
Somebody email me, let me know.

435
00:21:31.910 --> 00:21:33.775
I wanna come work for
you, if I can do that.

436
00:21:33.775 --> 00:21:36.260
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, so the public cloud, right?

437
00:21:36.260 --> 00:21:39.290
Public cloud, the biggest example we
have of the public cloud in the world is

438
00:21:39.290 --> 00:21:42.230
the internet or the worldwide web,
and we've had that for many years.

439
00:21:42.230 --> 00:21:45.100
And, again, we used to call public clouds,
the internet or

440
00:21:45.100 --> 00:21:47.410
the worldwide web because
that's what they were.

441
00:21:47.410 --> 00:21:48.700
Today, we call it a public cloud.

442
00:21:48.700 --> 00:21:52.770
It is simply a cloud that is available
to people, to individuals, right?

443
00:21:52.770 --> 00:21:54.010
And they can get into it.

444
00:21:54.010 --> 00:21:56.790
Some of them may have to log in and
they have to authenticate.

445
00:21:56.790 --> 00:21:57.380
Some may not.

446
00:21:57.380 --> 00:21:59.630
Some may just be open to everybody,
regardless.

447
00:21:59.630 --> 00:22:03.372
So, think about for instance,
going to Amazon.com,

448
00:22:03.372 --> 00:22:05.780
going to CNN, going to ITPro.tv.

449
00:22:05.780 --> 00:22:08.740
Right, whatever it is, all of that's
available through the public cloud.

450
00:22:08.740 --> 00:22:11.050
You get to it through the internet,
through the world wide web.

451
00:22:11.050 --> 00:22:13.005
You access one or more websites.

452
00:22:13.005 --> 00:22:16.425
The majority of that material is
available to you without you logging in.

453
00:22:16.425 --> 00:22:19.875
You can go to the ITPro.tv website
without being a member and

454
00:22:19.875 --> 00:22:22.685
look at demos of the shows and
things like that.

455
00:22:22.685 --> 00:22:25.315
So, you can see all that
without having to be a member.

456
00:22:25.315 --> 00:22:30.052
But then, you may have to log in and go
to the private side of that environment.

457
00:22:30.052 --> 00:22:33.442
Log into an environment where we only
have contents available to members, and

458
00:22:33.442 --> 00:22:36.842
that may cross over into
the private side of the cloud.

459
00:22:36.842 --> 00:22:38.672
And so, public and
private clouds can commingle.

460
00:22:38.672 --> 00:22:41.602
And that's often where we see
what is known as a hybrid cloud.

461
00:22:41.602 --> 00:22:44.032
A hybrid cloud is going to
combine the two together, or

462
00:22:44.032 --> 00:22:46.422
combine two of the three
cloud models together.

463
00:22:46.422 --> 00:22:48.312
Because it could be private,
public, and or

464
00:22:48.312 --> 00:22:50.610
community that are joined
together in a hybrid.

465
00:22:50.610 --> 00:22:53.890
But the idea of a hybrid simply means, we
join two of the three models together and

466
00:22:53.890 --> 00:22:57.540
we give access to both, in theory,
through one sort of common model.

467
00:22:57.540 --> 00:22:58.970
The community cloud, ultimately,

468
00:22:58.970 --> 00:23:02.010
the last cloud model we talk about,
is kind of interesting.

469
00:23:02.010 --> 00:23:04.380
People often think of it as
just being a private cloud.

470
00:23:04.380 --> 00:23:06.370
In effect, it is in one respect.

471
00:23:06.370 --> 00:23:08.010
It is a subset of the private cloud.

472
00:23:08.010 --> 00:23:10.970
But the way I often talk about
community cloud is the following.

473
00:23:10.970 --> 00:23:15.290
Private clouds are gonna be only available
to everybody in the organization.

474
00:23:15.290 --> 00:23:18.890
So, broadly available, but
only to the people in the organization.

475
00:23:18.890 --> 00:23:23.590
So, if you have a, let's say, a business,
we have 1000 team members, 1000 employees.

476
00:23:23.590 --> 00:23:27.020
A private cloud will be available
to all 1000 at the same time.

477
00:23:27.020 --> 00:23:30.150
So, services like email would be
available through the private cloud to

478
00:23:30.150 --> 00:23:31.254
everybody in the organization.

479
00:23:31.254 --> 00:23:35.220
Enterprise contact management, it's a file
and print sharing, would be available

480
00:23:35.220 --> 00:23:38.770
through a private cloud to everybody
in the organization at the same time.

481
00:23:38.770 --> 00:23:42.440
A community cloud is a cloud that
is generated by a sub-group.

482
00:23:42.440 --> 00:23:45.080
A group that has specific interests
that they want to deal with, and

483
00:23:45.080 --> 00:23:47.450
provide services around, within the cloud.

484
00:23:47.450 --> 00:23:49.930
But they only want it to be
open to members of that group.

485
00:23:49.930 --> 00:23:54.020
So, it's like a subset of the private
cloud, so in some organizations,

486
00:23:54.020 --> 00:23:57.670
we often see that we have private cloud
services like I mentioned email, file and

487
00:23:57.670 --> 00:24:00.120
print sharing, things like that,
available to everybody.

488
00:24:00.120 --> 00:24:04.120
And then, a group like sales and
marketing may go off on their own and

489
00:24:04.120 --> 00:24:06.890
create a community cloud that
is unique to their needs because

490
00:24:06.890 --> 00:24:11.560
you have things like social media
services, things like data analytics,

491
00:24:11.560 --> 00:24:15.040
things of that nature,
maybe unique to that particular group.

492
00:24:15.040 --> 00:24:17.930
And they want to be able to have
a community cloud that's specifically

493
00:24:17.930 --> 00:24:21.670
tailored for them, to offer those services
only to the members of that group.

494
00:24:21.670 --> 00:24:23.660
And that's what a community
cloud really does.

495
00:24:23.660 --> 00:24:28.450
It offers a limited, a focused, a group
of people who share common concerns.

496
00:24:28.450 --> 00:24:31.970
Partake of community cloud, and
then those people can exist and

497
00:24:31.970 --> 00:24:33.380
interact within that cloud.

498
00:24:33.380 --> 00:24:35.410
Right?
So, this is how the definition

499
00:24:35.410 --> 00:24:37.690
is ultimately going to
play out if you will.

500
00:24:39.000 --> 00:24:39.950
>> All right, very good Adam.

501
00:24:39.950 --> 00:24:43.900
Again, a lot of information and
I believe we're still not done

502
00:24:43.900 --> 00:24:47.600
with looking at vulnerabilities,
assessing and mitigating vulnerabilities

503
00:24:47.600 --> 00:24:51.220
in our security architecture, but
we're gonna save that for another one.

504
00:24:51.220 --> 00:24:53.370
So, we're gonna have a part three for
this episode, so

505
00:24:53.370 --> 00:24:54.830
make sure you come back for that one.

506
00:24:54.830 --> 00:24:57.090
Remember, if you guys wanna attend
one of Adam's classes live,

507
00:24:57.090 --> 00:25:00.520
shoot us an email, SeeAdam@ITPro.tv.

508
00:25:00.520 --> 00:25:02.718
For now, signing off, I'm Mike Roderick.

509
00:25:02.718 --> 00:25:03.861
>> I'm not.

510
00:25:03.861 --> 00:25:06.650
>> [LAUGH] And we'll see you next time.

511
00:25:06.650 --> 00:25:07.831
>> Take care.

512
00:25:07.831 --> 00:25:14.030
[MUSIC]
