episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.051 --> 00:00:10.051
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.929 --> 00:00:15.235
Hello and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.235 --> 00:00:20.040
I'm your host Mike Rodrick,
today we're doing our CISSP content, and

4
00:00:20.040 --> 00:00:24.960
specifically, we're continuing on to
assess and mitigate our vulnerabilities.

5
00:00:24.960 --> 00:00:29.600
And we've got some good stuff coming up
here Adam, I know we got some terminology

6
00:00:29.600 --> 00:00:33.850
we've got to go over, and a few other
things, so we'll just get right into it.

7
00:00:33.850 --> 00:00:35.440
Here's Mr. Adam Gordon.

8
00:00:35.440 --> 00:00:37.625
>> Vocabulary master Gordon to you sir.

9
00:00:37.625 --> 00:00:39.320
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, we're back.

10
00:00:39.320 --> 00:00:42.910
Let's talk a little bit more about
accessing and mitigating vulnerability.

11
00:00:42.910 --> 00:00:44.590
We've been having a very
good discussion so

12
00:00:44.590 --> 00:00:48.300
far in our other episodes about all
the things we have to do to think about

13
00:00:48.300 --> 00:00:50.656
how we're going to actually take
care of these issues and concerns.

14
00:00:50.656 --> 00:00:53.900
What we're going to do now is drill
down a little bit on some vocabulary,

15
00:00:53.900 --> 00:00:56.620
specifically related to encryption and
cryptography, that's going to

16
00:00:56.620 --> 00:01:00.240
help us to better understand the whole
thought process behind this approach.

17
00:01:00.240 --> 00:01:04.660
There's a lot of things that go on when we
think about encryption and cryptography.

18
00:01:04.660 --> 00:01:07.060
Lot of working parts, lot of language.

19
00:01:07.060 --> 00:01:10.500
And, you know information security is
as much about the language we speak,

20
00:01:10.500 --> 00:01:11.440
as about the things we do.

21
00:01:11.440 --> 00:01:15.330
And when it comes to preparing for,
and ultimately being successful

22
00:01:15.330 --> 00:01:19.510
to take a pass at the exam like the CISSP,
vocabulary is crucial.

23
00:01:19.510 --> 00:01:22.380
So we're going to make sure we spend
some time going over definitions.

24
00:01:22.380 --> 00:01:25.840
Speaking of which, we probably want to
make sure that we can see the definition,

25
00:01:25.840 --> 00:01:28.020
as opposed to just talking about them.

26
00:01:28.020 --> 00:01:29.316
Look, it's magic, I tell you.

27
00:01:29.316 --> 00:01:30.120
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's magic.

28
00:01:30.120 --> 00:01:32.040
>> [LAUGH]
>> So let's begin our conversation around

29
00:01:32.040 --> 00:01:36.530
the vocabulary with regards to encryption,
with regards to cryptography solutions.

30
00:01:36.530 --> 00:01:38.840
Let's talk about key clustering,
first one up on the list.

31
00:01:38.840 --> 00:01:41.790
You'll see key clustering talks about
different encryption keys ultimately

32
00:01:41.790 --> 00:01:44.650
generating the same ciphertext
from different plaintext.

33
00:01:44.650 --> 00:01:47.150
So what we're talking about
there is the idea of a key.

34
00:01:47.150 --> 00:01:51.490
An encryption key is effectively going to
be the magic ingredient when we talk about

35
00:01:51.490 --> 00:01:52.570
using cryptography.

36
00:01:52.570 --> 00:01:56.390
It's the thing that allows us to
effectively encrypt or decrypt on demand.

37
00:01:56.390 --> 00:01:59.000
I will talk, in a couple of minutes,
about the different kinds of keys and

38
00:01:59.000 --> 00:01:59.870
what they are.

39
00:01:59.870 --> 00:02:04.020
But different encryption keys ultimately
generate the same ciphertext.

40
00:02:04.020 --> 00:02:06.810
Ciphertext is just simply
the encrypted text.

41
00:02:06.810 --> 00:02:09.430
If we take an example of
the sentence the dog is blue,

42
00:02:09.430 --> 00:02:13.460
we run it through the encryption engine,
out the back end comes cipher text.

43
00:02:13.460 --> 00:02:17.740
What we put in on the front end, plain
text, is the message the dog is blue.

44
00:02:17.740 --> 00:02:21.890
So different keys generating
the same cipher text from

45
00:02:21.890 --> 00:02:26.460
the same plain text is a problem,
because now we have a pattern, and

46
00:02:26.460 --> 00:02:30.240
if we can latch onto a pattern, with
anything having to do with encryption or

47
00:02:30.240 --> 00:02:34.100
cryptography, we're going to find a way,
potentially, not a guarantee, but

48
00:02:34.100 --> 00:02:38.440
potentially find a way to exercise
some sort of an advantage and

49
00:02:38.440 --> 00:02:40.290
maybe break the cryptosystem.

50
00:02:40.290 --> 00:02:44.950
So key clustering is bad, because it
allows the attacker to find patterns

51
00:02:44.950 --> 00:02:48.110
that could potentially lead to
the exposure of one or more keys.

52
00:02:48.110 --> 00:02:53.330
Synchronous versus asynchronous
encryption and or decryption requests.

53
00:02:53.330 --> 00:02:55.100
Let's talk about how things are done.

54
00:02:55.100 --> 00:02:57.820
Synchronous processes
are done immediately.

55
00:02:57.820 --> 00:02:59.080
When you do something,

56
00:02:59.080 --> 00:03:02.580
or doing multiple things synchronously,
you're doing them immediately.

57
00:03:02.580 --> 00:03:06.090
When something is asynchronous, you're
peeling them up and doing them in some

58
00:03:06.090 --> 00:03:10.370
sort of organized fashion, but
they're not going to happen immediately.

59
00:03:10.370 --> 00:03:15.170
So, you may submit a request, but it may
be cued up and it may take a minute or

60
00:03:15.170 --> 00:03:16.500
two until it processes.

61
00:03:16.500 --> 00:03:18.960
That's what an asynchronous solution is.

62
00:03:18.960 --> 00:03:21.950
A synchronous solution is happening
in real time, as you submit it,

63
00:03:21.950 --> 00:03:22.980
it's being done.

64
00:03:22.980 --> 00:03:25.420
So we often talk about
a digital certificate and

65
00:03:25.420 --> 00:03:30.040
PKI when we automate the process of
using a certificate authority and

66
00:03:30.040 --> 00:03:35.750
we are submitting requests to the CA over
the web through a web server interface as

67
00:03:35.750 --> 00:03:40.360
being synchronous, because the system will
automatically generate the certificate and

00:27:19.870 --> 00:27:22.860

or something like that.

526
00:27:22.860 --> 00:27:26.760
And we're transposing,
we're shifting in effect, or permutating.

527
00:27:26.760 --> 00:27:28.460
We are modifying in some way.

528
00:27:28.460 --> 00:27:30.920
That's what transposition or
permutation is about.

529
00:27:30.920 --> 00:27:34.900
Substitution is just a very simple thing,
the letter A is really the number one,

530
00:27:34.900 --> 00:27:36.040
the number B is really the number two.

531
00:27:36.040 --> 00:27:40.280
And so, when we write, the dog is blue,
we would find the numerical equivalent, so

532
00:27:40.280 --> 00:27:41.600
we would simply say, 1,5,7,9 and

533
00:27:41.600 --> 00:27:46.000
then, we would translate that back to the
dog is blue, that would be substitution.

534
00:27:47.740 --> 00:27:52.640
SP network, the SP network stands for and
by the way SP stands for substitution and

535
00:27:52.640 --> 00:27:54.480
permutation as we talked about which is,

00:27:54.480 --> 00:27:59.250
effectively transpositioning, when we
talked about the idea of X oaring, right?

537
00:27:59.250 --> 00:28:01.740
And taking the output of one run and
using it as the input for

538
00:28:01.740 --> 00:28:03.840
the next, it's kind of hinting at this.

539
00:28:03.840 --> 00:28:08.220
It says most block ciphers do a series of
repeated substitutions and permutations to

540
00:28:08.220 --> 00:28:13.550
add what's called confusion and diffusion,
defined below, to the encryption process.

541
00:28:13.550 --> 00:28:19.050
So, the SP network is this idea of using
substitution and permutation, ultimately,

542
00:28:19.050 --> 00:28:22.030
to add confusion and
diffusion to the system so

543
00:28:22.030 --> 00:28:26.440
that we further obfuscate,
further hide the original data and

544
00:28:26.440 --> 00:28:29.820
make it that much more difficult for
somebody to break the encryption.

545
00:28:29.820 --> 00:28:33.850
Confusion provides or
allows us to effectively provide the idea

546
00:28:33.850 --> 00:28:37.940

mixing up things to effectively add so

547
00:28:37.940 --> 00:28:41.700
much randomness seemingly into
the system that it's very hard for

548
00:28:41.700 --> 00:28:44.840
us to really understand what is the real
data and what is the data that's been

549
00:28:44.840 --> 00:28:49.160
modified through multiple XOR's,
multiple permutations along the way.

550
00:28:49.160 --> 00:28:50.860
Effectively rendering, not the real data,

551
00:28:50.860 --> 00:28:54.480
but a representation of the encrypted
data multiple times over.

552
00:28:54.480 --> 00:28:57.680
Diffusion is the idea of
mixing up the location so

553
00:28:57.680 --> 00:29:02.580
that way, as we scatter the plain text

554
00:29:02.580 --> 00:29:06.410
people don't know where the real data is

555
00:29:06.410 --> 00:29:09.070
And as a result, they're not sure

00:29:09.070 --> 00:29:12.030

Avalanche effect, right, the avalanche

00:29:14.960 --> 00:29:18.470

00:29:19.450 --> 00:29:23.570

00:29:23.570 --> 00:29:27.160

562
00:29:27.160 --> 00:29:28.090

00:29:28.090 --> 00:29:29.900

related events that become larger and

00:29:40.440 --> 00:29:44.370

00:29:44.370 --> 00:29:48.180

570
00:29:52.580 --> 00:29:54.470

Because it gets amplified
through all those runts

asymmetric, we've been talking a lot about
how you can implement them, we can use

482
00:26:16.210 --> 00:26:19.430
the private key with, then we're limited
by that as we've been talking about.

483
00:26:19.430 --> 00:26:20.690
We have trouble transmitting that.

484
00:26:20.690 --> 00:26:22.870
So we're gonna have to keep
it ourselves very limited.

485
00:26:22.870 --> 00:26:26.600
When we use a public private key
pair we can use the private key or

486
00:26:26.600 --> 00:26:28.150
the public key depending on
what we're looking to do.

487
00:26:28.150 --> 00:26:29.530
Whether we're looking to sign or

488
00:26:29.530 --> 00:26:33.010
we're looking to securely transmit,
we may pair the two together.

489
00:26:33.010 --> 00:26:35.030
Symmetric and asymmetric encryption.

490
00:26:35.030 --> 00:26:38.690
Effectively allowing us to get
the advantages of symmetric encryption

491
00:26:38.690 --> 00:26:40.210
very quick.

492
00:26:40.210 --> 00:26:43.510
But the downside,
which is a single key hard to manage,

493
00:26:43.510 --> 00:26:46.650
we overcome that with asymmetric,
which is a dual key pair.

494
00:26:46.650 --> 00:26:49.270
We can use the public key of the recipient

495
00:26:49.270 --> 00:26:53.060
to effectively safeguard the sending
of the symmetric private key, and

496
00:26:53.060 --> 00:26:55.130
I'm sure that it will not be
compromised along the way.

497
00:26:56.180 --> 00:26:59.425
I'm out of things to talk about with
cryptography because my brain is hurting.

498
00:26:59.425 --> 00:27:00.880
>> [LAUGH]
>> We've talked about so much.

499

This is our fifth episode

500
00:27:02.535 --> 00:27:03.186

501

>> Five episodes.

502
00:27:03.975 --> 00:27:05.450
How often do we have five episodes.

503
00:27:05.450 --> 00:27:07.574
Only when they let me talk without

504
00:27:07.574 --> 00:27:08.991
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's how often we get five.

508

All five episodes regarding

509

We've been talking specifically about
vulnerabilities dealing with system

00:27:25.100 --> 00:27:29.880

511
00:27:29.880 --> 00:27:33.070
We're gonna have in the some upcoming
episodes additional discussions about

512
00:27:33.070 --> 00:27:37.690
assessing and mitigating vulnerabilities
in different areas, Web for instance,

513
00:27:37.690 --> 00:27:39.090
mobile, things like that.

514
00:27:39.090 --> 00:27:42.020
We're not done in other words,
we're talking about assessment and

515
00:27:42.020 --> 00:27:43.350
mitigation of vulnerabilities.

516
00:27:43.350 --> 00:27:46.960
But we really had to be very deep,
and very broad here in our discussion

517
00:27:46.960 --> 00:27:50.410
initially to set it up from the system
architecture perspective, so

518
00:27:50.410 --> 00:27:52.790
that we can then delve
into these specific areas,

519
00:27:52.790 --> 00:27:55.000
as we now go through
some additional material.

520
00:27:55.000 --> 00:27:58.650
Overall, as you prepare to study
from this entire section, and

521
00:27:58.650 --> 00:28:02.680
prepare to take and ultimately
successfully pass the CISSP exam.

522
00:28:02.680 --> 00:28:04.860
We spent a fair amount
of time on cryptography.

523
00:28:04.860 --> 00:28:05.910
There's a reason for that.

524
00:28:05.910 --> 00:28:07.710
It's very important for
you to understand it.

525
00:28:07.710 --> 00:28:11.590
It forms one of the fundamental
basic constructs that we use

526
00:28:11.590 --> 00:28:14.880
in every discussion we have
about security in any way.

527
00:28:14.880 --> 00:28:17.660
Because we're always talking about
confidentiality and integrity.

528
00:28:17.660 --> 00:28:19.380
These are two of the three pillars,

529
00:28:19.380 --> 00:28:21.920
the foundational elements
of information security.

530
00:28:21.920 --> 00:28:25.680
Cryptography is all about how we

531
00:28:25.680 --> 00:28:28.260
Make sure you understand what
we've talked about here,

532
00:28:28.260 --> 00:28:30.430
make sure you are comfortable
with the language.

533
00:28:30.430 --> 00:28:33.970
Make sure you understand how and

534
00:28:33.970 --> 00:28:35.800
These things will be very helpful to you.

535
00:28:35.800 --> 00:28:39.070
They were very important for

536

>> I tell you, that's great stuff, Adam.

537

Five episodes,

And remember,

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.009 --> 00:00:10.009
[MUSIC]

2

Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.300 --> 00:00:17.940
My name's Mike Rodrick,
I'll be your host today.

4
00:00:17.940 --> 00:00:21.450
And we're continuing on with our CISSP,
and specifically,

5
00:00:21.450 --> 00:00:25.740
we've been looking at assessing and
mitigating vulnerabilities, and we started

6
00:00:25.740 --> 00:00:29.920
off looking at system architecture,
we're gonna shift gears a little bit.

7
00:00:29.920 --> 00:00:33.720
We're gonna shift into web-based
vulnerabilities as well as some mobile

8
00:00:33.720 --> 00:00:38.430
vulnerabilities and ICS systems or
my industrial control systems.

9
00:00:38.430 --> 00:00:41.150
And here to help us with all
of that is Mr. Adam Gordon.

10
00:00:41.150 --> 00:00:41.958
How you doing, Adam?

11
00:00:41.958 --> 00:00:43.350
>> I'm good, I'm good.

12

I wanted to be Mike today and
actually be the host and

14

So we could do that cuz Mike

15

16
00:00:52.550 --> 00:00:55.058
So I'll go ahead and
step in since Mike hasn't volunteered.

17
00:00:55.058 --> 00:00:57.897
>> [LAUGH]
>> Let's talk about assessing and

18
00:00:57.897 --> 00:01:00.555
mitigating, or continuing our
thought process, I should say,

19
00:01:00.555 --> 00:01:01.974
about assessing and mitigating.

20
00:01:01.974 --> 00:01:06.364
We're focusing on web-based, on mobile,
on ICS, industrial control and

21
00:01:06.364 --> 00:01:09.280
on SCADA systems,
supervisory control systems.

22
00:01:09.280 --> 00:01:12.170
We're gonna talk about vulnerabilities and
ways to deal with them in those areas.

23
00:01:12.170 --> 00:01:15.440
We're gonna wrap that kind of
all up in one large discussion.

24
00:01:15.440 --> 00:01:18.490
Give us the ability to look
out across that landscape and

25
00:01:18.490 --> 00:01:21.750
figure out what we need to be doing
differently in order to be more secure.

26
00:01:21.750 --> 00:01:24.020
So as we think about
suggested protection for

27
00:01:24.020 --> 00:01:29.370
the web, we really want to be thinking
about is what goes on in the web services.

28
00:01:29.370 --> 00:01:31.310
What goes on with web services,
through the web?

29
00:01:31.310 --> 00:01:34.530
The idea is that we're having people come
in, in often cases, anonymously in some

30
00:01:34.530 --> 00:01:37.060
cases they are authorizing, and
we're knowing who they are, so

31
00:01:37.060 --> 00:01:39.410
they're coming in, and
they're providing credentials.

32
00:01:39.410 --> 00:01:42.157
But effectively, they're showing up and

33
00:01:42.157 --> 00:01:47.267
demanding from us that we provide goods
and services to them using protocols and

34
00:01:47.267 --> 00:01:51.020
using information that may or
may not show us who they are.

35
00:01:51.020 --> 00:01:54.860
It may be hard for us and others to know
really who somebody is other than through

36
00:01:54.860 --> 00:01:56.240
a username and a password.

37
00:01:56.240 --> 00:02:01.290
The protocol HTTP, the protocol HTTPS,
the protocol FTP, those kind of

38
00:02:01.290 --> 00:02:06.130
protocols really don't have authorization
associated with them directly.

39
00:02:06.130 --> 00:02:09.560
At least HTTP anyway, does not,
and certainly FTP does not.

40
00:02:09.560 --> 00:02:12.640
It is anonymous by design and
by nature more often than not.

41
00:02:12.640 --> 00:02:16.680
So when we think about associating and
think about identifying and

42
00:02:16.680 --> 00:02:21.450
think about analyzing vulnerabilities and
worrying about mitigation techniques,

43
00:02:21.450 --> 00:02:24.970
with regards to assessing weaknesses
in these systems, we have to start out

44
00:02:24.970 --> 00:02:28.500
from that assumption that, a lot of the
times that people are using these systems,

45
00:02:28.500 --> 00:02:30.170
may not be directly known to us.

46
00:02:30.170 --> 00:02:33.690
And we have to then take everything we
see with a grain of salt, so to speak.

47
00:02:33.690 --> 00:02:36.590
Be a little skeptical about where they're
coming from and what they're doing.

48
00:02:36.590 --> 00:02:40.980
And so what we have to think about is
really making the systems as hardened,

49
00:02:40.980 --> 00:02:46.330
as secure as we can up front, to prevent
the obvious things from going wrong.

50
00:02:46.330 --> 00:02:49.380
Don't give strangers the ability
to find open doors and window,

51
00:02:49.380 --> 00:02:52.960
in other words,
in our solutions, lock them up.

52
00:02:52.960 --> 00:02:55.150
Get rid of the unnecessary services.

53
00:02:55.150 --> 00:02:56.988
Make sure we're up-to-date on our patches.

54
00:02:56.988 --> 00:03:00.600
Make sure that we're not offering
information through a web service or

55
00:03:00.600 --> 00:03:04.590
generically in any form that should not
be seen because it is classified as

56
00:03:04.590 --> 00:03:05.630
confidential.

57
00:03:05.630 --> 00:03:09.440
So make sure we are safeguarding
information with data classification.

58
00:03:09.440 --> 00:03:13.630
Make sure we are using cryptography,
as we've talked about extensively.

59
00:03:13.630 --> 00:03:17.770
And encryption to safeguard data both
in transit, as well as in storage.

60
00:03:17.770 --> 00:03:20.720
And so these are the kind of things we
wanna be thinking about as we begin

61
00:03:20.720 --> 00:03:23.600
our conversation with
regards to web services.

62
00:03:23.600 --> 00:03:26.201
We wanna make sure we're
scanning constantly, looking for

63
00:03:26.201 --> 00:03:27.783
vulnerabilities in these systems.

64
00:03:27.783 --> 00:03:30.736
It is rare that a month goes by
without hearing about one or

65
00:03:30.736 --> 00:03:34.860
more vulnerabilities on a web platform,
without mentioning vendors by name,

66
00:03:34.860 --> 00:03:36.906
just generically, any web platform.

67
00:03:36.906 --> 00:03:38.612
Doesn't really matter.

68
00:03:38.612 --> 00:03:41.939
In other words, there are many
vulnerabilities out there that

69
00:03:41.939 --> 00:03:44.824
exist that are available to
bad actors in the web area,

70
00:03:44.824 --> 00:03:48.899
and the more we scan, the more proactive
we are, the more we probe and look for

71
00:03:48.899 --> 00:03:50.810
so that we ultimately can fix them.

72
00:03:50.810 --> 00:03:53.030
We know what they are before
the bad actors come and

73
00:03:53.030 --> 00:03:55.590
take them away from us,
those are things that we're gonna

74
00:03:55.590 --> 00:03:57.610
ultimately have to do if
we wanna stay secure.

75
00:03:57.610 --> 00:03:59.110
It's just very important to do.

76
00:03:59.110 --> 00:04:00.583
We should be using scanning technologies.

77
00:04:00.583 --> 00:04:06.230
We've talked about IDSs, IPSs, intrusion
detection, intrusion prevention systems.

78
00:04:06.230 --> 00:04:09.540
We should be using firewalls to
safeguard our infrastructure.

79
00:04:09.540 --> 00:04:13.812
Create a DMZ, a demilitarized zone
where web servers can safely live, but

80
00:04:13.812 --> 00:04:17.620
they are protected by at least one,
if not more than one, gateway device that

81
00:04:17.620 --> 00:04:22.660
will offer some form of inbound filtering
to prevent just random association and

82
00:04:22.660 --> 00:04:26.650
random communication from taking place,
or rather communication that is filtered.

83
00:04:26.650 --> 00:04:29.840
That we understand and we can control,
is really the goal here.

84
00:04:29.840 --> 00:04:33.810
Make sure we get rid of unnecessary and
unwanted administrative interfaces.

85
00:04:33.810 --> 00:04:37.085
Just because somebody thinks it's
a good idea to put a web interface into

86
00:04:37.085 --> 00:04:41.810
administer or configure a, front end for
something doesn't mean it's a good idea.

87
00:04:41.810 --> 00:04:43.290
Just means they thought
it was a good idea.

88
00:04:44.560 --> 00:04:47.740
Somebody thought it was a good idea to
build a ship called the Titanic and

89
00:04:47.740 --> 00:04:49.050
sail it in the middle of an ice field.

90
00:04:49.050 --> 00:04:50.385
That doesn't mean it was a good idea.

91
00:04:50.385 --> 00:04:51.369
>> [LAUGH]
>> It just means

92
00:04:51.369 --> 00:04:54.670
somebody thought it was and
turned out to be not such a good idea.

93
00:04:54.670 --> 00:04:58.010
So my point is when we
think about things like

94
00:04:58.010 --> 00:05:01.590
using web interfaces to configure
firewalls and switches and

95
00:05:01.590 --> 00:05:06.190
routers today, that may be very nice for
the administrator cuz it's convenient.

96
00:05:06.190 --> 00:05:07.630
You don't have to learn
about a command line,

97
00:05:07.630 --> 00:05:10.560
you don't have to worry about
remembering a bunch of commands.

98
00:05:10.560 --> 00:05:14.390
We can more easily view things, and
I get that, and that's perfectly fine.

99
00:05:14.390 --> 00:05:17.980
But the challenge with that is that
the bad actors also get that, and

100
00:05:17.980 --> 00:05:19.710
they also understand how
easy we're making it.

101
00:05:19.710 --> 00:05:22.350
And they are not gonna
sit on the sidelines and

102
00:05:22.350 --> 00:05:26.670
just watch you do your job and
not try to take that system away from you.

103
00:05:26.670 --> 00:05:28.610
They're gonna say,
well I want some of that.

104
00:05:28.610 --> 00:05:30.870
It's easy, I wanna get in there and
play around too.

105
00:05:30.870 --> 00:05:32.230
Adam, why don't you move over?

106
00:05:32.230 --> 00:05:33.790
Let me touch that router for a little bit.

107
00:05:33.790 --> 00:05:36.520
Let me see what I can do to
reconfigure that through the web.

108
00:05:36.520 --> 00:05:39.490
So if we're not smart about
how we manage web services and

109
00:05:39.490 --> 00:05:43.250
availability through the web, somebody's
gonna come and take that away from us.

110
00:05:43.250 --> 00:05:44.850
So one of the biggest
vulnerabilities we have,

111
00:05:44.850 --> 00:05:47.700
one of the biggest things we have
to mitigate with web services,

112
00:05:47.700 --> 00:05:51.390
is the availability,
the ubiquitousness of web access,

113
00:05:51.390 --> 00:05:56.040
that everybody can get to that front door
and knock on it to see if they can get in.

114
00:05:56.040 --> 00:05:58.290
Remember, we've talked about this before,
my,

115
00:05:58.290 --> 00:06:01.010
be this much better than
everybody else conversation.

116
00:06:01.010 --> 00:06:04.650
Well, with web services,
it's not only be this much better, but

117
00:06:04.650 --> 00:06:09.030
it's be this much better and be this much
better as we've talked about all the time.

118
00:06:09.030 --> 00:06:11.780
Because that web access is
available to everybody,

119
00:06:11.780 --> 00:06:15.230
regardless of whether you want them
to see it or not if you publicly

120
00:06:15.230 --> 00:06:18.130
make it available, if you publish it,
in other words, outside the organization.

121
00:06:18.130 --> 00:06:20.816
Even if it's inside the organization,
behind firewalls,

122
00:06:20.816 --> 00:06:23.143
you still have bad actors
potentially internally.

123
00:06:23.143 --> 00:06:24.660
And we have to worry about them as well.

124
00:06:24.660 --> 00:06:28.800
World would be a lot easier if we only
had bad people on the outside and

125
00:06:28.800 --> 00:06:29.870
good people on the inside.

126
00:06:29.870 --> 00:06:33.910
We wouldn't have to worry so much about
what goes on inside of our systems.

127
00:06:33.910 --> 00:06:36.900
But the problem is, we don't really
know where the bad actors are.

128
00:06:36.900 --> 00:06:39.230
We have to be thinking about this and
be aware of this as well.

129
00:06:39.230 --> 00:06:41.350
We also have to think
about input validation.

130
00:06:41.350 --> 00:06:44.230
How do we allow information
to be put into a web service?

131
00:06:44.230 --> 00:06:46.890
So for instance,
if somebody has a database and

132
00:06:46.890 --> 00:06:49.470
we are gathering data over the web,
and you have a form,

133
00:06:49.470 --> 00:06:53.410
a web enabled form that most of us
have probably seen time and again.

134
00:06:53.410 --> 00:06:57.350
We probably use something very
similar whenever we log on and/or

135
00:06:57.350 --> 00:07:00.900
provide account information the first
time we create an account at a website.

136
00:07:00.900 --> 00:07:04.180
You're asked to fill out some sort
of form on the web and submit that.

137
00:07:04.180 --> 00:07:08.290
That goes into a database on the back
end behind a secure firewall somewhere.

138
00:07:08.290 --> 00:07:10.510
So the web server itself
may be in the DMZ.

139
00:07:10.510 --> 00:07:14.750
The database is behind the internal part
of the DMZ on the local area network,

140
00:07:14.750 --> 00:07:18.340
cuz we know we shouldn't expose
the database unnecessarily.

141
00:07:18.340 --> 00:07:21.050
So we use a web front end to
effectively reach out to you and

142
00:07:21.050 --> 00:07:25.760
to effectively then pass that back to
a secure database stored somewhere else.

143
00:07:25.760 --> 00:07:29.900
The problem is that we don't validate and
control what input goes into that form.

144
00:07:29.900 --> 00:07:34.710
We may be injecting, this is the term
we use, injecting that data and

145
00:07:34.710 --> 00:07:38.540
as a result of that, information
that is incorrect, that's one issue.

146
00:07:38.540 --> 00:07:42.800
But also information that is malformed
into that database that can cause

147
00:07:42.800 --> 00:07:45.960
either denial-of-service attacks,
buffer overflows, or

148
00:07:45.960 --> 00:07:49.394
all sorts of things that can
go wrong with that database.

149
00:07:49.394 --> 00:07:52.613
Databases, especially those
connected to the web,

150
00:07:52.613 --> 00:07:55.912
are highly susceptible to
input validation attacks.

151
00:07:55.912 --> 00:07:59.201
If we don't validate the field,
if we don't say, for instance,

152
00:07:59.201 --> 00:08:03.331
that field could only have 50 characters
of text and it is gonna be alphanumeric.

153
00:08:03.331 --> 00:08:05.178
And we're gonna exclude
special characters.

154
00:08:05.178 --> 00:08:09.245
What will happen is somebody can put
special characters, more than 50.

155
00:08:09.245 --> 00:08:13.461
And they can inject command line code,
structures, and information and

156
00:08:13.461 --> 00:08:16.725
in this case commands that may
be executed in the database

157
00:08:16.725 --> 00:08:21.830
in such a way that it can actually expose
that in the database if we're not careful.

158
00:08:21.830 --> 00:08:23.650
This is called an input validation attack.

00:20:26.710 --> 00:20:30.210
So we could just delete them off the
system, but the reality is deleting them

405
00:20:30.210 --> 00:20:34.840
as we know from prior discussions, is
gonna lead to data remnants that will be

406
00:20:34.840 --> 00:20:38.000
left behind, in other words potentially,
and may be recoverable.

407
00:20:38.000 --> 00:20:41.030
So we have to securely delete them,
securely destroy them.

408
00:20:41.030 --> 00:20:43.930
We can't just simply hit the delete
button and delete the file.

409
00:20:43.930 --> 00:20:47.579
We have to make sure that they are stored
securely, trusted and tamper-proof,

410
00:20:47.579 --> 00:20:52.210
tamper-resistant storage using something
like a tpm, a trusted platform module or

411
00:20:52.210 --> 00:20:56.480
an hsm, a hardware security module,
or a software security module,

412
00:20:56.480 --> 00:20:57.850
they're called different things.

413
00:20:57.850 --> 00:21:00.640
But the idea is that we store them
in these containers while they're in

414
00:21:00.640 --> 00:21:01.640
the system.

415
00:21:01.640 --> 00:21:03.370
They are tamper resistant,
tamper proof, so

416
00:21:03.370 --> 00:21:05.940
if you try to break into them,
the keys are destroyed.

417
00:21:05.940 --> 00:21:07.280
They are effectively shredded,

418
00:21:07.280 --> 00:21:10.850
meaning they are encrypted, and
then the encryption keys are destroyed, so

419
00:21:10.850 --> 00:21:13.360
that way you can't get to them and
unencrypt the keys.

420
00:21:13.360 --> 00:21:18.040
Cryptor shredding or
being able to re-encrypt the data,

421
00:21:18.040 --> 00:21:21.020
if effect, is a very effective
method of destroying data securely,

422
00:21:21.020 --> 00:21:23.310
provided we get rid of
the new encryption keys.

423
00:21:23.310 --> 00:21:26.630
So we effectively get rid of those keys,
and do so securely and

424
00:21:26.630 --> 00:21:28.600
effectively render the data inoperable.

425
00:21:28.600 --> 00:21:31.420
So we wanna make sure we understand
that storage is important, but

426
00:21:31.420 --> 00:21:33.090
destroying is equally important.

427
00:21:33.090 --> 00:21:35.060
We have to overwrite,
we may have to degauss, and

428
00:21:35.060 --> 00:21:38.240
we may have to do various things to get
rid of those keys if they're digital.

429
00:21:38.240 --> 00:21:40.310
If they're written down somewhere
it may be easier, right?

430
00:21:40.310 --> 00:21:43.760
We can burn the paper, we can shred it,
we can do various things to get rid of it.

431
00:21:43.760 --> 00:21:46.420
If we have multiple copies,
we can go around and gather them up and

432
00:21:46.420 --> 00:21:47.450
destroy them.

433
00:21:47.450 --> 00:21:50.330
But ultimately we'll have to figure out
how to destroy keys successfully and

434
00:21:50.330 --> 00:21:51.690
to make sure they're not recoverable.

435
00:21:52.820 --> 00:21:55.610
We also want to keep in mind that
if certificates are compromised,

436
00:21:55.610 --> 00:21:59.500
there may be a cost associated with
revoking them and then reissuing them.

437
00:21:59.500 --> 00:22:02.360
Every so often, you hear about
a certificate being compromised.

438
00:22:02.360 --> 00:22:04.930
Somebody loses the certificate,
something happens.

439
00:22:04.930 --> 00:22:08.240
Malware may infect the system may become
compromised, and as a certificate

440
00:22:08.240 --> 00:22:12.870
administrator, we may have to go in and
revoke that certificate, use what's called

441
00:22:12.870 --> 00:22:16.390
a CRL, certificate revocation list,
and then create a brand new one.

442
00:22:16.390 --> 00:22:19.620
Now, in and of itself, that's really
not a very expensive thing to do.

443
00:22:19.620 --> 00:22:22.110
One certificate every so
often, not a big deal.

444
00:22:22.110 --> 00:22:25.220
But what if that was a root certificate
from a major software vendor

445
00:22:25.220 --> 00:22:28.440
like Microsoft, or Google, right, or

446
00:22:28.440 --> 00:22:32.140
somebody like that, who effectively
has issued that certificate

447
00:22:32.140 --> 00:22:36.260
to hundreds of millions of individuals
to effectively establish trust.

448
00:22:36.260 --> 00:22:39.740
Now all of a sudden it's not so
easy to reissue a brand new certificate.

449
00:22:39.740 --> 00:22:43.540
It is, but what I'm saying is, the pushing
of the button's not the hard part.

450
00:22:43.540 --> 00:22:46.930
The disseminating that out to hundreds of
millions of individuals that have to get

451
00:22:46.930 --> 00:22:50.230
rid of the old certificate and replace it
with a new one is incredibly complicated,

452
00:22:50.230 --> 00:22:52.120
time consuming, and expensive.

453
00:22:52.120 --> 00:22:54.180
So this is something to
be aware of as well.

454
00:22:54.180 --> 00:22:57.720
So, we wanna make sure we can safeguard
certificates and keys, but if they

455
00:22:57.720 --> 00:23:01.240
are lost for any reason or compromised,
we have to be prepared to take action.

456
00:23:01.240 --> 00:23:03.790
Key recovery is one of
those actions we may take.

457
00:23:03.790 --> 00:23:07.720
If the key is lost, not compromised,
but lost, we may be able to recover it.

458
00:23:07.720 --> 00:23:11.100
So if we have only a single private
key and we don't make a copy of it and

459
00:23:11.100 --> 00:23:12.410
we lose the key, we're done right?

460
00:23:12.410 --> 00:23:14.730
We can go home,
there's nothing else to discuss.

461
00:23:14.730 --> 00:23:19.910
But if we have a copy of the key and
we store that key copy somewhere securely,

462
00:23:19.910 --> 00:23:24.540
offsite or with a trusted third party or
through an escrow solution wherever it is,

463
00:23:24.540 --> 00:23:27.130
we can recover that key potentially
given the right circumstances.

464
00:23:27.130 --> 00:23:30.680
So multi-party or
third party key recovery is an option.

465
00:23:30.680 --> 00:23:33.590
We can split up the key and
store it in different places and

466
00:23:33.590 --> 00:23:34.760
have copies available.

467
00:23:34.760 --> 00:23:39.420
We may store it with what's known as
an escrow agent, an off-site trusted third

468
00:23:39.420 --> 00:23:43.200
party, but a single entity as opposed
to multiple parties that will be given

469
00:23:43.200 --> 00:23:47.020
information and instructions about how
to safely store the key for a fee.

470
00:23:47.020 --> 00:23:48.670
Obviously, we'll pay them.

471
00:23:48.670 --> 00:23:50.350
And then under certain circumstances,

472
00:23:50.350 --> 00:23:53.200
we probably have to validate
certain information.

473
00:23:53.200 --> 00:23:55.890
Maybe provide written attestation
about whatever we need done.

474
00:23:55.890 --> 00:23:58.870
There may be a process in other words
typically associated with this.

475
00:23:58.870 --> 00:24:01.260
When we show up, we can't just say,
hey, I'm there to get the key.

476
00:24:01.260 --> 00:24:02.610
Can I have Bob's key please?

477
00:24:02.610 --> 00:24:04.140
It's not quite that simple.

478
00:24:04.140 --> 00:24:05.741
So we may have to go through
a process to identify ourselves.

479
00:24:05.741 --> 00:24:09.144
But assuming we meet the criteria
associated with key recovery, we will be

480
00:24:09.144 --> 00:24:12.385
given a copy of the key, which can then
be used to ultimately Go ahead and

481
00:24:12.385 --> 00:24:15.861
recover the data, so we do want to
understand key recovery and how it works.

482
00:24:15.861 --> 00:24:17.071
It is very important, and

483
00:24:17.071 --> 00:24:19.990
key escrow is also gonna be
very important in this regard.

484
00:24:19.990 --> 00:24:22.220
We want to be thinking about that and
be aware of that.

485
00:24:22.220 --> 00:24:24.240
Along with certificates and
digital certificates and

486
00:24:24.240 --> 00:24:28.800
keys, we also want to think about how we
create the ability to manage data, and

487
00:24:28.800 --> 00:24:33.290
to effectively use digital information,
and to use trust to our advantage.

488
00:24:33.290 --> 00:24:35.060
We think about something known as DRM, or

489
00:24:35.060 --> 00:24:39.400
Digital Rights Management,
effectively applying safeguards to data so

490
00:24:39.400 --> 00:24:41.920
that it cannot be compromised
without our knowledge.

491
00:24:41.920 --> 00:24:46.630
So one of the biggest issues we have
in the modern systems we create,

492
00:24:46.630 --> 00:24:49.210
enterprise content management platforms,
for instance,

493
00:24:49.210 --> 00:24:53.770
like SharePoint, like WebSphere, is that
we store huge volumes of data in the web,

494
00:24:53.770 --> 00:24:56.370
or in the cloud via the web
we access them, and

495
00:24:56.370 --> 00:25:00.790
the problem becomes we may not understand
how to apply access controls properly, and

496
00:25:00.790 --> 00:25:05.100
so somebody may be able to get to
the data and see it within the interface.

497
00:25:05.100 --> 00:25:08.239
But we may not want them to remove it,
and if they can remove it,

498
00:25:08.239 --> 00:25:11.490
the attributes,
the protection attributes are not sticky.

499
00:25:11.490 --> 00:25:14.130
We call them sticky if
they stay with the data.

500
00:25:14.130 --> 00:25:18.100
If they're not sticky, the data itself
may be removed from the system,

501
00:25:18.100 --> 00:25:19.880
and the attributes don't go with the data.

502
00:25:19.880 --> 00:25:21.980
The data, in other words is unprotected.

503
00:25:21.980 --> 00:25:25.090
And this is obviously a very bad state
of affairs to find ourselves in.

504
00:25:25.090 --> 00:25:28.720
So as a result of that,
what we do is we use DRM technology.

505
00:25:28.720 --> 00:25:32.250
DRM technology allows us to apply
sticky attributes to the data.

506
00:25:32.250 --> 00:25:35.640
So no matter where the data goes,
effectively it stays protected.

507
00:25:35.640 --> 00:25:38.610
We can say you can see that data,
but you can't print it.

508
00:25:38.610 --> 00:25:41.400
You may be able to read it, but
only inside a certain application with

509
00:25:41.400 --> 00:25:44.530
a certain reader, and you may not
be able to screen capture it, so

510
00:25:44.530 --> 00:25:46.920
you cannot take a picture of it,
at least not in the system.

511
00:25:46.920 --> 00:25:50.210
You may say, well, I'll pull out my
camera, because I have an app for that.

512
00:25:50.210 --> 00:25:53.520
That's why I hate apps, and
I can go ahead and take a picture.

513
00:25:53.520 --> 00:25:54.680
So, yeah you can do that.

514
00:25:54.680 --> 00:25:56.920
I can't prevent that
from happening with DRM.

515
00:25:56.920 --> 00:25:58.940
I have this conversation
all the time with students.

516
00:25:58.940 --> 00:26:02.030
Some bright person in the room says,
well, what about taking a picture?

517
00:26:02.030 --> 00:26:03.520
Well, yeah, I could do that, right?

518
00:26:03.520 --> 00:26:07.130
The point is, I can't prevent everything,
but I can prevent most things, right?

519
00:26:07.130 --> 00:26:11.110
Like go karts going down the road, for
instance, we have to make sure, right,

520
00:26:11.110 --> 00:26:14.770
that we understand how to safely
coexist with the technology and

521
00:26:14.770 --> 00:26:16.370
the solutions that we're dealing with.

522
00:26:16.370 --> 00:26:19.210
Especially if they're home made go karts,
it's very important.

523
00:26:19.210 --> 00:26:21.660
So, when we think about
digital rights management,

524
00:26:21.660 --> 00:26:24.900
what we're thinking about is
the safety of the data, right?

525
00:26:24.900 --> 00:26:26.330
If we build a system,

526
00:26:26.330 --> 00:26:30.410
that has sticky attributes associated
with it, what we can do so

527
00:26:30.410 --> 00:26:34.400
we can make sure that when the data leaves
the system, we're not able to print it.

528
00:26:34.400 --> 00:26:37.540
We're not able to potentially open
it under certain circumstances.

529
00:26:37.540 --> 00:26:39.490
We may not be able to send it via email.

530
00:26:39.490 --> 00:26:41.900
We may not be able to forward
it if we do get it via email.

531
00:26:41.900 --> 00:26:44.200
There's lots of things
that we can do with DRM.

532
00:26:44.200 --> 00:26:47.600
So data rights management, or digital
rights management technology, is very

533
00:26:47.600 --> 00:26:50.800
comprehensive today, and it's one of the
key ways that we implement security and

534
00:26:50.800 --> 00:26:53.350
safeguarding when we think
about applying cryptography.

535
00:26:53.350 --> 00:26:54.740
That is what we're talking about,

536
00:26:54.740 --> 00:26:58.550
how we apply cryptography in different
situations, different solutions through

537
00:26:58.550 --> 00:27:02.690
PKI, use of digital certificates
with DRM technology, for instance.

538
00:27:02.690 --> 00:27:05.350
One of the ways we do that,
lots of different ways.

539
00:27:05.350 --> 00:27:08.800
There's different types of DRM,
there's what we call always on DRM, so

540
00:27:08.800 --> 00:27:10.260
name applies, it's always on.

541
00:27:10.260 --> 00:27:13.040
There may be DRM associated
with a USB key, so

542
00:27:13.040 --> 00:27:16.490
you may be able to use a USB key
fob to enable the DRM solution or

543
00:27:16.490 --> 00:27:20.180
be able to transfer data onto removal
media, but have the attribute stick.

544
00:27:20.180 --> 00:27:22.580
There's different ways DRM
may be implemented today.

545
00:27:22.580 --> 00:27:25.160
What we wanna think about
are things like digital watermarks,

546
00:27:25.160 --> 00:27:28.080
where we put digital watermarks
into the background of a document.

547
00:27:28.080 --> 00:27:29.560
You've probably seen those, right?

548
00:27:29.560 --> 00:27:32.620
Where they have the do not print,
authorized use only or

549
00:27:32.620 --> 00:27:34.520
whatever that shows up on every page.

550
00:27:34.520 --> 00:27:36.480
You may not see it when you read it but
when you go to print it,

551
00:27:36.480 --> 00:27:38.530
it's there,
it's kind of a light watermark.

552
00:27:38.530 --> 00:27:40.550
Those kind of things, pr property of so

553
00:27:40.550 --> 00:27:44.030
people know where you got it from,
those are all DRM solutions.

554
00:27:44.030 --> 00:27:47.760
Those watermarkings and those
fingerprintings of the data being able to

555
00:27:47.760 --> 00:27:51.870
insert random character strings, will
look like random character strings into

556
00:27:51.870 --> 00:27:54.940
the digital data, but is actually
a digital fingerprint that when stitched

557
00:27:54.940 --> 00:27:59.060
back together uniquely tags the data as
another form of DRM that we use as well.

558
00:27:59.060 --> 00:28:01.100
It's called fingerprinting, or
digital fingerprinting today.

559
00:28:01.100 --> 00:28:03.940
So I want you to just be thinking about
that and be aware of that as well.

560
00:28:03.940 --> 00:28:08.520
We've talked a lot about hashing as well
as digital signature, and what hashing is

561
00:28:08.520 --> 00:28:12.610
used for, remember creating integrity
is really what hashing is all about.

562
00:28:12.610 --> 00:28:16.320
Digital signature provide, digital
signatures, let me enunciate clearly.

563
00:28:16.320 --> 00:28:20.428
Digital signatures provide
non-repudiation and proof of origin.

564
00:28:20.428 --> 00:28:23.079
We want to make sure we understand what
those things are as we think about

565
00:28:23.079 --> 00:28:26.085
hashing, specifically, or rather we
thinking about applying cryptography or

566
00:28:26.085 --> 00:28:26.941
hashing I should say.

567
00:28:26.941 --> 00:28:28.457
When we think about hashing,

568
00:28:28.457 --> 00:28:32.470
what we also want to understand is what
hashing algorithms are that we can use.

569
00:28:32.470 --> 00:28:34.220
I mentioned a couple of them already.

570
00:28:34.220 --> 00:28:36.440
We talked about MD5, we talked about SHY1.

571
00:28:36.440 --> 00:28:41.360
I mentioned that MD5 produces
a 128 bit hashing output so

572
00:28:41.360 --> 00:28:43.510
the bitstream is 128 bits.

573
00:28:43.510 --> 00:28:46.430
I mentioned that SHY1, which is short for

574
00:28:46.430 --> 00:28:49.780
SHY160, is gonna produce
160 bit output streams.

575
00:28:49.780 --> 00:28:50.870
We wanna know that.

576
00:28:50.870 --> 00:28:53.190
We also want to know there
are some other hashing algorithms.

577
00:28:53.190 --> 00:28:56.860
Maybe not as frequently used,
maybe not as popular, right?

578
00:28:56.860 --> 00:28:58.790
But still very important to be aware of.

579
00:28:58.790 --> 00:29:00.890
HAVAL, which is one of
the ones that's out there,

580
00:29:00.890 --> 00:29:04.230
is gonna potentially produce a bit
stream output that's variable.

581
00:29:04.230 --> 00:29:10.250
Anything from 128 bits to 160,
192, 224 or 256 bits.

582
00:29:10.250 --> 00:29:14.526
So it has potentially five different
variable outlets that it can produce.

583
00:29:14.526 --> 00:29:17.383
There's also RIPEMD-160.

584
00:29:17.383 --> 00:29:22.550
RIPEMD-160 is gonna be
160 bit output block,

585
00:29:22.550 --> 00:29:25.370
but it operates similar to what MD5 is.

586
00:29:25.370 --> 00:29:30.490
So it actually looks like an MD5 hash,
but it produces 160 bit output,

587
00:29:30.490 --> 00:29:33.358
instead of 128 bit output.

588
00:29:33.358 --> 00:29:37.910
Let me, again, be clear about that because
my powers of enunciation are quickly,

589
00:29:37.910 --> 00:29:41.060
slowly but surely, and
quickly escaping me here, all right.

590
00:29:41.060 --> 00:29:45.690
As we are talking about ways we
apply cryptography in this episode,

591
00:29:45.690 --> 00:29:48.190
we've really been talking about
the different mechanisms that we can use.

592
00:29:48.190 --> 00:29:51.950
Some review, some a little bit more
in detail as we've gone back and

593
00:29:51.950 --> 00:29:55.160
drilled down on the ways we can
practically apply cryptography.

594
00:29:55.160 --> 00:29:58.460
In our next episode that's gonna
come up that we're gonna talk about,

595
00:29:58.460 --> 00:30:00.750
kind of our part two of
applying cryptography,

596
00:30:00.750 --> 00:30:03.070
we're gonna take a look at
how we break crypto systems.

597
00:30:03.070 --> 00:30:05.950
So understanding how to apply
cryptography's important.

598
00:30:05.950 --> 00:30:09.360
Understanding how it can be attacked, and
therefore, what we have to do to mitigate

599
00:30:09.360 --> 00:30:13.200
ultimately and defend, is gonna be
the subject of our next conversation.

600
00:30:13.200 --> 00:30:15.470
>> All right, good, Adam,
again a lot of great information there.

601
00:30:15.470 --> 00:30:18.110
You know, looking at that that applied
cryptography, taking what we've learned in

602
00:30:18.110 --> 00:30:20.910
the previous episodes and
seeing how we actually implement it,

603
00:30:20.910 --> 00:30:25.080
how it actually helps me protect my
information, my data, my websites,

604
00:30:25.080 --> 00:30:27.720
whatever it is we're trying to
protect out there in the real world.

605
00:30:27.720 --> 00:30:29.115
So thanks for that, Adam.

606
00:30:29.115 --> 00:30:33.231
Remember, if you guys want to attend one
of Adam's classes live, shoot us an email,

00:30:33.231 --> 00:30:34.388
SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

608
00:30:34.388 --> 00:30:36.850
That's gonna do it for this episode.

609
00:30:36.850 --> 00:30:38.580
Signing off, I'm Mike Roderick.

610

>> I'm Adam Gordon.

>> And we'll see you next time.

00:30:40.670 --> 00:30:41.477
>> Take care.

00:33:30.581 --> 00:33:34.300
But there's so many ways in which
a Cryptosystem can be attacked.

695
00:33:34.300 --> 00:33:39.560
That as defenders we really need to
be focused on good implementation,.

696
00:33:39.560 --> 00:33:42.260
Good architecture,
good administrative habits, right?

697
00:33:42.260 --> 00:33:44.570
All the things we've talked
about can be mitigated.

698
00:33:44.570 --> 00:33:46.910
They can be minimized
in terms of exposure.

699
00:33:46.910 --> 00:33:50.170
But they can't be dealt with and
a never seen from or heard from again.

700
00:33:50.170 --> 00:33:51.580
And if we can't zero them out.

701
00:33:51.580 --> 00:33:54.860
We're never gonna get rid of all of
the risks associated with cryptography.

702
00:33:54.860 --> 00:33:59.200
But if we're smart and we are doing
the things we know need to be done.

703
00:33:59.200 --> 00:34:02.190
We can minimize them to the point
to that it's very likely that

704
00:34:02.190 --> 00:34:06.180
our Cryptosystems will outlast our
attacker's abilities to attack them.

705
00:34:06.180 --> 00:34:08.950
This is really ultimately what we wanna
think about as we think about how

706
00:34:08.950 --> 00:34:09.880
do we defend.

707
00:34:09.880 --> 00:34:11.466
And by having knowledge
of how we are attacked,

708
00:34:11.466 --> 00:34:13.060
we'd become better at
thinking how we defend.

709
00:34:14.310 --> 00:34:16.030
>> Very good Adam,
a lot of great information there,

710
00:34:16.030 --> 00:34:18.940
really important to understand
what the bad guys are doing so

711
00:34:18.940 --> 00:34:20.490
that we can better defend against it.

712
00:34:20.490 --> 00:34:22.930
Understand the methods that they're using.

713
00:34:22.930 --> 00:34:26.170
To try to get into our systems and
try to crack our passwords or

714
00:34:26.170 --> 00:34:29.610
crack our cryptography,
we can better defend against that.

715
00:34:29.610 --> 00:34:30.562
Good stuff.

716
00:34:30.562 --> 00:34:34.760
All right, remember, if you guys want
to attend one of Adam's classes live,

717
00:34:34.760 --> 00:34:37.390
shoot us an e-mail, SeeAdam@itprov.tv.

718
00:34:37.390 --> 00:34:39.440
That's gonna do it for this one.

719
00:34:39.440 --> 00:34:41.201
Signing off, I'm Mike Roderick.

720
00:34:41.201 --> 00:34:42.176
>> I'm Adam Gordan.

721
00:34:42.176 --> 00:34:43.545
And we'll see you next time.

722
00:34:43.545 --> 00:34:48.260

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike talk about physical security and secure site design. They talk about defining boundaries and determining what needs to be protected. They talk about many different controls used for physical security, like cameras, fences and fire suppression systems. They also look at crime prevention through environmental design.
episodes.title: Physical Security
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:04.579
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:04.579 --> 00:00:09.461
Hello, and welcome to another

3
00:00:09.461 --> 00:00:15.490
exciting episode here at ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:15.490 --> 00:00:17.260
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

5
00:00:17.260 --> 00:00:19.900
Today, we're doing our CISSP.

6
00:00:19.900 --> 00:00:23.850
And specifically, we're gonna be getting
into Site and Facility Design, and

7
00:00:23.850 --> 00:00:25.950
to that end Physical Security.

8
00:00:25.950 --> 00:00:29.160
It's one of those areas that I think most
of us have a good understanding of some

9
00:00:29.160 --> 00:00:32.910
basic physical security, but there's
really some areas that sometimes I find

10
00:00:32.910 --> 00:00:36.320
that are kind of surprising,
that we don't think about, or get left

11
00:00:36.320 --> 00:00:40.260
off of the list or not checked so here
to help us with that is Mr. Adam Gordon.

12
00:00:40.260 --> 00:00:41.240
How are you doing Adam?

13
00:00:41.240 --> 00:00:42.510
>> I'm good, I'm good.

14
00:00:42.510 --> 00:00:45.345
>> I'm also anchored to the floor so
nobody can walk away with me.

15
00:00:45.345 --> 00:00:47.270
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm physically secure.

16
00:00:47.270 --> 00:00:47.780
>> Perfect.

17
00:00:47.780 --> 00:00:50.860
>> Very important, right, because I'm
wearing my extra special socks this

18
00:00:50.860 --> 00:00:52.780
morning, and
>> You don't anyone to steal those.

19
00:00:52.780 --> 00:00:54.060
>> I don't know if we've even seen that.

20
00:00:54.060 --> 00:00:55.290
Can we go back out to the wide shot here?

21
00:00:55.290 --> 00:00:56.760
>> I think we did.
We got to get rid of my name there.

22
00:00:56.760 --> 00:00:57.350
To see them.
So,

23
00:00:57.350 --> 00:01:00.850
I have the grey with the orange
polka dots on this morning.

24
00:01:00.850 --> 00:01:06.095
I'm rocking an orange polka dot grey pair
of socks in case anybody was wondering.

25
00:01:06.095 --> 00:01:07.700
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, so

26
00:01:07.700 --> 00:01:09.180
when we think about Physical Security.

27
00:01:09.180 --> 00:01:10.510
Right?
What we're thinking about ultimately

28
00:01:10.510 --> 00:01:11.280
Site Design.

29
00:01:11.280 --> 00:01:14.330
Physical Security,
>> So, to do the security, we're

30
00:01:14.330 --> 00:01:17.300
thinking about the things that we have
to do in order to make the operational

31
00:01:17.300 --> 00:01:21.260
environments that we are going to live and
work in every day more secure.

32
00:01:21.260 --> 00:01:23.650
Right?
The goal is to not let bad actors get to

33
00:01:23.650 --> 00:01:24.370
our stuff.

34
00:01:24.370 --> 00:01:27.350
If they come and confine our stuff,
they're probably going to take it away or

35
00:01:27.350 --> 00:01:29.610
we're going to have to fight with
them to make sure they can't.

36
00:01:29.610 --> 00:01:33.530
We'd rather keep them far away and
let them go bother somebody else, right?

37
00:01:33.530 --> 00:01:37.590
We often talk, and I have often talked
about this idea of being this much better

38
00:01:37.590 --> 00:01:40.090
than the attacker that's
coming to take your stuff.

39
00:01:40.090 --> 00:01:44.170
If you can do that, they're going to
hopefully go down the street somewhere,

40
00:01:44.170 --> 00:01:48.440
logically or physically, and they're going
to go play in somebody else's backyard.

41
00:01:48.440 --> 00:01:52.090
And if that person isn't that much better,
then they're going to take their stuff.

42
00:01:52.090 --> 00:01:55.110
That sucks for them, but
it doesn't suck for you and so,

43
00:01:55.110 --> 00:01:59.800
what you wanna make sure is that you don't
let people get near your stuff, right?

44
00:01:59.800 --> 00:02:03.820
This is a really important thought
process, so we gotta start figuring out

45
00:02:03.820 --> 00:02:07.420
how to do that by first understanding
where our stuff is, right?

46
00:02:07.420 --> 00:02:09.610
And what is the boundary of what is ours?

47
00:02:09.610 --> 00:02:12.730
So, we have to do a survey, specifically
do what's called a Site Survey.

48
00:02:12.730 --> 00:02:16.100
And a Security Site Survey is
really what we're focused on.

49
00:02:16.100 --> 00:02:18.310
What are the outlying boundaries?

50
00:02:18.310 --> 00:02:20.120
What are the areas we have to defend?

51
00:02:20.120 --> 00:02:21.440
What do they look like?

52
00:02:21.440 --> 00:02:23.080
What stuff is where?

53
00:02:23.080 --> 00:02:25.630
This is the goal of
doing a security survey.

54
00:02:25.630 --> 00:02:29.800
We have to understand all the security
measures were already in place, and

55
00:02:29.800 --> 00:02:33.330
figure out which ones are good and
which ones may not be so good.

56
00:02:33.330 --> 00:02:36.760
And the ones that are not so good we have
to mark and then ultimately maybe change.

57
00:02:36.760 --> 00:02:40.070
So, we may have locks on doors.

58
00:02:40.070 --> 00:02:41.540
For instance as an example.

59
00:02:41.540 --> 00:02:45.090
But those locks may be easily
broken they may not be very sturdy.

60
00:02:45.090 --> 00:02:48.750
They may not be locks that are going to
actually have a dead bolt that goes into

61
00:02:48.750 --> 00:02:52.910
the frame, but rather just one of those
you push the button in lock on the handle

62
00:02:52.910 --> 00:02:55.250
and the handle's kind of old and rickety.

63
00:02:55.250 --> 00:02:58.680
You can just grab it real hard and
turn it and the door opens.

64
00:02:58.680 --> 00:03:01.550
That kind of a system is not very secure.

65
00:03:01.550 --> 00:03:06.850
But a dead bolt that goes into a frame,
that frame is cross set into the door

66
00:03:06.850 --> 00:03:11.150
frame itself is cross set into
the wall with metal anchors and

67
00:03:11.150 --> 00:03:14.990
it's a metal frame, not a wood frame,
so it's harder to actually move.

68
00:03:14.990 --> 00:03:18.290
And, that kind of a system is
gonna be a lot more secure, right?

69
00:03:18.290 --> 00:03:20.930
So, we want to look at every possibility.

70
00:03:20.930 --> 00:03:23.350
Do we have windows on the ground
floor of our building?

71
00:03:23.350 --> 00:03:25.070
Most of us probably do.

72
00:03:25.070 --> 00:03:28.610
Do we put our data center right up against
an area where there are windows that face

73
00:03:28.610 --> 00:03:29.660
that outside.

74
00:03:29.660 --> 00:03:30.730
If we do that,

75
00:03:30.730 --> 00:03:33.770
that's probably not such a good idea
because somebody may be able to break in.

76
00:03:33.770 --> 00:03:38.410
They may be able to throw a rock through
the window, or who knows what, but get in.

77
00:03:38.410 --> 00:03:41.940
If we have offices that look out,
in other words, that's one thing.

78
00:03:41.940 --> 00:03:45.800
But even then, ground floor windows
are usually not a good idea in secure

79
00:03:45.800 --> 00:03:49.680
buildings because they give people
a potential avenue to attack us.

80
00:03:49.680 --> 00:03:51.420
So, we may see windows on upper levels,
but

81
00:03:51.420 --> 00:03:53.910
it's a lot harder to get to them,
traditionally.

82
00:03:53.910 --> 00:03:54.980
Do we have doors?

83
00:03:54.980 --> 00:03:57.350
We probably do, as we said.

84
00:03:57.350 --> 00:04:01.190
Do the doors that lead to the outside
of the building in remote areas,

85
00:04:01.190 --> 00:04:02.800
do they have handles on the outside?

86
00:04:02.800 --> 00:04:05.130
Do they have a way of being
opened from the outside?

87
00:04:05.130 --> 00:04:07.760
Or are they going to be
effectively just one way doors.

88
00:04:07.760 --> 00:04:11.550
Doors that open out, and can be opened
from the inside with a crash bar or

89
00:04:11.550 --> 00:04:14.680
something but have no handles,
no way at all

90
00:04:14.680 --> 00:04:18.450
to open the door from outside except
maybe a card key swipe of some kind, or

91
00:04:18.450 --> 00:04:21.620
some sort of a pad that lets you
put in a code to open the door.

92
00:04:21.620 --> 00:04:25.940
That's gonna be a much more secure
solution because those kinds of entrances

93
00:04:25.940 --> 00:04:28.990
are gonna be a lot tougher for
somebody to break into.

94
00:04:28.990 --> 00:04:30.170
There's nothing to grab onto.

95
00:04:30.170 --> 00:04:31.300
There's nothing to pick.

96
00:04:31.300 --> 00:04:33.260
There's nothing to pull or pry open.

97
00:04:33.260 --> 00:04:37.000
The door is flush against the building,
and there's no way to get into it, right?

98
00:04:37.000 --> 00:04:38.860
So, that's gonna be something to consider.

99
00:04:38.860 --> 00:04:42.790
Do we have closed-circuit TV systems
monitoring the entryways, right?

100
00:04:42.790 --> 00:04:44.440
So cameras above the doors.

101
00:04:44.440 --> 00:04:48.980
Do we have flood lighting that lights
the door areas so that they are obviously

102
00:04:48.980 --> 00:04:52.480
going to be something people pay attention
to when they walk around the building,

103
00:04:52.480 --> 00:04:53.530
drive around at night, whatever.

104
00:04:53.530 --> 00:04:58.260
You have this island of bright light
around a stair with a door next to it.

105
00:04:58.260 --> 00:05:00.260
People are gonna pay attention to that,
and see that, and

106
00:05:00.260 --> 00:05:03.010
they're gonna know that if they're
standing there somebody's gonna see that.

107
00:05:03.010 --> 00:05:05.170
So, this again the kind of
thing we wanna think about.

108
00:05:05.170 --> 00:05:10.270
Do we trim all of the landscaping
around buildings to move it back and

109
00:05:10.270 --> 00:05:12.650
prevent areas that can overgrow, so

110
00:05:12.650 --> 00:05:15.780
places that people may be able
to hide are gonna be obvious.

111
00:05:15.780 --> 00:05:17.200
That kind of thing.

112
00:05:17.200 --> 00:05:18.780
Do we have parking garages?

113
00:05:18.780 --> 00:05:21.160
A lot of us have parking garages
attached to our buildings.

114
00:05:21.160 --> 00:05:24.400
Do we have good lighting in the garage or
do we have a dark scary

115
00:05:24.400 --> 00:05:28.990
area where people may be able to hide and
potentially pop out and attack somebody.

116
00:05:28.990 --> 00:05:32.480
It's the kind of thing we have to
think about, it's all this stuff.

117
00:05:32.480 --> 00:05:33.750
Where do we put the building?

118
00:05:33.750 --> 00:05:37.170
Is the building sited in such a way
that we have good site lines so

119
00:05:37.170 --> 00:05:39.580
that people coming up to the building
are going to be observed?

120
00:05:39.580 --> 00:05:43.340
Or is the building set up in such a way
that you can't see people until they show

121
00:05:43.340 --> 00:05:44.600
up at your front door?

122
00:05:44.600 --> 00:05:46.890
That's a bad thing,
because you don't know who's coming and

123
00:05:46.890 --> 00:05:49.630
what they're coming with until
they're standing in front of you.

124
00:05:49.630 --> 00:05:52.160
So, in secure buildings you often
see them set back from the road.

125
00:05:52.160 --> 00:05:55.420
You will see there's really nothing
around them, traditionally.

126
00:05:55.420 --> 00:05:59.430
They may even be raised higher than
the road, so you have to drive up to them.

127
00:05:59.430 --> 00:06:01.170
Again allowing us to observe you.

128
00:06:01.170 --> 00:06:02.930
But not just drive up on a straight road.

129
00:06:02.930 --> 00:06:07.330
There's usually a winding road that forces
you to slow down and go very slowly

130
00:06:07.330 --> 00:06:10.540
cuz we don't want you gathering a great
rate of speed to then be able to crash

131
00:06:10.540 --> 00:06:13.940
through a gate or whatever may be there
for you then to be able to gain entry.

132
00:06:13.940 --> 00:06:16.690
So, when you approach a secure
base like a military base

133
00:06:16.690 --> 00:06:20.460
you often see they're are crash barriers
and you have to zig zag your way in.

134
00:06:20.460 --> 00:06:21.620
And then, theres a guard,

135
00:06:21.620 --> 00:06:24.950
there's typically a gate system and
there's a bunch of different solutions in

136
00:06:24.950 --> 00:06:28.440
place that overlap each other
to prevent access easily.

137
00:06:28.440 --> 00:06:32.710
Unless you drive up very slowly and they
let you in it's gonna be almost impossible

138
00:06:32.710 --> 00:06:35.230
for you crash through that gate and
get on the base, right.

139
00:06:35.230 --> 00:06:38.280
Unless you're coming in with a huge
truck and all sorts of stuff and

140
00:06:38.280 --> 00:06:39.970
they're gonna see that coming, right?

141
00:06:39.970 --> 00:06:41.630
So, this is the kind of
thing that we think about.

142
00:06:41.630 --> 00:06:45.230
Defining threats are gonna be very
important to us in understanding

143
00:06:45.230 --> 00:06:48.440
what kind of threats we may have, and
what a threat is and therefore taking

144
00:06:48.440 --> 00:06:51.820
steps to prevent them is really what
this conversation is all about.

145
00:06:51.820 --> 00:06:53.490
What are the targets
that we want to protect,

146
00:06:53.490 --> 00:06:55.820
and what are the threats
we want to defend against?

147
00:06:55.820 --> 00:06:58.860
This is the conversation that
ultimately a security professional

148
00:06:58.860 --> 00:06:59.850
needs to be thinking about.

149
00:07:00.860 --> 00:07:02.810
We think about facility
considerations like,

150
00:07:02.810 --> 00:07:05.080
rattled off a whole bunch
of them to you just now.

151
00:07:05.080 --> 00:07:07.200
We have to think about all
the things I mentioned, but

152
00:07:07.200 --> 00:07:10.060
also the people that work in the building,
and are we screening them?

153
00:07:10.060 --> 00:07:10.600
For instance,

154
00:07:10.600 --> 00:07:14.060
the cleaning crew that's there at night
often, do we really know who they are?

155
00:07:14.060 --> 00:07:16.810
I mean, they're often there
walking around in the evenings.

156
00:07:16.810 --> 00:07:20.080
If anybody is around, there's probably
nobody in the building at that point in

157
00:07:20.080 --> 00:07:22.190
time, especially if they
come late at night.

158
00:07:22.190 --> 00:07:25.590
You drive by, often a lot of times
I'll be working late in my office.

159
00:07:25.590 --> 00:07:28.870
When I'm leaving, I'll drive by the office
buildings around us, depending on

160
00:07:28.870 --> 00:07:32.530
what office I'm in and there are banks for
instance, there are big office towers.

161
00:07:32.530 --> 00:07:35.153
And you often see the banks,
11, 12 o'clock at night,

162
00:07:35.153 --> 00:07:39.000
10 o'clock at night lights are on,
there's people walking around in there.

163
00:07:39.000 --> 00:07:41.580
I'm not talking about the bankers
themselves, hopefully

164
00:07:41.580 --> 00:07:44.490
not talking about people that are there
borrowing money without permission.

165
00:07:44.490 --> 00:07:46.284
But typically it's
the cleaning crew right,

166
00:07:46.284 --> 00:07:48.906
you'll see them in there late at
night if you happen to drive by, and

167
00:07:48.906 --> 00:07:51.629
banks leave the windows open on purpose,
leave lights on on purpose.

168
00:07:51.629 --> 00:07:54.703
They want people on the outside to be able
to see what's going on on the inside so

169
00:07:54.703 --> 00:07:57.079
if there's a robbery somebody's
going to be observed, and

170
00:07:57.079 --> 00:07:59.680
when the police show up they
could see who's inside.

171
00:07:59.680 --> 00:08:02.751
Right, so this it's the same reason the
car dealers leave lights on all over their

172
00:08:02.751 --> 00:08:03.338
lots, right?

173
00:08:03.338 --> 00:08:06.856
Because they want people to be, obviously,
aware of the fact that they're watching,

174
00:08:06.856 --> 00:08:08.150
they have security there.

175
00:08:08.150 --> 00:08:10.520
But also if it's brightly light,
it's gonna be a lot tougher for

176
00:08:10.520 --> 00:08:11.270
you to steal a car.

177
00:08:11.270 --> 00:08:13.190
It's gonna be easier for us to see you.

178
00:08:13.190 --> 00:08:15.183
So these are all things people consider,
but

179
00:08:15.183 --> 00:08:17.082
who's walking around in there cleaning?

180
00:08:17.082 --> 00:08:22.140
I mean, obviously whoever is there
Is representing a cleaning service.

181
00:08:22.140 --> 00:08:25.290
A cleaning service may be the building's
own, may be the bank's own.

182
00:08:25.290 --> 00:08:26.750
They may have hired their own people.

183
00:08:26.750 --> 00:08:30.360
But it may be a contracted service
that the building maintenance

184
00:08:30.360 --> 00:08:31.600
people have brought in.

185
00:08:31.600 --> 00:08:33.340
And the bank may not
actually know who's there.

186
00:08:33.340 --> 00:08:34.520
They may have no knowledge of them.

187
00:08:34.520 --> 00:08:37.190
All they know is they show up in
the morning, their garbage is gone.

188
00:08:37.190 --> 00:08:38.790
But are the people there really trusted?

189
00:08:38.790 --> 00:08:40.170
Have they been cleared?

190
00:08:40.170 --> 00:08:42.010
This is a big question for us.

191
00:08:42.010 --> 00:08:44.360
Not maybe so much in a bank, cuz you're
not gonna be able to walk in and

192
00:08:44.360 --> 00:08:47.460
steal money from a bank,
just because you're there cleaning.

193
00:08:47.460 --> 00:08:49.750
It's very hard to do that,
money's locked up.

194
00:08:49.750 --> 00:08:52.810
But what about in an office building,
where stuff may be left out on the desks?

195
00:08:52.810 --> 00:08:56.160
And we may not really have a policy that
says we should walk around at night and

196
00:08:56.160 --> 00:08:59.020
clear everybody's desks, and
lock everything up that's secure.
