hear something or see something and
you're obviously gonna get caught.

422
00:18:59.420 --> 00:19:03.980
A lot of these are what we call delaying
solutions, they're delaying tactics.

423
00:19:03.980 --> 00:19:08.410
Having glass in a window in general is
unfortunately having a window and glass in

424
00:19:08.410 --> 00:19:11.800
it is a bad idea, because the reality is
if somebody wants to break in, they're

425
00:19:11.800 --> 00:19:15.900
gonna figure out a way to blow that window
out of the frame and crawl through.

426
00:19:15.900 --> 00:19:19.788
So the ultimate design solution should be,
if I wanna give people the ability to look

427
00:19:19.788 --> 00:19:22.820
out, I have to also understand
people may also come in.

428
00:19:22.820 --> 00:19:24.914
So how can I delay them long enough, and

429
00:19:24.914 --> 00:19:29.361
put enough controls in place around that
entryway, that they may be deterred, and

430
00:19:29.361 --> 00:19:33.330
as a result they maybe not be able
to successfully get into the system.

431
00:19:33.330 --> 00:19:35.140
That's really what the goal
is with this stuff.

432
00:19:35.140 --> 00:19:39.157
It's not to stop you, because we know that
if you're really that dead set on getting

433
00:19:39.157 --> 00:19:42.240
in, you're gonna strap a little
bit of explosive to the window and

434
00:19:42.240 --> 00:19:45.150
you're gonna blow it out of the frame,
and here you're gonna make a big noise.

435
00:19:45.150 --> 00:19:47.810
We're gonna know you're there, but
you're probably still gonna go in and

436
00:19:47.810 --> 00:19:50.360
do what you wanna do, cuz you're willing
to blow a window out of a building.

437
00:19:50.360 --> 00:19:53.860
You're probably not gonna be stopped by a
bunch a people yelling and screaming look,

438
00:19:53.860 --> 00:19:56.640
there's somebody there,
he's coming to attack us, right?

439
00:19:56.640 --> 00:19:58.340
So the reality is you're gonna get in.

440
00:19:58.340 --> 00:20:00.770
We have to figure out ways
to prevent you from doing so

441
00:20:00.770 --> 00:20:03.910
long enough, delay you,
that somebody will hopefully find you,

442
00:20:03.910 --> 00:20:06.910
figure that out, and then obviously
we can do things we need to do.

443
00:20:06.910 --> 00:20:11.930
So we have tempered glass, I talked
about this wired glass, laminated glass.

444
00:20:11.930 --> 00:20:14.430
You know about bullet resistant glass
probably, they have this in banks, for

445
00:20:14.430 --> 00:20:17.510
instance, and data centers
called bullet proof glass, but

446
00:20:17.510 --> 00:20:20.350
it's actually called bullet resistant
glass, that's the formal name for it.

447
00:20:20.350 --> 00:20:23.600
We have glass break sensors, you break the
glass, we know you broke it, and, yeah,

448
00:20:23.600 --> 00:20:24.680
we set off an alarm.

449
00:20:24.680 --> 00:20:28.160
We have noise sensors, right, so if you're
walking around somewhere late at night,

450
00:20:28.160 --> 00:20:31.490
you're making noise, acoustic sensors
are what they're called, they may go off.

451
00:20:31.490 --> 00:20:32.690
We have infrared sensors,

452
00:20:32.690 --> 00:20:36.210
right, sensors that will detect
rise in body temperature and heat.

453
00:20:36.210 --> 00:20:37.660
You see these in all the movies.

454
00:20:37.660 --> 00:20:41.770
You also may have line break sensors, the
infrared lights that are crisscrossing and

455
00:20:41.770 --> 00:20:45.690
kind of make the red pattern when they
spray the special spray to show you in

456
00:20:45.690 --> 00:20:46.950
museums and things like that.

457
00:20:46.950 --> 00:20:50.220
When you walk through the system you break
the contact points between the light

458
00:20:50.220 --> 00:20:52.140
beams, then the alarm goes off.

459
00:20:52.140 --> 00:20:54.560
This is the same principle you have
with your garage doors at home,

460
00:20:54.560 --> 00:20:55.360
as a matter of fact.

461
00:20:55.360 --> 00:20:58.539
You have infrared sensors on the bottom
on either side of the garage door,

462
00:20:58.539 --> 00:21:00.030
the safety sensors, right?

463
00:21:00.030 --> 00:21:02.614
Because that way if a child or
something is blocking the door,

464
00:21:02.614 --> 00:21:05.548
the door stops if you break the line
of the sensor as it's coming down,

465
00:21:05.548 --> 00:21:07.440
so that way they don't get crushed.

466
00:21:07.440 --> 00:21:10.090
It's the same principle its just
we use a bunch of more of them to

467
00:21:10.090 --> 00:21:13.090
protect the whole gateway or
doorway, it's the same idea.

468
00:21:13.090 --> 00:21:14.680
You see a lot of these
things everywhere you go.

469
00:21:15.740 --> 00:21:18.480
We talked about garages, right, and how
important it is to have lighting there,

470
00:21:18.480 --> 00:21:20.218
to make sure they're safe areas.

471
00:21:20.218 --> 00:21:24.770
You don't wanna walk into, I see this
a lot, I travel a lot, and I'm in hotels,

472
00:21:24.770 --> 00:21:27.690
I'm in airports, I'm in car rental
agencies at 2:00 in the morning and

473
00:21:27.690 --> 00:21:29.830
crazy times,
trying to get where I need to go.

474
00:21:29.830 --> 00:21:33.230
And a lot of times, you walk into
these garages at the airport, and

475
00:21:33.230 --> 00:21:36.270
a lot of them have these islands of light,
as I call them, and

476
00:21:36.270 --> 00:21:38.180
then these pools of darkness, right?

477
00:21:38.180 --> 00:21:41.450
So you've got areas that are well lit,
around the stairway typically,

478
00:21:41.450 --> 00:21:44.600
maybe around the landing for
the elevator where you come out.

479
00:21:44.600 --> 00:21:48.800
But then you look out and there's just
these dark rows that go off into infinity.

480
00:21:48.800 --> 00:21:51.500
You can't see what's down there,
you don't know who's there.

481
00:21:51.500 --> 00:21:54.190
I'm not saying and suggesting for a minute
that there necessarily would be somebody

482
00:21:54.190 --> 00:21:57.170
there, but you just don't know,
and it's scary.

483
00:21:57.170 --> 00:21:59.450
I mean it's scary as an individual,
whether you're a man or

484
00:21:59.450 --> 00:22:02.940
a woman to be looking down a long,
dark row of cars wondering if

485
00:22:02.940 --> 00:22:05.360
someone may be hiding there while
you're trying to go out and

486
00:22:05.360 --> 00:22:07.650
put your luggage in the back of the car,
do what you need to do.

487
00:22:07.650 --> 00:22:09.140
So it's not a good thing.

488
00:22:09.140 --> 00:22:12.460
You go to hotels, a lot of times
they're designed incredibly poorly.

489
00:22:12.460 --> 00:22:16.100
They have dark parking lots that wrap
around the back of the hotel, and there's

490
00:22:16.100 --> 00:22:19.950
one little spotlight, right, in the
middle, and then there's nothing right?

491
00:22:19.950 --> 00:22:21.820
And so I'm always thinking
well it's a rental car so

492
00:22:21.820 --> 00:22:23.775
if they break in I don't care,
it's not my car.

493
00:22:23.775 --> 00:22:25.285
>> [LAUGH]
>> So I'll park it anywhere.

494
00:22:25.285 --> 00:22:28.580
But the reality is it's unsafe,
because you may get out of the car,

495
00:22:28.580 --> 00:22:30.650
somebody may be there
trying to do you harm.

496
00:22:30.650 --> 00:22:32.890
So we have to think about these
things when we design buildings.

497
00:22:32.890 --> 00:22:36.780
We don't want garages that are dark and
scary, we want garages that are well lit.

498
00:22:36.780 --> 00:22:41.060
We also want to think about, this one
I often talk about with my customers.

499
00:22:41.060 --> 00:22:43.080
In secure environments, secure buildings,

500
00:22:43.080 --> 00:22:46.830
you're gonna have guards typically inside
the building, monitoring the perimeter.

501
00:22:46.830 --> 00:22:49.590
They actually will also typically walk
around the perimeter at night, as well.

502
00:22:49.590 --> 00:22:53.330
But you're gonna have them inside, looking
at screens typically, looking at cameras.

503
00:22:53.330 --> 00:22:54.730
We probably have perimeter lighting.

504
00:22:54.730 --> 00:22:57.830
We most likely will have spotlights and
things that light up areas of

505
00:22:57.830 --> 00:23:01.430
the perimeter, the gate, for instance,
the doorways, things like that.

506
00:23:01.430 --> 00:23:03.800
What we wanna make sure we have
is lighting the faces out.

507
00:23:03.800 --> 00:23:07.097
Right, we want lighting that is away
from the building facing out towards

508
00:23:07.097 --> 00:23:10.392
the perimeter, so that way the guards,
when they're looking at stuff,

509
00:23:10.392 --> 00:23:13.530
when they come out of a darkened
room into the dark lobby, typically,

510
00:23:13.530 --> 00:23:14.752
out into the environment,

511
00:23:14.752 --> 00:23:18.300
they're not gonna be blinded by light
shooting in from the perimeter.

512
00:23:18.300 --> 00:23:21.880
Because if you spotlight the doorway
of the building from 100 feet away and

513
00:23:21.880 --> 00:23:23.860
somebody steps out,
they're blinded to the night.

514
00:23:23.860 --> 00:23:25.800
You blow their night vision,
they can't see anything.

515
00:23:25.800 --> 00:23:27.240
So they're not gonna see people coming,

516
00:23:27.240 --> 00:23:29.938
they're not really gonna be able
to be effective as a deterrent.

517
00:23:29.938 --> 00:23:32.920
So we wanna be thinking of light
placement, this is also very important.

518
00:23:32.920 --> 00:23:36.340
Something we have to consider and
be thoughtful of as well.

519
00:23:36.340 --> 00:23:37.150
What about fires?

520
00:23:37.150 --> 00:23:39.750
When fires happen inside of a building,
we got to worry about this as well.

521
00:23:39.750 --> 00:23:42.290
Fire suppression is very important right?

522
00:23:42.290 --> 00:23:46.470
So we know we have different kinds of fire
suppression equipment based on the kind of

523
00:23:46.470 --> 00:23:47.230
fire that we have.

524
00:23:48.370 --> 00:23:51.610
Fire is fire, in the sense that
it all burns, it's all bad.

525
00:23:51.610 --> 00:23:53.837
But what causes the fire,
or what is burning?

526
00:23:53.837 --> 00:23:57.926
Is it you lighting a piece of paper
on fire, versus chemicals burning,

527
00:23:57.926 --> 00:24:01.280
versus heavy metals that might
have caught fire, right?

528
00:24:01.280 --> 00:24:02.170
That kind of stuff.

529
00:24:02.170 --> 00:24:04.540
Each kind of fire has to
be dealt with differently.

530
00:24:04.540 --> 00:24:07.930
If it's an electrical fire, you can't
spray water on an electrical fire.

531
00:24:07.930 --> 00:24:09.870
You could, but you're not gonna
be very happy with the outcome.

532
00:24:09.870 --> 00:24:11.170
Let me put it that way.

533
00:24:11.170 --> 00:24:15.870
However, if you want a really cool
fireworks show, that's the way to go.

534
00:24:15.870 --> 00:24:19.550
So we have different classes, class A,
class B, class C, and class D.

535
00:24:19.550 --> 00:24:23.420
When it comes to different kinds of fires,
you probably should know what they are.

536
00:24:23.420 --> 00:24:25.249
Class A is ordinary combustible materials.

537
00:24:25.249 --> 00:24:27.520
That's paper, wood, things like that.

538
00:24:27.520 --> 00:24:30.260
Just stuff you mess around with
you that may catch on fire, but

539
00:24:30.260 --> 00:24:33.180
you can easily put out with a fire
extinguisher, little bit of water, or

540
00:24:33.180 --> 00:24:35.110
smother it, whatever that may be.

541
00:24:35.110 --> 00:24:37.090
Class B, flammable or combustible liquids.

542
00:24:37.090 --> 00:24:38.970
This is gasoline, oil.

543
00:24:38.970 --> 00:24:43.015
Think of kitchen fires, where the pan
catches on fire cuz you have oil in it.

544
00:24:43.015 --> 00:24:43.920
That's a little bit different.

545
00:24:43.920 --> 00:24:46.200
You never throw water on
a combustible liquid fire.

546
00:24:46.200 --> 00:24:48.210
It spreads the combustible
liquid everywhere.

547
00:24:48.210 --> 00:24:52.310
It also typically blows up in a huge
cloud and will not only spray you, but

548
00:24:52.310 --> 00:24:53.810
catch fire to everything around it.

549
00:24:53.810 --> 00:24:55.360
So that's never a good idea.

550
00:24:55.360 --> 00:24:59.350
We use chemical suppressant there,
typically foam and/or some sort of

551
00:24:59.350 --> 00:25:03.320
chemical suppressant or cutting off
the oxygen if it's a small fire,

552
00:25:03.320 --> 00:25:07.350
like on a cook top, you put another-
>> Pan or?

553
00:25:07.350 --> 00:25:08.193
>> Thank you.

554
00:25:08.193 --> 00:25:08.854
Charades!

555
00:25:08.854 --> 00:25:10.810
>> [LAUGH]
>> Sounds like, two words, first word.

556
00:25:10.810 --> 00:25:13.490
You put pan on top of the other
pan to cut the oxygen off and

557
00:25:13.490 --> 00:25:14.500
effectively smother the fire.

558
00:25:14.500 --> 00:25:16.870
But obviously,
if it's a big fire somewhere,

559
00:25:16.870 --> 00:25:19.430
we have to use things like
chemical foam to deal with that.

560
00:25:19.430 --> 00:25:23.460
Class C fire is electrical equipment, as I
said no water allowed there, dry foam or

561
00:25:23.460 --> 00:25:25.660
chemical foam of some kind, typically.

562
00:25:25.660 --> 00:25:27.610
Maybe some sort of dry extinguisher, but

563
00:25:27.610 --> 00:25:30.040
again nothing with water
in it of any kind.

564
00:25:30.040 --> 00:25:34.140
Class D combustible metals,
these are really nasty in particular.

565
00:25:34.140 --> 00:25:37.460
These can do great harm, and
they are very difficult to deal with.

566
00:25:37.460 --> 00:25:39.092
You'll need to leave that
to the professionals.

567
00:25:39.092 --> 00:25:40.980
The firefighters have to come and
take care of that kind of stuff.

568
00:25:40.980 --> 00:25:43.610
They have special equipment that they
can use to deal with those fires.

569
00:25:43.610 --> 00:25:46.156
But it's not something your are going
to be equipped to deal with typically.

570
00:25:46.156 --> 00:25:49.563
But we should know what the different
classes of fire suppression and

571
00:25:49.563 --> 00:25:50.510
fire overall are.

572
00:25:50.510 --> 00:25:52.890
So we want to just be aware of that and
think about that.

573
00:25:52.890 --> 00:25:56.206
What about safeguarding server rooms and
interconnects for electrical equipment?

574
00:25:56.206 --> 00:25:58.010
Again, electrical rooms should be locked.

575
00:25:58.010 --> 00:26:01.630
You should have camera surveillance
on them, so should server rooms.

576
00:26:01.630 --> 00:26:04.660
People should not be able to go in and
play with circuit breakers, for instance.

577
00:26:04.660 --> 00:26:05.480
It's just a bad idea.

578
00:26:05.480 --> 00:26:07.862
It's a bad idea cuz a,
they could either hurt themselves,

579
00:26:07.862 --> 00:26:10.972
it's also a bad idea because b, they can
cut off power to you in the building.

580
00:26:10.972 --> 00:26:15.200
So again, if you're in a common building,
and there is a common electrical closet or

581
00:26:15.200 --> 00:26:18.650
server closet on each floor,
you have to make sure that's secured.

582
00:26:18.650 --> 00:26:21.960
You have to work with building
management to do that.

583
00:26:21.960 --> 00:26:25.480
There may be more than one tenant that
has rights and needs access to that.

584
00:26:25.480 --> 00:26:28.130
And there may be a bunch of vendors
that are coming in to do work for

585
00:26:28.130 --> 00:26:30.770
the building and for
individual tenants within the building.

586
00:26:30.770 --> 00:26:34.090
And again, you have to understand that
you may not have exclusive access to

587
00:26:34.090 --> 00:26:35.190
these systems.

588
00:26:35.190 --> 00:26:39.430
In one our buildings down in
South Florida, where I'm based,

00:26:39.430 --> 00:26:43.820
we have one of our centers where I work my
day job, when I'm not hanging out with you

00:26:43.820 --> 00:26:48.250
guys doing this, and we have a huge
facility, it's about 13,000 square feet.

591
00:26:48.250 --> 00:26:52.916
Our electrical room is at the back corner
of this particular area of the building.

592
00:26:52.916 --> 00:26:54.551
Now, we're not the only tenant, but

593
00:26:54.551 --> 00:26:56.816
we are the largest tenant
in that particular space.

594
00:26:56.816 --> 00:26:59.820
The space directly below us,
we happen to be in a mall.

595
00:26:59.820 --> 00:27:03.590
So we're upstairs in the office space
in a mall, mall is massive, huge mall.

596
00:27:03.590 --> 00:27:06.930
Downstairs, the Department
of Transportation for

597
00:27:06.930 --> 00:27:12.005
the State of Florida came in and opened up
a huge driver's license division there.

598
00:27:12.005 --> 00:27:14.650
So they took three or
four small offices, closed them all,

599
00:27:14.650 --> 00:27:17.390
consolidated them,
put them into this one space.

600
00:27:17.390 --> 00:27:21.680
They built a big data center right
below our electrical closet above,

601
00:27:21.680 --> 00:27:23.100
in the area where we control.

602
00:27:23.100 --> 00:27:26.230
They had to negotiate with
the building and ultimately, with us,

603
00:27:26.230 --> 00:27:31.040
have the contractors they use,
come in and drill conduit connections

604
00:27:31.040 --> 00:27:34.880
through our stone slab floor, our concrete
floor, it's like four feet thick.

605
00:27:34.880 --> 00:27:38.210
In order to go down through our area,
to bring their conduit for

606
00:27:38.210 --> 00:27:41.220
their fiber runs into their
data center below us.

607
00:27:41.220 --> 00:27:43.320
And so I had to show up at 2
o'clock in the morning for

608
00:27:43.320 --> 00:27:46.340
like three days in a row to sit there
with them while they're doing this, so

609
00:27:46.340 --> 00:27:48.840
they could drill through and
make sure it was working to set it up.

610
00:27:48.840 --> 00:27:49.900
And here's the interesting part.

611
00:27:49.900 --> 00:27:51.360
They did all this, which is fine.

612
00:27:51.360 --> 00:27:52.950
They set up the conduit, all that stuff,

613
00:27:52.950 --> 00:27:55.710
it's all good, it's all right through
the floor, everything's good.

614
00:27:55.710 --> 00:27:59.760
They left an interconnect gap of probably,
oh I'm guessing, what, maybe a foot,

615
00:27:59.760 --> 00:28:02.810
approximately, between the conduit and
the floor.

616
00:28:02.810 --> 00:28:07.310
And they never came back and
actually took care of it or

617
00:28:07.310 --> 00:28:11.160
enwrapped it, or set it up so it's totally
secure, so all the fiber is actually

618
00:28:11.160 --> 00:28:14.180
running right through that pipe, and
there's a gap of about a foot where it

619
00:28:14.180 --> 00:28:17.470
meets the floor where you can actually tap
right into the fiber if you wanted to.

620
00:28:17.470 --> 00:28:21.203
So the reality is that sometimes it
was just through dumb circumstance,

621
00:28:21.203 --> 00:28:25.442
I'm sure just they didn't realize, and
they forgot, and they never came back.

622
00:28:25.442 --> 00:28:27.030
They just never did.
It's been that way for years.

623
00:28:27.030 --> 00:28:27.780
It's never been a problem.

624
00:28:27.780 --> 00:28:28.960
We don't let anybody in there.

625
00:28:28.960 --> 00:28:31.100
It's locked up all the time,
and they don't have an issue.

626
00:28:31.100 --> 00:28:33.570
And they probably don't
even realize it's there.

627
00:28:33.570 --> 00:28:36.970
But the point is it is there, and in
theory, we could obviously get into it, or

628
00:28:36.970 --> 00:28:38.520
somebody could if they wanted to.

629
00:28:38.520 --> 00:28:40.400
So this is the kind of thing
you gotta think about.

630
00:28:40.400 --> 00:28:42.630
These are the kinds of things
that can obviously happen.

631
00:28:42.630 --> 00:28:46.602
So you're thinking about not just
things like that but also utilities.

632
00:28:46.602 --> 00:28:49.133
Power, how do we bring power
into the building as I said.

633
00:28:49.133 --> 00:28:53.089
We may use one provider, but in a secure
facility, we probably have to use multiple

634
00:28:53.089 --> 00:28:56.270
providers bringing in different
circuits from different areas.

635
00:28:56.270 --> 00:28:59.010
So if one is cut, we still have
power coming into the building,

636
00:28:59.010 --> 00:29:01.280
we can still achieve the end
results that we need.

637
00:29:01.280 --> 00:29:03.160
These are all gonna be things
that are very important.

638
00:29:03.160 --> 00:29:05.210
We have to worry about cable management.

639
00:29:05.210 --> 00:29:08.880
Are we, as I said locking down our cable,
so nobody can tap into the fiber, or

640
00:29:08.880 --> 00:29:10.380
is it open and exposed?

641
00:29:10.380 --> 00:29:13.480
When we run cable,
is it in conduit up in the walls,

642
00:29:13.480 --> 00:29:16.490
in the ceilings, or is it just run,
scattered everywhere, and

643
00:29:16.490 --> 00:29:19.980
somebody could effectively go up in
the ceiling and tap into cables?

644
00:29:19.980 --> 00:29:21.320
Cuz we've all had to do that.

645
00:29:21.320 --> 00:29:25.312
Oh, I need a cable run, I'm not calling
the cable guy, 75 bucks a cable run.

646
00:29:25.312 --> 00:29:26.728
So we get up there.

647
00:29:26.728 --> 00:29:28.713
Mike, go down the far end on the ladder.

648
00:29:28.713 --> 00:29:30.188
I'm gonna throw the cable ball to you.

649
00:29:30.188 --> 00:29:33.069
And it just randomly arcs across and
ends up, yep,

650
00:29:33.069 --> 00:29:35.960
that's exactly where we wanted it,
right there.

651
00:29:35.960 --> 00:29:39.060
The only thing you worry about is
not hitting the fluorescent lights

652
00:29:39.060 --> 00:29:41.010
to make sure you don't worry
about hitting the ballast, and

653
00:29:41.010 --> 00:29:43.130
as a result, you have interference.

654
00:29:43.130 --> 00:29:45.490
Other than that,
if you look up in most ceilings,

655
00:29:45.490 --> 00:29:48.450
you're probably gonna find a patchwork,
literally, of cable connections.

656
00:29:48.450 --> 00:29:51.390
And that's the reality, it's just how
it looks, so we wanna know about that,

657
00:29:51.390 --> 00:29:54.140
we wanna have someone to safeguard
these areas, think about them as well,

658
00:29:54.140 --> 00:29:55.640
this is all very important stuff.

659
00:29:55.640 --> 00:29:58.690
What about the rack itself,
what about the rack of servers?

660
00:29:58.690 --> 00:29:59.848
Are we locking the rack?

661
00:29:59.848 --> 00:30:04.183
Most racks come with locks, and most good
IT administrators promptly ignore them,

662
00:30:04.183 --> 00:30:07.113
forget where they are,
don't worry about the keys, and

663
00:30:07.113 --> 00:30:09.590
just don't bother to use them.

664
00:30:09.590 --> 00:30:13.650
So the reality is, when I walk into
secure data centers, I see cages.

665
00:30:13.650 --> 00:30:14.254
That's great.

666
00:30:14.254 --> 00:30:15.531
I walk in, I see racks.

667
00:30:15.531 --> 00:30:16.204
That's awesome.

668
00:30:16.204 --> 00:30:19.760
I walk up to the rack,
and the rack is open.

669
00:30:19.760 --> 00:30:24.150
And I'm thinking well,
that's good, but it's not great.

670
00:30:24.150 --> 00:30:25.420
I mean, let's be honest,

671
00:30:25.420 --> 00:30:28.350
it's a pain to have to unlock a rack every
time you want to go talk to a server and

672
00:30:28.350 --> 00:30:31.950
interact with it, but
there's a lock on the front for a reason.

673
00:30:31.950 --> 00:30:35.080
Because people may still climb
over the cage and get in, and

674
00:30:35.080 --> 00:30:37.140
you may not realize they're there.

675
00:30:37.140 --> 00:30:39.162
So this is something you
have to consider as well.

676
00:30:39.162 --> 00:30:40.605
Now they have manageable rack locks,

677
00:30:40.605 --> 00:30:43.800
ones that are automated that can be opened
with a card swipe or things like that.

678
00:30:43.800 --> 00:30:47.930
It doesn't have to be a key, but the point
is that if you don't take the extra step,

679
00:30:47.930 --> 00:30:50.590
that's usually where
the attacker is willing to go.

680
00:30:50.590 --> 00:30:53.970
They're gonna go that extra mile,
they're just gonna take it to the limit.

681
00:30:53.970 --> 00:30:56.529
If you're not willing to
do that as the Eagles said,

682
00:30:56.529 --> 00:30:58.225
take it to the limit one more time.

683
00:30:58.225 --> 00:31:00.421
>> [LAUGH]
>> If you're not willing to do that,

684
00:31:00.421 --> 00:31:02.960
I promise you, at some point,
an attacker will.

685
00:31:02.960 --> 00:31:05.880
And if they're willing to do that and
you're not, they win, and you lose.

686
00:31:06.980 --> 00:31:08.560
So that's really what
you have to think about.

687
00:31:08.560 --> 00:31:11.834
Restricting their ability to get
to that information is vital.

688
00:31:11.834 --> 00:31:15.060
If you're not able to do that, not willing
to do that, that's really an issue.

689
00:31:15.060 --> 00:31:16.720
That's something you have to think about.

690
00:31:16.720 --> 00:31:19.767
We've talked about uninterrupted power
supplies, we've talked about generators,

691
00:31:19.767 --> 00:31:20.802
talked about all this stuff.

692
00:31:20.802 --> 00:31:21.580
It's all important.

693
00:31:21.580 --> 00:31:24.563
We talked about HVAC systems and
why those are important.

694
00:31:24.563 --> 00:31:27.755
Last thing I just wanna talk about,
quickly, talked about water,

695
00:31:27.755 --> 00:31:31.731
talked about fire, mixing the two,
talked about sprinklers, fire suppression,

696
00:31:31.731 --> 00:31:32.853
all that kind of stuff.

697
00:31:32.853 --> 00:31:34.756
We wanna make sure we know,
actually two things.

698
00:31:34.756 --> 00:31:37.681
One, we wanna make sure we know the
different kinds of sprinkler systems, so

699
00:31:37.681 --> 00:31:39.133
let's just quickly talk about that.

700
00:31:39.133 --> 00:31:42.845
Then I wanna say a quick word about
fire suppression, but gas-based systems,

701
00:31:42.845 --> 00:31:44.965
systems that don't use water,
because these are important,

702
00:31:44.965 --> 00:31:46.555
and we have to know about them as well.

703
00:31:46.555 --> 00:31:49.665
If we have a system that uses water,
we have four different ways in

704
00:31:49.665 --> 00:31:52.600
which a sprinkler system uses
water in theory, can be set up.

705
00:31:52.600 --> 00:31:56.390
Could be a wet system, could be a dry
system, a pre-action system, or

706
00:31:56.390 --> 00:31:57.440
a deluge systems.

707
00:31:57.440 --> 00:31:59.254
Let's just quickly talk
about the differences.

708
00:31:59.254 --> 00:32:02.440
A wet system is basically water's
in the pipes at all times.

709
00:32:02.440 --> 00:32:04.267
You go ahead and set off the alarm,

710
00:32:04.267 --> 00:32:07.930
the sprinklers basically just
immediately drop water everywhere.

711
00:32:07.930 --> 00:32:11.713
This is the classic system that we have,
where in most hotels, most buildings, you

712
00:32:11.713 --> 00:32:15.660
see the little colored vial of liquid if
you go up and look at the sprinkler head.

713
00:32:15.660 --> 00:32:17.490
Red, green, orange, whatever it is,

714
00:32:17.490 --> 00:32:21.090
that liquid color indicates the boiling
point of the liquid in the glass.

715
00:32:21.090 --> 00:32:24.270
So, they will boil, the liquid will,
at different temperatures.

716
00:32:24.270 --> 00:32:27.790
Based on that, there's a certain delay
before the sprinkler head actually is

717
00:32:27.790 --> 00:32:31.690
active, because there's a little piston or
a valve that sits behind that little vial.

718
00:32:31.690 --> 00:32:35.190
When that vial breaks, it drops,
the head opens, in other words, and

719
00:32:35.190 --> 00:32:39.070
water is there sitting right behind that,
and as a result, water drops out.

720
00:32:39.070 --> 00:32:40.650
This is what's called a wet system.

721
00:32:40.650 --> 00:32:41.890
So, you know you often see in the movies.

722
00:32:41.890 --> 00:32:43.820
Right?
Somebody stands up there with a lighter,

723
00:32:43.820 --> 00:32:45.990
right, you know,
looks like they're at a concert.

724
00:32:45.990 --> 00:32:48.410
That's for those of you that are old
enough to remember what that means.

725
00:32:48.410 --> 00:32:52.170
So, they're there, they're doing this, and
then all of a sudden, they effectively

726
00:32:52.170 --> 00:32:55.400
boil the liquid, the thing bursts and
then all of sudden the sprinklers come on.

727
00:32:55.400 --> 00:32:57.400
But you'll notice,
they come on everywhere, right?

728
00:32:57.400 --> 00:32:58.670
Not just in one place.

729
00:32:58.670 --> 00:33:01.480
That's a wet system,
water in the pipe everywhere at once.

730
00:33:01.480 --> 00:33:04.990
A dry system is essentially the same but
there's no water in the pipe.

731
00:33:04.990 --> 00:33:07.890
There's air that is just
effectively keeping the pipe open.

732
00:33:07.890 --> 00:33:10.280
Water is contained in
a holding tank somewhere, and

733
00:33:10.280 --> 00:33:13.050
there's a valve further back in
the system, probably a series of them,

734
00:33:13.050 --> 00:33:16.530
that has to be released before the water
actually is gonna hit that system.

735
00:33:16.530 --> 00:33:19.460
So, there's a delay between the time
the sprinklers are open and

736
00:33:19.460 --> 00:33:21.370
the time actually water shows up.

737
00:33:21.370 --> 00:33:22.290
We're not talking about minutes.

738
00:33:22.290 --> 00:33:24.740
This is just a few seconds,
but it's not immediate.

739
00:33:24.740 --> 00:33:26.340
There is a small delay.

740
00:33:26.340 --> 00:33:27.450
Preaction systems,

741
00:33:27.450 --> 00:33:31.370
water is held back until the detectors
are going to effectively activate.

742
00:33:31.370 --> 00:33:34.360
The nice thing is that this
is an area controlled system.

743
00:33:34.360 --> 00:33:38.840
So, unlike a wet system which drenches
everything, a preaction system

744
00:33:38.840 --> 00:33:42.200
is going to effectively be targeted
based on where the alarm goes off.

745
00:33:42.200 --> 00:33:45.110
So, if it just goes off
in this area right here,

746
00:33:45.110 --> 00:33:48.240
in front of us, then it's just going
to be this one sprinkler, right?

747
00:33:48.240 --> 00:33:51.410
That goes off, nothing else is going
to go off and none of the other systems

748
00:33:51.410 --> 00:33:54.670
are going to be activated,
which is good because you obviously then

749
00:33:54.670 --> 00:33:58.050
minimize damage in other areas of the
building, because water showing up, and

750
00:33:58.050 --> 00:34:00.910
you know falling on desks, and
all sorts of stuff like that.

751
00:34:00.910 --> 00:34:05.890
And then the system,
all sprinklers in the system are open, and

752
00:34:05.890 --> 00:34:07.030
all the heads are wide open.

753
00:34:07.030 --> 00:34:10.050
This is almost like a rainfall in effect,
or a waterfall.

754
00:34:10.050 --> 00:34:12.820
And when water hits the system,
it comes pouring out everywhere.

755
00:34:12.820 --> 00:34:15.530
Looks like literally a series of
waterfalls that are gonna go in and

756
00:34:15.530 --> 00:34:16.410
drench the building.

757
00:34:16.410 --> 00:34:18.240
These are fast-action systems in a sense,

758
00:34:18.240 --> 00:34:22.020
they flood large areas very quickly
to put out very, very big fires.

759
00:34:22.020 --> 00:34:24.460
That's simply what these kind
of systems are used for.

760
00:34:24.460 --> 00:34:25.220
And a lot times,

761
00:34:25.220 --> 00:34:28.890
especially in data centers, we can't
use water because we know water and

762
00:34:28.890 --> 00:34:33.230
electricity do not mix, so we're gonna use
gas based suppression systems instead.

763
00:34:33.230 --> 00:34:38.110
So, when you walk into a data center, we
may have seen the caution stickers right?

764
00:34:38.110 --> 00:34:39.570
The flammable substance,

765
00:34:39.570 --> 00:34:43.440
dangerous gas whatever The warning
stickers that firefighters often to use

766
00:34:43.440 --> 00:34:46.070
to figure out what's in there
before they go in and fight a fire.

767
00:34:46.070 --> 00:34:48.820
We see them on the front
doors of these datacenters.

768
00:34:48.820 --> 00:34:52.250
They'll simply say caution gas in use,
or gas suppression in use.

769
00:34:52.250 --> 00:34:53.850
They typically will name the kind of gas.

770
00:34:53.850 --> 00:34:58.260
So may say FM-200,
it may say Aero-K, or argon, or

771
00:34:58.260 --> 00:35:00.970
CO2, whatever it is,
there's all these different gasses.

772
00:35:00.970 --> 00:35:03.440
What it probably doesn't say anymore,
is halon.

773
00:35:03.440 --> 00:35:06.120
At least it most likely
will not say that anymore.

774
00:35:06.120 --> 00:35:09.800
The only time you would've seen
a halon system, at least these days,

775
00:35:09.800 --> 00:35:11.540
would be if it hasn't
already been used and

776
00:35:11.540 --> 00:35:15.000
it's sitting there as a relic waiting
to be decommissioned and turned over.

777
00:35:15.000 --> 00:35:18.580
I've seen these less and less over
the last number of years with customers.

778
00:35:18.580 --> 00:35:22.720
I have two that actually still use, that
have halon systems that have not finally

779
00:35:22.720 --> 00:35:25.750
hit the benchmark where they have to
retire them but it's coming up very soon.

780
00:35:25.750 --> 00:35:27.650
Halon used to be the gas of choice.

781
00:35:27.650 --> 00:35:31.310
But it is no longer used
because it is a Greenhouse gas.

782
00:35:31.310 --> 00:35:33.250
And it causes problems with the ozone.

783
00:35:33.250 --> 00:35:36.530
And so when we would fire off these
systems, all the Halon would eventually

784
00:35:36.530 --> 00:35:38.540
get out of the building so
you have to vent the building,

785
00:35:38.540 --> 00:35:40.740
because Halon sucks all
the air out of the building.

786
00:35:40.740 --> 00:35:44.220
So effectively it sucks all the air away
from the fire, which is very good for

787
00:35:44.220 --> 00:35:45.790
fire suppression, not very good for you.

788
00:35:45.790 --> 00:35:48.880
If you happen to be sitting in the room
when this goes off, you will die.

789
00:35:48.880 --> 00:35:52.410
So, we often have breathing apparatuses
that are scattered around the data

790
00:35:52.410 --> 00:35:53.210
center for this.

791
00:35:53.210 --> 00:35:56.520
There's warning lights that go off, and
you usually have a small delay lag.

792
00:35:56.520 --> 00:35:59.740
So, you can get out of the area if
you need to before the gas goes off.

793
00:35:59.740 --> 00:36:03.730
But the idea is that Halon is no
longer allowed because of a treaty.

794
00:36:03.730 --> 00:36:04.720
We actually signed a treaty.

795
00:36:04.720 --> 00:36:06.310
The U.S did, many other countries did,

796
00:36:06.310 --> 00:36:10.770
called the Montreal protocol back
in 1987 that bans the use of Halon.

797
00:36:10.770 --> 00:36:13.320
And as a result of that its
been effectively banned for

798
00:36:13.320 --> 00:36:17.030
use in these systems for
about 30 years now.

799
00:36:17.030 --> 00:36:21.050
So, most of these systems are reaching the
end of their useful life where they can

800
00:36:21.050 --> 00:36:23.820
no longer be refilled with and so

801
00:36:23.820 --> 00:36:27.861
when they go off, they then are gonna
be switched over to something like.

802
00:36:27.861 --> 00:36:33.290
So kind of interesting little geek
gas information there, if you will.

803
00:36:33.290 --> 00:36:36.025
So, we're basically gonna wrap up
our conversation in this area.

804
00:36:36.025 --> 00:36:39.025
Finish up our discussion
about suppression systems.

805
00:36:39.025 --> 00:36:41.945
Throw it back over to Mr.
Mike here, and he's gonna take us out.

806
00:36:41.945 --> 00:36:42.625
>> Fantastic.

807
00:36:42.625 --> 00:36:43.825
A lot of great information again.

808
00:36:43.825 --> 00:36:44.675
Physical security?

809
00:36:44.675 --> 00:36:47.625
One of those areas that
sometimes get overlooked, or

810
00:36:47.625 --> 00:36:49.215
some of the finer details, right?

811
00:36:49.215 --> 00:36:51.505
We've really gotta pay attention to.

812
00:36:51.505 --> 00:36:52.085
Great stuff.

813
00:36:52.085 --> 00:36:52.755
Great insight, Adam.

814
00:36:52.755 --> 00:36:53.855
We appreciate that.

815
00:36:53.855 --> 00:36:57.345
Remember, if you guys wanna attend one of
Adam's classes live, shoot us an email.

816
00:36:57.345 --> 00:36:59.210
SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

817
00:36:59.210 --> 00:37:01.130
That's it for now.

818
00:37:01.130 --> 00:37:02.960
Signing off, I'm Mike Rodrick.

819
00:37:02.960 --> 00:37:04.290
>> I'm Montreal Protocol.

820
00:37:04.290 --> 00:37:05.450
>> We'll see you next time.

821
00:37:05.450 --> 00:37:06.380
Take care.

822

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.076 --> 00:00:15.251
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.251 --> 00:00:17.150
I'm your host Mike Roderick.

4
00:00:17.150 --> 00:00:18.340
Today, we're doing our CISSP, and

5
00:00:18.340 --> 00:00:23.210
specifically, we're going to be
going into secure network design.

6
00:00:23.210 --> 00:00:26.150
And in order to have a good
secure network design,

7
00:00:26.150 --> 00:00:28.680
we've really got to have
a good foundational knowledge.

8
00:00:28.680 --> 00:00:30.160
Right?
We've got to make sure we understand that

9
00:00:30.160 --> 00:00:34.120
foundational knowledge, as we move
on into those more advanced topics.

10
00:00:34.120 --> 00:00:37.140
And here to help us with all
of that is Mr. Adam Gordon.

11
00:00:37.140 --> 00:00:38.400
How are you doing Adam?

12

>> I'm good. I'm good.
I'm feeling very OSIish today.

13
00:00:40.480 --> 00:00:41.620
>> Oh Boy!
>> As a matter of fact.

14
00:00:41.620 --> 00:00:44.168
>> I know where we're going [LAUGH]
>> Yes, yes you do.

15
00:00:44.168 --> 00:00:46.880
That good old-fashioned OSI model.

16
00:00:46.880 --> 00:00:49.620
So when we talk about network
architecture, we talk about secure design,

17
00:00:49.620 --> 00:00:52.170
as Mike pointed out,
we have to build a good foundation.

18
00:00:52.170 --> 00:00:54.910
And we have to build a good foundation
of knowledge, but we also have to build

19
00:00:54.910 --> 00:00:59.090
a good foundation for actually everything
that will go on top of that knowledge.

20
00:00:59.090 --> 00:00:59.770
That's all the data.

21
00:00:59.770 --> 00:01:02.040
That's all the information that
we're gonna send and receive,

22
00:01:02.040 --> 00:01:05.100
and we do that by understanding,
at least in our world anyway,

23
00:01:05.100 --> 00:01:08.270
understand the OSI model,
the Open System Interconnect model.

24
00:01:08.270 --> 00:01:11.165
Good old fashioned seven layer,
top to bottom,

25
00:01:11.165 --> 00:01:14.930
bi-directional discussion of how
information is going to be managed,

26
00:01:14.930 --> 00:01:18.240
both physically and logically,
through one system to another.

27
00:01:18.240 --> 00:01:20.560
So what I'm gonna do is walk us through
that over the next couple minutes.

28
00:01:20.560 --> 00:01:21.950
Explain each layer to you.

29
00:01:21.950 --> 00:01:25.530
Give you effectively a high level
summary of what each layer does.

30
00:01:25.530 --> 00:01:30.210
We don't want you to go down the rabbit
hole here with the OSI model.

31
00:01:30.210 --> 00:01:32.940
Remember mile wide,
inch deep is the level we're looking for.

32
00:01:32.940 --> 00:01:34.260
We've talked about this.

33
00:01:34.260 --> 00:01:37.970
Trying to set a level for you in your
mind, with regards to data information

34
00:01:37.970 --> 00:01:40.930
management, that helps you to
focus on the right aspects,

35
00:01:40.930 --> 00:01:43.670
the right level of detail
without getting too bogged down.

36
00:01:43.670 --> 00:01:48.370
We don't want you to become the expert
knowledge master of the OSI world, but

37
00:01:48.370 --> 00:01:51.380
rather simply a practitioner of OSI.

38
00:01:51.380 --> 00:01:52.660
Go forth and practition.

39
00:01:52.660 --> 00:01:54.270
Go forth in OSI, as they say.

40
00:01:54.270 --> 00:01:55.690
So we're going to talk about the model.

41
00:01:55.690 --> 00:01:57.570
Give you a quick idea of
what happens at each layer.

42
00:01:57.570 --> 00:01:59.800
Explain the functionality,
in terms of interaction.

43
00:01:59.800 --> 00:02:02.630
Also put in some additional

00:20:53.410 --> 00:20:57.858

00:20:57.858 --> 00:21:02.309

00:21:02.309 --> 00:21:04.064

00:21:47.865 --> 00:21:52.350

00:21:54.870 --> 00:21:57.170

60

61

And we're gonna talk about the fact

00:03:07.331 --> 00:03:11.649
you can see on the screen in front of you,

00:03:11.649 --> 00:03:16.246

64
00:03:16.246 --> 00:03:21.037
We're gonna talk about five network

65
00:03:21.037 --> 00:03:22.310
A, B, C, D, and E.

66
00:03:22.310 --> 00:03:26.640
And we're gonna talk about what occurs
based on the class designation,

67
00:03:26.640 --> 00:03:30.380
in the middle column there,

68
00:03:30.380 --> 00:03:33.330
So if we imagine, and maybe,
Mike, down below the chart,

00:03:33.330 --> 00:03:35.920
maybe we can just type an IP

00:03:35.920 --> 00:03:40.710

hit a period, and then maybe just

72
00:03:45.410 --> 00:03:48.600
Like an underscore maybe, so
we can see or differentiate that.

73
00:03:48.600 --> 00:03:50.410
Yeah, period, underscore,
period, underscore, and

74
00:03:50.410 --> 00:03:51.560
maybe we can make it a little bigger.

75
00:03:51.560 --> 00:03:54.020
Mike will just blow that up for
us for a second, so we can see that.

76
00:03:54.020 --> 00:03:56.270
And you'll obviously see it
at the right level there, so

77
00:03:56.270 --> 00:03:57.730
you can see what it looks like.

78
00:03:57.730 --> 00:04:01.770
And so if we're talking about the first
octet range, we're talking about what

79
00:04:01.770 --> 00:04:05.480
goes into that first box, or that
numerical area there with the number 1.

80
00:04:05.480 --> 00:04:11.030
And so for Class A, we're talking about it
being able to be anything from 1 to 126.

81
00:04:11.030 --> 00:04:13.140
We have some rules
related to IP addresses.

82
00:04:13.140 --> 00:04:15.920
The first rule is that we
never start on a zero.

83
00:04:16.960 --> 00:04:20.525
And we never start on a zero because
a zero implies no valid IP address,

84
00:04:20.525 --> 00:04:23.194
in other words,
we're not able to send or receive.

85
00:04:23.194 --> 00:04:29.380
We don't also start on a 255 traditionally
because that implies broadcast.

86
00:04:29.380 --> 00:04:33.181
Meaning we're sending to everybody,
not having a unidirectional communication

87
00:04:33.181 --> 00:04:37.036
between two known endpoints, but rather
a multi-partner communication, we're

88
00:04:37.036 --> 00:04:40.634
broadcasting to anybody and everybody
that maybe around and wants to hear us.

89
00:04:40.634 --> 00:04:43.761
So when we talk about the range for
the first octet with class A,

90
00:04:43.761 --> 00:04:47.910
we're talking about it being something
in that first area there from 1 to 126.

91
00:04:47.910 --> 00:04:50.900
That's what we'll go into the first octet.

92
00:04:50.900 --> 00:04:52.789
Now the second octet, class B.

93
00:04:52.789 --> 00:04:56.415
Excuse me, not the second octet, but
the value rather, excuse me, for

94
00:04:56.415 --> 00:04:59.880
the first octet with Class B can
also anything from 128 to 191.

95
00:04:59.880 --> 00:05:03.280
So if it's a Class B address, it

96
00:05:05.040 --> 00:05:10.080
could be 128, 129, 130, 145,
170, 190, all the way up to 191.

97
00:05:10.080 --> 00:05:14.190
Class C will be anything from 192 to 223.

98
00:05:14.190 --> 00:05:17.809
Class D is gonna be from 224 to 239,
as you can see.

99
00:05:17.809 --> 00:05:19.637
Class D is often used for multicasting,

100
00:05:19.637 --> 00:05:23.020
so we typically refer to that as
the multicasting address range.

101
00:05:23.020 --> 00:05:26.260
And then Class E is reserved,
we call that a reserved range.

102
00:05:26.260 --> 00:05:29.210
You can see the range
there is from 240 to 255.

103
00:05:29.210 --> 00:05:32.290
So one other thing we wanna talk
about quickly here before we actually

104
00:05:32.290 --> 00:05:35.570
put some of the additional rules about
IP addresses up on the screen for

105
00:05:35.570 --> 00:05:37.170
you, talk about the first one.

106
00:05:37.170 --> 00:05:39.670
That the first octet is
never gonna start on a 0,

107
00:05:39.670 --> 00:05:44.010
never start on a 255 because of
lack of IP and broadcasting.

108
00:05:44.010 --> 00:05:47.050
But I wanna take notice of what's at the
bottom of that chart down there quickly.

109
00:05:47.050 --> 00:05:50.340
The asterisk that says 127
equals Loopback Adapter.

110
00:05:50.340 --> 00:05:54.910
We just wanna make sure we know that
the Loopback Adapter is gonna be the local

111
00:05:54.910 --> 00:05:58.750
diagnostics function on the network card
to ensure the network card is plugged in,

112
00:05:58.750 --> 00:06:00.760
powered on and working correctly.

113
00:06:00.760 --> 00:06:02.380
We often overlook it when we troubleshoot.

114
00:06:02.380 --> 00:06:04.150
We tend to ping an interface.

115
00:06:04.150 --> 00:06:06.120
We don't tend to ping
the Loopback Adapter.

116
00:06:06.120 --> 00:06:07.580
But the reality is you could.

117
00:06:07.580 --> 00:06:11.861
The address for
the Loopback Adapter is 127.0.0.1.

118
00:06:11.861 --> 00:06:16.130
But we actually reserve the entire
127 address class block, and

119
00:06:16.130 --> 00:06:20.580
we don't use it for anything other
than this 127.0.0.1 address.

120
00:06:20.580 --> 00:06:23.050
We just kind of assume it's off limits,
if you will.

121
00:06:23.050 --> 00:06:25.620
Cuz we don't really use it as
a networkable, or routable,

122
00:06:25.620 --> 00:06:27.060
IP address range.

123
00:06:27.060 --> 00:06:29.480
So it does actually exist in Class A.

124
00:06:29.480 --> 00:06:32.410
We didn't put it up in the first
octet range under Class A,

125
00:06:32.410 --> 00:06:34.120
because we didn't want to confuse you.

126
00:06:34.120 --> 00:06:38.409
But reality is, 127 is considered part of
the Class A block, but it's a special,

127
00:06:38.409 --> 00:06:41.982
what we call a set aside address,
special address that's used just for

128

00:28:27.620 --> 00:28:30.960

goes on about its way.

581
00:28:33.500 --> 00:28:37.790
It doesn't do any deep packet inspection,
doesn't bother to look at IP addresses,

582
00:28:37.790 --> 00:28:39.400
just reads the ship to label.

583
00:28:39.400 --> 00:28:41.590
So, as a result it ships
much more quickly.

00:28:41.590 --> 00:28:45.620
In other words, we send data out
past the router on the first hop

00:28:45.620 --> 00:28:47.320

00:28:47.320 --> 00:28:50.600

00:28:50.600 --> 00:28:54.030

00:28:56.640 --> 00:28:59.190

we stop, we deliver it,

590
00:28:59.190 --> 00:29:01.650
we hand the packet over,
it's delivered locally.

591
00:29:01.650 --> 00:29:03.870

00:29:03.870 --> 00:29:07.920
us dramatically because it allows us to
use effectively ship to labels that allow

00:29:07.920 --> 00:29:11.930

the LAN overall being carved out for

633
00:29:59.200 --> 00:30:03.010
extra security, and extra focus,
extra capabilities about this, right?

634
00:30:03.010 --> 00:30:06.620
We just showed you one way to create
a DMZ with a single firewall, but

635
00:30:06.620 --> 00:30:09.890
we would call that a dual honed or
multi honed device.

636
00:30:09.890 --> 00:30:12.520
Multiple network connections
on there that we can use, and

637
00:30:12.520 --> 00:30:16.720
we can use that thought process to be able
to create secure internal areas as well.

638
00:30:16.720 --> 00:30:18.490
So wanna be thinking about
network partitioning and

639
00:30:18.490 --> 00:30:22.380
security perimeters both external to
the network, on the boundary, but

640
00:30:22.380 --> 00:30:25.530
also potentially internally as we step
back, cuz we may have a need to be able to

641
00:30:25.530 --> 00:30:29.890
secure internal areas and make sure
that we are doing so in a proper way.

642
00:30:29.890 --> 00:30:31.660
So we just wanna make sure that
you're aware of those things, and

643
00:30:31.660 --> 00:30:32.840
the last thing we wanna
throw out there for

644
00:30:32.840 --> 00:30:34.590
you is something called a bastion host.

645
00:30:34.590 --> 00:30:36.340
It's fun to say also by the way.

646
00:30:36.340 --> 00:30:37.440
Bastion host.

647
00:30:37.440 --> 00:30:39.478
Sounds impressive and dark and doomy.

648
00:30:39.478 --> 00:30:40.640
Have a bastion host.

649
00:30:40.640 --> 00:30:41.540
Stripe.
>> [LAUGH]

650
00:30:41.540 --> 00:30:43.200
>> Luke I'm your father all right.

651
00:30:43.200 --> 00:30:45.380
By the way hey isn't that like
a big thing right Star Wars?

652
00:30:45.380 --> 00:30:45.890
>> Yeah coming up.

653
00:30:45.890 --> 00:30:48.040
>> Luke I'm your father that's coming up,
so Star Wars.

654
00:30:49.090 --> 00:30:51.680
So the bastion host is gonna be a machine

655
00:30:51.680 --> 00:30:54.250
that is going to be effectively
what we call fortified.

656
00:30:54.250 --> 00:30:55.340
It's a hardened machine.

657
00:30:55.340 --> 00:30:58.130
When we use the term bastion
host what we mean is a machine

658
00:30:58.130 --> 00:31:02.400
that is all services that are no longer
necessary, no longer needed, stripped out.

659
00:31:02.400 --> 00:31:04.850
All the applications we don't
need are stripped away.

660
00:31:04.850 --> 00:31:09.340
We should just be running the minimal
things necessary to make that system work,

661
00:31:09.340 --> 00:31:11.420
and if we do that we're
hardening the host, and

662
00:31:11.420 --> 00:31:13.620
we formally refer to
that as a bastion host.

663
00:31:13.620 --> 00:31:16.570
Just wanna make sure you're aware
of that terminology as well.

664
00:31:16.570 --> 00:31:17.320
>> Very good Adam.

665
00:31:17.320 --> 00:31:18.600
A lot of great information there.

666
00:31:18.600 --> 00:31:21.960
We took a look at wireless networks
some of the encryption that we would use

667
00:31:21.960 --> 00:31:22.950
on wireless.

668
00:31:22.950 --> 00:31:26.990
Some of the different IEEE
standards we gotta be familiar with

669
00:31:26.990 --> 00:31:31.580
as well as starting getting into laying
out your network and creating DMZ, or

670
00:31:31.580 --> 00:31:34.700
screen sub-nets or perimeters both

671
00:31:34.700 --> 00:31:39.070
with outside of our network to keep the as
you say the bad actors from getting in.

672
00:31:39.070 --> 00:31:42.450
But then possible internally as well for
more restricted portions of our network

673
00:31:42.450 --> 00:31:45.420
that not everybody in
the company needs access too.

674
00:31:45.420 --> 00:31:47.920
So great information Adam thank you for
all of that.

675
00:31:47.920 --> 00:31:51.600
Remember if you guys want to sit in one
of Adam's classes live shoot us an email

676
00:31:51.600 --> 00:31:54.080
at SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

677
00:31:54.080 --> 00:31:57.350
Let me do that one more
time SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

678
00:31:57.350 --> 00:32:01.410
>> Or you could see me here because I'm
standing in front of you right now.

679
00:32:01.410 --> 00:32:02.160
Here I am right now.

680
00:32:02.160 --> 00:32:02.970
>> There you go.

681
00:32:02.970 --> 00:32:04.720
All right ladies and gentlemen
that's going to do it for this one.

682
00:32:04.720 --> 00:32:06.760
Singing off I'm Mike Roderick.

683
00:32:06.760 --> 00:32:08.520
>> I am IEEE.

684
00:32:08.520 --> 00:32:09.510
Just before we sign off quick.

685
00:32:09.510 --> 00:32:10.870
Do you guys really know what IEEE is?

686
00:32:10.870 --> 00:32:11.750
Do you know what IEEE is?

687
00:32:11.750 --> 00:32:12.640
We often talk about it.

688
00:32:12.640 --> 00:32:13.440
>> Let's see.

689
00:32:13.440 --> 00:32:16.090
Institute of Electronics and
Electrical Engineers.

690
00:32:16.090 --> 00:32:17.690
>> You've got it backwards,
but it's right.

691
00:32:17.690 --> 00:32:20.280
Institute of Electrical and Electronics
Engineers is actually the formal title,

692
00:32:20.280 --> 00:32:22.850
but either way Mike was right,
so bonus points for him.

693
00:32:22.850 --> 00:32:27.200
But when we talk about IEEE we want you to
know that it is an actual organization.

694
00:32:27.200 --> 00:32:28.120
You should go out and check it out.

695
00:32:28.120 --> 00:32:29.700
That's where all the standards come from.

696
00:32:29.700 --> 00:32:30.380
Having said that.

697
00:32:30.380 --> 00:32:32.030
>> It makes for great bed time reading.

698
00:32:32.030 --> 00:32:33.340
>> It does.
Very, very good stuff.

699
00:32:33.340 --> 00:32:35.450
It's better than hitting yourself
in the head with a phone book.

700
00:32:35.450 --> 00:32:36.170
>> There you go.

701
00:32:36.170 --> 00:32:37.730
>> I'm Adam Gordon, and

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike discuss securing network devices. They talk about some of the risks associated with modems, switches, routers. They compare statefull and stateless firewalls. They also talk about transmission media and technologies like proxy, NAT and PAT.
episodes.title: Securing Network Devices
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.941 --> 00:00:16.230
>> Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.230 --> 00:00:17.500
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:17.500 --> 00:00:20.090
Today we're doing our cissp content and

5
00:00:20.090 --> 00:00:23.790
specifically we're going to be going
into securing our network devices.

6
00:00:23.790 --> 00:00:28.910
These are things like routers, switches,
wireless access points to name a couple.

7
00:00:28.910 --> 00:00:32.090
As well as the media that we
use to connect these devices.

8
00:00:32.090 --> 00:00:34.690
And to help us with all that,
we get a mister Adam Gordon.

9
00:00:34.690 --> 00:00:35.920
How's it going Adam?

10
00:00:35.920 --> 00:00:36.750
>> Good.
You know

11
00:00:36.750 --> 00:00:38.950
it's great when we can talk
about this stuff obviously.

12
00:00:38.950 --> 00:00:42.120
Right and we have a lot of fun talking
about it with you but obviously when

13
00:00:42.120 --> 00:00:45.080
we focus in on one specific area we
want to spend a little bit of time.

14
00:00:45.080 --> 00:00:47.970
And so what we're going to do here
in particular is talk about some of

15
00:00:47.970 --> 00:00:48.930
the hardware.

16
00:00:48.930 --> 00:00:50.780
Some of the things that we often use and
we may take for

17
00:00:50.780 --> 00:00:52.640
granted in order to
connect things together.

18
00:00:52.640 --> 00:00:53.460
Some old stuff.

19
00:00:53.460 --> 00:00:54.590
Things like modems.

20
00:00:54.590 --> 00:00:55.300
Some new stuff.

21
00:00:55.300 --> 00:00:57.490
You heard Mike talk about routers and
switches.

22
00:00:57.490 --> 00:01:01.250
We'll mix and blend things together, but
what we want to do ultimately is talk

23
00:01:01.250 --> 00:01:05.200
about how we can see these devices,
not so much from the usage perspective.

24
00:01:05.200 --> 00:01:06.620
We're not gonna tell
you what a modem does,

25
00:01:06.620 --> 00:01:08.900
I'm not gonna spend time
explaining what devices do.

26
00:01:08.900 --> 00:01:13.780
I'm gonna remind you of what they do but
most importantly we're gonna focus on how

27
00:01:13.780 --> 00:01:16.900
what they do can be used to
potentially cause security problems.

28
00:01:16.900 --> 00:01:20.930
So as a result of that, how do we defend
against those prompts really what the goal

29
00:01:20.930 --> 00:01:24.240
of securing network components and
devices is going to be.

30
00:01:24.240 --> 00:01:24.890
So lets jump in.

31
00:01:24.890 --> 00:01:26.710
Lets start with something
known as a modem.

32
00:01:26.710 --> 00:01:31.310
An older school technology, modulation
demodulation is what modem stands for,

33
00:01:31.310 --> 00:01:34.290
going from analog to digital,
digital back to analog.

34
00:01:34.290 --> 00:01:37.000
The idea very popular many,
many moons ago.

35
00:01:37.000 --> 00:01:39.780
If you remember a movie called WarGames,
Matthew Broderick and

36
00:01:39.780 --> 00:01:42.580
Ally Sheedy were both I think like 12
years old when this movie came out.

37
00:01:42.580 --> 00:01:47.225
One of the first things he did,
cinematographic masterpiece, a classic.

38
00:01:47.225 --> 00:01:47.775
Pretty cool movie.

39
00:01:47.775 --> 00:01:51.805
One of the interesting things about it
was that we saw Matthew Broderick doing

40
00:01:51.805 --> 00:01:54.635
the whole hacking thing,
which is one of the premises of the movie.

41
00:01:54.635 --> 00:01:58.625
He was using a Haze Bar 1,200 modem,
so you saw this massive modem,

42
00:01:58.625 --> 00:02:00.335
it's probably the size of my laptop.

43
00:02:00.335 --> 00:02:04.905
Big suction cups on it with big
analog rotary dial phone on it, and

44
00:02:04.905 --> 00:02:07.015
he was actually using that and
hacking in and

45
00:02:07.015 --> 00:02:09.660
ultimately finds out how
to get in the computers.

46
00:02:09.660 --> 00:02:10.770
And he uses a modem to do this.

47
00:02:10.770 --> 00:02:12.320
This is kind of the premise of the movie.

48
00:02:12.320 --> 00:02:14.040
If you haven't seen this you
should go out and rent it.

49
00:02:14.040 --> 00:02:15.165
It's actually a pretty cool movie.

50
00:02:15.165 --> 00:02:15.800
>> Absolutely.

51
00:02:15.800 --> 00:02:18.750
>> So the idea behind a modem is
effectively a translation device.

52
00:02:19.750 --> 00:02:22.660
Modems allow us to hook up a phone line,
an analogue phone line

53
00:02:22.660 --> 00:02:26.120
in the old school way of thinking about
things, and communicate across it.

54
00:02:26.120 --> 00:02:27.220
Modems are still around.

55
00:02:27.220 --> 00:02:29.220
It's not as if they've totally gone away.

56
00:02:29.220 --> 00:02:30.580
We don't see them very often.

57
00:02:30.580 --> 00:02:32.220
We don't use them very often.

58
00:02:32.220 --> 00:02:33.400
Well we may not realize they're there.

59
00:02:33.400 --> 00:02:37.350
We've talked a little bit about creating
a security perimeter, creating a boundary

60
00:02:37.350 --> 00:02:41.260
within the network, outside of the
network, in the network, things like that.

61
00:02:41.260 --> 00:02:42.960
Thought about DMZ's for instance.

62
00:02:42.960 --> 00:02:45.870
We've also talked about doing a survey
to understand what is there and

63
00:02:45.870 --> 00:02:47.970
then how to protect the things you find.

64
00:02:47.970 --> 00:02:50.410
One of the things we often find when
we come in and do audit work and

65
00:02:50.410 --> 00:02:53.970
surveys it that you may still have
modems that are sitting in systems, but

66
00:02:53.970 --> 00:02:55.729
you're just not familiar
with the fact they're there.

67
00:02:56.760 --> 00:03:00.750
Pbx systems traditionally will have
modems in them for maintenance purposes.

68
00:03:00.750 --> 00:03:05.840
So a vendor may have installed the pbx and
if you are still using an older analog pbx

69
00:03:05.840 --> 00:03:08.500
not a digital one,
you haven't gone to a gateway.

70
00:03:08.500 --> 00:03:10.300
An h3 23 voice gateway for

71
00:03:10.300 --> 00:03:15.080
void but rather an older pbx
that's mounted up on the wall.

72
00:03:15.080 --> 00:03:18.760
The way you know this is if you go into
your network telco system or your closet,

73
00:03:18.760 --> 00:03:19.950
wherever your wiring is.

74
00:03:19.950 --> 00:03:23.770
And if you see three or four big gray or
brown looking boxes hanging

75
00:03:23.770 --> 00:03:26.910
about halfway up on the ceiling and
they're kind of bolted to the wall,

76
00:03:26.910 --> 00:03:29.670
there's a bunch of cables
going to the bottom of them,

77
00:03:29.670 --> 00:03:32.980
then you probably have an older PBX, cuz
that's what those things would have been.

78
00:03:32.980 --> 00:03:34.160
Those have modems in them.

79
00:03:34.160 --> 00:03:35.710
That's how the vendor would
be able to get in and

80
00:03:35.710 --> 00:03:38.000
service them from externally,
from outside.

81
00:03:38.000 --> 00:03:40.900
And that's how we would often
do updates to the system.

82
00:03:40.900 --> 00:03:43.010
So if you have those still active,

83
00:03:43.010 --> 00:03:45.390
you actually have modems
whether you realize it or not.

84
00:03:45.390 --> 00:03:47.820
Laptops, older laptops, come with modems.

85
00:03:47.820 --> 00:03:51.370
Mine actually doesn't have a modem, but
it does have a cover over the modem

86
00:03:51.370 --> 00:03:53.640
port back here somewhere where
the modem would have gone.

87
00:03:53.640 --> 00:03:55.520
So there's no modem in my machine but

88
00:03:55.520 --> 00:03:57.720
you actually can still
get systems with modems.

89
00:03:57.720 --> 00:03:59.000
You just have to order them specially.

90
00:03:59.000 --> 00:04:01.470
So the reality is you still
may see them out there.

91
00:04:01.470 --> 00:04:04.440
The trick with a modem is to understand
that if a modem is plugged in,

92
00:04:04.440 --> 00:04:07.250
you essentially are going over
an unrestricted, uncontrolled,

93
00:04:07.250 --> 00:04:11.150
unmonitored separate communication
channel, an analog phone line.

94
00:04:11.150 --> 00:04:11.810
And the problem is,

95
00:04:11.810 --> 00:04:15.530
it's not going to be subject to
the normal monitoring we often do.

96
00:04:15.530 --> 00:04:20.340
Meaning the IDS, the IPS, the firewall
is not going to be aware of the analog

97
00:04:20.340 --> 00:04:22.840
communication taking
place across the modem.

98
00:04:22.840 --> 00:04:26.353
We don't tend to have systems that
monitor phone lines that way is what I'm

99
00:04:26.353 --> 00:04:27.318
suggesting to you.

100
00:04:27.318 --> 00:04:30.950
And those systems we use today were
not designed with that in mind.

101
00:04:30.950 --> 00:04:33.370
So if you have a modem and
you're communicating across it,

102
00:04:33.370 --> 00:04:36.160
you're effectively communicating on a
separate network we have no knowledge of.

103
00:04:36.160 --> 00:04:38.390
We will call this an out of band, right?

104
00:04:38.390 --> 00:04:40.400
Communication mechanisms
we've talked about.

105
00:04:40.400 --> 00:04:44.230
And this would be a communication channel
that we don't have any real knowledge of

106
00:04:44.230 --> 00:04:46.720
or vision of or ability to understand.

107
00:04:46.720 --> 00:04:48.220
I'm not saying that's a good or
a bad thing.

108
00:04:48.220 --> 00:04:50.680
I'm just pointing out to you
that from that perspective

109
00:04:50.680 --> 00:04:53.360
it's effectively an unrestricted
communication channel.

110
00:04:53.360 --> 00:04:55.150
No knowledge of what goes on there,
it could be good,

111
00:04:55.150 --> 00:04:57.080
it could be bad, we don't really know.

112
00:04:57.080 --> 00:04:59.560
It's not gonna be fast, we know that, but

113
00:04:59.560 --> 00:05:02.540
it's not gonna be necessarily
something that we have knowledge of.

114
00:05:02.540 --> 00:05:04.510
It was like a delayed joke reaction.

115
00:05:04.510 --> 00:05:05.560
>> Sorry.
>> I threw that out there,

116
00:05:05.560 --> 00:05:08.330
Mike's going along, yeah okay,
Adam's talking, I'm cool.

117
00:05:08.330 --> 00:05:10.495
Oh wait, he said something funny,
let me laugh for a second.

118
00:05:10.495 --> 00:05:13.090
>> [LAUGHTER]
>> So remember what my, my reference to

119
00:05:13.090 --> 00:05:16.870
that is the fact that modem lines are
traditionally much, much slower, right?

120
00:05:16.870 --> 00:05:19.060
This is an analog communication mechanism.

121
00:05:19.060 --> 00:05:22.030
We're ranking and
rating this in kilobits per second.

122
00:05:22.030 --> 00:05:24.990
Not megabits per second,
not gigabits per second.

123
00:05:24.990 --> 00:05:26.510
This is hurry up and wait.

124
00:05:26.510 --> 00:05:29.580
This is not hurry up and send,
so just be aware of that.

125
00:05:29.580 --> 00:05:32.350
We also have concentrators,
multiplexers, hubs and repeaters.

126
00:05:32.350 --> 00:05:35.540
A lot of this is old technology we haven't
really seen or talked about much or

127
00:05:35.540 --> 00:05:37.430
even know much about anymore.

128
00:05:37.430 --> 00:05:40.400
I mentioned hubs and repeaters in our
conversation about the OSI model.

129
00:05:40.400 --> 00:05:42.940
If you remember they
are a layer one device.

130
00:05:42.940 --> 00:05:45.800
Even though we don't see them
independently anymore they've been rolled

131
00:05:45.800 --> 00:05:47.670
up into the functionality of a switch, but

132
00:05:47.670 --> 00:05:49.820
we do still want to at
least be aware of those.

133
00:05:49.820 --> 00:05:53.740
Concentrators and multiplexers are things
that you may actually see, still,

134
00:05:53.740 --> 00:05:54.890
in certain systems.

135
00:05:54.890 --> 00:05:59.360
A concentrator's going to affect when we
take multiple devices, multiplex them,

136
00:05:59.360 --> 00:06:03.050
connect them into a system that allows
them to effectively be seen as one and

137
00:06:03.050 --> 00:06:04.530
transmit as one signal.

138
00:06:04.530 --> 00:06:08.680
So a concentrator will typically bring
together multiple system signals and

139
00:06:08.680 --> 00:06:11.020
then, effectively,
create one channel for them.

140
00:06:11.020 --> 00:06:14.730
A multiplexer is gonna effectively
going to be able to effectively,

141
00:06:14.730 --> 00:06:16.170
I just said effectively twice didn't I.

142
00:06:16.170 --> 00:06:17.020
Effectively, Effectively.

143
00:06:17.020 --> 00:06:19.306
Will effectively combine,
it's very effective.

144
00:06:19.306 --> 00:06:20.350
>> [LAUGH]
>> Will effectively combine

145
00:06:20.350 --> 00:06:23.770
multiple signals into a single signal for
transmission as well.

146
00:06:23.770 --> 00:06:26.170
Similar to what a concentrator does.

147
00:06:26.170 --> 00:06:30.970
A concentrator will multiplex, or
take multiple devices, transmit and

148
00:06:30.970 --> 00:06:33.790
create one association for them, so

149
00:06:33.790 --> 00:06:36.840
the concentrator brings together
multiple devices to multiplex,

150
00:06:36.840 --> 00:06:39.840
whereas the multiplexer is effectively
just focusing on the signal.

151
00:06:39.840 --> 00:06:41.230
In sending out one signal.

152
00:06:41.230 --> 00:06:46.590
We used to see these with early T1 lines,
with DSL technology,

153
00:06:46.590 --> 00:06:50.060
so if you had business DSL you
would have seen multiplexers and or

154
00:06:50.060 --> 00:06:51.580
concentrators probably.

155
00:06:51.580 --> 00:06:53.780
If you got a fractional T1,
at some point in time,

156
00:06:53.780 --> 00:06:57.370
you would have seen a multiplexer which
we often would call a channel bank.

157
00:06:57.370 --> 00:06:59.640
It's what you sometimes referred to as.

158
00:06:59.640 --> 00:07:02.160
You would see these,
they were usually rack mounted devices

159
00:07:02.160 --> 00:07:05.930
that would sit in the network room, be
connected up to the big box on the wall.

160
00:07:05.930 --> 00:07:09.150
The huge cable coming out of it
with the T1 circuits early on.

161
00:07:09.150 --> 00:07:10.750
These are the kinds of

the highest level at layer seven.
