00:28:41.860 --> 00:28:44.390
Circuit level proxies work down
below in the networking and

610
00:28:44.390 --> 00:28:47.940
transport layers of the OSI model to
create connections at a lower level with

611
00:28:47.940 --> 00:28:49.660
different kinds of functionality.

612
00:28:49.660 --> 00:28:52.410
Using the kinds of proxies
that we often see as well.

613
00:28:52.410 --> 00:28:55.270
Now, the last thing we wanna think about
in this area is something known as

614
00:28:55.270 --> 00:28:57.060
the content distribution network.

615
00:28:57.060 --> 00:29:01.700
These today, are typically gonna be
large scale systems that are going to,

616
00:29:01.700 --> 00:29:04.990
like proxies, cache information and
store them for us.

617
00:29:04.990 --> 00:29:07.950
But, they're typically gonna
have multiple copies of files or

618
00:29:07.950 --> 00:29:11.360
whatever we need, you'll think of
Netflix streaming movies to you.

619
00:29:11.360 --> 00:29:14.160
This is a content distribution
network that goes global.

620
00:29:14.160 --> 00:29:17.100
They've got hundreds of copies
of these movies loaded up on

621
00:29:17.100 --> 00:29:20.530
hundreds of servers around the world that
are load balanced so when you come in and

622
00:29:20.530 --> 00:29:23.890
say I want, you know, the X-Men or
whatever, you're gonna get it but

623
00:29:23.890 --> 00:29:27.330
you may get it from a server near you
may get it from a server far away.

624
00:29:27.330 --> 00:29:30.900
You may see copy 20 of 25,
or copy 1 of 100.

625
00:29:30.900 --> 00:29:33.500
It depends on what's
up in the rotation and

626
00:29:33.500 --> 00:29:36.570
what the load balancer says we're gonna
give you, because that's gonna be the most

627
00:29:36.570 --> 00:29:39.470
advantageous, quickest way,
to serve that content up.

628
00:29:39.470 --> 00:29:42.290
This is what's known as
a content distribution network.

629
00:29:42.290 --> 00:29:43.555
>> Fantastic stuff.

630
00:29:43.555 --> 00:29:46.330
Great look at a lot of the hardware
that we see on a daily basis.

631
00:29:46.330 --> 00:29:49.390
And some of the hardware that we might
not see, even though it's there.

632
00:29:49.390 --> 00:29:53.230
And some of the hardware that from the
days of the glory, the good old modems,

633
00:29:53.230 --> 00:29:55.710
and I'm telling you,
you take his recommendation,

634
00:29:55.710 --> 00:29:57.970
if you haven't scene War Games-
>> War Games,

635
00:29:57.970 --> 00:29:58.750
Good movie
>> You've got

636
00:29:58.750 --> 00:29:59.430
to see it
>> Good

637
00:29:59.430 --> 00:30:00.230
movie
>> It is a classic.

638
00:30:00.230 --> 00:30:02.320
[LAUGH]
>> Date night coming up, rent that movie.

639
00:30:02.320 --> 00:30:04.449
Good stuff!
>> All right, well, ladies and gentlemen,

640
00:30:04.449 --> 00:30:05.697
I hope you enjoyed everything.

641
00:30:05.697 --> 00:30:08.710
Remember, if you want to come
see one of Adam's classes live.

642
00:30:08.710 --> 00:30:11.960
Shoot us an email, SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

643
00:30:11.960 --> 00:30:16.250
That's going to do it for this episode,
signing off, I'm Mike Roderick.

644
00:30:16.250 --> 00:30:17.090
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

645
00:30:17.090 --> 00:30:20.100
>> And we'll see you next time.

646
00:30:20.100 --> 00:30:24.860
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike talk about using secure communication channels. They discuss risks introduced by various communication channels. Then they discuss ways to protect communications using various tunneling technologies, like PPTP, L2TP, IPSec and RADIUS.
episodes.title: Secure Communications
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.130 --> 00:00:15.341
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITproTV.

3
00:00:15.341 --> 00:00:20.250
I'm your host Mike Roderick,
today we're doing our CISSP content.

4
00:00:20.250 --> 00:00:22.930
And specifically we're gonna
be going into designing and

5
00:00:22.930 --> 00:00:28.630
establishing secure communications or
secure communication channels, right?

6
00:00:28.630 --> 00:00:32.087
We've talked about communication
channels in previous conversations.

7
00:00:32.087 --> 00:00:35.698
Gotta make sure that that information that
we're sending across those channels is

8
00:00:35.698 --> 00:00:39.270
protected and that those bad actors,
whoever wants it, can't get access to it.

9
00:00:39.270 --> 00:00:43.350
So here to help us with all that, is Mr.
Adam Gordon, how's it going, Adam?

10
00:00:43.350 --> 00:00:44.050
>> It's going well.

11
00:00:44.050 --> 00:00:46.960
Now I can tell you that, except if I
tell you that securely, then I'd have to

12
00:00:46.960 --> 00:00:49.400
have us encrypt that communication and
nobody would understand it.

13
00:00:49.400 --> 00:00:51.118
So instead, what I'm gonna do is this.

14
00:00:51.118 --> 00:00:51.936
Awesome.

15
00:00:51.936 --> 00:00:53.710
>> [LAUGH] I like it.

16
00:00:53.710 --> 00:00:56.340
>> All right, so let's talk a bit
about secure communication channels,

17
00:00:56.340 --> 00:00:57.710
how they work, what they are.

18
00:00:57.710 --> 00:00:59.670
We often start out at kind
of the baseline, right?

19
00:00:59.670 --> 00:01:01.780
And we've talked a lot about
older technologies and

20
00:01:01.780 --> 00:01:03.420
kind of worked our way up to newer ones.

21
00:01:03.420 --> 00:01:06.300
Reminding ourselves historically,
some of the things that's gone on.

22
00:01:06.300 --> 00:01:09.150
Where we've been, in other words, to
help us to understand where we're going.

23
00:01:09.150 --> 00:01:10.550
So, when we start this conversation,

24
00:01:10.550 --> 00:01:12.540
we want to start out talking
about voice generically.

25
00:01:12.540 --> 00:01:14.180
Not because it's older or newer, but

26
00:01:14.180 --> 00:01:17.690
just because it's a great place to think
about starting a conversation like this.

27
00:01:17.690 --> 00:01:20.180
Because voice touches,
voice communication does,

28
00:01:20.180 --> 00:01:22.660
many of the things that we think about and
we do today.

29
00:01:22.660 --> 00:01:25.290
We have what's called the plain
old fashion telephone system,

30
00:01:25.290 --> 00:01:27.510
what we commonly refer
to as the POTS network.

31
00:01:27.510 --> 00:01:30.100
That would have been the PSTN, the
publicly switched telephone network that

32
00:01:30.100 --> 00:01:32.780
we historically have used for
analog communication.

33
00:01:32.780 --> 00:01:35.700
We would send voice
communication over that.

34
00:01:35.700 --> 00:01:36.870
We may have what I mentioned earlier,

35
00:01:36.870 --> 00:01:39.510
which would have been the PBX,
the private branch exchange.

36
00:01:39.510 --> 00:01:43.570
Would have been an analog PBX, these
days would be a digital VOIP solution,

37
00:01:43.570 --> 00:01:46.800
a voice over IP solution kind
of morphing that technology.

38
00:01:46.800 --> 00:01:50.962
Blending data and voice on the same
system, through the same network lines.

39
00:01:50.962 --> 00:01:53.522
And then having to secure and
segment that traffic,

40
00:01:53.522 --> 00:01:56.390
manage it with quality of service,
what we call QOS.

41
00:01:56.390 --> 00:02:00.340
Securing it with encryption, but also
dealing with things such as jitter and

42
00:02:00.340 --> 00:02:01.200
sequencing errors.

43
00:02:01.200 --> 00:02:04.800
Where we may have problems because
of latency in the communication,

44
00:02:04.800 --> 00:02:06.305
causing disruption of the signal.

45
00:02:06.305 --> 00:02:09.676
And/or sequencing errors, where packets
show up out of sequence as we talk

46
00:02:09.676 --> 00:02:12.003
about sequence numbers and
how important they are.

47
00:02:12.003 --> 00:02:16.295
And if packets show up out of sequence,
then we may start hearing things that

48
00:02:16.295 --> 00:02:19.462
sound much like, and
this may [NOISE] like that, right?

49
00:02:19.462 --> 00:02:20.267
>> [LAUGH] [CROSSTALK]
>> And

50
00:02:20.267 --> 00:02:23.780
that's not you by the way, it's not your
ears, that's me purposely doing that.

51
00:02:23.780 --> 00:02:27.420
That could be jitter but that could
also be a question of sequencing errors.

52
00:02:27.420 --> 00:02:31.552
And what a sequence error would actually
sound like would be that you would hear,

53
00:02:31.552 --> 00:02:34.556
instead of the dog is blue,
you would hear the blue is dog.

54
00:02:34.556 --> 00:02:36.852
Because the packets show
up out of sequence, and

55
00:02:36.852 --> 00:02:39.870
are delivered and
then reconstructed in an incorrect manner.

56
00:02:39.870 --> 00:02:42.550
So we could have all of these problems and
concerns, right?

57
00:02:42.550 --> 00:02:44.418
Showing up and doing these kind of things.

58
00:02:44.418 --> 00:02:47.610
So we wanna be thinking about this when
we think about securing channels, and

59
00:02:47.610 --> 00:02:48.500
communications, and

60
00:02:48.500 --> 00:02:51.900
networks, we have to think about
not just the actual encryption.

61
00:02:51.900 --> 00:02:54.700
Do I keep the packets and
the data away from the bad guys?

62
00:02:54.700 --> 00:02:57.970
But I'm also securing,
in a sense that I'm optimizing and

63
00:02:57.970 --> 00:03:02.550
performance management data, so it shows
up the right way, follows the right path,

64
00:03:02.550 --> 00:03:04.230
is reproduced correctly?

65
00:03:04.230 --> 00:03:07.660
Latency, in other words, right,
transmission errors due to latency and

66
00:03:07.660 --> 00:03:10.337
sequencing problems,
can present as big of a challenge.

67
00:03:10.337 --> 00:03:14.593
Because they knock out the concept of
availability as packets that are not

68
00:03:14.593 --> 00:03:18.660
encrypted and are stolen from us and
expose confidentiality.

69
00:03:18.660 --> 00:03:21.320
So we remember,
we have three distinct pillars

70
00:03:21.320 --> 00:03:23.600
of information security
management we focus on.

71
00:03:23.600 --> 00:03:27.720
In this case, availability is gonna be a
very, very significant concern for us and

72
00:03:27.720 --> 00:03:29.840
we have to equally focus there.

73
00:03:29.840 --> 00:03:32.485
We talked about modems earlier
in one of our prior episodes,

74
00:03:32.485 --> 00:03:34.090
talked about them here with voice.

75
00:03:34.090 --> 00:03:36.579
I mentioned the whole
concept of what a modem does.

76
00:03:37.780 --> 00:03:39.560
Gave you the historical reference for

77
00:03:40.620 --> 00:03:44.640
thinking about why modems may be
important, why they are valuable to us.

78
00:03:44.640 --> 00:03:48.320
We talked about War Games, potentially,
as a movie you may want to watch.

79
00:03:48.320 --> 00:03:51.830
And another thing you saw in War Games
aside from the modem being used to hack,

80
00:03:51.830 --> 00:03:55.145
was that actually that hacking that
the modem was used to carry out,

81
00:03:55.145 --> 00:03:56.810
is given a very specific name.

82
00:03:56.810 --> 00:03:58.080
It's called war dialing.

83
00:03:58.080 --> 00:04:01.200
At least that was the old school way
of breaking into systems with modems.

84
00:04:01.200 --> 00:04:04.570
Now war dialing is, these days,
primarily a historical footnote, but

85
00:04:04.570 --> 00:04:06.760
it's actually making a comeback,
believe it or not.

86
00:04:06.760 --> 00:04:09.960
Because we have modems, as I've said,
in a lot of these older systems.

87
00:04:09.960 --> 00:04:12.110
And from a maintenance perspective,

88
00:04:12.110 --> 00:04:16.500
we are seeing them being exposed now
to the Internet through IP enabling

89
00:04:16.500 --> 00:04:19.890
on systems that may not realize they
still have modems associated with them.

90
00:04:19.890 --> 00:04:23.540
And because of that, because we're now
seeing these systems be effectively

91
00:04:23.540 --> 00:04:27.940
modernized and be exposed, the evidence
of modems being there may be found by

92
00:04:27.940 --> 00:04:29.430
hackers when they're probing and looking.

93
00:04:29.430 --> 00:04:32.250
And they may now try to get into
those modems and use them against us.

94
00:04:32.250 --> 00:04:35.070
So yet again,
doing the security inventory.

95
00:04:35.070 --> 00:04:37.910
Understanding what's available
to you becomes very important.

96
00:04:37.910 --> 00:04:41.128
Cuz what's available to you,
is also available to the bad actors.

97
00:04:41.128 --> 00:04:42.230
>> Bad actors.

98
00:04:42.230 --> 00:04:42.930
Absolutely correct.

99
00:04:42.930 --> 00:04:45.600
So, war dialing,
something very important to think about.

100
00:04:45.600 --> 00:04:49.975
Now a more modern version of war dialing
is something called war chalking and/or

101
00:04:49.975 --> 00:04:51.590
war driving.

102
00:04:51.590 --> 00:04:54.740
War driving and
war chalking are kind of the same thing.

103
00:04:54.740 --> 00:04:57.310
One is done in a car,
one is done without a car.

104
00:04:57.310 --> 00:04:59.070
But they both focus on the same activity.

105
00:04:59.070 --> 00:05:00.590
Hopefully you picked up on that subtle but

106
00:05:00.590 --> 00:05:02.460
important difference in
the reference there.

107
00:05:02.460 --> 00:05:04.580
They both deal with wireless networks.

108
00:05:04.580 --> 00:05:08.130
And they deal with the fact that war
driving is effectively somebody driving,

109
00:05:08.130 --> 00:05:11.310
literally, more of often than not
in a car, going around looking for

110
00:05:11.310 --> 00:05:13.030
wireless signals that are open.

111
00:05:13.030 --> 00:05:15.927
And when I travel, and
I travel a great deal to do what I do,

112
00:05:15.927 --> 00:05:19.671
I spend a lot of time in various places
around the world, not just in the US.

113
00:05:19.671 --> 00:05:23.120
But I travel globally, internationally,
to do a lot of the work I do.

114
00:05:23.120 --> 00:05:24.880
I'm often looking to get on the Internet.

115
00:05:24.880 --> 00:05:26.120
When I'm in strange places,

116
00:05:26.120 --> 00:05:29.320
I may or may not necessarily
have access to it directly.

117
00:05:29.320 --> 00:05:32.490
So, I will typically go online ahead
of time, knowing where I'm going, and

118
00:05:32.490 --> 00:05:33.780
I will look for coverage maps.

119
00:05:33.780 --> 00:05:36.050
Maps that people have actually
put up ahead of time and

120
00:05:36.050 --> 00:05:37.800
there are sites out there you can go and
find.

121
00:05:37.800 --> 00:05:39.990
And I'm not talking about
cell phone coverage maps.

122
00:05:39.990 --> 00:05:42.820
I'm talking about open wireless
access point coverage maps.

123
00:05:42.820 --> 00:05:45.880
So people have war drove,
if I can say that,

124
00:05:45.880 --> 00:05:50.205
or war drived, I don't know if that's
the proper terminology for the past tense.

125
00:05:50.205 --> 00:05:53.660
War driven perhaps,
I'm not an English grammatician.

126
00:05:53.660 --> 00:05:55.290
I'm definitely not.

127
00:05:55.290 --> 00:05:58.120
Math, English, not my forte at all.

128
00:05:58.120 --> 00:06:00.110
But if they have war driven
through an area, and

129
00:06:00.110 --> 00:06:03.870
they have marked all the open wireless
access points, they will typically put

130
00:06:03.870 --> 00:06:06.830
coverage maps up, that will then
tell you how you can find them.

131
00:06:06.830 --> 00:06:09.410
And then obviously, you can potentially
choose to take advantage of that.

132
00:06:09.410 --> 00:06:11.450
Let me be clear, I'm not suggesting for

133
00:06:11.450 --> 00:06:14.910
a minute, that you use this
information to hack into a business.

134
00:06:14.910 --> 00:06:18.770
I'm not suggesting for a minute that you
use this information to get up to no good.

135
00:06:18.770 --> 00:06:22.160
I'm merely pointing out to you that
somebody's probably done the due diligence

136
00:06:22.160 --> 00:06:25.230
and homework,
in terms of mapping the open sites.

137
00:06:25.230 --> 00:06:29.330
If you choose to connect across one and
use it, that's up to you.

138
00:06:29.330 --> 00:06:30.587
That may or may not be legal.

139
00:06:30.587 --> 00:06:33.440
I'm simply pointing out that that
information exists out there.

140
00:06:33.440 --> 00:06:34.980
And I want to be clear about that, right?

141
00:06:34.980 --> 00:06:36.120
Never want you to think for

142
00:06:36.120 --> 00:06:39.340
a minute that I'm suggesting you should
engage in a certain kind of behavior

143
00:06:39.340 --> 00:06:42.190
just because I talk about the fact
that that's a possibility.

144
00:06:42.190 --> 00:06:44.485
So it is possible to find
this information online.

145
00:06:44.485 --> 00:06:47.610
War chalking allows you, and

146
00:06:47.610 --> 00:06:50.710
it's done typically in the inner
city core, in downtown areas.

147
00:06:50.710 --> 00:06:51.950
Typically in the financial districts,

148
00:06:51.950 --> 00:06:56.450
business districts, where people actually
walk around instead of war driving, right?

149
00:06:56.450 --> 00:07:00.004
They'll mark the buildings and the open
access points on a site coverage map.

150
00:07:00.004 --> 00:07:01.918
But they actually will also use chalk,

151
00:07:01.918 --> 00:07:05.235
they will mark the actual open
access points in front of buildings.

152
00:07:05.235 --> 00:07:06.995
So if you know what to look for,

153
00:07:06.995 --> 00:07:09.455
you may see graffiti tags
on the side of a building,

154
00:07:09.455 --> 00:07:12.785
you may see literally somebody's
painted something on the sidewalk.

155
00:07:12.785 --> 00:07:13.997
It takes different forms.

156
00:07:13.997 --> 00:07:15.791
There may be a street sign
in front of the building,

157
00:07:15.791 --> 00:07:18.027
somebody's put a sticker up there,
kind of hidden from view.

158
00:07:18.027 --> 00:07:19.297
You have to know what to look for.

159
00:07:19.297 --> 00:07:23.357
But war shocking is the idea of marking
these open access points in buildings so

160
00:07:23.357 --> 00:07:25.517
that people that know what to look for
know that they are there and

161
00:07:25.517 --> 00:07:26.637
know how to use them.

162
00:07:26.637 --> 00:07:28.817
Just another way to
communicate this information.

163
00:07:28.817 --> 00:07:31.848
It's got a lot of interesting little
subcultural context going on with

164
00:07:31.848 --> 00:07:32.462
some of this.

165
00:07:32.462 --> 00:07:35.604
We have, indeed, an entire community and
a language and a context and

166
00:07:35.604 --> 00:07:39.436
behavior around these kind of activities,
that, as security professionals, we at

167
00:07:39.436 --> 00:07:43.170
least have to educate ourselves about
enough to understand how to interact with.

168
00:07:43.170 --> 00:07:45.940
Because that is indeed what
we are talking about here.

169
00:07:45.940 --> 00:07:47.620
Remember peer to peer applications?

170
00:07:47.620 --> 00:07:50.597
Remember P to P applications,
file sharing, Napster,

171
00:07:50.597 --> 00:07:52.153
big huge issue with Napster?

172
00:07:52.153 --> 00:07:55.804
You had Filezilla, you had Morpheus,
Limewire, Kazaa, Bear to Bear, or

173
00:07:55.804 --> 00:07:58.953
Bearshare or Sharebear, Bearshare,
whatever the hell it was.

174
00:07:58.953 --> 00:08:01.216
Right, you had all these
different ones out there.

175
00:08:01.216 --> 00:08:02.314
You know, and they're still around.

176
00:08:02.314 --> 00:08:04.101
There are some that are still around.

177
00:08:04.101 --> 00:08:07.816
But the reality is they really
have not become common anymore,

178
00:08:07.816 --> 00:08:11.110
in a sense that they are illegal for
the most part.

179
00:08:11.110 --> 00:08:13.690
The government tends to crack down on
these when they become a little too big.

180
00:08:13.690 --> 00:08:16.130
If you remember the whole
MegaUpload disaster and

181
00:08:16.130 --> 00:08:17.660
what went on with that system.

182
00:08:17.660 --> 00:08:21.215
Where people were eventually, because they
were using this technology to effectively

183
00:08:21.215 --> 00:08:23.964
share files illegally,
the government came in and shut down Mega.

184
00:08:23.964 --> 00:08:26.999
Took all their servers, took all their
data, and just one day they're there,

185
00:08:26.999 --> 00:08:28.290
next day they were gone.

186
00:08:28.290 --> 00:08:31.160
So these applications can
have a dark side to them.

187
00:08:31.160 --> 00:08:33.503
But we wanna know that peer
to peer applications and

188
00:08:33.503 --> 00:08:36.019
peer to peer sharing protocols
do exist potentially.

189
00:08:36.019 --> 00:08:38.330
They may still be use and
in play in your networks.

190

It's bad because ultimately the end
users don't find value in it.

416
00:19:25.950 --> 00:19:29.730
And this is one of the things that
a CISSP really have to be aware of.

417
00:19:29.730 --> 00:19:32.200
We can come up with
incredibly complicated,

418
00:19:32.200 --> 00:19:35.690
complex technological
solutions to problems.

419
00:19:35.690 --> 00:19:39.780
I don't doubt for a minute that most of
you out there are capable of coming up

420
00:19:39.780 --> 00:19:43.710
with some really cool and innovative
ways to do the things we do everyday.

421
00:19:43.710 --> 00:19:47.090
That may involve new technologies,
that may or may not be well understood.

422
00:19:47.090 --> 00:19:50.530
That's all good, we want that innovation,
we want that to happen, that's good.

423
00:19:50.530 --> 00:19:54.570
Problem is if it's not something that's
easily translatable into a user's world

424
00:19:54.570 --> 00:19:57.640
then what will ultimately happen is
the users will simply ignore and

425
00:19:57.640 --> 00:19:58.970
bypass that control.

426
00:19:58.970 --> 00:20:00.110
They just won't use it.

427
00:20:00.110 --> 00:20:03.365
And VPNs effectively are good
example of that technology.

428
00:20:03.365 --> 00:20:05.640
They became very difficult and
tedious to use.

429
00:20:05.640 --> 00:20:07.750
Most users decided it
wasn't worth the trouble.

430
00:20:07.750 --> 00:20:10.850
So while we had a good solution
it was implemented poorly.

431
00:20:10.850 --> 00:20:13.400
This is the web conversation
right all over again and

432
00:20:13.400 --> 00:20:17.750
as a result of that because it wasn't
easy to use it became less valuable.

433
00:20:17.750 --> 00:20:20.490
CISSP's have to do two things and
do them well.

434
00:20:21.500 --> 00:20:25.580
We ultimately have to make sure that
we are able to translate the incredibly

435
00:20:25.580 --> 00:20:29.900
complex environments we operate in
into simple distillable solutions for

436
00:20:29.900 --> 00:20:32.340
users that allow them to operate securely.

437
00:20:32.340 --> 00:20:35.190
And we then have to document
what we've done and

438
00:20:35.190 --> 00:20:38.670
make sure we test to enforce
the documentation and the policies and

439
00:20:38.670 --> 00:20:40.390
procedures, make sure we
know what's going on.

440
00:20:40.390 --> 00:20:43.090
And if we find a problem,
we have to step back and

441
00:20:43.090 --> 00:20:45.530
reengineer the solution to
make sure that it is usable.

442
00:20:45.530 --> 00:20:48.660
This is really distilled down in
it's essence, what CISSP's do.

443
00:20:48.660 --> 00:20:49.980
We do a lot more than that, by the way.

444
00:20:49.980 --> 00:20:51.610
I'm not saying that's
the only thing we do.

445
00:20:51.610 --> 00:20:52.950
But when you get right down to it,

446
00:20:52.950 --> 00:20:55.300
it's our job to make
the incredibly complex simple.

447
00:20:55.300 --> 00:20:58.490
Simple enough that average users
will actually follow the rules.

448
00:20:58.490 --> 00:21:00.700
If we can do that,
we've done our job well.

449
00:21:00.700 --> 00:21:03.130
If we can't, we gotta really
think about what we're doing and

450
00:21:03.130 --> 00:21:05.210
are we doing the right things for
the right reasons?

451
00:21:05.210 --> 00:21:10.010
So, VPNs are good technology but VPNs can
also lead to challenges and concerns.

452
00:21:10.010 --> 00:21:11.950
How do we use a VPN,
well we connect up and

453
00:21:11.950 --> 00:21:15.200
we create what's called a tunnel
ultimately to secure two end points and

454
00:21:15.200 --> 00:21:18.060
then to effectively establish
communication between them.

455
00:21:18.060 --> 00:21:20.390
What are the protocols that
may be used to create tunnels?

456
00:21:20.390 --> 00:21:23.150
One of them is PPTP,
point to point tunneling protocol.

457
00:21:23.150 --> 00:21:26.350
Another one is L2TP,
layer two tunneling protocol.

458
00:21:26.350 --> 00:21:31.130
Layer two tunneling protocol is gonna
actually take PPTP which is the gen one,

459
00:21:31.130 --> 00:21:34.930
first generation tunneling protocol that
was very popular and still remains so and

460
00:21:34.930 --> 00:21:38.260
is still used but it's used under
the guise of a new technology.

461
00:21:38.260 --> 00:21:41.340
Combines PPTP with something known as L2F,

462
00:21:41.340 --> 00:21:44.630
layer two forwarding protocol
which is a proprietary Cisco

463
00:21:44.630 --> 00:21:48.110
protocol that exists at layer two of
the OSI model at the data link layer.

464
00:21:48.110 --> 00:21:51.150
We combine the two together and
we get a rebrand and

465
00:21:51.150 --> 00:21:54.880
repurpose protocol called L2TP,
layer two tunneling.

466
00:21:54.880 --> 00:21:58.370
So PPTP is gonna be a tunneling
protocol that's actually very valuable.

467
00:21:58.370 --> 00:22:02.450
And the reason it sits at the heart of
L2TP is for two very important reasons.

468
00:22:02.450 --> 00:22:03.800
You actually know what they might be.

469
00:22:03.800 --> 00:22:04.685
You may or may not know.

470
00:22:04.685 --> 00:22:06.500
>> Built-in encryption capabilities.

471
00:22:06.500 --> 00:22:08.610
>> So it does have built-in
encryption capabilities, absolutely.

472
00:22:08.610 --> 00:22:10.550
So that's one of the very
important reasons why we do this.

473
00:22:10.550 --> 00:22:13.380
Because one of the downsides
to L2TP by itself,

474
00:22:13.380 --> 00:22:16.100
without something else,
is that it does not encrypt natively.

475
00:22:16.100 --> 00:22:17.760
So that is something to consider.

476
00:22:17.760 --> 00:22:19.570
But there's also another reason.

477
00:22:19.570 --> 00:22:21.530
Another reason that PBTP was very,

478
00:22:21.530 --> 00:22:25.420
very important is that it allowed us to
tunnel protocols and run them over other

479
00:22:25.420 --> 00:22:29.210
protocols that normally would not allow
for those protocols to be transmitted.

480
00:22:29.210 --> 00:22:31.080
In other words like all
good tunneling protocols,

481
00:22:31.080 --> 00:22:33.410
right, we're able to transmit
protocols that may or

482
00:22:33.410 --> 00:22:37.070
may not be routable inside of
a tunnel through protocols that are.

483
00:22:37.070 --> 00:22:39.610
So in other words we could take
if we really wanted to right,

484
00:22:39.610 --> 00:22:44.060
think about the logic of this, you could
take Net Bios and tunnel it through a PPTP

485
00:22:44.060 --> 00:22:47.860
connection and route it even though it
was never supposed to leave your subnet.

486
00:22:47.860 --> 00:22:50.550
Now that's kind of silly and
if you do that you need a hobby.

487
00:22:50.550 --> 00:22:51.995
Get out and talk to people more, right.

488
00:22:51.995 --> 00:22:53.230
>> [LAUGH]
>> Square dancing, something, but

489
00:22:53.230 --> 00:22:53.970
you don't wanna do that.

490
00:22:53.970 --> 00:22:57.720
But my point is, it would allow us
to be able to tunnel non-routable

491
00:22:57.720 --> 00:23:00.140
transmissions through a tunnel and
send it out.

492
00:23:00.140 --> 00:23:03.670
It does allow for things like
the addition of IPsec, PPTP does.

493
00:23:03.670 --> 00:23:05.120
So certainly, that's important.

494
00:23:06.150 --> 00:23:11.280
It does offer potentially the opportunity
to include encryption depending on how

495
00:23:11.280 --> 00:23:14.650
we would set it up and what we would do
with it but it really formed the basis for

496
00:23:14.650 --> 00:23:18.685
us for what we think of is [INAUDIBLE]
protocols because it was so flexible.

497
00:23:18.685 --> 00:23:19.905
And it did so many things.

498
00:23:19.905 --> 00:23:23.375
But there were limitations, and
so we updated it with L2TP,

499
00:23:23.375 --> 00:23:27.905
Layer 2 Tunneling Protocol,
PPTP plus L2F, but the downside to

500
00:23:27.905 --> 00:23:31.635
L2TP is that there's no native encryption,
no native authentication.

501
00:23:31.635 --> 00:23:34.590
So we often pair that with
what's known as IPsec.

502
00:23:34.590 --> 00:23:36.920
IP security which is
the security protocol.

503
00:23:36.920 --> 00:23:38.878
We talked about that,
when we talked about the OSI model.

504
00:23:38.878 --> 00:23:41.705
IP sec provides authentication and
encryption for us or

505
00:23:41.705 --> 00:23:45.024
at least the ability to provide
authentication and encryption.

506
00:23:45.024 --> 00:23:49.120
And so we often will see and
hear L2P deployed with IP sec.

507
00:23:49.120 --> 00:23:52.950
IP sec effectively is a suite of
protocols for communicating securely if

508
00:23:52.950 --> 00:23:55.660
you want to think of it that way and
that's what we do there.

509
00:23:55.660 --> 00:23:57.171
IPsec is made of up several components.

510
00:23:57.171 --> 00:23:59.143
We want to have a general
knowledge of what they are.

511
00:23:59.143 --> 00:24:02.055
We have authentication headers,
what are known as.

512
00:24:02.055 --> 00:24:05.258
Headers, Headers,
authentication headers, or.

513
00:24:05.258 --> 00:24:08.970
The authentication headers are gonna
provide the authentication capabilities.

514
00:24:08.970 --> 00:24:11.080
So, the integrity capabilities, and

515
00:24:11.080 --> 00:24:13.330
the authentication
capabilities come to us there.

516
00:24:13.330 --> 00:24:16.030
We also have encapsulation or
encapsulated security pay load.

517
00:24:16.030 --> 00:24:18.900
ESP wich is providing
the confidentiality protection,

518
00:24:18.900 --> 00:24:21.320
the encryption if you will of the data.

519
00:24:21.320 --> 00:24:23.490
And then we have what is known
as the security association or

520
00:24:23.490 --> 00:24:24.890
what's known as an SA.

521
00:24:24.890 --> 00:24:29.690
The SA is a one way agreement, a one way
negotiated agreement, uni-directional,

522
00:24:29.690 --> 00:24:33.990
we ultimately need two, so it's gonna be
a two one-way communication agreement

523
00:24:33.990 --> 00:24:38.670
conversation to get bi-directional
capabilities for ITSEC to be applied.

524
00:24:38.670 --> 00:24:41.470
But an SA is effectively a one
way communication agreement

525
00:24:41.470 --> 00:24:46.140
negotiated between, let's say the sender
and the receiver in one direction,

526
00:24:46.140 --> 00:24:48.910
that stipulates how IPsec
will be set up and used.

527
00:24:48.910 --> 00:24:51.820
So it's effectively like a SLA
if you wanna think about it,

528
00:24:51.820 --> 00:24:55.090
for a one-way communication channel to
be set up, established, and managed.

529
00:24:55.090 --> 00:24:56.680
That's what an SLA represents.

530
00:24:56.680 --> 00:24:58.380
So you have authentication headers.

531
00:24:58.380 --> 00:25:02.060
You have encapsulating security payload,
which is the extensible protocol set

532
00:25:02.060 --> 00:25:05.900
that allows us to provide confidentiality,
and then security associations that

533
00:25:05.900 --> 00:25:09.010
are negotiated one-way agreements
to govern communication.

534
00:25:09.010 --> 00:25:11.490
These are the building blocks
to components of IPSEC.

535
00:25:11.490 --> 00:25:14.980
Now IPSEC with L2TP is now
gonna be implemented, or

536
00:25:14.980 --> 00:25:18.330
L2TP with IPSEC is implemented
in one of two modes.

537
00:25:18.330 --> 00:25:20.790
We're gonna implement that in
either what's called tunnel mode or

538
00:25:20.790 --> 00:25:21.940
transport mode.

539
00:25:21.940 --> 00:25:25.070
So we have to just quickly talk about
the difference between the two.

540
00:25:25.070 --> 00:25:28.560
We often talk about the fact when we
think about IPSEC or L2TP with IPSEC,

541
00:25:28.560 --> 00:25:32.450
we think about how we tunnel and how we
transport, and what I often remind my

542
00:25:32.450 --> 00:25:36.400
students of is that we transport
up to the LAN or through the LAN.

543
00:25:36.400 --> 00:25:40.689
And you can think of us transporting to
the LAN side of the router or the gateway,

544
00:25:40.689 --> 00:25:43.180
and then we tunnel through the router.

545
00:25:43.180 --> 00:25:47.170
So we transport on the LAN,
and we tunnel through the WAN.

546
00:25:47.170 --> 00:25:50.900
Because we tunnel between end points,
between wide area network end points,

547
00:25:50.900 --> 00:25:51.975
which are routers.

548
00:25:51.975 --> 00:25:54.130
How we transport on
the local area network.

549
00:25:54.130 --> 00:25:56.930
So transport mode is used on the LAN.

550
00:25:56.930 --> 00:25:59.620
Tunnel mode is used between
routing endpoints on the WAN, and

551
00:25:59.620 --> 00:26:03.280
if that works for you and helps you
to figure that out then, obviously,

552
00:26:03.280 --> 00:26:04.550
that's something to consider.

553
00:26:04.550 --> 00:26:07.790
But tunnel mode is gonna be implemented
between routers, transport mode is

554
00:26:07.790 --> 00:26:11.450
implemented on the local area network
side, to be able to effectively transmit

555
00:26:11.450 --> 00:26:16.480
between a endpoint, a workstation of
some kind, and or server, excuse me.

556
00:26:16.480 --> 00:26:20.440
And ultimately up the the local area
network side, the LAN side of the router,

557
00:26:20.440 --> 00:26:24.100
or the LAN side of the gateway if you
will, is where we see transport mode.

558
00:26:24.100 --> 00:26:26.220
So we just want to think about that and
be aware of that.

559
00:26:26.220 --> 00:26:29.240
We also have something known as
Internet key exchange, or IKE.

560
00:26:29.240 --> 00:26:33.880
IKE is going to allow us to effectively
exchange keys, between the members

561
00:26:33.880 --> 00:26:37.605
that are going to be involved in
negotiating the SAs, and using an IPSEC.

562
00:26:37.605 --> 00:26:39.975
This is all still part of
the IPSEC conversation.

563
00:26:39.975 --> 00:26:43.885
So two devices that are exchanging
symmetric keys, private keys for

564
00:26:43.885 --> 00:26:48.055
the use of encryption,
inside of IPSEC are gonna use IKE,

565
00:26:48.055 --> 00:26:49.615
Internet key exchange in order to do that.

566
00:26:49.615 --> 00:26:51.945
Now, we have a couple of
different key exchange methods.

567
00:26:51.945 --> 00:26:54.905
IKE is the overarching thought
process we think about.

568
00:26:54.905 --> 00:26:56.071
We use Diffie-Hellman.

569
00:26:56.071 --> 00:26:59.800
Diffie-Hellman is the traditional
key exchange method that we use.

570
00:26:59.800 --> 00:27:02.830
We could also use public key certificates,
and we've talked about certificates, and

571
00:27:02.830 --> 00:27:05.670
if you remember that conversation
how certificates can be used and

572
00:27:05.670 --> 00:27:07.620
why, we can also use that.

573
00:27:07.620 --> 00:27:10.780
But Internet key exchange,
generically, refers to the idea of

574
00:27:10.780 --> 00:27:14.240
being able to exchange these private
keys and negotiate the use of them.

575
00:27:14.240 --> 00:27:15.800
And the mechanism for doing so

576
00:27:15.800 --> 00:27:18.250
is typically referred to as
the use of Diffie-Hellman,

577
00:27:18.250 --> 00:27:22.556
which is a key exchange protocol that
we can use to do that with IPSEC.

578
00:27:22.556 --> 00:27:25.410
And we also wanna think about
remote control protocols, or

579
00:27:25.410 --> 00:27:29.760
excuse me remote authentication protocols,
that track usage across systems.

580
00:27:29.760 --> 00:27:32.310
We commonly refer to this
as RADIUS technology.

581
00:27:32.310 --> 00:27:36.210
Remote authentication dial in user
service is what RADIUS stands for.

582
00:27:36.210 --> 00:27:38.550
Radius systems, believe it or
not, are still very popular,

583
00:27:38.550 --> 00:27:42.070
it's just you don't really tend to see
them in most modern networks directly,

584
00:27:42.070 --> 00:27:44.590
because they are typically
used by service providers.

585
00:27:44.590 --> 00:27:47.170
So we often see them at the Internet
service provider level,

586
00:27:47.170 --> 00:27:49.340
where they are using them to
be able to do three things.

587
00:27:49.340 --> 00:27:53.210
We refer to the triple
A of radius traditionally.

588
00:27:53.210 --> 00:27:55.990
We think about authentication.

589
00:27:55.990 --> 00:27:57.130
We think about authorization.

590
00:27:57.130 --> 00:28:00.890
And we think about auditing as the three
As that are represented by the radius

591
00:28:00.890 --> 00:28:01.760
capability.

592
00:28:01.760 --> 00:28:05.830
So, radius is effectively going to sit
on the border, right, of your network,

593
00:28:05.830 --> 00:28:07.300
a radius solution will.

594
00:28:07.300 --> 00:28:11.029
And it's gonna intercept all inbound
traffic that is actually looking to come

595
00:28:11.029 --> 00:28:12.975
in and gain access to your system.

596
00:28:12.975 --> 00:28:16.425
So any of the remote access technology,
remote access traffic coming in,

597
00:28:16.425 --> 00:28:19.835
is gonna pass it's traffic
stream through a radius device.

598
00:28:19.835 --> 00:28:23.715
Radius is then gonna look to authenticate,
to authorize, and to audit, so

599
00:28:23.715 --> 00:28:25.205
what radius does is it's a cut out.

600
00:28:25.205 --> 00:28:28.580
It's a proxy for
inbound authentication traffic.

601
00:28:28.580 --> 00:28:32.230
Radius server says hey, stop right
here on the border, stay right here,

602
00:28:32.230 --> 00:28:35.720
I'm going to go check on your credentials,
and see if you're legitimate or not.

603
00:28:35.720 --> 00:28:40.390
And the radius server goes off over here,
right there,

604
00:28:40.390 --> 00:28:43.750
right over there, and let's pretend for
just a minute that that

605
00:28:43.750 --> 00:28:48.310
thing I'm pointing to right there is
actually our directory service controller.

606
00:28:48.310 --> 00:28:51.300
In plain old fashioned English,
that's a domain controller.

607
00:28:51.300 --> 00:28:54.070
So the radius server's gonna talk
to the domain controller, and

608
00:28:54.070 --> 00:28:56.870
find out whether the credentials
provided are legitimate.

609
00:28:56.870 --> 00:28:59.830
The goal is, we don't want
the inbound traffic to talk directly

610
00:28:59.830 --> 00:29:03.040
to the domain controller,
because if it's a spoofed traffic send,

611
00:29:03.040 --> 00:29:05.920
or a masquerade of some kind,
we may have a bad actor that gains

612
00:29:05.920 --> 00:29:08.060
advantage by getting
directly into the network.

613
00:29:08.060 --> 00:29:11.670
And then can take advantage of that
access to do evil and to do harm.

614
00:29:11.670 --> 00:29:16.220
So, the radius box cuts out that
traffic's end, proxies get in effect.

615
00:29:16.220 --> 00:29:20.940
Stops it at a boarder, it goes over
on behalf of the system, says hey,

616
00:29:20.940 --> 00:29:22.170
is this authentic?

617
00:29:22.170 --> 00:29:26.100
The transmission then comes back to
the radius server, and says yes, it is.

618
00:29:26.100 --> 00:29:28.690
If that's the case,
we then authorize the user, and

619
00:29:28.690 --> 00:29:30.465
then we allow that traffic stream in.

620
00:29:30.465 --> 00:29:33.400
If the answer is no, we'e shut it off,
and don't allow it in.

621
00:29:33.400 --> 00:29:35.220
This is how a radius box works.

622
00:29:35.220 --> 00:29:38.800
But in addition, if we do allow it in,
we then are doing what's called auditing.

623
00:29:38.800 --> 00:29:41.110
Our third A in the AAA.

624
00:29:41.110 --> 00:29:43.810
The auditing is the actual
session management and

625
00:29:43.810 --> 00:29:46.385
more importantly session
monitoring that takes place.

626
00:29:46.385 --> 00:29:49.240
So that we log all the events that
take place during the session.

627
00:29:49.240 --> 00:29:49.950
Who are you?

628
00:29:49.950 --> 00:29:50.550
Where you going to?

629
00:29:50.550 --> 00:29:51.460
Where are you coming from?

630
00:29:51.460 --> 00:29:52.410
What are you doing?

631
00:29:52.410 --> 00:29:56.320
So ISPs use this to be able to keep track
of what is going on in their systems.

632
00:29:56.320 --> 00:29:57.790
When you get that nasty cease and

633
00:29:57.790 --> 00:30:01.430
desist letter from the ISP because
you're using P2P technology,

634
00:30:01.430 --> 00:30:05.120
to bit torrent files you're not supposed
to, the reason they know that is because

635
00:30:05.120 --> 00:30:07.570
you're using radius servers to
keep track of what you're doing.

636
00:30:07.570 --> 00:30:10.790
And they can tell that you're up to
no good because they're auditing

637
00:30:10.790 --> 00:30:12.290
your connections.

638
00:30:12.290 --> 00:30:14.990
Wake up people, everybody's
listening to what you're doing,

639
00:30:14.990 --> 00:30:16.340
you should know better, right?

640
00:30:16.340 --> 00:30:19.020
There's no such thing as privacy
in the digital domain anymore.

00:30:19.020 --> 00:30:21.010
So this is what radius technology does and

this is how radius servers

We also have older old school real old
school technology, Diameter and TACACS or

TACACS plus reaching back into our
grab bag of historical irrelevancies.

645
00:30:32.160 --> 00:30:34.630
So Diameter was actually
an improvement on radius.

646
00:30:34.630 --> 00:30:36.620
So it's like radius but radius plus.

647
00:30:36.620 --> 00:30:37.810
It was never really very popular.

648

It never really was deployed widely.

649
00:30:39.650 --> 00:30:42.430
It was a standard that was
thrown out there for a while.

650
00:30:42.430 --> 00:30:44.330
People thought about it.

651
00:30:44.330 --> 00:30:47.560
Never really went anywhere, so
it's just a historical footnote, but

652
00:30:47.560 --> 00:30:49.830
it was kinda like an improved
version of Radius.

653
00:30:49.830 --> 00:30:52.460
Radius was good enough that we kind of
just have it around still doing what it

654
00:30:52.460 --> 00:30:53.468
does today.

655
00:30:53.468 --> 00:30:57.690
TACACS or TACACS plus were really just
another version of this thought process to

656
00:30:57.690 --> 00:31:00.390

657
00:31:00.390 --> 00:31:03.920

encrypted the entire transmission for us,

658
00:31:03.920 --> 00:31:08.220
so the exchange of user credentials during
authentication would not be exposed.

659
00:31:08.220 --> 00:31:12.210
And so this is what the TACACS or
TACACS plus solutions also did for us.

660

>> All right, well you know there's

1
00:00:00.103 --> 00:00:10.103
[MUSIC]

2

Hello and welcome to another

We had a conversation

And what we need to understand with
radius in any remote access technology

00:01:00.790 --> 00:01:03.760
is that there's different kinds of
traffic that may actually come through

22
00:01:03.760 --> 00:01:04.840
those devices, right?

23
00:01:04.840 --> 00:01:08.160
So one of the common traffic

24

something that's driven by SNMP,
Simple Network Management Protocol.

25
00:01:12.010 --> 00:01:16.010
Which is effectively a protocol
that allows us to manage remotely

26
00:01:16.010 --> 00:01:18.490
devices like routers, switches, and

27
00:01:18.490 --> 00:01:23.950
all sorts of additional systems that will
then allow us to effectively connect,

28

29

30
00:01:32.134 --> 00:01:33.431
Things of that nature, right.

31
00:01:33.431 --> 00:01:38.385
And so we are gonna have now, currently,
three versions of SNMP, v1, v2, v3.

32
00:01:38.385 --> 00:01:41.025
V3 is the most recent version.

33
00:01:41.025 --> 00:01:42.415
That is the most secure.

34
00:01:42.415 --> 00:01:44.790
It does encrypt the traffic flow,
natively.

35
00:01:44.790 --> 00:01:47.495
SNMPv1 was encrypted by default.

36
00:01:47.495 --> 00:01:50.155
Let to some issues and
concerns about traffic management,

37
00:01:50.155 --> 00:01:53.815
exposure of passwords and
things of that nature.

38
00:01:53.815 --> 00:01:57.515
We actually use what is known as a
community string to be able to effectively

39
00:01:57.515 --> 00:01:59.840
interact with V as an SNMP device.

40
00:01:59.840 --> 00:02:01.410
You can think of it like a password.

41
00:02:01.410 --> 00:02:04.370
You would have to revive the community

42
00:02:04.370 --> 00:02:08.630
And they'll be able to manage it

43
00:02:08.630 --> 00:02:11.870

put information there and

44
00:02:11.870 --> 00:02:14.980
set it to get,
put set things like that were used.

45
00:02:14.980 --> 00:02:20.390
But ultimately, the idea is that
SNMPv3 encrypts that traffic and

46
00:02:20.390 --> 00:02:22.900
allows us to be more secure
in our communication.

47
00:02:22.900 --> 00:02:26.300
So you want to know about SNMP,
obviously important as a protocol.

48
00:02:26.300 --> 00:02:27.910
We have a lot of remote access services.

49
00:02:27.910 --> 00:02:29.070
We've talked about several of them.

50
00:02:29.070 --> 00:02:31.220
A lot of them are generic and

51
00:02:31.220 --> 00:02:34.180
are used regardless of what
kind of technology you may use.

52
00:02:34.180 --> 00:02:37.630
But there are other ones we haven't really
talked about that are gonna be older and

53
00:02:37.630 --> 00:02:39.700
perhaps used on certain platforms only.

54
00:02:39.700 --> 00:02:43.280
So something like Telnet,
which is an old historical footnote, but

55
00:02:43.280 --> 00:02:46.470
it's something we should not really
see being used in production today,

56
00:02:46.470 --> 00:02:50.190
because it is essentially a wide open,
no encryption based,

57
00:02:50.190 --> 00:02:54.180
clear communication solution for,
again, remote management of a system.

58
00:02:54.180 --> 00:02:58.140
So instead we replaced Telnet with
something like SSH, and some sort of

59
00:02:58.140 --> 00:03:02.710
a secure communication client,
whether you use PuTTY or something else.

60
00:03:02.710 --> 00:03:07.670
With SSH to then be able to encrypt that
traffic and remotely manage that system,

61
00:03:07.670 --> 00:03:11.960
is going to be a good alternative
solution for the use of Telnet.

62
00:03:11.960 --> 00:03:15.910
We may be using, if we're on a Linux or
Unix based system,

63
00:03:15.910 --> 00:03:20.720
things like rlogon,
RCP remote copy, RSH remote shell.

64
00:03:20.720 --> 00:03:23.420
So these are going to be tools
that are effectively able,

65
00:03:23.420 --> 00:03:27.120
or do enable us to able to do
remote access services securely

66
00:03:27.120 --> 00:03:30.060
across the Linux UNIX based
platforms of the world.

67
00:03:30.060 --> 00:03:34.440
So we're gonna be able to think about
how to implement them securely and

68
00:03:34.440 --> 00:03:38.740
have to again think about are we
tunneling, are we gonna be encrypting,

69
00:03:38.740 --> 00:03:41.010
are we gonna be able to just
use these are they open,

70
00:03:41.010 --> 00:03:43.780
are they not open, are they encrypted,
are they secure or are they not.

71
00:03:43.780 --> 00:03:47.140
You know, some of these things
are older technologies that may not

72
00:03:47.140 --> 00:03:48.410
have transmitting with encryption.

73
00:03:48.410 --> 00:03:50.030
May have transmitted in the clear.

74
00:03:50.030 --> 00:03:51.440
And we have to be aware of that.

75
00:03:51.440 --> 00:03:55.050
So the use of something like remote shell

76
00:03:55.050 --> 00:03:56.850
And we have to understand that and
be aware of that.

77
00:03:56.850 --> 00:03:59.340
So these are all things to be consider.

78

Screen scraping technology is something

79

You know we've had a print screen button

80
00:04:07.660 --> 00:04:09.800
We can effectively take

81

82
00:04:13.196 --> 00:04:16.703
if we're running software that allows

83
00:04:16.703 --> 00:04:19.587
we can then take that screen capture and

84
00:04:19.587 --> 00:04:22.650
And we may or may not be able to
prevent that behavior from occurring.

85
00:04:22.650 --> 00:04:25.500
You know, in Windows 7,
we have the ability to use the,

86
00:04:25.500 --> 00:04:29.000
with the built in Program
that we can go in.

87
00:04:29.000 --> 00:04:31.710
Yeah, the snipping program,
the snipping tool is what it's called.

88
00:04:31.710 --> 00:04:34.440
We can go in and take a screen
capture of anything on the screen.

00:04:34.440 --> 00:04:37.720

00:04:37.720 --> 00:04:39.480

91
00:04:39.480 --> 00:04:42.280
Paste that into a document, and

00:04:42.280 --> 00:04:44.280
send that off the system in some way.

93
00:04:44.280 --> 00:04:45.930
So remember that there may be ways for

00:04:45.930 --> 00:04:50.150
us to get around most of the controls that
you've put in place in the system already.

95
00:04:50.150 --> 00:04:51.970
We want to be thinking about that as well.

96
00:04:51.970 --> 00:04:56.001
We may open up terminal connections,
right, a remote desktop connection, an RDP

00:04:56.001 --> 00:04:59.873
connection, or some sort of remote console
to a system and remotely manage it.

98
00:04:59.873 --> 00:05:03.355
So we want to be thinking about that, how
secure is that, and how secure will those

99
00:05:03.355 --> 00:05:06.081
communications be is something
else that we have to consider and

100
00:05:06.081 --> 00:05:07.350
be concerned about.

101
00:05:07.350 --> 00:05:10.600
Today with virtual technologies,
especially virtualization,

102
00:05:10.600 --> 00:05:14.890
we don't directly connect to these systems
through a one to one connection, right.

103
00:05:14.890 --> 00:05:17.560
We're not using, even if we're
getting into a virtual machine,

104
00:05:17.560 --> 00:05:21.670
through a KBM of some kind directly at the
rack, right, it's still gonna be a remote

105
00:05:21.670 --> 00:05:25.970
communication that we effectively
are using to connect up to that system.

106
00:05:25.970 --> 00:05:26.740
More often than not,

107
00:05:26.740 --> 00:05:30.370
we're using a console that's opened

108
00:05:30.370 --> 00:05:33.640
We want to know that those console
sessions may or may not be protected,

109
00:05:33.640 --> 00:05:35.720
and again we have to think
about the architecture, and

110
00:05:35.720 --> 00:05:39.250
think about the protocols, and think about
the ways in which we're communicating.

111
00:05:39.250 --> 00:05:40.250
Speaking of protocols,

112
00:05:40.250 --> 00:05:44.925
speaking of architectures, speaking
about the ways in which we communicate.

113
00:05:44.925 --> 00:05:48.815
We want to think about certain topologies
or just generic designs that certain

114
00:05:48.815 --> 00:05:52.685
network systems are gonna have for us and
we want to be able to think about the fact

115
00:05:52.685 --> 00:05:56.515
that these designs, classic though they
are, are important for us to be aware of.

116
00:05:56.515 --> 00:06:01.155
So we're gonna take a few minutes to take
a little guided tour here, if you will,

117
00:06:01.155 --> 00:06:04.308
down into the design area
here of our little workshop.

118
00:06:04.308 --> 00:06:05.679
And we're gonna take a look and

119
00:06:05.679 --> 00:06:09.080
just talk about some of the classic

120
00:06:09.080 --> 00:06:11.260
This first one is gonna be a bus topology.

121
00:06:11.260 --> 00:06:15.770
And what we see on the screen in
front of us is two terminators,

00:06:15.770 --> 00:06:17.920
two connectors on either end, right.

00:06:17.920 --> 00:06:21.920
And we see that in the middle we've got

00:06:21.920 --> 00:06:25.600
connection point for all of the numbered

125
00:06:25.600 --> 00:06:28.870
These are gonna be the workstations,
or endpoints on the bus line.

126
00:06:28.870 --> 00:06:31.870
And all of them are connected up to
the bus and are able to send and

127
00:06:31.870 --> 00:06:34.130
transmit as long as they

128
00:06:34.130 --> 00:06:37.260
You'll connect in other words
through a the whatever we would use,

129
00:06:37.260 --> 00:06:39.220
a network tap or a network connection.

130
00:06:39.220 --> 00:06:41.650
Depending on the nature of
the technology at the time.

131
00:06:41.650 --> 00:06:44.770
But think of it as just
plugging in our computer

132
00:06:44.770 --> 00:06:47.360
directly to the bus line in some way.

133
00:06:47.360 --> 00:06:50.760
A bus is really just a dedicated
connection that exists between two

134
00:06:50.760 --> 00:06:55.080
terminated endpoints that allows us to
effectively be able to communicate.

135
00:06:55.080 --> 00:06:59.380
The challenge of course is with this,
right, if we were to take one of

136
00:06:59.380 --> 00:07:04.260

137
00:07:04.260 --> 00:07:07.430
maybe cutting the orange connection

138
00:07:07.430 --> 00:07:11.320
we may run into a problem because the boss
circuit may now have been broken.

139
00:07:11.320 --> 00:07:14.460
And so the problem would be that
now the other systems that remain

140
00:07:14.460 --> 00:07:16.600
may no longer be able to communicate.

141
00:07:16.600 --> 00:07:20.260
And so you can see that Mike is attempting
to create a cable break there for us,

142
00:07:20.260 --> 00:07:24.715
right and so we could potentially,
effectively disconnect the system.

143
00:07:24.715 --> 00:07:27.112
[LAUGH] This is live TV folks,
remember that.

144
00:07:27.112 --> 00:07:30.600
[LAUGH] So sometimes things work
as planned, other times not so

145
00:07:30.600 --> 00:07:31.520
much, but that's okay.

146
00:07:31.520 --> 00:07:35.410
So, if we have a little break line there
for instance, right, item number 3,

147
00:07:35.410 --> 00:07:38.140
maybe you're experiencing some
sort of trouble communicating.

148
00:07:38.140 --> 00:07:42.745
We now may have a problem with maintaining
the integrity of that bus line.

149
00:07:42.745 --> 00:07:46.300
And all the other systems on there may
be impacted negatively as a result.

150
00:07:46.300 --> 00:07:48.530
If we lose the terminator on either end,

151
00:07:48.530 --> 00:07:51.770
we lose the ability to communicate because
we no longer have a closed system either.

152
00:07:51.770 --> 00:07:52.506
That's also a problem.

153
00:07:52.506 --> 00:07:55.879
If one of the terminators were to fail or
somehow become unavailable,

154
00:07:55.879 --> 00:07:57.730
that could also be an issue.

155
00:07:57.730 --> 00:08:00.456
We have another diagram, if I'm not
mistaken that we're going to go to.

156
00:08:00.456 --> 00:08:03.176
This one is going to be a token ring,
or a ring network,

157
00:08:03.176 --> 00:08:05.080
that we're gonna be taking a look at.

158
00:08:05.080 --> 00:08:06.635
And so, another topology of ring.

159
00:08:06.635 --> 00:08:10.960
It's interesting because,
logically, the ring runs,

160
00:08:10.960 --> 00:08:13.020
or the topology runs, in a ring.

161
00:08:13.020 --> 00:08:17.160
So, when we look at it logically in terms
of the data flow, we see a ring, or

162
00:08:17.160 --> 00:08:18.290
at least we envision a ring.

163
00:08:18.290 --> 00:08:22.625
And we envision a ring that gets situated,
or it gets started up if you will,

164
00:08:22.625 --> 00:08:26.380
initialized, in either clockwise or
counter clockwise rotation.

165
00:08:26.380 --> 00:08:29.450
This ring is rotating clockwise,
as we can see.

166
00:08:29.450 --> 00:08:33.040
At least, if I'm standing correctly and
looking at that properly, it's clockwise.

167
00:08:33.040 --> 00:08:35.050
So, it is a clockwise rotation.

168
00:08:35.050 --> 00:08:37.240
We could have initiated the ring
going counter clockwise.

169
00:08:37.240 --> 00:08:39.990
The arrows would have, obviously,
flipped around and gone the other way.

170
00:08:39.990 --> 00:08:43.410
Rings were only initialized in
one direction at any one time.

171
00:08:43.410 --> 00:08:48.070
It can only transmit either clockwise or
counterclockwise at any one time.

172
00:08:48.070 --> 00:08:50.340
We may have two rings that
are co-terminus with each other,

173
00:08:50.340 --> 00:08:51.830
that run one inside the other.

174
00:08:51.830 --> 00:08:55.060
That would be a FDDI solution,
a fiber ring,

175
00:08:55.060 --> 00:08:57.290
that is used today with
fiber-optic cabling.

176
00:08:57.290 --> 00:09:00.020
And these kinda ring
solutions are still used.

177
00:09:00.020 --> 00:09:03.810
But the updated version of it is
used to wire up entire city cores.

178
00:09:03.810 --> 00:09:06.860
Because now we can transmit over
great distances, kilometers.

179
00:09:06.860 --> 00:09:09.910
And we can have redundancy with the rings
because they are transmitting in

180
00:09:09.910 --> 00:09:10.790
opposite directions.

181
00:09:10.790 --> 00:09:13.250
One is clockwise, one is counterclockwise.

182
00:09:13.250 --> 00:09:16.070
And the rings are then, as a result,
gonna become resilient.

183
00:09:16.070 --> 00:09:17.700
Because if one ring were to fail,

184
00:09:17.700 --> 00:09:20.860
then the transmissions on the other
ring can pick up the slack, in effect.

185
00:09:20.860 --> 00:09:23.680
So, this is kind of a modern
version that we see of token ring.

186
00:09:23.680 --> 00:09:26.290
But the interesting thing about
token ring is that physically,

187
00:09:26.290 --> 00:09:29.292
when you wire it up,
it actually looks like a star topology.

188
00:09:29.292 --> 00:09:32.160
We're gonna take a look at a star
topology here in a couple of minutes.

189
00:09:32.160 --> 00:09:35.220
But the idea behind a star is,
effectively,

190
00:09:35.220 --> 00:09:37.050
that all the endpoints
are gonna be connected up.

191
00:09:37.050 --> 00:09:39.100
And they're gonna be laid out,
not in a circle,

192
00:09:39.100 --> 00:09:42.460
this is not like a duck duck goose
kind of networking topology, but

193
00:09:42.460 --> 00:09:44.920
rather they're wired up to
a central connectivity device.

194
00:09:44.920 --> 00:09:49.160
You can see on the left side of that
diagram there that we see switch.

195
00:09:49.160 --> 00:09:51.550
We've got a bunch of work
stations hanging off it, and

196
00:09:51.550 --> 00:09:53.680
that is going to represent
a star topology.

197
00:09:53.680 --> 00:09:57.100
We've got a bunch of systems connecting
through a common connection point.

198
00:09:57.100 --> 00:09:59.220
In this case, a switch, and allowing for

199
00:09:59.220 --> 00:10:01.870
interchanger exchange of
information between them.

200
00:10:01.870 --> 00:10:06.290
So, token rings, physically, when you
look at them, look like star networks.

201
00:10:06.290 --> 00:10:10.260
But logically, they actually run as
if they were connected in a rings.

202
00:10:10.260 --> 00:10:12.735
It's kind of an interesting
dichotomy there, right?

203
00:10:12.735 --> 00:10:15.484
Because, physically, when you walk into
an office building that would have

204
00:10:15.484 --> 00:10:18.250
been running token ring, the network was
laid out like it was set up as a star.

205
00:10:18.250 --> 00:10:20.030
You would see people in cubes, right?

206
00:10:20.030 --> 00:10:22.105
They weren't sitting in
a circle facing each other.

207
00:10:22.105 --> 00:10:23.480
>> [LAUGH]
>> They would have been in a cube or

208
00:10:23.480 --> 00:10:26.140
something, and they would have
been just set up working normally.

209
00:10:26.140 --> 00:10:27.120
But when you looked under the hood,

210
00:10:27.120 --> 00:10:29.540
you would have found that they were
actually transmitting on a token ring.

211
00:10:29.540 --> 00:10:31.220
So, it would've been kind of
interesting in that respect.

212
00:10:31.220 --> 00:10:33.740
So, we have our star
topology there as well.

213
00:10:33.740 --> 00:10:38.130
And the idea with star, which is kind of
interesting is, as you see on the right,

214
00:10:38.130 --> 00:10:41.430
I believe, item number one kind of has
the orange lines here indicating a break,

215
00:10:41.430 --> 00:10:45.370
in theory, for connectivity
from that endpoint to the star.

216
00:10:45.370 --> 00:10:49.355
As long as the central connection device,
in this case the switch, stays up and

217
00:10:49.355 --> 00:10:52.655
is running, all the other end points 2,
3, and 4 are gonna still be

218
00:10:52.655 --> 00:10:56.945
able to connect to communicate through the
switch, and are not impacted by the fact

219
00:10:56.945 --> 00:10:59.715
that connection point or
unpoint number one goes dark.

220
00:10:59.715 --> 00:11:02.220
So, obviously that's gonna be valuable for
us.

221
00:11:02.220 --> 00:11:04.245
Wanna make sure we're
aware of that as well.

222
00:11:04.245 --> 00:11:05.325
So, we've done a star.

223
00:11:05.325 --> 00:11:06.135
We've done a ring.

224
00:11:06.135 --> 00:11:08.345
We've done a bus as well,
if I'm not mistaken.

225
00:11:08.345 --> 00:11:08.895
Right?

226
00:11:08.895 --> 00:11:10.900
We also have a mesh topology.

227
00:11:10.900 --> 00:11:13.560
And we may have a mesh there,
I believe, if I'm not mistaken.

228
00:11:13.560 --> 00:11:17.030
A mesh is going to look much
like what you see there.

229
00:11:17.030 --> 00:11:18.490
Again, logically,

230
00:11:18.490 --> 00:11:22.330
what we're thinking of is interconnects
from one system to all other systems.

231
00:11:22.330 --> 00:11:26.471
So, we're seeing what looks like a star
design in effect there in the middle of

232
00:11:26.471 --> 00:11:27.043
the mesh.

233
00:11:27.043 --> 00:11:30.387
Because the lower item,
let's say just item number 4 down there,

234
00:11:30.387 --> 00:11:34.609
at the lower left hand corner, is you'll
see connected up to number 1, is connected

235
00:11:34.609 --> 00:11:38.654
out to number 2, is connected over to
number 3, is connected over to number 5,

236
00:11:38.654 --> 00:11:42.210
and has a point coming off it that
connects to every other system.

237
00:11:42.210 --> 00:11:45.080
And all the other systems
are interconnected to each other as well.

238
00:11:45.080 --> 00:11:46.170
And so, in terms of a mesh,

239
00:11:46.170 --> 00:11:50.650
what we're seeing is that every system has
multiple connections to every other one.

240
00:11:50.650 --> 00:11:51.610
Now, this scales.

241
00:11:51.610 --> 00:11:53.420
But it doesn't scale very far, right?

242
00:11:53.420 --> 00:11:56.140
You get 20, 30, 40, 100 machines,
and try to set up a mesh,

243
00:11:56.140 --> 00:11:59.900
you're gonna run out of rubber bands
to wrap all the cables with, right?

244
00:11:59.900 --> 00:12:03.230
Because cable stacks are gonna get so
large, and the interconnects are so

245
00:12:03.230 --> 00:12:06.670
massive, that it's very difficult
to scale this technology

246
00:12:06.670 --> 00:12:08.750
out beyond a very small
number of workstations.

247
00:12:08.750 --> 00:12:12.660
So, while we do see meshes, we see them
really used for very small numbers of

248
00:12:12.660 --> 00:12:18.490
systems, traditionally, to create
redundancy in some very specific topology.

249
00:12:18.490 --> 00:12:22.790
So, for instance, you may see a 911
system that can never go offline,

250
00:12:22.790 --> 00:12:25.960
that has to be triple redundant or
quadruple redundant.

251
00:12:25.960 --> 00:12:28.660
And all the systems may be
interconnected with a mesh

252
00:12:28.660 --> 00:12:32.150
to make sure that no matter where the
failure occurs, those systems stay online.

253
00:12:32.150 --> 00:12:35.240
But we're talking about a very
small finite number of workstations

254
00:12:35.240 --> 00:12:38.650
in terms of the 911 operators and
the interconnects back to the server core.

255
00:12:38.650 --> 00:12:39.520
That kind of thing.

256
00:12:39.520 --> 00:12:41.880
That would be a mesh, traditionally.

257
00:12:41.880 --> 00:12:44.680
And so, we think about these
kinds of topologies, and

258
00:12:44.680 --> 00:12:47.540
we think about the standard,
classic network designs.

259
00:12:47.540 --> 00:12:51.410
We also think about hybrid, or
a star bus topology, right, as well.

260
00:12:51.410 --> 00:12:53.120
And I think we have a diagram for that.

261
00:12:53.120 --> 00:12:56.640
When we have a hybrid topology,
we often think of it as a star bus.

262
00:12:56.640 --> 00:12:59.090
The reality is,
we use the star topology, but

263
00:12:59.090 --> 00:13:02.100
we use a bus to interconnect
the various stars.

264
00:13:02.100 --> 00:13:03.100
So, where would you see this?

265
00:13:03.100 --> 00:13:05.930
If you think about a multistory
office building, for example, where

266
00:13:05.930 --> 00:13:10.250
we're gonna have stars laid out on every
floor, but between the floors we have to

267
00:13:10.250 --> 00:13:13.812
run networking interconnects and conduit
so that we can connect the network up.

268
00:13:13.812 --> 00:13:16.850
We're gonna use bus lines to
connect the stars together.

269
00:13:16.850 --> 00:13:19.290
And so, we often refer to
that as a hybrid network.

270
00:13:19.290 --> 00:13:20.720
And we call it a star bus,

271
00:13:20.720 --> 00:13:23.040
not to be confused with my
favorite place in the world.

272
00:13:23.040 --> 00:13:23.974
Starbucks, right?

273
00:13:23.974 --> 00:13:25.610
>> [LAUGH]
>> It is a star bus network.

274
00:13:25.610 --> 00:13:27.220
So, make sure we're aware of that.

275
00:13:27.220 --> 00:13:30.650
But these are all the different topology
types, right, that we're gonna see and

276
00:13:30.650 --> 00:13:31.920
that we wanna be aware of.

277
00:13:31.920 --> 00:13:34.840
So, just a quick guide there for
you, if you will,

278
00:13:34.840 --> 00:13:37.610
a visual guide to all of the different
network topologies we see.

279
00:13:37.610 --> 00:13:41.190
When we think about network topologies,
we think about the physical design,

280
00:13:41.190 --> 00:13:42.320
the layout of the network.

281
00:13:42.320 --> 00:13:45.140
We also have to think about the different
ways in which we transmit data

282
00:13:45.140 --> 00:13:46.010
across those networks.

283
00:13:46.010 --> 00:13:49.730
This would get into a conversation
quickly about unicast, multicast and

284
00:13:49.730 --> 00:13:51.170
broadcast transmissions.

285
00:13:51.170 --> 00:13:55.220
Unicast transmissions are literally, point
to point between two defined endpoints.

286
00:13:55.220 --> 00:13:57.200
A one to one communication.

287
00:13:57.200 --> 00:14:01.700
So, if Mike and I are having conversation
without anybody else being involved, and

288
00:14:01.700 --> 00:14:03.820
I say, Mike,
have you heard about this or that?

289
00:14:03.820 --> 00:14:06.060
And Mike says, Adam, yeah,
absolutely that's kinda cool.

290
00:14:06.060 --> 00:14:07.820
We're talking to each other directly.

291
00:14:07.820 --> 00:14:10.030
That's an example of
a unicast transmission.

292
00:14:10.030 --> 00:14:12.110
Think of picking up the phone and
calling somebody, right?

293
00:14:12.110 --> 00:14:14.750
It's also a good example
of a unicast transmission.

294
00:14:14.750 --> 00:14:17.640
Multicast transmissions
are one to a group.

295
00:14:17.640 --> 00:14:21.790
So, I send out a communication, but
I send it to a well defined group.

296
00:14:21.790 --> 00:14:23.530
And it's by invitation only,
in effect, right?

297
00:14:23.530 --> 00:14:25.018
May be subscription based.

298
00:14:25.018 --> 00:14:26.630
Maybe membership based.

299
00:14:26.630 --> 00:14:28.210
So, think of ITPro TV.

300
00:14:28.210 --> 00:14:32.420
Good example of multicasting in the sense
that, if you pay your membership fee

301
00:14:32.420 --> 00:14:35.990
every month, right, and then you're able
to access all the content in the library.

302
00:14:35.990 --> 00:14:37.080
You're a member.

303
00:14:37.080 --> 00:14:40.280
You are, then, part of the multicast
group that gets that content.

304
00:14:40.280 --> 00:14:43.560
If you're not a member, you may get
access to some of the demos, but

305
00:14:43.560 --> 00:14:46.040
you're not gonna obviously see
all the full-featured content

306
00:14:46.040 --> 00:14:47.470
that we provide to all of our members.

307
00:14:47.470 --> 00:14:49.810
So, this is an example of multicasting.

308
00:14:49.810 --> 00:14:52.340
We tend to use multicasting for
streaming media.

309
00:14:52.340 --> 00:14:54.090
We use it for desktop imaging.

310
00:14:54.090 --> 00:14:56.990
We use it for situations where we
have to be a member of a group.

311
00:14:56.990 --> 00:14:59.700
We then receive information
based on that membership.

312
00:14:59.700 --> 00:15:02.465
Broadcast transmission
is one to everybody.

313
00:15:02.465 --> 00:15:03.415
Walk into a room,

314
00:15:03.415 --> 00:15:07.815
stand up on the table, scream at the top
of your lungs, that's a broadcast.

315
00:15:07.815 --> 00:15:09.565
Whether everybody in the room
wants to hear you or

316
00:15:09.565 --> 00:15:13.685
not, is interested in what you have to
say, wants what you are talking about

317
00:15:13.685 --> 00:15:17.047
to be part of their world, they're gonna
hear it, whether they want it or not.

318
00:15:17.047 --> 00:15:17.757
That's a broadcast.

319
00:15:17.757 --> 00:15:19.057
They could choose to ignore it.

320
00:15:19.057 --> 00:15:21.837
But they're gonna be there and be present
for it whether they would like to or not.

321
00:15:21.837 --> 00:15:22.557
That's a broadcast.

322
00:15:22.557 --> 00:15:24.527
So, unicast, one to one.

323
00:15:24.527 --> 00:15:25.957
Multicast, one to a group.

324
00:15:25.957 --> 00:15:30.277
Broadcast, one to everybody, or one to
anybody within distance, if you will.

325
00:15:30.277 --> 00:15:32.567
Typically, within the sudden
of the broadcast domain

326
00:15:32.567 --> 00:15:33.827
is what the broadcast represents.

327
00:15:33.827 --> 00:15:37.627
Because broadcast transmissions
are traditionally not propagated,

328
00:15:37.627 --> 00:15:41.430
not routed beyond the router to prevent
what are known as broadcast storms.

329
00:15:41.430 --> 00:15:44.350
Now, there are certain
special exceptions to that.

330
00:15:44.350 --> 00:15:48.300
We do see bootstrap traffic being used and
propagated out beyond the router.

331
00:15:48.300 --> 00:15:52.290
So, for instance, DHCP broadcast
messages are propagated through routers.

332
00:15:52.290 --> 00:15:55.629
Because the special use of the protocol
and the ways we implement it.

333
00:15:55.629 --> 00:15:59.003
But out beyond that we don't typically
tend to transmit broadcasts out beyond

334
00:15:59.003 --> 00:16:00.035
our routed interface.

335
00:16:00.035 --> 00:16:03.170
So, just wanna think about that and
be aware of that as well.

336
00:16:03.170 --> 00:16:04.700
We also wanna talk about switch networks.

337
00:16:04.700 --> 00:16:08.150
And switch networks are gonna be the way
in which we actually move information back

338
00:16:08.150 --> 00:16:08.910
and forth.

339
00:16:08.910 --> 00:16:11.640
We can have circuit switching or
packet switching networks.

340
00:16:11.640 --> 00:16:15.850
Circuit switch networks dedicate or create
dedicated circuits between endpoints.

341
00:16:15.850 --> 00:16:19.460
These are basically going to be set up and
are going to be on all the time, and

342
00:16:19.460 --> 00:16:21.220
they're always available for us.

343
00:16:21.220 --> 00:16:24.440
Packet switch networks, data is
divided into packets, it's chunked.

344
00:16:24.440 --> 00:16:28.880
And transmitted over a shared network, so
a circuit switch network creates dedicated

345
00:16:28.880 --> 00:16:33.000
transmission connections that are
basically used for you in all your data.

346
00:16:33.000 --> 00:16:34.540
But they're exclusive to you.

347
00:16:34.540 --> 00:16:37.590
Packet switch networks are gonna
send all your packetized data

348
00:16:37.590 --> 00:16:40.910
across a common network mixed with
all other data from all other people.

349
00:16:40.910 --> 00:16:43.790
Think of the Internet as being the largest
packet switch network in the world,

350
00:16:43.790 --> 00:16:44.990
the World Wide Web.

351
00:16:44.990 --> 00:16:47.580
Think of circuit switch networks as
being networks that are dedicated

352
00:16:47.580 --> 00:16:49.040
communication channels.

353
00:16:49.040 --> 00:16:54.460
So think, for instance,
about maybe a tunnel between you and

354
00:16:54.460 --> 00:16:56.410
ultimately an endpoint that
you wanna communicate with.

355
00:16:56.410 --> 00:16:59.850
That's not quite an example of a circuit
switch network but it's kinda like that.

356
00:16:59.850 --> 00:17:04.880
A better example would be buying a
dedicated T1 line or dedicated OCS circuit

357
00:17:04.880 --> 00:17:08.790
enabling that as a point to point
between two known endpoints.

358
00:17:08.790 --> 00:17:11.870
That will be an example of a circuit
switch network that's dedicated to your

359
00:17:11.870 --> 00:17:13.120
particular needs.

360
00:17:13.120 --> 00:17:15.132
And then, we also have what
are called virtual circuits.

361
00:17:15.132 --> 00:17:17.220
We have what are known as
permanent virtual circuits.

362
00:17:17.220 --> 00:17:18.210
PVCs.

363
00:17:18.210 --> 00:17:21.098
These are established and
always there in effect always on.

364
00:17:21.098 --> 00:17:23.270
Or we have what are known
switch virtual circuits.

365
00:17:23.270 --> 00:17:24.150
SVCs.

366
00:17:24.150 --> 00:17:27.930
These are on demand, you initialize
the circuit when you have to send.

367
00:17:27.930 --> 00:17:30.760
You send it out based on the best
available path at the time.

368
00:17:30.760 --> 00:17:34.010
You tear it down when you're done and then
you no longer have to worry about that, so

369
00:17:34.010 --> 00:17:36.200
that's what's known as a switch,
a virtual circuit.

370
00:17:36.200 --> 00:17:38.820
So we have both dedicated and
switched systems.

371
00:17:38.820 --> 00:17:43.210
Excuse me, dedicated and virtual solutions
that you can use so be aware of that.

372
00:17:43.210 --> 00:17:46.910
We also have to talk about access control
but not from the traditional perspective

373
00:17:46.910 --> 00:17:49.210
we think about,
that's gonna be coming up in domain five.

374
00:17:49.210 --> 00:17:53.960
What we have to think about rather is
how we monitor on the wire for the send.

375
00:17:53.960 --> 00:17:57.270
And or the send request that's
gonna happen to transmit.

376
00:17:57.270 --> 00:18:00.629
And what happens if we have a collision
and we have to then monitor what's

377
00:18:00.629 --> 00:18:04.209
happening on the cable to ensure that,
that data collision is not gonna get in

378
00:18:04.209 --> 00:18:08.036
the way other communications and that we
resend the data when we actually need to.

379
00:18:08.036 --> 00:18:12.400
So this is actually known as carrier sense
multiple access, or what's known as CSMA.

380
00:18:13.710 --> 00:18:17.680
CSMA, generically, is this idea of
controlling access to the cable,

381
00:18:17.680 --> 00:18:19.510
to the send or transmission media.

382
00:18:19.510 --> 00:18:21.640
So that way,
we don't wind up with data collisions.

383
00:18:21.640 --> 00:18:25.190
And we don't wind up with problems
that prevent us from transmitting.

384
00:18:25.190 --> 00:18:28.060
But what we have to talk about
are the two specific variations.

385
00:18:28.060 --> 00:18:32.050
CSMACA, carrier sense multiple
access collision avoidance, and

386
00:18:32.050 --> 00:18:36.400
CSMACD, carrier sense multiple
access collision detection.

387
00:18:36.400 --> 00:18:40.120
Carrier sense multiple access
collision avoidance, CA,

388
00:18:40.120 --> 00:18:43.150
is always gonna be used
with wireless technologies.

389
00:18:43.150 --> 00:18:47.020
Carrier sense multiple access collision
detection, CD, is always associated with

390
00:18:47.020 --> 00:18:50.340
wired technologies,
Ethernet-based networks that are wired.

391
00:18:50.340 --> 00:18:52.420
So let's talk about
collision detection first.

392
00:18:52.420 --> 00:18:56.460
Collision detection allows us
to listen to the wire, listen or

393
00:18:56.460 --> 00:19:00.200
monitor to the cable or
on the wire for the scent.

394
00:19:00.200 --> 00:19:01.100
Now, how do we do that?

395
00:19:01.100 --> 00:19:02.410
Think about the logic of this.

396
00:19:02.410 --> 00:19:05.710
We're listening to a copper wire,
where in effect we'll be monitoring it

397
00:19:05.710 --> 00:19:08.050
to see if there's any data
transmitter to cross it.

398
00:19:08.050 --> 00:19:12.070
Well, we know that we send data on
a copper wire with electrical impulses,

399
00:19:12.070 --> 00:19:14.630
electrical pulses,
little pulses of electricity.

400
00:19:14.630 --> 00:19:16.020
Not enough to hurt you, but

401
00:19:16.020 --> 00:19:19.050
enough to register voltage
transmitting across the copper wire.

402
00:19:19.050 --> 00:19:21.190
Copper's a great conductor
of electricity so

403
00:19:21.190 --> 00:19:23.390
we can send it down the wire very easily.

404
00:19:23.390 --> 00:19:28.380
As a result, every network card is going
to be able to effectively sense the spike

405
00:19:28.380 --> 00:19:30.840
or the change in voltage
status on the wire.

406
00:19:30.840 --> 00:19:34.760
When there's a spike, there's voltage on
the wire, we know somebody's transmitting.

407
00:19:34.760 --> 00:19:37.750
When there's no spike, there's no voltage
on the wire, nobody's transmitting.

408
00:19:37.750 --> 00:19:40.210
It's a very straightforward
system when you think about it.

409
00:19:40.210 --> 00:19:43.940
As a result of that collision detection
allows everybody all the endpoints

410
00:19:43.940 --> 00:19:48.100
on the system to monitor for
effectively the voltage change.

411
00:19:48.100 --> 00:19:48.840
If we see or

412
00:19:48.840 --> 00:19:52.670
hear a voltage change occurring we know
that some thing is trying to transmit.

413
00:19:52.670 --> 00:19:56.260
Well, if they're trying to transmit we're
probably gonna wait and not transmit so

414
00:19:56.260 --> 00:19:57.720
that way we don't have a collision.

415

00:20:43.850 --> 00:20:47.980

00:20:47.980 --> 00:20:48.610

00:20:48.610 --> 00:20:51.650

00:20:51.650 --> 00:20:55.460

00:20:55.460 --> 00:20:58.270

00:20:58.270 --> 00:21:01.890

00:21:01.890 --> 00:21:06.150

00:21:06.150 --> 00:21:09.050

00:21:09.050 --> 00:21:12.656
Both parties resending, we're gonna keep
having collisions, this is a problem.

443
00:21:12.656 --> 00:21:15.290
What we have to do is,
both of us have to step back.

444
00:21:15.290 --> 00:21:17.100
We have to stop transmitting and

445
00:21:17.100 --> 00:21:20.520
one of us has to transmit before the other
in order to make sure that our data gets

446
00:21:20.520 --> 00:21:24.000
to where it's going before something
else gets on the wire and interrupts it.

447
00:21:24.000 --> 00:21:27.680
Because we can't really have multiple data
packets existing in the same space at

00:21:27.680 --> 00:21:28.830
the same time.

00:21:28.830 --> 00:21:31.520

00:21:31.520 --> 00:21:32.700
So we use an offset.

00:21:32.700 --> 00:21:37.110
We actually use a timing algorithm

00:21:37.110 --> 00:21:39.230
a millisecond offset, whatever that is.

00:21:39.230 --> 00:21:41.630
Five milliseconds, ten milliseconds,

00:21:41.630 --> 00:21:44.210

00:21:44.210 --> 00:21:47.130
It just depends on the nature of

00:21:47.130 --> 00:21:49.500

00:21:49.500 --> 00:21:51.280
Both parties will step

00:21:58.150 --> 00:22:00.380

00:22:00.380 --> 00:22:04.790
I'll resend as long as my send is

00:22:04.790 --> 00:22:05.810
there's no collision.

00:22:05.810 --> 00:22:08.610
I don't detect it,

00:22:08.610 --> 00:22:10.730

00:22:10.730 --> 00:22:14.010

00:22:14.010 --> 00:22:17.770

are then gonna be having to effectively

00:22:17.770 --> 00:22:22.210
yield resends on a collision detection

00:22:22.210 --> 00:22:25.280
