00:22:25.280 --> 00:22:27.090
Collision avoidance works.

00:22:27.090 --> 00:22:28.640
In a slightly different way.

00:22:28.640 --> 00:22:31.980

00:22:43.500 --> 00:22:44.523
Because remember,

00:22:50.050 --> 00:22:53.320
No way to transmit and see that

481
00:22:53.320 --> 00:22:56.340
We get wireless transmissions,
but that's not the same thing.

00:22:56.340 --> 00:22:59.670
And so, what we do in CA,

00:22:59.670 --> 00:23:02.170

00:23:02.170 --> 00:23:06.520

00:23:06.520 --> 00:23:11.050

00:23:11.050 --> 00:23:15.790

00:23:19.120 --> 00:23:20.740

00:23:20.740 --> 00:23:24.591

00:23:24.591 --> 00:23:26.765

00:23:26.765 --> 00:23:28.915
It's a very civil, very genteel.

00:23:28.915 --> 00:23:32.040
>> [LAUGH]

00:23:32.040 --> 00:23:35.010
So as a result of that, what happens is

00:23:35.010 --> 00:23:38.650
we send out a request to be able to
effectively get permission to transmit.

00:23:38.650 --> 00:23:42.110
If nobody objects,

00:23:42.110 --> 00:23:43.550

00:23:43.550 --> 00:23:45.020

00:23:45.020 --> 00:23:47.390
And then, we do our thing, and

00:23:47.390 --> 00:23:50.240

00:23:50.240 --> 00:23:52.410

00:23:52.410 --> 00:23:55.100

00:23:55.100 --> 00:23:58.580

00:23:58.580 --> 00:23:59.250

00:23:59.250 --> 00:24:02.695

00:24:02.695 --> 00:24:05.580

00:24:05.580 --> 00:24:06.720

00:24:06.720 --> 00:24:10.710

00:24:10.710 --> 00:24:12.450

00:24:13.490 --> 00:24:16.180

00:24:16.180 --> 00:24:19.660

00:24:19.660 --> 00:24:22.270

a E-carrier, may have an optical carrier,

642
00:30:19.020 --> 00:30:20.622
I mentioned OCS earlier.

643
00:30:20.622 --> 00:30:23.874
So T-carrier's a very popular prevalent
within North America, for instance,

644
00:30:23.874 --> 00:30:25.014
it's in the United States.

645
00:30:25.014 --> 00:30:30.540
We'll talk about a T1, T2, T3 as being the
level of bandwidth we'll get from an ISP.

646
00:30:30.540 --> 00:30:36.400
A T1's approximately about 1.4, 5, almost
1.5 megs about 1, 1.5 megs approximately.

647
00:30:36.400 --> 00:30:38.880
A T3 is gonna be significantly
higher than that,

648
00:30:38.880 --> 00:30:42.990
about 45 megs approximately as we
link multiple T-carriers together.

649
00:30:42.990 --> 00:30:45.700
So the idea is that we're talking
about a dedicated amount of bandwidth.

650
00:30:45.700 --> 00:30:48.951
In Europe, which is where E-carriers
are traditionally gonna be found and

651
00:30:48.951 --> 00:30:51.459
prevalent, we have a slightly
different way of ranking.

652
00:30:51.459 --> 00:30:53.520
An E1 is going to be close to a T1.

653
00:30:53.520 --> 00:30:56.650
It's about 2 megs approximately,
about just over 2 megs.

654
00:30:56.650 --> 00:31:00.780
And then a T3, or excuse me,
a T3 versus an E3 is going to be a very,

655
00:31:00.780 --> 00:31:02.370
very different scenario.

656
00:31:02.370 --> 00:31:03.990
So it's not really that important for

657
00:31:03.990 --> 00:31:07.900
you to necessarily know all the bandwidth
requirements on a T1 versus an E1.

658
00:31:07.900 --> 00:31:11.020
But it is important for
you to differentiate that a T-carrier

659
00:31:11.020 --> 00:31:14.820
is going to be a North American, typically
a US-centric way of dealing with bandwidth

660
00:31:14.820 --> 00:31:19.030
from a provider, whereas an E-carrier is
a European-centric way of identifying and

661
00:31:19.030 --> 00:31:20.270
dealing with bandwidth from a carrier.

662
00:31:20.270 --> 00:31:22.300
So I just want to make
sure we're aware of that.

663
00:31:22.300 --> 00:31:24.430
Those of you that may be in other
parts of the world, in other words,

664
00:31:24.430 --> 00:31:25.490
we don't want you to feel left out.

665
00:31:26.945 --> 00:31:29.980
Optical carrier networks
are gonna be dedicated high-speed

666
00:31:29.980 --> 00:31:33.270
bandwidth that a service provider
will sell to you and provide to you.

667
00:31:33.270 --> 00:31:36.136
This could go up as say
as hundreds of megabytes.

668
00:31:36.136 --> 00:31:38.261
Or excuse me, hundreds of megabytes,
that's gonna be really fast.

669
00:31:38.261 --> 00:31:38.877
>> Smoking.

670
00:31:38.877 --> 00:31:39.709
>> Smoking fast.

671
00:31:39.709 --> 00:31:41.462
>> [LAUGH]
>> Hundreds of gigabytes,

672
00:31:41.462 --> 00:31:44.329
if my mind was operating at gigabyte
speed before my mouth engaged,

673
00:31:44.329 --> 00:31:47.820
we wouldn't have as many of these little
oopsies as we're talking about things.

674
00:31:47.820 --> 00:31:52.290
Optical carrier networks can get up to
hundred of gigabytes in speed, very,

675
00:31:52.290 --> 00:31:52.994
very fast.

676
00:31:52.994 --> 00:31:54.590
You're buying very high speed,

677
00:31:54.590 --> 00:31:58.181
very large amounts of data on dedicated
bandwidth And dedicated provision

678
00:31:58.181 --> 00:32:01.615
circuits from a provider when you're
dealing with optical carriers.

679
00:32:01.615 --> 00:32:04.480
So you may get very,
very large volumes of data in other words.

680
00:32:04.480 --> 00:32:06.370
So you just want to be
thinking about that as well.

681
00:32:06.370 --> 00:32:09.482
We also have older technologies that
maybe use things like frame relay.

682
00:32:09.482 --> 00:32:10.459
Remember frame relay?

683
00:32:10.459 --> 00:32:11.570
ATM.

684
00:32:11.570 --> 00:32:13.040
Not the kind where you go and

685
00:32:13.040 --> 00:32:16.560
get money out of the bank but
asynchronous transfer mode technologies.

686
00:32:16.560 --> 00:32:20.030
This was gonna basically divide
data up into 53 byte cells.

687
00:32:20.030 --> 00:32:22.040
It's what ATM technology would do.

688
00:32:22.040 --> 00:32:25.390
We used a fixed length for
that technology transfer.

689
00:32:25.390 --> 00:32:28.625
Pretty fast, up to about 150 or
so megabytes.

690
00:32:28.625 --> 00:32:31.623
When I say fast and megabytes,
what I'm saying is at the time,

691
00:32:31.623 --> 00:32:34.405
this technology was really prevalent and
was being used.

692
00:32:34.405 --> 00:32:38.630
150 or 155 megabytes of transmission
speed was very, very fast.

693
00:32:38.630 --> 00:32:41.290
It is still very fast
on the back end plane,

694
00:32:41.290 --> 00:32:44.070
because most of our networks transmit
at gigabit speeds internally,

695
00:32:44.070 --> 00:32:46.880
but when we get out on the Internet,
they transmit much slower.

696
00:32:46.880 --> 00:32:48.070
Which is why you tend to have to wait for

697
00:32:48.070 --> 00:32:51.000
things to show up, cuz it's not
always as fast as you would think.

698
00:32:51.000 --> 00:32:54.910
But a frame relay network is gonna be
a network that's made up of the carrier

699
00:32:54.910 --> 00:32:58.550
provider switches linked together,
that's gonna rely on typically TCP

700
00:32:58.550 --> 00:33:01.320
based protocols to do error connection and
control.

701
00:33:01.320 --> 00:33:04.400
So a lot of the carrier providers
are using frame or ATM.

702
00:33:04.400 --> 00:33:07.930
Now the other key thing that we wanna just
mention quickly here is software defined

703
00:33:07.930 --> 00:33:11.850
networking which is a big technology
that we're hearing a lot about today.

704
00:33:11.850 --> 00:33:14.871
Software defining anything today,
software defining networks,

705
00:33:14.871 --> 00:33:17.892
software defining shortage,
software defining the data center,

706
00:33:17.892 --> 00:33:20.025
all of this implies two
very important things.

707
00:33:20.025 --> 00:33:24.931
Software defining implies configuration
based on some sort of software file so

708
00:33:24.931 --> 00:33:26.915
a config file, an answer file.

709
00:33:26.915 --> 00:33:30.482
And it implies automation to be able
to provision quickly and to use that

710
00:33:30.482 --> 00:33:34.168
answer file to effectively create
the opportunity for us to provision and

711
00:33:34.168 --> 00:33:37.750
therefore to manage whatever
the infrastructure is that we wanna use.

712
00:33:37.750 --> 00:33:41.550
When we think about software defining
networking, we're thinking about an SDN,

713
00:33:41.550 --> 00:33:43.710
a software defined network controller.

714
00:33:43.710 --> 00:33:46.370
You can think of this as
the brains of the operation.

715
00:33:46.370 --> 00:33:49.665
The controller is gonna use
two specific control elements.

716
00:33:49.665 --> 00:33:54.070
What's called a northbound API and
a southbound API.

717
00:33:54.070 --> 00:33:56.710
The southbound API or
the southbound interface,

718
00:33:56.710 --> 00:33:59.900
it's sometimes called an interface but
often called an API.

719
00:33:59.900 --> 00:34:04.000
But the southbound implies direction
going down from the controller,

720
00:34:04.000 --> 00:34:08.170
into the networking stack itself,
into the networking elements.

721
00:34:08.170 --> 00:34:10.120
The routers, the switches, etc.

722
00:34:10.120 --> 00:34:14.500
To implement configuration and
control at the networking layer.

723
00:34:14.500 --> 00:34:18.410
The northbound API and the northbound
interface implies going up in direction.

724
00:34:18.410 --> 00:34:22.830
This implies going up in to the user and
the application business logic here

725
00:34:22.830 --> 00:34:25.740
to be able to interact with
the configuration information and

726
00:34:25.740 --> 00:34:29.200
provisioning we need, that the application
needs in order to consume data.

727
00:34:30.370 --> 00:34:33.900
So software defined networking
implies interacting with and linking

728
00:34:33.900 --> 00:34:38.910
the application of the user data through
a control interface in to the networking.

729
00:34:38.910 --> 00:34:41.110
And the actual configuration
that takes place there.

730
00:34:41.110 --> 00:34:44.720
Through northbound and southbound APIs
through a common control interface.

731
00:34:44.720 --> 00:34:46.490
So we often talk about
an application layer.

732
00:34:46.490 --> 00:34:48.780
And the northbound API addresses that.

733
00:34:48.780 --> 00:34:50.320
We talk about the control layer.

734
00:34:50.320 --> 00:34:52.570
That's where the software
defined controller is.

735
00:34:52.570 --> 00:34:54.400
And we talk about an infrastructure layer.

736
00:34:54.400 --> 00:34:56.023
That it's the southbound API's business.

737
00:34:56.023 --> 00:34:58.836
That's where the infrastructure
is created and managed.

738
00:34:58.836 --> 00:35:01.130
It's where we actually connect to
the routing and the switching.

739
00:35:01.130 --> 00:35:03.610
So this is how software
defined networking is set up.

740
00:35:03.610 --> 00:35:05.619
And this is ultimately how we can,

741
00:35:05.619 --> 00:35:09.580
not only as I said, provision and
very quickly spin up technology.

742
00:35:09.580 --> 00:35:11.722
But we can actually automate
the provisioning and

743
00:35:11.722 --> 00:35:14.527
automate the control of that
technology through answer files and

744
00:35:14.527 --> 00:35:18.250
through what we will call workflow or
configuration management.

745
00:35:18.250 --> 00:35:19.340
>> All right, very good Adam,

746
00:35:19.340 --> 00:35:22.730
there's a lot of stuff that goes into
securing your communication channels.

747
00:35:22.730 --> 00:35:24.090
A lot of different channels.

748
00:35:24.090 --> 00:35:25.640
Really depends on
the technology you're using.

749
00:35:25.640 --> 00:35:28.090
We had a great look it from
the past to the present,

750
00:35:28.090 --> 00:35:30.180
kind of a glimpse into
where we might be heading.

751
00:35:30.180 --> 00:35:31.438
So appreciate that Adam.

752
00:35:31.438 --> 00:35:35.162
Remember if you guys wanna
sit in one of Adam's classes,

753
00:35:35.162 --> 00:35:37.730
send us an email SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

754
00:35:37.730 --> 00:35:38.670
That's gonna do it for this one.

755
00:35:38.670 --> 00:35:40.110
Signing off, I'm Mike Roderick.

756
00:35:41.210 --> 00:35:41.730
>> Oh, wait.

757
00:35:41.730 --> 00:35:42.370
That's me, yeah.

758
00:35:42.370 --> 00:35:44.190
I'm Adam Gordon, I forgot.

759
00:35:44.190 --> 00:35:45.200
We'll see you soon.

760
00:35:45.200 --> 00:35:45.880
It's been a long day.

761
00:35:45.880 --> 00:35:46.500
We'll see you soon.

00:35:46.500 --> 00:35:47.302
Come on back.

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike discuss ways to secure network communications to mitigate many network attacks. They talk about the importance of defense in depth. They also define the four phases of an attack. Then they capture some traffic to analyze.
episodes.title: Mitigate Network Attacks
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:07.548
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.548 --> 00:00:16.070
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.070 --> 00:00:17.270
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:17.270 --> 00:00:19.158
Today we're doing our CISSP.

5
00:00:19.158 --> 00:00:20.588
And specifically in this one,

6
00:00:20.588 --> 00:00:23.550
we're going to be looking at
mitigating network attacks.

7
00:00:23.550 --> 00:00:25.460
We've talked a lot about networks,

8
00:00:25.460 --> 00:00:29.040
we've talked a lot about the attacks
that can occur over these networks so

9
00:00:29.040 --> 00:00:32.710
that we better understand what
those bad guys are trying to do.

10
00:00:32.710 --> 00:00:36.760
It's important that we know how to try to
defend ourselves against these attacks as

11
00:00:36.760 --> 00:00:40.460
well and Mr. Adam Gordon here is
gonna help us through that we hope.

12
00:00:40.460 --> 00:00:41.430
How you doing, Adam?

13
00:00:41.430 --> 00:00:46.520
>> I am good, I am feeling attack
worthy today so exciting stuff.

14
00:00:46.520 --> 00:00:50.270
When we think about defending ourselves
against attacks we've often talked about

15
00:00:50.270 --> 00:00:53.020
the three pillars of information
security management.

16
00:00:53.020 --> 00:00:55.430
I want to remind ourselves of them,
right, what are they?

17
00:00:55.430 --> 00:01:00.040
Confidentiality, very important, keeping
information secret keeping it secure.

18
00:01:00.040 --> 00:01:03.330
Integrity, ensuring information is not
compromised without our knowledge,

19
00:01:03.330 --> 00:01:04.560
without our consent.

20
00:01:04.560 --> 00:01:08.020
And availability, making sure that
information is going to be there and

21
00:01:08.020 --> 00:01:11.572
available to be able to be used when and
where necessary.

22
00:01:11.572 --> 00:01:14.420
So I want to start our conversations
here by thinking about this.

23
00:01:14.420 --> 00:01:17.850
When we think about preventing or
mitigating network security attacks or

24
00:01:17.850 --> 00:01:21.725
preventing or mitigating network
concerns with network security.

25
00:01:21.725 --> 00:01:25.130
We want to make sure that we are thinking
about what it is we are focusing on,

26
00:01:25.130 --> 00:01:28.550
the things that impact confidentiality,
things that impact availability,

27
00:01:28.550 --> 00:01:31.190
things that impact integrity
are our goal here.

28
00:01:31.190 --> 00:01:32.380
Minimize those.

29
00:01:32.380 --> 00:01:34.810
And as a result, maximize security.

30
00:01:34.810 --> 00:01:38.540
Defense in depth is the order of the day,
we talked about this in other episodes.

31
00:01:38.540 --> 00:01:41.490
Creating a defense in depth architecture

32
00:01:41.490 --> 00:01:46.800
is really about making sure ultimately
that we are going to be able to

33
00:01:46.800 --> 00:01:51.120
ensure that we have mutually-reinforcing
concentric rings of protection.

34
00:01:51.120 --> 00:01:54.310
And when we do that and we're able to
do that, hopefully successfully and

35
00:01:54.310 --> 00:01:57.130
well, we're gonna architect
a solution that would allow us, for

36
00:01:57.130 --> 00:02:01.160
instance, to be able to put
boundary routers on our border.

37
00:02:01.160 --> 00:02:06.570
We're gonna put firewalls with NAT
capabilities there along with our routers.

38
00:02:06.570 --> 00:02:10.970
We're gonna run an IDS and or an IPS
solution along with them and in addition,

39
00:02:10.970 --> 00:02:12.680
stepping back let's say maybe three or

40
00:02:12.680 --> 00:02:17.840
four layers from there, we're then gonna
also be using multi-factor access control.

41
00:02:17.840 --> 00:02:21.370
We're gonna be using a RADIUS
device to allow inbound

42
00:02:21.370 --> 00:02:24.090
remote access to be monitored and proxied.

43
00:02:24.090 --> 00:02:25.110
We're gonna go ahead and

44
00:02:25.110 --> 00:02:29.000
use certificates to be able to
authenticate individuals uniquely.

45
00:02:29.000 --> 00:02:32.380
We're going to in addition not
only do all those things, but

46
00:02:32.380 --> 00:02:35.270
we're also gonna go ahead and we're gonna
ensure that we're up to date with all of

47
00:02:35.270 --> 00:02:37.780
our patch management on
all of our endpoints.

48
00:02:37.780 --> 00:02:40.380
We're gonna make sure that we've
hardened all of our hosts,

49
00:02:40.380 --> 00:02:44.840
stripping out all unnecessary software,
all unnecessary services.

50
00:02:44.840 --> 00:02:48.410
We're gonna make sure that we
are encrypting all traffic in transit and

51
00:02:48.410 --> 00:02:49.520
at rest.

52
00:02:49.520 --> 00:02:53.270
And I could go on and on, right, but
the idea is that by adding in all of these

53
00:02:53.270 --> 00:02:58.300
layers of capabilities and mutually
reinforcing each other with these layers,

54
00:02:58.300 --> 00:03:00.210
we're gonna create a defense
in depth solution.

55
00:03:00.210 --> 00:03:04.790
An architecture that hopefully is gonna
put security first and is also gonna

56
00:03:04.790 --> 00:03:09.670
prevent bad actors from gaining access
all the way in to the infrastructure.

57
00:03:09.670 --> 00:03:13.550
In other words, they may get past
the boundary router, they may get past

58
00:03:13.550 --> 00:03:17.620
the firewall, but are they gonna get
past the other 25 things on that list?

59
00:03:17.620 --> 00:03:18.470
Yeah, they may or they may not.

60
00:03:18.470 --> 00:03:21.100
It really just depends on how dedicated
they are and how good we are.

61
00:03:21.100 --> 00:03:24.040
But the point is the more things we
put between us and the bad people,

62
00:03:24.040 --> 00:03:27.810
the less likely it is the bad people will
get all the way through to touch us, and

63
00:03:27.810 --> 00:03:29.230
get to our information.

64
00:03:29.230 --> 00:03:31.150
And if that's the case, that's what
we really have to think about and

65
00:03:31.150 --> 00:03:32.030
what we wanna strive for.

66
00:03:32.030 --> 00:03:34.549
So defense in depth, very,
very important solution.

67
00:03:35.680 --> 00:03:37.400
We showed you in one
of our prior episodes,

68
00:03:37.400 --> 00:03:40.740
Mike was kind enough to help me out with
this, we put up a network sniffer and

69
00:03:40.740 --> 00:03:42.550
showed you what Ethereal was capable of.

70
00:03:42.550 --> 00:03:45.833
Really Wireshark, but I just prefer
saying Ethereal because that's how I know

71
00:03:45.833 --> 00:03:47.360
the product when I started using it.

72
00:03:47.360 --> 00:03:49.950
When I grew with it it
was called Ethereal.

73
00:03:49.950 --> 00:03:51.150
It sad that it's not there more.

74
00:03:51.150 --> 00:03:52.645
I should shed a tear.

75
00:03:52.645 --> 00:03:54.280
>> [LAUGH]
>> Perhaps we'll have a candle or

76
00:03:54.280 --> 00:03:56.220
a wake for it at some point later.

77
00:03:56.220 --> 00:03:59.230
But for now, we'll simply just
refer to it as Wireshark.

78
00:03:59.230 --> 00:04:02.580
When we talk about sniffing,
we're talking about being able to

79
00:04:02.580 --> 00:04:05.760
effectively capture all the packets
that run across our network.

80
00:04:05.760 --> 00:04:07.530
It's kind of interesting
how sniffing works, right?

81
00:04:07.530 --> 00:04:09.910
Because we have to do what's
called putting the network card,

82
00:04:09.910 --> 00:04:12.100
the interface, into promiscuous mode.

83
00:04:12.100 --> 00:04:13.990
It's pretty important to think about,
right?

84
00:04:13.990 --> 00:04:16.840
So when we think about something
being in promiscuous mode,

85
00:04:16.840 --> 00:04:20.110
what we think about it doing is
effectively being able to examine and

86
00:04:20.110 --> 00:04:23.290
get copies of everything that
comes across that interface.

87
00:04:23.290 --> 00:04:26.900
I mentioned when we did that OSI
model conversation in that episode

88
00:04:26.900 --> 00:04:30.280
that at the physical layer we examine and

89
00:04:30.280 --> 00:04:33.830
pull all the traffic up through
the physical layer in to the data link

90
00:04:33.830 --> 00:04:37.170
layer and then actually examine
the packets at the data link layer.

91
00:04:37.170 --> 00:04:40.260
If we're running the model
from the physical layer up,

92
00:04:40.260 --> 00:04:42.890
we're seeing traffic transmitted into
the system instead of traffic being

93
00:04:42.890 --> 00:04:44.610
transmitted out of the system.

94
00:04:44.610 --> 00:04:46.810
When we see it coming in,
we go to layer two.

95
00:04:46.810 --> 00:04:49.920
And layer two is really the border,
it's the boundary, it's the gateway

96
00:04:49.920 --> 00:04:54.260
that we have to get past if we want to get
that packet into the system and processed.

97
00:04:54.260 --> 00:04:56.600
And if you think about what
happened to layer two,

98
00:04:56.600 --> 00:05:00.430
the real interesting control mechanism
is the MAC address sublayer.

99
00:05:00.430 --> 00:05:03.540
Because what we do is we look at the data
header of every packet that's coming into

100
00:05:03.540 --> 00:05:05.720
the system and we examine the MAC address.

101
00:05:05.720 --> 00:05:08.410
And when we took a look at
the packet capture that Mike did and

102
00:05:08.410 --> 00:05:13.060
we looked at the session ID and
the sequencing information.

103
00:05:13.060 --> 00:05:16.470
We didn't really point it out, but it was
there, you just might not have seen it.

104
00:05:16.470 --> 00:05:19.210
But the MAC address as well as
the IP address of the source and

105
00:05:19.210 --> 00:05:21.320
destination was involved in that packet.

00:26:10.400 --> 00:26:11.370
And what's gonna happen?

563
00:26:11.370 --> 00:26:16.050
Everybody's gonna respond to you and
say hey, we're here four times.

564
00:26:16.050 --> 00:26:19.700
Smurf attacks, in other words, are
basically ping attacks that are propagated

565
00:26:19.700 --> 00:26:23.130
specifically to carry out distributed
denial of service, right?

566
00:26:23.130 --> 00:26:26.170
Because they're gonna take thousands
of machines, theoretically, and

567
00:26:26.170 --> 00:26:27.800
have them all attack you.

568
00:26:27.800 --> 00:26:28.740
And take you offline.

569
00:26:28.740 --> 00:26:31.360
It's actually denial of service
attacks that's against one machine.

570
00:26:31.360 --> 00:26:36.150
But the goal, ultimately, is to manipulate
the ping response by changing or spoofing

571
00:26:36.150 --> 00:26:40.340
the source header in the IP packet,
and this is what a smurf attack does.

572
00:26:40.340 --> 00:26:42.320
I don't know why we call it
a smurf attack ultimately,

573
00:26:42.320 --> 00:26:46.050
cuz it has nothing to do with being small
and blue, but It's what we call it.

574
00:26:46.050 --> 00:26:47.220
It's called a smurf attack.

575
00:26:47.220 --> 00:26:50.800
So, smurf attacks are malformed ping
attacks that manipulate the source

576
00:26:50.800 --> 00:26:51.760
header using TCP.

577
00:26:51.760 --> 00:26:53.780
That's what smurf attacks are.

578
00:26:53.780 --> 00:26:55.520
What about fraggle attacks.

579
00:26:55.520 --> 00:26:56.355
Remember Fraggle Rock?

580
00:26:56.355 --> 00:26:56.970
>> Mm-hm.
Yeah.

581
00:26:56.970 --> 00:26:58.730
Grew up with that.
>> Fraggle Rock was a cool show.

582
00:26:58.730 --> 00:27:00.240
Fraggle Rock was a cool show.

583
00:27:00.240 --> 00:27:04.260
So, fraggle attacks are basically
the same thing as smurf attacks, but

584
00:27:04.260 --> 00:27:06.880
propagated on UDP instead of TCP.

585
00:27:06.880 --> 00:27:09.140
Now, because it's UDP, we're not pinging.

586
00:27:09.140 --> 00:27:12.520
We do something a little bit different
to actually carry out the attack, but

587
00:27:12.520 --> 00:27:14.200
ultimately the end result is the same.

588
00:27:14.200 --> 00:27:16.250
We get everybody to respond to you and

589
00:27:16.250 --> 00:27:18.790
through denial of service,
effectively take you offline.

590
00:27:18.790 --> 00:27:23.030
But we use UDP instead of TCP
to carry out the fraggle attack.

591
00:27:23.030 --> 00:27:26.350
Again, pretty cool when you think about
it and debunk it and break it down.

592
00:27:26.350 --> 00:27:31.330
So, denial of service attacks overall can
come in many forms across many protocols.

593
00:27:31.330 --> 00:27:34.110
And this also something, excuse me,
we wanna make sure you're aware of.

594
00:27:34.110 --> 00:27:38.200
The distributed denial of service attack
which is a slightly different animal,

595
00:27:38.200 --> 00:27:45.160
is gonna be many systems attacking and
being used to attack one or more systems.

596
00:27:45.160 --> 00:27:49.330
So, the idea is that, a denial of service
attacks one system against one system.

597
00:27:49.330 --> 00:27:50.570
I try to take mike offline.

598
00:27:50.570 --> 00:27:52.030
That's a denial of service attack.

599
00:27:52.030 --> 00:27:55.140
Distributed denial of services,
all these systems attacking one or

600
00:27:55.140 --> 00:27:58.150
more systems,
to take them offline at the same time.

601
00:27:58.150 --> 00:28:01.280
We often talk about botnets or
zombie armies being used

602
00:28:01.280 --> 00:28:04.690
to execute the distributed denial of
service attacks and taking systems down.

603
00:28:04.690 --> 00:28:05.490
As a result of that.

604
00:28:05.490 --> 00:28:08.020
So, we just want to know
it's a scalability question

605
00:28:08.020 --> 00:28:09.500
with distributed denial
of service attacks.

606
00:28:09.500 --> 00:28:10.860
Just be thinking about that.

607
00:28:10.860 --> 00:28:15.170
We may execute SIN flood attacks which
effectively is gonna manipulate the TCP

608
00:28:15.170 --> 00:28:16.630
three way handshake.

609
00:28:16.630 --> 00:28:19.110
And set up a whole bunch of SIN requests,
right?

610
00:28:19.110 --> 00:28:22.510
From a lot of different machines in
bound and then never acknowledge them.

611
00:28:22.510 --> 00:28:23.920
And eventually over time we tie up so

612
00:28:23.920 --> 00:28:27.890
many resources on the target that it
just rolls over and stops working.

613
00:28:27.890 --> 00:28:31.010
This is called a sinflux,
another form of denial of service or

614
00:28:31.010 --> 00:28:33.950
distributed denial of service attacks,
depending on what we're thinking about.

615
00:28:33.950 --> 00:28:36.540
So, wanna be thinking about
these kinds of attacks.

616
00:28:36.540 --> 00:28:38.410
How they work and
what we're doing with them.

617
00:28:38.410 --> 00:28:41.380
These are all different ways so
we can take on and manipulate

618
00:28:41.380 --> 00:28:45.300
the network protocols and the knowledge we
have of them to ultimately attack systems.

619
00:28:45.300 --> 00:28:49.130
Remember, we've been talking about
different ways that ultimately

620
00:28:49.130 --> 00:28:51.660
we can see attacks happening
in order to mitigate them.

621
00:28:51.660 --> 00:28:53.670
And ultimately through mitigation right?

622
00:28:53.670 --> 00:28:58.460
Ultimately take some sort of steps in
order to be able to clearly and hopefully

623
00:28:58.460 --> 00:29:04.000
right with success prevent the attackers
from doing to us what we know they can do.

624
00:29:04.000 --> 00:29:07.000
The knowledge of that helps us
to be better at defending and

625
00:29:07.000 --> 00:29:09.360
this is what we've been trying to
put across to you in this episode.

626
00:29:09.360 --> 00:29:11.220
And so are the other ones as well.

627
00:29:11.220 --> 00:29:12.670
>> Very good, so if Adam loved it,

628

we've got a lot of information there

629
00:29:16.100 --> 00:29:19.690
some of the attacks we haven't talked

630
00:29:19.690 --> 00:29:21.669
Different devices we
can put on our network,

631
00:29:21.669 --> 00:29:24.700
where we can put them on our
network to help us keep us safe or

632
00:29:24.700 --> 00:29:28.780
at least reduce the likelihood of success

633
00:29:28.780 --> 00:29:29.950
We thank you for that.

634
00:29:29.950 --> 00:29:33.890
Remember, if you guys wanna attend one of
Adam's classes live send us an email here

636
00:29:35.600 --> 00:29:40.330
That's going to do it for this episode,
signing off for now I'm Mike Roderick.

>> I'm Adam Gordon.

>> And we'll see you next time.

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike discuss the concepts of identity and access management (IAM). They talk about the process of identifying, authenticating and authorizing a subject. They also talk about the identity lifecycle, and the concept of single sign-on.

So IAM, Identity and Access Management,

Reminding you that the subject

Remember that a subject is not just a

00:02:39.755 --> 00:02:41.490

A non-person entity and what we really

68

That's gonna be the starting point for

When we think about this whole

At least not most of us anyway, right?

But the reality is that we do have a very

Remember, as we also talked about before

a life cycle or a process and

We should have something like that,

Even if we don't have the cool animation

00:04:26.221 --> 00:04:29.300
What we are talking about is
something that you need to know.

94
00:04:29.300 --> 00:04:32.845
And when I say you need to know,
what I'm suggesting is it would be

95
00:04:32.845 --> 00:04:37.228
really beneficial for you to understand
the steps that we're about to talk about

96
00:04:37.228 --> 00:04:41.380
with regards to identity access
management, and the identity life cycle.

97
00:04:41.380 --> 00:04:44.900
So when we're thinking about
figuring out who somebody is,

98
00:04:44.900 --> 00:04:47.870
we often start with the thought
process of identification.

99
00:04:47.870 --> 00:04:51.230
So somebody shows up, says I'm so
and so, I wanna get in.

100
00:04:51.230 --> 00:04:55.060
Identification is the idea of them giving
you those credentials, whatever they are.

101
00:04:55.060 --> 00:04:58.770
Username and password, maybe it's
a PIN that they have with a card or

102
00:04:58.770 --> 00:05:03.260
a key of some kind, like a key fob
with a challenge-response solution.

103
00:05:03.260 --> 00:05:06.960
It may be something that they are,
it could be a biometric scanner.

104
00:05:06.960 --> 00:05:09.449
We'll talk about these things and
how they work, but

105
00:05:09.449 --> 00:05:11.953
the idea is we call these
factors of authentication.

106
00:05:11.953 --> 00:05:16.633
So identification is about presenting one
or more of the factors of authentication,

107
00:05:16.633 --> 00:05:20.728
so that the system, whatever that
system is, can ultimately take them and

108
00:05:20.728 --> 00:05:24.500
process them and decide whether you are or
are not a legitimate user.

109
00:05:24.500 --> 00:05:27.735
And if you are what level of access
you will be granted and if you're not,

110
00:05:27.735 --> 00:05:30.240
then effectively we tell you,
sorry you can't get in.

111
00:05:30.240 --> 00:05:32.270
And you have to come back later, and

112
00:05:32.270 --> 00:05:33.990
come back with somebody who is authorized,
right?

113
00:05:33.990 --> 00:05:36.320
Who does have the proper
credentials to be here.

114
00:05:36.320 --> 00:05:38.650
So identification comes first.

115
00:05:38.650 --> 00:05:40.760
We then go to authentication, right?

116
00:05:40.760 --> 00:05:44.850
We have to make sure that we understand
who the person is that's presenting

117
00:05:44.850 --> 00:05:47.010
the credentials, and so
we have to authenticate them.

118
00:05:47.010 --> 00:05:49.240
We take them it's usually and
automated process,

119
00:05:49.240 --> 00:05:54.000
a system that does this, and they're
gonna be processed, examined, compared.

120
00:05:54.000 --> 00:05:56.900
Making sure that what you are and
who you are and

121
00:05:56.900 --> 00:06:01.470
what you represent yourself as, is what we
already have on file, it's what we know,

122
00:06:01.470 --> 00:06:04.070
it's the known quantity or
quantities about you.

123
00:06:04.070 --> 00:06:07.390
So the factor or
factors of authentication are compared.

124
00:06:07.390 --> 00:06:10.555
Obviously, we're looking for
a match, we're not looking for

125
00:06:10.555 --> 00:06:13.425
a difference of any kind and
assuming that that works out,

126
00:06:13.425 --> 00:06:16.252
then we move to the third step,
which is authorization.

127
00:06:16.252 --> 00:06:21.170
Authorization, is the idea of being able
to say, okay, we've been given identity.

128
00:06:21.170 --> 00:06:24.590
We've authenticated it, so
we now say yes, everything is good.

129
00:06:24.590 --> 00:06:28.150
We now have to figure out what writes
our level of access we're gonna give you

130
00:06:28.150 --> 00:06:29.170
as a user, right?

131
00:06:29.170 --> 00:06:31.570
In a system, that's effectively
what we're talking about.

132
00:06:31.570 --> 00:06:35.070
We're gonna authenticate you, and
then we're going to authorize you, right?

133
00:06:35.070 --> 00:06:37.940
We're gonna say, okay,
you're gonna get this level of permission.

134
00:06:37.940 --> 00:06:39.800
We're gonna give you full control.

135
00:06:39.800 --> 00:06:41.250
We're gonna give you read only.

136
00:06:41.250 --> 00:06:42.850
We're gonna let you go over here.

137
00:06:42.850 --> 00:06:44.520
Do this, but not do that.

138
00:06:44.520 --> 00:06:45.658
Whatever that is, it varies.

139
00:06:45.658 --> 00:06:48.285
We're not really worried, per se,
right now about what that is.

140
00:06:48.285 --> 00:06:50.760
We're just worried about
the idea of the process step.

141
00:06:50.760 --> 00:06:55.360
So authentication, then authorization and
then ultimately after authorization,

142
00:06:55.360 --> 00:06:58.740
what we traditionally would wanna do,
is keep track of what you're doing, right.

143
00:06:58.740 --> 00:07:00.820
So we probably have some auditing,
logging,

144
00:07:00.820 --> 00:07:04.370
things like that going on to keep track of
you, to make sure that you're really not

145

00:28:26.730 --> 00:28:30.480
us as CISSPs cuz we have to be
involved in that whole cycle.

604
00:28:30.480 --> 00:28:33.800
We have to be involved in that
conversation and thinking through that and

605
00:28:33.800 --> 00:28:37.160
guiding the business towards
the activities and the decision points

606
00:28:37.160 --> 00:28:39.280
that are gonna allow this to
ultimately be implemented properly.

607
00:28:40.340 --> 00:28:40.870
>> Very good Adam!

608
00:28:40.870 --> 00:28:43.780
That's a great first look at our,
well I don't wanna say first look, but

609
00:28:43.780 --> 00:28:47.740
a really good look at identity and
access management or the IM process.

610
00:28:47.740 --> 00:28:50.250
And I know we've got more to go over.

611
00:28:50.250 --> 00:28:52.446
Unfortunately we're out of time
on this particular episode.

612
00:28:52.446 --> 00:28:56.082
So we're gonna call it here, but
don't worry we're coming back

613
00:28:56.082 --> 00:29:00.470
with more IM processes and continue to
look at controlling access subjects.

614
00:29:00.470 --> 00:29:02.820
Two objects, so
make sure you come back for that.

615
00:29:02.820 --> 00:29:04.290
Remember if you guys want to see Adam or

616
00:29:04.290 --> 00:29:07.058
a ten-one of Adam's classes live,
shoot us an email.

617
00:29:07.058 --> 00:29:09.521
SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

618
00:29:09.521 --> 00:29:10.543
That's gonna do it for now.

619
00:29:10.543 --> 00:29:12.540
Signing off, I'm Mike Roderick.

620
00:29:12.540 --> 00:29:13.619
>> I'm Adam Gordan.

621
00:29:13.619 --> 00:29:15.337

622

episodes.description: - In this episode, Adam and Mike begin their conversation on the concept of managing authentication. They talk about protecting data outside organization, sticky controls, encryption, privacy control, and integrity. They also talk about PII, temporal systems, identity management, and password management.
episodes.title: Manage Authentication
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

00:00:00.376 --> 00:00:10.376
[MUSIC]

00:00:12.179 --> 00:00:16.300
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITproTV.

00:00:16.300 --> 00:00:20.270
I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and
today we're doing our CISSP content.

00:00:20.270 --> 00:00:24.700
And specifically, we're gonna be
diving into managing authentication.

00:00:24.700 --> 00:00:29.700
We've already taken a look at some of
that process, right, with the IAA, IAM,

00:00:29.700 --> 00:00:31.800
I should say the Identity and
Access Management.

00:00:31.800 --> 00:00:34.610
And we saw that there's a lot
of moving parts to it as well.

00:00:34.610 --> 00:00:37.770
As Adam said, it's one of those things
that we might take for granted sometimes,

00:00:37.770 --> 00:00:41.290
cuz a lot of it can be automated and
we don't really see it happening.

00:00:41.290 --> 00:00:44.800
There's a lot to is so luckily for
use we've got the one and only Adam Gordon

00:00:44.800 --> 00:00:47.890
here to help us figure out what
the heck's going on in the background.

00:00:47.890 --> 00:00:49.850
How are you doing, Adam?

00:00:49.850 --> 00:00:49.620
>> I"m good, I'm goo.

00:00:49.620 --> 00:00:52.790
You know, I almost didn't make it in for
this episode because the door access

00:00:52.790 --> 00:00:55.500
control mechanism wouldn't work and
wouldn't let me in.

00:00:55.500 --> 00:00:57.935
That stupid key fob that
Mike gave me wasn't working.

00:00:57.935 --> 00:01:00.810
>> [LAUGH]
>> Must have been a fake token as opposed

00:01:00.810 --> 00:01:01.870
to a real token.

00:01:01.870 --> 00:01:04.435
>> We modified the authorization for
his authentication there.

00:01:04.435 --> 00:01:05.400
[LAUGH]
>> Don't let the long

00:01:05.400 --> 00:01:08.130
haired guy with the grey hair
come back in the studio.

00:01:08.130 --> 00:01:10.880
All right, so
let's continue our conversations right?

00:01:10.880 --> 00:01:14.430
You know we've talked a lot up
until now with regards to IM

00:01:14.430 --> 00:01:16.330
about the moving parts as Mike was saying.

00:01:16.330 --> 00:01:17.510
It's a great way of thinking about it.

00:01:17.510 --> 00:01:23.860
We've talked about the idea behind
identity and access management, the users

00:01:23.860 --> 00:01:27.750
or subjects and the objects, the data,
right,so, subject-object interaction.

00:01:27.750 --> 00:01:30.260
We talked a lot about the fact
that we have both physical and

00:01:30.260 --> 00:01:32.400
logical approaches to this system.

00:01:32.400 --> 00:01:34.940
Talked about some of the examples
of what those may look like.

00:01:34.940 --> 00:01:39.130
We've talked about the authentication
process and authorization process and

00:01:39.130 --> 00:01:43.300
how tokens are generated, the user tokens,
the virtual tokens, as we call them, and

00:01:43.300 --> 00:01:45.800
are given to user accounts
in a directory service.

00:01:45.800 --> 00:01:48.400
And we've talked about the different
factors of authentication.

00:01:48.400 --> 00:01:52.660
We talked about something you have,
something you know, and something you are.

00:01:52.660 --> 00:01:56.170
These are the three factors of
authentication we traditionally discuss.

00:01:56.170 --> 00:01:59.000
Now we're giving you some examples
of each of those and how they work.

00:01:59.000 --> 00:02:02.270
There are other ways in which we
can identify ourselves aligned

00:02:02.270 --> 00:02:06.140
with those three factors but things that
we don't always, and maybe not always in

00:02:06.140 --> 00:02:09.420
the top of our mind, thinking about and
Mike alluded to this when he said there is

00:02:09.420 --> 00:02:13.350
a lot of things going on, lot of it's
automated, stuff we may not even see.

00:02:13.350 --> 00:02:16.690
So for instance, we can use a Mac
address as a unique identifier.

00:02:16.690 --> 00:02:20.240
We often do that and do that all the time,
when we think about systems,

00:02:20.240 --> 00:02:22.780
right, because when we think
about a individual endpoint,

00:02:22.780 --> 00:02:26.580
a computer, not a person now, because I'm
not walking around with a MAC address.

00:02:26.580 --> 00:02:27.300
>> [LAUGH]
>> It would be great if I

00:02:27.300 --> 00:02:30.300
could put one on my back and
turn around show you what that look like.

00:02:30.300 --> 00:02:31.430
>> Scan when we need to.

00:02:31.430 --> 00:02:34.950
>> Scan it, you know in like,
you ever see 12 Monkeys, the movie?

00:02:34.950 --> 00:02:38.550
So they have, the Bruce Willis character
has the bar code tattoo, right,

00:02:38.550 --> 00:02:39.995
the expiration tattoo.

00:02:39.995 --> 00:02:41.180
So that kind of thing, right.

00:02:41.180 --> 00:02:41.990
We don't have that.

00:02:41.990 --> 00:02:44.240
Although I've seen a few
of those on people but

00:02:44.240 --> 00:02:45.670
we don't have that commonly, right.

00:02:45.670 --> 00:02:51.320
So, but we do have media access control
addresses, in other words MAC addresses.

00:02:51.320 --> 00:02:54.410
MAC addresses are going to be
uniquely assigned in theory anyway.

00:02:54.410 --> 00:02:58.164
If you don't violate the tenants of
the system, you're not up to no good and

00:02:58.164 --> 00:02:59.704
trying to spoof a MAC address.

00:02:59.704 --> 00:03:01.634
But if you're doing the right thing,

00:03:01.634 --> 00:03:05.442
a MAC address should be uniquely
identifying the individual IP endpoint.

00:03:05.442 --> 00:03:07.204
In other words, the network card or

00:03:07.204 --> 00:03:11.305
the network capable device that you're
using is gonna have a unique identifier.

00:03:11.305 --> 00:03:13.335
It has two, potentially, right?

00:03:13.335 --> 00:03:15.500
It has a MAC address, certainly.

00:03:15.500 --> 00:03:17.305
It may or
may not have an IP address that is unique.

00:03:17.305 --> 00:03:21.648
It should be unique, but the reality is,
we know we often reuse private internal IP

00:03:21.648 --> 00:03:24.999
addresses, so they're unique
within that address space, but

00:03:24.999 --> 00:03:29.344
they're not unique globally, because
there's lots and lots and lots of machines

00:03:29.344 --> 00:03:34.522
out there that have a 10.005 address or
192.168.0.20 or whatever that may be.

00:03:34.522 --> 00:03:35.120
Right?
But

00:03:35.120 --> 00:03:38.140
the point is it is unique within
the system it's being used in.

00:03:38.140 --> 00:03:39.420
So we can use IP addresses.

00:03:39.420 --> 00:03:43.260
We can use MAC addresses as unique
identifiers for access control.

00:03:43.260 --> 00:03:46.440
For instance when we talked about
wireless systems one of the security

00:03:46.440 --> 00:03:49.570
things that we told you would be
a good idea for you to consider and

00:03:49.570 --> 00:03:52.165
it is a thing by the way that
is a formal technical term.

00:03:52.165 --> 00:03:53.310
>> [LAUGH]
>> Security thing.

00:03:53.310 --> 00:03:54.160
I didn't call it a thingy.

00:03:54.160 --> 00:03:58.500
That would be the next technical term
you graduate to when you become a CISSP.

00:03:58.500 --> 00:04:00.900
But a technical thing,
one of the approaches right?

00:04:00.900 --> 00:04:03.240
It's part of the wireless architecture we
said would be good for you to implement

00:04:03.240 --> 00:04:07.870
would be to create a MAC address allow or
deny list effectively a block or

00:04:07.870 --> 00:04:11.510
allow list that you could use
with what's called MAC filtering,

00:04:11.510 --> 00:04:15.300
which is actual the formal name for
the approach to prevent certain systems

00:04:15.300 --> 00:04:17.420
from authenticating against
your wireless access point.

00:04:17.420 --> 00:04:20.590
So we can use addresses all
the time as mechanisms for

00:04:20.590 --> 00:04:22.570
effectively providing access control.

00:04:22.570 --> 00:04:26.220
We also have the ability to use
something like a radio frequency ID tag,

00:04:26.220 --> 00:04:26.830
an RFID tag.

00:04:26.830 --> 00:04:30.810
If you think about the fact that, although
we don't tend to see them in modern,

00:04:30.810 --> 00:04:33.610
everyday interactions in
the normal enterprise,

00:04:33.610 --> 00:04:37.540
cuz we don't tend to use RFID tags for
people, but we do use them for goods.

00:04:37.540 --> 00:04:42.270
So, for instance, we can tag
a pallet of servers that are being

00:04:42.270 --> 00:04:45.370
shipped from point A to point B or
being moved around a warehouse and

00:04:45.370 --> 00:04:48.410
we could track where they are and
we can not only know where they are but

00:04:48.410 --> 00:04:52.900
also know what they are in the sense that
we've programmed information into the chip

00:04:52.900 --> 00:04:55.280
that effectively tells us what's on
that pallet and that kind of stuff.

00:04:55.280 --> 00:04:58.950
So, we could tag people if we really
wanted to, we don't but we could.

00:04:58.950 --> 00:05:01.500
We could tag vehicles,
we could tag anything.

00:05:01.500 --> 00:05:05.110
So Costco for instance, right, uses RFID
tags in their warehouses to keep track

00:05:05.110 --> 00:05:08.610
of all the palleted stuff they have up on
the shelves, and when they do inventory

00:05:08.610 --> 00:05:12.140
they can just scan the tag and it tells
them, oh, you've got paper towels on that

00:05:12.140 --> 00:05:14.760
pallet, you're supposed to have so
much, that kind of thing.

00:05:14.760 --> 00:05:16.380
So we use our FIN tags as well.

00:05:16.380 --> 00:05:18.970
There's lots of different ways for
us to approach identity.

00:05:18.970 --> 00:05:21.420
It's not just the standard,
hey, who are you?

00:05:21.420 --> 00:05:23.460
I'm user X with password Y.

00:05:23.460 --> 00:05:25.130
There's a lot more too
it these days than that.

00:05:25.130 --> 00:05:28.280
We just want to be thinking about this and
understand the different solutions and

00:05:28.280 --> 00:05:32.930
approaches that we may be able to bring to
the party, because it really does today

00:05:32.930 --> 00:05:36.420
become a question of what
technology are we going to use and

00:05:36.420 --> 00:05:40.860
what approach does that technology allow
for with regards to authentication and

00:05:40.860 --> 00:05:43.250
authorization as well as identification?

00:05:43.250 --> 00:05:45.650
So we may be able to do
the standard stuff, right?

00:05:45.650 --> 00:05:48.900
But ultimately we can also get
creative and give people smart cards,

00:05:48.900 --> 00:05:52.590
we can give them chips, we can give
them embedded in the smart card.

00:05:52.590 --> 00:05:55.200
We can give them some sort
of a PIN to go with it.

00:05:55.200 --> 00:05:59.890
These are not new concepts, but
especially in roughly about the last year,

00:05:59.890 --> 00:06:04.410
yeah, probably about the last year or
so, in the United States in particular,

00:06:04.410 --> 00:06:07.190
we're moving to a chip and
PIN solution with credit cards,

00:06:07.190 --> 00:06:11.950
because of compliance with PCIDSS
regulations or requirements I should say.

00:06:11.950 --> 00:06:13.800
And so all the major banking vendors,

00:06:13.800 --> 00:06:18.400
all the major financial services vendors
and all the retailers are having to retool

00:06:18.400 --> 00:06:20.620
all of the systems they use
to do processing of payments.

00:06:20.620 --> 00:06:23.670
So if you've gotten one of these credit
cards recently or your bank has reissued

00:06:23.670 --> 00:06:27.470
it or said hey, we're not going to meet
the October deadline, instead we're

00:06:27.470 --> 00:06:30.920
gonna get an extension so we're not
gonna do it, which is what my bank did.

00:06:30.920 --> 00:06:32.700
No, it's not a big deal.

00:06:32.700 --> 00:06:33.280
We don't really need to comply.

00:06:33.280 --> 00:06:35.520
We'll just get around to it
in the next year and half.

00:06:35.520 --> 00:06:37.200
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's effectively what they told me.

00:06:37.200 --> 00:06:40.340
I said wow that's really interesting
considering that everybody else is

00:06:40.340 --> 00:06:42.230
doing it, but you go do your own thing.

00:06:42.230 --> 00:06:44.760
You be you, right, do you,
that's what's important.

00:06:44.760 --> 00:06:46.150
So my bank has not done that yet.

00:06:46.150 --> 00:06:49.620
I should say that it was my bank because
I'm switching banks because they clearly

00:06:49.620 --> 00:06:52.150
aren't all that interested
in getting that done.

00:06:52.150 --> 00:06:54.652
But whether they've done it yet or
not, really not all that important.

00:06:54.652 --> 00:06:56.930
What is important is the idea
they're going to reissue a card,

00:06:56.930 --> 00:06:58.780
going to have a little chip.

00:06:58.780 --> 00:07:02.141
It's probably a one by one square
on the front of the card or

00:07:02.141 --> 00:07:04.700
embedded somewhere in the card.

00:07:04.700 --> 00:07:07.160
And now if you start using those cards,
you're gonna walk up and

00:07:07.160 --> 00:07:08.661
use the traditional readers.

00:07:08.661 --> 00:07:12.411
So you have to swipe it but if its a chip
and pin card you can't swipe it anymore

00:07:12.411 --> 00:07:15.987
the way you did before, you have to
stick it in the bottom of the reader and

00:07:15.987 --> 00:07:18.660
it has to sit in there
while their processing it.

00:07:18.660 --> 00:07:20.789
Now this has actually been going on for
years in Europe.

00:07:20.789 --> 00:07:22.507
We're really just behind the times.

00:07:22.507 --> 00:07:25.940
So whenever I travel over
to Europe on business,

00:07:25.940 --> 00:07:29.200
I've been there Probably three
times this year on business alone.

00:07:29.200 --> 00:07:29.870
I know, it's a rough life.

00:07:29.870 --> 00:07:30.500
I do, I get it.

00:07:30.500 --> 00:07:31.102
I understand, right?

00:07:31.102 --> 00:07:32.729
>> [LAUGH]
>> But I've been there a lot recently,

00:07:32.729 --> 00:07:34.200
let's put it that way.

00:07:34.200 --> 00:07:38.240
But when I was there the last couple of
times actually, one of my cards happens to

00:07:38.240 --> 00:07:41.940
already have the chip on it, and
has had it for the better part of a year.

00:07:41.940 --> 00:07:44.703
And when you're over there, they're kind
enough, they walk up, cuz they know,

00:07:44.703 --> 00:07:47.189
especially if you're an American or
a tourist, you're not from Europe,

00:07:47.189 --> 00:07:48.418
that you may not be familiar with it.

00:07:48.418 --> 00:07:51.810
So whenever you're out somewhere,
which is like the most hilarious thing in

00:07:51.810 --> 00:07:55.198
the world, so we're out at a bar after
hours, like going out and drinking and

00:07:55.198 --> 00:07:57.680
having fun, and so
everybody's had a bunch of drinks.

00:07:57.680 --> 00:08:00.260
We're all sitting there, okay,
who's gonna pay the check?

00:08:00.260 --> 00:08:03.100
Fine, I'll pay the check, so
the bar person comes over.

00:08:03.100 --> 00:08:04.520
So here's the deal,
they bring you the reader,

00:08:04.520 --> 00:08:07.400
and it's literally like
a hand held reader.

00:08:07.400 --> 00:08:09.679
It's bigger than this, but
basically they give this thing to you,

00:08:09.679 --> 00:08:12.550
it's got the paper roll at the top,
it's got the big slot in the bottom for

00:08:12.550 --> 00:08:14.568
you to stick the card in and
they just hand it to you.

00:08:14.568 --> 00:08:15.595
>> [LAUGH]
>> They're like, okay,

00:08:15.595 --> 00:08:16.585
well you should know what to do with it.

00:08:16.585 --> 00:08:18.550
Well no, I'm not sure what to do with it.

00:08:18.550 --> 00:08:19.855
So they explain it to you,
great, so you take the card,

00:08:19.855 --> 00:08:22.815
you put it in the bottom, leave it in
there, does its thing, prints it out.

00:08:22.815 --> 00:08:25.955
It's like a little adding machine, paper
roll on the top, so that's kinda cool.

00:08:25.955 --> 00:08:28.454
It works a lot better, it's a lot
funnier when you've all been drinking.

00:08:28.454 --> 00:08:29.133
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

00:08:29.133 --> 00:08:31.625
nobody really understands the concept,
right?

00:08:31.625 --> 00:08:32.940
It's a lot of fun.

00:08:32.940 --> 00:08:35.590
So idea is that you simply stick
the card in the bottom of the reader,

00:08:35.590 --> 00:08:37.930
it does its stuff,
it authenticates, it processes.

00:08:37.930 --> 00:08:40.600
The trick is you can't pull the card
out until it says it's done.

00:08:40.600 --> 00:08:44.200
I know this because I did that and I got
in trouble, cuz you have to do it again.

00:08:44.200 --> 00:08:46.930
So you have to make sure that you
leave the chip in place, the card and

00:08:46.930 --> 00:08:47.480
chip in place.

00:08:47.480 --> 00:08:50.240
But this is the kind of thing that
we can do with these systems today.

00:08:51.280 --> 00:08:53.900
The idea behind all of this, remember,

00:08:53.900 --> 00:08:56.890
is to ensure that identity is
going to be validated, right?

00:08:56.890 --> 00:09:00.160
We wanna make sure we're not allowing
strangers to get access to our systems.

00:09:00.160 --> 00:09:03.280
This is really what the important
thought process is here behind this.

00:09:03.280 --> 00:09:06.540
Now, we also have to think about
the fact that when data is being used

00:09:06.540 --> 00:09:08.500
we may not be able to authenticate.

00:09:08.500 --> 00:09:11.380
We may not be able to authorize, we may
not be able to provide identification

00:09:11.380 --> 00:09:13.590
at every step in
the transactional process.

00:09:13.590 --> 00:09:16.500
We talked about SSO,
we talked about single sign on and

00:09:16.500 --> 00:09:20.120
the idea that you basically
authenticate once and you access many.

00:09:20.120 --> 00:09:22.590
So that happens in directory systems,
that's okay.

00:09:22.590 --> 00:09:26.200
But what about data that's being sent or
transmitted across the wire?

00:09:26.200 --> 00:09:28.236
So, data that's effectively in transit,

00:09:28.236 --> 00:09:31.977
how are we authenticating the fact that
from the place that we're sending it from

00:09:31.977 --> 00:09:35.662
to the place that we're ultimately
winding up, that somewhere along the way,

00:09:35.662 --> 00:09:38.707
anywhere along the way,
including that endpoint at the far end?

00:09:38.707 --> 00:09:41.204
How do we know that the data
hasn't been intercepted?

00:09:41.204 --> 00:09:44.296
How do we know that somebody that sees
the data has rights to see it and

00:09:44.296 --> 00:09:47.480
somebody that does see the data
is not actually a bad actor?

00:09:47.480 --> 00:09:51.710
This becomes complicated, because we
can't stop everybody that sees the data

00:09:51.710 --> 00:09:53.820
on the path and say, hey, who are you?

00:09:53.820 --> 00:09:55.690
Right?
Or turn around and close your eyes,

00:09:55.690 --> 00:09:59.910
put on this blindfold, you're not supposed
to see this data, that just doesn't work.

00:09:59.910 --> 00:10:01.970
Now, we've talked about a mechanism,
right?

00:10:01.970 --> 00:10:04.670
A control, that we can implement
that will offset that,

00:10:04.670 --> 00:10:09.130
that will effectively compensate for the
fact that we can't provide identification.

00:10:09.130 --> 00:10:13.260
All the way through an authentication and
authorization, all the way through.

00:10:13.260 --> 00:10:15.900
We've talked about the fact
that we can implement,

Because the ultimate goal, is not just to
make sure bad actors don't get in, but

00:21:50.950 --> 00:21:54.107
that the people inside the perimeter
don't do stupid things and

00:21:54.107 --> 00:21:57.556
as a result of that make problems that
then allow the bad actors to get in

00:21:57.556 --> 00:21:59.150
because something goes wrong.

00:21:59.150 --> 00:22:02.799
So it's as much about internal maintenance
as it is about external vigilance,

00:22:02.799 --> 00:22:04.167
when we talk about security.

00:22:04.167 --> 00:22:06.700
It's very,
very important to think about both.

00:22:06.700 --> 00:22:09.690
So password management is one of those
areas where we can have a very big impact,

00:22:09.690 --> 00:22:12.570
because you can create
policies that mandate, right?

00:22:12.570 --> 00:22:15.300
That users have to create
complex passwords,

00:22:15.300 --> 00:22:16.940
they have to change them every 30 days.

00:22:16.940 --> 00:22:20.940
They can't reuse them except if
they've already used other passwords

00:22:20.940 --> 00:22:22.240
15 or 20 times.

00:22:22.240 --> 00:22:26.170
Those kinda things are important,
password management deals with all this.

00:22:26.170 --> 00:22:27.520
We have password management systems,

00:22:27.520 --> 00:22:30.640
we can automate this whole process,
wanna be thinking about that.

00:22:30.640 --> 00:22:34.700
Account management, allows us to provision
users, create them automatically,

00:22:34.700 --> 00:22:37.320
you maybe even use a template
that pre-populates certain

00:22:37.320 --> 00:22:38.160
information for them.

00:22:38.160 --> 00:22:42.130
And then can assign permissions
to them based on role delegation,

00:22:42.130 --> 00:22:45.470
based on group membership generically,
is more often than not what we do.

00:22:45.470 --> 00:22:47.650
Again, automation can be a good thing,
right?

00:22:47.650 --> 00:22:51.340
We don't have to manually handcraft every
user account that's created in the system.

00:22:51.340 --> 00:22:55.150
But we do have to have a record of what
users are doing, where they were created,

00:22:55.150 --> 00:22:55.770
when, and why.

00:22:55.770 --> 00:22:58.320
And what permissions they
are gonna be granted as a result,

00:22:58.320 --> 00:22:59.310
this is gonna be important.

00:22:59.310 --> 00:23:02.000
So account management typically
is gonna have some sort of

00:23:02.000 --> 00:23:03.470
workflow associated with it.

00:23:03.470 --> 00:23:07.320
It's gonna be an automated system, it's
gonna have provisioning capabilities so

00:23:07.320 --> 00:23:09.760
you can create templates and
things like that.

00:23:09.760 --> 00:23:11.990
And so you may have a standard
template for normal user,

00:23:11.990 --> 00:23:15.820
you may have a template for a management
level user, you may have a template for

00:23:15.820 --> 00:23:18.990
a remote user that needs special
permissions assigned to them,

00:23:18.990 --> 00:23:21.910
that can come in remotely cuz
they're not gonna be in the office.

00:23:21.910 --> 00:23:24.940
These are different things you can
think about and ultimately you can do.

00:23:24.940 --> 00:23:27.520
We need to have a central repository,
we've talked about this, the directory

00:23:27.520 --> 00:23:31.330
service, the LDAP directory where
we're gonna store these user accounts.

00:23:31.330 --> 00:23:34.550
So we have some sort of central
repository where everything will be and

00:23:34.550 --> 00:23:35.610
we have user profiles.

00:23:35.610 --> 00:23:37.700
We have to think about
the profile that's created.

00:23:37.700 --> 00:23:40.570
The token represents the sum
total of user access, but

00:23:40.570 --> 00:23:42.495
it doesn't represent
the whole user profile.

00:23:42.495 --> 00:23:46.725
The profile is more than that, it's the
permissions but it's also the settings.

00:23:46.725 --> 00:23:47.930
It's all the data
associated with the user.

00:23:47.930 --> 00:23:51.350
It's all that stuff,
the email address, the home address,

00:23:51.350 --> 00:23:52.655
the date of birth potentially.

00:23:52.655 --> 00:23:56.503
These all may be unique identifier
fields in the user Profile

00:23:56.503 --> 00:23:58.998
that is created inside the directory.

00:23:58.998 --> 00:24:02.430
A lot of times we'll have
enlarged organizations.

00:24:02.430 --> 00:24:05.720
You will have a level or
an area there where you can say,

00:24:05.720 --> 00:24:09.150
okay the management person or the person
who reports on this team is this and

00:24:09.150 --> 00:24:11.860
you can actually set up
some of that hierarchy.

00:24:11.860 --> 00:24:15.960
You'll have room for the address so where
they work, what division, what department,

00:24:15.960 --> 00:24:18.890
things like that because then we
can use what we call attributes.

00:24:18.890 --> 00:24:20.180
These are all attributes.

00:24:20.180 --> 00:24:24.530
We can use attributes like these to
do attribute based authentication or

00:24:24.530 --> 00:24:28.560
attribute based access control, where we
can say a user logs in, they authenticate.

00:24:28.560 --> 00:24:31.420
They don't just provide a user name and
a password, they may have to

00:24:31.420 --> 00:24:35.710
provide several additional attributes that
are known only to the user in theory.

00:24:35.710 --> 00:24:36.800
So who their boss is.

00:24:36.800 --> 00:24:40.483
Their direct report, who or
what division they work in and

00:24:40.483 --> 00:24:45.159
perhaps what uniques employee
identification, employee ID they have.

00:24:45.159 --> 00:24:48.394
So on a log on stream that uses
apps based authentication and

00:24:48.394 --> 00:24:50.929
attribute based access control mechanisms.

00:24:50.929 --> 00:24:54.971
You have a log on four, right, not just
username and password, but you're gonna

00:24:54.971 --> 00:24:58.779
have three or four fields that ask for
a variety of different attributes, and

00:24:58.779 --> 00:25:02.880
as a result to that, by providing that
whole effectively profile of information,

00:25:02.880 --> 00:25:06.515
we're then gonna be able to
authenticate the user based on that.

00:25:06.515 --> 00:25:09.130
You may have seen this in
a slightly different form,

00:25:09.130 --> 00:25:12.410
where you have security questions, right,
if you have to reset your password or

00:25:12.410 --> 00:25:15.800
something like that, or
you call up a vendor or call up a company,

00:25:15.800 --> 00:25:18.180
credit card companies for
instance will do this.

00:25:18.180 --> 00:25:20.890
If you need to get into the account but
you don't know your PIN or

00:25:20.890 --> 00:25:24.170
your password, they'll ask you
security questions to reset it.

00:25:24.170 --> 00:25:26.400
So, where'd you go to school,

00:25:26.400 --> 00:25:29.150
what was your favorite color, what comic
book did you read in the fourth grade.

00:25:29.150 --> 00:25:31.566
All that stupid stuff you have to answer,
right.

00:25:31.566 --> 00:25:33.780
And I struggle with this myself, right.

00:25:33.780 --> 00:25:36.150
So I put that stuff in,
thinking all right, I'm smart.

00:25:36.150 --> 00:25:37.260
I'm gonna remember, right?

00:25:37.260 --> 00:25:38.150
Where did I go to school?

00:25:38.150 --> 00:25:39.270
Well, how could I forget that?

00:25:39.270 --> 00:25:40.590
I don't know what happens.

00:25:40.590 --> 00:25:43.270
It's like somebody comes along,
wipes my memory when I'm on the phone with

00:25:43.270 --> 00:25:47.000
these people, because I sit there, or
I'm on the website trying to do it.

00:25:47.000 --> 00:25:49.550
And no matter what I put in,
it's just never right.

00:25:49.550 --> 00:25:50.570
And I've got news for you.

00:25:50.570 --> 00:25:52.422
I know when my favorite in the world.

00:25:52.422 --> 00:25:54.381
It doesn't change, right?

00:25:54.381 --> 00:25:55.110
So I'm right.

00:25:55.110 --> 00:25:56.100
I know I'm right.

00:25:56.100 --> 00:25:58.340
The stupid system is wrong, right.

00:25:58.340 --> 00:26:02.170
How many ways can you possibly tell me
it's not the answer that I'm giving you

00:26:02.170 --> 00:26:03.100
and it can't be right?

00:26:03.100 --> 00:26:08.190
The only thing I'm thinking of honestly
and I think this is why it happens is, and

00:26:08.190 --> 00:26:11.480
this is bad design on the part of
the vendor and the implementation,

00:26:11.480 --> 00:26:15.250
because I know for a fact all kidding
aside, I've done this recently and

00:26:15.250 --> 00:26:19.350
two of the answers I gave specifically
to these questions were 100% accurate.

00:26:19.350 --> 00:26:21.670
Because I actually went through this with
them when I got on the phone because

00:26:21.670 --> 00:26:22.200
I was so enraged.

00:26:22.200 --> 00:26:23.900
And I said you got to be kidding me.

00:26:23.900 --> 00:26:26.110
How can I not know the answer
to these two questions?

00:26:26.110 --> 00:26:26.970
It's this.

00:26:26.970 --> 00:26:29.350
And the woman said let me check and
absolutely it is but

00:26:29.350 --> 00:26:30.440
your system wouldn't take it.

00:26:30.440 --> 00:26:31.640
So what's the problem?

00:26:31.640 --> 00:26:34.590
The only thing I can think of is that
actually they are case sensitive.

00:26:34.590 --> 00:26:36.900
>> Right.
>> But they're not telling you

00:26:36.900 --> 00:26:37.310
that they're case sensitive.

00:26:37.310 --> 00:26:40.950
So you know if you don't realize that
you type it in a certain way and

00:26:40.950 --> 00:26:45.500
then all of a sudden they're like,
well, yeah, but the P in the middle of

00:26:45.500 --> 00:26:49.670
that wasn't in Cyrillic, and you didn't
type it in uppercase, or in kenji or

00:26:49.670 --> 00:26:51.680
something, so no, we can't let you in.

00:26:51.680 --> 00:26:52.750
That's just dumb.

00:26:52.750 --> 00:26:53.990
It's bad implementation.

00:26:53.990 --> 00:26:55.650
Bad architecture, bad design.

00:26:55.650 --> 00:26:58.850
What you should do in that system is
put a big sign on the front that tells

00:26:58.850 --> 00:27:03.710
users hey, by the way, your information
that you provided Is case sensitive.

00:27:03.710 --> 00:27:05.440
So hey, pay attention.

00:27:05.440 --> 00:27:06.300
Put it in the right way.

00:27:06.300 --> 00:27:08.290
Because I'm sitting there
hacking away at the keyboard.

00:27:08.290 --> 00:27:09.800
It's got to be this.

00:27:09.800 --> 00:27:09.590
It's got to be this.

00:27:09.590 --> 00:27:10.440
It's got to be this.

00:27:10.440 --> 00:27:11.620
It's not this.

00:27:11.620 --> 00:27:15.370
So there is potentially liability for
you to implement a system and

00:27:15.370 --> 00:27:17.930
not get it right,
even though the intention is there.

00:27:17.930 --> 00:27:20.620
So, really, real world scenario,
real important thing for

00:27:20.620 --> 00:27:22.850
you to think about as CISSPs.

00:27:22.850 --> 00:27:26.140
We often talk a lot about design and
how important design is.

00:27:26.140 --> 00:27:29.640
We don't spend a lot of time really
harping on the idea that good design

00:27:29.640 --> 00:27:31.310
equals good security, right.

00:27:31.310 --> 00:27:35.100
Because the system itself is secure,
the problem is it's so frustrating for

00:27:35.100 --> 00:27:38.880
users to use that they are gonna
try to find a way around it.

00:27:38.880 --> 00:27:42.400
I'm so frustrated with that system,
with that vendor, that I really,

00:27:42.400 --> 00:27:45.460
legitimately, am thinking about not
doing business with them anymore,

00:27:45.460 --> 00:27:49.100
not because they did anything wrong,
but because their system is so

00:27:49.100 --> 00:27:51.380
screwed up that I can't
use it the right way.

00:27:51.380 --> 00:27:53.110
It's not convenient for me.

00:27:53.110 --> 00:27:55.110
That is a significant challenge.

00:27:55.110 --> 00:27:56.994
And that is something that
us security professionals,

00:27:56.994 --> 00:27:59.490
we really have to think about as
part of this whole discussion.

00:27:59.490 --> 00:28:03.910
If access control becomes so tedious for
our end users, that they can't use it

00:28:03.910 --> 00:28:08.370
well, they're going to go out of there way
to break the system and make it not work.

00:28:08.370 --> 00:28:11.970
And if they do that then the problem
becomes, we've effectively

00:28:11.970 --> 00:28:15.190
wound up at the same place we were
trying to avoid being by generating and

00:28:15.190 --> 00:28:16.760
creating the system in the first place.

00:28:16.760 --> 00:28:20.670
They're gonna expose information because
they're not doing the right things.

00:28:20.670 --> 00:28:21.700
Negative outcome, right.

00:28:21.700 --> 00:28:23.480
So want to make sure we're aware of that,
we're thinking about that,

00:28:23.480 --> 00:28:24.690
we understand that.

00:28:24.690 --> 00:28:28.860
I know I mentioned a couple of times in
previous episodes that the LDAP directory

00:28:28.860 --> 00:28:32.590
standard is the x.500 standard, but I want
to make sure you make that connection

00:28:32.590 --> 00:28:36.210
again here, obviously specifically
in this domain, very relevant,

00:28:36.210 --> 00:28:38.230
very important information
to deliver to you.

00:28:38.230 --> 00:28:42.500
Here, we talk about x.500 being
the international standard for

00:28:42.500 --> 00:28:43.565
directory services.

00:28:43.565 --> 00:28:47.435
X.400 is the international standard for
electronic messaging.

00:28:47.435 --> 00:28:51.575
So email systems use x.400
standard conventions.

00:28:51.575 --> 00:28:55.314
Directory service systems use
x.500 directory service standards,

00:28:55.314 --> 00:28:56.585
please be aware of that.

00:28:56.585 --> 00:29:00.872
There actually is an ISO standard for
x.500,

00:29:00.872 --> 00:29:07.819
9594-1: 2014 meaning it's 2014
year update for the standard.

00:29:07.819 --> 00:29:11.694
But ISO 9594-1 is actually the update for
the x.500 standard for

00:29:11.694 --> 00:29:14.320
directory services in
case you're interested.

00:29:14.320 --> 00:29:15.200
Don't need to know that,

00:29:15.200 --> 00:29:18.920
by the way, just to be clear,
not exam critical information.

00:29:18.920 --> 00:29:20.660
Really just more for your own benefit.

00:29:20.660 --> 00:29:23.535
And then we talked a lot about LDAP
generically it's the protocol.

00:29:23.535 --> 00:29:26.770
Lightweight Directory Access Protocol that
is used to derive directory services,

00:29:26.770 --> 00:29:29.720
so just keep that in mind be aware
of that obviously important for

00:29:29.720 --> 00:29:30.580
you to think about.

00:29:30.580 --> 00:29:34.980
When we think about LDAPs specifically and
I'm gonna put Mike on the spot again but

00:29:34.980 --> 00:29:38.530
I'm gonna give him a chance this time
I'm gonna ask him to pay attention to me

00:29:38.530 --> 00:29:41.790
I'm also gonna give him a preview
of what I'm about to ask him.

00:29:41.790 --> 00:29:45.640
Mike's ears just perked up and
his eyes just lit up when I said that.

00:29:45.640 --> 00:29:48.800
So LDAP, let's talk about LDAP for
just a second, right.

00:29:48.800 --> 00:29:51.300
So we know LDAP is a protocol that's
used for directory services, and

00:29:51.300 --> 00:29:54.270
we know that when we implement it in
the active directory, for instance,

00:29:54.270 --> 00:29:56.770
in Windows,
that it gives us certain capabilities.

00:29:56.770 --> 00:30:00.200
Do you know what the actual common
attributes that we often talk about for

00:30:00.200 --> 00:30:01.320
LDAP are?

00:30:01.320 --> 00:30:02.540
>> The common attributes?

00:30:02.540 --> 00:30:04.300
>> Common attributes.

00:30:04.300 --> 00:30:06.580
Now, that's probably not the best way,
it may not be the best and

00:30:06.580 --> 00:30:09.410
easiest way to ask that question,
cuz that's not real clear.

00:30:09.410 --> 00:30:12.270
Right, what we're really talking about
though and if I explain it this way,

00:30:12.270 --> 00:30:14.300
I think Mike will definitely
make the connection and get it.

00:30:14.300 --> 00:30:18.530
What we're really talking about is
what are the components that make up

00:30:18.530 --> 00:30:22.890
naming convention for an object within
LDAP, within the active directory.

00:30:22.890 --> 00:30:24.470
>> Our distinguished name.

00:30:24.470 --> 00:30:27.750
>> Right so we have distinguished name,
we have a common name right, so

00:30:27.750 --> 00:30:29.310
distinguished name and common name right?

00:30:29.310 --> 00:30:32.630
We have the domain component, so we have
the distinguished name, common name, and

00:30:32.630 --> 00:30:33.660
domain component.

00:30:33.660 --> 00:30:38.480
And we have the container, which is
the O.U. Organizational Unit, right.

00:30:38.480 --> 00:30:43.900
So in LDAP, we have a very specific,
very prescribed way of creating an object.

00:30:43.900 --> 00:30:47.425
An object is going to be the user
object or the computer object.

00:30:47.425 --> 00:30:49.855
I know we say objects are data here,
I get that.

00:30:49.855 --> 00:30:54.285
But in the language of LDAPs specifically,
we talk about it being a user object,

00:30:54.285 --> 00:30:56.235
even though it really is the subject,
just so

00:30:56.235 --> 00:30:58.420
you understand that and
we confuse you totally.

00:30:58.420 --> 00:30:59.995
>> [LAUGH]
>> Notice we spend all this time building

00:30:59.995 --> 00:31:03.570
that knowledge the right way Throw
that out, and we'll reset everything.

00:31:03.570 --> 00:31:07.640
So when we create the user object in LDAP,
we actually have four distinct component

00:31:07.640 --> 00:31:12.370
parts that have to be provided or somehow
programmed in to the creation strength.

00:31:12.370 --> 00:31:15.900
We need the distinguished name,
the common name, the domain component,

00:31:15.900 --> 00:31:18.870
which is effectively the domain name,
the name space, and

00:31:18.870 --> 00:31:21.770
the O.U., which is the container
within the directory service

00:31:21.770 --> 00:31:24.700
that that object is
actually gonna exist in.

00:31:24.700 --> 00:31:25.620
So I want to make sure we understand.

That's why you need ultimately,

>> Alright.

I keep talking about this with Mike.

We need some minions right, or

That's exactly what you do.

If you do something

That's my particular take on things.

So that's why we need those kind

It's very, very important.

All right, so we talked about a whole

our ability to understand

But until we do that just keep in mind and

The importance of the ability to manage

It's the ability to understand how to

00:23:07.336 --> 00:23:10.766

00:23:16.705 --> 00:23:20.030

00:23:20.030 --> 00:23:23.990

00:23:23.990 --> 00:23:28.700

501
00:23:28.700 --> 00:23:30.330
Then that's a bad thing, right?

502
00:23:30.330 --> 00:23:34.370
Because we have effectively,
falsely accepted you into the system.

503
00:23:34.370 --> 00:23:35.600
You weren't supposed to be there, but

504
00:23:35.600 --> 00:23:37.910

505
00:23:37.910 --> 00:23:39.270
It's one type of error.

506
00:23:39.270 --> 00:23:43.516
There are two types of errors we deal with
in biometric systems, false accepts or

507
00:23:43.516 --> 00:23:44.395
false rejects.

508
00:23:44.395 --> 00:23:46.943
False rejects are where
a valid user walks up,

00:23:46.943 --> 00:23:49.631
swipes their finger, and
is not allowed entry.

510
00:23:49.631 --> 00:23:50.687
That's a false reject.

511
00:23:50.687 --> 00:23:53.892
You should not have been rejected,
but we did reject you.

512
00:23:53.892 --> 00:23:57.068
When a non-authorized user walks up and
scans and is allowed entry,

513
00:23:57.068 --> 00:23:58.890
it's called a false accept.

514
00:23:58.890 --> 00:24:02.180
Of the two, clearly,
the false accepts are worse, right?

515
00:24:02.180 --> 00:24:03.980
We don't want the bad users getting in.

516
00:24:03.980 --> 00:24:08.200
We may upset legitimate users by falsely
rejecting them, but that's okay,

517
00:24:08.200 --> 00:24:09.560
they'll get over it, right?

518
00:24:09.560 --> 00:24:11.890
What's important is we don't
wanna let the bad people in.

519
00:24:11.890 --> 00:24:13.080
So we don't want false acceptance,

520
00:24:13.080 --> 00:24:15.110
and we wanna obviously
minimize both errors, right?

521
00:24:15.110 --> 00:24:17.050
Because obviously both are problematic.

522
00:24:17.050 --> 00:24:20.160
Now what we do is we measure these,

523
00:24:20.160 --> 00:24:22.940
so effectively on a grid if you
want to think of it that way.

524
00:24:22.940 --> 00:24:26.411
And we track them, right, it's gonna look
almost like a bell curve, right, so you're

525
00:24:26.411 --> 00:24:29.700
gonna have a line that goes something like
this for the number of false accepts.

526
00:24:29.700 --> 00:24:31.890
A line that goes something like this for
false rejects.

527
00:24:31.890 --> 00:24:32.930
Where they cross over and

528
00:24:32.930 --> 00:24:36.450
meet in the middle, somewhere those
two lines are gonna intersect.

529
00:24:36.450 --> 00:24:39.500
That's called the CER, or
the cross over error rate.

530
00:24:39.500 --> 00:24:42.050
That is the point at which
the number of false accepts and

531
00:24:42.050 --> 00:24:44.252
false rejects is essentially the same.

532
00:24:44.252 --> 00:24:48.040
We wanna manage that number
down as low as possible.

533
00:24:48.040 --> 00:24:51.570
By lowering that threshold,
we are effectively tuning the system,

534
00:24:51.570 --> 00:24:55.350
optimizing it, making it run better,
because it's not rejecting or

535
00:24:55.350 --> 00:25:00.120
accepting people as often falsely, so
it's gonna have less errors overall.

536
00:25:00.120 --> 00:25:02.260
So the CER, the crossover error rate,

537
00:25:02.260 --> 00:25:05.300
it's a very important measure
of biometric system accuracy.

538
00:25:05.300 --> 00:25:08.170
And you wanna make sure you know
the difference between false reject and

539
00:25:08.170 --> 00:25:09.670
false accept errors.

540
00:25:09.670 --> 00:25:10.959
Wanna make sure we're aware of those.

32

Making sure that desktop

33

34

39

So just wanna make sure

48

We've talked about some of these other

52
00:02:33.350 --> 00:02:35.160
We want to also think about the fact that

00:02:36.340 --> 00:02:40.420
when we are going to be validating
somebody who is coming in and

54

authenticating and

55

After we authorize them, giving them

want to make sure we focus on

57
00:02:49.350 --> 00:02:53.110
Generically the idea of identity proofing

58
00:02:53.110 --> 00:02:56.986
that process which is the idea of
validating the user's identity.

59
00:02:56.986 --> 00:03:02.350
So for instance, if I walk up to

60
00:03:02.350 --> 00:03:05.360
right, and I have on the magic
bands that they use now, and

>> [CROSSTALK] any park?

>> I can walk in any park in the world,

65

You wouldn't know by looking at me that

00:03:16.960 --> 00:03:17.470
in my life.

67
00:03:17.470 --> 00:03:20.140
But I've retained certain elements
of that, some more than others.

68
00:03:20.140 --> 00:03:24.110
But if you have a magic band, right,
it's basically a Disney wristwatch.

69
00:03:24.110 --> 00:03:28.380
It's one of those grey bands that they

70

And what you do is you walk up and

you may have to do your

00:03:37.144 --> 00:03:41.134
They now use them for the hotel access if

74
00:03:41.134 --> 00:03:45.560
to effectively log in and open up the door

75
00:03:45.560 --> 00:03:47.620
So it's kind of an all in one device,

76
00:03:47.620 --> 00:03:54.110
But if you have a magic band,

And so when you do this,

And so you show up, and they give

If you stay on the grounds at the hotel,
with them, in the Disney parks,

86
00:04:24.115 --> 00:04:27.446
you get a box with your magic bands

00:04:27.446 --> 00:04:28.583
They have your name on them.

88

Obviously, Disney is

They're paying like $0.02 apiece, I'm

00:04:45.380 --> 00:04:46.380
So if you stay on the grounds,

So you can have a pink one or

when you show up and you do that,
