102
00:05:02.860 --> 00:05:06.780
If you don't have that because you're
staying on the grounds, when you go and

103
00:05:06.780 --> 00:05:09.360
you get your tickets or
you buy like a one day ticket or whatever.

104
00:05:09.360 --> 00:05:12.660
Then they'll give you the equivalent
to let you scan in for the day and

105
00:05:12.660 --> 00:05:14.300
it's like a single use kinda thing.

106
00:05:14.300 --> 00:05:19.520
However you do it, you can't just walk up
and say well, here's my receipt I paid.

107
00:05:19.520 --> 00:05:20.100
Can you let me in?

108
00:05:20.100 --> 00:05:23.050
Because that's not the identity
proofing system that they use,

109
00:05:23.050 --> 00:05:26.470
they actually sell you a ticket or
device that lets you prove your identity.

110
00:05:26.470 --> 00:05:28.820
Cuz they're linking it
to your biometric scan.

111
00:05:28.820 --> 00:05:32.648
So as a result, identity proofing becomes
really important because we have to

112
00:05:32.648 --> 00:05:35.209
understand how that works
in the systems we're in.

113
00:05:35.209 --> 00:05:39.539
So a lot of times in many companies,
you will have some sort of identity badge.

114
00:05:39.539 --> 00:05:43.548
It's a smart card typically, it's got your
picture on it, it's a swipe of some kind,

115
00:05:43.548 --> 00:05:46.770
so it's usually got a chip embedded
in it that'll store identities.

116
00:05:46.770 --> 00:05:49.390
Maybe digital certificates,
things like that and

117
00:05:49.390 --> 00:05:51.350
then you can also put that into a reader.

118
00:05:51.350 --> 00:05:52.900
In the US military we call them CAC cards,

119
00:05:52.900 --> 00:05:54.670
in the US government and
government and military.

120
00:05:54.670 --> 00:05:57.249
Common access control cards,
although we're moving away from those.

121
00:05:57.249 --> 00:05:59.593
Slowly but surely, but they use CAC cards.

122
00:05:59.593 --> 00:06:03.688
And so CAC cards are basically your
military ID with a chip embedded in it,

123
00:06:03.688 --> 00:06:06.463
a smart chip that stores
your digital identity and

124
00:06:06.463 --> 00:06:11.041
is then inserted into a USB reader that
effectively then opens up a secure system.

125
00:06:11.041 --> 00:06:14.726
Where it let's you log on and get into
whatever kinda systems you may need, so

126
00:06:14.726 --> 00:06:17.277
when you have that kind of
a thought process going on,

127
00:06:17.277 --> 00:06:19.109
that's how we do identity proofing.

128
00:06:19.109 --> 00:06:21.040
We're using that particular tool,
whatever it is.

129
00:06:21.040 --> 00:06:24.790
So, want to be thinking about identity
proofing and understand that this concept

130
00:06:24.790 --> 00:06:28.600
is really how we begin the process
of kicking off, getting somebody to

131
00:06:28.600 --> 00:06:32.040
identify themselves, and ultimately
then figure out how that's gonna work.

132
00:06:32.040 --> 00:06:33.950
Remember, we can also
do this electronically.

133
00:06:33.950 --> 00:06:36.500
We often do it electronically,
we're not talking individuals.

134
00:06:36.500 --> 00:06:39.310
We're passing these credentials
electronically back and forth.

135
00:06:39.310 --> 00:06:42.196
So, we talk about the fact that we're
going to automate, but also that we're

136
00:06:42.196 --> 00:06:44.970
gonna gather this information and
store it electronically in systems.

137
00:06:44.970 --> 00:06:47.879
We haven't really talked about
federation up till now, but

138
00:06:47.879 --> 00:06:51.380
federation of Federated ID Management
is also very important.

139
00:06:51.380 --> 00:06:56.180
Federation is the idea of extending trust
to a partner in a business relationship.

140
00:06:56.180 --> 00:06:58.930
So if Mike and
I are gonna go into business and

141
00:06:58.930 --> 00:07:03.000
we're gonna set up two separate
companies that do similar things but

142
00:07:03.000 --> 00:07:05.060
we're not directly gonna
compete with each other.

143
00:07:05.060 --> 00:07:07.950
As a matter of a fact, one of us may be
able to supply the other with a critical

144
00:07:07.950 --> 00:07:11.500
part for
their particular item that they're making.

145
00:07:11.500 --> 00:07:13.251
A sprocket or whatever it is.

146
00:07:13.251 --> 00:07:16.860
And so if Mike's making stuff and
I can supply raw parts to him,

147
00:07:16.860 --> 00:07:21.982
then we may develop a relationship that's
just a buyer, supplier kinda relationship.

148
00:07:21.982 --> 00:07:25.109
But if we wanna take that a little bit
deeper, integrate it a little bit more

149
00:07:25.109 --> 00:07:27.604
formally, we may choose to
do what's called federating.

150
00:07:27.604 --> 00:07:31.947
Federating allows Mike and I to negotiate
trust relationship between our two

151
00:07:31.947 --> 00:07:35.638
companies, allows us to tie our
systems more closely together.

152
00:07:35.638 --> 00:07:40.268
So Mike may have a provisioning system for
inventory management that he wants me

153
00:07:40.268 --> 00:07:44.774
to tie into, so that I can know when he's
running low on parts that I provide.

154
00:07:44.774 --> 00:07:46.791
And that I can automatically
ship them to him, and

155
00:07:46.791 --> 00:07:49.671
he doesn't have to worry about getting
on the phone every three days and

156
00:07:49.671 --> 00:07:52.680
running through a long drawn-out
process of managing inventory.

157
00:07:52.680 --> 00:07:54.742
We can automate that whole system,
that kind of thing.

158
00:07:54.742 --> 00:07:58.522
So what we call JIT, or Just In Time
delivery, is something we can set up and

159
00:07:58.522 --> 00:08:01.342
use, but it would have to be
through a federated model So

160
00:08:01.342 --> 00:08:03.626
federation's the idea of extending trust.

161
00:08:03.626 --> 00:08:07.112
And the idea of trust is identification
and management of identification of

162
00:08:07.112 --> 00:08:10.390
individuals, so that we understand
who they are in authorizing them.

163
00:08:10.390 --> 00:08:13.960
So, federated ID management,
very big area,

164
00:08:13.960 --> 00:08:16.050
very popular today within access control.

165
00:08:16.050 --> 00:08:18.270
So we wanna understand
the value of federation.

166
00:08:18.270 --> 00:08:22.270
Many businesses that are strategically
partnering will federate.

167
00:08:22.270 --> 00:08:25.183
When we go through a merger and
acquisition, what we call M and

168
00:08:25.183 --> 00:08:25.805
A activity.

169
00:08:25.805 --> 00:08:29.900
When we buy a company,
we effectively are acquiring their assets.

170
00:08:29.900 --> 00:08:34.000
We may actually choose to federate with
the IT infrastructure, as opposed to just

171
00:08:34.000 --> 00:08:37.180
gobbling it up, and consuming it
directly for a period of time.

172
00:08:37.180 --> 00:08:39.670
So we can integrate
the directory services.

173
00:08:39.670 --> 00:08:42.280
We can integrate the messaging services,
things like that.

174
00:08:42.280 --> 00:08:46.510
It's easier to federate, to extend trust
to do that, than it is to potentially just

175
00:08:46.510 --> 00:08:49.562
consume everything, and
try to pour it all into our system.

176
00:08:49.562 --> 00:08:51.956
Making it really difficult to do that
based on the kinds of systems we're

177
00:08:51.956 --> 00:08:52.477
dealing with.

178
00:08:52.477 --> 00:08:55.966
So instead of keeping them totally
isolated and separate we may effectively

179
00:08:55.966 --> 00:08:59.140
build a trust bridge and the trust
bridge is the federation concept.

180
00:08:59.140 --> 00:09:00.830
That's what we often refer to it as.

181
00:09:00.830 --> 00:09:03.590
So just want to think about that and
obviously understand that.

182
00:09:03.590 --> 00:09:06.300
We use certain languages,
certain security languages and

183
00:09:06.300 --> 00:09:08.810
protocols to be able to
drive these concepts.

184
00:09:08.810 --> 00:09:10.460
I've mentioned SSAML, security search and

185
00:09:10.460 --> 00:09:14.890
markup language, in one of our episodes
at some point prior to this conversation.

186
00:09:14.890 --> 00:09:17.850
But it was I'm sure just in passing,
didn't really spend a lot of time on it.

187
00:09:17.850 --> 00:09:20.370
SSAML is, currently version 2.0,

188
00:09:20.370 --> 00:09:24.870
is the version of an XML based protocol
that is gonna effectively be used

189
00:09:24.870 --> 00:09:27.950
to be able to drive a lot of these
security things that we're talking about.

190
00:09:27.950 --> 00:09:32.170
We use it to be able to
pass security information,

191
00:09:32.170 --> 00:09:36.720
pass what we call assertions back and
forth with regards to authentication,

192
00:09:36.720 --> 00:09:39.570
with regards to authorization,
with regards to identity.

193
00:09:39.570 --> 00:09:41.670
So, we're effectively
gonna use this language,

194
00:09:41.670 --> 00:09:45.140
it's kind of an accepted standard language
that most systems can understand and

195
00:09:45.140 --> 00:09:49.150
use to effectively drive authentication
in many of our systems today.

196
00:09:49.150 --> 00:09:53.480
So, SSAML is a language that the security
practitioners, security professional,

197
00:09:53.480 --> 00:09:57.110
the CISSP would definitely wanna make
sure they are aware of the necessity,

198
00:09:57.110 --> 00:09:58.220
heard about before.

199
00:09:58.220 --> 00:10:01.550
That they have knowledge of and
that they identify, and assert, or

200
00:10:01.550 --> 00:10:05.540
rather coordinate and really think
of with regards to access control.

201
00:10:05.540 --> 00:10:07.430
This is where we tend to see SSAML.

202
00:10:07.430 --> 00:10:10.228
So SSAML relies on a bunch
of different standards.

203
00:10:10.228 --> 00:10:12.754
The most important one
is the XML language,

204
00:10:12.754 --> 00:10:16.721
because XML really underlies what
SSAML is and what it's able to do.

205
00:10:16.721 --> 00:10:18.680
And so XML is used with SSAML.

206
00:10:18.680 --> 00:10:22.371
We use SOAP, which is a service
oriented architecture for

207
00:10:22.371 --> 00:10:24.690
being able to provide services.

208
00:10:24.690 --> 00:10:26.190
We're gonna use HTTP, so

209
00:10:26.190 --> 00:10:29.370
web related protocols are used
as part of SSAML as well.

210
00:10:29.370 --> 00:10:33.260
So these are all things that SSAML

501
00:23:27.450 --> 00:23:29.540
You imagine if I come to you and say, hey,

502
00:23:29.540 --> 00:23:33.100
can you give me kind of a summary of
what's going on in the last 24 hours here?

503
00:23:33.100 --> 00:23:34.680
I'm trying to get caught up.

504
00:23:34.680 --> 00:23:36.800
And you can't tell me anything,
cuz you don't know.

505
00:23:36.800 --> 00:23:39.945
You could say, well, I'm here and

506
00:23:39.945 --> 00:23:42.936
don't really know much more than that,
I'm sitting in a chair.

507
00:23:42.936 --> 00:23:44.140
>> [LAUGH]
>> Not really sure.

508
00:23:44.140 --> 00:23:47.380
I know a lot of stuff's happening,
but, it's happening outside, and

509
00:23:47.380 --> 00:23:50.770
I don't see what's out there,
and nothing's gone on in here.

510
00:23:50.770 --> 00:23:51.979
I don't know what to tell you.

511
00:23:51.979 --> 00:23:55.138
That would not be a very useful
conversation of either one of us.

512
00:23:55.138 --> 00:23:57.857
So what we need to understand is
exactly what's happening in a given

513
00:23:57.857 --> 00:23:58.678
the moment in time.

514
00:23:58.678 --> 00:24:01.837
We talked about the value of NTP,
Network Time Protocol, and

515
00:24:01.837 --> 00:24:05.851
the value of time stamping things to
authenticate when they're occurring and

516
00:24:05.851 --> 00:24:10.320
to understand contextually what was going
on around them at that moment in time.

517
00:24:10.320 --> 00:24:11.940
Logs give us that context.

518
00:24:11.940 --> 00:24:14.800
They tell us hey,
at this moment in time on this system,

519
00:24:14.800 --> 00:24:19.190
this person was doing this or tried to
do this but failed for whatever reason.

520
00:24:19.190 --> 00:24:20.010
They couldn't get in.

521
00:24:20.010 --> 00:24:20.990
Things didn't work.

522
00:24:20.990 --> 00:24:22.560
It's very important information.

523
00:24:22.560 --> 00:24:26.100
When I do assessment work, when I do
audit work, when I do forensics work for

524
00:24:26.100 --> 00:24:29.280
customers, one of the most important
things we look at are log files.

525
00:24:29.280 --> 00:24:33.250
We don't have logs of the systems that
are affected, the gateway devices,

526
00:24:33.250 --> 00:24:36.490
right, all the systems that may have
been touched by the compromise or

527
00:24:36.490 --> 00:24:39.530
the breach, or that we're assessing,
looking for vulnerabilities or whatever.

528
00:24:39.530 --> 00:24:42.530
If we don't have logs,
it's incredibly difficult.

529
00:24:42.530 --> 00:24:46.590
I would hazard a guess to say it may
be impossible to do our job properly.

530
00:24:46.590 --> 00:24:48.180
Cuz we don't have a record.

531
00:24:48.180 --> 00:24:51.630
We have no way of understanding and
developing the knowledge of what was going

532
00:24:51.630 --> 00:24:55.270
on in the system over the period of time
that we're looking at or we're examining.

533
00:24:55.270 --> 00:24:57.220
So this is very, very, very important.

534
00:24:57.220 --> 00:25:02.102
Log management generically is the idea of,
as the name implies, right, gathering up,

535
00:25:02.102 --> 00:25:03.490
managing the logs.

536
00:25:03.490 --> 00:25:06.460
It could be on a local machine,
just one machine, one device.

537
00:25:06.460 --> 00:25:08.810
Logs locally there,
we get them, we look at them.

538
00:25:08.810 --> 00:25:11.090
Things like Event Viewer, right,
would be helpful for that.

539
00:25:11.090 --> 00:25:15.300
But we've also talked about SEM systems,
where we can gather log information up and

540
00:25:15.300 --> 00:25:17.050
we can centrally manage it.

541
00:25:17.050 --> 00:25:19.075
We can put it into a common area.

542
00:25:19.075 --> 00:25:22.675
Gather it up, if you will, using
technology such as Netflow, which is Cisco

543
00:25:22.675 --> 00:25:27.415
proprietary technology for grabbing
information, logging information from

544
00:25:27.415 --> 00:25:31.805
multiple devices and centrally sending
it to a Netflow server and managing it.

545
00:25:31.805 --> 00:25:35.105
The open source version of that,
the non-proprietary Cisco,

546
00:25:35.105 --> 00:25:39.780
meaning the actually, [COUGH]
what

547
00:25:39.780 --> 00:25:41.825
was the snarky comment I was gonna make?

548
00:25:41.825 --> 00:25:43.390
>> [LAUGH]
>> On the cheap version,

549
00:25:43.390 --> 00:25:45.360
you don't have a pay a huge licensing and

550
00:25:45.360 --> 00:25:48.690
royalty fee for the sFlow,
is what I was trying to say.

551
00:25:48.690 --> 00:25:51.246
sFlow is kind of the open
source version of NetFlow.

552
00:25:51.246 --> 00:25:55.145
NetFlow's supported by many vendors and is
implemented by the Mware for instance and

553
00:25:55.145 --> 00:25:56.564
their virtualization stack.

554
00:25:56.564 --> 00:26:00.505
They support it, but you obviously have
to pay a premium in effect to use that

555
00:26:00.505 --> 00:26:05.210
technology because you're using a licensed
proprietary version of something.

556
00:26:05.210 --> 00:26:08.780
sFlow is just simply the open source
version that's available in most systems,

557
00:26:08.780 --> 00:26:11.000
whether you are supporting Cisco gear or
not.

558
00:26:11.000 --> 00:26:15.610
Either one of these systems are gonna be
able to effectively grab log information

559
00:26:15.610 --> 00:26:17.370
and send it to a collector.

560
00:26:17.370 --> 00:26:21.155
A collector is just generically, a server
that is gonna be centrally gathering.

561
00:26:21.155 --> 00:26:22.825
And then monitoring and

562
00:26:22.825 --> 00:26:26.065
ultimately managing the logs that are
coming in from all these different points.

563
00:26:26.065 --> 00:26:29.915
I don't know if you've ever heard of Kiwi,
Kiwi's one of those old syslog servers

564
00:26:29.915 --> 00:26:32.655
that I think SolarWinds had
that they put in market.

565
00:26:32.655 --> 00:26:34.257
They still have a free version.

566
00:26:34.257 --> 00:26:37.085
So syslog servers are kind
of what our first gen

567
00:26:37.085 --> 00:26:38.915
technology that we're talking about.

568
00:26:38.915 --> 00:26:42.075
SEM systems are really just
like syslog on steroids,

569
00:26:42.075 --> 00:26:46.380
because what they've done is they've
taken the ability to aggregate logs and

570
00:26:46.380 --> 00:26:49.270
brought business intelligence and
big data analytics to the party.

571
00:26:49.270 --> 00:26:53.100
And have now effectively given us
a platform that we can look at logs,

572
00:26:53.100 --> 00:26:56.240
manage them, assess them,
report on them and analyze them and

573
00:26:56.240 --> 00:26:57.720
visualize them in real time.

574
00:26:57.720 --> 00:27:01.220
So data visualization,
business intelligence, dashboarding,

575
00:27:01.220 --> 00:27:04.980
scorecarding, these are all capabilities
of a SEM system traditionally.

576
00:27:04.980 --> 00:27:08.800
And things like Splunk, for instance,
are gonna be good examples of this.

577
00:27:08.800 --> 00:27:11.120
There's a whole bunch of them
out there that can be used.

578
00:27:11.120 --> 00:27:13.210
A lot of them are very good,
very powerful, but

579
00:27:13.210 --> 00:27:15.110
they are big and they are expensive.

580
00:27:15.110 --> 00:27:16.850
So you just have to think
about what those are.

581
00:27:16.850 --> 00:27:20.010
A log management traditionally is one of
the things that from an assessment and

582
00:27:20.010 --> 00:27:23.260
testing standpoint, we have to be
focused on and thinking about as well.

583
00:27:23.260 --> 00:27:26.090
We don't often think about logging and
log files and

584
00:27:26.090 --> 00:27:28.586
log management as part of assessment and
testing.

585
00:27:28.586 --> 00:27:32.280
But it actually is going to play a very
crucial role in giving us the data and

586
00:27:32.280 --> 00:27:34.670
the documentary evidence that
we have to assess against.

587
00:27:34.670 --> 00:27:36.740
So it actually is a very
important part of what we do.

588
00:27:36.740 --> 00:27:39.680
We have to think about security software
overall as part of assessment and

589
00:27:39.680 --> 00:27:40.370
testing as well.

590
00:27:40.370 --> 00:27:43.442
You know we have anti-malware and
anti-virus software, pretty common,

591
00:27:43.442 --> 00:27:44.580
pretty traditional.

592
00:27:44.580 --> 00:27:47.637
We have intrusion detection,
intrusion prevention systems,

593
00:27:47.637 --> 00:27:49.285
talked a lot about these already.

594
00:27:49.285 --> 00:27:53.346
Things like remote access softwares
such as VPN gateways, radio solutions,

595
00:27:53.346 --> 00:27:54.464
we mentioned those.

596
00:27:54.464 --> 00:27:57.947
We have proxies, we've talked about
application level proxies on the web.

597
00:27:57.947 --> 00:28:02.323
We've talked about firewalls, we've talked
about vulnerability assessment systems,

598
00:28:02.323 --> 00:28:05.517
talked about authentication systems,
access control systems.

599
00:28:05.517 --> 00:28:08.234
All these things are gonna
play a part in security and

600
00:28:08.234 --> 00:28:12.621
security software that is gonna be able to
provide these capabilities as also part of

601
00:28:12.621 --> 00:28:14.320
assessment and testing.

602
00:28:14.320 --> 00:28:18.172
Not because necessarily,
we need the information coming from them,

603
00:28:18.172 --> 00:28:19.776
although we certainly do.

604
00:28:19.776 --> 00:28:22.687
What we really need to do though is
think about this as being the target of

605
00:28:22.687 --> 00:28:24.970
the assessments,
the target of the testing, right.

606
00:28:24.970 --> 00:28:27.610
We wanna test how good these systems are.

607
00:28:27.610 --> 00:28:28.440
How are they configured?

608
00:28:28.440 --> 00:28:29.740
Are they doing their job?

609
00:28:29.740 --> 00:28:30.890
If not, why not?

610
00:28:30.890 --> 00:28:33.060
If they are,
let's make sure we do more of that, right.

611
00:28:33.060 --> 00:28:34.660
Because that's good,
we wanna keep doing that.

612
00:28:34.660 --> 00:28:36.690
So wanna be thinking about that.

613
00:28:36.690 --> 00:28:39.500
We get a lot of common data in
operating systems that's gonna

614
00:28:39.500 --> 00:28:40.790
help us drive security.

615
00:28:40.790 --> 00:28:42.340
Operating system related events,

616
00:28:42.340 --> 00:28:46.790
we talked about with logging,
task manager events, process information.

617
00:28:46.790 --> 00:28:50.090
This is all stuff that may be valuable and
stuff that we wanna be thinking about.

618
00:28:50.090 --> 00:28:53.280
Think about all the stuff that gets logged
in your systems on a regular basis.

619
00:28:53.280 --> 00:28:55.440
Think about the volume of
information that's there.

620
00:28:55.440 --> 00:28:56.770
How can you make heads or
tails out of that?

621
00:28:56.770 --> 00:28:57.740
It may be tough.

622
00:28:57.740 --> 00:29:00.280
It may be something we have to think
about and obviously understand.

623
00:29:00.280 --> 00:29:04.100
So log analysis is gonna be
very crucial to what we do and

624
00:29:04.100 --> 00:29:06.360
again, these kind of systems
can help us to do this.

625
00:29:06.360 --> 00:29:09.470
But keep in mind the log analysis
is often reactive, right.

626
00:29:09.470 --> 00:29:11.785
It's often something we do after the fact.

627
00:29:11.785 --> 00:29:13.425
I can't remember the last time, honestly.

628
00:29:13.425 --> 00:29:14.775
And I'm being honest
with you when I say this.

629
00:29:14.775 --> 00:29:18.025
Now, I can't really remember, that means
I'm kind of implying that I haven't been

630
00:29:18.025 --> 00:29:20.035
honest up until this point, right?

631
00:29:20.035 --> 00:29:23.407
So let me put on my yes,
I'm gonna tell you the truth hat.

632
00:29:23.407 --> 00:29:24.517
So what I'm saying or

633
00:29:24.517 --> 00:29:28.164
what I'm implying is when I talk
about log analysis is the following.

634
00:29:28.164 --> 00:29:31.148
The idea that more often than not,
if you're honest with yourself and

635
00:29:31.148 --> 00:29:34.487
most security professionals are honest
with each other, in a candid moment,

636
00:29:34.487 --> 00:29:37.082
they will tell you that they
don't really ever look at logs.

637
00:29:37.082 --> 00:29:40.682
Until they have a problem, they're going
back to research what went wrong, right.

638
00:29:40.682 --> 00:29:42.789
So, we often look at them reactively,
we look at them post-incident,

639
00:29:42.789 --> 00:29:46.797
post-breach, because we know there's
stuff there that's important.

640
00:29:46.797 --> 00:29:51.540
But if we and we also know, right, that if
we have been looking at them proactively

641
00:29:51.540 --> 00:29:54.860
and have really been tracking and
continuously monitoring, we may have

642
00:29:54.860 --> 00:29:58.460
actually been able to stop this event
from occurring, whatever the event was.

643
00:29:58.460 --> 00:29:59.780
But because we're so busy doing so

644
00:29:59.780 --> 00:30:02.210
many other things,
we just really don't have time.

645
00:30:02.210 --> 00:30:04.400
I mean, who has time to sit around and
read log files every day?

646
00:30:04.400 --> 00:30:06.470
It's tough to do, right?

647
00:30:06.470 --> 00:30:08.310
There's just so
many other things going on.

648
00:30:08.310 --> 00:30:11.430
This is one of the reasons we need
automated systems that can track and

649
00:30:11.430 --> 00:30:12.250
monitor activity.

650
00:30:12.250 --> 00:30:15.780
So IBS, IPS solutions become
very important for this.

651
00:30:15.780 --> 00:30:19.400
This is why we need continuous monitoring
because we have systems that will

652
00:30:19.400 --> 00:30:20.530
always stay awake.

653
00:30:20.530 --> 00:30:25.420
If you remember in, I think it was
Terminator 3, in another movie reference,

654
00:30:25.420 --> 00:30:27.300
pop culture time,
we should have a sign for that.

655
00:30:27.300 --> 00:30:28.952
Pop culture could pop up, right?

656
00:30:28.952 --> 00:30:34.380
So in, I think it was Terminator 3, where
at some point the Terminator character,

657
00:30:34.380 --> 00:30:37.400
Arnold Schwarzenegger,
is now become the good guy, right?

658
00:30:37.400 --> 00:30:39.680
And he's trying to protect everybody.

659
00:30:39.680 --> 00:30:44.880
And, at one point, the mother says
she's back at one of these things.

660
00:30:44.880 --> 00:30:49.060
She says, at some point, hey, I need
somebody who effectively is always gonna

661
00:30:49.060 --> 00:30:52.860
be there, is always gonna watch,
is always gonna protect him, and

662
00:30:52.860 --> 00:30:56.050
this is kind of why I made the Terminator
into the good guy to do this.

663
00:30:56.050 --> 00:30:57.580
Because he never sleeps, right.

664
00:30:57.580 --> 00:30:59.680
He's always there and
he's never gonna stop.

665
00:30:59.680 --> 00:31:03.750
He's just always gonna be there
protecting this vital resource we have.

666
00:31:03.750 --> 00:31:07.070
So the general idea is
that we can automate it.

667
00:31:07.070 --> 00:31:10.070
We can do this so
we can always protect, right.

668
00:31:10.070 --> 00:31:13.200
And it's important to understand
that if we do this, and

669
00:31:13.200 --> 00:31:16.750
we do it well, we can actually
not necessarily win all the time.

670
00:31:16.750 --> 00:31:19.100
Because there are still gonna be attacks
that'll happen without our knowledge.

671
00:31:19.100 --> 00:31:21.220
And they're gonna come and
we're not gonna see them coming.

672
00:31:21.220 --> 00:31:23.870
But we're gonna probably find
a lot more of these attacks.

673
00:31:23.870 --> 00:31:26.290
We're probably gonna be more
successful at stopping them.

674
00:31:26.290 --> 00:31:28.198
And so
this is something else to think about.

675
00:31:28.198 --> 00:31:32.110
And something that you as CISSPs really
need to think about and understand.

676
00:31:32.110 --> 00:31:35.420
How do we get the organization to
be more aware, more proactive?

677
00:31:35.420 --> 00:31:38.700
How do I move them into that direction and
that frame of mind?

678
00:31:38.700 --> 00:31:41.160
This is part of what assessment and
testing is all about.

679
00:31:41.160 --> 00:31:44.380
If we can understand and
validate current state, we can

680
00:31:44.380 --> 00:31:47.660
figure out how to become more proactive
and stop things before they start.

681
00:31:47.660 --> 00:31:48.650
>> Great information, Adam.

682
00:31:48.650 --> 00:31:50.550
You have a good look at assessment and
testing.

683
00:31:50.550 --> 00:31:52.350
I know we've got more information to go.

00:31:52.350 --> 00:31:56.650
It's a pretty big topic, but
a really good, just get started in there.

685
00:31:56.650 --> 00:32:00.530
Looking at that current state, looking at
where it is we wanna be, and then as you

686
00:32:00.530 --> 00:32:05.280
said, examining that gap in between and
figuring out what that root cause is.

687
00:32:05.280 --> 00:32:07.156
So thank you for that,
Adam, appreciate that.

Remember, if you guys want to

00:32:10.778 --> 00:32:14.089

00:32:14.089 --> 00:32:15.390

00:32:16.250 --> 00:32:18.260
So signing off, I'm Mike Rodrick.

I can't do better than that.

So it's obviously gonna be a very
important thought process for us as well.

492
00:21:57.300 --> 00:21:59.780
We have to think about system
operation and maintenance.

493
00:21:59.780 --> 00:22:02.050
What goes on when we're operating and
maintaining a system?

494
00:22:02.050 --> 00:22:04.540
We have to probe and
test during these phases as well

495
00:22:04.540 --> 00:22:08.277
to better understand what the ultimate
limitations of the system maybe.

496
00:22:08.277 --> 00:22:12.095
Your software testing is limited by our
ability to understand the system and

497
00:22:12.095 --> 00:22:13.315
by the access we're given.

498
00:22:13.315 --> 00:22:15.655
So we have to be thinking about
the things that we can do and

499
00:22:15.655 --> 00:22:17.755
the things that may be available to us.

500
00:22:17.755 --> 00:22:20.075
We obviously are going to be
thinking about expected results.

501
00:22:20.075 --> 00:22:21.760
We assume certain things will happen.

502
00:22:21.760 --> 00:22:23.640
We may not expect everything that happens,
so

503
00:22:23.640 --> 00:22:27.820
we have to document what does happen, so
that way we can go back and assess that,

504
00:22:27.820 --> 00:22:31.990
and figure out whether or not it was (a)
expected, and (b), if it was not expected,

505
00:22:31.990 --> 00:22:34.955
then what are we gonna do to be able
to figure out how to address that.

506
00:22:34.955 --> 00:22:40.300
If purple unicorns come spouting out the
top of the server when we do fuzz testing

507
00:22:40.300 --> 00:22:44.120
and we did not expect that, that may be
something we wanna take note of, right?

508
00:22:44.120 --> 00:22:46.260
Because that could be a bit
of a challenge for us.

509
00:22:46.260 --> 00:22:49.330
Unless you like purple unicorns,
in which case it's perfectly acceptable.

510
00:22:49.330 --> 00:22:51.295
I happen to think they're
absolutely lovely myself so

511
00:22:51.295 --> 00:22:53.070
that;s just something to consider, right?

512
00:22:53.070 --> 00:22:56.178
But if we have unexpected behavior, we
wanna make sure we're thinking about that,

513
00:22:56.178 --> 00:22:58.280
and most importantly we're capturing that.

514
00:22:58.280 --> 00:23:00.510
So we understand what
the outcome of that will be.

515
00:23:00.510 --> 00:23:02.590
So, software testing, right?

516
00:23:02.590 --> 00:23:04.270
We've talked a lot about what we're doing.

517
00:23:04.270 --> 00:23:07.050
Are there tenets, are there best
practices, are there things we should be

518
00:23:07.050 --> 00:23:10.970
thinking about doing, as CISSPs,
as security professionals?

519
00:23:10.970 --> 00:23:12.420
Absolutely there are, right?

520
00:23:12.420 --> 00:23:15.460
We should make sure that if we have
expected outcomes that have been

521
00:23:15.460 --> 00:23:18.900
identified as we were just talking about,
we should document them and

522
00:23:18.900 --> 00:23:21.100
we should test to validate
whether they occur.

523
00:23:21.100 --> 00:23:23.340
So in other words if there
are requirements the system is supposed to

524
00:23:23.340 --> 00:23:26.672
meet and we know what those are, we should
make sure our tests reflect those and

525
00:23:26.672 --> 00:23:29.350
see whether that's the actual case or not.

526
00:23:29.350 --> 00:23:33.550
A good test case has a high probability
of exposing errors, more often than not.

527
00:23:33.550 --> 00:23:37.180
And if you have well formed test cases,
you should find errors.

528
00:23:37.180 --> 00:23:38.980
That's one of the key things we look for.

529
00:23:38.980 --> 00:23:42.250
A successful test is considered to be
one that does find an error, and so

530
00:23:42.250 --> 00:23:43.580
we wanna make sure that we know that.

531
00:23:43.580 --> 00:23:45.600
I'm not saying that if you
run a bunch of tests and

532
00:23:45.600 --> 00:23:47.580
you find no errors, that's a failure.

533
00:23:47.580 --> 00:23:49.500
I'm just pointing out that if
you run a bunch of tests and

534
00:23:49.500 --> 00:23:52.740
don't find errors,
we don't consider that successful.

535
00:23:52.740 --> 00:23:54.750
What we say is,
you simply didn't find errors.

536
00:23:54.750 --> 00:23:58.088
The goal, remember, I don't wanna
seem negative when I say this,

537
00:23:58.088 --> 00:24:01.740
but the goal with testing is that we're
looking for what we know is there.

538
00:24:01.740 --> 00:24:05.326
We know errors are there, we're just not
sure if we've identified where they are,

539
00:24:05.326 --> 00:24:06.754
and therefore, why they exist.

540
00:24:06.754 --> 00:24:10.460
The goal by pushing the boundaries here
is to try to figure out what those errors

541
00:24:10.460 --> 00:24:12.870
are, try to make sure we know about them.

542
00:24:12.870 --> 00:24:16.520
If you run a set of tests against
the system you get no errors.

543
00:24:16.520 --> 00:24:17.870
It could mean one of three things right?

544
00:24:17.870 --> 00:24:20.150
It could mean that the tests were
perfectly fine you set them up

545
00:24:20.150 --> 00:24:20.870
the right way.

546
00:24:20.870 --> 00:24:24.170
You did all the right things and there
legitimately are no errors in the system.

547
00:24:24.170 --> 00:24:26.090
We can throw that one off to the side and
forget about it.

548
00:24:26.090 --> 00:24:28.320
>> Right.
>> Cuz that's not really never happens,

549
00:24:28.320 --> 00:24:32.550
like, we put a zero up and, you know,
Mike, put a line in front of that for me.

550
00:24:32.550 --> 00:24:34.160
>> [LAUGH]
>> Put a zero up, we do that, right?

551
00:24:34.160 --> 00:24:35.610
No, we can't see it in the wide shot.

552
00:24:35.610 --> 00:24:37.400
Put a zero up like that,
right, there we go, right?

553
00:24:37.400 --> 00:24:38.360
That's never happened.

554
00:24:38.360 --> 00:24:39.490
That doesn't happen, right?

555
00:24:39.490 --> 00:24:41.490
So we can say that, but
we know that's not the case.

556
00:24:41.490 --> 00:24:43.205
So although that is an option,

557
00:24:43.205 --> 00:24:47.895
reality says that it's probably not
really the case that there aren't errors.

558
00:24:47.895 --> 00:24:52.495
So the second option is you didn't setup
the testing properly to uncover the errors

559
00:24:52.495 --> 00:24:55.675
that are there, which means you have
a flaw in the testing methodology.

560
00:24:55.675 --> 00:24:57.395
The third thing is, you ran the test.

561
00:24:57.395 --> 00:24:58.615
They were set correctly.

562
00:24:58.615 --> 00:25:00.225
But you didn't run them long enough.

563
00:25:00.225 --> 00:25:02.245
Didn't test the right areas of the system.

564
00:25:02.245 --> 00:25:05.875
And or you found errors, but you're
not recognizing them because you don't

565
00:25:05.875 --> 00:25:09.480
understand what you're seeing,
which can also be a problem, legitimately.

566
00:25:09.480 --> 00:25:11.900
You may get bad data that
indicates there are problems, but

567
00:25:11.900 --> 00:25:13.650
you may not know how to interpret it.

568
00:25:13.650 --> 00:25:16.010
And this is also something to
be aware of and to consider.

569
00:25:16.010 --> 00:25:17.770
So again,
this is why we need professionals.

570
00:25:17.770 --> 00:25:21.630
This is why we need trained experts
that understand systems, and

571
00:25:21.630 --> 00:25:23.350
understand output from tests.

572
00:25:23.350 --> 00:25:26.640
To look at it and go, yeah,
this line right here, where it says five.

573
00:25:26.640 --> 00:25:28.650
And it really normally is
only supposed to be three.

574
00:25:28.650 --> 00:25:30.470
That's the problem, right?

575
00:25:30.470 --> 00:25:33.650
Because five indicates something's going
on that's not supposed to be happening.

576
00:25:33.650 --> 00:25:36.850
We may look at that, Mike and I,
and go well that looks like five.

577
00:25:36.850 --> 00:25:37.540
Five's good, right?

578
00:25:37.540 --> 00:25:39.550
I mean it's bigger than four,
less than six.

579
00:25:39.550 --> 00:25:40.820
It's a good number, right?

580
00:25:40.820 --> 00:25:42.230
So five is okay.

581
00:25:42.230 --> 00:25:43.090
We don't know.

582
00:25:43.090 --> 00:25:44.840
The problem is we're not
the ones who can tell you for

583
00:25:44.840 --> 00:25:46.480
sure whether that's good or not.

584
00:25:46.480 --> 00:25:49.280
You need the application expert
that understands the code

585
00:25:49.280 --> 00:25:51.960
that can tell you whether five
is actually an expected outcome.

586
00:25:51.960 --> 00:25:54.160
And if it is let's
identify what it means and

587
00:25:54.160 --> 00:25:56.540
if it's not why the hell is it showing up?

588
00:25:56.540 --> 00:25:57.950
And what's it doing what's it mean?

589
00:25:57.950 --> 00:26:01.490
So you may understand what's there,
but not really get it or

590
00:26:01.490 --> 00:26:04.410
you just may not see it,
either way that can be a problem as well.

591
00:26:04.410 --> 00:26:06.280
That's something else we have
to think about and be aware of.

592
00:26:06.280 --> 00:26:07.680
So these are things you want to

593
00:26:07.680 --> 00:26:10.030
think about when we're talk
about software testing.

594
00:26:10.030 --> 00:26:11.980
When we talk about software testing and
code testing,

595
00:26:11.980 --> 00:26:14.025
we're talking about
different levels of testing.

596
00:26:14.025 --> 00:26:15.655
We talk about unit level testing.

597
00:26:15.655 --> 00:26:18.535
Unit level testing is the fact
that we're gonna test one little

598
00:26:18.535 --> 00:26:20.315
functional component, right?

599
00:26:20.315 --> 00:26:23.915
When we talk about system level testing,
we're talking about the entire system.

600
00:26:23.915 --> 00:26:25.715
So, if I go ahead and I grab

601
00:26:26.915 --> 00:26:31.925
my handy dandy testing implementation
visual aid tool here, my water bottle,

602
00:26:31.925 --> 00:26:35.355
right, there are effectively three
components to this water bottle, right?

603
00:26:35.355 --> 00:26:37.190
There is the bottle itself.

604
00:26:37.190 --> 00:26:37.980
There is the water.

605
00:26:37.980 --> 00:26:39.900
I'm not pouring this out to show
you there's water in there.

606
00:26:39.900 --> 00:26:41.340
But you can see there is water.

607
00:26:41.340 --> 00:26:43.970
So there's the information,
or the liquid inside.

608
00:26:43.970 --> 00:26:46.990
There's the container, and
there's also the sealing mechanism,

609
00:26:46.990 --> 00:26:49.060
which is the cap that goes on the top.

610
00:26:49.060 --> 00:26:52.540
If I was doing unit level testing,
I would have to test the cap,

611
00:26:52.540 --> 00:26:55.390
I would have to test the bottle,
I would have to test the water.

612
00:26:55.390 --> 00:26:58.510
These are the three units that
make up the actual system.

613
00:26:58.510 --> 00:27:01.310
When I want to do the system testing,
I have to put the cap on the bottle,

614
00:27:01.310 --> 00:27:02.200
this is important right?

615
00:27:02.200 --> 00:27:03.840
Because then when you do this at Mike,

616
00:27:03.840 --> 00:27:05.880
I want to make sure that
water doesn't come out.

617
00:27:05.880 --> 00:27:08.710
So when we put all three together,
and we test the system.

618
00:27:08.710 --> 00:27:10.940
I have to make sure all
the components work.

619
00:27:10.940 --> 00:27:13.870
So this is how we are gonna
be doing system testing.

620
00:27:13.870 --> 00:27:16.670
We talked about integration
testing where we are integrating,

621
00:27:16.670 --> 00:27:18.110
we're putting the components together.

622
00:27:18.110 --> 00:27:22.170
I take the system container, I put
the water in and then I test those two.

623
00:27:22.170 --> 00:27:24.090
I put the cap on, I test all three.

624
00:27:24.090 --> 00:27:25.100
That's the integration,

625
00:27:25.100 --> 00:27:28.340
the building of all the units
together to create the system.

626
00:27:28.340 --> 00:27:31.980
That's a separate level of testing, and
then we do system testing on top of that.

627
00:27:31.980 --> 00:27:34.540
So, we're gonna do
different kinds of testing.

628
00:27:34.540 --> 00:27:37.330
We have different test cases that
we use to do the testing, right?

629
00:27:37.330 --> 00:27:40.975
And we're gonna obviously wanna see
what happens at each individual level,

630
00:27:40.975 --> 00:27:42.210
the unit level.

631
00:27:42.210 --> 00:27:44.480
Is the cap gonna meet
the requirements in the stress test,

632
00:27:44.480 --> 00:27:47.140
gonna keep the water in the bottle-
>> Thankfully yes.

633
00:27:47.140 --> 00:27:48.430
>> The container itself, right what?

634
00:27:48.430 --> 00:27:50.050
>> Thankfully yes. [LAUGH] >> In
this case, right, thankfully yes.

635
00:27:50.050 --> 00:27:51.710
Mike's saying thankfully it did, great.

636
00:27:51.710 --> 00:27:53.085
Mike is dry, you'll notice, right.

637
00:27:53.085 --> 00:27:55.196
>> [LAUGH]
>> Absolutely no water was harmed

638
00:27:55.196 --> 00:27:57.029
in the filming of this episode at all.

639
00:27:57.029 --> 00:28:00.280
So I just wanna make sure we think about
the fact that we can test different

640
00:28:00.280 --> 00:28:00.934
components.

641
00:28:00.934 --> 00:28:04.381
We test the building of this components
into the integration of it, the system.

642
00:28:04.381 --> 00:28:11.521
We do unit testing of
the individual parts.

643
00:28:11.521 --> 00:28:13.274
We do the integration
putting them all together.

644
00:28:13.274 --> 00:28:17.123
And then, we do the system testing which
is the entire system integrated fully as

645
00:28:17.123 --> 00:28:17.980
a coherent unit.

646
00:28:17.980 --> 00:28:19.360
We're going to do all three.

647
00:28:19.360 --> 00:28:21.720
This is also going to be very
important for us to consider.

648
00:28:21.720 --> 00:28:25.750
And when we talk about testing,
finally, to wrap up our conversation in

649
00:28:25.750 --> 00:28:28.650
this particular episode,
we also have to understand the outcome.

650
00:28:28.650 --> 00:28:30.160
We talked a lot about,
we have to have metrics.

651
00:28:30.160 --> 00:28:32.580
We have to understand and
measure what we're seeing.

652
00:28:32.580 --> 00:28:34.660
So metrics are going to be very important,
right?

653
00:28:34.660 --> 00:28:35.580
What kind of metrics?

654
00:28:35.580 --> 00:28:37.170
Well, it depends on what we're testing.

655
00:28:37.170 --> 00:28:40.600
We may just simply look at the fact
that the water stayed in the bottle so

656
00:28:40.600 --> 00:28:42.330
was it a success, yes or no?

657
00:28:42.330 --> 00:28:44.260
May look at how much
water is in the bottle.

658
00:28:44.260 --> 00:28:48.740
May look at how much volume the actual can
contain versus how much liquid's in there

659
00:28:48.740 --> 00:28:50.800
versus the stress test of keeping
the liquid in the bottle,

660
00:28:50.800 --> 00:28:52.980
because of the number of times
we shook it or whatever.

661
00:28:52.980 --> 00:28:54.490
So all these ways to measure things.

662
00:28:54.490 --> 00:28:56.200
My point is metrics, generically,

663
00:28:56.200 --> 00:29:00.240
are important because they give us data
about outcomes success or failure and

664
00:29:00.240 --> 00:29:03.330
this is ultimately what we're looking for
when we're doing assessment and testing.

665
00:29:03.330 --> 00:29:04.590
>> Very good, Adam.

666
00:29:04.590 --> 00:29:08.730
Again, a lot of great information there
we looked at assessment and testing and

667
00:29:08.730 --> 00:29:14.840
we saw monitoring doing real user
monitoring verses synthetic monitoring.

668
00:29:14.840 --> 00:29:19.600
A lot of looking at code, and
how complex that can be, and really,

669
00:29:19.600 --> 00:29:22.730
the importance of bringing in people
that can help you, trained experts,

670
00:29:22.730 --> 00:29:25.560
as Adam said, in that particular area,
if it's not yours.

671
00:29:25.560 --> 00:29:27.640
And when you're analyzing thousands or

672
00:29:27.640 --> 00:29:30.860
millions of lines of code,
that can be a very complex process.

673
00:29:30.860 --> 00:29:32.650
So thanks Adam, for
all that great information.

674
00:29:32.650 --> 00:29:34.990
Remember, if you wanna sit in
one of Adam's classes live,

675
00:29:34.990 --> 00:29:38.171
shoot us an email here
at SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

676
00:29:38.171 --> 00:29:40.010
Signing off for now.

677
00:29:40.010 --> 00:29:41.260
I'm Mike Roderick.

678
00:29:41.260 --> 00:29:42.150
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

679
00:29:42.150 --> 00:29:43.510
>> And we'll see you next time.

680
00:29:43.510 --> 00:29:46.205
>> Take care, everybody.

681
00:29:46.205 --> 00:29:47.946
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Adam and Mike present more on assessment and testing by talking about common structural coverage methods. They talk about the importance of determining if the important metrics are being monitored. They also look at auditing and interpreting audit results.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.289 --> 00:00:15.351
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.351 --> 00:00:17.210
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:17.210 --> 00:00:20.490
Today we're doing our CISSP content and

5
00:00:20.490 --> 00:00:24.720
specifically we're looking
at assessment and testing.

6
00:00:24.720 --> 00:00:27.540
This is our third part so
if you missed those first few parts,

7
00:00:27.540 --> 00:00:31.550
make sure you go back and watch those as
we are continuing our thought process.

8
00:00:31.550 --> 00:00:34.750
With that in mind, I'm just going to turn
it right back over to Mr. Adam Gordon.

9
00:00:34.750 --> 00:00:35.680
How's it going Adam?

10
00:00:35.680 --> 00:00:36.510
>> Good, good, good.

11
00:00:36.510 --> 00:00:38.330
How is that water treating you by the way?

12
00:00:38.330 --> 00:00:39.801
>> Yeah, it's good.
I got all dried up.

13
00:00:39.801 --> 00:00:40.843
[LAUGH]
>> Alright, that's good, good.

14
00:00:40.843 --> 00:00:43.580
We don't want you catching cold
while we're talking about security.

15
00:00:43.580 --> 00:00:46.900
So we were talking about metrics,
talked a bit about how we measure things,

16
00:00:46.900 --> 00:00:48.680
how we test them, why that's important.

17
00:00:48.680 --> 00:00:49.660
When we think about metrics,

18
00:00:49.660 --> 00:00:52.490
we also wanna talk about something
specific known as coverage metrics.

19
00:00:52.490 --> 00:00:56.000
It's really where we're gonna kinda jump
back in and continue our conversations.

20
00:00:56.000 --> 00:00:58.530
Coverage metrics
are a measure of completeness

21
00:00:58.530 --> 00:01:00.250
with respect to test selection criteria.

22
00:01:00.250 --> 00:01:01.650
What does that mean in English?

23
00:01:01.650 --> 00:01:03.760
In plain language,
what that really means is,

24
00:01:03.760 --> 00:01:08.210
did we select the right things to test,
and did we test them the right way?

25
00:01:08.210 --> 00:01:09.370
So, how do we know that, right?

26
00:01:09.370 --> 00:01:10.530
How do we know for sure?

27
00:01:10.530 --> 00:01:12.340
And so the structural metrics,

28
00:01:12.340 --> 00:01:15.070
the common structural coverage
metrics we need to think about

29
00:01:15.070 --> 00:01:18.580
are different ways of measuring how
complete and how accurate our tests are.

30
00:01:18.580 --> 00:01:20.510
So, I wanna go through
the common ones with you, so

31
00:01:20.510 --> 00:01:21.540
make sure you're comfortable with them.

32
00:01:21.540 --> 00:01:24.160
We have a total of seven, we wanna talk
about with you in the next couple of

33
00:01:24.160 --> 00:01:28.430
minutes, give you some quick definitions,
make sure you're good with what they are.

34
00:01:28.430 --> 00:01:30.480
You would want to potentially
know about these and

35
00:01:30.480 --> 00:01:33.540
at least have a sentence or so
summary of what each one does

36
00:01:33.540 --> 00:01:36.060
in order to become comfortable
with them if asked about them.

37
00:01:36.060 --> 00:01:37.850
First one is statement coverage.

38
00:01:37.850 --> 00:01:42.590
Statement coverage allows us to
think about making sure that

39
00:01:42.590 --> 00:01:44.680
the sufficient test cases are created for

40
00:01:44.680 --> 00:01:47.430
each program statement that they
have to be executed at least once.

that we can tell who it is.

523
00:23:09.370 --> 00:23:13.260
Malware that is being created is being
written by people that create software.

524
00:23:13.260 --> 00:23:17.000
It's just very specifically, certain
kinds of software that's being written

525
00:23:17.000 --> 00:23:19.930
specifically with certain
criminal enterprises in mind.

526
00:23:19.930 --> 00:23:23.470
And so, as a result, author identification
is also an area that we study,

527
00:23:23.470 --> 00:23:27.210
that we try to figure out how to do
when it comes to forensic examination.

528
00:23:27.210 --> 00:23:30.460
Certain authors are well known,
certain malware is well known.

529
00:23:30.460 --> 00:23:33.390
And the signs of who wrote that
malware will trickle down in

530
00:23:33.390 --> 00:23:35.570
to other pieces of
software that they touch.

531
00:23:35.570 --> 00:23:39.275
We may be able to look at the author
identification and maybe able to say, oh,

532
00:23:39.275 --> 00:23:40.478
this is done by so and so.

533
00:23:40.478 --> 00:23:43.260
And then, go out and
try to find out what they were up to.

534
00:23:43.260 --> 00:23:44.790
We can do content analysi.

535
00:23:44.790 --> 00:23:51.456
We can look at the stuff that
goes on inside the goat.

536
00:23:51.456 --> 00:23:55.623
The systematic is what I'm trying to say,
systematic analysis of the code's purpose.

537
00:23:55.623 --> 00:23:58.598
In other words, we can literally go
line by line examining the code,

538
00:23:58.598 --> 00:24:00.000
try to understand what it does.

539
00:24:00.000 --> 00:24:02.983
And what each line of code is
representing in terms of an action.

540
00:24:02.983 --> 00:24:05.310
On the surface,
the program may look innocent.

541
00:24:05.310 --> 00:24:08.280
When we look under the hood, we may
see that it has a nefarious purpose.

542
00:24:08.280 --> 00:24:10.610
So we wanna make sure we're aware of that.

543
00:24:10.610 --> 00:24:13.810
Hardware and or embedded device analysis,
we may do this as well.

544
00:24:13.810 --> 00:24:15.000
We can look at what's going on.

545
00:24:15.000 --> 00:24:17.480
I mentioned something like
a hardware key logger and

546
00:24:17.480 --> 00:24:20.410
something like that in one of our
prior episodes may be a problem.

547
00:24:20.410 --> 00:24:23.300
A lot of hardware devices
today can be stealthed to be

548
00:24:23.300 --> 00:24:25.050
made to look like something they're not.

549
00:24:25.050 --> 00:24:27.430
Look at all the different ways
USB devices come today, right?

550
00:24:27.430 --> 00:24:30.970
I mean, you have a standard USB drive, but
you got earrings that are USB devices.

551
00:24:30.970 --> 00:24:33.240
You got pen caps that are USB devices.

552
00:24:33.240 --> 00:24:35.260
You got all sorts of crazy stuff.

553
00:24:35.260 --> 00:24:38.510
So while it may not seem obvious,
right, and I'm not suggesting for

554
00:24:38.510 --> 00:24:40.520
a minute that this is a USB device.

555
00:24:40.520 --> 00:24:43.720
But you'll imagine if the top of the pen
came off, and there was a little USB

556
00:24:43.720 --> 00:24:46.940
device on the side, you could plug in and
then clip back on and

557
00:24:46.940 --> 00:24:50.140
walk out with information, right,
just sitting in your pocket.

558
00:24:50.140 --> 00:24:51.500
You notice I got that right.

559
00:24:51.500 --> 00:24:52.450
I was looking there.

560
00:24:52.450 --> 00:24:53.820
I wasn't [INAUDIBLE] and I got it right.

561
00:24:53.820 --> 00:24:54.500
>> It was slick.

562
00:24:54.500 --> 00:24:56.670
>> It finally figured
out the direction thing.

563
00:24:56.670 --> 00:24:58.720
It only took all week, but
I finally figured it out.

564
00:24:58.720 --> 00:25:01.000
I didn't go over here, which would
have been my normal inclination.

565
00:25:01.000 --> 00:25:04.500
All right, so the idea would be
that this could be a USB device.

566
00:25:04.500 --> 00:25:07.527
It happens to be a pen, but
we don't know for sure what it is.

567
00:25:07.527 --> 00:25:10.978
And the idea is that it could be a piece
of hardware that's masquerading to

568
00:25:10.978 --> 00:25:11.820
something else.

569
00:25:11.820 --> 00:25:16.110
Again, we have to examine and in theory
be suspect and really be suspicious of

570
00:25:16.110 --> 00:25:20.730
everything, right, because anything today
in theory could contain information

571
00:25:20.730 --> 00:25:25.368
gathering, information monitoring,
information observation capabilities.

572
00:25:25.368 --> 00:25:29.073
We talked about cell phones one of our
prior episodes and how problematic they

573
00:25:29.073 --> 00:25:32.151
can be in secure environments,
because they can be turned on and

574
00:25:32.151 --> 00:25:36.270
remotely controlled for video, for audio,
for monitoring capabilities, right?

575
00:25:36.270 --> 00:25:38.465
So these are the kinds of things we
wanna make sure we're aware of and

576
00:25:38.465 --> 00:25:40.180
we're thinking about as well.

577
00:25:40.180 --> 00:25:45.740
We also have to consider legal issues and
concerns with regards to jurisdiction.

578
00:25:45.740 --> 00:25:50.500
The issue and concern here is what law is
going to be relevant for where we are.

579
00:25:50.500 --> 00:25:55.430
Are we in a state,
hypothetically let's just say Florida,

580
00:25:55.430 --> 00:25:57.980
where there may be certain
laws that the state has

581
00:25:57.980 --> 00:26:00.620
that will say that evidence has to be
managed and gathered a certain way.

582
00:26:00.620 --> 00:26:04.470
And then there may be federal laws, laws
that are in the case of the United States,

583
00:26:04.470 --> 00:26:10.110
at the federal level, that may override
those state laws or may not, it depends.

584
00:26:10.110 --> 00:26:13.440
There may be international laws that
override federal and state laws.

585
00:26:13.440 --> 00:26:17.110
We may be in a different country and the
laws of that country are gonna apply and

586
00:26:17.110 --> 00:26:19.560
not the laws where maybe
we call our home base, or

587
00:26:19.560 --> 00:26:21.070
where we would normally work out of.

588
00:26:21.070 --> 00:26:25.180
In other words a CISSP that jumps on
a plane to go do incident response

589
00:26:25.180 --> 00:26:29.100
in Bolivia is not gonna be bound by
the laws of the United States anymore,

590
00:26:29.100 --> 00:26:31.080
you're bound by the laws of Bolivia.

591
00:26:31.080 --> 00:26:34.300
And you have to understand that
if you work extranationally,

592
00:26:34.300 --> 00:26:38.200
outside of your country and other
geography, as a security professional,

593
00:26:38.200 --> 00:26:42.160
you are responsible for understanding what
the laws and the accepted practices and

594
00:26:42.160 --> 00:26:44.390
behaviors are in that country.

595
00:26:44.390 --> 00:26:48.260
It may be illegal for
you to do certain things in country X or

596
00:26:48.260 --> 00:26:51.140
Y that you can do in your home country.

597
00:26:51.140 --> 00:26:53.770
For instance,
it's illegal to use encryption

598
00:26:53.770 --> 00:26:56.160
in certain countries the way
we do in the United States.

599
00:26:56.160 --> 00:26:58.062
It's against the law.

600
00:26:58.062 --> 00:27:02.820
In China, as an example, we're not
allowed to use encryption the same way.

601
00:27:02.820 --> 00:27:05.990
If you do you're violating the state
secrecy and privacy acts, and

602
00:27:05.990 --> 00:27:07.660
you can actually go to jail.

603
00:27:07.660 --> 00:27:10.060
So there are considerations,

604
00:27:10.060 --> 00:27:13.750
significant concerns that a CISSP
would have to be aware of.

605
00:27:13.750 --> 00:27:14.720
This may not apply to you.

606
00:27:14.720 --> 00:27:16.020
You may not work internationally.

607
00:27:16.020 --> 00:27:19.110
It may not be a big deal for you,
and you may just simply say, well,

608
00:27:19.110 --> 00:27:20.180
I work in this country.

609
00:27:20.180 --> 00:27:21.890
This is where I live,
this is what I do, and

610
00:27:21.890 --> 00:27:23.500
I've just gotta know the law of the land.

611
00:27:23.500 --> 00:27:27.510
Absolutely, but also understand that there
are different laws in different lands.

612
00:27:27.510 --> 00:27:28.690
And just be aware of that.

613
00:27:28.690 --> 00:27:32.460
Just to be clear, we're not gonna
expect you to know what those laws are.

614
00:27:32.460 --> 00:27:34.460
Right, we're not gonna
give you a geography quiz.

615
00:27:34.460 --> 00:27:38.110
And ask you where it is or is not
appropriate for you to do certain things.

616
00:27:38.110 --> 00:27:42.900
We do expect you as a CISSP to understand,
generically, that the laws of the location

617
00:27:42.900 --> 00:27:45.910
where you operate are the laws
you must be aware of and follow.

618
00:27:45.910 --> 00:27:47.390
That is very important.

619
00:27:47.390 --> 00:27:49.536
We carry out different
types of investigation.

620
00:27:49.536 --> 00:27:52.905
There will be criminal investigations,
maybe civil investigations,

621
00:27:52.905 --> 00:27:55.777
maybe operational investigations
within an organization,

622
00:27:55.777 --> 00:27:58.057
just internally to figure
out what's going on.

623
00:27:58.057 --> 00:27:59.307
There could be e-discovery,

624
00:27:59.307 --> 00:28:02.300
which is typically used in the cloud
very often to find evidence.

625
00:28:02.300 --> 00:28:05.050
So we have to understand there are
different types of investigations that may

626
00:28:05.050 --> 00:28:08.120
occur and different outcomes
from different investigations,

627
00:28:08.120 --> 00:28:11.425
specifically the difference between
criminal and civil for instance, right?

628
00:28:11.425 --> 00:28:15.360
In a criminal investigation,
and potentially a criminal suit

629
00:28:15.360 --> 00:28:19.680
that follows that, if you're dragged into
court, potentially you can be found guilty

630
00:28:19.680 --> 00:28:24.140
of violating the law and in theory be
given jail time, a jail sentence for that.

631
00:28:24.140 --> 00:28:26.730
Criminal outcomes typically
involve jail time and

632
00:28:26.730 --> 00:28:28.800
sentences involving you going away.

633
00:28:28.800 --> 00:28:30.628
They put you in the big house as they say,
right?

634
00:28:31.710 --> 00:28:36.680
In the civil cases, when you are found
guilty, if you are, you may face a fine,

635
00:28:36.680 --> 00:28:39.110
typically a financial fine of some kind.

636
00:28:39.110 --> 00:28:41.960
You may have to pay restitution or
damages to somebody.

637
00:28:41.960 --> 00:28:45.230
So if you go back to the OJ Simpson
example we talked about earlier,

638
00:28:45.230 --> 00:28:46.780
interesting outcome in that case.

639
00:28:46.780 --> 00:28:50.098
OJ Simpson was not found guilty
in the criminal suit, all right.

640
00:28:50.098 --> 00:28:52.700
He was effectively found
innocent in theory of committing

641
00:28:52.700 --> 00:28:56.740
the crime that he stood to
potentially be guilty of, right,

642
00:28:56.740 --> 00:28:59.360
the fact that he theoretically
murdered those two people.

643
00:28:59.360 --> 00:29:02.070
But he was found guilty in
the civil portion of the trial.

644
00:29:02.070 --> 00:29:04.890
So he actually was found guilty in
theory of a crime that they said he did

645
00:29:04.890 --> 00:29:07.630
not commit in the civil trial
if you think about that, and

646
00:29:07.630 --> 00:29:11.110
was effectively made to pay damages for
something that,

647
00:29:11.110 --> 00:29:15.300
supposedly, in the criminal version of
that trial, he was found innocent of.

648
00:29:15.300 --> 00:29:17.520
So it's kind of interesting
that the outcomes can differ

649
00:29:17.520 --> 00:29:18.330
when you think about this.

650
00:29:18.330 --> 00:29:21.810
Because the civil case and the criminal
case have two very different outcomes and

651
00:29:21.810 --> 00:29:22.826
two different focuses.

652
00:29:22.826 --> 00:29:24.630
So I wanna just make sure
we're aware of that, and

653
00:29:24.630 --> 00:29:25.901
we're thinking about that as well.

654
00:29:25.901 --> 00:29:30.630
All right, probably a good place for
us to think about taking a break and

655
00:29:30.630 --> 00:29:32.200
coming back talking about some more stuff.

656
00:29:32.200 --> 00:29:33.860
>> Sounds good to me, we'll do just that.

657
00:29:33.860 --> 00:29:37.600
We'll take a little break and we'll come
back with more great CISSP for you guys.

658
00:29:37.600 --> 00:29:40.120
Remember if you want to attend
one of Adam's classes live,

659
00:29:40.120 --> 00:29:44.520
all you gotta do is shoot us
an email here at SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

660
00:29:44.520 --> 00:29:46.780
For now signing off, I'm Mike Rodrick.

661
00:29:46.780 --> 00:29:47.975
>> Oh, that would be me.

662
00:29:47.975 --> 00:29:49.870
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm, who am I today?

663
00:29:49.870 --> 00:29:50.927
I'm George Smith.

664
00:29:50.927 --> 00:29:53.690
That's right, I'm George Smith,
and we'll see you next time.

665

This is what we were talking about or

how to monitor, how to track activity.

30
00:01:17.740 --> 00:01:21.720
Secure operations concepts is all about
this idea of keeping track of things and

31
00:01:21.720 --> 00:01:23.940
doing so in a way that forces us and

32

ensures that we're gonna be acting
in a secure manner and if we don't,

33

We then wanna know that something's going
on so we can take steps to stop it, right?

34
00:01:30.840 --> 00:01:35.090
And so we often talk about logging,
we talk about intrusion gathering, or

35
00:01:35.090 --> 00:01:38.530
excuse me, intrusion detection,
which we can then use to gather evidence,

36
00:01:38.530 --> 00:01:41.940
intrusion prevention, which we can then
use to not only gather evidence, but

37
00:01:41.940 --> 00:01:46.250
ultimately then alert and take action
to prevent activity from taking place.

38
00:01:46.250 --> 00:01:49.220
We wanna make sure we know
the difference between IDSs and IPSs.

39
00:01:49.220 --> 00:01:53.260
We've harped on this definition in several

40
00:01:53.260 --> 00:01:57.330
obviously very important for you to know,
IDS is intrusion detection systems,

41
00:01:57.330 --> 00:01:59.650
they're considered to

42
00:01:59.650 --> 00:02:03.870
Solutions that monitor, that can alert,
that can tell us something is going on.

43
00:02:03.870 --> 00:02:07.980
People often mistake this for activity
that's implying that they can take action.

44
00:02:07.980 --> 00:02:10.650
Reality is no,
they can simply alert and monitor.

45
00:02:10.650 --> 00:02:14.610
IPS is intrusion prevention systems,
are gonna be able to do everything an IDS

46
00:02:14.610 --> 00:02:19.970
does, so think of it as IDS plus but
it can take action to stop an attack.

47
00:02:19.970 --> 00:02:22.990
So an IDS will be able
to see an attack coming.

48
00:02:22.990 --> 00:02:25.960
Will be able to tell you hey there's
a distributed denial of service event

49
00:02:25.960 --> 00:02:26.910
taking place.

50
00:02:26.910 --> 00:02:27.730
Mike wake up.

51
00:02:27.730 --> 00:02:28.890
Mike you should pay attention.

52
00:02:28.890 --> 00:02:31.170
Mike there's an IDS event happening but

53
00:02:31.170 --> 00:02:33.350
the IDS can only tell
Mike hey pay attention.

54
00:02:33.350 --> 00:02:34.680
It can only alert Mike.

55
00:02:34.680 --> 00:02:35.940
It can't actually do anything.

56
00:02:35.940 --> 00:02:38.050
Mike has to go and manually intervene and

57
00:02:38.050 --> 00:02:40.150
if Mike pays attention to
the alert maybe he will.

58
00:02:40.150 --> 00:02:43.049
If he doesn't you know then unfortunately
we're gonna have a problem right?

59
00:02:44.130 --> 00:02:47.740
But the IPS system can do all that,
can tell Mike hey Mike you should pay

60
00:02:47.740 --> 00:02:51.300
attention but if Mike doesn't take action,
the IPS can go ahead and

61
00:02:51.300 --> 00:02:55.920

62
00:02:55.920 --> 00:02:59.330

63
00:02:59.330 --> 00:03:01.910
It can effectively reprogram
a route in the router.

64
00:03:01.910 --> 00:03:04.895
It can take steps to take
down a website and secure it.

65
00:03:04.895 --> 00:03:06.550
Do all sorts of different stuff.

66
00:03:06.550 --> 00:03:10.350
So the idea is that it monitors actively,
but it also responds actively.

67
00:03:10.350 --> 00:03:12.350
I want to make sure we
understand the difference there.

68
00:03:12.350 --> 00:03:15.530
We've also talked about SIEM systems
before, Security Information and

69
00:03:15.530 --> 00:03:17.060

70
00:03:17.060 --> 00:03:19.260

71

centrally manage and control them,

72
00:03:24.010 --> 00:03:28.860
bring them into a common area, and
then provide depacket inspection,

73
00:03:28.860 --> 00:03:31.230
deblogging analysis capabilities,

74

they're going to be able to do business
intelligence and aggregation for us.

75

solutions look at any of the infographics

00:25:48.120 --> 00:25:49.740
And I'll go through these again.

536
00:25:49.740 --> 00:25:50.990
Disposition.

537
00:25:50.990 --> 00:25:54.650
So a total of six items in the life cycle,
right?

538
00:25:54.650 --> 00:25:59.560
Creation of data,
distribution of data, use of data,

539
00:25:59.560 --> 00:26:04.732
maintenance regarding data, so the up
keep of data, disclosure, disposition.

540
00:26:04.732 --> 00:26:07.260
These are the six stages of
the information life cycle.

541
00:26:07.260 --> 00:26:10.590
Just wanna make sure we understand
what's going on with all of them.

542
00:26:10.590 --> 00:26:14.960
We also wanna make sure we understand
what and who an information owner is.

543
00:26:14.960 --> 00:26:19.060
The information owner is the entity
that is ultimately responsible for

544
00:26:19.060 --> 00:26:23.690
the disposition of data, meaning
the permissions assigned, the user rights

545
00:26:23.690 --> 00:26:27.590
given, and what is done with the data
in terms of how it is classified.

546
00:26:27.590 --> 00:26:29.330
That is all in the wheelhouse.

547
00:26:29.330 --> 00:26:32.070
All under the purview,
under the direct control and

548
00:26:32.070 --> 00:26:34.070
responsibility of the information owner.

549
00:26:34.070 --> 00:26:36.730
Want to make sure we understand that and
know that as well.

550
00:26:36.730 --> 00:26:39.810
We've talked about data classification,
data categorization,

551
00:26:39.810 --> 00:26:41.400
why these things are important.

552
00:26:41.400 --> 00:26:44.310
Want to remind ourselves
the classification is a way that we can

553
00:26:44.310 --> 00:26:48.480
effectively specify what level
of protection data should get.

554
00:26:48.480 --> 00:26:53.280
Should it be top secret, should be eyes
only, should be publicly available,

555
00:26:53.280 --> 00:26:54.860
for official use only?

556
00:26:54.860 --> 00:26:58.490
It's about the appropriate level
of clearance that data should be

557
00:26:58.490 --> 00:27:01.770
basically ascribed to so when users see
it, they're gonna match up to it, and

558
00:27:01.770 --> 00:27:05.010
they're gonna only be able to see it
if they're cleared at that level.

559
00:27:05.010 --> 00:27:10.650
Categorization is the idea of depending on
the kind of data, understanding the impact

560
00:27:10.650 --> 00:27:14.180
resulting from the loss of confidentiality
where the data to be exposed.

561
00:27:14.180 --> 00:27:16.190
What is the impact of data loss,
in other words,

562
00:27:16.190 --> 00:27:18.360
is what we're thinking about
when we categorize data.

563
00:27:18.360 --> 00:27:21.930
So we'll want to understand that whether
it's confidentiality, integrity, or

564
00:27:21.930 --> 00:27:25.970
available that is lost and compromised,
we do want to understand all of that.

565
00:27:25.970 --> 00:27:28.520
And that's what
categorization is all about.

566
00:27:28.520 --> 00:27:30.370
So we want to make sure
we're thinking about that.

567
00:27:30.370 --> 00:27:32.800
We also want to be thinking about
retention periods and schedules,

568
00:27:32.800 --> 00:27:35.330
when we managing data,
we have to make sure from a security

569
00:27:35.330 --> 00:27:38.710
operations standpoint, we don't keep
data any longer than we need to,

570
00:27:38.710 --> 00:27:41.540
but we also make sure that we
keep it as long as we need to.

571
00:27:41.540 --> 00:27:44.690
Don't want to go back and look for data
two years from now that's supposed to be

572
00:27:44.690 --> 00:27:48.200
there for five and find out it was
deleted 30 days after we created it and

573
00:27:48.200 --> 00:27:49.250
we don't have a back up of it.

574
00:27:49.250 --> 00:27:50.490
That would be bad.

575
00:27:50.490 --> 00:27:53.530
So we violated the retention schedule,
if that's the case.

576
00:27:53.530 --> 00:27:57.560
Monitoring retention schedules, making
sure that we keep a hold of data for

577
00:27:57.560 --> 00:27:58.780
as long as we need to.

578
00:27:58.780 --> 00:28:02.080
But we get rid of data when
the retention period is expired so

579
00:28:02.080 --> 00:28:05.000
we no longer have the liability
of owning it is very important.

580
00:28:05.000 --> 00:28:06.880
Want to make sure we're
aware of that as well.

581
00:28:06.880 --> 00:28:11.370
And we want to finish up our
discussion in this area, talking about,

582
00:28:11.370 --> 00:28:15.350
a mechanism that we have mentioned before,
something that's very important,

583
00:28:15.350 --> 00:28:18.280
something known as an SLA,
a Service Level Agreement.

584
00:28:18.280 --> 00:28:21.850
Service level agreements are gonna be
effectively contractual documents.

585
00:28:21.850 --> 00:28:25.920
They bind us as customers to our
provider that is providing a good or

586
00:28:25.920 --> 00:28:29.510
a service and they are in mutual
agreement that allows for and stipulates,

587
00:28:29.510 --> 00:28:33.920
lays out what the expectations on
both sides of that solution are.

588
00:28:33.920 --> 00:28:36.770
The service provider will say I'm gonna
provide a good or a service to you.

589
00:28:36.770 --> 00:28:40.440
I'm gonna make sure it's available during
these times for this amount of time

590
00:28:40.440 --> 00:28:45.430
under these conditions and that as the
customer you then can expect this from me.

591
00:28:45.430 --> 00:28:48.030
The customer side is I'm gonna
pay this amount of money.

592
00:28:48.030 --> 00:28:51.130
I'm gonna follow these rules if I
have to escalate a server's problem.

593
00:28:51.130 --> 00:28:53.800
I'm gonna follow this reporting
mechanism in other words.

594
00:28:53.800 --> 00:28:55.950
And if something goes wrong and
Mr. and Mrs.

595
00:28:55.950 --> 00:29:00.400
Service Provider, you can't fix it in the
agreed upon time, then these penalties or

596
00:29:00.400 --> 00:29:03.310
these issues are then gonna become
part of what we have to discuss.

597
00:29:03.310 --> 00:29:07.001
You may have a give back,
maybe some sort of a credit for

598
00:29:07.001 --> 00:29:09.819
service things of that nature can occur.

599
00:29:09.819 --> 00:29:13.790
So SLA's are very important because they
are contractual vehicles that help us

600
00:29:13.790 --> 00:29:16.370
essentially to manage
service expectations.

601
00:29:16.370 --> 00:29:19.020
Now you may also have
something known as a OLA

602
00:29:19.020 --> 00:29:22.730
as well as a PLA although
they're not really as common,

603
00:29:22.730 --> 00:29:25.790
we should probably just define and talk
about what they are for just a minute.

604
00:29:25.790 --> 00:29:30.820
So SLA's are Service Level Agreements,
OLAs, Operational Level Agreements.

605
00:29:30.820 --> 00:29:33.680
These are internal facing SLAs.

606
00:29:33.680 --> 00:29:38.180
SLAs are traditionally between an external
service provider outside the business and

607
00:29:38.180 --> 00:29:39.100
the business itself.

608
00:29:39.100 --> 00:29:43.560
The IT arm of the business is gonna
sign off on it or ultimately, engage,

609
00:29:43.560 --> 00:29:46.980
and the SLA is the customer
representing the business.

610
00:29:46.980 --> 00:29:52.040
Even though sometimes legal signs off,
HR may get involved, central purchasing,

611
00:29:52.040 --> 00:29:56.410
ultimately it's the business that is the
customer, and the service provider that

612
00:29:56.410 --> 00:29:59.990
are contracting, and a representative of
the business represents the business and

613
00:29:59.990 --> 00:30:00.900
signs off on the SLA.

614
00:30:00.900 --> 00:30:03.165
So that's an external agreement.

615
00:30:03.165 --> 00:30:09.034
In OLA, an Operational Level Agreement,
there's gonna be an internal facing SLA.

616
00:30:09.034 --> 00:30:13.095
It is between the IT function of the
business and different business units for

617
00:30:13.095 --> 00:30:17.347
consumption of services, like provisioning
of email, provisioning of VOIP,

618
00:30:17.347 --> 00:30:18.770
things like that.

619
00:30:18.770 --> 00:30:23.540
So when you have different business units
that centrally consume IT services and

620
00:30:23.540 --> 00:30:25.640
you have what's known
as a charge back model,

621
00:30:25.640 --> 00:30:28.370
a model that effectively charges them for
IT services.

622
00:30:28.370 --> 00:30:31.210
You may use OLAs to
stipulate how that works and

623
00:30:31.210 --> 00:30:33.240
those first internal facing SLAs.

624
00:30:33.240 --> 00:30:37.040
And then you may have what's known
as a PLA, a Privacy Level Agreement.

625
00:30:37.040 --> 00:30:40.880
These are relatively new, really brought
on by the advent of cloud computing and

626
00:30:40.880 --> 00:30:45.660
the idea there is that when we have
a PLA we are focusing on privacy and

627
00:30:45.660 --> 00:30:48.530
the agreement on the expectation
of how to manage privacy, and

628
00:30:48.530 --> 00:30:51.430
the privacy requirements that
are necessary to safe guard data.

629
00:30:51.430 --> 00:30:52.450
This is known as a PLA.

630
00:30:52.450 --> 00:30:55.330
So I just want to make sure we
understand the different kinds

631
00:30:55.330 --> 00:30:58.380
of levels of agreements, right,
that may actually be stipulated and

632
00:30:58.380 --> 00:31:01.200
be found as we're talking
about secure operations.

633
00:31:01.200 --> 00:31:01.940
>> Very good and

634
00:31:01.940 --> 00:31:06.250
we got a lot of great information there
talking about secure operations concepts.

635
00:31:06.250 --> 00:31:09.120
Remember if you guys want to
attend one of Adam's classes live,

636
00:31:09.120 --> 00:31:13.150
shoot us an email at See Adam@itpro.tv.

637
00:31:13.150 --> 00:31:15.250
Signing off for
this one I'm Mike Roderick.

638
00:31:15.250 --> 00:31:18.034
>> I'm Adam Gordon,
we'll see you next time.

639

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike discuss implementing safeguards to protect the media used to store data. They talk about encryption for both data at rest and data in motion. They also talk about securely disposing media.

computers, depending on the kind

I mean, if you think about the fact

But the reality is you just may not have

use in theory, not to take pictures,

It is a clear sheet of film that we use,

we store information that has

00:04:25.608 --> 00:04:29.009
It's reduced down so

you can put a lot of information on,

00:05:09.310 --> 00:05:13.110

00:05:13.110 --> 00:05:15.660

00:05:40.660 --> 00:05:43.740

00:05:43.740 --> 00:05:47.630
But the reality with these kinds

113
00:05:52.381 --> 00:05:55.339
And we don't tend to think a lot about

00:05:55.339 --> 00:05:59.215
Because you take, like I probably do,
I know you do, I have thumb drives sitting
