And so you would leave behind a lot
of additional junk that ultimately,

341
00:16:53.170 --> 00:16:55.760
over time, would pile and may or
may not be important, may or

342
00:16:55.760 --> 00:16:59.360
may not be prevalent, may or
may not be a security liability, but

343
00:16:59.360 --> 00:17:03.080
clearly was potentially gonna
prove to be a challenge over time.

344
00:17:03.080 --> 00:17:05.360
That may not be the same
thing as leaving data behind.

345
00:17:05.360 --> 00:17:08.850
But the reality is, there may have been
data associated with that installation or

346
00:17:08.850 --> 00:17:10.720
uninstallation that also was not removed.

347
00:17:10.720 --> 00:17:14.897
And so we have to be thinking about all
these kind of things when we're thinking

348
00:17:14.897 --> 00:17:19.110
about how we're going to use protection
mechanisms to safeguard media.

349
00:17:19.110 --> 00:17:22.175
This is gonna be the kind of
conversation that in our mind

350
00:17:22.175 --> 00:17:24.470
a CISSP is gonna wanna have.

351
00:17:24.470 --> 00:17:27.650
And ultimately,
a CISSP is responsible for it.

352
00:17:27.650 --> 00:17:28.180
So you remember,

353
00:17:28.180 --> 00:17:32.170
we've talked about, and I've stressed to
you in many of our discussions together,

354
00:17:32.170 --> 00:17:36.510
it's the CISSP's responsibility to
focus the business on these risks.

355
00:17:36.510 --> 00:17:39.580
We may not have all the answers, but
it's our responsibility to drive

356
00:17:39.580 --> 00:17:44.250
the conversation and ultimately frame
the questions that will lead to solutions.

357
00:17:44.250 --> 00:17:47.760
>> Very good Adam, a great look at how
we can employ our resource protection

358
00:17:47.760 --> 00:17:52.270
techniques across a wide variety of
media that we've gotta consider.

359
00:17:52.270 --> 00:17:56.090
All right, remember, if you guys want
to attend one of Adam's classes live,

360
00:17:56.090 --> 00:18:00.380
all you gotta do is shoot us an email,
SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

361
00:18:00.380 --> 00:18:02.150
That being said,
we're gonna sign off for now.

362
00:18:02.150 --> 00:18:02.896
I'm Mike Rodrick.

363
00:18:02.896 --> 00:18:04.388
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

364
00:18:04.388 --> 00:18:05.526
>> And we'll see you next time.

365
00:18:05.526 --> 00:18:11.079
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike talk about incident management and incident response. They break down the five critical components of incident response - detect, determine, minimize, resolve, and document.
episodes.title: Incident Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:01.184 --> 00:00:11.184
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.304 --> 00:00:16.147
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.147 --> 00:00:17.202
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:17.202 --> 00:00:20.488
Today we're doing our CISSP content.

5
00:00:20.488 --> 00:00:22.126
And specifically, in this episode,

6
00:00:22.126 --> 00:00:24.645
we're gonna be looking at
incident management, right?

7
00:00:24.645 --> 00:00:27.524
Something that we really hope
we don't have to do, but

8
00:00:27.524 --> 00:00:30.654
the reality is we probably will
if we're in it long enough,

9
00:00:30.654 --> 00:00:34.140
and it's very important that
we understand how to do it.

10
00:00:34.140 --> 00:00:38.140
Before we get to that situation and here
to help us with that is Mr. Adam Gordon.

11
00:00:38.140 --> 00:00:39.210
How's it going, Adam?

12
00:00:39.210 --> 00:00:40.060
>> Good, good.
So

13
00:00:40.060 --> 00:00:44.130
could we classify an incident as being
you're about to introduce a topic but

14
00:00:44.130 --> 00:00:46.600
you screwed up and we have to do
it again in order to get it right?

15
00:00:46.600 --> 00:00:47.340
That-
>> I think so.

16
00:00:47.340 --> 00:00:48.992
>> Could actually be an incident, right,

17
00:00:48.992 --> 00:00:51.915
that could be something we wanna
manage and perhaps have a response to?

18
00:00:51.915 --> 00:00:53.960
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm just saying that could happen.

19
00:00:53.960 --> 00:00:56.530
Not that it happens here but
it could happen at some point.

20
00:00:56.530 --> 00:00:57.350
>> They would never know.

21
00:00:57.350 --> 00:01:00.110
>> They would never know that,
that's true, but unless we told them.

22
00:01:00.110 --> 00:01:01.085
But we would never do that.

23
00:01:01.085 --> 00:01:04.050
Cuz then they would know and
we wouldn't want that to happen.

24
00:01:04.050 --> 00:01:05.400
All right, so incident response.

25
00:01:05.400 --> 00:01:07.095
Let's talk about incident
response a little bit.

26
00:01:07.095 --> 00:01:11.800
So as CISSPs, as security professionals,
we wanna make sure

27
00:01:11.800 --> 00:01:15.020
that as Mike pointed out, right,
all kidding aside, things will happen.

28
00:01:15.020 --> 00:01:19.230
We have to understand that on occasion,
when we are dealing with concerns,

29
00:01:19.230 --> 00:01:22.620
we may actually want to, or dealing
rather with just general issues and

30
00:01:22.620 --> 00:01:26.160
things that are going on day to day,
moment to moment in terms of management,

31
00:01:26.160 --> 00:01:30.640
that at certain points in time, hopefully
a lot of points in time, things go well.

32
00:01:30.640 --> 00:01:34.040
But there are gonna be points in
time where things don't go so well.

33
00:01:34.040 --> 00:01:35.230
Things are gonna happen.

34
00:01:35.230 --> 00:01:39.230
We're gonna have some sort of a problem,
some sort of an incident, an event.

35
00:01:39.230 --> 00:01:40.730
Hopefully it's not catastrophic.

36
00:01:40.730 --> 00:01:44.200
We have disaster recovery and
business continuity concerns that we'll

37
00:01:44.200 --> 00:01:47.970
at some point get into that help us
understand how to deal with those things,

38
00:01:47.970 --> 00:01:49.250
if those events occur.

39
00:01:49.250 --> 00:01:53.630
But generically, when we do have some sort
of an incident, an event that occurs that

40
00:01:53.630 --> 00:01:56.790
has a negative impact in our world,
it's called an incident.

41
00:01:56.790 --> 00:02:00.770
When we have an incident that occurs,
we can't just randomly decide we're gonna

42
00:02:00.770 --> 00:02:05.070
deal with it in a certain way this time
and maybe a different way the next time.

43
00:02:05.070 --> 00:02:08.593
As a CISSP, as a security professional,
we have to have a plan,

44
00:02:08.593 --> 00:02:12.703
we have to be prepared, and we have to
go then execute the plan when there's

45
00:02:12.703 --> 00:02:15.350
an incident that calls for our attention.

46
00:02:15.350 --> 00:02:18.870
And so, incident management is
really all about incident response.

47
00:02:18.870 --> 00:02:20.950
Really all about formulating that plan,

48
00:02:20.950 --> 00:02:25.260
practicing to understand what that plan
entails, being prepared, in other words.

49
00:02:25.260 --> 00:02:26.660
And then, if called upon,

50
00:02:26.660 --> 00:02:30.745
being able to be confident in executing
whatever the plan or the response may be.

51
00:02:30.745 --> 00:02:34.595
Any kind of incident response is
really about identifying a problem,

52
00:02:34.595 --> 00:02:37.295
so understanding what the issue or
concern is.

53
00:02:37.295 --> 00:02:39.665
Detection, in other words,
is gonna be crucial.

54
00:02:39.665 --> 00:02:44.665
Determining cause, so root cause analysis
traditionally, things like that.

55
00:02:44.665 --> 00:02:47.945
Minimizing damage, so
how are we gonna prevent the issue or

56
00:02:47.945 --> 00:02:52.105
the concern from having anything other
than the immediate impact that's already

57
00:02:52.105 --> 00:02:55.180
been effectively inflicted
on the organization.

58
00:02:55.180 --> 00:03:00.378
Resolving the problem, and then ultimately
as we do that, documenting each step.

59
00:03:00.378 --> 00:03:03.310
So we wanna make sure that
in our minds generically

60
00:03:03.310 --> 00:03:06.980
we're thinking about this kind of thought
process I just shared with you, right.

61
00:03:06.980 --> 00:03:11.080
Detect, determine, minimize,
resolve, and ultimately document.

62
00:03:11.080 --> 00:03:14.710
These are gonna be the five critical
components of incident response.

63
00:03:14.710 --> 00:03:17.800
So we have all sorts of ways
we can go about doing this.

64
00:03:17.800 --> 00:03:22.070
We may have a group of individuals
that are trained with special skills

65
00:03:22.070 --> 00:03:24.570
that help us to come in and
forensically examine, talked

66
00:03:24.570 --> 00:03:28.860
a little bit about forensic examination,
rules of evidence, chain of custody,

67
00:03:28.860 --> 00:03:33.555
the approaches we use in some of our
prior conversations in earlier episodes.

68
00:03:33.555 --> 00:03:35.510
Wanna make sure we understand
that incident handling and

69
00:03:35.510 --> 00:03:39.114
response has three distinct
phases associated with it.

70
00:03:39.114 --> 00:03:42.850
There're gonna be triage, kind of,
if you think about triage,

71
00:03:42.850 --> 00:03:44.790
we're thinking about getting in there,

72
00:03:44.790 --> 00:03:49.100
assessing early on, figuring out
the extent of the concern and the damage.

73
00:03:49.100 --> 00:03:53.750
Assessing whether or not and measuring
whether or not the damage is catastrophic.

74
00:03:53.750 --> 00:03:56.540
It is gonna be painful,
but we can survive.

75
00:03:56.540 --> 00:03:57.830
It is minimal.

76
00:03:57.830 --> 00:04:01.220
It's really just nothing,
we don't have to worry about it.

77
00:04:01.220 --> 00:04:02.280
So detection,

78
00:04:02.280 --> 00:04:06.780
identification, notification, these are
activities that take place during triage.

79
00:04:06.780 --> 00:04:11.270
Investigation is the secondary phase,
takes place after triage.

80
00:04:11.270 --> 00:04:14.930
Analysis, reaction, recovery,
containment, tracking,

81
00:04:14.930 --> 00:04:18.430
these are all actions that take
place in the investigative phase.

82
00:04:18.430 --> 00:04:22.250
During recovery, last phase, we're gonna
get the business back up and running,

83
00:04:22.250 --> 00:04:23.730
get things back to normal.

84
00:04:23.730 --> 00:04:27.830
Really try to deal with whatever the
outcome or the fallout of the incident is.

85
00:04:27.830 --> 00:04:29.500
So triage, investigation,

86
00:04:29.500 --> 00:04:34.600
recovery are the three distinct handling
phases that we concern ourselves with.

87
00:04:34.600 --> 00:04:37.970
And as security professionals, we have
to think about activities that go on

88
00:04:37.970 --> 00:04:40.360
in each of these phases,
it will be very important.

89
00:04:40.360 --> 00:04:43.940
We think about attack detection,
we're often thinking

90
00:04:43.940 --> 00:04:47.890
about some thing that may happen to us
that's blatant, that's obvious, right?

91
00:04:47.890 --> 00:04:52.470
Somebody comes along, breaks through
the front door of the office and

92
00:04:52.470 --> 00:04:55.070
then comes and
steals our servers and runs away.

93
00:04:55.070 --> 00:04:58.800
It's pretty obvious that detection
is involved there in the sense that

94
00:04:58.800 --> 00:05:02.420
detection means hey, when somebody drives
through the front of the building and

95
00:05:02.420 --> 00:05:06.940
is running through your data center,
right, with servers under each arm.

96
00:05:06.940 --> 00:05:09.960
Remember the bionic man, right,
the Six Million Dollar Man years ago?

97
00:05:09.960 --> 00:05:12.920
We can make him stronger, we can make
him quicker, I'm running in place,

98
00:05:12.920 --> 00:05:13.660
look at that circle.

99
00:05:13.660 --> 00:05:14.840
Do that again, I'm running in place.

100
00:05:14.840 --> 00:05:15.563
It's so awesome, right.

101
00:05:15.563 --> 00:05:19.081
So you can see I'm running in place, and
by the way, I've also got my cool socks.

102
00:05:19.081 --> 00:05:21.937
You can't really see the pattern too
well today, but they are the orange and

103
00:05:21.937 --> 00:05:22.478
blue colors.

104
00:05:22.478 --> 00:05:23.360
>> Nice,
a little gameshow color going [CROSSTALK]

105
00:05:23.360 --> 00:05:24.181
>> Yeah, a little gameshow

106
00:05:24.181 --> 00:05:24.927
color going on there.

107
00:05:24.927 --> 00:05:25.508
>> There you go.

108
00:05:25.508 --> 00:05:26.646
>> So that's kind of neat.

109
00:05:26.646 --> 00:05:30.405
So when you're running through the data
center with the servers under each arm,

110
00:05:30.405 --> 00:05:32.463
it would probably be
more like one of these.

111
00:05:32.463 --> 00:05:34.797
You've got one server doing one of
these to keep people out the way.

112
00:05:34.797 --> 00:05:37.201
Heisman Trophy pose, right, so-
>> There you go.

113
00:05:37.201 --> 00:05:38.954
[LAUGH]
>> When you're doing that kind of stuff,

114
00:05:38.954 --> 00:05:40.160
attack detection is obvious, right?

115
00:05:40.160 --> 00:05:41.900
Somebody's driven through the front door.

116
00:05:41.900 --> 00:05:44.870
There is one or more unknown people
running through your data center.

117
00:05:44.870 --> 00:05:48.410
There's probably something going on,
right, you need to pay attention to that.

118
00:05:48.410 --> 00:05:50.460
But the reality is that it
may not be obvious, right.

119
00:05:50.460 --> 00:05:51.900
We may have malware.

120
00:05:51.900 --> 00:05:56.850
We may have somebody that's
inflicting an attack surreptitiously.

121
00:05:56.850 --> 00:05:58.610
They've back doored one or more systems.

122
00:05:58.610 --> 00:06:01.360
They are remotely accessing them but
they're under our radar.

123
00:06:01.360 --> 00:06:02.550
We're not really seeing them.

124
00:06:02.550 --> 00:06:04.890
We're not aware of the fact
that they are there.

125
00:06:04.890 --> 00:06:09.400
Recently we just heard over the last
few days about a series of different

126
00:06:09.400 --> 00:06:14.410
kinds of attacks and concerns, one of them
having to do with Juniper, huge network

127
00:06:14.410 --> 00:06:19.660
supplier of security related products,
especially router switches, router gear.

128
00:06:19.660 --> 00:06:23.280
And the issues and concerns they have
with potentially now being identified

129
00:06:23.280 --> 00:06:27.450
a master backdoor that may have been
placed into their software on their

130
00:06:27.450 --> 00:06:32.170
equipment that could allow in theory,
a bad actor not only to gain access but

131
00:06:32.170 --> 00:06:35.790
to decrypt all the data flowing
through their devices in real time.

132
00:06:35.790 --> 00:06:40.870
And as a result potentially of access to
any device that ran this software for

133
00:06:40.870 --> 00:06:44.570
at least three years according to
the early returns on these reports.

134
00:06:44.570 --> 00:06:47.790
And this can affect not just
businesses but clearly anybody,

135
00:06:47.790 --> 00:06:50.910
any organization that has
deployed this kind of technology.

136
00:06:50.910 --> 00:06:54.090
So it could be something that goes dormant
and it stays hidden for a long time

137
00:06:54.090 --> 00:06:57.100
that we don't know about, it could be
something that's in our face, right.

138
00:06:57.100 --> 00:07:00.464
So thinking about signature or
pattern matching is one of the ways

139
00:07:00.464 --> 00:07:04.695
we do attack detention techniques to be
able to find and to capture this behavior.

140
00:07:04.695 --> 00:07:09.228
This is the classic let me update my
malware or anti-malware software, let me

141
00:07:09.228 --> 00:07:13.980
update my antivirus software, I download
the latest signatures, I put them in.

142
00:07:13.980 --> 00:07:16.287
The engine goes through scans looking for
evidence and

143
00:07:16.287 --> 00:07:18.130
behavior that matches the pattern.

144
00:07:18.130 --> 00:07:21.610
We could do protocol anomaly or
statistical anomaly based scanning or

145
00:07:21.610 --> 00:07:22.860
detection as well.

146
00:07:22.860 --> 00:07:26.700
Protocol anomaly, why are we seeing
a protocol we've never seen before.

147
00:07:26.700 --> 00:07:32.576
Our normal traffic patterns are HDTP,
HDTPS, maybe some SNMP,

148
00:07:32.576 --> 00:07:39.240
some SMTP, some MTP, probably protocols
like that are pretty prevalent.

149
00:07:39.240 --> 00:07:44.890
So TCP, UDP based protocols, but we may
never see Protocol X and Protocol Y.

150
00:07:44.890 --> 00:07:45.636
Right?
And so

151
00:07:45.636 --> 00:07:49.267
if all of a sudden we start seeing those
protocols, then that may be unusual.

152
00:07:49.267 --> 00:07:52.783
And so these systems that do
protocol based anomaly scanning or

153
00:07:52.783 --> 00:07:56.897
detection are gonna create a baseline
profile of what normal behavior and

154
00:07:56.897 --> 00:07:58.500
normal traffic equals.

155
00:07:58.500 --> 00:08:00.700
They're gonna start flagging protocols.

156
00:08:00.700 --> 00:08:02.267
That are not part of that baseline.

157
00:08:02.267 --> 00:08:03.689
This is again something to think about.

158
00:08:03.689 --> 00:08:08.107
Statistical anomaly based detection,
same idea, but instead of just looking at

159
00:08:08.107 --> 00:08:12.370
protocol traffic or protocols,
we're looking at the traffic flow overall.

160
00:08:12.370 --> 00:08:16.620
How much traffic from all locations
to what locations, what IP addresses,

161
00:08:16.620 --> 00:08:20.460
what MAC addresses, what are we using,
what are the transmission mechanisms?

162
00:08:20.460 --> 00:08:23.830
Things like that, we're gonna build
again a baseline of normal behavior.

163
00:08:23.830 --> 00:08:27.740
The longer these systems run,
the better they get at detecting anomalies

164
00:08:27.740 --> 00:08:30.720
because the better they
understand what normal equals.

165
00:08:30.720 --> 00:08:34.270
Right, if I just really met you for
the first time and I said to you hey,

166
00:08:34.270 --> 00:08:35.720
do you know a lot about me?

167
00:08:35.720 --> 00:08:37.710
You're gonna say,
well no not really, we just met.

168
00:08:37.710 --> 00:08:39.010
I don't know much about you.

169
00:08:39.010 --> 00:08:41.970
But if we spend a lot of time together,
we're gonna learn a lot more

170
00:08:41.970 --> 00:08:44.830
about each other just through the time
we spent talking and interacting.

171
00:08:44.830 --> 00:08:47.160
And it's gonna be easier
to answer that question.

172
00:08:47.160 --> 00:08:51.120
And so the systems that run for long
periods of time, examining your traffic,

173
00:08:51.120 --> 00:08:54.980
building your baseline, are gonna be
a lot better at finding anomalies.

174
00:08:54.980 --> 00:08:57.080
So these programs,
in other words have to be tuned.

175
00:08:57.080 --> 00:08:58.900
They have to be, what's called broken in.

176
00:08:58.900 --> 00:09:02.470
We often talk about a break in period with
these, where you have to run them for

177
00:09:02.470 --> 00:09:05.740
several weeks, maybe even several
months before they really get good.

178
00:09:05.740 --> 00:09:08.460
At understanding all the things that
potentially are going on in the system.

179
00:09:08.460 --> 00:09:10.256
So just wanna be thinking about that.

180
00:09:10.256 --> 00:09:12.160
We have anti-malware, antivirus systems,

181
00:09:12.160 --> 00:09:15.020
we talked about these,
hopefully have a sense of what they are.

182
00:09:15.020 --> 00:09:16.820
Hopefully you're running them,
by the way, and

183
00:09:16.820 --> 00:09:20.095
not just running one; shouldn't you be
running more than one of these, right?

184
00:09:20.095 --> 00:09:24.025
The problem with running a single
antivirus and/or anti-malware program

185
00:09:24.025 --> 00:09:28.795
today is that the signature files that are
put up by the vendor may not be enough and

186
00:09:28.795 --> 00:09:29.985
may not be current enough and

187
00:09:29.985 --> 00:09:32.445
be updated enough to capture
everything that's out there.

188
00:09:32.445 --> 00:09:35.285
Because not every vendor is
gonna have a signature for

189
00:09:35.285 --> 00:09:38.725
every attack that exists, and
they may have different signatures for

190
00:09:38.725 --> 00:09:41.330
different derivatives or
versions of that attack.

191
00:09:41.330 --> 00:09:42.940
Because malware can change.

192
00:09:42.940 --> 00:09:46.550
We have polymorphic viruses
that can effectively morph or

193
00:09:46.550 --> 00:09:48.430
change every time they execute.

194
00:09:48.430 --> 00:09:51.290
And so there's a lot of things
going on out there that

195
00:09:51.290 --> 00:09:54.140
one vendor by themselves may
not be able to keep up with.

196
00:09:54.140 --> 00:09:56.380
The recommendation in the Enterprise,
that you run at least two or

197
00:09:56.380 --> 00:09:58.610
three different programs, overlapping.

198
00:09:58.610 --> 00:10:00.450
Because chances are good,
if you run two or

199
00:10:00.450 --> 00:10:03.242
three different vendors programs,
between the three of them,

200
00:10:03.242 --> 00:10:07.350

00:21:03.220 --> 00:21:07.450
is gonna say what needs to be said, but
is not gonna get dragged down rabbit holes

428
00:21:07.450 --> 00:21:09.740
about giving out more
information than they should.

429
00:21:09.740 --> 00:21:12.630
This is very important when we
think about reporting with regards

430
00:21:12.630 --> 00:21:13.860
to incident response, right?

431
00:21:13.860 --> 00:21:17.250
Because we have to make sure that
we're not gonna give out information

432
00:21:17.250 --> 00:21:19.260
that can compromise an investigation.

433
00:21:19.260 --> 00:21:20.310
We don't wanna start rumors.

434
00:21:20.310 --> 00:21:21.430
They're not on purpose, but

435
00:21:21.430 --> 00:21:24.520
we just don't wanna give out information
that may not be accurate, in other words.

436
00:21:24.520 --> 00:21:28.517
And we wanna make sure that the
information we are giving out is gonna be

437
00:21:28.517 --> 00:21:32.130
okay to discuss, but
also is gonna be appropriate to release.

438
00:21:32.130 --> 00:21:33.720
And these are things to consider.

439
00:21:33.720 --> 00:21:36.760
So, wanna make sure when we're
thinking of recovery, ultimately,

440
00:21:36.760 --> 00:21:38.010
getting back to normal.

441
00:21:38.010 --> 00:21:41.250
That we are eradicating any traces
of whatever may have occurred, and

442
00:21:41.250 --> 00:21:43.600
we are restoring any and
all affected systems.

443
00:21:43.600 --> 00:21:46.870
And, of course, obviously,
as a result of that, restoring any or

444
00:21:46.870 --> 00:21:48.258
all affected capabilities.

445
00:21:48.258 --> 00:21:50.470
So, we wanna make sure we get back
to normal, in other words, right?

446
00:21:50.470 --> 00:21:52.820
So, if we need to have a web server,

447
00:21:52.820 --> 00:21:55.130
then we need to make sure that web
server's functioning correctly.

448
00:21:55.130 --> 00:21:57.600
We need to make sure we can resolve and
get to the web.

449
00:21:57.600 --> 00:22:00.810
These are all things that we, you would
want to make sure are gonna be intact.

450
00:22:00.810 --> 00:22:03.490
We need to also think about
what's known as lessons learned.

451
00:22:03.490 --> 00:22:06.970
In project management speak,
this would be a post mortem, or

452
00:22:06.970 --> 00:22:09.840
a post implementation review, a PIR.

453
00:22:09.840 --> 00:22:12.220
Project management speaks
about it differently.

454
00:22:12.220 --> 00:22:14.712
But the end of the day, we're really
talking about root cause analysis.

455
00:22:14.712 --> 00:22:17.720
We wanna make sure we understand
what the true nature,

456
00:22:17.720 --> 00:22:20.610
the true purpose behind that
particular incident was.

457
00:22:20.610 --> 00:22:22.122
The reason why it occurred.

458
00:22:22.122 --> 00:22:24.960
We wanna know the how,
the when, the who, the what.

459
00:22:24.960 --> 00:22:28.130
But we really, ultimately,
wanna understand the why.

460
00:22:28.130 --> 00:22:28.920
Why did this occur?

461
00:22:28.920 --> 00:22:30.500
What was the root reason for this?

462
00:22:30.500 --> 00:22:32.520
Was it a misconfiguration?

463
00:22:32.520 --> 00:22:34.070
Was it operator error?

464
00:22:34.070 --> 00:22:37.130
Was it going to be because
we were infected with

465
00:22:37.130 --> 00:22:41.200
a bad malware that came
through on a scanned media?

466
00:22:41.200 --> 00:22:44.290
Was it because the system
had been rooted by somebody?

467
00:22:44.290 --> 00:22:45.830
Was it internal action?

468
00:22:45.830 --> 00:22:48.650
There's all these answers
that could go into the why.

469
00:22:48.650 --> 00:22:50.020
We wanna know what it was.

470
00:22:50.020 --> 00:22:55.110
If we keep asking why, iteratively,
until we get down to what

471
00:22:55.110 --> 00:23:00.560
we call the root cause why,
the ultimate why.

472
00:23:00.560 --> 00:23:04.420
I sound like the prophet of why here,
right?

473
00:23:04.420 --> 00:23:05.740
I keep asking why.

474
00:23:05.740 --> 00:23:10.170
Just keep saying why, boys and girls,
and everything will become right.

475
00:23:10.170 --> 00:23:11.490
All copacetic.

476
00:23:11.490 --> 00:23:15.040
So, the Japanese actually
have a methodology for this.

477
00:23:15.040 --> 00:23:18.520
Specifically, Toyota as a company
has a methodology for this.

478
00:23:18.520 --> 00:23:20.370
It's called the seven Ws.

479
00:23:20.370 --> 00:23:23.860
And they use it to kind of drive
their manufacturing process.

480
00:23:23.860 --> 00:23:26.700
And they use it to understand
how to get to root cause.

481
00:23:26.700 --> 00:23:29.630
It's actually well-studied in
industrial engineering, and

482
00:23:29.630 --> 00:23:33.830
it's a methodology that no matter how many
people have tried to reproduce, it's very

483
00:23:33.830 --> 00:23:38.045
difficult because the reality is getting
the root cause is very challenging.

484
00:23:38.045 --> 00:23:41.560
Because sometimes even though we ask
the question, we're really not able to

485
00:23:41.560 --> 00:23:44.830
understand how to derive the answer,
which is really what, ultimately, we need.

486
00:23:44.830 --> 00:23:47.960
Which is what caused this
particular event to occur?

487
00:23:47.960 --> 00:23:49.270
Why did it occur?

488
00:23:49.270 --> 00:23:50.680
Yeah.
We may come up with answers, but

489
00:23:50.680 --> 00:23:54.390
they may not be at the root, ultimately,
at the bottom of what really occurred.

490
00:23:54.390 --> 00:23:56.181
Or we may not be willing to go there,
right?

491
00:23:56.181 --> 00:23:59.068
People may just not be willing to
accept responsibility, and say,

492
00:23:59.068 --> 00:24:02.472
yeah, I'm the one who did that thing,
and as a result, it's really my fault.

493
00:24:02.472 --> 00:24:03.602
So in the general thought process
of how we do incident response,

494
00:24:03.602 --> 00:24:04.865
we're really just ultimately dealing
with events that are occurring.

495
00:24:04.865 --> 00:24:08.790
But we do want you to think about that and
do need you to understand that.

496
00:24:08.790 --> 00:24:13.140
So asking why, going through and asking
why, it's relatively very important.

497
00:24:13.140 --> 00:24:16.050
We may also look at things like
failure mode and affects analysis.

498
00:24:16.050 --> 00:24:19.485
What's called FMEA, it's another
approach to get through root cause.

499
00:24:19.485 --> 00:24:24.260
Parental analysis, analysis, diagrams.

500
00:24:24.260 --> 00:24:27.640
These are all examples of potentially
how to get to root cause through

501
00:24:27.640 --> 00:24:32.100
fault domain analysis and different
solutions that ultimately allow us to map

502
00:24:32.100 --> 00:24:37.020
out the sequence of events and
trace them back to the origination point.

503
00:24:37.020 --> 00:24:38.358
When they do outbreak studies for

504
00:24:38.358 --> 00:24:40.804
viruses this is effectively
the methodology that's used.

505
00:24:40.804 --> 00:24:42.770
We trace back to patient zero.

506
00:24:42.770 --> 00:24:44.885
And that's the idea,
that's root cause, ultimately.

507
00:24:44.885 --> 00:24:47.436
So we wanna make sure we
understand that logic and

508
00:24:47.436 --> 00:24:49.689
really understand how that can impact us.

509
00:24:49.689 --> 00:24:52.926
We also need to think about problem
versus incident management and

510
00:24:52.926 --> 00:24:57.190
the definition of what a problem is versus
the definition of what an incident is.

511
00:24:57.190 --> 00:25:00.570
So in the general thought process
of how we do incident response,

512
00:25:00.570 --> 00:25:04.325
we're really just ultimately dealing
with events that are occurring.

513
00:25:04.325 --> 00:25:07.496
But the question becomes is it an event
that we've never seen before or

514
00:25:07.496 --> 00:25:09.280
is it an event that we have seen before?

515
00:25:09.280 --> 00:25:12.398
And if we have seen it before and it
becomes a repetitive event then why are we

516
00:25:12.398 --> 00:25:15.915
responding to it the same way we have been
responding to it before because ultimately

517
00:25:15.915 --> 00:25:18.360
the outcome is probably
going to be the same?

518
00:25:18.360 --> 00:25:22.070
So, we have to differentiate between
events that have never occurred and

519
00:25:22.070 --> 00:25:23.550
events that are repetitive.

520
00:25:23.550 --> 00:25:27.880
Incidents are events that we've never
seen before, we don't have knowledge of.

521
00:25:27.880 --> 00:25:31.400
They effectively are occurring for the
first time in the traditional definition.

522
00:25:31.400 --> 00:25:32.480
A problem,

523
00:25:32.480 --> 00:25:36.070
at least in the classic definition of
what an incident versus a problem is.

524
00:25:36.070 --> 00:25:40.390
A problem is classified as an incident
that has become systemic or is repetitive.

525
00:25:40.390 --> 00:25:44.430
In other words, it keeps recurring and
it's grown up to become a problem.

526
00:25:44.430 --> 00:25:48.690
So incidents are things we've never
seen before, first time events,

527
00:25:48.690 --> 00:25:52.220
problems are repetitive incidents that
have not really been root caused and

528
00:25:52.220 --> 00:25:54.525
have not actually been solved properly.

529
00:25:54.525 --> 00:25:57.625
In the sense we put a patch on them,
we think we dealt with them, but

530
00:25:57.625 --> 00:26:01.545
then in hindsight as we look at them
later, through analysis we see it keeps

531
00:26:01.545 --> 00:26:04.275
reoccurring and as a result of
that we understand, hopefully,

532
00:26:04.275 --> 00:26:07.465
if we do this right, we understand we
haven't really found the root cause and

533
00:26:07.465 --> 00:26:09.819
we have to keep drilling down
to figure out what that is.

534
00:26:10.920 --> 00:26:11.500
>> Very good, Adam.

535
00:26:11.500 --> 00:26:14.020
It's a great look at
that incident management,

536
00:26:14.020 --> 00:26:17.640
something that we hope we don't have to
deal with but in reality we're going to.

537
00:26:17.640 --> 00:26:22.000
Now we have a better understanding of how
we need to handle that to make sure we

538
00:26:22.000 --> 00:26:25.020
minimize damage,
handle that situation properly.

539
00:26:25.020 --> 00:26:25.520
Thanks for that.

540
00:26:25.520 --> 00:26:28.260
And remember if you guys want to
attend one of Adam's classes live

541
00:26:28.260 --> 00:26:33.020
All you got to do is shoot us
an email here SeeAdam@itpro.tv

542
00:26:33.020 --> 00:26:34.870
signing off I'm Mike Roderick.

543
00:26:34.870 --> 00:26:37.350
>> I'm first incident
responder Adam Gordon.

544
00:26:37.350 --> 00:26:38.450
>> And we'll see you next time.

545
00:26:38.450 --> 00:26:39.295
>> Take care everybody.

546
00:26:39.295 --> 00:26:47.050
[NOISE].

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike discuss preventative measures. They talk about making sure the preventative measures in place are appropriate for a specific risk, and making sure they are working as expected.
episodes.title: Preventative Measures
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.092 --> 00:00:16.240
Hello, welcome to another exciting
episode here at ITpro TV.

3
00:00:16.240 --> 00:00:19.600
I'm your host Mike Roderick,
today we're doing our CISSP content,

4
00:00:19.600 --> 00:00:23.610
and specifically we're gonna be
looking at how to operate and

5
00:00:23.610 --> 00:00:25.960
maintain our preventative measures, right.

6
00:00:25.960 --> 00:00:28.580
We've talked a lot about
the different preventative measures

7
00:00:28.580 --> 00:00:29.940
that we have available.

8
00:00:29.940 --> 00:00:33.300
Gotta make sure we're working those
right and keeping them going.

9
00:00:33.300 --> 00:00:36.020
So here to help us with all that is Mr.
Adam Gordon.

10
00:00:36.020 --> 00:00:37.150
How's it going Adam?

11
00:00:37.150 --> 00:00:37.680
>> Good, good.

12
00:00:37.680 --> 00:00:40.035
We're gonna talk a little bit
about preventative measures.

13
00:00:40.035 --> 00:00:44.280
So let's start by thinking about what
it is we are looking to prevent, right?

14
00:00:44.280 --> 00:00:46.500
Because if we have preventive measures,
and

15
00:00:46.500 --> 00:00:49.820
we're not sure what we're focusing them
on, then they might not be appropriate.

16
00:00:49.820 --> 00:00:52.660
So what we want to understand
is; what are the concerns we may

17
00:00:52.660 --> 00:00:54.370
have as a security professional?

18
00:00:54.370 --> 00:00:56.310
That would force us or think us.

19
00:00:56.310 --> 00:00:57.010
Or think us?

20
00:00:57.010 --> 00:00:58.030
Listen to me.

21
00:00:58.030 --> 00:01:01.280
Would ask us to think about the ways
in which we may have to actually use

22
00:01:01.280 --> 00:01:02.450
a preventative measure.

23
00:01:02.450 --> 00:01:05.780
What we have to get good at as security
professionals is understanding risk.

24
00:01:05.780 --> 00:01:08.760
We talked a lot about risk and
why risk is important.

25
00:01:08.760 --> 00:01:09.940
We've talked about threats.

26
00:01:09.940 --> 00:01:11.200
We've talked about vulnerabilities.

27
00:01:11.200 --> 00:01:13.690
We talked about threat sources and
threat events.

28
00:01:13.690 --> 00:01:16.420
All, reminding you of all
this vocabulary yet again.

29
00:01:16.420 --> 00:01:17.880
Because it is important.

30
00:01:17.880 --> 00:01:19.620
So if we're focused on risk, and

31
00:01:19.620 --> 00:01:23.940
we're focused on vulnerability, then the
preventative measures we have to be using

32
00:01:23.940 --> 00:01:28.080
really have to be tailored to help us to
understand how to address those concerns.

33
00:01:28.080 --> 00:01:32.100
Things like firewalls, for instance,
which will be border gateway devices

34
00:01:32.100 --> 00:01:35.200
that will filter inbound and
or outbound traffic.

35
00:01:35.200 --> 00:01:41.460
Looking for IP address,
Mac address, protocol, port number.

36
00:01:41.460 --> 00:01:44.684
These are the kind of things that we
use to match traffic and allow or

37
00:01:44.684 --> 00:01:46.480
to deny it through the firewall.

38
00:01:46.480 --> 00:01:49.940
So these are designed effectively,
as we've talked about these devices,

39
00:01:49.940 --> 00:01:54.070
to filter,
to do examination of traffic flow.

40
00:01:54.070 --> 00:01:57.180
We've also talked about the fact that
firewalls can be either stateless or

41
00:01:57.180 --> 00:01:57.730
stateful.

42
00:01:57.730 --> 00:02:01.620
You wanna remember the difference between
the two, making sure that we understand

43
00:02:01.620 --> 00:02:04.000
that firewalls can operate
at the network layer,

44
00:02:04.000 --> 00:02:06.190
the application layer of the OSI model.

45
00:02:06.190 --> 00:02:07.980
They can be found in different places,

46
00:02:07.980 --> 00:02:11.260
they can have access to different
information as a result of that.

47
00:02:11.260 --> 00:02:14.600
And so we want to understand that
services, ports, protocols would obviously

48
00:02:14.600 --> 00:02:17.580
be things that we'd be looking at
up near the application layer.

49
00:02:17.580 --> 00:02:21.530
Whereas IP addresses, MAC addresses are
things we traditionally want to be looking

50
00:02:21.530 --> 00:02:24.144
at down towards the network layer,
and maybe even lower into

51
00:02:24.144 --> 00:02:27.075
the to the data link later if we're
looking at Mac addresses, right.

52
00:02:27.075 --> 00:02:30.055
So wanna be thinking about where
the device is, where it operates,

53
00:02:30.055 --> 00:02:34.425
what kind of access to information it will
have as part of a preventative measure.

54
00:02:34.425 --> 00:02:38.815
We've also talked about IDSs,
intrusion detection systems, IPSs,

55
00:02:38.815 --> 00:02:40.575
intrusion prevention systems.

56
00:02:40.575 --> 00:02:43.680
We've spoken about whether they
are network based or host based.

57
00:02:43.680 --> 00:02:47.320
Network based devices will be effectively
installed at flow points within

58
00:02:47.320 --> 00:02:51.260
the organizational flow of
information in the routing path.

59
00:02:51.260 --> 00:02:54.510
So this will typically be a device
of some kind that is installed

60
00:02:54.510 --> 00:02:58.410
at a key choke point we wanna monitor
on the network or in the network.

61
00:02:58.410 --> 00:03:01.640
And all the traffic will flow through
that device on its way to and

62
00:03:01.640 --> 00:03:03.290
from wherever it's going.

63
00:03:03.290 --> 00:03:07.810
If it is a host based IDS or IPS,
it's gonna be an agent based solution

64
00:03:07.810 --> 00:03:12.090
that will effectively allow us to
install software on a single entity.

65
00:03:12.090 --> 00:03:13.850
We're traditionally
thinking about servers,

66
00:03:13.850 --> 00:03:15.520
not really desktops in this regard.

67
00:03:16.980 --> 00:03:21.130
No reason we couldn't in theory put
an IDS or an IPS on a desktop, but

68
00:03:21.130 --> 00:03:25.050
the traditional place we find them is on
servers that we wanna monitor traffic

69
00:03:25.050 --> 00:03:29.500
against, so web servers, email servers,
database servers, file and

70
00:03:29.500 --> 00:03:32.890
print servers tend to be the targets
of this kind of monitoring,

71
00:03:32.890 --> 00:03:34.600
cuz they tend to be
the targets of attacks.

72
00:03:34.600 --> 00:03:37.220
That's really where we wanna
see the behavior occurring.

73
00:03:37.220 --> 00:03:41.560
So we'll be putting a software agent of
some kind, a little program Onto a system.

74
00:03:41.560 --> 00:03:45.740
We will then be using that program to
gather data about the information flow in

75
00:03:45.740 --> 00:03:46.960
and out of that computer.

76
00:03:46.960 --> 00:03:50.784
And then we're then going to ship that off
into a management solutions somewhere.

77
00:03:50.784 --> 00:03:54.380
And aggregate the data and
analysis it, visualize it.

78
00:03:54.380 --> 00:03:58.150
Use business intelligence to assess it and
to look for patterns.

79
00:03:58.150 --> 00:03:59.570
Also to retain the data for

80
00:03:59.570 --> 00:04:02.830
a period of time so we can look back
historically and see what's been going on.

81
00:04:02.830 --> 00:04:05.030
So these are the kind of
activities we would see there.

82
00:04:05.030 --> 00:04:08.390
Difference between host based and
network based will be important for

83
00:04:08.390 --> 00:04:10.070
you to consider as well.

84
00:04:10.070 --> 00:04:15.730
Keep in mind there are traditionally
two ways we do IDS or IPS solutions.

85
00:04:15.730 --> 00:04:17.560
We can assign from network and host based.

86
00:04:17.560 --> 00:04:21.080
There are two ways we drive the engines
then after we do the analysis,

87
00:04:21.080 --> 00:04:24.700
the scanning and therefore
the pattern matching on our data.

88
00:04:24.700 --> 00:04:27.780
We could do pattern matching or
we could do anomaly detection.

89
00:04:27.780 --> 00:04:29.540
Pattern matching is
the idea of looking for

90
00:04:29.540 --> 00:04:31.710
behavior that matches certain signatures.

91
00:04:31.710 --> 00:04:36.020
So we can think of this much
like we would a antivirus or

92
00:04:36.020 --> 00:04:40.150
anti malware software item where we
are downloading signature file and

93
00:04:40.150 --> 00:04:42.950
then we are effectively looking for
behavior that matches that.

94
00:04:42.950 --> 00:04:46.390
Call that pattern matching or
signature file detection.

95
00:04:46.390 --> 00:04:48.920
We then can also do anomaly detection.

96
00:04:48.920 --> 00:04:51.780
Anomaly detection is much like
we talked about with protocol or

97
00:04:51.780 --> 00:04:53.990
statistical anomaly thought processes.

98
00:04:53.990 --> 00:04:56.700
When we look at AV or
malware software, and

99
00:04:56.700 --> 00:04:59.770
we look at the idea that we can
develop a base line effect.

100
00:04:59.770 --> 00:05:02.390
We understand what is normal, right?

101
00:05:02.390 --> 00:05:05.770
And then when we know what's normal,
we then can know what is abnormal.

102
00:05:05.770 --> 00:05:09.790
And if we understand what's abnormal or
not normal, We can see deltas or gaps, and

103
00:05:09.790 --> 00:05:14.240
we can then start zeroing in on that
kind of traffic, and then identify it,

104
00:05:14.240 --> 00:05:16.130
of course, and understand it as such.

105
00:05:16.130 --> 00:05:17.540
So, just want to think about that.

106
00:05:17.540 --> 00:05:19.928
Want to think about the ways in
which anomaly detection may work.

107
00:05:19.928 --> 00:05:22.415
Your anomaly detection
may not look at anything.

108
00:05:22.415 --> 00:05:25.855
Suspicious log ons during or
outside of the normal log on period,

109
00:05:25.855 --> 00:05:28.935
you learn how to fail log on
attempts at 2 in the morning when

110
00:05:28.935 --> 00:05:31.345
we don't normally see a lot of traffic
would potentially be an anomaly.

So they do a quick headcount.

337
00:16:04.994 --> 00:16:07.513
And then ultimately you have
to stand outside and wait.

338
00:16:07.513 --> 00:16:10.790
So we're hanging out, we're waiting,
everybody's just kind of talking.

339
00:16:10.790 --> 00:16:13.900
And then eventually the base security
officer comes out and says, okay,

340
00:16:13.900 --> 00:16:17.650
it's all clear, or comes out and says a
couple of times, there actually is a fire,

341
00:16:17.650 --> 00:16:18.600
it's not a drill.

342
00:16:18.600 --> 00:16:21.008
We heard the fire trucks coming,
the whole nine yards.

343
00:16:21.008 --> 00:16:23.540
Eventually they clear the building and
they say, yeah, it's all clear,

344
00:16:23.540 --> 00:16:24.280
you can come back in.

345
00:16:24.280 --> 00:16:25.990
And then you have to go
through the process,

346
00:16:25.990 --> 00:16:29.890
put the badge back on, badge back in,
go through the gate, go in the other way.

347
00:16:29.890 --> 00:16:33.250
But it's a process, and you gotta make
sure people understand the process.

348
00:16:33.250 --> 00:16:37.010
It's very important,
not just with regards to fire safety, but

349
00:16:37.010 --> 00:16:38.330
with regards to anything.

350
00:16:38.330 --> 00:16:39.660
If there was an incident,

351
00:16:39.660 --> 00:16:43.630
the same thought process should apply,
people show be trained as to what to do.

352
00:16:43.630 --> 00:16:47.790
Talked about the fact that the first
responder is probably not going to be

353
00:16:47.790 --> 00:16:50.680
a security professional, it's probably
going to be an individual user.

354
00:16:50.680 --> 00:16:54.750
They're going to be at the point of the
attack, and we have to train them enough

355
00:16:54.750 --> 00:16:57.300
to make them understand they should pay
attention to the warning signs, and

356
00:16:57.300 --> 00:16:58.430
then report back to us.

357
00:16:58.430 --> 00:16:59.230
It's very important.

358
00:16:59.230 --> 00:17:01.640
So, think about that,
make sure we're aware of that.

359
00:17:01.640 --> 00:17:06.232
Obviously updating IPSs and IDSs regularly
with signature file updates, with

360
00:17:06.232 --> 00:17:11.620
patches from the vendor, very important,
gotta do that, just like anything else.

361
00:17:11.620 --> 00:17:13.070
We may using white listing or

362
00:17:13.070 --> 00:17:17.740
black listing on these devices to be
able to create allow or deny lists.

363
00:17:17.740 --> 00:17:22.670
We may be doing spam filtering, we may be
doing sand boxing, or honey potting, or

364
00:17:22.670 --> 00:17:26.460
honey nets to be able to catch and
examine traffic and

365
00:17:26.460 --> 00:17:28.560
information that may
prove to be a challenge.

366
00:17:28.560 --> 00:17:31.750
There are lots of different ways
to achieve this end result today.

367
00:17:31.750 --> 00:17:34.340
Any or all of these technologies
are appropriate, but

368
00:17:34.340 --> 00:17:35.320
we have to understand them.

369
00:17:35.320 --> 00:17:37.890
We have to understand them for
what they are, their limitations, but

370
00:17:37.890 --> 00:17:39.195
also their capabilities.

371
00:17:39.195 --> 00:17:40.510
Sandboxing has become very,

372
00:17:40.510 --> 00:17:43.420
very important today because
of the rise of virtualization.

373
00:17:43.420 --> 00:17:44.950
It's very prevalent today.

374
00:17:44.950 --> 00:17:46.650
You can create a virtual machine, and

375
00:17:46.650 --> 00:17:52.010
we can use one in almost any circumstance
to not only recreate behavior but

376
00:17:52.010 --> 00:17:55.680
also to create an environment where we can
test things because we can isolate them.

377
00:17:55.680 --> 00:17:59.510
We can effectively put a VM on a host,
disconnect it from the network so

378
00:17:59.510 --> 00:18:03.740
it cannot communicate, we call it
isolating the VM, and as a result of that,

379
00:18:03.740 --> 00:18:07.790
we effectively have a memory bubble that
allows us to be interactive with the VM.

380
00:18:07.790 --> 00:18:12.060
We can infect the VM with malware, we can
examine what it does, without allowing it

381
00:18:12.060 --> 00:18:16.000
to escape beyond the memory bubble to get
into the host and affect anything else.

382
00:18:16.000 --> 00:18:18.970
And this is how a lot of
AV research is done today.

383
00:18:18.970 --> 00:18:22.530
We use virtualized sandbox
environments to effectively reproduce

384
00:18:22.530 --> 00:18:26.530
the behavior of the malware, or
reproduce the behavior of the issue, and

385
00:18:26.530 --> 00:18:30.090
the thing that we were talking about and
examining, to then better understand it.

386
00:18:30.090 --> 00:18:33.010
So when we think about patch management,
vulnerability management,

387
00:18:33.010 --> 00:18:36.430
we're thinking about these kinds
of thought processes as well.

388
00:18:36.430 --> 00:18:39.020
We know generically that
patch management is critical.

389
00:18:39.020 --> 00:18:42.330
We have to apply patches to systems,
we have to keep up to date with them.

390
00:18:42.330 --> 00:18:46.300
On average most major vendors put out,
I don't know, I'm guessing,

391
00:18:46.300 --> 00:18:49.810
maybe 15 to 20 patches a month,
maybe every other month.

392
00:18:49.810 --> 00:18:52.840
Microsoft tends to put out at
least 10 to 15 patches a month.

393
00:18:52.840 --> 00:18:54.750
VM ware maybe not so much.

394
00:18:54.750 --> 00:18:56.480
Cisco, maybe not so much.

395
00:18:56.480 --> 00:18:58.090
But they do put out patches.

396
00:18:58.090 --> 00:19:01.730
Juniper is gonna be putting out a major
patch, they actually already did actually.

397
00:19:01.730 --> 00:19:04.910
They have an emergency patch they
put out to deal with their issue.

398
00:19:04.910 --> 00:19:07.520
And I love the guidance
that comes with this.

399
00:19:07.520 --> 00:19:10.260
You need to apply the patch,
it's really important blah, blah, blah.

400
00:19:10.260 --> 00:19:11.760
And it's super critical,

401
00:19:11.760 --> 00:19:15.090
this is the official term,
it's a super critical patch.

402
00:19:15.090 --> 00:19:16.970
You should apply it immediately.

403
00:19:16.970 --> 00:19:19.410
Yeah, it's super critical we
should apply it immediately.

404
00:19:19.410 --> 00:19:22.300
What you should have done, was done
a better job of figuring out if some body

405
00:19:22.300 --> 00:19:25.690
broke in to your systems immediately
is what really should have happened.

406
00:19:25.690 --> 00:19:29.780
But, reality is look, this stuff is
tough to find, it's tough to understand,

407
00:19:29.780 --> 00:19:30.990
it's tough to diagnose.

408
00:19:30.990 --> 00:19:31.900
If they had known about,

409
00:19:31.900 --> 00:19:34.920
it I'm sure they would have taken steps
to obviously, immediately deal with it.

410
00:19:34.920 --> 00:19:37.150
So we don't wanna make fun
of a situation like this.

411
00:19:37.150 --> 00:19:40.680
It's very serious, all kidding aside, and
there are a lot of potential concerns and

412
00:19:40.680 --> 00:19:44.920
liabilities, that could come out of
an attack on a major vendor like this.

413
00:19:44.920 --> 00:19:48.110
But, there's nothing wrong with laughing
at somebody elses pain once in a while,

414
00:19:48.110 --> 00:19:49.660
as long as you don't do it too often,
right?

415
00:19:49.660 --> 00:19:52.180
So, when we talk about patch management,

416
00:19:52.180 --> 00:19:56.720
we talk about vulnerability concerns, this
really, an event like this focuses us,

417
00:19:56.720 --> 00:20:00.670
focuses our minds, on the fact that A,
we don't wanna be that person.

418
00:20:00.670 --> 00:20:04.220
We don't wanna be the person
who obviously has this concern.

419
00:20:04.220 --> 00:20:07.350
But if we're using a vendor's product and
we don't know that the vendor has

420
00:20:07.350 --> 00:20:10.220
been compromised, cuz the vendor
doesn't know they've been compromised,

421
00:20:10.220 --> 00:20:13.830
then we're obviously gonna be at the mercy
of the vendor to figure out how to fix it.

422
00:20:13.830 --> 00:20:16.210
You know kudos, and all kidding aside,
kudos to Juniper for

423
00:20:16.210 --> 00:20:19.220
putting out a patch right away,
as soon as they figured it out.

424
00:20:19.220 --> 00:20:20.270
Getting it out there.

425
00:20:20.270 --> 00:20:23.240
Telling every customer they have
to apply this patch immediately

426
00:20:23.240 --> 00:20:26.160
no matter what else they're doing,
it's a priority for them.

427
00:20:26.160 --> 00:20:29.060
They did all the right things,
that's exactly what they need to do.

428
00:20:29.060 --> 00:20:31.840
And obviously, as a customer, you have
to then take that to the next level,

429
00:20:31.840 --> 00:20:35.540
pay attention to it and understand
the impact of running a potential system

430
00:20:35.540 --> 00:20:37.900
with this kind of root
level vulnerability.

431
00:20:37.900 --> 00:20:40.098
This can be a very,
very big concern for you.

432
00:20:40.098 --> 00:20:43.770
So determining if patching is necessary,
it's obviously a combination of examining

433
00:20:43.770 --> 00:20:46.740
the system,
understanding what the vendor guidance is.

434
00:20:46.740 --> 00:20:48.460
And you know what?
We often make mistakes doing

435
00:20:48.460 --> 00:20:49.940
the security professionals,

436
00:20:49.940 --> 00:20:54.790
we often don't spend as much time as
we should reading the patch guidance,

437
00:20:54.790 --> 00:20:58.670
the release notes, really understanding
what patches are designed to do.

438
00:20:58.670 --> 00:21:01.750
We do regression testing, hopefully,
we do patch testing, hopefully.

439
00:21:01.750 --> 00:21:03.710
We do have a sense of
what the patches are.

440
00:21:03.710 --> 00:21:05.980
Hopefully, we understand
the impact of them, and

441
00:21:05.980 --> 00:21:09.790
hopefully you're doing your due diligence
and exercising due care with those things.

442
00:21:09.790 --> 00:21:12.260
But I find,
when I talk to security professionals,

443
00:21:12.260 --> 00:21:15.380
that they don't tend to spend a lot
of time reading the release notes and

444
00:21:15.380 --> 00:21:17.700
really understanding what
a patch is designed to do.

445
00:21:17.700 --> 00:21:20.800
They apply it after they test it to
make sure it doesn't break anything, but

446
00:21:20.800 --> 00:21:23.280
they don't necessarily
know what the patch does.

447
00:21:23.280 --> 00:21:25.800
They just know generically yeah,
the vendor put out these four patches,

448
00:21:25.800 --> 00:21:28.740
I was told I gotta apply them,
our change window is tomorrow night,

449
00:21:28.740 --> 00:21:32.710
we're regression testing today in QA,
and we've teed them up for tomorrow.

450
00:21:32.710 --> 00:21:36.290
But if you ask the security professional
what do the patches actually do?

451
00:21:36.290 --> 00:21:39.372
I'm not really sure, I just know we gotta
apply them is what you often hear, and

452
00:21:39.372 --> 00:21:40.670
that's a little scary, right?

453
00:21:41.670 --> 00:21:46.410
That's effectively saying to me,
I don't really know what I'm doing, but

454
00:21:46.410 --> 00:21:48.780
I think I'm doing what I'm supposed to,
so I'm just gonna go ahead and

455
00:21:48.780 --> 00:21:51.150
do that until somebody tells
me to do something else.

456
00:21:51.150 --> 00:21:55.250
Due diligence and
due care is not about blindly following

457
00:21:55.250 --> 00:21:59.630
a prescribed path simply because
it sounds like it's a good idea.

458
00:21:59.630 --> 00:22:02.820
Years ago, or just in general at
least when I was growing up anyway,

459
00:22:02.820 --> 00:22:06.090
my grandmother, my mother,
my parents in general,

460
00:22:06.090 --> 00:22:10.370
but certainly my grandmother in
particular, would often sit me down and

461
00:22:10.370 --> 00:22:13.800
tell me, basically in plain English,
don't be stupid.

462
00:22:13.800 --> 00:22:18.260
Right, don't do things that other people
do just because they're doing them.

463
00:22:18.260 --> 00:22:19.110
You often hear people say,

464
00:22:19.110 --> 00:22:21.960
would you jump off the roof if
somebody else jumped off the roof?

465
00:22:21.960 --> 00:22:24.842
Well, no, I wouldn't jump off
the roof if somebody else did, right,

466
00:22:24.842 --> 00:22:27.675
unless they were below me and
I could land on them, in which case then,

467
00:22:27.675 --> 00:22:30.260
they would break my fall,
it wouldn't be a big deal.

468
00:22:30.260 --> 00:22:34.430
But you don't wanna be that blind
leading the blind kind of person, right.

469
00:22:34.430 --> 00:22:37.470
We don't wanna be in that situation
where we're doing something

470
00:22:37.470 --> 00:22:41.440
because we think we have to, but we
really don't understand what we're doing.

471
00:22:41.440 --> 00:22:43.630
Make sure you're not that
security professional.

472
00:22:43.630 --> 00:22:49.400
CISSP's first and foremost,
have to understand how to offer guidance,

473
00:22:49.400 --> 00:22:52.380
and offer a perspective on
what is appropriate, and

474
00:22:52.380 --> 00:22:54.410
also what is possible in the business.

475
00:22:54.410 --> 00:22:55.970
And again, I've said this several times,

476
00:22:55.970 --> 00:22:59.090
if you're not clear on that,
it's okay to say, I don't know.

477
00:22:59.090 --> 00:23:01.910
As long as you're willing to
come back with a solution and

478
00:23:01.910 --> 00:23:04.570
an alternative,
after you've done some research.

479
00:23:04.570 --> 00:23:08.750
I sit down and talk to senior level
executives all the time in companies, and

480
00:23:08.750 --> 00:23:10.520
I'm always asked for
my opinion on this or that.

481
00:23:10.520 --> 00:23:11.950
Hey Adam, what do you think about this?

482
00:23:11.950 --> 00:23:13.740
Is this something we
should be concerned about?

483
00:23:13.740 --> 00:23:15.100
Should we be doing this cloud thing?

484
00:23:15.100 --> 00:23:16.790
How are we dealing with
this thing over here?

485
00:23:16.790 --> 00:23:18.710
What are you seeing from other customers?

486
00:23:18.710 --> 00:23:20.315
Help us to better understand our world.

487
00:23:20.315 --> 00:23:23.080
It's what I spend the majority
of my time doing.

488
00:23:23.080 --> 00:23:26.180
And I'm the first person to tell
a customer, to tell a colleague,

489
00:23:26.180 --> 00:23:28.780
to tell a friend, I'm an expert at this,

490
00:23:28.780 --> 00:23:31.090
I can help you with this,
I can do this with my eyes closed.

491
00:23:31.090 --> 00:23:32.806
I don't know the first thing about that.

492
00:23:32.806 --> 00:23:34.720
You're not gonna wanna
talk to me about it, but

493
00:23:34.720 --> 00:23:37.110
guess what,
I can find somebody that you can.

494
00:23:37.110 --> 00:23:40.250
Let me give, give me a couple of days,
let me make a couple of phone calls,

495
00:23:40.250 --> 00:23:41.140
send an email.

496
00:23:41.140 --> 00:23:43.540
I'm gonna hook you up with somebody
that's gonna be able to give you good

497
00:23:43.540 --> 00:23:46.260
information, because this is
just not something that I do.

498
00:23:46.260 --> 00:23:47.860
And I don't wanna give
you wrong information,

499
00:23:47.860 --> 00:23:49.550
I don't wanna give you bad guidance.

500
00:23:49.550 --> 00:23:52.400
Because I may make a mistake
just not knowing the terrain,

501
00:23:52.400 --> 00:23:55.940
not knowing the details, not
understanding the technology that well.

502
00:23:55.940 --> 00:24:00.870
So determining when a patch is necessary,
understanding what action we should take,

503
00:24:00.870 --> 00:24:03.920
this is something that a trained
professional needs to do.

504
00:24:03.920 --> 00:24:08.380
If you're not able to do that, you need to
find the people that are and partner with

505
00:24:08.380 --> 00:24:12.250
them in the scenarios that are deployed,
or that are happening in front of you.

506
00:24:12.250 --> 00:24:17.060
Remember that applying a patch is
a question of following a prescribed

507
00:24:17.060 --> 00:24:21.290
procedure, you should have that
procedure inside the organization.

508
00:24:21.290 --> 00:24:24.270
We should have policies that dictate
we should do have patch management.

509
00:24:24.270 --> 00:24:26.830
We should have procedures that dictate
that we'll download patches from

510
00:24:26.830 --> 00:24:30.960
the vendor, insert comma and
parentheses and comment here.

511
00:24:30.960 --> 00:24:34.560
Adam said make sure you read
patch release notes, got that?

512
00:24:34.560 --> 00:24:37.880
Then what we're gonna
do is test the patches

513
00:24:37.880 --> 00:24:40.820
in a variety of different
scenarios within our organization.

514
00:24:40.820 --> 00:24:45.050
Again, sandboxing, virtualization
to drive regression testing and QA.

515
00:24:45.050 --> 00:24:47.990
It's an acceptable mechanism today,
you may not do it that way,

516
00:24:47.990 --> 00:24:50.080
you may load up a bunch of physical boxes.

517
00:24:50.080 --> 00:24:54.100
Whatever you do, just make sure that
the first time that patch is deployed and

518
00:24:54.100 --> 00:24:57.120
looked at, is not the time you
put it into production, right?

519
00:24:57.120 --> 00:24:59.875
Because that will obviously,
potentially lead to some concerns.

520
00:24:59.875 --> 00:25:04.542
If anybody is old enough to remember, and
was a professional working during this

521
00:25:04.542 --> 00:25:09.550
time, remembering the NT4, service pack
six versus service pack six A debacle.

522
00:25:09.550 --> 00:25:11.820
You don't wanna be on the bleeding
edge of patch management and

523
00:25:11.820 --> 00:25:15.280
find out that you patch your host just
then to turn around and watch a blue

524
00:25:15.280 --> 00:25:20.290
screen, which was the original version of
the NT4 service pack six service pack did.

525
00:25:20.290 --> 00:25:22.380
So if you were the first kid
on your block to say yes,

526
00:25:22.380 --> 00:25:25.350
I'm gonna patch my NT Four
back office implementation.

527
00:25:25.350 --> 00:25:28.310
You were then, the next morning,
the first kid on your block who got

528
00:25:28.310 --> 00:25:31.428
the blue screen to watch the system
never come back up again.

529
00:25:31.428 --> 00:25:34.920
So you wanna make sure that you
understand the impact of these patches.

530
00:25:34.920 --> 00:25:38.495
And all major vendors, by the way,
have had their oopsy moments with NT Four,

531
00:25:38.495 --> 00:25:42.720
six like patching, every vendor has had
at least one of those, if not more.

532
00:25:42.720 --> 00:25:46.800
And it's not uncommon, it doesn't happen
very often, but it's not uncommon.

533
00:25:46.800 --> 00:25:49.830
So as a result of that you understand
the impact of what you're doing to your

534
00:25:49.830 --> 00:25:50.700
systems.

535
00:25:50.700 --> 00:25:56.276
Very, very significant kind of concern
that we have to pay attention to here,

536
00:25:56.276 --> 00:25:58.803
right, good
>> All right very good Adam, we got

537
00:25:58.803 --> 00:26:02.938
a great look at going over preventative
measures, making sure we've got those and

538
00:26:02.938 --> 00:26:07.070
then a great look at patch management
gotta keep everything up and running.

539
00:26:07.070 --> 00:26:08.536
So thanks for all that information Adam.

540
00:26:08.536 --> 00:26:12.676
Remember if you guys want to,
Sit in one of Adam's classes live,

541
00:26:12.676 --> 00:26:15.742
shoot us an email here
at SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

542
00:26:15.742 --> 00:26:19.880
That being said, we're gonna sign off for
this one, I'm Mike Roderick.

543
00:26:19.880 --> 00:26:20.595
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

544
00:26:20.595 --> 00:26:22.749
>> And we'll see you next time.

00:30:56.085 --> 00:30:59.415

less for
