00:22:42.030 --> 00:22:44.510
most of the time that our
company has been open.

470
00:22:44.510 --> 00:22:47.120
I don't handle hands on day
to day management anymore.

471
00:22:47.120 --> 00:22:50.040
I'm still that back stop for
our system engineers and

472
00:22:50.040 --> 00:22:52.090
our facility managers that do that.

473
00:22:52.090 --> 00:22:55.340
But I'm much more of a kind of
a higher level consultant for

474
00:22:55.340 --> 00:22:57.270
them if they have a technical
problem these days.

475
00:22:57.270 --> 00:22:59.160
I don't get the phone call,
in other words, at two in the morning,

476
00:22:59.160 --> 00:23:00.325
if things don't work anymore.

477
00:23:00.325 --> 00:23:02.480
>> [LAUGH]
>> At least not on a regular basis anyway.

478
00:23:02.480 --> 00:23:06.060
But until very recently, even though
we had outsourced to the cloud,

479
00:23:06.060 --> 00:23:09.970
if something wasn't working I would still
get phone calls at all hours day and

480
00:23:09.970 --> 00:23:12.700
night saying hey by the way
this is not happening or

481
00:23:12.700 --> 00:23:16.320
this is an issue and what do we do, who
do we talk to, how do we deal with this?

482
00:23:16.320 --> 00:23:20.950
So it is important to know who's gonna be
on call and who's gonna pick up the phone

483
00:23:20.950 --> 00:23:23.800
and who's gonna be able to give
you that institutional knowledge.

484
00:23:23.800 --> 00:23:26.840
I get those phone calls because I've
been with the company since we opened.

485
00:23:26.840 --> 00:23:30.020
There's nobody that's been around
longer than me other than the owner of

486
00:23:30.020 --> 00:23:34.830
the company who founded our little
happy slice of the world here,

487
00:23:34.830 --> 00:23:38.280
right with regards to the company
I work for, not ITPro.TV.

488
00:23:38.280 --> 00:23:41.535
So when we think about that,
right they're not calling the owner,

489
00:23:41.535 --> 00:23:45.075
they're calling me because all the teams
know that if nobody else knows,

490
00:23:45.075 --> 00:23:49.071
Adam probably knows cuz he's been here
long enough that he's probably seen it, so

491
00:23:49.071 --> 00:23:51.557
he probably knows what it is and
knows how to fix it.

492
00:23:51.557 --> 00:23:54.062
That may or may not be the case,
by the way, but

493
00:23:54.062 --> 00:23:57.927
that is something that often comes up so
you do want to think about that.

494
00:23:57.927 --> 00:23:59.291
So, it is important to know who to call,

495
00:23:59.291 --> 00:24:01.110
right, it's important to
kinda fail through that.

496
00:24:01.110 --> 00:24:03.070
What if we have multiple locations?

497
00:24:03.070 --> 00:24:05.360
How do we deal with disaster recovery and
planning for them?

498
00:24:05.360 --> 00:24:07.190
Is it the same for every location?

499
00:24:07.190 --> 00:24:08.190
Is it different?

500
00:24:08.190 --> 00:24:10.700
And these are things we'd wanna be
aware off and be thinking about.

501
00:24:10.700 --> 00:24:12.410
Who do we actually communicate with?

502
00:24:12.410 --> 00:24:14.000
Do we communicate with stakeholders?

503
00:24:14.000 --> 00:24:16.380
Do we communicate up and down the chain?

504
00:24:16.380 --> 00:24:19.180
Are we authorized to give out certain
information to certain individuals,

505
00:24:19.180 --> 00:24:20.104
may be not to others.

506
00:24:20.104 --> 00:24:23.610
Do I have people calling me again
in these disaster scenarios,

507
00:24:23.610 --> 00:24:25.630
not just from companies, my own company,

508
00:24:25.630 --> 00:24:31.040
but from external companies I have
relationships with as a consultant.

509
00:24:31.040 --> 00:24:34.880
And I'm under NDA to be able to talk
about their technology with them but

510
00:24:34.880 --> 00:24:35.800
nobody else.

511
00:24:35.800 --> 00:24:37.780
And if I don't know the person
on the other end of the phone,

512
00:24:37.780 --> 00:24:41.030
because I don't deal with them normally,
I can't talk to them.

513
00:24:41.030 --> 00:24:41.880
I just don't know who they are.

514
00:24:41.880 --> 00:24:43.390
They may not be representing the company.

515
00:24:43.390 --> 00:24:46.550
They may be trying to socially
engineer information out of me.

516
00:24:46.550 --> 00:24:48.990
So, when I get a strange
phone call from a vendor or

517
00:24:48.990 --> 00:24:52.000
a customer, unless I have
a personal relationship with them,

518
00:24:52.000 --> 00:24:54.710
unless it's somebody I know,
that I've done business with.

519
00:24:54.710 --> 00:24:58.570
It's George from company Y, and
I know George, and I deal with George all

520
00:24:58.570 --> 00:25:01.600
the time, I'm not talking to somebody
that just randomly calls up and

521
00:25:01.600 --> 00:25:04.270
says, I represent so and so,
they told me to call you.

522
00:25:04.270 --> 00:25:05.390
We're having this problem.

523
00:25:05.390 --> 00:25:07.080
My first response is, that's nice.

524
00:25:07.080 --> 00:25:07.870
You have my number.

525
00:25:07.870 --> 00:25:09.110
I don't care what's happening.

526
00:25:09.110 --> 00:25:12.600
Find so and so and get them on the phone
and explain to them and apologize to them.

527
00:25:12.600 --> 00:25:15.030
If it's legitimately
that this is who you are.

528
00:25:15.030 --> 00:25:17.670
That I'm just following the procedure
that we've agreed upon, and

529
00:25:17.670 --> 00:25:18.610
I'm not going to talk to you.

530
00:25:18.610 --> 00:25:21.630
You have to have them call me, unless
they're standing in the room with you,

531
00:25:21.630 --> 00:25:24.720
in which case, put your phone on
speaker and let me talk to them, but

532
00:25:24.720 --> 00:25:26.190
other than that I'm not gonna talk to you.

533
00:25:26.190 --> 00:25:29.440
I don't wanna be rude but I can't help
you cuz I don't know who you are.

534
00:25:29.440 --> 00:25:32.400
And that's important you have to
understand and think about that as well.

535
00:25:32.400 --> 00:25:36.420
We have to test these policies,
these plans, on a regular basis.

536
00:25:36.420 --> 00:25:38.430
We have to be relentless
with testing them.

537
00:25:38.430 --> 00:25:41.620
We wanna go through and talk about the
different testing strategies that exist,

538
00:25:41.620 --> 00:25:43.320
so let's just quickly
enumerate what they are.

539
00:25:44.490 --> 00:25:47.110
We have what's known as
a check list check or

540
00:25:47.110 --> 00:25:49.450
a desk check sometimes
referred to either way.

541
00:25:49.450 --> 00:25:53.640
This is where you basically read a copy of
the DR plan, you read your portion of it.

542
00:25:53.640 --> 00:25:55.950
You gotta check off a box or
sign that you read it.

543
00:25:55.950 --> 00:25:57.215
But you're Just sitting at your desk,

544
00:25:57.215 --> 00:25:59.335
you're isolated,
nobody else is there with you.

545
00:25:59.335 --> 00:26:01.405
You're not discussing
the plan with anybody,

546
00:26:01.405 --> 00:26:03.045
you're just doing like a dry read.

547
00:26:03.045 --> 00:26:05.475
You're saying yep, plan looks good,
my stuff's in there,

548
00:26:05.475 --> 00:26:06.505
looks like it's up to date.

549
00:26:06.505 --> 00:26:07.745
I don't know about anybody else's,

550
00:26:07.745 --> 00:26:11.322
I'm really just signing off on mine, and
you sign off that you read the plan.

551
00:26:11.322 --> 00:26:12.792
That's the extent of the test.

552
00:26:12.792 --> 00:26:13.682
That's okay.

553
00:26:13.682 --> 00:26:15.062
It's valuable at one level.

554
00:26:15.062 --> 00:26:18.642
The stuff you're responsible for
has been vetted but it's not really a good

555
00:26:18.642 --> 00:26:22.312
overall testing of the plan holistically
throughout the entire organization.

556
00:26:22.312 --> 00:26:24.632
We may have what's known
as a tabletop exercise or

557
00:26:24.632 --> 00:26:26.692
sometimes called
a structured walk through.

558
00:26:26.692 --> 00:26:30.092
This is where we put everybody in a room,
so it's kind of like a WebEx or

559
00:26:30.092 --> 00:26:31.952
a video conference or a meeting.

560
00:26:31.952 --> 00:26:32.802
You may attend remotely or

561
00:26:32.802 --> 00:26:36.230
you may be there in person, and we're all
gonna go through the elements of the plan.

562
00:26:36.230 --> 00:26:39.460
We're gonna talk through it together so
there is now exchange of ideas and

563
00:26:39.460 --> 00:26:41.870
dialogue, but
we're not actually doing anything.

564
00:26:41.870 --> 00:26:44.790
We're not simulating any of
the events that are gonna happen.

565
00:26:44.790 --> 00:26:46.570
We're not shutting off systems.

566
00:26:46.570 --> 00:26:48.910
We're not doing real validation or
verification.

567
00:26:48.910 --> 00:26:53.120
We're simply verbally talking through
the plan, it's the next level of testing

568
00:26:53.120 --> 00:26:58.330
strategy simulation, this could be
done today using virtual environments.

569
00:26:58.330 --> 00:27:02.060
It may be done doing a war games scenario
where we actually put everybody in a room.

570
00:27:02.060 --> 00:27:04.540
And we do actually have a facilitator, and

571
00:27:04.540 --> 00:27:09.645
we walk through a scenario-based playback
of what a typical DR event may be.

572
00:27:09.645 --> 00:27:11.595
So everybody's in the room in their roles.

573
00:27:11.595 --> 00:27:13.725
They're all acting as if
things are happening.

574
00:27:13.725 --> 00:27:15.875
They're reacting to what
they're told is happening.

575
00:27:15.875 --> 00:27:18.295
They're taking the steps they would
normally take, in other words, but

576
00:27:18.295 --> 00:27:19.185
it's all fake, right?

577
00:27:19.185 --> 00:27:21.497
It's all what we call Hollywood magic,
right?

578
00:27:21.497 --> 00:27:23.057
So that's simulation.

579
00:27:23.057 --> 00:27:26.087
Parallel testing is where we
actually are going to go ahead, and

580
00:27:26.087 --> 00:27:30.687
we're going to run the fail over system,
as well as the real system in parallel.

581
00:27:30.687 --> 00:27:34.827
We may shut down portions of the system
and fail over portions to the DR,

582
00:27:34.827 --> 00:27:38.287
to the parallel recovery site
to see what will happen.

583
00:27:38.287 --> 00:27:41.257
But we're not fully interrupting and
shutting down everything.

584
00:27:41.257 --> 00:27:44.400
So this is like a limited
interruption test, if you will.

585
00:27:44.400 --> 00:27:46.930
Full interrupt or full scale is where
we're actually gonna go through and

586
00:27:46.930 --> 00:27:50.860
load and shut everything off fail it all
over, and then try to fail it back and

587
00:27:50.860 --> 00:27:52.070
see what happens.

588
00:27:52.070 --> 00:27:55.940
Banks have to do this at least once a year
by regulation within the United States for

589
00:27:55.940 --> 00:27:59.920
instance, healthcare providers have to
do this once a year as well typically

590
00:27:59.920 --> 00:28:02.640
because of regulation within in the US,
so they have to go through and

591
00:28:02.640 --> 00:28:06.940
do full interruption or
full scale examinations, other DR plants.

592
00:28:06.940 --> 00:28:10.800
Wanna make sure, that we understand the
five different test strategies that exist.

593
00:28:10.800 --> 00:28:12.200
Just one more time quickly.

594
00:28:12.200 --> 00:28:14.190
Desk check, or checklist test,

595
00:28:14.190 --> 00:28:17.810
it's referred to either way, tabletop,
and/or structured walkthrough.

596
00:28:17.810 --> 00:28:19.600
Again, you hear that
referred to either way.

597
00:28:19.600 --> 00:28:24.440
Simulation simulation,
parallel and full interruption

598
00:28:24.440 --> 00:28:27.870
are sometimes called full scale tests,
wanna make sure we're familiar with these.

599
00:28:27.870 --> 00:28:31.070
Remember, keeping in mind that
we have to constantly update and

600
00:28:31.070 --> 00:28:34.820
maintain the details of the plan
is also very important.

601
00:28:34.820 --> 00:28:37.610
We just wanna quickly wrap up
with a thought process of BCP.

602
00:28:37.610 --> 00:28:39.660
We've talked about DR after recovery,

603
00:28:39.660 --> 00:28:42.250
we wanna just talk about
business continuity for a minute.

604
00:28:42.250 --> 00:28:46.970
Business continuity planning, BCP,
Is the twin brother of the DRP, or

605
00:28:46.970 --> 00:28:49.770
twin sister of DRP, or
however you like to frame that

606
00:28:49.770 --> 00:28:54.300
where DR is all about making sure we can
stabilize after the immediate event and

607
00:28:54.300 --> 00:28:58.490
create some sort of you know secure
environment to begin recovering from.

608
00:28:58.490 --> 00:29:03.470
BCP is all about that recovery process
extended, till we get back to normal.

609
00:29:03.470 --> 00:29:07.780
So we talk about DR as being
the stabilizer after the event, and

610
00:29:07.780 --> 00:29:09.810
BCP about what we do to go home.

611
00:29:09.810 --> 00:29:11.560
Going home means, getting back to normal.

612
00:29:11.560 --> 00:29:13.640
Getting everything back to the way it was.

613
00:29:13.640 --> 00:29:16.510
We often have different teams
that do both of these activities.

614
00:29:16.510 --> 00:29:19.950
So you'll have a team that does DR,
and they stabilize the environment,

615
00:29:19.950 --> 00:29:22.670
while another team is then
gonna go into BCP recovery.

616
00:29:22.670 --> 00:29:25.050
And it's actually gonna start
to restore services, and

617
00:29:25.050 --> 00:29:28.570
do all of the things that are necessary
there in order to be able to effectively

618
00:29:28.570 --> 00:29:31.370
bring back the systems,
and bring them online.

619
00:29:31.370 --> 00:29:33.650
We wanna make sure that
we use the BCP plan.

620
00:29:33.650 --> 00:29:35.370
We do have a plan for that as well.

621
00:29:35.370 --> 00:29:37.780
And the key there is that we have
to do something known as a BIA,

622
00:29:37.780 --> 00:29:40.000
a business impact analyses.

623
00:29:40.000 --> 00:29:43.030
And what we have to do with a BIA
is look at all the services,

624
00:29:43.030 --> 00:29:45.120
all the things we do in the organization.

625
00:29:45.120 --> 00:29:48.700
We have to prioritize them and
understand how important they are.

626
00:29:48.700 --> 00:29:51.630
So if I said to you,
hey can you survive email?

627
00:29:51.630 --> 00:29:54.920
You may say to me well, absolutely no,
we need email to do our business.

628
00:29:54.920 --> 00:29:58.120
So we rank and
prioritize our importance as deserved.

629
00:29:58.120 --> 00:30:01.350
Will then figure out what
the top level services are,

630
00:30:01.350 --> 00:30:04.140
the middle level, the low level
kin of ranking in priority order.

631
00:30:04.140 --> 00:30:07.770
How important everything is from most
to least and that becomes our list of

632
00:30:07.770 --> 00:30:11.340
services that we manage against
when we have to do a BCP event.

633
00:30:11.340 --> 00:30:14.420
When we have to go through and
actually start to recover services.

634
00:30:14.420 --> 00:30:18.230
Here is the interesting thing with BCP,
we are going to use the input of the BIA,

635
00:30:18.230 --> 00:30:21.630
the Business Impact Analysis
to identify critical services.

636
00:30:21.630 --> 00:30:23.980
Do you think Quick quiz for you right?

637
00:30:23.980 --> 00:30:27.030
Do you think we should restore
the most critical service,

638
00:30:27.030 --> 00:30:28.870
email hypothetically the most critical.

639
00:30:28.870 --> 00:30:31.320
Should we restore that most
critical service first

640
00:30:31.320 --> 00:30:35.000
coming out of a disaster as we're looking
to stabilize and get back to normal?

641
00:30:35.000 --> 00:30:38.220
Or should we restore the least
critical service, let's say file and

642
00:30:38.220 --> 00:30:40.270
print is the least critical service,
right?

643
00:30:40.270 --> 00:30:42.140
Should we restore the most critical first,
or

644
00:30:42.140 --> 00:30:44.760
the least critical first,
what do you think?

645
00:30:44.760 --> 00:30:45.760
>> I would go with the least critical.

646
00:30:45.760 --> 00:30:46.340
>> Least critical.

647
00:30:46.340 --> 00:30:47.690
>> I would wanna test my methods and

648
00:30:47.690 --> 00:30:50.470
make sure that we were able to get
something back up and running first.

649
00:30:50.470 --> 00:30:51.820
>> Absolutely, and most important,

650
00:30:51.820 --> 00:30:53.405
and Mike's 100%
>> Incorrect.

651
00:30:53.405 --> 00:30:56.565
And most importantly about that thought
process is, not only do we wanna test,

652
00:30:56.565 --> 00:30:58.915
not only do we wanna make sure it's good,
and we can do that, but

653
00:30:58.915 --> 00:31:02.335
what if we restored our most critical
service, and we found out that there was

654
00:31:02.335 --> 00:31:05.365
still a problem, and we have not
totally stabilized the environment?

655
00:31:05.365 --> 00:31:07.485
We in effect would've just blown it up,
and

656
00:31:07.485 --> 00:31:11.340
ruined any chance that we can recover
it in a reasonable amount of time.

657
00:31:11.340 --> 00:31:14.820
So that is going to be a huge
liability and risk for us.

658
00:31:14.820 --> 00:31:18.710
We do want to make sure when we are
thinking about BCP, we are thinking about

659
00:31:18.710 --> 00:31:23.260
the idea that we actually have to recover
in reverse order from least to most,

660
00:31:23.260 --> 00:31:26.910
as Mike helped us understand and pointed
out with regards to service priority.

661
00:31:26.910 --> 00:31:31.870
What drives that priority ranking of
services is our business impact analysis.

662
00:31:31.870 --> 00:31:32.457
Very good.

663
00:31:32.457 --> 00:31:34.220
>> All right Adam, great look there.

664
00:31:34.220 --> 00:31:35.260
Lot of information.

665
00:31:35.260 --> 00:31:39.300
Looking at disaster recovery as well
as some fault tolerance capabilities.

666
00:31:39.300 --> 00:31:42.610
And again, talk about planning and
making sure that everything is

667
00:31:42.610 --> 00:31:45.950
laid out ahead of time because during
the event, during the disaster or

668
00:31:45.950 --> 00:31:50.090
whatever it is, that's not when we
are making those clear rational decisions.

669
00:31:50.090 --> 00:31:52.640
And the importance of keeping
it up to date, testing it.

670
00:31:52.640 --> 00:31:53.180
Right?

671
00:31:53.180 --> 00:31:57.240
You don't want to be the one that doesn't
have a hard copy of that vendor list

672
00:31:57.240 --> 00:32:01.800
offsite, and to have to call Adam on the
West Coast at 3 o'clock in the morning,

673
00:32:01.800 --> 00:32:04.170
hoping he might know one
of your vendors for you.

674
00:32:04.170 --> 00:32:05.250
So, appreciate that.

675
00:32:05.250 --> 00:32:08.932
And remember, if you guys want to
sit in one of Adam's classes live,

676
00:32:08.932 --> 00:32:12.434
all you gotta do is shoot us
an email here at SeeAdam@itpro.tv.

677
00:32:12.434 --> 00:32:14.470
Signing off I'm Mike Roderick.

678
00:32:14.470 --> 00:32:15.310
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

679
00:32:15.310 --> 00:32:16.685
>> And we'll see you next time.

680
00:32:16.685 --> 00:32:22.670
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike talk about physical security and personnel security. They look at physical access controls like man traps. They also talk about the importance of protecting our most valuable resource, our personnel.
episodes.title: Physical / Personnel Security
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.004 --> 00:00:10.004
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.257 --> 00:00:15.926
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.926 --> 00:00:17.550
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:17.550 --> 00:00:20.574
Today we're doing our CISSP content.

5
00:00:20.574 --> 00:00:25.129
And specifically in this episode we're
going to be getting into physical

6
00:00:25.129 --> 00:00:27.820
security as well as personnel security.

7
00:00:27.820 --> 00:00:30.109
And here to help us with that is Mr.
Adam Gordon.

8
00:00:30.109 --> 00:00:31.330
How's it going Adam?

9
00:00:31.330 --> 00:00:34.020
>> I'm feeling rather secure this
morning and a little personal, so

10
00:00:34.020 --> 00:00:35.860
we'll see how that goes.

11
00:00:35.860 --> 00:00:39.532
When we talk about both physical and
personnel security, what we're thinking

12
00:00:39.532 --> 00:00:43.006
about is how do we safe guard information,
how do we safeguard resources.

13
00:00:43.006 --> 00:00:46.471
But how do we also safeguard the most
important resource, the individuals that

14
00:00:46.471 --> 00:00:50.390
work for us, when they're traveling,

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike talk about applying security in the software development life cycle. They stress the concept of securing early and often. They also cover the development phases, project initiation and planning, and system design specifications. They finish with development and implementation, documentation and testing, and certification and accreditation.
episodes.title: Software Dev Security

are checked, they are well documented,

634

635
00:31:58.680 --> 00:32:00.240

We talk about that TQM,

648

650

ensuring continuity of operations,
detection and defects of weaknesses and

651
00:32:50.422 --> 00:32:53.563
then documenting those so
we can go back and fix them over time.

652
00:32:53.563 --> 00:32:55.693
This is where the rubber meets the road so

653

654

All right Adam,

a lot of great information on
software development security.

So a good look at some of those models,

I love that phrase,
security early and often.

659
00:33:10.126 --> 00:33:12.196
I think it's really what

660
00:33:12.196 --> 00:33:15.576
So, remember, if you guys want to

00:33:15.576 --> 00:33:19.496

00:33:19.496 --> 00:33:21.769
Signing off for this episode,

54

Change management is
all about understanding

55
00:02:35.450 --> 00:02:38.740

whatever that state is today.

56

And as we impact that something,
through an add, a modification, a revoke,

57
00:02:43.930 --> 00:02:49.050
an update, whatever it may be, anything
that in any way alters that current state,

58

that known good state as
we often talk about it.

59

Then change management has to come along,
kick in, and

61

saying to yourself, well Adam,

that's good.

something that's brand new and

66

Maybe I don't have anything that exists.

Maybe I don't have to worry about that.

68

Well you still do, right, because

69

you have other things, right,

70

71

72
00:03:25.040 --> 00:03:29.130
the good, the service, the system,

73

But it's about ultimately
integrating those things,

74

whatever that is, into the existing
system, the existing service,

75
00:03:34.840 --> 00:03:37.930
the existing offering or
software that you have.

76
00:03:37.930 --> 00:03:39.980
And you have those in your systems.

77
00:03:39.980 --> 00:03:42.010
There is something there today.

78
00:03:42.010 --> 00:03:46.250
It may not be something that directly
relates to what we're gonna do with SDLC,

79
00:03:46.250 --> 00:03:49.140
but unless we can validate it

80
00:03:49.140 --> 00:03:53.520
that it will not impact in any way what
the current state of the system is.

81
00:03:53.520 --> 00:03:57.420
The impact or the change that that
SDLC that you're working through

82
00:03:57.420 --> 00:04:00.650

83

And this is what change

84
00:04:02.940 --> 00:04:05.820
It's about, obviously, generically,
the idea of change, but

85
00:04:05.820 --> 00:04:11.180
in this regard, in this circumstance with
specificity related to this conversation.

86
00:04:11.180 --> 00:04:14.130
It's about not only what you're doing,
but the impact of what

87
00:04:14.130 --> 00:04:18.080
you're doing on the existing things
that are already up and running.

88
00:04:18.080 --> 00:04:20.580
That are in your system,
that make up and affect your work.

89
00:04:20.580 --> 00:04:22.850
So it's about what changes
you're going to introduce, and

90
00:04:22.850 --> 00:04:24.640
what impact those changes

91
00:04:24.640 --> 00:04:27.845
We've spoken before about

About the idea of intended consequence.

00:04:30.060 --> 00:04:33.310
About the idea of unmanaged and
undocumented change.

94
00:04:33.310 --> 00:04:38.130
And the negative specificity that that
can have and that can bring in to.

95
00:04:38.130 --> 00:04:40.080
And the vulnerability Abilities and
the threats and

96
00:04:40.080 --> 00:04:44.040
the risks that that can implement or
introduce into your organization.

97
00:04:44.040 --> 00:04:46.170
Either looked for or
unlooked for, intended or

98
00:04:46.170 --> 00:04:49.970
unintended, unintended consequences
are still consequences, right.

99
00:04:49.970 --> 00:04:52.780
And even though we didn't mean to
do something, if the outcome is,

100
00:04:52.780 --> 00:04:55.810
hey, that happened, then guess what,
you're still responsible.

101
00:04:55.810 --> 00:04:59.130
So, at the end of the day,
whether you do it on purpose or not,

102
00:04:59.130 --> 00:05:03.440
you still as a CISSP are responsible for
understanding how to manage that outcome.

103
00:05:03.440 --> 00:05:04.590
Due care and due diligence.

104
00:05:04.590 --> 00:05:06.260
We never get away from those terms.

105
00:05:06.260 --> 00:05:07.810
We never move away from risk.

106
00:05:07.810 --> 00:05:12.050
We never move away from the ideas that
these systems that are under our care

107
00:05:12.050 --> 00:05:15.840
are feeding our management have
to be monitored continuously,

108
00:05:15.840 --> 00:05:20.000
have to be audited regularly,
have to be validated on an ongoing basis.

109
00:05:20.000 --> 00:05:22.280
And that anything that
impacts them negatively or

110
00:05:22.280 --> 00:05:25.960
impacts them positively, either way,
it has to documented and accounted for.

111
00:05:25.960 --> 00:05:27.825
So very, very important,
it's a thought process, right?

112
00:05:27.825 --> 00:05:28.481
>> Very good, yes.

113
00:05:28.481 --> 00:05:29.670
>> So yeah, so something to consider.

00:05:41.795 --> 00:05:43.720
So think about change management.

123
00:05:43.720 --> 00:05:44.850
It's very, very important.

So successful change management.

125
00:05:47.300 --> 00:05:48.980
What does that require,
what does that entail.

126
00:05:48.980 --> 00:05:49.980
It entails a couple of things.

127
00:05:49.980 --> 00:05:52.320
First, awareness of current state, right?

128
00:05:52.320 --> 00:05:54.790
What it is, the as is in other words,

129
00:05:54.790 --> 00:05:58.590
that we are thinking about, the current
state of affairs must be well documented.

130
00:05:58.590 --> 00:05:59.840
If we don't know what we're doing today,

131
00:05:59.840 --> 00:06:01.750
if we don't know what
the system is capable of,

132
00:06:01.750 --> 00:06:05.480
we don't understand what is going on,
how can we possibly understand what

133
00:06:05.480 --> 00:06:09.370
change is happening in the impact of that
change, good, bad, or indifferent, right.

134
00:06:09.370 --> 00:06:10.570
Cuz change could be good.

135
00:06:10.570 --> 00:06:11.300
It could be negative.

136
00:06:11.300 --> 00:06:12.600
It could also be value neutral.

137
00:06:12.600 --> 00:06:15.520
And in fact, we could make a change but

138
00:06:15.520 --> 00:06:17.860
It just keeps going and everything's okay.

139
00:06:17.860 --> 00:06:20.460
But the reality is,
whether change is good, bad, or

140
00:06:20.460 --> 00:06:23.710
value neutral,
the reality of that situation is if

141
00:06:23.710 --> 00:06:27.900
we don't understand what the modern
current state documented as is state is,

142
00:06:27.900 --> 00:06:31.660
we have no idea how to measure change and
no idea how to measure impact change.

143
00:06:31.660 --> 00:06:34.910
So it's our responsibility to understand
the current states of our systems.

144
00:06:34.910 --> 00:06:35.840
Very important.

145
00:06:35.840 --> 00:06:38.510
So, we have to understand
effectively what that is.

146
00:06:38.510 --> 00:06:39.850
We have to communicate that effectively.

147
00:06:39.850 --> 00:06:41.710
We have to document that effectively.

148
00:06:41.710 --> 00:06:43.680
This implies continuous monitoring,

149
00:06:43.680 --> 00:06:47.340
implies auditability of all

150
00:06:47.340 --> 00:06:50.170
It implies traceability of all
transactions in the system.

151
00:06:50.170 --> 00:06:53.090
It implies visibility to everything
that's going on in the system.

152
00:06:53.090 --> 00:06:55.680
All these things are part

You can take, and

00:07:04.570 --> 00:07:08.010
It's very easy, and

00:07:08.010 --> 00:07:11.670

00:07:11.670 --> 00:07:13.460

00:07:19.310 --> 00:07:21.850
It may look easy, but

00:07:21.850 --> 00:07:26.810
But understanding whether you have a good
grasp of change and change management

163
00:07:26.810 --> 00:07:31.110
in you organization, is actually a fairly
straightforward and easy thought process.

164
00:07:31.110 --> 00:07:33.150
Not managing change, let me be clear.

165
00:07:33.150 --> 00:07:34.770
Managing change is complicated.

166
00:07:34.770 --> 00:07:37.720
But understanding whether you
are doing that effectively

167
00:07:37.720 --> 00:07:41.300
in your organization is actually
fairly straight forward and easy.

168
00:07:41.300 --> 00:07:43.120
It's a fairly simple litmus test.

00:07:43.120 --> 00:07:43.990
A litmus test,

00:07:43.990 --> 00:07:47.940
generically, is a test that we can
use to validate an assumption, right?

171
00:07:47.940 --> 00:07:51.645
If we think about saying yes,
this is like this or like that.

172
00:07:51.645 --> 00:07:54.465
We can use a litmus test,
a validation test to see whether or

173
00:07:54.465 --> 00:07:56.525
not that statement is true or false.

174
00:07:56.525 --> 00:07:59.772
We can understand whether we have
a good handle on change using a fairly

175
00:07:59.772 --> 00:08:01.765
straightforward and simple litmus test.

176
00:08:01.765 --> 00:08:04.144
If our documentation Is good, for

177
00:08:04.144 --> 00:08:08.005
documentation speaks to our
ability to manage change.

178
00:08:08.005 --> 00:08:12.506
We should be able to look at, understand,
and see evidence of a well formed, robust,

179
00:08:12.506 --> 00:08:16.140
and mature change management
process in the organization.

180
00:08:16.140 --> 00:08:20.560
If we have a well documented,
well thought out, well operating or

181
00:08:20.560 --> 00:08:24.810
good, and well implemented
change management process,

182
00:08:24.810 --> 00:08:29.150
then no change should be allowed to occur
without running through that process,

183
00:08:29.150 --> 00:08:31.512
without documentation,
and without approval.

184
00:08:31.512 --> 00:08:34.280
And if change has not been approved,
it should never be implemented.

185
00:08:34.280 --> 00:08:37.360
If we can look to that process and
we can look to that system, and

186
00:08:37.360 --> 00:08:41.650
it's working, then we know that change
management has been implemented correctly.

187
00:08:41.650 --> 00:08:44.970
We don't know whether it's actually
functioning as well as it could.

188
00:08:44.970 --> 00:08:46.860
We need to do more due diligence.

189
00:08:46.860 --> 00:08:49.110
We need to investigate to establish that.

190
00:08:49.110 --> 00:08:53.676
But what we can tell on the surface
is that there is a well-documented,

191
00:08:53.676 --> 00:08:57.450
well-understood, and
implemented process that speaks to change,

192
00:08:57.450 --> 00:09:00.590
the impact of change, the management
of change in the organization.

193
00:09:00.590 --> 00:09:01.790
Remember, when we come in and

194
00:09:01.790 --> 00:09:05.480
do auditing work, this is one of the key
things we look for as a security auditor,

195
00:09:05.480 --> 00:09:09.070
we're gonna ask you what kind of change
management process do you have in place?

196
00:09:09.070 --> 00:09:10.170

00:04:37.740 --> 00:04:41.150

94
00:04:41.150 --> 00:04:43.980
The ACID test is going to be

95
00:04:43.980 --> 00:04:47.580

96
00:04:47.580 --> 00:04:51.380

97
00:04:51.380 --> 00:04:55.770
ACID is an acronym A-C-I-D

98
00:04:55.770 --> 00:04:58.840

99
00:04:58.840 --> 00:05:01.340
And I'll repeat those terms and

100
00:05:01.340 --> 00:05:05.810
But the ACID test generically is the test
that is perform to get all transaction in

101
00:05:05.810 --> 00:05:06.750
the system.

102
00:05:06.750 --> 00:05:11.360
And a transaction, if is what we called
well formed, must roll through and

103
00:05:11.360 --> 00:05:15.910
effectively hit all four stages of
the acid test in order to be committed and

104
00:05:15.910 --> 00:05:18.440
to be seen as something that
is valid within the system.

105
00:05:18.440 --> 00:05:22.160
A well formed transaction,
in other words, passes the acid test.

106
00:05:22.160 --> 00:05:24.585
So the acid test starts with atomicity.

107
00:05:24.585 --> 00:05:27.380
Atomicity is all about all or none.

108
00:05:27.380 --> 00:05:32.090
Meaning we either commit the entire
transaction or we commit none of it.

109
00:05:32.090 --> 00:05:32.850
In other words,

110
00:05:32.850 --> 00:05:36.980
when we think about atomicity, we're think
about getting a transaction right and

111
00:05:36.980 --> 00:05:39.640
being able to commit it based on
it being successfully completed or

112
00:05:39.640 --> 00:05:43.225
having to roll it back, because nothing
can be done unless it is successful.

113
00:05:43.225 --> 00:05:47.225
Therefore the data must always go from one
known state through another known state,

114
00:05:47.225 --> 00:05:50.485
perhaps several known states,
to its completed resting state,

115
00:05:50.485 --> 00:05:53.315
which is transformed based
on the transaction or

116
00:05:53.315 --> 00:05:55.013
whatever it is we're
looking to accomplish.

117
00:05:55.013 --> 00:05:57.575
So atomicity is all about all or none.

118
00:05:57.575 --> 00:05:58.265
Consistency.

119
00:05:58.265 --> 00:05:59.785
Change is maintained consistency.

120
00:05:59.785 --> 00:06:01.100
Again, known state.

121
00:06:01.100 --> 00:06:04.940
Moving data from one known state to
another is what consistency is all about.

122
00:06:04.940 --> 00:06:08.370
Isolation, pending transactions
are invisible to others.

123
00:06:08.370 --> 00:06:12.600
Meaning while transaction is in process
it is not shown in the database is being

124
00:06:12.600 --> 00:06:13.400
complete.

125
00:06:13.400 --> 00:06:17.130
It is not affecting other data and it is
not going to show up in any other system

126
00:06:17.130 --> 00:06:21.050
anywhere until we consider it complete,
mark it as such, and commit it.

127
00:06:21.050 --> 00:06:21.820
And then durability.

128
00:06:21.820 --> 00:06:23.780
When you say you're done, it is done.

129
00:06:23.780 --> 00:06:27.130
In other words, durability is
committing of the transaction and

130
00:06:27.130 --> 00:06:31.040
writing that transaction into the system
in a way that it will not be undone.

131
00:06:31.040 --> 00:06:33.460
It is considered to be
part of the dataset now.

132
00:06:33.460 --> 00:06:38.140
The ACID test effectively equals
all changes to data being invisible

133
00:06:38.140 --> 00:06:39.199
until they are done.

134
00:06:40.370 --> 00:06:43.340
All chain is to data being
invisible until they are done.

135
00:06:43.340 --> 00:06:46.258
That is what the ACID
test effectively equals.

136
00:06:46.258 --> 00:06:49.980
Understanding the ACID test as
a way to create integrity but

137
00:06:49.980 --> 00:06:52.710
also ensure availability and
consistency of data.

138
00:06:52.710 --> 00:06:56.100
within a data base management

And is that data in flux?

145

00:07:13.335 --> 00:07:16.395

confidentiality and

147

So, for instance, when you go and

Prior to payday, been a long holiday,

Let's assume hypothetically for purposes
of our conversation that the minute that

177

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike talk about the different malware types. They talk about the importance of security awareness and training. They also break down the concept of a trusted computing base, as well as input validation, process control and sandboxing.

00:04:23.240 --> 00:04:27.660

93
00:04:27.660 --> 00:04:28.740
A virus needs help.

00:04:30.490 --> 00:04:33.270

to hopefully, be a little bit
more aware of those things and

578
00:26:46.031 --> 00:26:48.840
prevent them from falling prey
to it when it does occur.

579
00:26:48.840 --> 00:26:52.510
Things like software forensics and
sandboxing, also very important for

580
00:26:52.510 --> 00:26:56.240
us to think about and to be aware of,
making sure we can analyze information,

581
00:26:56.240 --> 00:26:58.990
like the dynamic information in RAM,
in memory.

582
00:26:58.990 --> 00:27:03.610
Making sure we can gather that if we have
a problem, sandboxing to virtually isolate

583
00:27:03.610 --> 00:27:07.135
information that's running in a memory
bubble so we can prevent the system

584
00:27:07.135 --> 00:27:11.135
from being further compromised while
we're examining what's going on with it.

585
00:27:11.135 --> 00:27:12.725
The use of virtual technology for
instance.

586
00:27:12.725 --> 00:27:14.465
Virtualization good example of this.

587
00:27:14.465 --> 00:27:16.045
Provides a protective bubble or

588
00:27:16.045 --> 00:27:19.777
cocoon around the system that will isolate
it and that's something else to consider.

589
00:27:19.777 --> 00:27:21.957
We have to think about
configuration management here,

590
00:27:21.957 --> 00:27:25.307
as well, and understand the importance and
the impact of configuration management.

591
00:27:25.307 --> 00:27:27.217
We talked a lot about change management,
but

592
00:27:27.217 --> 00:27:29.347
configuration management
is also important.

593
00:27:29.347 --> 00:27:33.017
Keeping track of those baselines,
understanding what the expected norm,

594
00:27:33.017 --> 00:27:36.117
whatever that may be defined as,
is gonna be for a system.

595
00:27:36.117 --> 00:27:37.697
And then operating accordingly.

596
00:27:37.697 --> 00:27:41.710
And then not only doing that, but
also doing continuous monitoring and

597
00:27:41.710 --> 00:27:45.900
doing compliance validation to verify
whether that baseline is indeed in play.

598
00:27:45.900 --> 00:27:48.430
Is it still the expected
norm that we are seeing?

599
00:27:48.430 --> 00:27:51.090
Or has the system configuration
changed in some way?

600
00:27:51.090 --> 00:27:54.950
If it has, integrity may now be an issue,
confidentiality may be an issue,

601
00:27:54.950 --> 00:27:57.740
availability may be an issue,
and we may have a problem.

602
00:27:57.740 --> 00:27:59.490
And we have to monitor for that.

603
00:27:59.490 --> 00:28:03.460
We have to access that on an ongoing basis
to ensure that changes are not happening

604
00:28:03.460 --> 00:28:06.370
without our knowledge and
most importantly without our permission.

605
00:28:06.370 --> 00:28:08.530
So these are things to consider as well.

606
00:28:08.530 --> 00:28:11.610
So we have to be thinking about all these
things as we look at how we're gonna safe

607
00:28:11.610 --> 00:28:13.090
guard and protect the system.

608
00:28:13.090 --> 00:28:15.748
It's gonna be very important for
us to have a complete picture.

609
00:28:15.748 --> 00:28:19.640
Not just of the software, not just of
secure development of the software,

610
00:28:19.640 --> 00:28:22.900
not just the hardware, not just
implementation of the hardware, but

611
00:28:22.900 --> 00:28:26.710
all the things that go with that
plus the policies, the procedures,

612
00:28:26.710 --> 00:28:30.100
the expectations, the awareness,
and the implementation.

613
00:28:30.100 --> 00:28:34.210
The TCB, the trust the computing base,
the reference monitor, memory management,

614
00:28:34.210 --> 00:28:36.370
all of this stuff becomes very
important as we look at and

615
00:28:36.370 --> 00:28:38.400
think through the logic of this.

616
00:28:38.400 --> 00:28:39.020
>> Very good Adam.

617
00:28:39.020 --> 00:28:41.540
Again another great episode,
a lot of information there.

618
00:28:41.540 --> 00:28:44.590
We started off with a look
at some malware and

619
00:28:44.590 --> 00:28:48.080
then rehashing the different types of
malware that we have to deal with.

620
00:28:48.080 --> 00:28:51.925
Went through some blasts from the past,
things that are still there like IRQs that

621
00:28:51.925 --> 00:28:55.838
we might not think about anymore because
our operating systems deal with it for us.

622
00:28:55.838 --> 00:28:56.984
But very important for

623
00:28:56.984 --> 00:29:01.270
us to at least to understand what's going
on under that hood, so we can validate it.

624
00:29:01.270 --> 00:29:04.930
Make sure that it is being done
securely or if we have an issue there.

625
00:29:04.930 --> 00:29:07.860
So a lot of great information Adam,
thank you for that, we appreciate it.

626
00:29:07.860 --> 00:29:09.430
Hope you guys enjoyed this episode.

627
00:29:09.430 --> 00:29:13.366
Remember if you wanna attend
one of Adam's classes live,

628
00:29:13.366 --> 00:29:16.591
shoot us an email here
at seeadam@itpro.tv.

629
00:29:16.591 --> 00:29:18.495
Signing off for now, I'm Mike Rodrick.

630
00:29:18.495 --> 00:29:19.516
>> I'm a trojan virus.

631
00:29:19.516 --> 00:29:20.897
>> And we'll see you next time.

632
00:29:20.897 --> 00:29:26.900

episodes.description: In this episode, Adam and Mike finish their conversation on software development security. They talk about assessing software security, assessing and defining risk, auditing and logging. They also talk about regression testing, system integration, acceptance testing, and software assurance.
episodes.title: Software Dev Security Part 5
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.055 --> 00:00:10.055
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.941 --> 00:00:15.120
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.120 --> 00:00:16.960
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:16.960 --> 00:00:20.200
Today we're doing our CISSP content.

5
00:00:20.200 --> 00:00:24.432
And specifically we're gonna continue our
look at software development security.

6
00:00:24.432 --> 00:00:27.400
And in this episode we're gonna
take you to that next step.

7
00:00:27.400 --> 00:00:30.649
We've learned about the different
software development models,

8
00:00:30.649 --> 00:00:33.622
we've talked about implementing
security early and often.

9
00:00:33.622 --> 00:00:36.954
Adam's taught us a lot of things about
how to make sure we're developing that

10
00:00:36.954 --> 00:00:37.884
software security.

11
00:00:37.884 --> 00:00:40.530
We've talked about malware as well.

12
00:00:40.530 --> 00:00:44.090
Now we want to take a look at
the effectiveness of software security.

13
00:00:44.090 --> 00:00:46.350
And here to help us with
that is Mr Adam Gordon.

14
00:00:46.350 --> 00:00:47.460
How's it going, Adam?

15
00:00:47.460 --> 00:00:51.070
>> Good, good so, let's talk a bit
about assessment, effectiveness,

16
00:00:51.070 --> 00:00:51.780
software security,

17
00:00:51.780 --> 00:00:55.340
all things that Mike just kind of
introduced his thought processes for us.

18
00:00:55.340 --> 00:00:59.500
When we are thinking about how to decide,
right, whether or

19
00:00:59.500 --> 00:01:02.230
not something is working,
we have to have a couple of things.

20
00:01:02.230 --> 00:01:06.730
We have to have a baseline for what we
assume would logically equal success.

21
00:01:06.730 --> 00:01:10.293
We have to have a way to measure where
we are currently at the present moment,

22
00:01:10.293 --> 00:01:13.594
where we would like to go in the process
to get us from point A to point B.

23
00:01:13.594 --> 00:01:16.507
And we have to then
understand unequivocally and

24
00:01:16.507 --> 00:01:19.491
through a relatively
straightforward process,

25
00:01:19.491 --> 00:01:22.770
what the definition or
the bar for success will equal.

26
00:01:22.770 --> 00:01:25.312
And when we think about assessment,
we have to think about all these things.

27
00:01:25.312 --> 00:01:28.385
And so when we think about
assessing software security,

28
00:01:28.385 --> 00:01:31.660
we have to understand what
the current state of security is.

29
00:01:31.660 --> 00:01:34.890
We have to define what security may be,
or what it will not be.

30
00:01:34.890 --> 00:01:38.610
We have to then understand whether or
not we meet that definitely currently.

31
00:01:38.610 --> 00:01:41.340
If we do, we have to figure out
how to quantify and measure that.

32
00:01:41.340 --> 00:01:43.322
If we don't,
we have to figure out where the gaps are.

33
00:01:43.322 --> 00:01:46.370
And then we have to decide
what success will look like.

34
00:01:46.370 --> 00:01:50.593
It could look like what we do today,
it may look like something very different,

35
00:01:50.593 --> 00:01:53.190
it may look like a combination
of the two things.

36
00:01:53.190 --> 00:01:57.965
And then, based on understanding
those things, we then have to define,

37
00:01:57.965 --> 00:02:00.506
document, and declare what our as is,

38
00:02:00.506 --> 00:02:04.213
what our progression from as
is into the to be looks like.

39
00:02:04.213 --> 00:02:08.180
What to be equals, our desired state,
what success equals.

40
00:02:08.180 --> 00:02:11.729
And then we have to come up with a plan
to measure that, not only in the current

41
00:02:11.729 --> 00:02:15.455
state in the present moment, but
continuously to assess compliance ongoing.

42
00:02:15.455 --> 00:02:19.328
And then understand from the baseline
perspective if we do deviate what our,

43
00:02:19.328 --> 00:02:23.650
not only compliance issue will be, but
also what our mitigation solution will be.

44
00:02:23.650 --> 00:02:26.970
How do we then impact that
mitigation is used or

45
00:02:26.970 --> 00:02:29.780
the concept of mitigation will
be used to impact positively

46
00:02:29.780 --> 00:02:32.550
the changes we see to bring them
back into alignment in effect.

47
00:02:32.550 --> 00:02:36.740
And how to we impact that change,
that drift or delta in such a way

48
00:02:36.740 --> 00:02:40.590
through gap analysis, and ultimately
through remediation, that we can address

49
00:02:40.590 --> 00:02:44.540
whatever deviations we find and bring our
system or systems back into compliance.

50
00:02:44.540 --> 00:02:47.460
This is the process we have to think
about and go through, ultimately.

51
00:02:47.460 --> 00:02:50.610
One of the most important things we can
do along the way is understand, and

52
00:02:50.610 --> 00:02:54.370
we've talked a lot about this in prior
conversations, understand, assess,

53
00:02:54.370 --> 00:02:59.630
and ultimately define what risk is and
what risk equals within the organization.

54
00:02:59.630 --> 00:03:02.501
One of the great tools we have
to think about doing that would

55
00:03:02.501 --> 00:03:04.234
be the Risk Management Framework.

56
00:03:04.234 --> 00:03:06.923
NIST 800 or in NIST SP 800-37 r1 is gonna

57
00:03:06.923 --> 00:03:10.061
be the current version of
the Risk Management Framework,

58
00:03:10.061 --> 00:03:13.340
or at least the guidance around
Risk Management Framework.

59
00:03:13.340 --> 00:03:15.270
Risk Management Framework,
one form or another,

60
00:03:15.270 --> 00:03:17.770
has been around for
probably over a decade now.

61
00:03:17.770 --> 00:03:21.400
But the idea is that we wanna be
thinking about the thought processes

62
00:03:21.400 --> 00:03:23.380
associated with risk identification.

63
00:03:23.380 --> 00:03:26.143
Remember, we talked about threat actors,
we talked about threat,

64
00:03:26.143 --> 00:03:27.740
we talked about vulnerability.

65
00:03:27.740 --> 00:03:30.420
We talked the availability to
exploit that vulnerability.

66
00:03:30.420 --> 00:03:31.130
And then, ultimately,

67
00:03:31.130 --> 00:03:35.200
what all that equals or culminates in
is the idea of identification of risk,

68
00:03:35.200 --> 00:03:39.610
management of risk, and the measurement
of risk in relation to the business.

69
00:03:39.610 --> 00:03:43.700
The exposure factor and the impact and
the liability we have as a result of that.

70
00:03:43.700 --> 00:03:46.750
So, the Risk Management Framework
comes to mind here,

71
00:03:46.750 --> 00:03:49.030
something we wanna remind ourselves of,
be aware of think about.

72
00:03:49.030 --> 00:03:53.510
With CISSPs it's always very
important think about risk.

73
00:03:53.510 --> 00:03:56.057
So I share to you a little practical
story that happened to me just

74
00:03:56.057 --> 00:03:59.188
earlier today that I was asking Mike
about, he helped me to resolve the issue.

75
00:03:59.188 --> 00:04:03.280
And it really kinda just, at a baseline
level, demonstrates the potentiality for

76
00:04:03.280 --> 00:04:06.440
risk and the exposure associated
with risk or liability.

77
00:04:06.440 --> 00:04:12.000
So, as many of us do, my car has a remote
control option, remote key entry option.

78
00:04:12.000 --> 00:04:16.800
And so, I've used that remote
probably several times a day for

79
00:04:16.800 --> 00:04:20.120
the last three and a half years since
I bought that car, with no trouble.

80
00:04:20.120 --> 00:04:21.670
Got it from the dealer,
everything was fine.

81
00:04:21.670 --> 00:04:23.320
Click a button, boom, door opens.

82
00:04:23.320 --> 00:04:24.830
Click a button, boom, door closes.

83
00:04:24.830 --> 00:04:26.260
Occasionally click the wrong button,

84
00:04:26.260 --> 00:04:29.000
boom, alarm goes off,
you don't want that to happen too often.

85
00:04:29.000 --> 00:04:32.180
But I'm the first one to admit I'm one of
those people that sets it off on occasion

86
00:04:32.180 --> 00:04:32.980
by accident.

87
00:04:32.980 --> 00:04:34.290
So I go to do that this morning,

88
00:04:34.290 --> 00:04:36.670
not set off the alarm, that was not
what I wanted to do this morning.

89
00:04:36.670 --> 00:04:39.030
But to open and
then ultimately close the door.

90
00:04:39.030 --> 00:04:42.014
And so
I pull up here at the ITProTV studios,

91
00:04:42.014 --> 00:04:44.783
the palatial place that ITProTV-
>> [LAUGH]

92
00:04:44.783 --> 00:04:45.712
>> And the studios are.

93
00:04:45.712 --> 00:04:47.859
And the valet driver was
not here this morning,

94
00:04:47.859 --> 00:04:51.517
wasn't available to park my car for me,
have to about that, by the way, right-

95
00:04:51.517 --> 00:04:52.770
>> He took an extended vacation.

96
00:04:52.770 --> 00:04:53.860
>> Took an extended vacation, so

97
00:04:53.860 --> 00:04:56.880
I had to park my own car this morning
when I pulled up here at ITProTV.

98
00:04:56.880 --> 00:04:59.743
And so I went ahead, parked the car,
and went to lock it.

99
00:04:59.743 --> 00:05:03.000
And I went to use the remote, and
remote's dead, it's not working.

100
00:05:03.000 --> 00:05:06.130
And I'm pressing of course, you know,
cuz you stand there dumbstruck, right?

101
00:05:06.130 --> 00:05:09.050
It's like you pick up the phone,
there's no dial tone, you're like, what?

102
00:05:09.050 --> 00:05:09.980
No dial tone.

103
00:05:09.980 --> 00:05:11.800
So I'm going like this, it's not working.

104
00:05:11.800 --> 00:05:14.860
Finally, being the intelligent,
smart human being that I am,

105
00:05:14.860 --> 00:05:16.170
I eliminate the obvious.

106
00:05:16.170 --> 00:05:18.880
Because I banged it on my
hand to make sure it's not

107
00:05:18.880 --> 00:05:21.460
that the gremlins inside aren't awake and
moving.

108
00:05:21.460 --> 00:05:23.290
We do the stupidest things sometimes.

109
00:05:23.290 --> 00:05:26.500
And so ultimately I finally figured out
through process of elimination, fine,

110
00:05:26.500 --> 00:05:29.810
scientific method right,
eliminate the obvious things.

111
00:05:29.810 --> 00:05:31.150
It must be the battery, it's not working.

112
00:05:31.150 --> 00:05:34.151
So, I figured that out,
I come inside, we do our shows and

113
00:05:34.151 --> 00:05:36.310
our episodes this morning, no problem.

114
00:05:36.310 --> 00:05:37.753
And I say at some point to Mike, hey,

115
00:05:37.753 --> 00:05:40.142
gotta get a battery to replace
the battery that's in there.

116
00:05:40.142 --> 00:05:43.473
He says oh well go down, so and so,
go down this area, there is a place,

117
00:05:43.473 --> 00:05:44.210
get a battery.

118
00:05:44.210 --> 00:05:45.500
So, when I did all that.

119
00:05:45.500 --> 00:05:47.490
Came back, took care of it, it's fine.

120
00:05:47.490 --> 00:05:48.826
And by the way,
valet parker's still not outside.

121
00:05:48.826 --> 00:05:50.169
>> [LAUGH]
>> Just thought I'd mention that,

122
00:05:50.169 --> 00:05:52.030
was not here when I came
back from lunch either.

123
00:05:52.030 --> 00:05:53.315
So had to park my own car again.

124
00:05:53.315 --> 00:05:55.450
>> [LAUGH]
>> Just saying, I'm talent here, you know,

125
00:05:55.450 --> 00:05:57.100
I was expecting a little bit more,
that's all.

126
00:05:57.100 --> 00:06:00.250
I'm suggesting, nothing really big deal,
but you might wanna take a note.

127
00:06:00.250 --> 00:06:01.670
Just think about that for the next time.

128
00:06:01.670 --> 00:06:03.770
So I park my own car,
and it worked just fine.

129
00:06:03.770 --> 00:06:04.810
So that's not the risk part.

130
00:06:04.810 --> 00:06:05.970
The risk part was, hey, you know what,

131
00:06:05.970 --> 00:06:09.290
if the battery failed,
did I have a spare battery with me?

132
00:06:09.290 --> 00:06:12.780
The answer is clearly no, or I wouldn't
have a funny story to talk about with you.

133
00:06:12.780 --> 00:06:16.230
But because I didn't assess the risk,
the likelihood of the battery failing,

134
00:06:16.230 --> 00:06:18.360
it's been working for
over three years, no problem.

135
00:06:18.360 --> 00:06:21.650
What's the likelihood that thing's
gonna fail, and randomly fail today?

136
00:06:21.650 --> 00:06:23.810
Well, obviously pretty
good because it did.

137
00:06:23.810 --> 00:06:26.610
But did I assess that,
was I concerned about that?

138
00:06:26.610 --> 00:06:29.260
In the grand scheme of things, not really,
cuz I could have just used the key as I

139
00:06:29.260 --> 00:06:32.430
did this morning to lock
the car with no trouble.

140
00:06:32.430 --> 00:06:35.740
However, as with all good things, I found
out something new as a feature on my car I

141
00:06:35.740 --> 00:06:38.620
did not realize that my car
did until this happened.

142
00:06:38.620 --> 00:06:41.740
So in all the years I've had the car,
never had the battery on the remote fail.

143
00:06:41.740 --> 00:06:45.210
So when it failed this morning, being,
as I said, the idiot that I am,

144
00:06:45.210 --> 00:06:47.490
I'm sitting there trying to do
this to press, it's not working.

145
00:06:47.490 --> 00:06:50.349
So I go to open the door to see
if the door is locked or not.

146
00:06:50.349 --> 00:06:52.416
And the thing starts, the thing,
the car, let me be technical.

147
00:06:52.416 --> 00:06:54.147
>> [LAUGH]
>> The thing with wheels,

148
00:06:54.147 --> 00:06:56.440
you know the thing that you drive,
you go down the road and moves.

149
00:06:56.440 --> 00:06:59.660
So the car starts beeping at me,
or pinging, the, hey,

150
00:06:59.660 --> 00:07:03.070
the door's open light comes on on
the dash, but it normally never pings.

151
00:07:03.070 --> 00:07:04.123
You know that annoying,
hey your seatbelt's not on.

152
00:07:04.123 --> 00:07:05.053
>> Yeah, ding ding, yeah.

153
00:07:05.053 --> 00:07:06.570
>> Same kinda thing, ding ding ding.

154
00:07:06.570 --> 00:07:08.890
So it's doing that and
the light's flashing on the dash,

155
00:07:08.890 --> 00:07:09.980
it's one of the warnings.

156
00:07:09.980 --> 00:07:14.390
And so I close the door and I lock it
with the key, double check and it's fine.

157
00:07:14.390 --> 00:07:19.230
And so I get in, and being the person
that I am, I don't take the current

158
00:07:19.230 --> 00:07:22.550
status quo to be the status quo and
I don't take well enough as being good.

159
00:07:22.550 --> 00:07:24.520
So I go out today before I
go to replace the battery.

160
00:07:24.520 --> 00:07:25.992
I'm thinking, well,
it's been two hours, right, it'll work.

161
00:07:25.992 --> 00:07:28.160
>> [LAUGH]
>> So I try it again.

162
00:07:28.160 --> 00:07:31.425
Doesn't work, that battery's totally dead,
but I did that.

163
00:07:31.425 --> 00:07:34.525
Open the door, it's pinging me again,
this has never happened in three and

164
00:07:34.525 --> 00:07:36.055
a half,
almost four years I've owned the car.

165
00:07:36.055 --> 00:07:38.495
And so once I got the battery in and
I got it fixed and I did that,

166
00:07:38.495 --> 00:07:42.485
I figured out that not just the light
